Q:abandon  [ə'bændən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 放纵： carefree, freedom from constraint
A: ♣例  added spices to the stew with complete abandon 肆无忌惮地向炖菜里面加调料
A: ♣近  unconstraint, uninhibitedness, unrestraint
A: ♠考法2  v. 放纵： to give (oneself) over unrestrainedly
A: ♣例  abandon oneself to emotion 感情用事，abandon herself to a life of complete idleness 放纵自己过着闲散的生活
A: ♣近  indulge, surrender, give up
A: ♠考法3  v. 放弃： to withdraw from often in the face of danger or encroachment
A: ♣例  abandon the ship/homes 弃船，离家
A: ♣反  salvage 救援
A: ♠考法4  v. 停止做某事： to put an end to (something planned or previously agreed to)
A: ♣例  the bad weather forced NASA to abandon the launch 坏天气迫使NASA停止了发射
A: ♣近  abort, drop, repeal, rescind, revoke, call off
A: ♣反  keep, continue, maintain, carry on 继续

Q:abase  [ə'beis]
A: ♠考法1  v. 降低（地位、职位、威望或尊严）： to lower in rank, office, prestige, or esteem
A: ♣例  was unwilling to abase himself by pleading guilty to a crime that he did not commit 不愿意屈就自己去承认一个莫须有的罪名
A: ♣近  debauch, degrade, profane, vitiate, discredit, foul, smirch, take down
A: ♣反  elevate, ennoble, uplift, aggrandize, canonize, deify, exalt 使高贵，使有声望

Q:abash  [ə'bæʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使尴尬，使羞愧： to destroy the self-possession or self-confidence of ,disconcert, embarrass
A: ♣例  Nothing could abash him. 没有什么可以使他感到难堪。
A: ♣近  discomfit, disconcert, discountenance, faze, fluster, nonplus, mortify
A: ♣反  embolden 使大胆

Q:abate  [ə'beit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 减轻（程度或者强度）： to reduce in degree or intensity
A: ♣例  abate his rage/pain 平息他的愤怒/减轻痛苦
A: ♣近  moderate, recede, subside, remit, wane, die (away or down or out),let up, phase down, ratchet (down)，taper off
A: ♣反  intensify
A: ♠考法2  v. 减少（数量或者降低价值）： to reduce in amount or value
A: ♣例  abate a tax 降低税收
A: ♣近  de-escalate, deplete, downscale, dwindle,
A: ♣反  augment, promote 增加
A: ♠考法3  v. 停止，撤销： to put an end to
A: ♣例  abate a nuisance 停止伤害
A: ♣近  abrogate, annul, invalidate, nullify, rescind, vacate

Q:abbreviate  [ə'bri:vieit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 缩写，缩短： to make briefer
A: ♣例  abbreviate the word “building” as “bldg.” 将“building”缩写作“bldg”
A: ♣近  abridge, curtail, cut back, syncopate，truncate
A: ♣反  extend, protract, elongate, lengthen, prolong 延长

Q:abdicate  ['æbdikeit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 正式放弃（权力、责任）： to renounce a throne，to relinquish (power or responsibility) formally
A: ♣例  abdicate the throne/crown 退位
A: ♣近  cede, relinquish, renounce, resign, step down (from)
A: ♣反  constitute, assume, usurp 任命，承担，篡位

Q:aberrant  [æ'berənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 异常的，非常规的： deviating from the usual or natural type
A: ♣例  This behavior might be aberrant enough to draw attention. 这样的行为已经异常得足以引起人们的注意。
A: ♣近  abnormal, anomalous, peculiar, singular, unwonted，uncustomary
A: ♣反  normal, natural, regular, standard, typical 正常的，标准典型的

Q:abet  [ə'bet]
A: ♠考法1  v. 帮助，怂恿： to assist or support in the achievement of a purpose
A: ♣例  aid and abet (法律)协助教唆
A: ♣近  ferment, foment, provoke, instigate, stir (up), whip (up)
A: ♠考法2  v. 鼓励： to actively encourage (as an activity or plan)
A: ♣近  aid, assist, back, support, prop (up)
A: ♣反  stymie, frustrate, obstruct, thwart, impede, forestall , hinder 阻挠

Q:abeyance  [ə'beiəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 中止，搁置： temporary inactivity
A: ♣例  hold the plan in abeyance 使计划暂停
A: ♣近  doldrums, quiescence, moratorium, latency, dormancy, suspension, cold storage, deep freeze
A: ♣反  continuance, fulfillment 继续，履行

Q:abhor  [əb'hɔ:]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 深恶痛绝，极度厌恶： to regard with extreme repugnance
A: ♣例  He abhors the way people leave their trash at the picnic sites in the park. 他很厌恶人们把垃圾留在公园的野餐点。
A: ♣近  abominate, despise, detest, execrate, loathe
A: ♣反  greatly admire 非常崇拜

Q:abiding  [ə'baidiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 永久的： lasting for a long time; enduring
A: ♣例  an abiding love of Espanol 对西班牙语持久的热爱
A: ♣近  ageless, enduring, eternal, everlasting, perennial, perpetual, timeless
A: ♣反  evanescent , ephemeral 短暂的

Q:abject  [æb'dʒekt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无精打采的： cast down in spirit, spiritless
A: ♣例  a man made abject by suffering 被生活折磨得无精打采的人
A: ♣近  spiritless
A: ♣反  spirited, excited, exultant 狂喜的，令人兴奋的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （地位、身份）悲惨、凄凉的： sunk to or existing in a low state or condition
A: ♣例  abject poverty 让人绝望的贫穷
A: ♠考法3  adj. 卑微的，讨好的： expressing or offered in a humble and often ingratiating spirit
A: ♣例  abject flattery 卑躬屈膝般的恭维； an abject apology 讨好般的、真心的道歉
A: ♣近  base, humble, menial, servile, slavish

Q:abjure  [æb'dʒuə]
A: ♠考法1  v. 发誓放弃： a firm and final rejecting or abandoning often made under oath
A: ♣例  abjure one’s belief 发誓放弃信仰
A: ♣近  recant, renege, renounce, abnegate, forswear (also foreswear), repudiate
A: ♣反  affirm, espouse, embrace 拥护
A: ♠考法2  v. 抵制，避免： to resist the temptation of
A: ♣例  abjure extravagance 抵制铺张浪费
A: ♣近  keep (from), refrain (from), withhold (from)
A: ♣反  bow to, give in to, submit to, succumb to, surrender to, yield to 屈从于

Q:abnegate  ['æbniɡeit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 否认： deny, renounce
A: ♣例  abnegated the idea of freedom 放弃自由的观念
A: ♣近  recant, renege, repudiate, unsay, forswear (also foreswear), take back,
A: ♣反  reaffirm 再肯定，重申
A: ♠考法2  v. 投降，放弃，交出（权力等）：surrender, relinquish
A: ♣例  abnegated her powers 交出她拥有的权力
A: ♣近  cede, resign, step aside (from), step down (from)
A: ♣反  adhere to 依附，坚持

Q:abominate  [ə'bɔmineit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 憎恶： to hate or loathe intensely, abhor
A: ♣例  We abominate jokes that make fun of people who have physical disabilities. 我们鄙视对有生理缺陷的人开玩笑。
A: ♣近  despise, detest, execrate, loathe
A: ♣反  esteem, love, adore 尊敬，爱

Q:aboveboard  [ə,bʌv'bɔ:d]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无欺诈的，光明正大的： free from all traces of deceit or duplicity
A: ♣例  This transaction was totally aboveboard, so there was no reason to question it. 这项交易完全公开公正，没有必要质疑。
A: ♣反  chicanery, surreptitious, underhanded 偷偷摸摸的

Q:abrade  [ə'breid]
A: ♠考法1  v. 磨损，精神上折磨： to rub or wear away especially by friction; wear down spiritually
A: ♣例  My skin was abraded. 我的皮肤被磨损了。
A: ♣近  chafe, excoriate, rasp, graze, scuff
A: ♣反  augment 增加

Q:abreast  [ə'brest]
A: ♠考法1  adv. 并排地： beside one another with bodies in line
A: ♣例  a group of youths riding four abreast 四个一排骑着车的孩子们
A: ♣近  alongside, side by side
A: ♣反  aimlessly, desultorily, erratically, haphazardly, irregularly, randomly, willy-nilly 随意地
A: ♠考法2  adj. 熟知的： up to a particular standard or level especially of knowledge of recent developments
A: ♣例  She tried to keep abreast of the latest fashion trends. 她总是尽可能地跟上时尚的潮流。
A: ♣近  acquainted, conversant, informed, knowledgeable, versed, well-informed
A: ♣反  ignorant, unacquainted, unfamiliar, uninformed, unknowledgeable 无知的，不熟悉的

Q:abridge  [ə'bridʒ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 缩短，缩小： to shorten in duration or extent
A: ♣例  modern transportation abridges distance 现代运输方式缩短了路途
A: ♣近  curtail, truncate, cut back
A: ♣反  extend in length, protract, amplify 延长，放大
A: ♠考法2  v. 在不改变本意的条件下删减词语， 缩写： to shorten by omission of words without sacrifice of sense
A: ♣例  an abridged edition 精简版
A: ♣近  abbreviate, curtail, condense, syncopate

Q:abrogate  ['æbrəuɡeit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 官方的正式废除： to abolish by authoritative action, annul
A: ♣例  abrogate the law/ treaty 废除法律、条约
A: ♣近  disannul, invalidate, nullify, quash, rescind, roll back, strike down
A: ♣反  embrace, uphold, institute 采纳，支持，建立
A: ♠考法2  v. 无视（某事的）存在： to treat as nonexistent
A: ♣例  abrogate their responsibilities 抛开、不顾他们的责任

Q:abscond  [əb'skɔnd]
A: ♠考法1  v. 偷偷离开： to depart secretly and hide oneself
A: ♣例  abscond from the prison 越狱
A: ♣近  flee, lam, run off, break out (of), clear out

Q:absent  ['æbsənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 未出现的，缺乏的： not present, attending or existing
A: ♣例  The city's usual stir of activity was conspicuously absent due to the report of an escaped lion from the zoo. 一则动物园狮子逃跑的消息让这座城市缺少往日的繁华。
A: ♣近  away, lacking, missing, nonexistent, wanting
A: ♣反  existent, present 存在的，出现的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不专心的，走神的： lost in thought
A: ♣例  seemed absent because he nodded but didn’t say anything 他只点了点头但没说话，看起来像是走神了
A: ♣近  abstracted, distracted, preoccupied
A: ♣反  alert, vigilant, watchful, wary 警惕的；attentive, heedful, mindful 专注的

Q:absolute  [æbsə'lju:t]
A: ♠考法1 adj. 专制的： unconstrained by constitutional or other provisions
A: ♣例  absolute ruler 专制的统治者
A: ♣近  arbitrary, autocratic, despotic, dictatorial, monocratic, tyrannical
A: ♠考法2 adj. 无限的： unqualified in extent or degree; total
A: ♣例  absolute silence 鸦雀无声
A: ♣近  complete, utter, deadly, downright, out-and-out
A: ♣反  qualified 有限的，有保留的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 完美的、纯净不掺杂的： free from imperfection free or relatively; free from mixture
A: ♣例  absolute alcohol 无水酒精（纯酒精）
A: ♣近  plain, refined, unadulterated, unalloyed, undiluted, unmixed
A: ♣反  adulterated, alloyed, diluted, impure, mixed 掺杂的，不纯的
A: ♠考法4  adj. 不容置疑的，确凿的： positive, unquestionable
A: ♣例  absolute proof 确凿的证据
A: ♣近  clear, deciding, decisive, definitive
A: ♣反  inconclusive, indecisive, unclear 不明确的

Q:absolve  [əb'zɔlv]
A: ♠考法1  v. 使无罪，解除责任： to set free from an obligation or the consequences of guilt, exculpate
A: ♣例  absolve somebody from blame 使某人免受责备
A: ♣近  acquit, exonerate, vindicate
A: ♣反  blame, criminate, incriminate 定罪

Q:abstain  [əb'stein]
A: ♠考法1  v. 自我克制，主动戒绝： to refrain from something by one's own choice
A: ♣例  abstain from smoking/voting 戒烟，弃权
A: ♣近  forgo, keep from, refrain from, withhold (from)
A: ♣反  bow to, give in to, submit to, succumb to, surrender to, yield to 屈服于

Q:abstemious  [æb'sti:mjəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （吃喝等）有节制的，节俭的： marked by restraint especially in the consumption of food or alcohol, sparring
A: ♣例  an abstemious diet 有节制的饮食， abstemious meals 节俭的晚餐
A: ♣近  continent, temperate, self-abnegating, self-denying
A: ♣反  indulgent 放纵的

Q:abstract  [æb'strækt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 做总结，概括： to make an abstract of，summarize
A: ♣例  abstracted the 135-page report in three short paragraphs 将一份135页的报告概括为三段话
A: ♣近  digest, recapitulate, synopsize, sum up, boil down
A: ♣反  elaborate 详细描述
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使分心： to draw away the attention of
A: ♣例  personal problems abstracted him 私人问题让他分心
A: ♣近  detract, divert, call off, throw off
A: ♣派  abstraction n. 心不在焉
A: ♣反  attention 关注

Q:abstruse  [æb'stru:s]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 难以理解的： difficult to comprehend : recondite
A: ♣例  the abstruse calculations 复杂深奥的计算
A: ♣近  arcane, esoteric, hermetic (also hermetical), recondite
A: ♣反  accessible, patent, shallow, superficial 可了解的，肤浅的

Q:absurd  [əb'sə:d]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不合理的：ridiculously unreasonable, unsound, or incongruous
A: ♣例  an absurd argument 无稽之谈
A: ♣近  wild, bizarre, ludicrous, insane, nonsensical, preposterous, half-baked
A: ♣反  rational, sensible, realistic, reasonable 理性的，合理的

Q:abundant  [ə'bʌndənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 大量的： marked by great plenty (as of resources)
A: ♣例  a abundant land 一片富饶的土地
A: ♣近  ample, cornucopian, teeming, replete, abounding
A: ♣反  infrequent, rare, uncommon, inadequate, scanty, scarce 稀少的，罕见的

Q:abuse  [ə'bju:s]
A: ♠考法1  v. 辱骂抨击： language that condemns or vilifies usually unjustly, intemperately, and angrily
A: ♣例  He alleged that he was verbally abused by his colleagues. 他声称受到了同事的言语攻击。
A: ♣近  assail, bash, castigate, excoriate, lambaste
A: ♣派  abusive 辱骂的
A: ♠考法2  v. 不正当不合理使用： to put to a wrong or improper use; 过分过量使用：to use excessively
A: ♣例  abuse a privilege 滥用特权； abuse alcohol 酗酒
A: ♣近  misemploy, misuse

Q:abut  [ə'bʌt]
A: ♠考法1  v. 邻接，毗邻： to touch at one end or side; lie adjacent
A: ♣例  Our land abuts a wildlife preserve. 我们的土地靠近一片野生动物保护区。
A: ♣近  skirt, verge on, border on, butt on, march with

Q:abysmal  [ə'bizməl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 极低的或极可怜的： immeasurably low or wretched
A: ♣例  abysmal living conditions 极可怜的生活条件
A: ♣近  bottomless
A: ♣反  shallow shoal
A: ♠考法2  adj. （程度）很深的、极端的： immeasurably great
A: ♣例  abysmal ignorance 极端的无知；an abysmal cliff 深不见底的悬崖
A: ♣近  profound
A: ♣反  skin-deep, superficial 肤浅的

Q:accede  [æk'si:d]
A: ♠考法1  v. 赞成： to express approval or give consent
A: ♣例  acceded to their pleas 同意了他们的请愿
A: ♣近  acquiesce, assent, consent, subscribe, come round
A: ♣反  demur, dissent 反对
A: ♠考法2  v. 就任，就职：To arrive at or come into an office or dignity:
A: ♣例  accede to the throne 就任国王

Q:accelerate  [ək'seləreit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 加速： to cause to move faster
A: ♣例  accelerate his steps 加快脚步
A: ♣近  balloon, escalate, snowball, mushroom, proliferate, burgeon, build up
A: ♣反  retard 减速
A: ♠考法2  v. 使提前发生： to bring about at an earlier time
A: ♣例  accelerate their departure 提前离开
A: ♠考法3  v. 变大，变多： to become greater in size, extent, volume, amount, or number
A: ♣例  toy purchases accelerate dramatically during the Christmas season 玩具销售量在圣诞期间暴涨
A: ♣近  accumulate, balloon, enlarge, escalate, mushroom, proliferate, snowball, roll up
A: ♣反  contract, decrease, diminish, dwindle, lessen, recede, wane

Q:accessible  [ək'sesəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可以到达的： situated within easy reach
A: ♣例  the town accessible by rail 有铁路通达的城镇
A: ♣近  handy, reachable
A: ♣反  inconvenient, unhandy, unreachable, untouchable
A: ♠考法2  adj. 可理解的： capable of being understood or appreciated
A: ♣例  The information ought to be made more accessible. 信息应该更清晰易懂。
A: ♣近  apprehensible, fathomable, legible, scrutable
A: ♣反  abstruse, incoherent, incomprehensible, inscrutable, insensible 深奥的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 能够获得的： possible to get
A: ♣例  The data is not currently accessible. 数据目前还不可用。
A: ♣近  available, attainable, obtainable, procurable
A: ♣反  unattainable, unavailable, unobtainable

Q:accessory  [ək'sesəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 辅助的，附属的： having a secondary, supplementary, or subordinate function.
A: ♣例  accessory features such as call-waiting 类似呼叫等待的附属功能
A: ♣近  accessory, peripheral, supplementary
A: ♣反  of primarily importance, chief, main, principal 主要的
A: ♠考法2  n. 帮凶： one associated with another in wrongdoing
A: ♣例  two accessories, the driver of the getaway car and the dishonest bank teller, were charged in the robbery case 两个帮凶，逃逸车辆的司机和不诚信的银行出纳，在抢劫案中被控告
A: ♣近  abettor, confederate

Q:accidental  [,æksi'dentəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 意外发生的，偶然的： occurring unexpectedly or by chance
A: ♣例  The discovery of gold was entirely accidental. 黄金的发现纯属偶然。
A: ♣近  incidental, fortuitous, unintended, unintentional, unpremeditated, unwitting
A: ♣反  calculated, deliberate, intended, planned, premeditated 预先计划好的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 附带的，不重要的： not being a vital part of or belonging to something
A: ♣例  Its commercial value was accidental. 它的商业价值微乎其微。
A: ♣近  alien, extraneous, external, adventitious
A: ♣反  inherent, innate, intrinsic 内在的，固有的

Q:acclaim  [ə'kleim]
A: ♠考法1  n. 称赞： public acknowledgment or admiration for an achievement
A: ♣例  Many people were involved in the search, but the person who actually found the missing girl got all the acclaim. 许许多多的人都参与了搜救行动，但是只有真正找到那个迷失的小女孩的人才受到称赞。
A: ♣近  accolade, applause, credit, distinction, homage, honor, kudos, laud, laurels
A: ♠考法2  vt. 赞扬，赞颂： to declare enthusiastic approval of
A: ♣例  He was acclaimed as the country's greatest modern painter. 他被盛赞为国内最优秀的现代画家。
A: ♣近  accredit, applaud, cheer, commend, endorse, exalt, hail, praise, salute, tout
A: ♣反  castigate, excoriate, lambaste, pan, slam 猛烈抨击

Q:acclimate  [ə'klaimit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使适应： to change (something) so as to make it suitable for a new use or situation
A: ♣例  acclimate oneself to a nine-to-five office job 适应朝九晚五的坐班生活
A: ♣近  adjust, accommodate, shape, suit, tailor
A: ♣反  make unfamiliar with 使不熟悉

Q:accolade  [ækəu'leid]
A: ♠考法1  n. 同意，赞赏： an expression of approval
A: ♣反  disapprobation 不赞成
A: ♣例  won virtually every accolade that the film world has to offer 赢得了电影界几乎一致的赞赏
A: ♣近  applause, credit, distinction
A: ♠考法2  v. 赞扬： to praise or honor
A: ♣反  excoriation, criticism, reprobation, castigation, cutting remark, derogation, reproof. denigration, denunciation, swearword 批评，谴责

Q:accommodate  [ə'kɔmədeit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 提供所需（例如服务、借贷、寄宿）： to provide with something desired, needed, or suited (as a helpful service, a loan, or lodgings)
A: ♣例  This cruise ship was big enough to accommodate over 600 people. 该游轮可以为超过600人提供食宿。
A: ♣近  fit, hold, take
A: ♠考法2  v. 改变以适应新情况、新场景： to change (something) so as to make it suitable for a new use or situation
A: ♣例  accommodated the lectern to the height of the guest speaker 将讲台的高度调节得适合讲演者
A: ♣近  acclimate, adjust, condition, conform, doctor, edit, shape, suit, tailor
A: ♠考法3  v. 使和谐： to bring to a state free of conflicts, inconsistencies, or differences
A: ♣例  The idea that the United States could harmoniously accommodate all was a fiction. 认为美国能够和谐一切就是幻想。
A: ♣近  attune, conciliate, conform, coordinate, reconcile
A: ♣反  disharmonize 使不和谐

Q:accomplish  [ə'kʌmpliʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 完成，实现： to carry through (as a process) to completion
A: ♣例  I don’t think we can accomplish our goal unless we cooperate. 我认为只有合作才能实现我们的目标。
A: ♣近  achieve, commit, execute, fulfill, make, perpetrate, prosecute, carry out
A: ♣反  fail 失败
A: ♣派  accomplishment n. 成就；accomplished adj. 有造诣的

Q:accord  [ə'kɔ:d]
A: ♠考法1  n. 一致： a state of consistency
A: ♣例  This map doesn't seem to be in accord with the current layout of the streets. 这幅地图似乎与当前的街道情况不尽一致。
A: ♣近  accordance, agreement, conformity, congruence, congruity, consonance, harmony, tune
A: ♣反  conflict, disagreement, incongruence, incongruity, incongruousness 不一致
A: ♠考法2  vi. 相符合，相一致： to be consistent or in harmony
A: ♣例  a theory that accords with the known facts 与已知事实相一致的理论‖He claims that the newspaper’s quote does not accord with what he actually said. 他声称报纸引用的他的话与原文并不相符。
A: ♣近  agree, chord, cohere, coincide, conform, correspond, fit, harmonize, jibe, sort, square, tally
A: ♣反  differ, disagree 不相同，不一致
A: ♠考法3  vt. 授予，给予： to grant or give especially as appropriate, due, or earned
A: ♣例  Women were finally accorded the right to vote in 1920. 女性最终在1920年获得了投票权。
A: ♣近  accord, award, grant, vest, vouchsafe
A: ♣反  withhold 保留，不给予；recant, retract, withdraw 撤回，收回
A: ♣派  accordance n. 一致，和谐

Q:accost  [ə'kɔst]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 以挑衅的形式搭讪： to approach and speak to often in a challenging or aggressive way
A: ♣例  accosted by three gang members 被三个混混搭讪

Q:accrete  [æ'kri:t]
A: ♠考法1  v. 逐渐增长： to grow or increase gradually, as by addition
A: ♣例  silt accreting at the mouth of the river 泥沙在河口淤积
A: ♣近  accumulate, build up, pile (up), stack (up)
A: ♣反  wear away, reduction in substance caused by erosion 侵蚀，减少
A: ♣派  accretion n. 慢慢增加

Q:accumulate  [ə'kju:mjuleit]
A: ♠考点1 vi. 逐渐增长： to increase gradually in quantity or number
A: ♣例  accumulate a fortune 积攒了一笔财富
A: ♣近  mount, swell, garner, snowball, build up, bulk (up)
A: ♣反  dissipate, diminish, dwindle, recede, wane 消散，减少

Q:acerbic  [ə'sə:bik]

A: ♣例  acerbic commentary 尖酸的评论
A: ♣近  pungent, sardonic, satiric, scalding, scathing
A: ♣反  sweet, saccharin 甜的，糖精（甜）
A: ♣派  acerbity n. 酸

Q:acknowledge  [ək'nɔlidʒ]

A: ♣例  He refused to acknowledge the fact that her daughter has gone. 他拒绝承认女儿已经死去的事实。
A: ♣近  admit, agree, allow, concede, confess, grant, own
A: ♣反  deny 否认
A: ♣派  acknowledgement n. 承认

Q:acme  ['ækmi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 顶点，极点： the highest point or stage, as of achievement or development
A: ♣例  the acme of his career 他事业的巅峰
A: ♣近  culmination, pinnacle, tip-top, high-water mark
A: ♣反  bottom, nadir, rock bottom 最低点
A: ♠考法2  n. 最佳典范： the most perfect type or example
A: ♣例  a movie that has come to be regarded as the acme of the Hollywood musical 这部影片被认为是好莱坞音乐剧的最佳典范
A: ♣近  apotheosis, epitome, exemplar

Q:acquiesce  [,ækwi'es]

A: ♣例  acquiesce to my own fleecing 默许我的敲竹杠行为
A: ♣近  assent, consent, subscribe, come round
A: ♣反  resist, defy, dissent 抵制，不同意

Q:acquire  [ə'kwaiə]

A: ♣例  bacteria that acquire tolerance to antibiotics 产生了抗药性的细菌‖I have never acquired a taste for wine. 我从来就不具备对葡萄酒酒的品味能力。
A: ♣近  attain, capture, draw, gain, garner, get, make, obtain, procure, realize, reap, secure, win, bring in
A: ♣反  forfeit, lose 丧失

Q:acquisitive  [ə'kwizitiv]

A: ♣例  Acquisitive developers are trying to tear down the ancient temple and build a shopping mall instead. 贪婪的开发商打算铲平这座古老的神庙，取而代之地建造一座购物中心。
A: ♣近  avaricious, avid, coveting, covetous, grabby, grasping, mercenary, moneygrubbing, rapacious
A: ♣反  benevolent, generous, liberal, philanthropic, munificent 慷慨的

Q:acrid  ['ækrid]

A: ♣例  acrid smell of tobacco 烟草刺鼻的味道
A: ♠考点2 adj. 刻薄的： marked by the use of wit that is intended to cause hurt feelings
A: ♣例  acrid temper 刻薄的性情
A: ♣反  gentle 温和的

Q:acrimonious  [,ækri'məunjəs]

A: ♣例  the acrimonious debate between the two candidates 候选人之间言辞激烈的辩论
A: ♣近  embittered, hard, rancorous, resentful, sore

Q:acumen  [ə'kju:men]

A: ♣例  the business acumen 商业方面的洞察力
A: ♣近  keenness, shrewdness, canniness, clear-sightedness, hardheadedness
A: ♣反  unable to discerning 不能辨别的

Q:acute  [ə'kju:t]

A: ♣例  an acute thinker 思维敏锐的思想者
A: ♣近  delicate, fine, keen, perceptive, sensitive
A: ♠考法2  adj. 严重的，急性的： needing immediate attention
A: ♣例  acute appendicitis 急性阑尾炎
A: ♣近  exigent, imperative, compelling, urgent
A: ♣反  mild, noncritical, nonurgent 轻微的，不严重的
A: ♠考法3  adj. （程度、影响）极强： extreme in degree, or effect
A: ♣例  experiencing acute distress over the misunderstanding with her best friend 因误会她的死党陷入了深深的痛苦
A: ♣近  dreadful, excruciating, profound
A: ♣反  light, moderate, soft 程度温和的

Q:ad-lib  [æd'lib]

A: ♣近  extemporary, impromptu, improvisational, offhanded
A: ♣反  considered, planned, premeditated, rehearsed

Q:adamant  ['ædəmənt]

A: ♣近  hardheaded, headstrong, intransigent, pertinacious, obdurate, uncompromising
A: ♣反  vacillatory, incline to yield, amenable, compliant, relenting, yielding 动摇的，易屈从的

Q:adapt  [ə'dæpt]

A: ♣近  adjust, conform, edit, accommodate, shape, suit, tailor

Q:addict  [ə'dikt,'ædikt]

A: ♣例  be addicted to drug/ alcohol 沉溺于毒品、酒
A: ♠考法2  n. 对某事上瘾的人： a person with a strong and habitual liking for something

A: ♣近  devotee, enthusiast, fanatic, maniac
A: ♣反  nonfan 非粉丝

Q:adhere  [əd'hiə]

A: ♣近  cleave, cling, hew
A: ♣反  detach 分离
A: ♠考法2  v. 服从命令： to act according to the commands of
A: ♣例  adhere to the rules 遵守规定
A: ♣近  cling to, hew to, stand by, stick to, comply with
A: ♣反  defy, disobey, rebel against 不服从，反抗
A: ♠考法3  v. 坚定地支持： to give steadfast support to
A: ♣例  our coach adheres to the belief that we can win this game if we just have a positive attitude 我们的教练坚定地相信，只有我们有积极的态度，我们就能拿下比赛
A: ♣近  keep to, stand by, stick to or with
A: ♣反  defect from 叛变
A: ♣派  adherent n. 追随者：a follower of a leader, party, or profession
A: ♣反  forerunner 先行者

Q:adjourn  [ə'dʒə:n]

A: ♣近  prorogate, prorogue, recess, suspend
A: ♣反  convoke 召集，召开会议

Q:adjudicate  [ə'dʒu:dikeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 裁决，判定： to hear and settlea case, dispute or conflict
A: ♣例  When my wife and I asked the salesclerk to adjudicate our disagreement, she agreed with me that the white shoes looked better. 我和我妻子要求售货员来裁决我们之间的争论，最后她还是同意了我的观点，认为白色的鞋子看起来更漂亮。
A: ♣近  adjudge, arbitrate, decide, determine, judge, referee, settle, umpire

Q:adjunct  ['ædʒʌŋkt]

A: ♣例  Massage therapy can be used as an adjunct along with the medication. 按摩治疗可以作为药物治疗的补充疗法。
A: ♣近  appendage, appliance, attachment, add-on
A: ♣反  essential element 重要部分

Q:admonish  [əd'mɔniʃ]

A: ♣近  counsel
A: ♠考法2  v. 责备： to reprove gently but earnestly.
A: ♣例  admonished her for littering 责备她乱扔垃圾
A: ♣近  chide, reprimand, reproach, reprove, tick off
A: ♣派  admonishment n. 责备

Q:adore  [ə'dɔ:]

A: ♣近  fancy, relish, savor, delight in, rejoice in
A: ♠考法2  vt. 宠爱： to feel passion, devotion, or tenderness for
A: ♣例  adored his wife 宠爱他的妻子
A: ♣近  cherish
A: ♣反  abhor, abominate, despise, detest, execrate, loathe 讨厌，嫌弃

Q:adulate  ['ædjuleit]

A: ♣近  overpraise, belaud, soft-soap, butter up
A: ♣反  scorn, disdain, vituperate, disparage 鄙视

Q:adulterate  [ə'dʌltəreit]

A: ♣反  enrich, fortify, strengthen 加入养分

Q:adumbrate  ['ædʌmbreit]

A: ♣例  adumbrate a plan 透露计划
A: ♣反  revelation 完全显示
A: ♠考法2  vt. 预示着： to give a slight indication of beforehand
A: ♣例  The strife in Bloody Kansas adumbrated the civil war that would follow. 发生在堪萨斯州的流血冲突预示了之后的南北内战的爆发。
A: ♣近  forerun, harbinger, herald, prefigure

Q:adventitious  [,ædven'tiʃəs]

A: ♣近  alien, extraneous, external, foreign, supervenient
A: ♣反  constitutional, essential, intrinsic, inborn, inbred, innate, inherent 天生的

Q:adversity  [əd'və:səti]

A: ♣例  The fire is the test of gold, adversity of strong man.(Martha Graham) 烈火试真金，逆境炼勇士。——玛莎?葛兰姆‖finally overcame all the adversities of the Great Depression and rebuilt their fortunes 终于度过了大萧条的困境，开始重新创造他们的财富
A: ♣近  ill, hardship, misadventure, mischance, mishap, tragedy
A: ♣反  fortune, luck, serendipity 好运气

Q:advert  [əd'və:t]

A: ♣派  advertent a 留意的
A: ♣反  inattentive, remiss, heedless, negligent 疏忽的

A: ♣近  back, champion, endorse, patronize
A: ♣反  impunge 提出异议

Q:affable  ['æfəbl]

Q:affectation  [,æfek'teiʃən]

A: ♣例  the rolling of the ship made the young sailor squeamish 摇晃的船只让年轻的水手感到恶心
A: ♣近  fa?ade, guise, mannerism, pose, pretense, show
A: ♣反  artlessness, genuineness, innocence, naivety 天真，淳朴

Q:affinity  [ə'finəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 喜欢，亲切感： a habitual attraction to some activity or thing
A: ♣例  always had an affinity for nurturing living things 喜欢培养活物
A: ♣近  bent, penchant, predilection, predisposition, proclivity, propensity
A: ♣反  aversion, repugnance, antipathy 厌恶
A: ♠考法2  n. 相似： the fact or state of having something in common
A: ♣例  a study showing an affinity between obesity and socioeconomic status 一项表现了肥胖程度和社会经济水平之间相似性的研究
A: ♣近  association, bearing, kinship

Q:affirm  [ə'fə:m]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 声称为真，肯定属实： to assert (as a judgment or decree) as valid or confirmed
A: ♣例  He was unwilling to affirm without further study that the painting is an original Rembrandt. 在缺乏进一步研究的情况下，他不愿意声称这幅画作是出自伦布兰特的正品。
A: ♣近  allege, assert, aver, avouch, avow, contend, declare, insist, maintain, profess, protest, purport, warrant
A: ♣反  deny, gainsay 否定，反对
A: ♣派  affirmation n. 肯定，确认

Q:affix  [ə'fiks]

A: ♣近  attach, bend, fix
A: ♣反  detach, undo, unfasten, unhook 松开，分开

Q:affliction  [ə'flikʃən]

A: ♣例  She listened with deep affliction as her daughter told her about the latest trouble she was in. 她怀着巨大的痛苦聆听着女儿告诉她目前艰难的处境。
A: ♣近  agony, anguish, dolor, excruciation, grief, hurt, misery, pain, rack, torment, torture, travail, tribulation, woe
A: ♣反  bliss, cheer, delight, ecstasy, elation, euphoria, exhilaration, exuberance, exultation, felicity, joy, jubilation, pleasure, rapture 喜悦，高兴

Q:affluent  ['æfluənt]

A: ♣例  affluent society 富裕的社会
A: ♣近  opulent, loaded, deep-pocketed, silk-stocking, well-endowed, well-off, well-to-do
A: ♣反  needy, impecunious, impoverished, indigent, penurious 贫困的

Q:agape  [ə'ɡeip]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 急切盼望的： having or showing signs of eagerly awaiting something
A: ♣例  At the sound of the sleigh bells the children were all agape, waiting for Santa to appear. 听到雪橇铃，孩子们开始好奇地等待圣诞老人的到来。
A: ♣近  agog, anticipant, anticipatory
A: ♣反  apathetic, indifferent, unconcerned, uninterested 不感兴趣的，不为所动的

Q:aggrandize  [ə'ɡrændaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 增加、提高力量、财富、地位、声誉等： to enhance the power, wealth, position, or reputation of
A: ♣例  exploited the situation to aggrandize himself 借势而上使得自己地位提升、财富增长
A: ♣近  augment, boost , expand, magnify, add (to),pump up
A: ♣反  relegate, disparage, efface, abase, demean 降级，贬低

Q:aggravate  ['æɡrəveit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 加重，恶化： to make worse, more serious, or more severe
A: ♣例  Stress and lack of sleep could aggravate the situation. 压力和睡眠不足使情况恶化。
A: ♣近  complicate, worsen
A: ♣反  alleviate, succor, console, assuage, mitigate, relieve 减轻，安慰
A: ♠考法2  v. 使不爽： to disturb the peace of mind of (someone) especially by repeated disagreeable acts
A: ♣例  it really aggravates me when I arrive 10 minutes before the stated closing time, and the store's closed already 我在号称的打烊时间前10分钟到达，但发现商店已经关门了，让我很不爽
A: ♣近  annoy, bother, nettle, vex

Q:aggregate  ['æɡriɡət]
A: ♠考法1  n. 集合体： a mass or body of units or parts somewhat loosely associated with one another
A: ♣例  An empire is the aggregate of many states under one common head. 帝国是以一个共同领袖领导的若干国家的集合体。
A: ♣近  sum, summation, totality
A: ♣反  isolated units 隔离的单位
A: ♠考法2  v. 集合，聚集： to collect or gather into a mass or whole
A: ♣例  aggregates content from many other sites 搜罗集合了其他网站的内容
A: ♣近  coalesce, join together 结合，连接
A: ♣派  disaggregate v. 分解
A: ♣反  disperse 分散

Q:aggressive  [ə'ɡresiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 好斗的： having a quality of anger and determination that makes it ready to attack others
A: ♣例  aggressive behavior 具有攻击性的行为
A: ♣近  fierce, assaultive, combative, militant, confrontational, go-getting, self-assertive, truculent, pugnacious
A: ♣反  even-tempered, nonbelligerent, pacific, uncombative, uncontentious 心平气和的，不好斗的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 强有力的，强烈的： marked by or uttered with forcefulness
A: ♣例  an aggressive campaign to win the African-American vote 一次能够获得非裔美国人选票的强有力的竞选
A: ♣近  dynamic, energetic, full-blooded, vigorous

Q:aggrieve  [ə'ɡri:v]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使苦恼,悲痛： to give pain or trouble to, distress
A: ♣反  gratify 使高兴，满足
A: ♣派  aggrieved adj. 苦恼的，怨念的
A: ♣例  a line of aggrieved ticket-holders, demanding a refund for the cancelled play 一队怨念的购票者，为取消的话剧要求退款
A: ♣近  discontent, disgruntled, displeased, dissatisfied, malcontent

Q:agility  [ə'dʒiləti]
A: ♠考法1  n. （身手）敏捷： ease and grace in physical activity
A: ♣例  His agility on the parallel bars has won him several medals. 他在双杠上的矫捷身姿助他赢得了数枚奖牌。
A: ♣近  deftness, dexterity, nimbleness, sleight, spryness
A: ♣反  awkwardness, clumsiness, gaucheness, gawkiness, gracelessness, ungainliness （行动）笨拙

Q:agitate  ['ædʒiteit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 煽动，激起： to attempt to arouse public feeling
A: ♣例  agitate for better conditions 为得到更好的工作条件而煽动
A: ♣近  debate, dispute, bat (around or back and forth), hash (over or out), talk over
A: ♠考法2  v. 使不安： to excite and often trouble the mind or feelings of : disturb
A: ♣例  There's no need to agitate the patient about little things. 没必要因为鸡毛蒜皮的事让患者烦躁。
A: ♣近  bother, discomfort, discompose, perturb
A: ♣反  calm, compose, soothe, tranquilize 平息抚慰，淡定

Q:agog  [ə'ɡɔɡ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 极度感兴趣的： showing urgent desire or interest
A: ♣例  Children were agog over new toys. 孩子们见到了新玩具极其兴奋。
A: ♣近  avid, ardent, enthusiastic, solicitous, voracious
A: ♣反  apathetic, indifferent, uneager, unenthusiastic 漠不关心的，无情的

Q:agonize  ['æɡənaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 折磨，使痛苦： to cause to suffer agony
A: ♣例  She got into more trouble, further agonizing her poor mother. 她惹上了更多的麻烦，进一步加剧了她可怜的母亲所遭受的痛苦。
A: ♣近  bedevil, beset, besiege, curse, excruciate, harrow, persecute, plague, rack, torment, torture
A: ♣反  comfort, console, solace, soothe 安抚，安慰
A: ♠考法2  vi. 感到痛苦： to suffer agony, torture, or anguish
A: ♣例  She agonized for days over the moral issues involved. 一连几天她都为被卷入的道德纠纷而感到痛苦。
A: ♣近  anguish, bleed, hurt, mourn, sorrow, suffer
A: ♣反  cheer, crow, delight, exult, joy, rejoice 感到高兴

Q:agreeable  [ə'ɡri:əbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 令人愉悦的： pleasing to the mind or senses especially as according well with one's tastes or needs
A: ♣例  Would you mind putting on some agreeable music for dinner ? 你介意为晚饭放一些令人愉快的音乐吗？‖the agreeable melancholy resulting from a sense of the transitoriness of natural beauty 因为感慨自然之美稍纵即逝而产生的令人愉悦的忧伤
A: ♣近  congenial, delectable, delicious, delightful, dulcet, enjoyable, felicitous, gratifying, heavenly, palatable, pleasing, satisfying, savory
A: ♣反  abhorrent, abominable, disagreeable, disgusting, loathsome, nauseating, repellent, repugnant, repulsive, revolting 令人厌恶的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 随和的： having an easygoing and pleasing manner especially in social situations
A: ♣例  I have an agreeable art teacher who lets me do pretty much whatever I want. 我的艺术老师性格非常好，总是允许我去做我想做的事情。
A: ♣近  affable, genial, good-natured, good-tempered, gracious, mellow, nice, pleasant, sweet, well-disposed
A: ♣反  choleric, dyspeptic, fussy, grouchy, irascible, irritable, peevish, touchy 脾气不好的，易怒的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 相一致的： being in harmony
A: ♣例  These new security measures

Q:airtight  ['εətait]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无瑕疵的： having no noticeable weakness, flaw, or loophole
A: ♣例  an airtight argument 滴水不漏、无懈可击的论断
A: ♠考法2  adj. 密封的，不透气的：impermeable to air or nearly so
A: ♣例  an airtight seal 不透气的封口

Q:alacrity  [ə'lækrəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 反应迅速，乐意： promptness in response : cheerful readiness
A: ♣例  accepted the invitation with alacrity 欣喜地接受了邀请
A: ♣近  amenability, gameness, obligingness, willingness
A: ♣反  dilatoriness, hesitance and reluctance 拖延，犹豫和不情愿

Q:alibi  ['ælibai]
A: ♠考法1  n. 不在场的证明；托辞，借口： an excuse usually intended to avert blame or punishment (as for failure or negligence)
A: ♣例  He always has a very creative alibi for undone homework. 他对于不完成作业总是有各种新奇的借口。
A: ♣近  defense, justification, plea, reason

Q:alienate  ['eiljəneit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使…疏远： to make unfriendly, hostile, or indifferent especially where attachment formerly existed
A: ♣例  His heartless treatment of their mother during the divorce proceeding has completely alienated the two children. 他在离婚过程中对妻子表现出来的残酷，已经彻底地让两个孩子与他疏远起来。
A: ♣近  alien, disaffect, disgruntle, sour
A: ♣反  reconcile 使…重归于好
A: ♠考法2  vt. 转让，让渡： to convey or transfer (as property or a right) usually by a specific act rather than the due course of law
A: ♣例  A landowner has a right to alienate his right of ownership - in other words, he can sell the land if he wants to. 地主拥有转让所有权的权力——也就是说如果愿意，他可以出售他的土地。
A: ♣近  assign, cede, convey, deed, make over
A: ♣反  expropriate 接纳他人财产
A: ♣派  unalienable adj. 不可予夺的，不可转让的

Q:align  [ə'lain]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 排成一行： to bring into line or alignment
A: ♣例  align the cars with the curb 使车与路缘对齐
A: ♣反  askew, awry, warped 歪斜的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 调准，校准： to adjust to produce a proper relationship or orientation
A: ♣例  align the wheels of the truck 调整卡车的轮子
A: ♣反  improperly adjusted, irregular 调整不当的，不规则的

Q:allay  [ə'lei]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 减轻： to subdue or reduce in intensity or severity, alleviate
A: ♣例  allay one’s fears or doubts 减轻某人的恐惧或怀疑
A: ♣近  assuage, ease, mitigate, mollify, palliate, relieve, soothe
A: ♣反  excite, aggravate, foment, increase the intensity of, exacerbate 激起，加重

Q:allegiance  [ə'li:dʒəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 忠诚： devotion or loyalty to a person, group, or cause
A: ♣例  They swore their allegiance to the USA. 他们宣誓效忠美国。
A: ♣近  commitment, dedication, piety, faithfulness, steadfastness
A: ♣反  inconstancy, infidelity, perfidiousness, treachery

Q:alleviate  [ə'li:vieit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 缓和，减轻： relieve, lessen
A: ♣例  alleviate pain/suffering 减轻痛苦
A: ♣近  ease, assuage, mitigate, mollify, palliate, soothe
A: ♣反  exacerbate 加剧

Q:alloy  ['ælɔi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 合金，混合物： a distinct entity formed by the combining of two or more different things
A: ♣例  Brass is an alloy, consisting of copper and zinc. 黄铜是一种由铜和锌组成的合金。‖Television news has always been an alloy of journalism and show business. 电视新闻一直以来都是新闻界和演艺圈的混合体。
A: ♣近  admixture, amalgam, cocktail, composite, compound, fusion, intermixture, mix, mixture, synthesis
A: ♣反  element （构成整体的）单个元素
A: ♠考法2  vt. 掺杂，降低纯度： to debase by the addition of an inferior element
A: ♣例  idealism that was alloyed with political skill 因为掺入了政治技能而被削弱理想主义
A: ♣近  adulterate, contaminate, dilute, extend, lace, pollute, sophisticate, thin
A: ♣反  purify 纯化
A: ♣派  unalloyed adj. 纯粹的，未掺杂的

Q:allude  [ə'lju:d]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 间接提到： to convey an idea indirectly
A: ♣例  He also alluded to his rival's past marital troubles. 他间接提到了对手过去的婚姻问题。
A: ♣近  imply, indicate, infer, insinuate, intimate, suggest

Q:allure  [ə'ljuə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 吸引： to attract or delight as if by magic
A: ♣近  entice, seduce, solicit, tempt, captivate, enchant, lead on
A: ♣派  alluring 诱惑的，有吸引力的
A: ♣例  an alluring smile 迷人的微笑
A: ♣反  unattractive 无吸引力的
A: ♠考法2  v. 诱惑做某事： to lead away from a usual or proper course by offering some pleasure or advantage
A: ♣例  allured by the promise of big bucks, he decided to have a go at a job on the trading floor of the stock market 被赚大钱的许诺所引诱，他决定投身股票市场工作
A: ♣近  bait, beguile, decoy, entice, seduce, lead on

Q:ally  ['ælai]

A: ♣近  supporter, confederate, sympathizer
A: ♣反  adversary, rival 对手
A: ♠考法2  v. 加入联盟：to enter into an alliance
A: ♣例  several tribes allied to fend off the invaders 几个部落联合起来抵抗侵略者
A: ♣反  disband 解散

Q:aloft  [ə'lɔft]

A: ♣例  The balloon stayed aloft for days 气球在空中停留了很多天。
A: ♣近  overhead
A: ♣反  grounded 着陆地

Q:aloof  [ə'lu:f]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 孤高的，不合群的：removed or distant either physically or emotionally
A: ♣例  an aloof church 一座孤零零的教堂； stood apart with aloof dignity 带着超然的尊严站在一旁
A: ♣近  detached, offish, unsociable, withdrawn, standoffish
A: ♣反  sociable 好社交的

Q:altruism  ['æltruizəm]

A: ♣反  egoism利己主义
A: ♣派  altruistic adj.利他的
A: ♣反  egotistic, self-centered, self-concerned, selfish 自私的

Q:amalgamate  [ə'mælɡəmeit]

A: ♣例  to amalgamate with an American company 与一家美国公司合并
A: ♣近  mix, fuse, intermix, compound, meld, comingle, integrate, intermingle
A: ♣反  separate, isolate分开，隔离

Q:ambiguous  [æm'biɡjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj.有多种理解方式的；不确定的：open to more than one interpretation；doubtful or uncertain
A: ♣例  Students have ambiguous feelings about their role in the world. 学生们为他们在世界中的角色感到迷茫。Frustrated by ambiguous instructions因为不明确的指示而受挫
A: ♣近  doubtful, equivocal, unclear, uncertain
A: ♣反  distinct, pellucid, patent, blatant, explicit, lucid, perspicuous 清楚的，明显的

Q:ambivalent  [,æmbi'veilənt]

A: ♣近  conflicting, contradictory, mixed
A: ♣反  certain, decided, definite, positive, resolute, sure, unquestioning 明确的，毫无疑问的
A: ♣派  ambivalence n. 矛盾心理

Q:amble  ['æmbl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. / n. 漫步，闲逛：to walk slowly or leisurely; stroll

A: ♣近  ramble, saunter, stroll, wander, dally, dawdle
A: ♣反  step quickly 快走

Q:ambrosial  [æm'brəuzjəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （食物或者气味）特别美味的：something extremely pleasing to taste or smell
A: ♣例  The ambrosial aroma of the roast stimulated our appetites. 烤肉的美味香气刺激了我们的食欲。
A: ♣近  savory, aromal, aromatic, perfumed, redolent, odorous
A: ♣反  fetid, noisome, stenchy, malodorous, rancid 恶臭的

Q:ameliorate  [ə'mi:ljəreit]

A: ♣例  to ameliorate the suffering of people who have lost their jobs 改善失业人员的痛苦
A: ♣近  improve, convalesce, recuperate
A: ♣反  aggravate, worsen, deteriorate恶化
A: ♣派  ameliorator n. 改良物
A: ♣反  damper n. 抑制因素

Q:amenable  [ə'mi:nəbl]

A: ♣例  a high-spirited and rebellious girl not at all amenable to persuasion. 一个泼辣而反叛的女孩根本不听从劝告。
A: ♣近  compliant, docile, submissive, tractable, obedient
A: ♣反  intransigent, contumacious不妥协的；intractable, recalcitrant, refractory 倔强的；uncontrollable, ungovernable, unruly 难管束的

Q:amenity  [ə'mi:nəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. （环境，设备等的）舒适，人性化：something that conduces to comfort, convenience, or enjoyment
A: ♣例  the amenity of the new surroundings 新环境的宜人之处
A: ♣近  comfort, convenience, affability
A: ♠考法2  n. 融洽，和谐：the quality of being pleasant or agreeable
A: ♣例  a discussion conducted in perfect amenity 在和谐融洽的气氛中进行的讨论
A: ♣近  agreeability, cordiality, harmony, accord, concord, consonance
A: ♣反  discordance, inharmony 不和谐

Q:amiable  ['eimjəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 好脾气的，友好易相处的：being friendly, sociable, and congenial
A: ♣例  an amiable teacher not easily annoyed 一个不易惹恼易相处的老师
A: ♣近  friendly, affable, amicable, genial, easy to get along with
A: ♣反  disagreeable, ill-natured, ill-tempered, unamiable, ungenial, ungracious, unpleasant 坏脾气的，令人不愉快的

Q:amicable  ['æmikəbl]

A: ♣近  friendly, affable, amicable, genial, easy to get along with
A: ♣反  antagonistic, hostile, unfriendly有敌意的

Q:amity  ['æməti]
A: ♠考法1  n.友好, 亲善和睦关系：friendship; especially: friendly relations between nations
A: ♣例  live in amity with his neighbors 与邻居和谐相处；They parted in amity. 他们很友好地分别了。
A: ♣近  friendship
A: ♣反  enmity, hostility敌意

Q:amorphous  [ə'mɔ:fəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无固定形状的having no definite form: shapeless
A: ♣例  an amorphous cloud mass 一团无定形的云
A: ♣近  shapeless, unformed, unshaped
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不可归类的being without definite character or nature : unclassifiable
A: ♣例  an amorphous segment of society 不可归类的社会阶段
A: ♣近  unclassifiable

Q:anachronistic  [ə,nækrə'nistik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 时代错误的： chronologically misplaced
A: ♣例  Despite the occasional anachronistic word or concept, he has a good feel for the period. 尽管有时会犯一些词汇和概念上的时代性错误，但他对于那个时代的整体把握还是不错的。
A: ♣近  anachronic,anachronous
A: ♣反  accurate 准确的

Q:analgesic  [,ænæl'dʒi:sik]
A: ♠考法1  n. 镇痛剂：a medication that reduces or eliminates pain
A: ♣例  Aspirin is a kind of analgesic. 阿司匹林是一种止痛剂。
A: ♣同 anesthetic, anodyne

Q:analogous  [ə'næləɡəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 相似的，可比较的： having qualities in common
A: ♣例  Bad-mouthing your sister is analogous to slapping her in the face - it's just as bad. 说你姐姐的坏话和当面扇她耳光是类似的——它们都是不好的行为。
A: ♣近  akin, cognate, comparable, connate, corresponding, matching, parallel, resembling, similar, suchlike
A: ♣反  different, disparate, dissimilar, diverse, unlike 不同的，不相似的

Q:anarchist  ['ænəkist]
A: ♠考法1  n. 反抗权威的人：a person who rebels against any authority, established order, or ruling power
A: ♣同 rebel, insurgent
A: ♣派  anarchy n. 混乱 ：a state of lawlessness or political disorder due to the absence of governmental authority
A: ♣近  chaos, disarray, topsy-turviness, commotion, turmoil
A: ♣反  order 有序

Q:anathema  [ə'næθəmə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 诅咒：a ban or curse solemnly pronounced by ecclesiastical authority and accompanied by excommunication
A: ♣近  curse, execration, imprecation, malediction
A: ♣反  benediction, benison, blessing 祝福

Q:ancillary  [æn'siləri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 次要的：of secondary importance
A: ♣例  The company hopes to boost its sales through ancillary products. 公司想通过辅助产品来增加销量。
A: ♣近  subordinate, subsidiary
A: ♣反  main 主要的；paramount 最主要的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 辅助的，补充的 : auxiliary, supplementary
A: ♣例  the need for ancillary evidence 对补充证据的需要
A: ♣例  Some practice in the deft use of words may well be ancillary to the study of natural science. 熟练使用文字的练习对于自然科学的研究也是有帮助的。
A: ♣近  auxiliary, supplementary

Q:anecdote  ['ænikdəut]
A: ♠考法1  n. 短小有趣的故事：a usually short narrative of an interesting, amusing, or biographical incident
A: ♣例  He told us all sorts of humorous anecdotes about his childhood. 他告诉了我们所有关于他童年的奇闻趣事。
A: ♣例  He is a master raconteur with endless anecdotes. 他是讲故事的超级高手，总有讲不完的奇闻趣事。

Q:anemic  [ə'ni:mik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 缺乏力量、活力、精神的：lacking force, vitality, or spirit
A: ♣例  an anemic economic recovery. 毫无活力的经济复苏
A: ♣例  Investors are worried about the stock's anemic performance. 投资者担心股市低迷的表现。
A: ♣近  sapless, infirm, feeble, decrepit, wan, pale, pallid, effete, lethargic
A: ♣反  vigorous, spirited 精力充沛的；forceful有力量的

Q:anesthetic  [,ænis'θetik]
A: ♠考法1  n. 止痛剂 : something (as a drug) that relieves pain
A: ♣例  The dentist waited until the anesthetic took effect. 牙医等止痛药生效。
A: ♣近  analgesic, anodyne
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无感觉的，麻木的：lacking awareness or sensitivity
A: ♣例  be anesthetic to their feelings 对他们的感受麻木不仁
A: ♣反  sensate有感觉的

Q:animate  ['ænimeit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 活的：having or showing life
A: ♣例  The lecture was about ancient worship of animate and inanimate objects. 演讲是关于对生命体和非生命体的古代崇拜。
A: ♣近  breathing, live, living
A: ♣反  dead, expired, deceased, lifeless, nonliving 无生命的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 有活力的：having much high-spirited energy and movement
A: ♣例  Animate dance will get the blood pumping. 有活力的舞蹈会让人热血沸腾。
A: ♣近  bouncing, brisk, energetic, sprightly, vivacious
A: ♣反  inactive, lackadaisical, languid, listless, leaden 没有活力的，无精打采的
A: ♠考法3  v. 使有活力，支持：to give spirit and support to
A: ♣例  The writer's humor animates the novel. 作者的幽默使小说富有生命力。
A: ♣近  brace, energize, enliven, invigorate, ginger (up), pep up, vitalize 使有活力
A: ♣反  damp, dampen, deaden使没活力
A: ♣派  animation 生命力，活力：the quality or condition of being alive, active, spirited, or vigorous.
A: ♣反  lassitude, lethargy疲倦,疲乏
A: ♠考法4  v. 使行动，驱使：to move to action
A: ♣例  a criminal animated by greed 一个受贪婪驱使的罪犯
A: ♣近  goad, prod, spur, galvanize, stimulate
A: ♠考法5  v. 使活灵活现，使栩栩如生：to make or design in such a way as to create apparently spontaneous lifelike movement
A: ♣例

Q:animus  ['æniməs]
A: ♠考法1  n. 敌意：a usually prejudiced and often spiteful or malevolent ill will, enmity
A: ♣例  She felt no animus toward those who had wronged her. 她对那些冤枉了她的人没有敌意。
A: ♣近  animosity, antagonism, antipathy, hostility, rancor
A: ♣反  friendliness, amity, amenity 友好

Q:annex  [ə'neks]
A: ♠考法1  n. 裙楼，副楼： a building added on to a larger one or an auxiliary building situated near a main one
A: ♣例  The new annex that will serve as the permanent home for the school library. 新的裙楼将成为学校图书馆的永久住所。
A: ♣近  addition, extension, penthouse
A: ♠考法2  vt. 添加，合并： to join (something) to a mass, quantity, or number so as to bring about an overall increase
A: ♣例  plans to annex the supply room so as to make the classroom bigger 计划将工具房并入教室，从而扩充其容量
A: ♣近  adjoin, affix, append, attach, subjoin, tack
A: ♣反  abate, deduct, remove, subtract 削减
A: ♠考法3  vt. 吞并，夺取（土地等）： to incorporate (a country or other territory) within the domain of a state
A: ♣例  Rome annexed the Nabatean kingdom in 106 AD. 公元前106年罗马帝国吞并了古城那巴顿。
A: ♣近  acquire, appropriate, arrogate, expropriate, seize, take over
A: ♣反  lose 失去

Q:annotate  ['ænəuteit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 做注解： to furnish (a literary work) with critical commentary or explanatory notes
A: ♣例  The advent of e-books enables user to freely annotate what they are reading without worrying about being fined by libraries. 电子书的出现使得用户可以在不用担心被图书馆处以罚金的情况下自由地在读物上作注。
A: ♣近  commentate, footnote, gloss
A: ♣派  annotation n. 注解，注释

Q:annoy  [ə'nɔi]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 不断烦扰：to disturb or irritate especially by repeated acts
A: ♣例  Mosquitoes annoy us in the summer. 夏天蚊子总是不断烦扰我们。
A: ♣例  The sound of footsteps on the bare floor annoyed the downstairs neighbors. 楼上地板的脚步声吵得楼下住户心烦。
A: ♣近  aggravate, bother, chafe, gall, grate, irk, nettle, peeve, pique, rile, ruffle, spite, vex
A: ♣反  soothe, defuse, allay, conciliate, propitiate, mitigate, assuage, appease, pacify, placate, calm, settle, subdue, solace, mollify 平息，抚慰

Q:annul  [ə'nʌl]
A: ♠考法1  v. 宣告无效，取消：to declare or make legally invalid or void
A: ♣例  The marriage was annulled last month. 婚约上个月取消了。
A: ♣近  disannul, cancel, invalidate, abrogate, nullify, repeal, rescind
A: ♣反  make legal使合法；enact 制定
A: ♠考法2  v. 抵消 to balance with an equal force so as to make ineffective
A: ♣例  Unfortunately, his arrogant attitude annuls the many generous favors he does for people. 不幸的是，他傲慢的态度抵消了他之前对人民的慷慨恩惠。
A: ♣近  counterbalance, neutralize

Q:anomalous  [ə'nɔmələs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不普通的，不平常的 being out of the ordinary
A: ♣例  He is in an anomalous position as the only part-time teacher in XDF. 他和别人不一样的是，他是XDF唯一的兼职老师。
A: ♣近  aberrant, abnormal, atypical, phenomenal, singular, uncustomary, unwonted
A: ♣反  unexceptional, unextraordinary 普通的，平常的
A: ♣派  anomaly n. 反常 deviation or departure from the normal or common order, form, or rule.
A: ♠考法2  adj. 反常的，不正常的departing from some accepted standard of what is normal
A: ♣例  an anomalous burst of anger from this usually easygoing person 一个随和的人的一反常态的暴怒
A: ♣反  natural 自然的；standard 标准的

Q:anonymous  [ə'nɔniməs]

A: ♣例  He made an anonymous phone call to the police. 他给警察打了一个匿名电话。
A: ♣例  The donor wishes to remain anonymous. 捐赠者希望保持匿名身份。
A: ♣近  incognito, innominate, unnamed, unidentified, untitled
A: ♣反  dubbed, named, termed 有名字的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无特色的 lacking individuality, distinction, or recognizability
A: ♣例  the anonymous faces in the crowd大众脸

Q:antagonize  [æn'tæɡənaiz]

A: ♣例  He did not mean to antagonize you. 他并没有要反对你。
A: ♣例  antagonize a bill 反对一项议案
A: ♣近  counteract, disagree
A: ♣反  agree, concede, grant 同意；win over 使某人同意
A: ♠考法2  vt. 激起敌意：to incur or provoke the hostility of
A: ♣例  His remark antagonized his friends. 他的评述激怒了他的朋友。
A: ♣近  aggravate, exasperate, gall, inflame, nettle, provoke, peeve, pique, irritate, rile, roil, chafe, grate, ruffle,vex
A: ♣反  soothe, defuse, allay, conciliate, propitiate, mitigate, assuage, appease, pacify, placate, calm, settle, subdue, solace, mollify 平息，抚慰

Q:antedate  [,ænti'deit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 比…早，早于： to be of an earlier date than
A: ♣例  The church antedates the village itself. 这座教堂甚至在村庄之前就存在了。‖Dinosaurs antedate cavemen by millions of years. 恐龙比穴居人要早几百万年出现。
A: ♣近  antecede, forego, predate, preexist
A: ♣反  follow, postdate, succeed 晚于

Q:antediluvian  [,æntidi'lu:viən]

A: ♣例  He has antediluvian notions about the role of women in the workplace. 他对职场女性抱有老掉牙的看法。
A: ♣例  an antediluvian automobile 古董级的汽车
A: ♣近  aged, age-old, prehistoric, antique, aged, immemorial
A: ♣反  modern, new, recent 新的
A: ♠考法2  n. 保守的人：a person with old-fashioned ideas
A: ♣例  an antediluvian who thought a woman without talent is virtuous 一个认为“女子无才便是德”的保守的人
A: ♣近  reactionary
A: ♣反  modern, trendy 潮人

Q:anterior  [æn'tiəriə]

A: ♣近  antecedent, foregoing, former, forward, precedent, preceding, prior
A: ♣反  after, ensuing, following, posterior, subsequent, succeeding 后面的，后来的

Q:antic  ['æntik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 滑稽可笑的：characterized by clownish extravagance or absurdity
A: ♣例  The clown came on with many antic gestures. 小丑上场表演许多滑稽动作。
A: ♣近  chucklesome, comedic, comic, droll, farcical, laughable, ludicrous, hilarious
A: ♣反  humorless, unamusing, uncomic, unfunny, unhumorous 不好笑的grave 庄重的；serious, solemn, somber 严肃的

Q:antipathy  [æn'tipəθi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 厌恶，反感： settled aversion or dislike
A: ♣例  I feel no antipathy towards any of my opponents in the tournament. 我对锦标赛中碰到的任何对手都不存在反感。
A: ♣近  animosity, animus, antagonism, bitterness, enmity, gall, grudge, hostility, jaundice, rancor
A: ♣反  amity 友好，和睦；liking, partiality, predilection, prepossession 偏爱，喜爱
A: ♠考法2  n. 令人反感的事物： an object of aversion
A: ♣例  Cruelty to animals is one of my most deeply felt antipathies. 虐待动物是最让我反感的行为之一。
A: ♣近  abhorrence, abomination, anathema, aversion, detestation, execration
A: ♣反  beloved, darling, dear, love 令人喜爱的人或事物

Q:antiquated  ['æntikweitid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 古老的，过时的： outmoded or discredited by reason of age: being out of style or fashion
A: ♣例  We saw an antiquated hand-cranked rope-making machine at the textiles museum. 我们在纺织博物馆里看到了一台手摇式古董制绳机。‖antiquated methods of farming 已经过时的耕种技术
A: ♣近  antique, archaic, dated, fossilized, moribund, moth-eaten, obsolete, outdated, outmoded, outworn, prehistoric, rusty
A: ♣反  contemporary, current, modern, recent 当前的，现代的

Q:antithetical  [,ænti'θetik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 完全对立的，相反的： being in direct and unequivocal opposition
A: ♣例  Spiritual ideals seem antithetical to the materialism embraced by modern society. 精神上的理想境界往往同当代社会所推崇的唯物主义相抵触。
A: ♣近  antipodal, antipodean, contradictory, contrary, diametric, opposite, polar
A: ♣反  equivalent, identical, same 完全一致的，相等的

Q:apathy  ['æpəθi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 冷漠，缺乏情感：lack of feeling or emotion
A: ♣例  People have shown surprising apathy toward these important social problems. 人们对于这些重要的社会问题显示出了令人惊讶的冷漠。
A: ♣近  affectlessness, emotionlessness, impassiveness, impassivity, insensibility, numbness, phlegm
A: ♣反  emotion, feeling, sensibility 有感情
A: ♠考法2  n. 缺乏兴趣，不关心：lack of interest or concern
A: ♣例  She heard the story with apathy. 她毫无兴趣的听完了这个故事。
A: ♣例  Her poor grades are proof enough of her apathy concerning all matters academic. 她可怜的分数足以证明他对所有学术问题都没兴趣。
A: ♣近  disinterestedness, disregard, incuriosity, insouciance, nonchalance, unconcern
A: ♣反  concern, interest, regard 关心，有兴趣，在意

Q:aphorism  ['æfərizəm]

A: ♣例  When decorating, remember the familiar aphorism, “less is more.” 装修时需要记住的一句格言是“少即是多”。
A: ♣近  adage, epigram, maxim, proverb

Q:apocalyptic  [ə,pɔkə'liptik]

A: ♣例  No one listened to her apocalyptic predictions. 没有人听她的预言。
A: ♣近  prophetic, predictive, prognostic, farsighted
A: ♠考法2  adj. 重要的，转折点的 of, relating to, or being a major turning point
A: ♣例  the apocalyptic Battle of Stalingrad leading to the ultimate defeat of Nazi Germany 具有转折点意义的斯大林格勒战役导致了最后纳粹德国的战败
A: ♣反  trivial, petty, minor, immaterial, inconsequential, insignificant 不重要的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 夸大的 wildly unrestrained : grandiose
A: ♣例  apocalyptic tone 夸大的语气

Q:apocryphal  [ə'pɔkrifəl]

A: ♣反  factual, true, truthful, authentic真的

Q:apoplectic  [,æpəu'plektik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 极度愤怒的：extremely angry; furious
A: ♣例  He became apoplectic about wasteful government spending. 他对于政府的浪费开销变得怒不可遏。
A: ♣例  The coach was so apoplectic when the player missed the free throw that he threw his clipboard onto the court. 教练对球员罚篮不进非常气愤以至于把战术板扔到了球场上。
A: ♣近  choleric, enraged, furious, incensed, indignant, infuriated, irate, ireful, outraged
A: ♣反  angerless, delighted, pleased 不生气的，高兴的

Q:apostasy  [ə'pɔstəsi]

A: ♣例  Some people completely abandon the faith after apostasy. 有些人在放弃自己的宗教信仰后就再也不相信任何其他宗教信仰了。
A: ♠考法2  n. 变节，背叛：abandonment of a previous loyalty : defection
A: ♣例  He was looked down upon for apostasy. 他因为背叛而受到鄙视。
A: ♣近  defection, perfidy, treacherousness, recreancy
A: ♣反  fidelity, allegiance, loyalty, piety 忠诚，虔诚

Q:appall  [ə'pɔ:l]

A: ♣例  He felt appalled by the whole idea of marriage so we broke up. 结婚使他恐惧，因此我们分手了。
A: ♣近  dismay, terrify, intimidate, frighten, horrify, daunt, deter
A: ♣反  embolden, encourage, nerve 使大胆，鼓起勇气

Q:apparition  [,æpə'riʃən]

A: ♣近  ghost, phantasm, phantom, shade, shadow, specter, spirit, spook, sprite, vision, visitant, wraith
A: ♣反  entity, substance 实体

Q:appeal  [ə'pi:l]

A: ♣反  absolve 赦免；exonerate, exculpate 开脱免罪；vindicate 辩护

Q:appealing  [ə'pi:liŋ]

Q:applause  [ə'plɔ:z]

A: ♣反  hissing, booing 发出嘘声

Q:applicable  ['æplikəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可用的，可行的： capable of being put to use or account
A: ♣例  Is that Act applicable in this case where suspect is a foreigner? 那条法规适用于这个嫌犯不是本国公民的案件么？
A: ♣近  actionable, applicative, applied, functional, practicable, serviceable, useful, workable
A: ♣反  impractical, inapplicable, unusable, unworkable, useless 不可用的，不可行的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 相关的，有关的： having to do with the matter at hand
A: ♣例  He rarely makes comment that is applicable to our discussion. 他的评论很少和我们讨论的题目搭边。
A: ♣近  apposite, apropos, germane, material, pointed, relative, relevant
A: ♣反  extraneous, immaterial, impertinent, inapposite, irrelevant, pointless 无关的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 合适的，恰当的： meeting the requirements of a purpose or situation
A: ♣例  He has been busy in selecting the most applicable word for his PhD thesis. 他一致忙于为自己的博士论文选择最为恰当词汇。
A: ♣近  appropriate, apt, becoming, befitting, felicitous, fitting, meet, pretty, proper, right, suitable
A: ♣反  improper, inappropriate, inapt, incongruous, malapropos, misbecoming, unbecoming, unfitting, unmeet, unseemly, unsuitable, wrong 不恰当的

Q:apposite  ['æpəuzit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 相关的，合适的highly pertinent or appropriate: apt
A: ♣例  to enrich his essay with some very apposite quotations from famous people 用名人名言来丰富他的文章
A: ♣近  applicable, apropos, germane, pointed, relative, relevant
A: ♣反  extraneous, irrelevant, impertinent, irrelative, pointless 无关的

Q:appreciable  [ə'pri:ʃiəbl]

A: ♣近  apprehensible, perceptible, detectable, discernible, palpable, distinguishable, sensible
A: ♣反  impalpable, imperceptible, inappreciable, indistinguishable, insensible, undetectable 不能感知的

Q:apprehension  [,æpri'henʃən]

A: ♣例  She had a strong apprehension about her sister's health 她非常担心她姐姐的健康。

A: ♣反  composure, equanimity 镇定；unconcern 冷漠
A: ♠考法2  n. 逮捕：seizure by legal process : arrestment
A: ♣例  apprehension of the thief 逮捕小偷
A: ♣近  arrest
A: ♣反  discharge 释放
A: ♠考法3  n. 理解：the knowledge gained from the process of coming to know or understand something
A: ♣例  a good apprehension of how computer systems work 对计算机是如何工作的有很好的理解
A: ♣近  understanding, comprehension
A: ♣反  incomprehension

Q:apprehensive  [,æpri'hensiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 知晓的，理解的： having specified facts or feelings actively impressed on the mind
A: ♣例  I am fully apprehensive of the options, I assure you. 我向你保证这些观点我都理解了。
A: ♣近  alive, aware, cognizant, mindful, sensible, sentient, ware, witting
A: ♣反  ignorant, insensible, oblivious, unaware, unconscious, unmindful, unwitting 不知晓的，无知觉的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 恐惧的，害怕的： anxious or fearful about the future
A: ♣例  People apparently haven’t recovered from the devastating terrorist attack and are still terribly apprehensive about the future. 人们显然没有从那场严重的恐怖袭击中恢复过来，对于未来仍然充满了恐惧。
A: ♣近  afraid, aghast, fearful, frightened, horrified, hysterical, scared, shocked, terrified
A: ♣反  dauntless, fearless, intrepid, unafraid 无所畏惧的；confident 充满自信的
A: ♣派  apprehension n. 理解；忧虑，恐惧

Q:apprise  [ə'praiz]
