A: ♣近  inform, acquaint, make known to
A: ♣反  withhold information 隐瞒信息

Q:approbation  [,æprəu'beiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 同意：an expression of warm approval
A: ♣例  The proposal met his approbation. 这项建议得到了他的同意。
A: ♣近  approval, favor
A: ♣反  disapproval, disapprobation, disfavor不同意

Q:appropriate  [ə'prəuprieit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 私自挪用to take possession of or make use of exclusively for oneself, often without permission
A: ♣例  to appropriate private property 盗用私人财产
A: ♣例  The economy has been weakened by corrupt officials who have appropriated the country's resources for their own use. 经济因为腐败的官员们私自挪用国家资源而被削弱了。
A: ♣近  purloin, pirate, embezzle, peculate, usurp
A: ♠考法2  adj. 适当的：especially suitable or compatible: fitting
A: ♣例  Red wine is a more appropriate choice with the meal. 红酒更适合这顿饭。
A: ♣例  I don't think jeans and a T-shirt are appropriate attire for a wedding. 我觉得穿牛仔和T恤去婚礼不太得体。
A: ♣近  apt, becoming, felicitous, fitting, proper, meet, suitable, apposite, apropos
A: ♣反  improper, inapposite, inappropriate, inapt, unmeet, unseemly, unsuitable 不合适的

Q:apropos  ['æprəpəu]
A: ♠考法1  adj.相关的：being both relevant and opportune
A: ♣例  The actor announced to reporters that he would only answer to apropos questions about the movie. 演员向记者表示，他只回答那些和电影有关的问题。
A: ♣近  appliacable, apropos, germane, pointed, relative, relevant
A: ♣反  extraneous, irrelevant, impertinent, irrelative, pointless 无关的
A: ♠考法2  prep. 关于，有关：having to do with
A: ♣例  to make a number of telling observations apropos the current political situation 做了很多关于当前政治形势有力的观察
A: ♣近  apropos, apropos of, as far as, as for, as regards (also as respects), as to, concerning, of, on, regarding, respecting, touching, toward (or towards)

Q:apt  [æpt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 恰当的,合适的：exactly suitable; appropriate
A: ♣例  apt remark/ choice/ description 恰当的评述、选择、描述
A: ♣近  apropos, germane, relative, relevant, appropirate
A: ♣反  extraneous, irrelevant, impertinent, irrelative无关的；inappropriate, improper, unseemly 不恰当的，不合时宜的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 有…倾向的，可能的：having a tendency : likely
A: ♣例  He is apt to fly out in rage. 他容易发脾气。
A: ♣近  likely, inclined, tending, given
A: ♣反  unlikely 不可能的；disinclined 没有…倾向的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 聪明的keenly intelligent and responsive
A: ♣例  an apt pupil 一个聪明的小学生
A: ♣例  He is apt at mathematics. 他擅长数学。
A: ♣近  brilliant, clever, quick-witted, ready-witted, smart
A: ♣反  foolish, dull, dumb, stupid, unintelligent 傻的

Q:arable  ['ærəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 适合耕种的： fit for or used for the growing of crops
A: ♣例  explore the west for arable land 向西探索适合耕种的土地
A: ♣近  cultivable, tillable
A: ♣反  barren, sterile, infertile, unfruitful, unproductive 贫瘠的

Q:arbitrary  ['ɑ:bitrəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 专横的，独断专行的： having or showing a tendency to force one's will on others without any regard to fairness or necessity
A: ♣例  an arbitrary piano teacher who makes all her students do the same exercises over and over again 一个让学生反复练习同一首曲子的专横的老师
A: ♣近  dictatorial, imperious, peremptory, willful
A: ♠考法2  adj. 独裁的，拥有无限权力的： exercising power or authority without interference by others
A: ♣例  a nation with no tradition of democracy, only a long history of arbitrary rulers 一个从来没有民主的传统，只有长期的独裁统治的国家
A: ♣近  autocratic, czarist, despotic, monocratic, tyrannic, tyrannous
A: ♣反  limited （权力）受限的；democratic 民主的；republican 共和的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 缺乏计划的，随意的： lacking a definite plan, purpose, or pattern
A: ♣例  The order of the names of the 10 semifinalists is entirely arbitrary. 半决赛上十名上场选手的顺序完全是随机的。
A: ♣近  aimless, desultory, erratic, haphazard, scattered, slapdash, stray, willy-nilly
A: ♣反  methodical, orderly, organized, regular, systematic, systematized 有序的，有组织的

Q:arcane  [ɑ:'kein]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （语言）晦涩的，隐晦的： having an often intentionally veiled or uncertain meaning
A: ♣例  The rebate form uses arcane language, the only purpose of which seems to be to disqualify buyers from actually getting a rebate. 折扣单上的条文晦涩难懂，这样做的唯一目的也许就是让消费者不能真正地享受到折扣。
A: ♣近  ambiguous, dark, elliptical, equivocal, murky, mysterious, mystic, nebulous, occult, opaque
A: ♣反  accessible, clear, obvious, plain, unambiguous, unequivocal 清晰明了的，明确的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 深奥的，难以理解的： difficult for one of ordinary knowledge or intelligence to understand
A: ♣例  Grammatical rules seem extremely arcane to generations of students who were never taught grammar in the first place. 对那些从未学习过语法的几代学生来说，语法规则犹如天书。
A: ♣近  abstruse, cryptic, deep, enigmatic, esoteric, hermetic, impenetrable, inscrutable, recondite, uncanny
A: ♣反  easy, facile, shallow, simple, superficial 浅显易懂的

Q:archaic  [ɑ:'keiik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 过时的，久远的：no longer current or applicable; antiquated
A: ♣例  archaic laws 过时的法律
A: ♣近  antiquated, outdated, outmoded, prehistoric, superannuated
A: ♣反  fashionable 流行的；up-to-date, fresh, modern, new, novel 新的
A: ♣派  archaism 古语：the use of archaic diction or style
A: ♣反  modern diction 新语

Q:archetype  ['ɑ:kitaip]
A: ♠考法1  n.典范，榜样：an ideal example of a type
A: ♣例  an archetype of the successful entrepreneur 成功企业家的典范
A: ♣近  ideal, a perfect example, quintessence
A: ♠考法2  n.先驱，鼻祖：something belonging to an earlier time from which something else was later developed
A: ♣例  The abacus is sometimes cited as the archetype of the modern digital calculator 算盘是现代计算器的鼻祖
A: ♣近  antecedent, foregoer, forerunner, precursor, predecessor, prototype
A: ♠考法3  n. 原型：something from which copies are made
A: ♣例  “‘Frankenstein’... ‘Dracula’... ‘Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde’... the archetypes that have influenced all subsequent horror stories”(New York Times) “‘弗兰肯斯坦’…‘德秋拉’…‘杰基尔博士和海德先生’影响了所有继之而来的恐怖故事的原型”(纽约时报)
A: ♣近  archetype, prototype

Q:ardor  ['ɑ:də]
A: ♠考法1  n. 狂热：strong enthusiasm or devotion; zeal
A: ♣例  His ardor was damped. 他的热情被泼了冷水。
A: ♣近  avidity, zeal, fervor, fervency, fervidness, passion, passionateness, vehemence
A: ♣反  apathy, torpor, impassivity, insensitivity 冷漠，麻木

Q:arduous  ['ɑ:djuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 难以做到，费劲的：hard to accomplish or achieve: difficult
A: ♣例  a long and arduous undertaking 一项长期艰苦的任务
A: ♣例  an arduous journey across miles of desert 艰苦的沙漠之旅
A: ♣近  grueling, laborious, taxing, onerous, burdensome
A: ♣反  easy, simple, unchallenging, undemanding, facile, effortless不费劲的

Q:argot  ['ɑ:ɡəu]
A: ♠考法1  n. 隐语，黑话，行话：a specialized vocabulary or set of idioms used by a particular group
A: ♣例  groups communicating in their own secret argots 用他们秘密的行话交流的团体
A: ♣近  argot, cant, jargon, shoptalk
A: ♣反  standard language 标准的语言；common verbalism大众的言语

Q:argument  ['ɑ:ɡjumənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 争吵，争论： an often noisy or angry expression of differing opinions
A: ♣例  The couple’s arguments were often loud enough to be heard all over the neighborhood. 这对夫妻吵架的声音往往大到能被邻居听见。
A: ♣近  altercation, controversy, disagreement, dispute, hassle, imbroglio, quarrel, squabble, tiff, wrangle
A: ♠考法2  n. （逻辑上的）论证： a coherent series of statements leading from a premise to a conclusion
A: ♣例  In his argument the author committed several logical fallacies which undermined its soundness. 在作者的论述中出现了若干逻辑谬误，从而降低了它论证的力度。
A: ♣近  account, accounting, argumentation, case, explanation, rationale, reasoning
A: ♠考法3  n. 观点，论点： an idea or opinion that is put forth in a discussion or debate
A: ♣例  It is and will always be my argument that we have too many problems here on earth to concern ourselves with manned trips to Mars. 我现在和以后的观点都将会是：在我们解决地球上的问题之前，不应该花太多的心思考虑载人火星计划的事情。
A: ♣近  assertion, point, position, stand, thesis

Q:arid  ['ærid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 干燥的： marked by little or no precipitation or humidity
A: ♣例  arid wastelands unfit for human habitation 不适合人类居住的干燥荒原
A: ♣近  droughty, dry, sere, thirsty, waterless
A: ♣反  damp, dank, humid, moist, wet 湿润的，潮湿的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无趣的，无聊的： causing weariness, restlessness, or lack of interest
A: ♣例  arid wastelands unfit for human habitation 不适合人类居住的干燥荒原
A: ♣近  dreary, dull, flat, humdrum, jading, jejune, monochromatic, monotonous, pedestrian, stale, stodgy, tedious, wearisome
A: ♣反  absorbing, engaging, engrossing, gripping, interesting, intriguing, involving, riveting 有趣的，吸引人的

Q:array  [ə'rei]
A: ♠考法1  n. 排列，阵列： a regular and imposing grouping or arrangement
A: ♣例  a marching band’s carefully choreographed array 前进中的乐队所摆出的经过复杂编排的方针
A: ♣近  arrangement, disposal, disposition, distribution, ordering, sequence, setup
A: ♣反  disorder, disorganization 混乱，无序
A: ♠考法2  vt. 排列，摆放： to arrange or display in or as if in an array
A: ♣例  data arrayed in descending order 按照降序排列的数据‖arrayed his baseball cards in order of their rarity and consequent monetary value 把他的棒球卡按照稀有程度——也即价值排列
A: ♣近  arrange, classify, codify, dispose, marshal, organize, range, systematize, draw up, lay out
A: ♣反  derange, disarrange, disarray, disorder, mess, rumple, upset 弄乱，打乱
A: ♠考法3  vt. 装饰，装修： to dress or decorate especially in splendid or impressive attire
A: ♣例  He had already arrayed himself in his best clothes. 他已经穿上了他最好的服装。‖a door arrayed for the holidays with a beautiful evergreen wreath 被美丽的常青花环妆点的节日大门
A: ♣近  adorn, beautify, bedeck, bedizen, blazon, embellish, emblaze, emboss, enrich, garnish, ornament, trim
A: ♣反  blemish, deface, disfigure, mar, scar, spoil 破坏，

Q:arrest  [ə'rest]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使不活跃：to make inactive
A: ♣例  arrest the growth of the tumor 抑制肿瘤生长
A: ♣近  check, rein, curb, contain, hamper, thwart, bring to a halt
A: ♣反  vitalize, activate, animate, invigorate 使有生气；prod, goad, spur, galvanize, provoke, stimulate 刺激
A: ♠考法2  n/v. 停止：the stopping of a process or activity; to bring to a standstill
A: ♣例  Science cannot yet arrest the process of aging. 科学不能阻止衰老。
A: ♣近  cease, cessation, closure, conclusion, discontinuance, discontinuation, ending, halt, stop, termination; check, stop
A: ♣反  continuance, continuation 继续
A: ♠考法3  v. 逮捕：to take or keep under one's control by authority of law
A: ♣例  She was charged with resisting arrest. 她因为拘捕受到起诉。
A: ♣近  apprehend
A: ♣反  discharge 释放
A: ♠考法4  v. 吸引注意力：to hold the attention of as if by a spell
A: ♣例  The behavior of the daredevil arrested pedestrians. 冒失鬼的行为吸引了行人们的注意力。
A: ♣近  enchant, fascinate, bedazzle, grip, hypnotize, mesmerize

Q:arresting  [ə'restiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 吸引人的：attracting and holding the attention; striking
A: ♣例  an arresting spectacle 吸引人的奇观
A: ♣近  absorbing, engaging, engrossing, enthralling, fascinating, gripping, immersing, intriguing, riveting
A: ♣反  boring, drab, tedious, monotonous, uninteresting 乏味的，单调的

Q:arrhythmic  [ə'riðmik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不规律的：lacking rhythm or regularity
A: ♣例  arrhythmic pulse 不规律的脉搏
A: ♣近  irregular, disorderly
A: ♣反  regular, orderly 规律的

Q:arrogance  ['ærəɡəns]
A: ♠考法1  n．傲慢，自大：overbearing pride
A: ♣例  Her arrogance has earned her a lot of enemies. 她的傲慢给她带来了很多敌人。
A: ♣近  assumption, bumptiousness, haughtiness, hauteur, imperiousness, loftiness, peremptoriness, pomposity, pompousness, presumptuousness, superciliousness
A: ♣反  humility, modesty, humbleness, unassumingness 谦虚

Q:articulate  [ɑ:'tikjulət]
A: ♠考法1  v. 清晰地表达：to utter clearly and distinctly
A: ♣例  He cannot articulate his thoughts. 他不能清楚地表达他的想法。
A: ♣例  a theory first articulated by ancient philosophers 被古时哲学家阐明的理论
A: ♣近  enunciate
A: ♣反  murmur, mumble, mutter, slur 模糊地说
A: ♠考法2  adj. 表达清晰的：able to express oneself clearly and well
A: ♣例  The television crew covering the science fair were looking for photogenic and articulate students to explain their projects on the air
A: ♣近  eloquent, fluent, silver-tongued, well-spoken
A: ♣反  inarticulate, ineloquent, unvocal 表达不清楚的

Q:ascendant  [ə'sendənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有影响力的，主宰的：dominant in position or influence; superior.
A: ♣例  This idea was in the ascendant. 这种思想处于主导地位。
A: ♣近  superior, dominant, sovereign
A: ♣反  having no influence/ power 没有影响力的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 上升的：moving upward : rising
A: ♣例  The teacher told the students to write even numbers in ascendant order. 老师让学生们按升序写出偶数。
A: ♣反  declining 下降的

Q:ascetic  [ə'setik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 禁欲的：practicing strict self-denial as a measure of personal and especially spiritual discipline
A: ♣例  This is an ascetic diet of rice and beans. 这是一顿禁欲的隐私，只有米饭和豌豆。
A: ♣近  abstemious, abstinent, self-denying
A: ♣反  sumptuous, luxurious 奢侈的；licentious, sybaritic, voluptuous 放荡的，沉溺于酒色的
A: ♠考法2  n. 禁欲者：a person who renounces material comforts and leads a life of austere self-discipline, especially as an act of religious devotion.
A: ♣例  We normally see an ascetic meditating in a Yogic pose. 我们通常会看见一个苦行者以瑜伽的姿势来冥想。
A: ♣近  stoic, spartan
A: ♣反  sybarite, hedonist, voluptuary 奢侈逸乐的，人享乐主义者，酒色之徒

Q:aseptic  [æ'septik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 消毒的，无菌的：preventing infection
A: ♣例  Surgery must be in aseptic environments. 手术必须处在无菌环境下
A: ♣近  sterile, germfree
A: ♣反  germy, unsterile 有细菌的；contaminated, tainted 被污染的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 缺乏活力的：lacking vitality
A: ♣近  inactive, lackadaisical, languid, listless, spiritless
A: ♣反  active, animated, energetic, energetic, vivacious 有活力的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 冷漠的：emotion, or warmth
A: ♣例  aseptic essays 没有感情的文章；an aseptic smile 漠然的微笑
A: ♣近  affectlessness, emotionlessness, impassiveness, impassivity, insensibility, numbness, phlegm
A: ♣反  emotion, feeling, sensibility 有感情

Q:askew  [ə'skju:]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不成直线，歪的：out of line, awry
A: ♣例  The picture hung askew. 画挂歪了。
A: ♣例  His tie was askew. 他的领带歪了。
A: ♣近  crooked, cockeyed, oblique, lopsided, skewed, aslant, slanted, slanting, listing, tilted, awry
A: ♣反  aligned 列成一行的；straight, erect 直的

Q:aspect  ['æspekt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 外表，容貌：appearance to the eye or mind
A: ♣例  His face had a frightening aspect. 他的脸很吓人。
A: ♣近  appearance, look, figure, presence, mien

Q:asperity  [æ'sperəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. （举止、性情）粗暴：roughness of manner or of temper
A: ♣例  She responded with such asperity that we knew she was offended by the question. 她如此粗鲁的回答问题以至于我们知道这个问题冒犯到了她。
A: ♣近  roughness, crudity, rudeness, poignancy, harshness
A: ♣反  softness, mildness 脾气好
A: ♠考法2  n.（环境）艰苦：rigor, severity
A: ♣例  He has encountered more than his share of asperities on the road to success. 在成功的道路上他已经遇到过比他应该承受的更多的艰辛。
A: ♣近  severity, hardness, hardship, rigor

Q:aspersion  [ə'spə:ʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 诽谤，中伤：a false or misleading charge meant to harm someone's reputation
A: ♣例  cast aspersions on my loyalty 诽谤我的忠诚
A: ♣近  defamation, besmirchment, calumny, calumniation, maligning, obloquy, vilification
A: ♣反  glowing tribute, eulogy, extolling, laudation, praise, commendation, compliment 热情赞赏，表扬；flattery, adulation拍马屁

Q:aspirant  [ə'spaiərənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 有抱负者, 有野心者：one who aspires, as to advancement, honors, or a high position
A: ♣例  a bevy of ever-smiling aspirants for the Miss America title 一群想当美国小姐的少女
A: ♣例  Envy can make oneself backward, self-confidence can tells him to be a aspirant. 妒忌能使自己落后，自信能使自己上进。
A: ♣近  seeker
A: ♣反  noncandidate 非候选人
A: ♠考法2  adj. 想成为…的：seeking to attain a desired position or status
A: ♣例  The pilot was an aspirant astronaut. 这个飞行员想成为航天员。

Q:assail  [ə'seil]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 抨击，严厉批评： to criticize harshly and usually publicly
A: ♣例  The union organizers assailed the chemical company for failing to provide a safe working environment. 工会主席因为这家化工企业不能为员工提供安全的生产环境而对其进行了严厉的抨击。
A: ♣近  abuse, bash, belabor, blast, castigate, excoriate, lambaste, savage, scathe, slam, trash, vituperate
A: ♣反  acclaim, commend, compliment, hail, laud, praise 表扬，称赞
A: ♠考法2  vt. 攻击，猛攻： to take sudden, violent action against
A: ♣例  He was assailed by a young man with a knife. 他被一个持刀的年轻人揍了一顿。
A: ♣近  assault, attack, beset, charge, raid, rush, storm, strike, set on
A: ♣反  defend, guard, protect, shield 防御，守卫
A: ♣派  assailable adj. 易受攻击的

Q:assent  [ə'sent]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 同意：to agree to something especially after thoughtful consideration
A: ♣例  The general proposed a detailed plan and the president assented. 将军提出了一个细节化的计划，总统同意了该计划。
A: ♣近  accede, agree, assent, consent, subscribe, come round
A: ♣反  dissent, disagree 不同意

Q:assert  [ə'sə:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 断言，肯定地说出：to state or declare positively and often forcefully or aggressively
A: ♣例  asserted one’s innocence.坚称自己无罪
A: ♣例  He asserted that there were corrupt officials in the government. 他断言道政府里面一定存在腐败的官员。
A: ♣近  aver, allege, avow, avouch, insist
A: ♣反  deny, gainsay 否认

Q:assertive  [ə'sə:tiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 武断的，强烈自信的：inclined to bold or confident assertion; aggressively self-assured.
A: ♣例  You will have to make many personal judgments when being assertive. 当武断的时候你不得不做出很多个人选择。
A: ♣近  assertory, self-assured, self-assertive, peremptory
A: ♣反  diffident 不自信的

Q:assess  [ə'ses]
A: ♠考法1  v. 评估重要性、尺寸、价值等：to determine the importance, size, or value of
A: ♣例  We need to assess whether or not the system is working. 我们需要评估这个系统是否工作。
A: ♣近  evaluate, appraise, guesstimate
A: ♠考法2  v. 征收费用（如罚款）：to establish or apply as a charge or penalty
A: ♣例  The utility company will assess a fee if your payment is late. 如果你付款晚了，公共事业公司会罚款。
A: ♣近  assess, charge, exact, fine, lay, levy, put
A: ♣反  remit 免除（债务）

Q:assiduous  [ə'sidjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 勤勉的，专心仔细的：marked by careful unremitting attention or persistent application; busy
A: ♣例  tended his garden with assiduous attention 专心仔细地照看他的花园
A: ♣例  The project required some assiduous planning. 项目需要细心的规划。
A: ♣近  diligent, industrious, sedulous
A: ♣反  idle, inactive, unbusy, unemployed, unoccupied 空闲的
A: ♣派  assiduity n. 勤勉：persistent application or diligence; unflagging effort.

Q:assuage  [ə'sweidʒ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 缓和，减轻：to lessen the intensity of
A: ♣例  He couldn't assuage his guilt over the divorce. 他无法减轻自己在离婚中的罪行。
A: ♣反  aggravate, exacerbate 加强，恶化
A: ♠考法2  vt. 平息，抚慰：to pacify or calm
A: ♣例  Life contains sorrows that cannot be assuaged, and it is important to be honest in acknowledging this. 生活中存在着无法平息的悲伤，诚实地承认这个事实才是重要的。
A: ♣近  compose, soothe, calm, pacify, placate, appease, lighten, relieve, alleviate, assuage, allay, mitigate, moderate, conciliate, propitiate
A: ♣反  aggravate, annoy, enrage, exasperate, incense, infuriate, ire, irk, irritate, madden, nettle, peeve, provoke, rile, roil, vex 煽动，激起
A: ♠考法3  vt. 使满足：to put an end to by satisfying
A: ♣例  assuage his thirst 消渴
A: ♣例  That meal certainly assuaged my hunger. 那顿大餐满足了我的口腹之欲。
A: ♣近  satisfy, sate, satiate, quench

Q:astounding  [ə'staundiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 令人吃惊的，出乎意料的：causing astonishment or amazement
A: ♣例  The richness and variety of the undersea environment are astounding．富饶而多样的海底环境是令人惊奇的。
A: ♣近  amazing, astonishing, blindsiding, dumbfounding, shocking, startling, stunning, stupefying
A: ♣反  unsurprising 平常的

Q:astute  [ə'stju:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 机敏的，有洞察力的：having or showing shrewdness and perspicacity
A: ♣例  Astute salesmen know how to invest emotionally. 精明的推销员知道如何进行感情投资。
A: ♣近  canny, smart, shrewd, perspicacious, clear-eyed, clear-sighted, savvy, hardheaded
A: ♣反  unknowing 无知的

Q:asunder  [ə'sʌndə]
A: ♠考法1  adv. 分离成多部分或多片：into separate parts or pieces
A: ♣例  broken asunder 打碎
A: ♣例  Buildings were burst asunder. 建筑物已经被炸成碎片了。
A: ♣近  piecemeal
A: ♣反  in a piece 完整一片；together 在一起
A: ♠考法2  adv. 分离：apart from each other in position
A: ♣例  A quite conscience sleeps in thunder, but rest and guilt live far asunder. 平静的良心能在雷声中入睡，而安宁和负罪则无法毗邻。
A: ♣例  Our opinions are wide as the poles asunder. 我们的意见完全相反。
A: ♣近  apart
A: ♣反  together 在一起

Q:asylum  [ə'sailəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 收容所/ 保护所：an inviolable place of refuge and protection giving shelter to criminals and debtors/ something (as a building) that offers cover from the weather or protection from danger
A: ♣例  an insane asylum 疯人院
A: ♣例  The embassy serves as an asylum for that country's nationals in need of help. 大使馆作为那国需要帮助的公民的保护所。
A: ♣近  harbor, haven, refuge, sanctuary, sanctum

Q:asymmetrical  [,æsi'metrik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不平衡的,不对称的：having no balance or symmetry
A: ♣例  the asymmetrical construction 非对称的建筑
A: ♣近  asymmetric, nonsymmetrical, unsymmetrical, unbalanced
A: ♣反  symmetrical 对称的；balanced 平衡的

Q:asymmetry  [æ'simətri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 不对称，不平衡： lack of balance or symmetry
A: ♣例  functional asymmetry of cerebral hemispheres 大脑两半球功能不对称性
A: ♣近  disproportion, imbalance
A: ♣反  symmetry 对称；balance, proportion 平衡
A: ♣派  asymmetric adj. 不对称的

Q:atone  [ə'təun]
A: ♠考法1  v. 赎罪，弥补：to make amends, as for a sin or fault
A: ♣例  Blood must atone for blood. 以命抵命。
A: ♣例  Even death cannot atone for the offence. 罪不容诛。
A: ♣近  redeem

Q:atrocious  [ə'trəuʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 极坏的, 极其残忍的：extremely wicked, brutal, or cruel
A: ♣例  Murder is an atrocious crime. 犯罪是一种极其恶劣的犯罪活动。
A: ♣近  heinous
A: ♣反  benign, kind, kindhearted, benignant, good-hearted, humane, sympathetic, tenderhearted 善良的，好的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 让人极为不满意的 extremely unsatisfactory
A: ♣例  The service on plane was atrocious. 飞机上的服务让人极为不满意。
A: ♣反  satisfactory 令人满意的； wonderful 精彩的，极好的

Q:atrophy  ['ætrəfi]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 萎缩，衰退： to waste away; wither or deteriorate
A: ♣例  The years following the closing of the last textile mill, the town atrophied. 随着最后一家纺织厂的倒闭，整个城镇开始衰退。
A: ♣近  crumble, decay, decline, degenerate, descend, devolve, ebb, regress, retrograde, rot, sink, worsen
A: ♣反  ameliorate, improve, meliorate 改善，提升

Q:attenuate  [ə'tenjueit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 使降低（数量，力量，价值）： to lessen the amount, force, magnitude, or value of
A: ♣例  an investment attenuated by inflation 一份因通货膨胀而贬值的投资.
A: ♣近  cheapen, devalue, downgrade, reduce, write down
A: ♣反  appreciate, enhance, upgrade, mark up 升值，提升
A: ♣派  attenuation n. 弱化，贬值

Q:attest  [ə'test]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 证实，为…作证： to give evidence or testimony to the truth or factualness of
A: ♣例  Her fine work attests her ability. 她的优秀作品能够证明她的能力。‖I can attest that she was at the party. 我可以为她当时在聚会上作证。
A: ♣近  argue, authenticate, certify, corroborate, substantiate, support, testify, validate, verify, vindicate
A: ♣反  contradict, disprove, gainsay, rebut, refute 反驳，否定

Q:attune  [ə'tju:n]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使协调，使和谐： to bring into harmony
A: ♣例  After years spent in academia, he found it difficult to attune himself to the corporate culture. 在学术圈摸爬滚打多年之后，他发现自己很难融入企业文化之中。
A: ♣近  accommodate, conciliate, conform, coordinate, key, reconcile
A: ♣反  disharmonize 使不和谐；disarray, disorder, disorganize, disrupt 弄乱，打乱
A: ♣派  attunement n. 调音，协调

Q:audacious  [ɔ:'deiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 大胆的，（但往往）愚勇的： fearlessly, often recklessly daring; bold
A: ♣例  an audacious plan 一个冒进的计划
A: ♣近  bold, adventurous, brash, brassy, brazen, rash, reckless
A: ♣反  cautious, circumspect, guarded, wary 小心谨慎的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 蔑视（法律、礼节）的，无礼的： contemptuous of law, religion, or decorum
A: ♣近  impertinent, impudent, insolent
A: ♣反  timid, meek 温顺的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 乐于冒险的： inclined or willing to take risks
A: ♣例  audacious adventurers risking everything they had for a shot at glory 为了荣誉而孤注一掷的冒险家们
A: ♣近  daring, emboldened, enterprising, nervy, venturesome
A: ♠考法4  adj. 大胆创新的： marked by originality and verve
A: ♣例  an audacious interpretation of two dramas 对两部戏剧的创造性阐述
A: ♣派  audacity n. 胆量，不敬

Q:augur  ['ɔ:ɡə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 预言家： one who predicts future events or developments
A: ♣例  The ancient Roman augurs predicted the future by reading the flight of birds. 古罗马的预言家们通过鸟类的航线来预测未来
A: ♣近  forecaster, foreseer, diviner, foreteller, prophesier, visionary
A: ♠考法2  v. 出现好兆头： to show signs of a favorable or successful outcome
A: ♣例  This augurs well for us. 这是一个好兆头
A: ♣近  forebode, promise
A: ♠考法3  vt. 预言：to tell of or describe beforehand
A: ♣例  The fortune-teller augured nothing but a series of calamities for me. 占卜人预言在我身上将会有一系列大灾难发生
A: ♣近  forecast, predict, presage, prognosticate, prophesy

Q:august  ['ɔːɡəst]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 威严的，庄重的： having or showing a formal and serious or reserved manner
A: ♣例  Unsurprisingly, the head of the bank is an august white-haired gentleman. 不出所料的，银行的总裁是一名白发苍苍的、令人顿生敬意的绅士。
A: ♣近  distinguished, imposing, portly, solemn, staid, stately
A: ♣反  flighty, frivolous, giddy, goofy, silly, undignified 轻浮的，不庄重的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 盛大的，令人印象深刻的： large and impressive in size, grandeur, extent, or conception
A: ♣例  an august golden anniversary celebration for the company 盛大的周年庆祝会
A: ♣近  baronial, epic, grandiose, imperial, magnificent, majestic, massive, monumental, noble, regal, splendid
A: ♣反  common, humble, mediocre, ordinary, unimposing, unimpressive 普通的，一般的

Q:auspicious  [ɔ:'spiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 好兆头的： pointing toward a happy outcome
A: ♣例  began the season with an auspicious win against their strongest football rival 在赛季之初就战胜了最强的对手，为整个赛季赢得了好兆头
A: ♣近  bright, encouraging, golden, heartening, hopeful, promising, propitious
A: ♣反  baleful, dark, direful, doomy, foreboding, gloomy, menacing, minatory, ominous, portentous, sinister, threatening 不详的，凶兆的

Q:austere  [ɔ'stiə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 朴素的，朴实无华： markedly simple or unadorned
A: ♣例  For the private office of the CEO of the large corporation, the room is unexpectedly austere. 出人意料的是，大公司总裁的私人办公室居然十分朴素。
A: ♣近  plain, spartan, stark, unadorned
A: ♣反  deluxe, lavish, luxurious, plush, sumptuous 奢华的；elaborate, fancy 花哨的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 严肃的，令人生畏的： stern and cold in appearance or manner
A: ♣例  an austere fortress at the top of some formidable cliffs 建立在悬崖峭壁之上的一座令人畏惧的堡垒‖In his memory his deceased grandfather is an austere, distant, cold person. 在他的记忆之中，已过世的祖父是一个严肃、冷漠而难以接近的人。
A: ♣近  dour, fierce, flinty, forbidding, formidable, gruff, intimidating, lowering, rough, rugged, severe, steely
A: ♣反  benign, benignant, gentle, mild, tender 和蔼的，温柔的

Q:authentic  [ɔ:'θentik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 真实的，非仿造的： being exactly as appears or as claimed
A: ♣例  found an authentic Native American arrowhead 发现了一支美洲土著的箭头
A: ♣近  bona fide, certified, genuine
A: ♣反  bogus, counterfeit, fake, mock, phony, spurious 伪造的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 准确的，相符合的： following an original exactly
A: ♣例  an authentic reconstruction of the Parthenon 帕台农神殿的准确复刻
A: ♣近  accurate, exact, precise, right, veracious
A: ♣反  corrupt, false 错误的
A: ♣派  authenticity n. 真实，真实性

Q:authority  [ɔ:'θɔrəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. （某领域的）权威人士： a person with a high level of knowledge or skill in a field
A: ♣例  a leading authority on neural anatomy 一名神经解剖学领域的权威人士
A: ♣近  expert, connoisseur, maestro, master, virtuoso
A: ♣反  amateur 业余爱好者 inexpert 非专家
A: ♠考法2  n. 管辖权，控制： lawful control over the affairs of a political unit (as a nation)
A: ♣例  The sheriff had authority over the whole county. 郡守对于整个郡都有管辖权
A: ♣近  administration, governance, regime, regimen
A: ♠考法3  n. 影响力： the power to direct the thinking or behavior of others usually indirectly
A: ♣例  He speaks with a persuasive authority on matters of public health. 他就公共健康事务发表了带有影响力的、令人信服的评论
A: ♣近  clout, credit, leverage, weight
A: ♠考法4  n. （管束他人的）权力： the right or means to command or control others
A: ♣例  By the authority vested in me, I now pronounce you married. 依我所拥有的权力，我宣布你们成为夫妻
A: ♣近  arm, command, control, dominion, reign
A: ♣反  impotence, powerlessness 无权力
A: ♠考法5  n. 根据，理由： a warrant for action
A: ♣例  On what authority do you make such a claim? 你的指控有何理由？
A: ♣近  grounds, justification

Q:autocracy  [ɔ:'tɔkrəsi]

A: ♣例  It signified the British rejection of autocracy by constituting the first formal restraining of the power of the monarch 英国对于独裁体制的反抗表现在它对君王权力进行的正式约束
A: ♣近  absolutism, dictatorship, totalitarianism, tyranny
A: ♣反  democracy 民主，民主制度
A: ♣派  autocratic adj. 独裁的

Q:automatic  [,ɔ:tə'mætik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （机器等）自动的： acting or operating in a manner essentially independent of external influence or control
A: ♣例  Will your next car be a manual or an automatic? 你下辆车是手动挡还是自动挡？‖Modern subwaysare equipped with automatic screen doors. 现代地铁都装备了自动屏蔽门。
A: ♣近  automated, robotic, self-acting, self-operating, self-regulating
A: ♣反  manual 手动的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 自发的，情不自禁的： acting or done spontaneously or unconsciously
A: ♣例  Carl’s automatic use of the brakes narrowly averted a collision. 卡尔不经意间所踩的刹车勉强避免了一场车祸。
A: ♣近  impulsive, instinctive, involuntary, mechanic, mechanical, natural, spontaneous
A: ♣反  calculated, deliberate, intentional, planned, predetermined, premeditated, studied 有计划的，蓄意的
A: ♣派  automatically adv. 自动地

Q:autonomy  [ɔ:'tɔnəmi]

A: ♣例  The province has been granted autonomy. 这个省份被授予了自治权
A: ♣近  self-governance, sovereignty
A: ♣反  dependence, subjection 附属，依赖
A: ♠考法2  n. 自我主导的自由，尤其是精神独立： self-directing freedom and especially moral independence
A: ♣例  a teacher who encourages individual autonomy 一个鼓励精神独立的老师
A: ♣近  independence, liberty, free will
A: ♣反  constraint, duress 限制
A: ♣派  autonomous adj. 自治的

Q:avarice  ['ævəris]

A: ♣反  generosity, magnanimity慷慨
A: ♣派  avaricious adj. 贪婪的

Q:aver  [ə'və:]
A: ♠考法1  v. 声称为真： to state as a fact usually forcefully
A: ♣例  was tearfully averring his innocence 涕泪俱下地声明他的清白
A: ♣近  allege, assert, avouch, avow, declare, purport, warrant
A: ♣反  deny, gainsay 否认
A: ♠考法2  v. （态度强硬而明确地）声明： to state clearly and strongly
A: ♣例  She averred that she didn't need any help choosing her own clothes. 她态度强硬地声明：在买衣服的问题上不需要别人指手画脚
A: ♣近  affirm, insist, maintain, profess

Q:aversion  [ə'və:ʃən]

A: ♣例  a natural aversion toward insects 天生对昆虫的反感
A: ♣近  distaste, horror, loathing, nausea, repugnance, repulsion, revulsion
A: ♠考法2  n. 令人厌恶的事物：something or someone that is hated

A: ♣近  abhorrence, abomination, antipathy, detestation, execration
A: ♣反  love 令人喜爱的事物

Q:avid  [,ævid]

A: ♣例  avid movie fans 急切的影迷
A: ♣近  agog, ardent, eager, keen, impatient, thirsty
A: ♣反  apathetic, indifferent 不在乎的

A: ♣派  avidity n. 贪婪

Q:avowal  [ə'vauəl]

A: ♣反  disavowal 否认，否定

Q:awash  [ə'wɔʃ]

A: ♣例  The streets were awash from the heavy rains. 街道因为大雨被水淹没了
A: ♣近  doused, drenched, saturated, sodden, soggy, soaked, afloat
A: ♣反  dry, arid, dehydrated, drained 干燥的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （如洪水般）泛滥的： filled, covered, or completely overrun as if by a flood
A: ♣例  The program is currently awash in submissions and will not be accepting any more until next term. 该项目的申请人数过多，因此下一轮之前不会再接受任何申请
A: ♣近  abounding, abundant, flush, fraught, replete, swarming, teeming, thronging
A: ♣反  dearth, insufficient, scant 匮乏的

Q:awe  [ɔ:]

A: ♣例  She gazed in awe at the great stone. 她敬畏地凝视着那块巨石
A: ♣近  admiration, reverence, respect, veneration
A: ♣反  irreverence, insolence, scorn, superciliousness 蔑视，不敬
A: ♣派  awesome adj. 令人敬畏的

Q:awkward  ['ɔ:kwəd]

A: ♣例  awkward with a needle and thread 缺乏灵巧的针线活技术
A: ♣近  handless, maladroit
A: ♣反  adroit, deft, dexterous, proficient, skilled 灵巧的

A: ♣例  Her awkward handling of the seating arrangements resulted in many hurt feelings. 她那缺乏智谋的座次安排伤害了许多人的感情
A: ♣近  botched, bungling, fumbled, inept, inexpert, maladroit

A: ♣例  an awkward design 一份粗劣的设计
A: ♣近  clumsy, gauche, graceless, gawkish
A: ♣反  elegant, graceful, polished, lithe, coordinated 优雅的

A: ♣近  discomfiting, disturbing, disconcerting, embarrassing, flustering
A: ♠考法5  adj. （因过大过重或设计问题）难以操作的： difficult to use or operate especially because of size, weight, or design
A: ♣例  The manual can opener is too a

Q:awning  ['ɔ:niŋ]

A: ♣近  awning, ceiling, cover, roof, tent

Q:awry  [ə'rai]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 弯曲或扭曲的： in a turned or twisted position or direction
A: ♣例  Her sunglass is awry. 她墨镜戴歪了
A: ♣近  askew, aslant, lopsided, slanted
A: ♣反  aligned, direct, even, straight 成行的，笔直的
A: ♠考法2  adj./adv. 走样的（地），出差错的（地）： off the correct or expected course
A: ♣例  Operation Redwing was initially launched by US special-operation troops in hopes of capturing or killing a Taliban leader but went awry. 由美军特种部队发起、代号为“红翼”的军事行动的起初目的是捕获或击杀一名塔利班头目，然而行动在执行过程中出现了差错
A: ♣近  amiss, aside, astray, erroneous
A: ♣反  right, well 无差错的

Q:axiomatic  [,æksiəu'mætik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 公理的： based on or involving an axiom or system of axioms
A: ♣例  Euclidean geometry is based on five axiomatic principles. 欧几里得几何学是在五条公理的基础上建立的
A: ♣近  dictum, fundamental, maxim
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不言自明的： taken for granted, self-evident
A: ♣例  an axiomatic truth 一个不言而明的真理
A: ♣近  self-evident, prima facie
A: ♣反  controversial 有争议的
A: ♣派  axiom n. 公理

Q:babble  ['bæbl]
A: ♠考法1  v. 发出含糊无意义的嘟囔声，胡乱说： to utter a meaningless confusion of words or sounds
A: ♣例  Babies babble before they can talk. 婴儿在会说话以前含糊不清地发音
A: ♣近  drivel, gabble, gibber, jabber, prattle, abracadabra
A: ♣反  articulate 清晰地说出
A: ♠考法2  v. 闲聊： to engage in casual or rambling conversation
A: ♣例  The little girls babbled contentedly for the whole ride home. 两个小姑娘在回家的路上高兴地闲聊
A: ♣近  chatter, prate

Q:backfire  ['bæk,faiə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 产生相反的结果，事与愿违： to have the reverse of the desired or expected effect
A: ♣例  My plan to throw her a surprise party backfired when she ended up sobbing that everyone had forgotten her birthday. 我本想给她的生日开一个聚会作为惊喜，但没想到事与愿违：她啜泣着说所有人都忘记了她的生日。
A: ♣近  boomerang
A: ♣反  succeed 成功

Q:backhanded  ['bæk'hændid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 间接的，含沙射影的, 虚情假意的： indirect, devious, especially sarcastic
A: ♣例  a backhanded compliment 虚情假意的恭维话
A: ♣近  feigned, roundabout, sarcastic, hypocritical, two-faced, double-faced, left-handed
A: ♣反  forthright 直截了当的; artless, candid, genuine, honest, sincere 真挚的，真诚的

Q:backslide  [,bæk'slaid]
A: ♠考法1  vi. （情况等）倒退，固态萌发： to revert to a worse condition
A: ♣例  Keep these things in mind to help prevent you from backsliding. 牢记这些东西，他们能防止你旧病复犯。
A: ♣近  degenerate, lapse, recidivate, relapse, retrograde, retrogress
A: ♣近  advance, progress 进步，前进

Q:badger  ['bædʒə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 不断纠缠或骚扰： to harass or annoy persistently
A: ♣例  badger him into purchasing 不断地骚扰劝说他购买
A: ♣近  bait, plague

Q:badinage  [bædinɑ:ʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 打趣，善意的玩笑： playful repartee, banter
A: ♣例  the sophisticated badinage of the characters in plays by Oscar Wilde 奥斯卡?王尔德作品中意味深长的玩笑话
A: ♣近  banter, persiflage, repartee

Q:baffle  ['bæfl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 挫败，阻挠： to frustrate or check (a person) as by confusing or perplexing
A: ♣例  baffled by the language barrier 受到语言障碍的阻挠
A: ♣近  balk, beat, check, discomfit, foil, frustrate, thwart
A: ♣反  advance, cultivate, encourage, forward, foster, further, nurture, promote 促进，鼓舞
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使疑惑： to throw into a state of mental uncertainty
A: ♣例  I was baffled by many of the scientific terms used in the article. 这篇文章中各种学术词汇让我很困惑。
A: ♣近  befog, befuddle, bewilder, confound, discombobulate, disorient, maze, mystify, perplex, puzzle, vex
A: ♣反  clarify, elucidate 澄清，阐明
A: ♣派  baffling adj. 令人困惑的

Q:baffling  ['bæfliŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 令人疑惑的，难以理解的： making great mental demands; hard to comprehend or solve
A: ♣例  I was constantly ill, with a baffling array of symptoms. 我常常生病，而且有着一系列令人困惑的症状。
A: ♣近  befuddling, bewildering, confounding, confusing, enigmatic, puzzling, perplexing
A: ♣反  apparent, distinct, evident, lucid, manifest, obvious, patent, pellucid, perspicuous, plain, transparent 明确的，明显的

Q:bait  [beit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 逗弄，激怒： to persecute or exasperate with unjust, malicious, or persistent attacks
A: ♣例  bait him with gibes about his humble origin 取笑他的平凡出身以烦扰他
A: ♣近  badger, annoy, harass, heckle
A: ♣反  appease, pacify, mollify, disarm 平息，使缓和
A: ♠考法2  v.引诱： to lead away from a usual or proper course by offering some pleasure or advantage
A: ♣例  the investment scheme baits the greedy and the unscrupulous 这份投资计划吸引贪婪者和轻信者上钩
A: ♣近  allure, decoy, entice, seduce
A: ♠考法3  n. 诱饵： something (as food) used in luring especially to a hook or trap
A: ♣例  The squad leader has finally realized that his team was a bait. 队长终于意识到他的队伍是一个诱饵
A: ♣近  allurement, snare, trap, temptation

Q:bale  [beil]
A: ♠考法1  n. 痛苦，悲哀： woe, sorrow
A: ♣例  relieve spirit from the bale 从悲痛中解脱
A: ♣近  misery, suffering, anguish, grief
A: ♣反  joy 快乐

Q:baleful  ['beilful]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有害的： harmful or malignant in intent or effect
A: ♣例  a policy with baleful effects 一个带来不良后果的政策
A: ♣近  harmful, pernicious, detrimental
A: ♣反  beneficent 有益的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 凶兆的： foreboding or threatening evil
A: ♣例  a baleful look 面露凶色
A: ♣近  direful, doomy, ominous, ill-boding, minatory, portentous, sinister
A: ♣反  unthreatening 不构成威胁的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 致命的： likely to cause or capable of causing death
A: ♣例  a medicine that is beneficial in small doses but baleful in large 是药三分毒
A: ♣近  deadly, fatal, lethal
A: ♣反  healthy, wholesome 有益健康的

Q:balk  [bɔ:k]
A: ♠考法1  v. 阻碍： to check or stop by or as if by an obstacle
A: ♣近  circumvent, frustrate, foil, thwart
A: ♣反  advance, forward, foster, nurture, promote 推进
A: ♠考法2  v. 不愿接受，拒绝： to show unwillingness to accept, do, engage in, or agree to
A: ♣例  She balked at the very idea of compromise. 她固执地拒绝妥协的想法
A: ♣近  decline, refuse, spurn, repudiate, turn down
A: ♣反  accept, approve 同意
A: ♣派  balky adj. 倔强的

Q:balky  ['bɔ:ki]

A: ♣例  a balky mule 犟骡子
A: ♣近  contumacious, defiant, perverse, intractable, obstreperous, refractory, unruly, untoward, wayward. willful
A: ♣反  compliant, docile, subdued, submissive, tractable 顺从的

Q:ballad  ['bæləd]
A: ♠考法1  n. 由简单诗节和叠句组成的民歌： a narrative poem, often of folk origin and intended to be sung, consisting of simple stanzas and usually having a refrain
A: ♣例  a haunting ballad about loneliness 一段有关寂寞的缭绕于心的民谣
A: ♣近  ditty, jingle, lyric, vocal

Q:balloon  [bə'lu:n]

A: ♣近  inflate, escalate, expand, burgeon, mushroom, snowball
A: ♣反  decrease, taper, dwindle, diminish, recede, wane 减少

Q:balm  [bɑ:m]

A: ♣例  Friendship is the finest balm in need. 危难关头，友情是最好的安慰
A: ♣反  irritant 刺激物
A: ♣派  balmy adj. 柔和的
A: ♠考法2  n. 香气： a sweet or pleasant smell
A: ♣例  The balm of the restaurant's backyard garden enhances the aura of romance. 餐馆后院传来的阵阵芳香增加了浪漫的情调
A: ♣近  aroma, fragrance, incense, perfume, redolence
A: ♣反  fetor, malodor, stench, stink 恶臭

Q:banal  [bə'nɑ:l]

A: ♣反  novel, innovative, arresting 新颖的
A: ♣派  banality n. 陈腐

Q:bane  [bein]
A: ♠考法1  n. 祸根：a source of harm or ruin
A: ♣例  Drinking was the bane of his life. 饮酒是他一生的祸根
A: ♣近  affliction, curse, nemesis, scourge
A: ♣反  blessing, boon, felicity, windfall 福根
A: ♠考法2  n. 有害的物质：a substance that by chemical action can kill or injure a living thing
A: ♣例  a plant that is believed to be the bane of the wolf 一种被认为对狼有毒害作用的植物
A: ♣近  toxic, toxin, venom
A: ♣派  baneful adj. 有害的

Q:banish  ['bæniʃ]

A: ♣例  Since the diplomatic relation between the two nations has been broken, diplomats were all banished. 随着两国外交关系的断裂，所有的外交人员都被驱逐出境

A: ♣反  repatriate 遣返
A: ♠考法2  vt. 赶出：to drive or force out

A: ♣派  banishment n. 驱逐

Q:banter  ['bæntə]

A: ♣近  badinage, persiflage, repartee

Q:barb  [bɑ:b]

A: ♣例  delivered one last barb to his ex-girlfriend as he stalked away 在他转身离去之前，给他前女友留下了最后一句尖锐的批评
A: ♣近  affront, criticism, offense, outrage, sarcasm, slight
A: ♣反  praise, applause, compliment 称赞

Q:barbarous  ['bɑ:bərəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 野蛮的，凶残的： mercilessly harsh or cruel
A: ♣例  insulted by barbarous language 被粗暴的语言侵犯
A: ♣近  brutal, atrocious, fiendish, heartless, savage, truculent, vicious
A: ♣反  merciful, benevolent , humane, sympathetic 仁慈的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 未开化的： uncivilized
A: ♣例  some barbarous behaviors such as eating with your fingers 一些没有教养的举止，比如直接用手拿东西吃
A: ♣近  wild, uncultivated
A: ♣反  civilized, decent, decorous 举止得体的

Q:barefaced  ['bεəfeist]

A: ♣例  a barefaced lie 一个公然的谎言
A: ♣近  apparent, plain, bald, evident, manifest, obvious, perspicuous
A: ♣反  secret, furtive, clandestine, surreptitious 秘密的

Q:bargain  ['bɑ:ɡin]
A: ♠考法1  n. 协议： an agreement between parties settling what each gives or receives in a transaction
A: ♣例  They made a bargain that one would help the other next week. 他们达成了一项协议：下周其中一人将帮助另外一人
A: ♣近  accord, compact, contract, covenant, deal, pact, settlement
A: ♠考法2  vi. 讨价还价： to negotiate over the terms of a purchase
A: ♣例  bargain over the price 讨价还价
A: ♣近  haggle, negotiate

Q:baroque  [bə'rɔk]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 华丽装饰的，过分雕琢，复杂的： characterized by extravagance, complexity, or flamboyance
A: ♣例  a baroque prose 一篇辞藻华丽的散文
A: ♣近  byzantine, complicated, convoluted, elaborate, fancy, intricate, knotty, labyrinthine, lavish, tangled
A: ♣反  austere, plain, simple 朴实无华的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （程度）过分的： going beyond a normal or acceptable limit in degree or amount
A: ♣例  Eventually even the movie seems bored by its baroque violence. 到最后这电影也因为其中过度的暴力元素而显得让人厌烦
A: ♣近  exorbitant, extravagant, lavish, overdue
A: ♣反  moderate, modest, temperate 适度的

Q:barrage  ['bærɑ:ʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 弹幕： a heavy curtain of artillery fire directed in front of friendly troops to protect them
A: ♣例  Troops are advancing under the shield of barrage. 部队在弹幕的掩护下前进
A: ♣近  bombardment, fusillade
A: ♠考法2  n. 有压倒之势的、集中的倾泻（如言语）： an overwhelming, concentrated outpouring, as of words
A: ♣例  The announcement was met with a barrage of criticism and protests. 此公告一出，批评和抗议的声音四起
A: ♣近  salvo, hail, cannonade, shower, storm, volley
A: ♠考法3  v. （同时）袭来： to attack with a rapid or overwhelming outpouring of many things at once
A: ♣例  The athlete was barraged with requests for an autograph. 请求运动员签名的呼声如排山倒海般袭来
A: ♣近  bomb

Q:barren  ['bærən]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不育的： incapable of producing offspring
A: ♣例  a poor, barren woman 一名可怜的不孕女子
A: ♣近  fruitless, impotent, infertile, effete
A: ♣反  prolific, fecund 多产的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不产生结果的，无效的： producing no results; unproductive
A: ♣例  That line of investigation proved barren, so the police tried other avenues. 那个方向的调查已经被证明是没有结果的了，所以警察开始尝试其他的途径
A: ♣近  bootless, ineffective, inefficacious, unavailing, vain
A: ♣反  effective, successful, productive, virtuous 有效的，成功的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 贫瘠的： deficient in production of vegetation and especially crops
A: ♣例  barren deserts and wastelands 贫瘠的沙漠和荒野
A: ♣近  desolate, impoverished, waste
A: ♣反  arable, fruitful, luxuriant, verdant 富饶繁茂的
A: ♠考法4  adj. 极度匮乏的： utterly lacking in something needed, wanted, or expected
A: ♣例  Their proposal for revitalizing the downtown business district is utterly barren of practical methods. 他们意图重振中心商业区的计划缺乏能够起效的方法
A: ♣近  bare, bereft, destitute, void
A: ♣反  filled, flush, fraught, full, replete, rife 充沛的

Q:barricade  [,bæri'keid]

A: ♣近  fence, hedge, wall, barrier, obstacle, blockade, obstruction
A: ♠考法2  v. 用障碍物阻止通过： to prevent access to by means of a barricade
A: ♣例  streets have been barricaded by authorities 街道被当局封锁了
A: ♣近  bar, check, hinder, impede, obstruct, wall off
A: ♣反  permit 允许

Q:barter  ['bɑ:tə]

Q:bash  [bæʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 猛击： a forceful blow
A: ♣例  He has not been the same ever since he received that bash on his head. 自从他脑袋被别人打了之后，他就变得大不一样。
A: ♣近  bang, bat, beat, crack, hit, knock, lash, poke, pound, punch, slam, slap, smash, spank, stroke, swat
A: ♠考法2  vt. 攻击，用力击打： to strike violently and often repeatedly
A: ♣例  The angry child kept bashing her toy with a hammer until it broke. 愤怒的小孩用锤子不断地敲击她的玩具，直到它彻底被破坏。
A: ♣近  baste, batter, buffet, hammer, lace, maul, nail, smash, strike
A: ♠考法3  vt. 抨击，严厉批评： to criticize harshly and usually publicly
A: ♣例  In all of talk radio no other host seems to enjoy bashing liberals as much as he does. 在电台节目再没有像他一样热衷于抨击自由主义者的主持人了。
A: ♣近  abuse, assail, belabor, blast, castigate, excoriate, lambaste, savage, scathe, slam, trash, vituperate
A: ♣反  acclaim, commend, compliment, hail, laud, praise 表扬，称赞

Q:bask  [bɑ:sk]

A: ♣反  drudge, grind, hustle, labor, moil, plod, slave, sweat, toil, travail, work （辛苦地）干活，工作

A: ♣近  band, body, cluster, party

Q:bathetic  [bə'θetik]

A: ♣派  bathos n. 平凡的事物

Q:bawdy  ['bɔ:di]

A: ♣近  indebted, obligated, obliged

Q:behoove  [bi'hu:v]

A: ♣例  It behooves you at least to try. 你至少也应该尝试一下。
A: ♣近  befit, beseem, fit, serve, suite

Q:beige  [beiʒ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 缺乏特征的： lacking distinction
A: ♣例  Some food critics have dismissed that chef's version of French cuisine as beige and boring. 一些美食评论家认为那名厨师所做的法国菜平凡无奇，令人厌倦。
A: ♣近  characterless, faceless, featureless, indistinctive, neutral, noncommital, vanilla
A: ♣反  diagnostic, discriminating, distinct, distinctive, distinguishing, identifying, peculiar, typical 特征的

Q:belabor  [bi'lebə]
A: ♠考法1  v.（当众）严厉批评： to criticize harshly and usually publicly
A: ♣例  It’s not wise to belabor other people's flaws when you're hardly perfect yourself. 如果你自己还做不到完美，去指责他人是不明智的
A: ♣近  beat, baste, batter, excoriate, lambaste, abuse, assail, vituperate, scathe
A: ♣反  applaud, extol, eulogize, endorse, acclaim 赞扬
A: ♠考法2  v. 就…作过度的说明，喋喋不休： to explain or insist on excessively
A: ♣例  belabor the obvious 就显而易见的问题喋喋不休
A: ♣近  dwell on, harp on
A: ♣反  disregard, omit, ignore, neglect, slight, slur over 忽略

Q:beleaguer  [bi'li:ɡə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 包围，围攻： to surround (as a fortified place) with armed forces for the purpose of capturing or preventing commerce and communication
A: ♣例  beleaguered the castle for months 围攻堡垒长达数月
A: ♣近  siege, besiege, invest, blockade
A: ♣反  retreat, withdraw 撤退
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使困扰，使烦恼，使消沉： trouble, harass, beset
A: ♣例  We are still beleaguered by the very problem. 我们仍然就为这一个问题而感到困扰
A: ♣近  annoy, harass, pester, plague, tease
A: ♣反  delight 使愉悦
A: ♣派  beleaguering adj. 扰人的

Q:belie  [bi'lai]
A: ♠考法1  v. 错误地描述；误述： to picture falsely; misrepresent
A: ♣例  The report belied the real severity of the aftermath. 这个报道错误地评价了后果的严重性
A: ♣近  misrepresent, falsify
A: ♣反  betray, reveal 表明，暴露，揭露（伪装）
A: ♠考法2  v. 证明…为假： to show (something) to be false or wrong
A: ♣例  Practical experience belies this theory. 实践证明这个理论是错误的
A: ♣近  debunk, discredit, refute, shoot down
A: ♣反  attest, confirm, validate, verify 证实
A: ♠考法3  v. 掩饰： to keep secret or shut off from view
A: ♣例  Security Council issued false assurances that belied the true gravity of the situation. 安理会发布了不真实的承诺，掩盖了局势的严重性
A: ♣近  conceal, curtain, disguise, mask
A: ♣反  disclose, expose 揭露
A: ♠考法4  v. 与…相对立；与…相矛盾： to be counter to; contradict
A: ♣例  At first glance, life at the boarding school seemed to belie all the bad things I had heard about it. 乍看之下，寄宿学校的生活似乎不同于我所听说的有关它的糟糕情形
A: ♣近  contradict, contravene
A: ♣反  agree 与…相一致

Q:belligerence  [bi'lidʒərəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 好斗，好战： an aggressive or truculent attitude, atmosphere, or disposition
A: ♣例  Among the Native American tribes of the colonial period, the Iroquois were known for their belligerence. 在殖民时期的美洲土著部落中，易洛魁人因为他们的好战而著名。
A: ♣近  aggressiveness, assaultiveness, bellicosity, combativeness, contentiousness, disputatiousness, feistiness, militance, pugnacity, quarrelsomeness, scrappiness, truculence
A: ♣反  pacifism 爱好和平

Q:belligerent  [bi'lidʒərənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 好斗的，好战的： inclined to or exhibiting assertiveness, hostility, or combativeness
A: ♣例  The coach became quite belligerent and spit at an umpire after being thrown out of the game. 教练变得好斗起来，以至于在被罚出场外之后转身向裁判吐口水。
A: ♣近  aggressive, agonistic, assaultive, bellicose, combative, contentious, disputatious, feisty, gladiatorial, militant, pugnacious, quarrelsome, truculent, warlike
A: ♣反  dove, pacific, peaceful 爱好和平的
A: ♣派  belligerence n. 好战，好斗

Q:bellwether  ['bel,weðə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 领导者，带头人： one that takes the lead or initiative
A: ♣例  Paris is a bellwether of the fashion industry. 巴黎是一座引领时尚潮流的都市
A: ♣近  leader, pacemaker, pilot, trendsetter
A: ♣反  follower, disciple, imitator 跟随者，弟子，模仿者

Q:beneficent  [bi'nefisənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 仁慈的，好慈善的： characterized by or performing acts of kindness or charity
A: ♣例  beneficent couple who are regular volunteers at an orphan 一对在孤儿院做义工的慈善的夫妇
A: ♣近  kind, altruistic, benevolent, philanthropic, benign, compassionate, sympathetic
A: ♣反  atrocious, barbarous, truculent, vicious 残忍的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （对个人或社会）有益的： promoting or contributing to personal or social well-being
A: ♣例  the beneficent effect of sunshine 日光浴的益处
A: ♣近  helpful, advantageous, favorable, kindly, profitable, salutary
A: ♣反  detrimental, harmful, noxious, toxic 有害的
A: ♣派  beneficently adv. 仁慈地

Q:benign  [bi'nain]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 好心的，仁慈的：showing kindness and gentleness
A: ♣例  a benign coach 一名仁慈的教练
A: ♣近  beneficent, gentle, kind
A: ♣反  abrasive, caustic, coarse, hard, harsh, rough, scathing, stern 粗暴的，严厉的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无害的： not causing or being capable of causing injury or hurt
A: ♣例  Don’t worry; his eccentricities are entirely benign. 别担心，他那些古怪行为不会给人带来伤害
A: ♣近  harmless, innocent, innocuous, inoffensive
A: ♣反  baleful, deleterious, detrimental, harmful, injurious, pernicious 有害的

Q:berate  [bi'reit]

A: ♣例  He berated them in public. 他公开谴责他们
A: ♣近  castigate, flay, lambaste, scold, rail, upbraid, reproach, reprimand
A: ♣反  commend, compliment, praise 表扬，赞颂

Q:beseech  [bi'si:tʃ]

A: ♣例  They besought the military to act immediately. 他们恳求军方立即采取行动
A: ♣近  appeal, conjure, entreat, implore, petition, plead, supplicate
A: ♣反  demand （依据权力等）要求

Q:beset  [bi'set]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使苦恼，骚扰： to cause persistent suffering to
A: ♣例  He has been beset by a lack of self-confidence virtually his entire life. 事实上他的一生都在被缺乏自信所困扰。
A: ♣近  agonize, anguish, bedevil, besiege, curse, excruciate, harrow, persecute, plague, rack, torment, torture
A: ♣反  comfort, console, solace, soothe 安抚，安慰
A: ♠考法2  vt. 攻击，袭击： to set upon
A: ♣例  The settlers were beset by savages. 定居者们遭到了野蛮人的袭击。‖The unsuspecting tourists were suddenly beset by robbers. 丝毫没有准备的游客遭到了歹徒的突然袭击。
A: ♣近  assail, assault, attack, charge, raid, rush, storm, strike, set on
A: ♣反  defend, guard, protect, shield 防御，守卫

Q:besmirch  [bi'smə:tʃ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 弄脏，弄污： to make dirty; soil
A: ♣例  besmirched the white bed sheets with their dirty hands 用他们的脏手把白床单弄脏了
A: ♣近  foul, smirch, smudge, taint
A: ♣反  clean, cleanse 清洁
A: ♠考法2  v. 诽谤，玷污： to detract from the honor or luster of
A: ♣例  besmirch your reputation by fabricating scandals 通过捏造丑闻来玷污你的名声
A: ♣近  defile, smear, soil, stain
A: ♣反  honor 授予荣誉

Q:bewitching  [bi'witʃiŋ]

A: ♣例  bewitching woman who has never lacked for suitors 一个从不缺乏追求者的迷人女子
A: ♣近  alluring, appealing, attractive, captivating, charismatic, enchanting, engaging, entrancing, glamorous, luring, magnetic, seductive
A: ♣反  repellent, repelling, repugnant, repulsive, revolting 令人反感的

Q:bifurcate  ['baifəkeit]

A: ♣近  divide, diverge, fork
A: ♣反  coalesce 联合 converge 汇合

Q:bigot  ['biɡət]

A: ♣例  He is a bigot, or “a slave of dogma”. 一个固执己见的人，换而言之就是——教条主义的奴隶
A: ♣近  dogmatist, partisan
A: ♣反  depreciator, disparager 贬低他人的人
A: ♣派  bigoted 固执己见的

Q:blackmail  ['blækmeil]

A: ♣例  It looks like these pornographic pictures were being used for blackmail. 看起来有人用这些不雅照进行敲诈勒索。
A: ♣近  extortion

Q:bland  [blænd]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 味道平淡的： not irritating or stimulating; soothing
A: ♣例  stick to bland diet to lose weight 坚持清淡的饮食以减肥
A: ♣近  mild, light, soft, soothing, tender
A: ♣反  pungent, tangy, zesty 味道刺激的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无趣的： dull, insipid
A: ♣例  a bland story with na?ve plot 一个情节幼稚的无聊故事
A: ♣近  banal, sapless, insipid
A: ♣反  riveting, enchanting 诱人的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 温和的，和蔼的： not harsh or stern especially in nature or effect
A: ♣例  bland food that was good for babies and invalids 对婴儿和病患有益的温和的食物
A: ♣近  balmy, benign, bland, delicate, mellow, nonabrasive
A: ♣反  abrasive, caustic, coarse, hard, harsh, rough, scathing, stern 刺激性的

Q:blandishment  ['blændiʃmənt]

A: ♣近  flattery, adulation

Q:blase  ['bla:zei]

A: ♣例  Years of extravagance has made him totally blasé. 长期的奢华生活已使他彻底麻木
A: ♣近  indifferent, jaded, unconcerned, world-weary
A: ♣反  zealous, fanatic 狂热的 curious 好奇的


Q:blast  [blæst]
A: ♠考法1  n. 爆炸： an explosion or violent detonation
A: ♣例  blast wave of a nuclear bomb 原子弹的冲击波
A: ♣近  burst, detonation, eruption, outburst
A: ♣反  implosion 向内爆裂
A: ♠考法2  n. 一阵猛烈的强风： a violent gust of wind
A: ♣例  blasts of bleak air 阵阵阴风
A: ♣近  blow, flurry
A: ♠考法3  n. 巨响： a loud explosive sound
A: ♣例  a sharp blast of the horn startled the other driver 一声尖锐刺耳的喇叭声惊吓到了另一名司机
A: ♣近  bang, boom, thunderclap
A: ♣反  murmur, whisper 轻言轻语
A: ♠考法4  vt. 炸裂，爆破： to cause to break open or into pieces by or as if by an explosive
A: ♣例  The highway engineers will have to blast that hill in order to put a road through here. 为了建设一条公路，道路工程师们必须对那座山进行爆破
A: ♣近  demolish, explode, smash, blow up
A: ♠考法5  vt. 斥责，抨击： to criticize harshly and usually publicly
A: ♣例  blasted the new governor for every little misstep 就每一个小的失误都要抨击新的执政官
A: ♣近  abuse, assail, belabor, castigate, lambaste, scathe, vituperate

Q:blatant  ['bleitənt]

A: ♣近  boisterous, clamant, clamorous, vociferous
A: ♣反  quiet, reticent, taciturn 沉默少语的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （让人生厌地）惹人注目的： very noticeable especially for being incorrect or bad
A: ♣例  a blatant lie 明目张胆的谎言 || a blatant error in simple addition 简单的加法运算中的一个明显错误
A: ♣近  conspicuous, flagrant, glaring, patent, striking, pronounced
A: ♣反  subtle, unimpressive 细微的

Q:blazon  ['bleizən]

A: ♠考法2  v. 修饰，装扮： to make more attractive by adding something that is beautiful or becoming
A: ♣例  The university’s dormitory has been blazoned with banners celebrating graduation. 学校宿舍被那些庆祝毕业的横幅所装点
A: ♣近  adorn, bedeck, embellish, garnish
A: ♣反  blemish, deface, mar, spoil 损害，破坏

Q:blemish  ['blemiʃ]

A: ♣近  blotch, defect, fault, flaw, mar, spot, scar
A: ♠考法2  v. 损害，降低： to reduce the soundness, effectiveness, or perfection of
A: ♣例  A scratch blemished the finish on the car. 一道刮痕破坏了车子表面的涂层
A: ♣近  break, disfigure, harm, hurt, impair, injure, spoil, vitiate
A: ♣反  fix, renovate, repair, revamp 翻新，维修
A: ♣派  unblemished adj. 纯净的

Q:blight  [blait]

A: ♣反  flourish 生长繁茂
A: ♠考法2  v. 损害： to impair the quality or effect of

A: ♣近  damage, deteriorate, harm, impair, mar, ruin
A: ♣派  blighted adj. 枯萎的，毁坏的

Q:bliss  [blis]

A: ♣近  heaven, paradise

A: ♣派  blissful adj. 带来幸运的

Q:blithe  [blaið]

Q:blueprint  ['blu:print]

A: ♣近  arrangement, design, plan, scheme

A: ♣近  arrange, budget, calculate, organize, frame, lay out

Q:bluff  [blʌf]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 直率的，（说话）直截了当的： being or characterized by direct, brief, and potentially rude speech or manner
A: ♣例  Frankly speaking, he is a bluff but good-hearted teacher. 老实说，这个老师说话很直率，但是心地善良。
A: ♣近  abrupt, brusque, crusty, curt, downright, forthright, snippy, straightforward, unceremonious
A: ♣反  circuitous, mealy-mouthed （说话）拐弯抹角的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 欺骗： to cause to believe what is untrue; deceive
A: ♣例  I successfully bluffed the interviewer into believing that I could really speak French and thus would be the perfect person to serve in the newspaper’s Paris bureau. 我成功地欺骗了面试官，让他相信我会法语，从而成为报社在巴黎办事处的不二人选。
A: ♣近  bamboozle, beguile, cozen, deceive, delude, dupe, fool, hoax, misguide, misinform, mislead, trick
A: ♣反  disabuse, disenchant, disillusion 使清醒

Q:blunder  ['blʌndə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 过失： a gross error or mistake resulting usually from stupidity, ignorance, or carelessness
A: ♣例  That's your second blunder today. 这是你今天犯的第二个低级错误了
A: ♣近  mistake, gaffe, lapse, error
A: ♠考法2  v. 在…方面犯了很愚蠢且通常很严重的错误；糟蹋： to make a stupid, usually serious error in; botch
A: ♣近  screw up, mess up
A: ♠考法3  v. 蹒跚：to move unsteadily or confusedly
A: ♣例  Without my glasses I blundered into the wrong room.因为没戴眼镜，所以我蹒跚地走入了错误的房间
A: ♣近  stumble, falter, limp, plod
A: ♣派  blundering adj. 蹒跚行走的

Q:blunt  [blʌnt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使变钝：to make less sharp or definite
A: ♣近  dull, deaden, hebetate, benumb, enfeeble, attenuate
A: ♣反  whet, sharpen 磨尖
A: ♠考法2  vt. 减弱（力度等）：to reduce or weaken in strength or feeling
A: ♣例  The abrupt music blunted the effect of the movie's final tragic scene. 突兀的音乐让电影结束时悲剧场景的氛围大打折扣
A: ♣近  dampen, deaden
A: ♠考法3  adj. 直率的：being or characterized by direct, brief, and potentially rude speech or manner
A: ♣例  He values honesty and is quite blunt about telling people what he doesn't like about them. 他重视诚实，经常直率地告诉别人他们何处使他不满
A: ♣近  abrupt, bluff, brusque, curt, gruff
A: ♣反  circuitous, mealy-mouthed 拐弯抹角的

Q:blur  [blə:]
A: ♠考法1  v. （使）变得朦胧，（使）变得不清楚： to (cause sth. to) become vague or indistinct
A: ♣例  Sorrowful tears blurred her eyes. 悲伤的眼泪模糊了她的双眼
A: ♣近  shroud, becloud, befog, obscure
A: ♣反  clear 使清晰
A: ♠考法2  v. 使不易理解： to make (something) unclear to the understanding
A: ♣例  An article for the layman that blurs the distinction between the two kinds of cholesterol. 一篇针对业余读者的文章把两种胆固醇的区别弄得模糊不清
A: ♣近  obfuscate
A: ♣反  clarify, illuminate 阐明，说清楚
A: ♣派  blurring adj. 朦胧的

Q:blurt  [blə:t]

A: ♣例  blurt out the secret 脱口说出了秘密
A: ♣近  burst, bolt, ejaculate, cry out
A: ♣反  muffle, mute 使缄默

Q:bluster  ['blʌstə]
A: ♠考法1  v. 狂妄自大地大声说： to speak in a loudly arrogant or bullying manner
A: ♣例  He was blustering alone in the meeting, which triggered wide dissatisfaction. 他一人在会议上夸夸其谈，引得众人不满。
A: ♣近  roar, clamor, bluster, rattle
A: ♣反  whisper 小声嘀咕
A: ♠考法2  n. 大声吹嘘或恐吓： loudly boastful or threatening speech
A: ♣近  grandiloquence, braggadocio
A: ♠考法3  n. 喧闹的状态： a state of noisy, confused activity
A: ♣例  a mayor who got things done without a lot of bluster 一个能把事情低调解决的市长
A: ♣近  disturbance, pandemonium, tumult, turmoil
A: ♣派  blustering adj. 大吵大闹的

Q:boggle  ['bɔɡl]
A: ♠考法1  v. 因为怀疑、恐惧而犹豫： to hesitate because of doubt, fear, or scruples
A: ♣例  boggle at the dilemma 身处困境而犹豫不决
A: ♣近  hesitate, falter, waver
A: ♠考法2  v. 笨拙地做： to make or do (something) in a clumsy or unskillful way
A: ♣例  She boggled her first effort to make Christmas cookies. 她第一次尝试圣诞蛋糕做得笨手笨脚
A: ♣近  botch, bungle.

Q:bogus  ['bəuɡəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 伪造的，假冒的： being such in appearance only and made or manufactured with the intention of committing fraud
A: ♣例  The evidence turned out to be completely bogus and the suspect may be innocent. 由于证据被发现是彻底伪造的，嫌犯很有可能是无辜的。
A: ♣近  counterfeit, fake, false, forged, inauthentic, phony , queer, sham, snide, spurious, unauthentic
A: ♣反  authentic, genuine, real, unfaked, bona fide 真实的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 虚伪的，做作的： lacking in natural or spontaneous quality
A: ♣例  There was often a lot of bogus conviviality at the company’s parties. 公司的聚会上往往有着虚伪的欢乐。
A: ♣近  affected, assumed, contrived, factitious, feigned, plastic, pretended, pseudo, simulated, unnatural
A: ♣反  artless, natural, spontaneous, unaffected, uncontrived, unfeigned, unforced 真诚的，不虚伪的

Q:boisterous  ['bɔistərəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 喧嚷的，吵闹的： noisily turbulent
A: ♣例  a boisterous queue in front of the pavilion 场馆前喧闹的队伍 || boisterous mirth. 喧闹的欢笑
A: ♣近  rowdy, vociferous, blatant, clamorous, raucous, rambunctious
A: ♣反  quiet, sedate 安静的
A: ♣派  boisterousness n. 喧闹

Q:bolster  ['bəulstə]

A: ♣例  pillows that bolster the building 支撑房屋的柱子
A: ♣近  brace, buttress, bear, sustain, undergird, underpin, uphold, prop up

A: ♣例  news that bolsters the morale of the troops鼓舞军队士气的消息
A: ♣近  buoy, reinforce
A: ♣反  dampen 泼冷水

Q:bombast  ['bɔmbæst]

A: ♣例  “Their eloquence is all bombast”, said Charles Kingsley. “他们的雄辩是虚张声势”，查理斯?金斯利如此说道

A: ♣反  understatement 保守的观点
A: ♣派  bombastic adj. 夸大的

Q:bonhomie  ['bɔnɔmi:]

A: ♣近  affability, amiability, geniality
A: ♣派  bonhomous adj. 和蔼的

Q:boo  [bu:]

A: ♣例  boo the actor off the stage 把演员嘘下舞台
A: ♣近  jeer, scorn
A: ♣反  applaud 鼓掌

Q:boon  [bu:n]

A: ♣例  The new solar battery booster is a boon for photographers. 这个光伏充电器是摄影家的福音
A: ♣近  gift, benevolence, present, windfall
A: ♣反  misfortune, scourge 灾祸
A: ♠考法2  adj. 喜欢集体行动的： likely to seek or enjoy the company of others
A: ♣近  convivial, extroverted, gregarious, social, outgoing
A: ♣反  reclusive 隐居

Q:boor  [buə]

A: ♣例  acting like boor 表现得很粗鲁
A: ♣近  peasant, barbarian, buffoon
A: ♣反  sentimentalist 多愁善感的人

Q:bootless  ['bu:tlis]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无用的： useless, unprofitable, futile
A: ♣例  The meeting turns out to be a bootless attempt. 这个会议被证明是一次徒劳的尝试
A: ♣近  barren, ineffective, futile, abortive, fruitless, vain
A: ♣反  worthy, virtuous有价值的

Q:bore  [bɔ:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 令人厌烦的人或事物： one that causes boredom
A: ♣例  For once, the graduation speaker wasn't a real bore. 就这一次毕业演讲者不是那么令人厌倦。
A: ♣近  drip, droner, snoozer, yawner
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使厌倦，使厌烦： to make weary by being dull, repetitive, or tedious
A: ♣例  The professor's lifeless and unimaginative teaching style bored the students to death. 教授毫无生气和想象力的说教方式让学生厌倦至极。
A: ♣近  jade, pall, tire, weary
A: ♣反  absorb, engage, engross, enthrall, fascinate, grip, interest, intrigue 使充满兴趣，使全神贯注
A: ♣派  boring adj. 令人厌烦的；boredom n. 厌烦，乏味

Q:bound  [baund]
A: ♠考法1  n. 界限： a real or imaginary point beyond which a person or thing cannot go
A: ♣例  The language in the novel really is beyond the bounds of decency. 这本小说的语言实在太不得体了
A: ♣近  environs, limits, confines, perimeter
A: ♣反  unrestrainedness 无边无际
A: ♠考法2  vt. 给…设置限制： to set limits or bounds to
A: ♣例  The country is bounded by river. 这个国家的领土以河水为界
A: ♣近  limit, demarcate, delimit
A: ♣反  enfranchise, free, liberate 释放
A: ♠考法3  adj. 投入的，坚定的：fully committed to achieving a goal
A: ♣例  I am bound and determined to write a novel before I turn 30. 我下定决心在30岁之前要写本小说
A: ♣近  resolute, determined, single-minded, bent on
A: ♣反  faltering, hesitant, vacillating, wavering, weak-kneed 动摇的
A: ♣派  boundless adj. 无边无际、无约束的

Q:boycott  ['bɔikɔt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 联合抵制，拒绝参与： to engage in a concerted refusal to have dealings with (as a person, store, or organization) usually to express disapproval or to force acceptance of certain conditions
A: ♣例  This brand is being boycotted for damaging environment. 因为破坏环境，这个品牌正在被抵制
A: ♣近  refuse
A: ♣反  patronize 经常光顾

Q:bracing  ['breisiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 令人振奋的，给人带来活力的： giving strength, vigor, or freshness
A: ♣例  a bracing news from the frontline来自前线的振奋人心的消息
A: ♣近  invigorating, rejuvenating, reviving, stimulating
A: ♣反  vapid 乏味的
A: ♣派  brace v. 支持，使充满活力

Q:brake  [breik]
A: ♠考法1  v. 刹车： to cause to move or proceed at a less rapid pace
A: ♣例  A seagull swooped down in front of her car, causing her to slam on the brakes. 一只海鸥飞到车窗前，她猛踩刹车。
A: ♣近  decelerate, retard, slacken
A: ♣反  accelerate, hasten, rush, speed up 加速

Q:brandish  ['brændiʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （带有威胁性地）挥舞： to shake or wave (as a weapon) menacingly
A: ♣例  I could see that the suspect was brandishing a knife and was in no way inclined to surrender. 我可以看到嫌犯在挥舞着一把刀，完全没有要投降的倾向。
A: ♣近  shake, swing, wave
A: ♣反  drop 放下（武器等）

Q:brash  [bræʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 愚勇的，鲁莽的： foolishly adventurous or bold
A: ♣例  that brash motorcyclist likes to show off by riding on only one wheel 那个鲁莽的摩托车手喜欢炫耀单轮骑车
A: ♣近  audacious, brassy, daredevil, madcap, reckless, temerarious
A: ♣反  circumspect, guarded, heedful, prudent, wary
A: ♠考法2  adj. 缺乏判断力的，不明智的： showing poor judgment especially in personal relationships or social situations
A: ♣例  He was reprimanded for his brash comments to the media about the team's coaching staff. 他因对媒体说了一些有关教练组的不明智的评论被指责。
A: ♣近  imprudent, injudicious, tactless, undiplomatic
A: ♣反  advisable, discreet, tactful 明智的

Q:brassy  ['brɑ:si]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 厚脸皮的，不知羞耻的： displaying or marked by rude boldness
A: ♣例  brassy reporters 厚颜无耻的记者
A: ♣近  audacious, bold-faced, brazen, impertinent, impudent, insolent
A: ♣反  diffident, unassertive, retiring, timid 羞怯的，谦逊的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 华而不实地炫耀的： cheap and showy; flashy
A: ♣反  furtive 隐秘的

Q:bravado  [brə'vɑ:dəu]
A: ♠考法1  n. 假装勇敢： a pretense of bravery
A: ♣例  I remembered his youthful bravado. 我还记得他的年少鲁莽。
A: ♠考法2  n. 虚张声势： blustering swaggering conduct
A: ♣例  strove to prevent our courage from turning into bravado 努力阻止我们的勇气蜕变成虚张声势

Q:bravura  [brə'vjuərə]
A: ♠考法1  adj/n. 优秀演技： brilliant technique or style in performance
A: ♣例  a truly bravura performance of the ballet 一场极其精彩的芭蕾舞演出
A: ♣近  adroit, artful, dexterous, masterful, virtuoso
A: ♣反  amateur, artless, unprofessional, unskillful

Q:brazen  ['breizən]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 蛮横大胆的，厚颜无耻的： marked by contemptuous boldness
A: ♣例  a brazen disregard for the rules 蛮横大胆的对规则漠视
A: ♣近  bold-faced, impertinent, impudent, insolent
A: ♣反  modest, self-effacing, diffident, retiring, timid 谦虚的，胆小的
A: ♠考法2  v. 大胆自信地去面对或从事： to face or undergo with bold self-assurance
A: ♣例  brazened out the crisis 沉着面对危机 || Some people prefer to brazen a thing out rather than admit defeat. 有的人不愿承认失败，而是宁肯厚着脸皮干下去。
A: ♣近  confront, outface, defy
A: ♣反  dodge, duck, shirk, sidestep 躲开，避谈

Q:breach  [bri:tʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 对伦理、法律准则的破坏： a breaking of a moral or legal code
A: ♣例  cheating on the exam was a serious breach of the military academy's honor code 考试作弊是对军校的荣誉准则的严重破坏
A: ♣近  malefaction, transgression, trespass, violation, wrongdoing
A: ♠考法2  v. 违背： to fail to keep
A: ♣例  a builder being sued by a homeowner for breaching a contract 建筑商因违约被房主起诉
A: ♣近  contravene, fracture, infringe, transgress
A: ♣反  obey, observe, comply with, conform to 遵守

Q:brevity  ['brevəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 简短，简洁： shortness of duration
A: ♣例  the best quality a graduation speech can have is brevity 好的毕业演讲必须简洁
A: ♣近  briefness, conciseness, shortness
A: ♣反  lengthiness 冗长
A: ♠考法2  n. 精炼： the quality or state of being marked by or using only few words to convey much meaning
A: ♣例  if brevity is the soul of wit, then that speech wasn't at all witty 如果说精炼是智慧的灵魂，那么演讲毫无智慧可言
A: ♣近  conciseness, pithiness, sententiousness, terseness
A: ♣反  diffuseness, long-windedness, prolixity, verbosity, wordiness 冗长啰嗦

Q:bribe  [braib]
A: ♠考法1  v. 贿赂，收买： to give something, such as money or a favor, offered or given to a person in a position of trust to influence that person's views or conduct.
A: ♣例  They bribed him to keep quiet about the incident. 他们收买他，希望其保持缄默。
A: ♣近  corrupt, pay off, square

Q:bridle  ['braidl]
A: ♠考法1  v. 限制： to keep from exceeding a desirable degree or level (as of expression)
A: ♣例  try to bridle your criticism next time so that it is helpful and not hurtful 下回控制好批评的语气，让其既顺耳又有益
A: ♣近  check, contain, curb, constrain, inhibit, regulate, restrain, tame, rein in

Q:brim  [brim]
A: ♠考法1  n. 边缘，边界： an upper or outer margin
A: ♣例  The brim of the teacup was banded with gold. 茶杯的边缘被镀上了金。
A: ♣近  borderline, bound, boundary, circumference, confines, edge, frame, fringe, margin, perimeter, periphery, skirt, verge
A: ♣反  center, core, heart, kernel 核心
A: ♠考法2  vi. 充满： to be or become full often to overflowing
A: ♣例  a secondhand bookstore that was brimming with bargains 一个到处都是减价品的二手书店‖eyes brimming with tears 饱含热泪的双眼
A: ♣近  bristle, bulge, burst, bustle, buzz, crawl, hum, overflow, pullulate, swarm, teem
A: ♣反  lack, need, want 缺少，缺乏
A: ♠考法3  vt. 加满，倒满： to put into (something) as much as can be held or contained
A: ♣例  He brimmed the glass with milk, and now I’m afraid that I will spill it. 他向杯子里倒了太多牛奶，我现在担心会不会洒出来。
A: ♣近  charge, cram, heap, jam, load, pack, stuff
A: ♣反  clear, empty, evacuate, vacate, void 清空

Q:brisk  [brisk]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 充满生机，有活力的： marked by much life, movement, or activity
A: ♣例  brisk and concise response 轻快而简洁的回答
A: ♣近  animated, bouncing, bustling, frisky, kinetic, sprightly, vibrant
A: ♣反  lackadaisical, languid, leaden, dead, inactive, lifeless 没有生机的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 刻薄的，言辞或方式尖刻辛辣的： keen or sharp in speech or manner
A: ♣例  a brisk greeting 尖刻的祝贺

Q:bristle  ['brisl]
A: ♠考法1  v. 怒不可遏，咆哮： to express one's anger usually violently
A: ♣例  bristle at the suggestion of gay marriage 对基情怒不可遏
A: ♣近  bluster, fulminate, rampage, fume, storm
A: ♣反  cower 畏缩
A: ♠考法2  v. 供应充足： to be copiously supplied
A: ♣例  starting a new life in New York city bristling with possibilities 在有着无限机会的纽约开始新生活
A: ♣近  brim, overflow, swarm, teem

Q:brittle  ['britl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 易碎的，脆弱的，易坏的： easily broken, cracked, or snapped
A: ♣例  as brittle as glass 像玻璃一样脆弱
A: ♣近  crispy, crumbly, flaky, friable
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不热心的，不真心的： lacking in friendliness or warmth of feeling
A: ♣例  a brittle apology that was anything but heartfelt 一个毫不真诚的道歉
A: ♣近  chilly, frigid, frosty, glacial, unfriendly, unsympathetic
A: ♣反  cordial, genial, warmhearted 热心的

Q:broach  [brəutʃ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 开启，启封： to open for the first time
A: ♣例  broach a keg of beer 开一小桶酒
A: ♣近  break
A: ♣反  close off 关闭
A: ♠考法2  v. 提出讨论： to present or bring forward for discussion
A: ♣例  broached the topic of plans for next year's parade 将明年的游行活动计划摆上讨论日程
A: ♣近  moot, place, raise, bring up

Q:bromide  ['brəumaid]

A: ♣例  a newspaper editorial offering the timeworn bromide that people should settle their differences peacefully 报纸编辑又拿出那一套呼吁和平解决纷争的陈词滥调
A: ♣近  banality, cliché, platitude, homily, truism, chestnut, shibboleth

Q:brook  [bruk]
A: ♠考法1  v. 忍受，容许： to stand for, tolerate
A: ♣例  brook no inference with his plans 不能容忍别人对于他计划的干涉
A: ♣近  abide, countenance, endure, stomach
A: ♠考法2  n. 小溪流： a natural stream of water normally smaller than and often tributary to a river: creek
A: ♣例  there are tiny fish and frogs in that brook 那条小溪里有小鱼还有小青蛙
A: ♣近  creek, rivulet

Q:browbeat  ['braubi:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 恐吓： to intimidate by a stern manner or arrogant speech: bully
A: ♣例  They would often browbeat the younger child until he cried. 他们总是把小朋友欺负到哭为止。
A: ♣近  blackjack, bulldoze, bully, cow, hector, intimidate

Q:bruit  [bru:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （未经证实地）散播消息： to make (as a piece of information) the subject of common talk without any authority or confirmation of accuracy
A: ♣例  It’s been bruited that… 到处传播……
A: ♣近  circulate, whisper, noise about
A: ♣反  keep secret 保持秘密

Q:buck  [bʌk]
A: ♠考法1  v. 阻止，反对： to refuse assent, to refuse to give in to
A: ♣例  buck the system 不遵守制度
A: ♣近  defy, fight, oppose, repel, withstand
A: ♣反  assent to, bow to, submit to, succumb to, surrender to, yield to 赞成，服从
A: ♠考法2  v. 转移，交接： to shift possession of (something) from one person to another
A: ♣例  buck each box to the next person in line 将每一个盒子传给队伍中的后一人
A: ♣近  transfer, hand over

Q:budge  [bʌdʒ]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 改变立场或态度： to alter a position or attitude
A: ♣例  Nothing would budge him. 没有什么可以改变他的主意。
A: ♠考法2  v. 停止抵抗，屈服： to cease resistance (as to another’s arguments, demands, or control)
A: ♣例  despite hours of intense pressure, she refused to budge from her position 尽管被连续施压几小时，她仍旧不肯改变立场
A: ♣近  concede, relent, submit, succumb, surrender
A: ♣反  resist 拒绝，抵抗

Q:bulge  [bʌldʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 凸起： a protuberant or swollen part or place
A: ♣例  bulging eyes 暴鱼眼
A: ♣近  convexity, projection, protrusion, protuberance, swell
A: ♣反  depressed region, cavity, dent, indent, recess, pit 凹陷，坑
A: ♠考法2  n. 比赛中的优势地位： the more favorable condition or position in a competition
A: ♣例  somehow she got the bulge on him in the race for the statehouse 她在州议员竞选中领先了他
A: ♣近  high ground, inside track, upper hand, whip hand
A: ♣反  disadvantage, drawback, handicap, liability 劣势
A: ♠考法3  n. 暴涨，突增，在数目或数量上突然而且是临时性的增加： a sudden, usually temporary increase in number or quantity
A: ♣例  The baby boom created a bulge in school enrollment. 生育高峰造成学校入学人数的暴涨。
A: ♠考法4  v. 充满： to be copiously supplied
A: ♣例  this guidebook to San Francisco positively bulges with useful information 这本对旧金山的指南包含了很多有用信息
A: ♣近  brim, bristle, overflow, swarm, teem

Q:bully  ['buli]
A: ♠考法1  n. 欺凌弱小者： a person who habitually treats others in an overbearing or intimidating manner
A: ♣例  they had to deal with the local bullies 他们要对付当地恶霸
A: ♣近  bullyboy, hector, intimidator
A: ♣反  underdog 被欺负的人
A: ♠考法2  adj. 最好的，最棒的： of the very best kind
A: ♣例  that's a bully idea for reviving the town's retail center 真是个重整镇上零售中心的好主意
A: ♣近  awesome, fabulous, fantastic, superb, marvelous, unsurpassed, excellent

Q:bumble  ['bʌmbl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 含糊不清地说，杂乱无章地说： to speak rapidly, inarticulately, and usually unintelligibly
A: ♣例  Overcome with stage fright, I could only bumble through the speech. 由于怯场，我结结巴巴地说完了演讲稿。
A: ♣近  babble, drivel, drool, gabble, gibber, jabber, prattle, sputter
A: ♣反  articulate, enunciate, pronounce 清楚地说
A: ♠考法2  vi. 笨拙地行动： to move, act, or proceed clumsily
A: ♣例  I sort of bumbled through the dance number, hoping that it would soon end. 我笨拙地跟着曲子舞蹈，心里指望着它快点结束。
A: ♣近  blunder, flounder, limp, lumber, plod, struggle, stumble, trudge
A: ♣反  coast, drift, glide, sail, slide （轻松地）行动，滑动

Q:bumptious  ['bʌmpʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 专横傲慢的，自以为是的： having a feeling of superiority that shows itself in an overbearing attitude
A: ♣例  a bumptious young man whose family wealth gave him a sense of entitlement 一个傲慢的富二代 || be bumptious over one’s inferiors 对下级态度傲慢
A: ♣近  assumptive, haughty, imperious, overweeing, peremptory, pompous, presuming, presumptuous, self-assertive, supercilious
A: ♣反  humble, modest, unarrogant, unpretentious 谦虚的，低调的

Q:bungle  ['bʌŋɡl]

A: ♣例  bungle a job 搞砸了一项工作
A: ♣近  boggle, bumble, fumble, mess up, screw up
A: ♣反  bring off 成功

Q:buoy  [bɔi]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使充满勇气和力量，使振作： to fill with courage or strength of purpose
A: ♣例  the sudden improvement in his health buoyed him up 身体的突然好转让他很振奋
A: ♣近  embolden, hearten, inspire, bear up, buck up
A: ♣反  daunt, discourage, dishearten, dispirit 使沮丧，泼冷水

Q:buoyant  ['bɔiənt]
