A: ♣例  a buoyant balloon 一个能浮起来的气球
A: ♣反  leaden 沉重的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 心情好的： having or showing a good mood or disposition
A: ♣例  in a buoyant mood 轻松快乐的心情
A: ♣近  blithe, chipper, eupeptic, lightsome, upbeat, winsome, effervescent
A: ♣反  dour, gloomy, morose, saturnine, sullen 沮丧的

Q:burgeon  ['bə:dʒən]
A: ♠考法1  v. 迅速成长扩大，蓬勃发展： to grow and expand rapidly; flourish
A: ♣例  My confidence began to burgeon. 我的信心开始迅速增强。
A: ♣近  accelerate, accumulate, balloon, boom, build up, escalate, mount, multiply, mushroom, proliferate,, roll up, snowball, wax, flourish, prosper
A: ♣反  wane, wither, waste away, subside, subdue 衰退

Q:burlesque  [bə:'lesk]
A: ♠考法1  v. 夸张滑稽地模仿以嘲弄他人的文学艺术作品，恶搞： to copy or exaggerate (someone or something) in order to make fun of
A: ♣例  burlesquing the teacher's nervous tic isn't very nice 恶搞老师紧张的痉挛不是好的行为
A: ♣近  caricature, imitate, mock, parody, spoof, travesty

Q:burnish  ['bə:niʃ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 擦亮，磨光： to make smooth or glossy usually by repeatedly applying surface pressure
A: ♣例  burnish the knife 磨光刀
A: ♣近  buff, polish, furbish, grind, smoothen

Q:bustle  ['bʌsl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 忙乱，喧闹： noisy, energetic, and often obtrusive activity
A: ♣例  the hustle and bustle of the big city 熙熙攘攘的大都市‖I couldn't concentrate in all the bustle of the student lounge. 学生休息室里过于嘈杂，我无法专心。
A: ♣近  bluster, coil, disturbance, furor, hurricane, pandemonium, stir, storm, tumult, turmoil, uproar, welter, whirl
A: ♣反  calm, hush, peace, quiet, rest, stillness, tranquillity 宁静，祥和；order 秩序
A: ♠考法2  vi. （快速地）行走： to move briskly and often ostentatiously
A: ♣例  the hostess bustled about, taking care of last-minute preparations for the party. 女主人四处走着，为聚会做最后的准备。
A: ♣近  blast, bolt, careen, career, dash, fly, hustle, rush, rustle, speed, whirl
A: ♣反  crawl, creep, lag, poke 缓慢行进

Q:buttress  ['bʌtris]
A: ♠考法1  n. 扶墙： a projecting structure for supporting or giving stability to a wall or building
A: ♣近  anchor, mainstay, pillar, reliance, standby
A: ♠考法2  vt. 提供支撑的证据或者信息： to provide evidence or information for (as a claim or idea)
A: ♣例  a mass of circumstantial evidence buttresses the prosecutor's case 大量支持起诉人案件的证据
A: ♣近  bolster, corroborate, reinforce, substantiate, shore up
A: ♣反  contravene, challenge 反对，质疑

Q:byzantine  [bi'zæntain]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 错综复杂的： complicated or secretive, having many parts or aspects that are usually interrelated
A: ♣例  a bill to simplify the byzantine tax structure 一项试图简化繁琐税收制度的提案
A: ♣近  convoluted, intricate, involved, labyrinthine, sophisticated, tangled
A: ♣反  straightforward, plain, simple, uncomplicated 直截了当的，不复杂的

Q:cache  [kæʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 囤货，藏货： a supply stored up and often hidden away
A: ♣例  maintain a cache of food in case of emergencies 保存着食物的隐藏处以防万一
A: ♣近  stash, stockpile, store, deposit, hoard, reserve
A: ♠考法2  v. 隐藏： to put into a hiding place
A: ♣例  cached the fugitive slaves in their cellar until they could make their way to Canada 将奴隶们藏匿在房间的地下室直到他们能够顺利逃去加拿大
A: ♣近  conceal, ensconce, secrete, squirrel away
A: ♣反  display, exhibit 展示

Q:cachet  ['kæʃei]
A: ♠考法1  n. 威望，声望： a mark or quality, as of distinction, individuality, or authenticity
A: ♣例  Federal courts have a certain cachet which state courts lack. 联邦法院拥有州立法院所不具备的威信。
A: ♣近  credit, distinction, esteem, homage, kudos, prestige
A: ♣反  infamy, notoriety 不好的名声

Q:cacophony  [kæ'kɔfəni]
A: ♠考法1  n. 刺耳的声音： loud, confused, and usually inharmonious sound
A: ♣例  the cacophony of a pet store full of animals 宠物商店里各种动物叽叽呱呱的声音
A: ♣近  blare, bluster, clamor, decibel, din, discordance, racket
A: ♣反  quiet, silence, still, stillness 安静

Q:cadge  [kædʒ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 乞讨，乞求： beg, sponge
A: ♣例  cadge a free cup of coffee 讨到一杯免费的咖啡
A: ♣反  earn 赚钱

Q:cajole  [kə'dʒəul]
A: ♠考法1  v. 哄骗： to urge with gentle and repeated appeals, teasing, or flattery; wheedle
A: ♣例  cajoled her into doing his laundry for him 哄骗她帮他洗衣服
A: ♣近  blandish, blarney, palaver, wheedle, soft-soap, sweet-talk

Q:calamity  [kə'læməti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 大灾难： a disastrous event marked by great loss and lasting distress and suffering
A: ♣例  This latest breakdown of the car is inconvenient, but not a calamity. 最近的汽车抛锚确实带来了不便，但还不是一场灾难。‖an economic calamity 金融风暴
A: ♣近  apocalypse, cataclysm, catastrophe, debacle, disaster, tragedy
A: ♣反  benediction, boon, felicity, godsend, manna, windfall 天赐好运，幸事

Q:calcify  ['kælsifai]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使僵化： to make inflexible or unchangeable
A: ♣例  a leg that calcified 一条麻木僵直的腿
A: ♣近  harden, obdurate, ossify
A: ♣反  make malleable, make pliant, make more flexible 使灵活

Q:calculated  ['kælkjuleitid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 经过计算（成败得失）的，经过深思熟虑的： engaged in, undertaken, or displayed after reckoning or estimating the statistical probability of success or failure
A: ♣例  He took a calculated risk and got in on the ground floor of the new enterprise. 他深思熟虑一番之后决定冒这个险，踏出了迈向新计划的第一步。
A: ♣近  advised, considered, deliberate, knowing, measured, reasoned, studied, thoughtful, weighed
A: ♣反  automatic, casual, instinctive, spontaneous, unstudied 随意的，不假思索的

Q:calibrate  ['kælibreit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 校准，调校： to check, adjust, or determine by comparison with a standard (the graduations of a quantitative measuring instrument)
A: ♣例  We need to calibrate the sextants navigation. 我们要为航行校准六分仪。
A: ♣近  adjust, align, gauge, graduate, measure
A: ♣派  calibration n. 校准

Q:calligraphy  [kə'liɡrəfi]
A: ♠考法1  n. （优美的）书法： artistic, stylized, or elegant handwriting or lettering
A: ♣例  she specializes in scrollwork with beautiful calligraphy 她很擅长花体字
A: ♣近  longhand, manuscript, penmanship, script

Q:callous  ['kæləs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无同情心的, 冷漠的： emotionally hardened; unfeeling
A: ♣例  a callous indifference to the suffering of others 对他人的痛苦的漠不关心
A: ♣近  affectless, uncharitable, unsparing, remorseless, indurate, ruthless
A: ♣反  sympathetic, compassionate, merciful, tender, warmhearted 有同情心的

Q:callow  ['kæləu]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 缺乏老练、不成熟的： lacking in adult experience or maturity
A: ♣例  callow young man 未经世事的年轻人
A: ♣近  green, immature, inexperienced, juvenile, unfledged, unripened, puerile
A: ♣反  adult, experienced, grown-up, mature, ripe 成熟的

Q:calumniate  [kə'lʌmnieit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 诽谤，造谣，中伤： to utter maliciously false statements, charges, or imputations about
A: ♣近  asperse, blacken, defame, libel, malign, smear, traduce, vilify
A: ♣反  vindicate 辩护
A: ♣派  calumnious 造谣的
A: ♣反  flattering 谄媚的
A: ♣派  calumny n. 诽谤、中伤： a false statement maliciously made to injure another's reputation
A: ♣反  approbation 嘉许

Q:camaraderie  [,kæmə'rɑ:dəri:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 友情： a spirit of friendly good-fellowship
A: ♣例  There is great camaraderie among the teammates. 组员之间有着深厚的情谊。
A: ♣近  brotherhood, comradeship, fellowship
A: ♣反  enmity 敌意

Q:cameo  ['kæmiəu]
A: ♠考法1  n. 栩栩如生的描绘： 一种简洁的、生动的描述或刻画： a brief, vivid portrayal or depiction
A: ♣例  a literary cameo 文学描写
A: ♠考法2  v. 客串： to make a brief but dramatic appearance, as in a film
A: ♣例  She cameoed as Anne Boleyn in A Man for All Seasons. 在所有季节的人中她客串安妮?波列思。

Q:camouflage  ['kæmuflɑ:ʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 伪装： behavior or artifice designed to deceive or hide
A: ♣例  the soldiers must wear protective jungle camouflage while on patrol 士兵们在巡逻的时候必须穿上迷彩服来保护自身安全
A: ♣近  costume, guise, cloak, dress up
A: ♣反  unmask 揭露

Q:canard  [kæ'nɑ:d]
A: ♠考法1  n. 谣传，误传： an unfounded or false, deliberately misleading story.
A: ♣例  it's a popular canard that the actress died under scandalous circumstances 有一种广泛的说法声称女演员死于绯闻的压力
A: ♣近  story, whisper

Q:candor  ['kændə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 坦白，直率，诚挚： unreserved, honest, or sincere expression
A: ♣例  the members of the rock band speak with candor about their recent squabbling 摇滚乐队成员对于他们最近的内讧直言不讳
A: ♣近  bluntness, forthrightness, frankness, unreservedness, straightforwardness
A: ♣反  artifice, mendacity, dissembling, dissimulation, indirection 谎言，不直接

Q:canny  ['kæni]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 精明的，聪明的： careful and shrewd, especially where one's own interests are concerned
A: ♣例  He is a canny card player who is good at psyching out his opponents. 他是一个善于琢磨对手心思的精明的扑克玩家。
A: ♣近  astute, clever, hardheaded, heady, knowing, savvy, sharp, shrewd, smart
A: ♣反  ignorant, unknowing 无知的；foolish, idiotic, imbecile, moronic, silly, thoughtless, witless 愚笨的

Q:canon  ['kænən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 正教，标准： a basis for judgment; a standard or criterion
A: ♣例  the canons of polite society 文明社会的法规
A: ♣近  dogma
A: ♠考法2  n. 真经，真典： the authentic works of a writer
A: ♣反  apocrypha 伪经
A: ♣派  canonical adj. 正教的： conforming to a general rule or acceptable procedure : orthodox
A: ♣反  heterodox, nontraditional 非正统的
A: ♣派  canonize v. 作为神圣的来对待，使神圣化： to treat as sacred; glorify
A: ♣近  adore, adulate, idolize, deify, worship
A: ♣反  abase, degrade, demean, humiliate 贬低

Q:canonize  ['kænənaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 过分宠爱，过分崇拜： to love or admire too much
A: ♣例  a singing star so canonized by his fans that they refuse to believe anything bad about him 一个受到粉丝疯狂追捧的歌星，他们不会相信任何关于他的负面新闻
A: ♣近  adore, adulate, canonize, dote, worship
A: ♣反  abhor, abominate, belittle, despise, detest, disdain, dislike, disparage, hate, loathe 厌恶，鄙视
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使…崇高，使…神圣： to assign a high status or value to
A: ♣例  Some movie buffs canonized David Fincher as today’s most preeminent director. 一些影迷把大卫?芬奇视作是当今世界上最为出色的导演。
A: ♣近  aggrandize, deify, dignify, elevate, ennoble, enshrine, ensky, enthrone, glorify, magnify
A: ♣反  abase, degrade, demean, humble, humiliate 贬低，瞧不起

Q:canvass  ['kænvəs]
A: ♠考法1  v. 仔细检查或详尽地讨论；审查： to examine carefully or discuss thoroughly; scrutinize:
A: ♣例  “The evidence had been repeatedly canvassed in American courts” 证据已在美国的法庭中反复被审查过。
A: ♠考法2  v. 游说：去（一个地区）的各处或找到（个人）来拉选票或定单： to go through (a region) or go to (persons) to solicit votes or orders
A: ♣例  canvass voters 拉选票
A: ♣近  interview, poll, solicit, survey

Q:capitulate  [kə'pitjuleit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 投降，默许： to give up all resistance; acquiesce; yield
A: ♣例  one side finally capitulated when it became clear that they couldn’t win the argument 意识到他们不能拿下这场辩论后，该方投降了
A: ♣近  budge, concede, relent, submit, succumb, surrender, knuckle under
A: ♣反  resist, oppose 抵抗

Q:caprice  [kə'pri:s]
A: ♠考法1  n. 一时冲动的决定： an impulsive change of mind
A: ♣例  an out-of-character caprice led him to take the day off from work and go to the beach 一时冲动让他决定休假一天，去海滩度假
A: ♣近  crank, fancy, vagary, vagrancy, whimsy
A: ♠考法2  n. 反复无常，善变： an inclination to change one's mind impulsively.
A: ♣例  his knack for picking racetrack winners appears to owe as much to caprice as it does to a canny assessment of horseflesh 他赌马屡赌虑赢，要归功于自己的反复无常而不是对于赛马本身独到精明的评估。
A: ♣近  freakishness, impulsiveness, whimsicalness
A: ♣反  confirmation 确认
A: ♣派  capricious adj. 反复无常的，善变
A: ♣反  steadfast, resolute, constant, pertinacious 坚定不变的

Q:captious  ['kæpʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 吹毛求疵的，爱挑毛病的： marked by an often ill-natured inclination to stress faults and raise objections
A: ♣例  a captious and cranky eater who has never met a vegetable he didn’t hate 一个古怪又挑剔的食客，从来就没有他不讨厌的蔬菜
A: ♣近  carping, caviling, critical, faultfinding, hypercritical, judgmental, overcritical
A: ♣反  appreciative 表示欣赏的

Q:captivate  ['kæptiveit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 吸引： to attract and hold by charm, beauty, or excellence
A: ♣例  I was captivated by her brilliant mind. 我被她的才华横溢所吸引。
A: ♣近  allure, beguile, bewitch, enchant, fascinate, magnetize
A: ♣反  repulse 使烦感

Q:cardinal  ['kɑ:dinəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 主要的，非常重要的： of foremost importance; paramount
A: ♣例  the cardinal rule of medicine: do no harm 药物的首要标准就是无害
A: ♣近  dominant, overbearing, overriding, paramount, preeminent, primal, supreme
A: ♣反  minor 次要的

Q:careen  [kə'ri:n]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 蹒跚而行，不稳地行走： to lurch or swerve while in motion
A: ♣例  He careened unsteadily to the couch after hitting his head. 在撞到头以后，他摇摇摆摆地走向沙发。
A: ♣近  dodder, lurch, reel, sway, teeter, totter, waddle, wobble
A: ♠考法2  vi. 狂奔，快速运动： to rush headlong or carelessly
A: ♣例  Sounding its siren, an ambulance careened through the intersection. 救护车响着警笛飞驰通过十字路口。
A: ♣近  blast, bolt, bustle, career, dash, fly, hustle, rush, rustle, speed, whirl
A: ♣反  crawl, creep, lag, poke 缓慢行进

Q:carefree  ['kεəfri:]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无忧无虑的： free from care as having no worries or troubles
A: ♣例  passengers on a luxury cruise ship enjoying a carefree vacation 在豪华游轮上享受着无忧旅途的乘客‖carefree college students on spring break 春假期间无忧无虑的大学生
A: ♣近  blithe, debonair, gay, insouciant, lighthearted, lightsome, slaphappy, unconcerned
A: ♣反  careworn 焦虑的

Q:careworn  ['kεəwɔ:n]

A: ♣例  a careworn face 忧心忡忡的脸
A: ♣反  lighthearted 心情愉快的

Q:caricature  ['kærikətjuə]

A: ♣派  caricaturist n.漫画家
A: ♠考法2  v. 嘲笑性模仿或夸张： to copy or exaggerate (someone or something) in order to make fun of
A: ♣例  caricatured the supervisor's distinctive walk 模仿督导员独特的走路方式
A: ♣近  burlesque, imitate, mock, parody, spoof, travesty

Q:carnal  ['kɑ:nəl]

A: ♣例  seen with carnal eyes 用肉眼看 || carnal remains 遗体
A: ♣近  corporal, corporeal, fleshly, material, somatic
A: ♣反  spiritual 精神的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 世俗的： worldly
A: ♣例  a carnal mind 凡心
A: ♣近  earthborn, mundane, temporal, terrestrial, worldly

Q:carouse  [kə'rauz]

A: ♣例  stay at home instead of going out and carousing with friends 呆在家里而不是出去和朋友们狂饮作乐
A: ♣近  binge, jamboree, revel, roister, wassail

Q:carp  [kɑ:p]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 对小事吹毛求疵，挑剔： to make often peevish criticisms or objections about matters that are minor, unimportant, or irrelevant
A: ♣例  carped about the order of names on the wedding invitations 对于婚礼请柬上的名单顺序吹毛求疵
A: ♣近  cavil, fuss, niggle, nitpick
A: ♠考法2  v. 没完没了地表现不满意： to express dissatisfaction, pain, or resentment usually tiresomely
A: ♣近  gripe, grizzle, grouch, grouse, grumble, wail
A: ♣反  crow, delight, rejoice

Q:carve  [kɑ:v]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 雕刻： to create a three-dimensional representation of (something) using solid material
A: ♣例  carved a statue out of rare marble 用纯的大理石雕刻了一尊雕像
A: ♣近  sculpture
A: ♠考法2  v. （通过长期不懈努力）产生或导致： to produce or bring about especially by long or repeated effort
A: ♣例  finally carved out a niche for the sport in the school's athletic program 在学校运动计划中寻找到了自己的定位 || carve out a way through the enemy 从敌营中杀出一条血路
A: ♣近  forge, grind out, thrash out, work out, work up

Q:cascade  [kæs'keid]
A: ♠考法1  n. （尤指小的）瀑布： a steep usually small fall of water
A: ♣例  The river forms a series of cascades as it drops a total of 200 feet in elevation. 这条河前后海拔差达200余英尺，故而形成了一系列的小瀑布。
A: ♣近  fall, waterfall
A: ♣反  cataract 大瀑布

Q:cast  [kæst]
A: ♠考法1  n. 演员，演员阵容： a set of characters or persons
A: ♠考法2  vt. 选派（演员）： to assign (as an actor) to a role or part
A: ♣近  He was cast in the leading role. 他是男一号。
A: ♠考法3  vt. 提出： to put forth, give off, to place as if by throwing
A: ♣例  cast doubt on their reliability 对它们的可靠性提出质疑
A: ♣近  discharge, emanate, irradiate, issue, shoot, throw out, give out
A: ♠考法4  v. 抛弃： to get rid of as useless or unwanted
A: ♣例  once she became rich and didn't need them anymore, she cast off all her old friends like so much junk 当她有钱了不再需要朋友了，她把老友像糟粕一样抛弃
A: ♣近  ditch, dump, jettison, toss

Q:castigate  ['kæstiɡeit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 强烈（公开）指责： to criticize harshly and usually publicly
A: ♣例  The author castigated the prime minister as an ineffective leader. 作者谴责首相行政无作为。
A: ♣近  berate, chastise, lambaste, reprimand, reproach, rebuke, vituperate, excoriate, rail (at or against)
A: ♣反  approbate, accolade, extol 认可，赞美
A: ♠考法2  v. 惩罚： to inflict a penalty on for a fault or crime
A: ♣例  a judge who believes in castigating criminals to the full extent of the law 法官认为应该最大程度地惩罚罪犯
A: ♣近  chasten, chastise, correct, discipline, penalize
A: ♣反  excuse, pardon, spare 宽恕

Q:catalyze  ['kætəlaiz]

A: ♣例  a reinstitution of the draft would catalyze protests around the country 草案的提出会激发全国范围的抗议
A: ♣近  breed, beget, effectuate, engender, generate, prompt, spawn, yield, result in , bring (about
A: ♣反  retard, prevent, inhibit 阻挠，抑制
A: ♣派  catalyst n. 催化剂：an agent that provokes or speeds significant change or action
A: ♣例  a catalyst for change of lifestyle 生活方式变化的催化剂
A: ♣反  inhibitor 抑制剂

Q:catastrophe  [kə'tæstrəfi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 大灾难： the final event of the dramatic action especially of a tragedy
A: ♣近  apocalypse, calamity, cataclysm, debacle, tragedy
A: ♠考法2  n. 彻底的失败： utter failure : fiasco
A: ♣例  the party was a catastrophe 该派对就是一个杯具
A: ♣近  bummer, debacle, disaster, fiasco, fizzle, washout
A: ♣反  blockbuster, hit, smash, success, winner 大胜

Q:categorical  [,kæti'ɡɔ:rikəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 没有例外的，无条件限制的，绝对的： being without exception or qualification; absolute
A: ♣例  a categorical denial 完全的否认
A: ♣近  definite, downright, fair, utter, thorough, unalloyed, unconditional, unqualified
A: ♣反  conditional, qualified 有条件的

Q:catholic  ['kæθəlik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 普遍的，包容的： not limited or specialized in application or purpose
A: ♣例  a catholic taste in music 对于音乐的兼容并包的品味
A: ♣近  unlimited, unqualified, unrestricted, unspecialized, all-around (also all-round)
A: ♣反  narrow, limited, restricted, specialized 狭隘的

Q:caustic  ['kɔ:stik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 腐蚀性的： capable of destroying or eating away by chemical action : corrosive
A: ♣例  The chemical was so caustic that it ate through the pipes. 化学性质如此具有腐蚀性，以至于把管道都腐蚀了。
A: ♣反  palliating 减缓的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 挖苦讽刺的，刻薄的： marked by incisive sarcasm
A: ♣例  caustic movie reviews 尖酸刻薄的影评
A: ♣近  acerbic, acrid, barbed, mordant, pungent, sardonic, satiric, scathing, sharp
A: ♣反  genial, smooth, kind, innocuous 和蔼的，（言论，行为等）无害的

Q:caveat  ['kæviæt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 警告，告诫： a warning of a specific limitation of something such as information or an agreement
A: ♣例  a final caveat 最终的告诫
A: ♣近  warning, admonish

Q:cavil  ['kævil]
A: ♠考法1  v. 挑剔，吹毛求疵： to find fault unnecessarily; raise trivial objections :quibble
A: ♣例  Let us not cavil too much. 让我们别太挑剔。 || caviling about the price of a cup of coffee 对一杯咖啡的价钱挑刺
A: ♣近  carp, fuss, niggle, nitpick, quibble

Q:cavort  [kə'vɔ:t]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 欢快地蹦跳或行走，雀跃： to bound or prance about in a sprightly manner; caper
A: ♣例  Children are cavorting in the sand. 孩子们在沙子中嬉戏。
A: ♣近  caper, disport, frisk, gambol, rollick, romp
A: ♣反  trudge 蹒跚地走

Q:cede  [si:d]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （根据条约）放弃，割让： to surrender possession of, especially by treaty
A: ♣例  cede the island to America 把岛屿割让给了美国
A: ♣近  relinquish, render, yield, renounce, resign, turn in, turn over, step aside (from), give up, hand over, lay down
A: ♣反  possess 拥有

Q:cellular  ['seljulə]

A: ♣例  the cellular construction of a beehive 蜂巢的多孔结构
A: ♣近  porous

Q:cement  [si'ment]

A: ♣派  censorship n. 审查制度

A: ♣例  censorious comment 尖刻的评论
A: ♣反  eulogistic 赞美的

A: ♣反  commend, extol, laud, endorse 支持，赞同

Q:census  ['sensəs]
A: ♠考法1  n. 户口普查： an official survey of the population of a country that is carried out in order to find out how many people live there and to obtain details of such things as people's ages and jobs
A: ♣近  tale, tally

Q:ceremonious  ['seriməuniəs]

A: ♣近  correct, decorous, formal, nice, proper, punctilious, starchy, stiff, stilted
A: ♣反  casual, easygoing, informal, unceremonious 随意的，不正式的

Q:certitude  ['sə:titju:d]

A: ♣反  doubt, dubiety, incertitude, uncertainty 不确定

A: ♣近  check, cutoff, closure, discontinuance, expiration, halt, shutdown, termination
A: ♣反  commencement, start continuation 开始，继续

Q:chaff  [tʃɑ:f]

A: ♣近  banter, gag, jape, jest, quip, wisecrack

Q:chagrin  ['ʃæɡrin]

A: ♣反  elation, cheerfulness, proud satisfaction, delight 兴高采烈

Q:channel  ['tʃænəl]

A: ♣例  Water was drained from the swamp through a specially constructed channel. 这块沼泽通过一条特殊建造的水渠源源不断地向外输水。
A: ♣近  aqueduct, canal, conduit, course, flume, racecourse, raceway, watercourse, waterway
A: ♠考法2  n. 海峡： a narrow body of water between two land masses
A: ♣例  the world record for swimming the channel between Alaska and Chukotskiy 横渡阿拉斯加和楚科奇之间海峡（也即白令海峡）的世界纪录
A: ♣近  narrows, neck, sound, strait
A: ♠考法3  vt. 将…导向，投入： to cause to move to a central point or along a restricted pathway
A: ♣例  a youth who channeled all of his energy into sports 一个将毕生精力都投入体育之中的少年
A: ♣近  canalize, channelize, conduct, direct, funnel, pipe, siphon

A: ♣反  order 有秩序
A: ♣派  chaotic adj. 混乱的，无序的：happening in a state of complete disorder and confusion
A: ♣反  strictly structured, strictly featured 构造严谨的，特征严谨的

A: ♣反  repulsion, repulsiveness 反感，厌恶

A: ♠考法2  vt. 同意，一致： to be in agreement on every point
A: ♣例  their story of what happened checks with the report of the eyewitness 他们的说法和目击者的供词一致
A: ♣近  accord, cohere, conform, correspond, dovetail, fit, harmonize, jibe, tally
A: ♣反  differ, disagree with 反对

A: ♣近  beloved, dear, favored, favorite, fond, loved, pet, precious, special, sweet
A: ♣反  abhorred, abominated, despised, detested, disdained, disliked, execrated, hated, loathed 被厌恶的

Q:chicanery  [ʃi'keinəri]

A: ♣例  Well-doer never does chicanery and person who is good at chicanery does not belong well-doer. 善者不辩，辩者不善。|| He wasn't above using chicanery to win votes. 他不是用欺骗来赢得选票的。
A: ♣近  deception, artifice, legerdemain, wile, subterfuge
A: ♣反  aboveboard action 光明正大的行为；honest dealing诚实的行为；forthrightness坦白

Q:chide  [tʃaid]

Q:chivalrous  ['ʃivəlrəs]

A: ♣例  still engages in chivalrous behavior, such as opening doors for people 仍然坚持着有风度的行为，比如帮别人开门
A: ♣近  big, elevated, gallant, great, greathearted, high, high-minded, lofty, lordly, magnanimous, natural, sublime
A: ♣反  base, debased, degenerate, degraded, ignoble, ignominious, low 品行低劣的，可鄙的
A: ♣派  chivalry n. 骑士风度

Q:choleric  ['kɔlərik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 易怒的，暴躁的：easily angered; bad-tempered.
A: ♣例  choleric disposition 易怒的性情 || men of the choleric type take to kicking and smashing易怒的人喜欢踢和打碎东西
A: ♣近  crabby, cranky, irascible, peevish, petulant, bad-tempered, hot-tempered, short-tempered, testy
A: ♣反  difficult to provoke, pacific, placid, calm, serene, tranquil, composed, nonchalant 难以被激怒的，平静的
A: ♣派  choler n. 易怒：ready disposition to irritation : irascibility also : anger
A: ♠考法2  adj. 生气的：feeling or showing anger: angry, irate
A: ♣例  I absolutely get choleric when a salesman calls during the dinner hour. 当一个推销员午休时间打来电话的时候我彻底愤怒了。
A: ♣近  angered, apoplectic, ballistic, enraged, furious, incensed, inflamed, enflamed, infuriated, irate, ireful, outraged, rankled, riled, wrathful
A: ♣反  angerless, delighted, pleased

Q:chorale  [kɔ'rɑ:l]

A: ♣近  choir, chorus, consort, ensemble

Q:chord  [kɔ:d]

A: ♣例  The revised system chords perfectly with the original goals. 新版的系统非常符合最初的目标。
A: ♣近  accord, agree, conform, consist, correspond, dovetail, fit, harmonize, jibe, rhyme, square, tally
A: ♣反  differ from, disagree with

Q:chromatic  [krəu'mætik]

A: ♣例  the chromatic paintings of Matisse and the other Fauvists 马蒂斯和其他野兽派画家的彩色画
A: ♣近  colored , colorful, motley, multicolored, multihued, varicolored, variegated, kaleidoscopic
A: ♣反  colorless, pallid, blanched 无色的；monochromatic, monochromic, monotone, self-colored 单色的

Q:chronic  ['krɔnik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 经常发生的，复发的：marked by long duration or frequent recurrence
A: ♣例  chronic disease 慢性病
A: ♣近  frequent, usual, routine
A: ♣反  sporadic 偶然发生的；infrequent 不经常的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 习惯性的，不可能改变的：being such by habit and not likely to change
A: ♣例  a chronic smoker who has quit many times 一个戒了很多次烟的老烟民
A: ♣近  inveterate

Q:churl  [tʃə:l]
A: ♠考法1  n. 粗野的人; a rude, boorish person
A: ♣例  By the 19th century, ‘churl’ had a new and pejorative meaning, “one inclined to uncivil or loutish behavior”. 19世纪的时候，churl有了一个新的贬义含义的意思，“一个粗鲁没有教养的人”
A: ♣近  boor, lout
A: ♣派  churlish adj. 粗野的，暴躁的：of, like, or befitting a churl; boorish or vulgar
A: ♣近  crude, coarse, boorish, loutish, uncultured, unpolished
A: ♣反  genteel, complaisance, courtly, polished文雅的，彬彬有礼的；sophisticated 机智圆滑的
A: ♠考法2  n. 吝啬鬼：a mean grasping person who is usually stingy with money
A: ♣例  Don't bother asking a churl for donations. 别自找麻烦向一个吝啬鬼要捐款。
A: ♣近  miser, niggard, skinflint, penny-pincher
A: ♣反  generous/ liberal/ munificent person 慷慨的人；waster, wastrel, spendthrift, prodigal, profligate, dissipater 败家子

Q:cipher  ['saifə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 无影响或无价值的人：a person of no importance or influence
A: ♣例  The intern is a mere cipher in the company. 这个实习生在公司里是个无足轻重的小人物。
A: ♣近  dwarf, half-pint, insect, insignificancy, lightweight, morsel, nonentity, nothing, nullity, snippersnapper, whippersnapper, zero
A: ♣反  big shot, big wheel, bigwig, eminence, figure, personage
A: ♠考法2  v. 计算（价值）：to determine (a value) by doing the necessary mathematical operations
A: ♣例  We were surprised by how much we had spent on the cruise after we had ciphered out the grand total. 当我们算出我们沉船游览的总花费时，我们都惊呆了。
A: ♣近  compute, work out
A: ♠考法3  n. 密码： a method of transforming a text in order to conceal its meaning
A: ♣例  convert their messages into cipher 把他们的信息转换成密码
A: ♣近  code, secret message

Q:circuitous  [sə'kju:itəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不直接的：not being forthright or direct in language or action
A: ♣例  We took a circuitous route to the airport so as to avoid the massive traffic jam. 我们走了一条迂回的路线去机场来躲避堵车。
A: ♣近  indirect, circular, roundabout
A: ♣反  direct, straight, straightforward 直接的
A: ♣派  circuity n. 不直接：lack of straightforwardness
A: ♣反  straightforwardness, direction 直接
A: ♠考法2  adj. 冗长的：using or containing more words than necessary to express an idea
A: ♣例  a circuitous explanation for what seems like a fairly basic concept 对一个非常基本的概念的冗长的解释
A: ♣近  circumlocutory, diffuse, long-winded, prolix, rambling, verbose, windy
A: ♣反  compact, concise, pithy, succinct, terse 简洁的

Q:circumlocution  [,sə:kəmlə'kju:ʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 绕圈子的说话：the use of unnecessarily wordy and indirect language, evasion in speech
A: ♣例  The other son of your parents’ is a circumlocution for your brother. 你父母的其他儿子是你兄弟的绕圈子的说法。
A: ♣近  equivocation, shuffle, tergiversation
A: ♣反  pithy utters, straightforward utter , express succinctly简洁地表达；direct encounter 直接面对
A: ♣派  circumlocutory a. 绕圈子的
A: ♣反  direct 直接的
A: ♠考法2  n. 冗长：the use of too many words to express an idea
A: ♣例  your papers have to be five pages long, but that's five pages of substance, not circumlocution. 你的论文要求是5页，但是那5页都是实质内容，不是废话。
A: ♣近  diffuseness, diffusion, long-windedness, prolixity, redundancy, verbalism, verboseness, verbosity, windiness, wordage, wordiness
A: ♣反  conciseness, concision, pithiness, succinctness, terseness 简洁

Q:circumscribe  ['sə:kəmskraib]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 限制：to limit narrowly; restrict
A: ♣例  Teammates circumscribed his enthusiasm so as not to make the losing side feel worse. 队友们抑制了他的热情为了不让失败者更难过。
A: ♣近  cap, limit, confine, delimit, restrict
A: ♣反  exceed 超过，超越
A: ♠考法2  vt. 包围，围绕：to surround by or as if by a boundary
A: ♣例  fields circumscribed by tall trees 被高树包围的地方 || Circumscribe a circle around a square. 画正方形的外接圆。
A: ♣近  surround, encompass

Q:circumspect  ['sə:kəmspekt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 谨慎的；小心的：careful to consider all circumstances and possible consequences: prudent
A: ♣例  The banks should have been more circumspect in their dealings. 银行本应该在它们的交易当中更加谨慎。
A: ♣近  alert, careful, gingerly, guarded, heedful, prudent, cautious, chary, wary
A: ♣反  careless, incautious, unmindful, unwary 不小心，不谨慎的；audacious, reckless 大胆的，鲁莽的

Q:circumvent  [,sə:kəm'vent]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 躲避（不遵从）：to avoid having to comply with (something) especially through cleverness
A: ♣例  circumvent all the red tape 绕过所有官方程序繁文缛节 || He found a way to circumvent the law. 他发现了一个逃避法律的方法。
A: ♣近  avoid, bypass, dodge, sidestep, skirt, get around
A: ♣反  comply with, follow, obey, observe 遵从；confront, direct encounter 直接面对

Q:civility  [si'viləti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 彬彬有礼：courteous behavior; politeness
A: ♣例  They greeted us with civility. 他们有礼貌地招呼我们。
A: ♣近  politeness, courtesy, politeness, genteelness, gentility, graciousness
A: ♣反  discourteousness, discourtesy, impoliteness, incivility, rudeness, surliness, ungraciousness 无礼，粗鲁

Q:claim  [kleim]
A: ♠考法1  v. 要求（权利）：to ask for especially as a right
A: ♣例  a fragile claim to fame 对名誉不切实际的要求 || After many years had passed, he suddenly appeared to claim his inheritance. 很多年已经过去，他突然出现要求继承遗产。
A: ♣近  call for, command, quest
A: ♣反  renounce 放弃
A: ♠考法2  v. 断言：to state as a fact usually forcefully
A: ♣例  People claim that they have been kidnapped by aliens. 人们断言称他们被外星人绑架了。
A: ♣近  allege, assert
A: ♣反  deny, gainsay 否认
A: ♠考法3  v. 剥夺生命：to deprive of life
A: ♣例  Cancer claims hundreds of thousands of Americans each year. 癌症每年要剥夺成千上万美国人的生命。
A: ♣反  animate 使有生命
A: ♠考法4  n. 权利：a legal right to participation in the advantages, profits, and responsibility of something
A: ♣例  A shareholder has a claim in the business. 股东在企业有权利（收益权、选举权等）。

Q:clamor  ['klæmə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 喧闹，喧哗，噪声： loud, confused, and usually inharmonious sound
A: ♣例  A clamor arose from the crowd as the prisoner was brought forward. 当犯人被带上前台时，人群中爆发出一阵骚动。‖the clamor of a dozen people practicing the trumpet at once 一群人同时练习小号时发出的噪音
A: ♣近  blare, bluster, cacophony, clangor, discordance, howl, racket, rattle, roar, tumult, uproar, vociferation
A: ♣反  quiet, silence, still, stillness 寂静；calm, lull, serenity, tranquility 宁静，祥和
A: ♣派  clamorous adj. 喧闹的

Q:clan  [klæn]
A: ♠考法1  n. （有共同爱好的）团体，帮派： a group united by a common interest or common characteristics
A: ♣例  That clan of football fans has parties every weekend on which the New England Patriots play. 只要是新英格兰爱国者队有比赛的周末，那帮球迷就会举行聚会。
A: ♣近  body, bunch, circle, clique, community, coterie, coven, crowd, fold, network, pack, ring, set
A: ♣反  clannish adj. 派系的；团结的

Q:clandestine  [klæn'destin]

A: ♣例  their clandestine love affair 他们的秘密恋情
A: ♣近  secret, covert, furtive, surreptitious, sneaky, stealthy, undercover, underground, underhand, underhanded
A: ♣反  open, overt, public 公开的； aboveboard 光明正大的

Q:clarion  ['klæriən]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 清楚响亮的：loud and clear
A: ♣例  clarion call for democracy 对民主的高声呼吁 || The Internationale is a clarion call to the labouring people of the world. 《国际歌》是唤起全世界劳动人民的响亮号角。
A: ♣反  soft and indistinct 柔和模糊的

Q:clarity  ['klærəti]
A: ♠考法1  n.清晰、清楚：the quality or state of being clear: lucidity
A: ♣例  Clarity of diction is vital for a XDF teacher. 发音清楚对新东方老师来说是至关重要的。
A: ♣近  clarity, explicitness, lucidity, lucidness, perspicuity, perspicuousness
A: ♣反  obscureness, obscurity, unclarity 模糊，不清晰
A: ♣派  clarify v. 澄清，使清晰：to free of confusion
A: ♣例  clarify his mind 理清思路；clarify a subject 澄清某一问题
A: ♣近  purify, clear, elucidate, explain, illuminate, illustrate
A: ♣反  obfuscate, obscure
A: ♠考法2  n. 清澈透明：the state or quality of being easily seen through
A: ♣例  mountain streams with water of incredible clarity 难以置信般清澈透明的山涧
A: ♣近  clearness, limpidity, limpidness, translucence, translucency, transparency
A: ♣反  cloudiness, opacity, opaqueness, turbidity, turbidness 浑浊，不透明

Q:clasp  [klɑ:sp]

Q:cleave  [kli:v]

A: ♣例  You should resolutely cleave to the facts in your report. 你应该在报道中坚持客观的原则。
A: ♣近  adhere, cling, hew, stick
A: ♣反  defect 叛变
A: ♠考法2  vt. 分隔，割裂： to divide by or as if by a cutting blow
A: ♣例  His spade cleaved the firm sand with a harsh crunch. 他的锹凿开了坚实的砂土，发出尖锐刺耳的嘎扎声。
A: ♣近  cut, decouple, disconnect, disjoin, dissever, dissociate, divide, part, ramify, sever, slice, split, sunder
A: ♣反  join, link, unify, unite 连接，接合

Q:clement  ['klemənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 宽容的，善良的：tolerant and kind in the judgment of and expectations for others
A: ♣例  Clement judge reduced the sentence. 仁慈的法官减轻了刑罚。
A: ♣近  charitable, lenient, merciful
A: ♣反  harsh, severe, stern, strict 严厉的,严格的
A: ♣派  clemency n. 仁慈
A: ♠考法2  adj. 气候温和的：marked by temperatures that are neither too high nor too low
A: ♣例  Hawaii is known for its delightfully clement climate. 夏威夷以它宜人的温和气候著称。
A: ♣近  mild, genial, gentle, balmy, equable
A: ♣反  harsh, inclement, severe 严酷的

Q:cliché  ['kli:ʃei]

A: ♣近  banality, bromide, platitude, trite, bathetic, hackneyed, stereotypical
A: ♣反  fresh, new, original, creative 新的，创造性的

Q:cling  [kliŋ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 粘结，粘合： a physical sticking to as if by glue
A: ♣例  For certain types of materials that plastic wrap has very little cling. 对于某些材料，那种塑料保鲜袋的粘性不好。
A: ♣近  adherence, bonding, cohesion
A: ♠考法2  vi. 紧贴，支持： to adhere as if glued firmly
A: ♣例  a dozen magnets clinging to the refrigerator 贴靠在冰箱门上的磁石‖continued to cling to the old ideas of child rearing long after they had gone out of fashion 仍然坚持关于抚养孩子的老观念，尽管它们已经过时
A: ♣近  adhere, cleave, hew, stick
A: ♣反  defect 叛变

Q:clog  [klɔɡ]

A: ♣例  impede with a clog 用障碍物阻止
A: ♣近  balk, bar, block, deterrent, drag, fetter, holdback, hurdle, impediment, inhibition, interference, obstacle, obstruction, shackles, stop, stumbling block, trammel
A: ♠考法2  v. 阻碍：to create difficulty for the work or activity of
A: ♣例  They always clog the courts. 他们一直阻挠法庭工作。
A: ♣近  encumber, fetter, hinder, hold back, hold up, impede, inhibit, interfere with, obstruct, shackle, stymie, tie up, trammel
A: ♣反  aid, assist, help 帮助；facilitate 促进
A: ♠考法3  v. 堵塞：to prevent passage through by filling with something
A: ♣例  Within a few years the pipe began to clog up. 没有几年，管子就开始堵塞了。
A: ♣近  block, choke, clot, gum up, jam, obstruct, occlude, stop up, stuff
A: ♣反  clear, free, open up, unblock, unclog, unstop

Q:clot  [klɔt]

A: ♣近  array, assemblage, band, block, bunch, cluster, clutch, collection, constellation, grouping, huddle, knot, lot, muster, package
A: ♠考法2  v. 堵塞：to prevent passage through by filling with something
A: ♣例  Within a few years the pipe began to clog up. 没有几年，管子就开始堵塞了。
A: ♣近  block, choke, clog, gum up, jam, obstruct, occlude, stop up, stuff
A: ♣反  clear, free, open up, unblock, unclog, unstop
A: ♠考法3  v. 凝结：to turn from a liquid into a substance resembling jelly
A: ♣例  Scabs form over cuts when your blood starts to clot. 当血液开始凝结的时候，伤口处会形成血痂。
A: ♣近  congeal, jell, jelly

Q:cloudburst  ['klaudbə:st]

Q:coagulate  [kəu'æɡjuleit]

A: ♣反  melt, liquefy, fluidify, dissolve 融化，溶解；thin 使变稀薄
A: ♣派  coagulant n. 凝结剂：an agent that causes a liquid to coagulate

Q:coarse  [kɔ:s]

A: ♣例  the coarse surface of the sandpaper 砂纸的粗糙表面

A: ♠考法2  adj. （声音）刺耳的： harsh, raucous, or rough in tone
A: ♣例  a coarse laugh from the living room 客厅里传来的一阵刺耳笑声
A: ♣近  croaking, croaky, grating, gravel, gruff, husky, rasping, raspy, rusty, scratchy, throaty
A: ♣反  gentle, gliding, golden, liquid, mellifluent, mellifluous, mellow, soothing, sweet, tender （声音）柔美的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 粗俗的： lacking in delicacy or refinement

A: ♣反  civilized, cultivated, cultured, genteel, polished, refined, smooth, tasteful 有教养的，举止得体的
A: ♠考法4  adj. （质量）低劣的： of low, common, or inferior quality
A: ♣例  coarse imitations of quality merchandise 高级商品的粗劣仿制品
A: ♣近  execrable,

Q:coeval  ['kəu'i:vəl]

A: ♣近  apropos, germane, relative, relevant
A: ♣反  extraneous, irrelevant, impertinent, irrelative 无关的

Q:collapse  [kə'læps]

A: ♣例  President Bush is vowing to rebuild bridge which collapsed last year. 布什总统发誓要重建这座去年坍塌的桥梁。|| One ant-hole may cause the collapse of a thousand-li dyke. 千里之堤，毁于蚁穴。

A: ♣反  decompress, expand, open, outspread, outstretch 展开，扩张
A: ♠考法2  n. 完全耗尽体力：a complete depletion of energy or strength
A: ♣例  He suffered a mental collapse under the strain of studying for his bar exam. 他在紧张的律师考试的复习下脑力消耗殆尽。
A: ♣近  exhaustion, tiredness, lassitude, weariness
A: ♣反  refreshment, rejuvenation, revitalization 重新充满活力

A: ♣近  defeat, nonachievement, nonsuccess
A: ♣反  accomplishment, achievement, success

Q:commencement  [kə'mensmənt]

A: ♣例  There was a large turnout at the commencement of the conference, but the numbers dwindled as it progressed. 在会议开始的时候，有很多人出席。但是随着会议的发展，人慢慢变少了。
A: ♣近  birth, onset, outset, start, genesis, inception, nascence, threshold
A: ♣反  close, conclusion, end, ending 结束

A: ♣例  The purpose of a commencement speaker is to dispense wisdom. 毕业典礼的演讲者的目的是传播智慧。

Q:commend  [kə'mend]

A: ♣例  Jason commended his students' studious attitude. Jason表扬了他的学生的用功的态度。
A: ♣近  approbate, praise, acclaim, applaud, compliment, eulogize, extol
A: ♣反  blame, criticize, reprehend, reprobate, chide, rebuke, reprimand, reproach, reprove, censure, admonish berate, deplore, execrate 责备，批评，谴责诅咒，憎恶，痛骂
A: ♠考法2  vt. 委托保管：to entrust for care or preservation
A: ♣例  I commend my fate into your hands. 我的命运就拜托给你了。
A: ♣近  commit, delegate, deliver, entrust, confide, consign, hand over
A: ♣反  hold, keep, retain
A: ♠考法3  vt. 推荐：to recommend as worthy of confidence or notice
A: ♣例  I commend this book to anyone interested in learning more about American history. 我把这本书推荐给所有对美国历史感兴趣的人。

Q:commensurate  [kə'menʃərit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 同样大小的：equal in measure or extent
A: ♣例  Five yards is commensurate with fifteen feet. 5码等于15英尺。
A: ♣近  equal, tantamount
A: ♣反  unequal, disparate, preponderant 不相同的，（重量，重要性，数量上）超过的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 相称的，相当的：corresponding in size or degree; proportionate
A: ♣例  a job commensurate with her abilities 一份与她能力相称的工作
A: ♣近  commensurable, commensurate, proportionate
A: ♣反  disproportionate 不相称的

Q:commingle  [kɔ'miŋɡl]
A: ♠考法1  v. 充分混合：to blend thoroughly into a harmonious whole
A: ♣例  Ground waters originating in different beds commingle. 来源于不同层位的地下水相互混合。|| Fact and fiction commingle in the story. 事实和虚构混合成了故事。
A: ♣近  amalgamate, fuse, mix, immix, commix, compound, mingle, immingle, intermingle, intermix, merge
A: ♣反  break down, break up, separate, unmix 分开

Q:commiserate  [kə'mizəreit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 表示怜悯，同情： to feel or express sympathy
A: ♣例  commiserated over their failure 对他们的失败表示同情‖We commiserated with him but there was little we could do to make the situation better. 我们很同情他的遭遇，但是也只能表示无能为力。
A: ♣近  ache, bleed, compassionate, condole, sympathize, yearn

Q:commitment  [kə'mitmənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 致力，投入：the state or an instance of being obligated or emotionally impelled
A: ♣例  a commitment to a cause 投身于某项事业
A: ♣近  dedication, devotedness, fealty, piety, steadfastness
A: ♠考法2  n. 确信：a strong belief in something
A: ♣近  conviction, belief, faith
A: ♠考法3  n. 承诺，表态：the act of revealing one’s view of
A: ♣例  He made a commitment to pay the rent on time. 他承诺按时交房租。
A: ♣反  ambivalence, equivocation 矛盾，含糊其辞

Q:committed  [kə'mitid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 忠诚的： loyal to a belief, organization, or group, and willing to work hard for it
A: ♣例  remain committed to one’s youthful ideal 坚持不懈地追求自己年轻时的理想
A: ♣近  loyal, faithful, allegiant
A: ♣反  disloyal 不忠诚的
A: ♣派  noncommittal adj. 不明确的：giving no clear indication of attitude or feeling
A: ♣例  a noncommittal reply 一个不明确的回答
A: ♣反  confirmable 确定的

Q:commodious  [kə'məudjəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 宽敞舒适的comfortably or conveniently spacious: roomy
A: ♣例  a commodious closet 宽敞的衣橱
A: ♣近  spacious, roomy
A: ♣反  constricted, cramped, snug, constringed 狭窄的

Q:commonsensical  ['kɔmən,sensikəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 符合常识的，有依据的：displaying common sense，based on sound reasoning or information
A: ♣例  The only commonsensical solution would be to divide the children into groups according to age. 唯一合理的解决办法就是按照年龄把孩子分成组。
A: ♣近  justified, logical, rational, reasonable, reasoned, valid, well-founded, levelheaded
A: ♣反  groundless, illogical, invalid, irrational, nonrational, nonsensical, nonvalid, unfounded, uninformed, unjustified, unreasonable, unreasoned, unsound 无逻辑的，不合理的；preposterous 荒谬的

Q:commotion  [kə'məuʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 骚乱：an agitated disturbance
A: ♣例  The commotion was created when the nation's top rock band arrived in town. 当顶级摇滚乐队来到小镇时，人们骚乱了。
A: ♣近  tumult, turmoil, pandemonium, hurry-scurry
A: ♣反  tranquility, calmness, quiet, serenity 安静；order 有序

Q:compatible  [kəm'pætəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 一致的，能共存的： capable of existing together in harmony
A: ♣例  I don’t think that they could be compatible as roommates. 我不觉得他们做了室友之后生活会很和谐。‖a theory that is compatible with what we already know about early man 一个与对远古人类的已有知识不存在矛盾的理论
A: ♣近  accordant, coherent, concordant, conformable, congruent, congruous, consonant, harmonious
A: ♣反  conflicting, incompatible, incongruous, inconsistent, inharmonious 有冲突的，矛盾的

Q:compelling  [kəm'peliŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 极具说服力的： having the power to persuade
A: ♣例  made a compelling argument against military intervention 就反对军事干预提出了很有说服力的论证‖If you can’t present any compelling evidence to prove your innocence, you will be found guilty. 如果你找不出任何能证明你清白的有力证据，你就会被定罪。
A: ♣近  conclusive, convincing, decisive, effective, forceful, persuasive, satisfying, strong, telling
A: ♣反  feeble, weak 说服力不足的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 迫切的，紧迫的： needing immediate attention
A: ♣例  There is no compelling need to raise taxes at this time. 现在没有迫切的提升税率的必要。
A: ♣近  burning, clamant, critical, crying, dire, emergent, exigent, imperative, imperious, importunate, instant, necessitous, pressing, urgent
A: ♣反  minor, negligible, trivial, unimportant 不重要的，琐碎的

Q:compendium  [kəm'pendiəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 摘要：a brief summary of a larger work or of a field of knowledge: abstract
A: ♣例  a compendium of information 资料概要
A: ♣近  abstract, brief, overview
A: ♣派  compendious adj. 简洁而全面的：concise and comprehensive
A: ♣例  his compendious knowledge of this subject 他关于这一学科全面的知识
A: ♣近  concise, brief, laconic, compendiary, succinct
A: ♠考法2  目录：各种项目的列表或集合：a list or collection of various items.
A: ♣例  Compendium of Materia Medica 《本草纲目》
A: ♣近  compilation, miscellany

Q:complacency  [kəm'pleisənsi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 自满，无忧患意识：a feeling of self-satisfaction, coupled with an unawareness of trouble
A: ♣例  Complacency is the enemy of study. 自满乃学习之敌。|| A momentary complacency that was quickly dispelled by the shock of cold reality. 短暂的自满很快就被残酷的现实赶跑了。
A: ♣近  conceit, pomposity, pompousness, pride, self-admiration, self-assumption, smugness, vanity
A: ♣反  anxiety 忧虑；humbleness, humility, modesty 谦虚

Q:complacent  [kəm'pleisənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 自满的，自鸣得意的： feeling or showing an often excessive or unjustified satisfaction and pleasure in one's status, possessions, or attainments
A: ♣例  a complacent junior accountant who was certain of her indispensability to the company 一个确信自己对于公司而言无可替代而自满的年轻会计
A: ♣近  assured, consequential, egoistic, overweening, pompous, prideful, proud, smug, vain, vainglorious
A: ♣反  egoless, humble, modest, uncomplacent 谦逊的，谦卑的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无所谓的，不关心的： having or showing a lack of interest or concern
A: ♣例  We can't afford to be complacent about rural illiteracy rates. 我们不能对农村的文盲率坐视不理。
A: ♣近  apathetic, casual, disinterested, insouciant, nonchalant, perfunctory, pococurante, unconcerned
A: ♣反  attentive, concerned, heedful, interested, mindful 关注的，感兴趣的
A: ♣派  complacency n. 自满

Q:complaisance  [kəm'pleizəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 愿意顺从，讨好，彬彬有礼：disposition to please or comply: affability
A: ♣例  She speaks with complaisance. 说话彬彬有礼。|| The complaisance of his girlfriend is such that she meekly goes along with everything he says. 他的女朋友讨好他，对他言听计从。
A: ♣例  ♣近  affability, amenability, amiability, good-naturedness
A: ♣反  obstinacy 固执；churlishness 粗野

Q:complementary  [,kɔmpli'mentəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 互补的： mutually supplying each other’s lack
A: ♣例  The complementary contributions of the cooking and cleanup committees were essential to the success of the barbecue. 负责食物和卫生的两个小组之间的相互配合是野炊成功的关键。
A: ♣近  correlative, interdependent, reciprocal, supplemental, supplementary
A: ♣反  contradictory, incompatible 矛盾的

Q:compliant  [kəm'plaiənt]

A: ♣例  a corrupt regime aided by a compliant television station 一个在顺从的电视台帮助下的腐败政府
A: ♣近  amenable, conformable, docile, submissive, tractable
A: ♣反  balky, contumacious, disobedient, incompliant, insubordinate, intractable, noncompliant, obstreperous, rebel, rebellious, recalcitrant, refractory, unamenable, ungovernable, unruly, willful, wayward顽固，难驾驭的

Q:complicate  ['kɔmplikeit]

A: ♣近  complex, embarrass, entangle, ravel, perplex, sophisticate, tangle
A: ♣反  simplify, streamline 简化
A: ♣派  complicated adj. 复杂的，麻烦的

Q:compliment  ['kɔmplimənt]

A: ♣例  a man meriting the compliments and homage of his fellows 一个值得他的伙伴们尊敬和称赞的人
A: ♣近  praise, commend, eulogize, extol, laud
A: ♣反  vituperate 责骂
A: ♣派  complimentary adj. 称赞的：expressing or containing a compliment
A: ♣反  vituperative 责骂的
A: ♠考法2  n. 敬意，免费赠送的礼物：formal and respectful recognition : honor
A: ♣例  How about a delicious dessert then, with our compliment? 给您上点甜点怎么样，算是我们小小的敬意。

Q:comply  [kəm'plai]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 遵从：to conform, submit, or adapt (as to a regulation or to another's wishes) as required or requested
A: ♣例  the devices comply with industry standards 设备要遵循工业标准 || There will be penalties against individuals who fail to comply. 谁不遵从谁就会受到惩罚。
A: ♣近  conform, submit, observe
A: ♣反  defy, disobey, rebel against, violate, breach, transgress 违背

Q:compose  [kəm'pəuz]
A: ♠考法1  v. 使镇定：to free from agitation: calm
A: ♣例  She took a deep breath and composed herself. 她做了一个深呼吸，控制住了自己的情绪。
A: ♣近  contain, settle
A: ♣反  agitate, discompose, disquiet, disturb, perturb, upset, vex
A: ♣派  composed adj. 镇静的，安定的：free from agitation: calm
A: ♣反  distraught, restless 发狂的，不平静的
A: ♣派  composure n. 镇定：a calmness or repose especially of mind, bearing, or appearance
A: ♠考法2  v. 组成，构成：to form the substance of : constitute
A: ♣例  composed of many ingredients 有很多配料组成
A: ♣近  constitute, comprise, make up

Q:compound  ['kɔmpaund]
A: ♠考法1  n. 混和物：composed of or resulting from union of separate elements, ingredients, or parts
A: ♣例  mixed the chemicals together to form a new compound 将化学试剂混合形成新的化合物
A: ♣近  admixture, alloy, amalgam, amalgamation, cocktail, combination, composite, fusion, intermixture, meld, mix, conflation, synthesis
A: ♠考法2  adj. 混合的：consisting of two or more substances, ingredients, elements, or parts
A: ♣例  a compound word 复合词 || “Steamboat” is a compound noun. “汽船”是一个复合名词。
A: ♣近  amalgamated
A: ♣反  noncompound　非混合的
A: ♠考法3  vt. 混合：to put or bring together so as to form a new and longer whole
A: ♣例  the German language's propensity for compounding words 德语喜欢复合单词
A: ♣近  chain, conjugate, couple, hook, interconnect, interlink, join, link, yoke
A: ♣反  disconnect, disjoin, disjoint, dissever, disunite, separate, unchain, uncouple, unhitch, unyoke 分开
A: ♠考法4  v. 扩大，增多：to make greater in size, amount, or number
A: ♣例  We compounded our error by waiting too long to call for help. 我们等着不寻求帮助会增大我们的错误。
A: ♣近  Aggrandize, amplify, augment, boost, enlarge, escalate, expa

Q:comprehend  [,kɔmpri'hend]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 理解，了解： to grasp the nature, significance, or meaning of
A: ♣例  the age at which children can comprehend the difference between right and wrong 一个小孩可以开始分辨是非的年龄‖With internet, television, cellphone and even radio down, we are unable to comprehend what has happened. 互联网、电视、手机乃至无线电都不起作用了，我们无法获知发生了什么。
A: ♣近  appreciate, apprehend, assimilate, behold, catch, cognize, conceive, discern, grasp, perceive, recognize, savvy, see, seize, sense, understand
A: ♣反  misapprehend, misconceive, misinterpret, misperceive, misunderstand 误解
A: ♠考法2  vt. 包括，包含： to contain or hold within a total scope, significance, or amount
A: ♣例  Our notion of morality should comprehend much more than proper sexual behavior. 我们的道德观不应该仅仅止步于恰当的性行为。
A: ♣近  carry, contain, embrace, encompass, entail, involve, number, subsume, take in
A: ♣反  exclude, leave, omit, preclude 排除，忽略
A: ♣派  comprehensive adj. 全面的，综合的；comprehension n. 理解； comprehensible adj. 可理解的

Q:compress  [kəm'pres]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 压缩（体积）：to reduce in size or volume as if by squeezing
A: ♣例  compress a computer file 压缩电脑文档 || The science textbook compresses a lot of information about human reproduction into a few short chapters. 科学教科书将人类的生殖知识压缩成了几个短章节。
A: ♣近  capsule, collapse, compact, condense, constrict, constringe, contract, shrink, telescope
A: ♣反  increase in volume, decompress, expand, outspread, outstretch 体积增大，扩张；balloon 膨胀

Q:compromise  ['kɔmprəmaiz]
A: ♠考法1  v. 妥协：to adjust or settle by mutual concessions
A: ♣例  Eventually we reached a compromise on the number of hours per week that would be devoted to piano practice. 最后我们在每周练琴的时间上妥协了。
A: ♣近  accommodation, negotiation
A: ♠考法2  v. 使危险：to place in danger
A: ♣例  Officials were concerned that his statements would compromise national security. 官员们认为他的言论会危害国家安全。
A: ♣近  hazard, imperil, jeopardy, jeopardize, menace, peril, venture

Q:compunction  [kəm'pʌŋkʃən]

A: ♣近  anxiety, misgiving, scruple
A: ♣反  absence of misgiving 不担忧

Q:concatenate  [kɔn'kætineit]

A: ♣例  The movie actually concatenates several episodes from various books into one extended narrative. 这部电影把很多书中的片段混合成了一个故事。

A: ♣反  disconnect, disjoin, disjoint, dissever, disunite, separate, unchain, uncouple, unhitch, unyoke 分开

Q:concave  [kɔn'keiv]

A: ♣例  a concave lens 凹透镜
A: ♣近  dented, depressed, dished, indented, recessed
A: ♣反  bulging, convex, protuberant 凸的

Q:conceal  [kən'si:l]

A: ♣例  Drunkenness reveal what soberness conceal. 酒后吐真言
A: ♣近  cache, secrete, disguise, mask, occult, ensconce
A: ♣反  display, exhibit 展示；bare, disclose, expose, reveal, uncover, unmask 揭露

Q:concede  [kən'si:d]

A: ♣例  She grudgingly conceded his point. 她不情愿的承认了他的观点。
A: ♣近  acknowledge, grant, confess
A: ♣反  refuse to grant , deny 拒绝承认，否认
A: ♣派  concession n. 让步: the act of yielding
A: ♣反  aggression 侵犯
A: ♠考法2  v. 停止抵抗：to cease resistance (as to another's arguments, demands, or control)
A: ♣例  He conceded as soon as it became clear that he could not win. 当他明显赢不了的时候他就停止了抵抗。
A: ♣近  capitulate, give in, quit, submit, succumb, surrender
A: ♣反  resist 抵抗

Q:concentrate  ['kɔnsəntreit]

A: ♣例  concentrate one’s efforts 集中精力
A: ♣近  center, focus, rivet
A: ♣反  deploy, dispel, disperse, dissipate 散开，驱散
A: ♠考法2  vt. 浓缩：to make less dilute
A: ♣例  prolonged boiling is required to concentrate the sap when making maple syrup
A: ♣近  condense
A: ♣反  dilute, water down 稀释
A: ♠考法3  v. 聚集：to come together in one body or place
A: ♣例  recent immigrants tend to concentrate in port cities. 进来的移民倾向于聚集在海港城市。
A: ♣近  accumulate, amass, assemble, collect, congregate, garner
A: ♣反  dispel, disperse, dissipate, scatter, break up, disband 驱散，解散

Q:concerted  [kən'sə:tid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 共同完成的：planned or accomplished together
A: ♣例  The ITER project, commendable though it is, should be merely a component of a concerted effort. “国际热核聚变实验堆”计划虽然是值得称赞的，但是它仅仅是（人类）齐心协力的一部分。|| A victory results from the concerted effort of the entire team. 一项成功来自于整个团队的齐心协力。
A: ♣近  collaborative, combined, cooperative, united
A: ♣反  separate 分开的；individual, single, sole, solitary 单独的

Q:conciliate  [kən'silieit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 平息，抚慰：to lessen the anger or agitation of
A: ♣例  A principal trying to conciliate the parents who did not receive their tickets to the graduation ceremonies. 校长试着平息这对没有收到他们的毕业晚会门票的家长的气愤情绪。
A: ♣近  appease, pacify, assuage, conciliate, mollify, placate, propitiate, calm (down), ease, soothe, palliate, disarm
A: ♣反  annoy, enrage, vex, nettle, rile, incense, inflame, exasperate, infuriate, discompose, disturb, perturb, upset 烦扰，激怒，打扰
A: ♠考法2  vt. 调解：to make compatible : reconcile
A: ♣例  It will be hard to conciliate the views of labor and management regarding health benefits. 调解劳资双方对于健康保险金的观点很难。
A: ♣近  attune, reconcile, coordinate, accommodate
A: ♣反  discontent 不满；disharmonize 使不和谐
A: ♣派  conciliatory adj. 调和的，安抚的
A: ♣反  contentious 好争吵的；belligerent好战的

Q:concise  [kən'sais]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 简洁的：marked by brevity of expression or statement
A: ♣例  a clear and concise account of the accident 一个清楚间断的事故描述 || Concise Design of Spacecraft Automatic System 航天器自动控制系统简要设计
A: ♣近  aphoristic, compendious, curt, laconic, pithy, succinct, terse, elliptical
A: ♣反  circuitous, circumlocutory, diffuse, long-winded, prolix, verbose, windy, wordy 冗长的

Q:concord  ['kɔŋkɔ:d]
A: ♠考法1  n．一致，和睦：harmony or agreement of interests or feelings; accord
A: ♣例  No discord, no concord. 不打不成交
A: ♣近  comity, compatibility, peace
A: ♣反  conflict, discord, dissension, variance 冲突，不和

Q:concrete  [kən'kri:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 实体的，实在的： relating to or composed of matter
A: ♣例  concrete objects like rocks and trees 像石头、树这一类的实物
A: ♣近  physical, substantial, substantive
A: ♣反  airy, diaphanous, gossamery, immaterial, tenuous, thin, vaporous 虚无飘渺的，非实体的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 事实性的，明确的： existing in fact and not merely as a possibility
A: ♣例  Concrete evidence, and not just a theory, must be presented at a trial. 在法庭上需要出示确凿的证据，而非臆测。
A: ♣近  effective, existent, factual, genuine, real, true, very, de facto
A: ♣反  conjectural, hypothetical, ideal, platonic, suppositional, theoretical 猜测的，理论上的

Q:concur  [kən'kə:]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 同意：to express agreement
A: ♣例  concur with an excellent opinion 同意一个好的想法
A: ♣近  agree, coincide
A: ♣反  differ, disagree 不同意
A: ♠考法2  v. 同一时间发生、存在：to occur or exist at the same time
A: ♣例  The race to the moon, the Vietnam War, and the civil rights movement all concurred in the 1960s. 登月，越战和人权运动都发生在二十世纪六十年代。
A: ♣近  coexist, synchronize, co-occur
A: ♠考法3  v. 团结合作：to participate or assist in a joint effort to accomplish an end
A: ♣例  All people concurred to pass the reform legislation 所有人都联合起来使改革的法案通过。
A: ♣近  band together, collaborate, concert, conjoin, league, team up, unite

Q:condemn  [kən'dem]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 谴责（为不道德的、邪恶的）： to declare to be reprehensible, wrong, or evil usually after weighing evidence and without reservation
A: ♣例  a policy widely condemned as racist 一个被广泛谴责为种族歧视的政策‖It is a sign of human progress that slavery, which was once common, is now universally condemned. 曾经很平常的奴隶制如今却沦落到人人谴责的境地，这不能不说是人类文明的进步。
A: ♣近  anathematize, censure, damn, decry, denounce, execrate, reprimand, reprehend, reproach, reprobate
A: ♣反  commend, endorse, extol, laud, praise 赞扬，赞颂

Q:condescending  [,kɔndi'sendiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 摆出高人一等的姿态的：displaying a patronizingly superior attitude
A: ♣例  treat sb. in a condescending manner 以屈尊俯就的态度对待某人
A: ♣近  patronizing
A: ♣派  condescension n. 屈尊俯就：patronizing attitude or behavior

Q:condign  [kən'dain]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 应得的，恰当的：deserved, appropriate
A: ♣例  condign punishment 应得的惩罚 || A suspension without pay is condign punishment for breaking the company's code of business ethics 停职是违反公司商业道德准则应得的惩罚。
A: ♣近  due, deserved, merited, justified, warranted
A: ♣反  undeserved, undue, unmerited不应得的

Q:conditional  [kən'diʃənəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有条件的，受制约的： subject to, implying, or dependent upon a condition
A: ♣例  a conditional offer 有条件限制的录取‖Their support is conditional on their approval of his proposals. 他只有让他的提案得到他们的同意才能得到援助。
A: ♣近  contingent, dependent, subject, tentative
A: ♣反  absolute, categorical, unconditional 不受制约的；independent 独立的

Q:condole  [kən'dəul]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 表达同情：to express sympathetic sorrow
A: ♣例  We condole with him on the death of his father. 我们对他父亲的死向他深表同情。
A: ♣近  compassionate, sympathize with, yearn over
A: ♣派  condolence n. 同情; sympathy with another in sorrow

Q:condone  [kən'dəun]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 宽恕，忽视：to overlook, forgive, or disregard (an offense) without protest or censure.
A: ♣例  By his silence, he seemed to condone their behavior. 他的沉默流露出了他对他们行为的宽恕。|| He is too quick to condone his friend's faults. 她太快了以至于忽视了他朋友的过错。
A: ♣近  disregard, ignore, overlook, remit, shrug off, gloss over
A: ♣反  denounce 谴责；exact 强求

Q:conducive  [kən'dju:siv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有益的，有促进的：tending to promote or assist
A: ♣例  be conducive to education 于教育有利的
A: ♣例  The state's long-standing low tax is conducive to entrepreneurship. 政府长期的低税率有利于创业者。
A: ♣近  facilitative, useful
A: ♣反  unhelpful, useless 无用的

Q:confident  ['kɔnfidənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有信心的，自信的：having or showing assurance and self-reliance
A: ♣例  Thicker and fuller hair would make a man more confident at work. 越来越浓密的头发让男人在工作中更加自信。
A: ♣近  assured, self-assured, self-confident
A: ♣反  diffident 不自信的

Q:confine  [kən'fain]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 禁闭，监禁：to shut or keep in, especially to imprison
A: ♣例  The thief was confined in a prison. 小偷被关在监狱里。
A: ♣近  imprison, commit, confine, immure, incarcerate, jail
A: ♣反  discharge, free, liberate, release 释放
A: ♠考法1  v. 限制：to keep within limits
A: ♣例  Please confine yourself to the subject 请不要离题。
A: ♣近  limit, circumscribe, restrict
A: ♣反  exceed 超越，超过

Q:conflagration  [,kɔnflə'ɡreiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 大火： a large destructive fire
A: ♣例  All the stock was destroyed in a warehouse conflagration. 仓库里所有的货物都被一场大火烧毁了。
A: ♣近  holocaust, inferno
A: ♠考法2  n. 武装冲突，战争： a state of armed violent struggle between states, nations, or groups
A: ♣例  What began as a skirmish over disputed territory erupted into a conflagration that swept the continent. 这场席卷整个大陆的战争是由之前关于有纠纷的领土的小冲突引发的。
A: ♣近  conflict, war, warfare
A: ♣反  peace 和平；truce 休战

Q:conflate  [kən'fleit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 混合： to turn into a single mass or entity that is more or less the same throughout
A: ♣例  The movie conflates documentary footage and dramatized reenactments so seamlessly and ingeniously that viewers may not know what is real and what is not. 电影将纪实档案和娱乐性的夸张如此巧妙无缝地糅合起来，以至于观众不知道哪一部分是真实的，哪一部分是虚构的。
A: ♣近  amalgamate, combine, composite, fuse, homogenize, immingle, incorporate, integrate, interfuse, meld, merge, mingle, mix
A: ♣反  disunite, divide, part, separate, sunder 分离
A: ♣派  conflation n. 合并

Q:confluence  ['kɔnfluəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 汇合，混合：the coming together of two or more things to the same point
A: ♣例  a happy confluence of beautiful weather and spectacular scenery during our vacation 旅途中美好的天气和壮丽的景色令人欣喜的汇合
A: ♣近  conjunction
A: ♣反  divergence 分叉

Q:conform  [kən'fɔ:m]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使协调： bring into harmony or accord
A: ♣例  We have to conform this new rule with existing policy regarding student-run organizations on campus. 我们必须要让这些新规定与现行的校园学生社团的政策相协调。
A: ♣近  accommodate, attune, conciliate, coordinate, key, reconcile
A: ♣反  disharmonize 使不和谐
A: ♠考法2  vt. 调整（以适应）： to change (something) so as to make it suitable for a new use or situation
A: ♣例  I can be funny or serious, for I always conform my behavior to the situation. 我会根据情况调整举止，因此我有时候会很活泼，有时候会很严肃。
A: ♣近  acclimate, acclimatize, accommodate, adjust, condition, doctor, edit, fashion, fit, put, shape, suit, tailor
A: ♠考法3  vi. 遵照，遵从： to be obedient or compliant
A: ♣例  an independent-minded person who refuses to conform to another’s wishes 一个思想独立的拒绝遵照他人的意愿行动的人
A: ♣近  adhere, comply, follow, goose-step, mind, observe
A: ♣反  defy, disobey, rebel 不从，反抗
A: ♣派  conformist n. 墨守成规的人；conformism n. 守旧

Q:confound  [kən'faund]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使困惑： to throw into a state of mental uncertainty
A: ♣例  We are all confounded by his self-contradictory claims. 我们都对他自相矛盾的言论感到困惑
A: ♣近  baffle, bewilder, confuse, muddle, perplex, puzzle
A: ♣反  clarify 使清醒
A: ♠考法2  v. 无法区分，混淆： to fail to differentiate (a thing) from something similar or related
A: ♣例  I think you must have confounded astrology with astronomy. 我想你一定是把占星术和天文学搞混了
A: ♣近  misidentify, mistake, mix up
A: ♣反  discriminate, distinguish 区分
A: ♠考法3  v. 证明为假，证伪：to prove to be false
A: ♣例  new discoveries that confounded much of what archaeologists thought they have known about the ancient Mayan civilization 一些新的发现，它们颠覆了考古学家们长期以来对于古代玛雅文明的认识
A: ♣近  belie, debunk, falsify, disprove, rebut, refute
A: ♣反  confirm, validate, verify 证实，证明为真
A: ♣派  confounding adj. 使人困惑的

Q:confront  [kən'frʌnt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 直接对抗，直面： to come face to face with, especially with defiance or hostility
A: ♣例  You must confront your fear in order to conquer it. 要战胜你的恐惧，就必须首先敢于面对
A: ♣近  affront, brazen, encounter, face, meet
A: ♣反  dodge, duck, parry, shirk, sidestep 躲避
A: ♣派  confrontation n. 对抗，冲突

Q:congeal  [kən'dʒi:l]
A: ♠考法1  v.凝固，固化： to change from a fluid to a solid state by or as if by cold
A: ♣例  The blood had started to congeal. 血液开始凝结了
A: ♣近  coagulate, solidify, indurate, clot
A: ♣反  melt, liquefy 熔化，液化
A: ♣派  congealment n. 凝固

Q:congenial  [kən'dʒi:njəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 和善的，友好的： having or marked by agreement in feeling or action
A: ♣例  a congenial host who invited us for a feast 一位邀请我们美餐一顿的和善主人
A: ♣近  agreeable, amicable, compatible, unanimous, united
A: ♣反  discordant, incompatible 不和睦的，不和谐的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 令人愉悦的： giving pleasure or contentment to the mind or senses
A: ♣例  a couple relaxing in the congenial atmosphere of a luxury health SPA 一对沉浸在奢华水疗寓所中令人愉快气氛里的夫妻
A: ♣近  delightful, dulcet, felicitous, palatable
A: ♣反  unpleasant 令人不悦的
A: ♣派  congeniality n. 友善

Q:congruent  ['kɔŋɡruənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 和谐一致的： being in agreement, harmony, or correspondence; congruous
A: ♣例  a theory congruent with the known facts 一个与已知事实相一致的理论
A: ♣近  consonant, compatible, consistent, harmonious, accordant
A: ♣反  disagreeable 不一致的；conflicting, incompatible 冲突的，不可协调的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 全等的：coinciding exactly when superimposed
A: ♣例  These two triangles are congruent. 这两个三角形是全等的
A: ♣近  identical, exact
A: ♣反  disparate 迥异的
A: ♣派  congruity n. 和谐一致

Q:conjecture  [kən'dʒektʃə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 揣测的结果： a conclusion deduced by surmise or guesswork
A: ♣例  That was only a conjecture, not a fact. 那只是猜测而非事实
A: ♣近  speculation, supposition, surmise, theory
A: ♣反  fact 事实；axiom 公理
A: ♠考法2  v. 猜测，估计（大小、数量等）： to decide the size, amount, number, or distance of (something) without actual measurement
A: ♣近  calculate, estimate, guess, gauge
A: ♣反  prove 证明
A: ♠考法3  v. （没有依据地）认为： to form an opinion from little or no evidence
A: ♣例  conjecture that this disease is caused by a defective gene 揣测这种疾病是由基因缺陷导致的
A: ♣近  assume, imagine, presume, speculate, suppose

Q:conjure  ['kʌndʒə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 请求，恳求： to charge or entreat earnestly or solemnly
A: ♣例  I conjure you to hear my plea for mercy. 请您发发慈悲吧。‖He conjured them with his dying breath to look after his children. 临终前他恳求他们照顾他的孩子。
A: ♣近  appeal, beseech, besiege, entreat, impetrate, implore, importune, petition, plead, pray, solicit, supplicate
A: ♠考法2  vi. 在脑海中浮现： to form a mental picture of
A: ♣例  With certain flowers I instantly conjure up memories of our Caribbean honeymoon. 这些鲜花让我立即回想起加勒比海的蜜月之旅。
A: ♣近  conceive, dream, envisage, envision, fancy, fantasize, feature, ideate, image, picture, vision, visualize

Q:connive  [kə'naiv]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 暗中合作：to cooperate secretly or have a secret understanding; collude
A: ♣例  They connived to take over the throne. 他们密谋篡位
A: ♣近  conspire, intrigue, plot, collude, intrigue, machinate ,put up
A: ♠考法2  v. 纵容：假装忽视或并未采取措施阻止错误： to pretend ignorance of or fail to take action against something one ought to oppose
A: ♣例  The guards were suspected of conniving at the prisoner's escape. 警卫人员有纵容犯人越狱的嫌疑
A: ♣近  blink, disregard, overlook, wink
A: ♣反  disapprove 反对
A: ♣派  conniver n. 共谋者

Q:connoisseur  [,kɔnə'sə:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 鉴赏家（尤其艺术领域）： a person who enjoys with discrimination and appreciation of subtleties and details especially in matters of culture or art
A: ♣例  a connoisseur of wine and cigarette 烟酒鉴赏的行家
A: ♣近  aesthete, cognoscente
A: ♠考法2  n. 专家： a person with a high level of knowledge or skill in a field
A: ♣例  works that are highly prized by connoisseurs of art glass 被玻璃艺术制品专家高度赞誉的作品
A: ♣近  adept, artist, authority, maestro, master, maven, proficient, virtuoso
A: ♣反  amateur, inexpert, nonexpert 业余者，非专业者；tyro, neophyte 新手

Q:conscientious  [,kɔnʃi'enʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 仔细的，一丝不苟的： taking, showing, or involving great care and effort
A: ♣例  a conscientious researcher 一丝不苟的研究者
A: ♣近  careful, exact, heedful, meticulous, painstaking, scrupulous
A: ♣反  careless, remiss 粗心大意的
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有良心的，正直的： governed by or conforming to the dictates of conscience
A: ♣例  a conscientious police officer 一名有良心的警察
A: ♣近  conscionable, ethical, honest, moral, upright, principled, scrupulous
A: ♣反  unscrupulous 不正直的
A: ♣派  conscience n. 良心

Q:consensus  [kən'sensəs]
A: ♠考法1  n. 一致同意： general agreement; unanimity
A: ♣例  The board has finally reached a consensus. 董事会最终达成了一致
A: ♣近  accord, assent, agreement, harmony, unanimity, unison
A: ♣反  disagreement 不同意见

Q:consent  [kən'sent]
A: ♠考法1  n. 同意，赞同： the approval by someone in authority for the doing of something
A: ♣例  We had to get our neighbor’s consent in order to trim the tree from his side. 想要从邻居家那边修剪树木，我们得先得到他们的同意。
A: ♣近  allowance, approval, authorization, clearance, concurrence, granting, license, sanction, warrant
A: ♣反  interdiction, prohibition, proscription 禁止
A: ♠考法2  vi. 同意： to give assent or approval
A: ♣例  consent to being tested in her neurobiology experiment 同意作为被试参加神经生物学的实验‖refused to consent to the marriage 拒绝这桩婚事
A: ♣近  acquiesce, agree, approve, assent, subscribe
A: ♣反  dissent 反对；deny, veto 否决

Q:consequence  ['kɔnsi,kwəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 结果： something produced by a cause or necessarily following from a set of conditions
A: ♣例  negative consequences of the war 战争带来的负面后果
A: ♣近  aftermath, effect, outcome, result
A: ♣反  source, origin, cause, antecedent 根源、原因
A: ♠考法2  n. 重要性，价值：significance; importance
A: ♣例  a mistake of no consequence 不重要的错误
A: ♣近  moment, magnitude, weight
A: ♣反  triviality 琐碎的事
A: ♣派  consequential adj. 重要的

Q:conservative  [kən'sə:vətiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 守旧的，不愿改变的： favoring traditional views and values; tending to oppose change
A: ♣例  a conservative political stance 一个守旧的政治立场
A: ♣近  hidebound, reactionary, die-hard
A: ♣反  radical, aggressive 激进的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不招摇的，低调的： not excessively showy
A: ♣例  dressing in conservative outfits so as to make a good impression at job interviews 身着低调得体的套装以期待在面试时留下一个好印象
A: ♣近  muted, repressed, low-key, understated, unpretentious
A: ♣反  flamboyant, ostentatious, splashy 浮夸的，张扬的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 谨慎小心的： having or showing a close attentiveness to avoiding danger or trouble
A: ♣例  He made conservative investments, and so he wasn't ruined when the market went into a free fall. 他只做了一份谨慎保守的投资，以防市场崩盘时不至于破产
A: ♣近  alert, heedful, cautious, circumspect, gingerly, guarded, wary, vigilant
A: ♣反  heedless 不谨慎的，莽撞的

Q:conservatory  [kən'sə:və,tɔ:ri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 温室： a greenhouse for growing or displaying plants
A: ♣例  The college's conservatory is entirely devoted to cultivating and displaying orchids. 学校的温室几乎全部用于兰花的种植和观赏了
A: ♣近  greenhouse, hothouse
A: ♠考法2  n. 艺术学院： a school specializing in one of the fine arts
A: ♣例  an opera conservatory 歌剧学院

Q:conserve  [kən'sə:v]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 保存，避免浪费： to keep in a safe or sound state, especially to avoid wasteful or destructive use
A: ♣例  conserve natural resources 保护自然资源
A: ♣近  husband, preserve, save
A: ♣反  dissipate, lavish, waste, squander 浪费
A: ♣派  conservation n. 保护

Q:considerable  [kən'sidərəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （数量上）可观（而值得注意）的： sufficiently large in size, amount, or number to merit attention
A: ♣例  a considerable amount of fortune 一笔可观的财富
A: ♣近  extensive, substantial, large-scale
A: ♠考法2  adj. 值得考虑的，重要的：worth consideration; significant
A: ♣例  a considerable artist 一位举足轻重的艺术家
A: ♣近  important, significant, consequential, momentous, weighty
A: ♣反  trivial 不值一提的；insubstantial, negligible, nominal, trifling 不要重的，可忽视的

Q:consign  [kən'sain]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 转交，转移（给他人）： to give, transfer, or deliver into the hands or control of another
A: ♣例  The record shows that the deliveryman had consigned our package to a next-door neighbor. 记录显示邮递员把我们的包裹转投给隔壁邻居了。‖a writer consigned to oblivion 湮没无闻的作家
A: ♣近  commend, commit, confide, delegate, deliver, entrust, hand, recommend, repose, transfer, transmit, vest
A: ♣反  hold, keep, retain 保留

Q:console  [kən'səul]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 安慰，藉慰： to alleviate the grief, sense of loss, or trouble of; comfort
A: ♣例  Only her children could console her when her husband died. 只有她的孩子们才能安抚她失去丈夫的悲痛
A: ♣近  comfort, solace, soothe, calm
A: ♣反  distress, torment, torture 使痛苦
A: ♣派  consolation n. 安慰

Q:consolidate  [kən'sɔlideit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使联合，统一： to join together into one whole; unite
A: ♣例  consolidate several small school districts 合并了几个小的校区
A: ♣近  unify, combine, amalgamate
A: ♣反  dissolve, sunder, fragment 解散
A: ♠考法2  vt. 加固，使安全： to make firm or secure; strengthen
A: ♣例  consolidate the defense line 加固防线
A: ♣近  enhance, strengthen, fortify, reinforce
A: ♣反  abate, attenuate, undermine, weaken 削弱
A: ♣派  consolidation n. 合并；加固

Q:consonant  ['kɔnsənənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 和谐一致的：being in agreement or harmony; free from elements making for discord
A: ♣例  His performance was rarely consonant with his reputation. 他的表现与名气大不相符
A: ♣近  harmonious, compatible, congenial, consistent, congruous, correspondent
A: ♣反  conflicting, dissonant, discrepant, inconsistent 不和谐的，不一致的
A: ♣派  consonance n. 和谐，一致

Q:conspicuous  [kən'spikjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 显而易见的，吸引人的： obvious to the eye or mind, attracting attention
A: ♣例  a conspicuous change in her appearance 她外貌的明显改变
A: ♣近  apparent, clear, distinct, evident, manifest, plain, patent, noticeable
A: ♣反  hidden, concealed 隐藏的
A: ♣派  conspicuousness n. 显然性

Q:conspire  [kən'spaiɔ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 合谋，秘谋： to plan together secretly to commit an illegal or wrongful act or accomplish a legal purpose through illegal action
A: ♣例  A group of POWs conspired to abscond. 一批战俘密谋潜逃
A: ♣近  plot, contrive, connive, cogitate, intrigue, put up
A: ♣派  conspiracy n. 密谋

Q:consternation  [,kɔnstə'neiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 惊愕，恐慌，恐惧： a state of paralyzing dismay
A: ♣例  The two girls stared at each other in consternation without any idea about what to do. 两个小女孩惊恐地望着对方，显得不知所措。
A: ♣近  alarm, apprehension, dread, fear, fright, horror, terror, trepidation
A: ♣反  bravery, courage, dauntlessness, fearlessness, fortitude, intrepidity, stoutness, valor 勇气，无畏

Q:constitute  ['kɔnstitju:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 指派，任命： to appoint to an office, function, or dignity
A: ♣例  He was constituted manager. 他被任命为经理
A: ♣近  nominate, designate, authorize
A: ♣反  discharge, dismiss 撤除职务；abdicate, resign 退位，辞职
A: ♠考法2  v. 构成： make up, form, compose
A: ♣例  Water constitutes the greater part of the human body. 人体中包含着大量的水分
A: ♣近  compose, comprise, form
A: ♣派  constitution n. 构成；宪法；体格

Q:constrain  [kən'strein]
A: ♠考法1  v. 限制：to force by imposed stricture, restriction, or limitation
A: ♣例  Low temperature constrains the chemical reactivity. 低温降低了化学反应活性
A: ♣近  bridle, check, confine, imprison, restrain, trammel
A: ♣反  release 释放
A: ♠考法2  v. 使人屈服于（压力、感情等）：to cause (a person) to give in to pressure
A: ♣例  constrained by his conscience to tell the truth 受他良心的驱使而说实话
A: ♣近  coerce, compel, oblige, sandbag
A: ♣派  constrained adj. 受限的

Q:constrict  [kən'strikt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 压缩，压紧： to make smaller or narrower by or as if by binding or squeezing
A: ♣例  lives constricted by poverty 因为贫穷而拮据的生活‖Severe migraine can be treated with a drug which constricts the blood vessels. 某些能使血管收缩的药物可用来治疗严重的偏头痛。
A: ♣近  capsule, collapse, compact, condense, constringe, contract, narrow, squeeze, telescope
A: ♣反  decompress, expand, open, outspread, outstretch 扩张，使伸展

Q:constringe  [kən'strindʒ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使紧缩： to make narrow or draw together
A: ♣例  A styptic pencil stopped the bleeding by constringing the small blood vessels at the site of cut. 止血笔通过挤压伤口处的血管阻止了出血
A: ♣近  capsule, constrict, narrow, compress, squeeze, telescope
A: ♣反  broaden, expand, outstretch 扩展，扩宽

Q:construct  [kən'strʌkt]
A: ♠考法1  v. 建造，建立： to form by assembling or combining parts
A: ♣例  construct a new library 建一座新图书馆
A: ♣近  assemble, build, fabricate, make, produce, rear, set up
A: ♣反  demolish, destroy, raze 摧毁
A: ♠考法2  v. 创造，想出： to create or think of by clever use of the imagination
A: ♣例  He managed to construct a theory that fits all the facts. 他成功提出了一个与所有事实相吻合的理论
A: ♣近  contrive, devise, excogitate, fabricate, vamp up
A: ♣派  construction n. 建设，建造

Q:consummate  ['kɔnsə,meit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 专业的，有造诣的： extremely skilled and accomplished
A: ♣例  a consummate liar 一个老练的骗子
A: ♣近  accomplished, finished, virtuosic, versed, veteran
A: ♣反  amateur 业余的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无纰漏的，完美的： complete in every detail; perfect
A: ♣例  The difficult aria displayed her consummate skill. 高难度的咏叹调展示了她完美的技巧
A: ♣近  flawless, impeccable, perfect
A: ♣反  defective 有漏洞的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 最高档次的，最大规模的： of the greatest or highest degree or quantity
A: ♣近  maximum, paramount, supreme, top, utmost
A: ♣反  minimal 最少量的

Q:contagious  [kən'teidʒəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 传染的： communicable by contact; catching
A: ♣例  contagious diseases 传染病
A: ♣近  infectious, pestilent, transmissible
A: ♣反  incommunicable 不传染的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （情绪等）唤起共鸣的：exciting a similar feeling or reaction in others
A: ♣例  The enthusiasm of the new club members was contagious. 新成员的热情具有很强的感染力
A: ♣近  catching, epidemic, spreading
A: ♣派  contagiousness n. 可传染性

Q:contaminate  [kən'tæmi,neit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 染污，掺杂： to soil, stain, corrupt, or infect by contact or association
A: ♣例  Bacteria contaminated the wound. 细菌感染了伤口
A: ♣近  pollute, defile, taint, infect
A: ♣反  purify, sanitize 净化
A: ♣派  contamination n. 污染；contaminant n. 污染物

Q:contemplate  ['kɔntəm,pleit]
A: ♠考法1  vt./vi. 沉思，仔细思索： to view or consider with continued attention
A: ♣例  contemplate the vastness of the universe 沉思着宇宙的广袤无垠‖She contemplated the problem for several hours before reaching a decision. 她苦苦思索了几个小时的问题后才做出决定。
A: ♣近  cogitate, consider, deliberate, meditate, mull, perpend, pore, revolve, ruminate, study, weigh, wrestle
A: ♣反  disregard, ignore, overlook, slight 忽视
A: ♣派  contemplation n. 沉思，思索

Q:contempt  [kən'tempt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 蔑视，鄙视： open dislike for someone or something considered unworthy of one's concern or respect
A: ♣例  my undying contempt for people who abuse animals 我对于虐待动物者的无尽鄙视‖Her contempt for illiterate was obvious. 你可以很明显地看出她对文盲的鄙夷。
A: ♣近  contemptuousness, despisement, despite, despitefulness, disdain, misprision, scorn
A: ♣反  admiration, esteem, estimation, regard, respect, reverence, veneration 尊敬，敬仰
A: ♣派  contemptible adj. 可鄙的；contemptuous adj. 蔑视的

Q:contend  [kən'tend]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 竞争，争夺： to strive or vie in contest or rivalry or against difficulties
A: ♣例  two traditional rivals contending for the championship 两支争夺冠军头衔的老对手
A: ♣近  battle, fight, race, rival, vie
A: ♣反  capitulate, quit, succumb, surrender, give in 投降
A: ♠考法2  vt. 声明，声称： to state as a fact usually forcefully
A: ♣例  contended that his opponent was wrong about practically everything 宣称对手几乎在所有问题上都犯了错误‖that the his considerable experience made him the best candidate 声称因为他见多识广，所以是最佳人选
A: ♣近  affirm, allege, assert, aver, avouch, avow, declare, insist, maintain, profess, protest, purport, warrant
A: ♣反  deny, gainsay 否认

Q:content  ['kɔntent]
A: ♠考法1  v. 使满足： to appease the desires of
A: ♣例  One glass of beer every day could content him. 每天一杯啤酒就能满足他
A: ♣近  satisfy, gratify, rejoice
A: ♣反  discontent 不满足
A: ♠考法2  n. 主题： a major object of interest or concern (as in a discussion or artistic composition)
A: ♣例  Although I appreciate the poem's lyrical qualities, I don't understand its content. 虽然我很欣赏这首诗歌的节奏美，但我无法理解其主题
A: ♣近  motive, subject, theme, topic
A: ♠考法3  n. 内容，内涵： the idea that is conveyed or intended to be conveyed to the mind by language, symbol, or action
A: ♣例  The speech was filled with fancy words but devoid of any real content. 这篇演讲辞藻华丽，但是没什么实质性内容
A: ♣近  intention, purport, sense, significance
A: ♣派  contented adj. 满足的

Q:contentious  [kən'tenʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 引起争论的： likely to cause contention; argumentative
A: ♣例  contentious contents in a movie 电影中引发争论的内容
A: ♣近  controversial, disputatious, polemical, scrappy
A: ♠考法2  adj. 好争论的，好战的：exhibiting an often perverse and wearisome tendency to quarrels and disputes
A: ♣例  The Tartars were a contentious people who terrorized much of Asia and eastern Europe during the Middle Ages. 鞑靼是一个好斗的民族，他在中世纪时期统治了大片亚洲和东欧的土地
A: ♣近  belligerent, bellicose, combative, truculent, litigious, pugnacious
A: ♣反  dovish, peace-loving 爱好和平的

Q:contiguous  [kən'tiɡjuəs]

A: ♣例  contiguous nations at war 交战中的邻国
A: ♣近  adjacent, abutting, neighboring, juxtaposed, verging
A: ♣反  apart, separate 分开的
A: ♣派  contiguity 接壤

Q:contort  [kən'tɔ:t]

A: ♣例  a contorted version of the truth 被歪曲的真相
A: ♣近  deform, distort, warp, misshape
A: ♣派  contortion n. 扭曲

Q:contract  ['kɔntrækt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 契约，合同：a binding agreement between two or more persons or parties, especially one that is written and enforceable by law
A: ♣例  a billion-dollar contract from Department of Defense 来自国防部的巨额合同
A: ♣近  agreement, compact, convention, treaty
A: ♠考法2  v. 收缩：to reduce in size by drawing together; shrink
A: ♣例  contract muscle 收缩肌肉
A: ♣近  compress, condense, concentrate
A: ♣反  expand 扩展；inflate 膨胀
A: ♠考法3  v. 感染疾病：to become affected by a disease or disorder
A: ♣例  contracted a severe cold that later turned into pneumonia 染上了重感冒，最终发展成肺炎
A: ♣近  catch, get, sicken
A: ♣反  heal 痊愈
A: ♣派  contractor n. 承包商

Q:contradict  [,kɔntrə'dikt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 否认，反驳；相矛盾： to assert the contrary of; to imply the opposite or a denial of
A: ♣例  contradict a rumor 反驳谣言‖Your actions contradict your words. 你的行为和你说的话自相矛盾。
A: ♣近  deny, disaffirm, disavow, disclaim, disconfirm, disown, gainsay, negate, negative, refute, reject, repudiate
A: ♣反  acknowledge, admit, avow, concede, confirm 承认
A: ♣派  contradictory adj. 矛盾的，相反的

Q:contravene  [,kɔntrə'vi:n]
A: ♠考法1  v. 违反，反对：to violate, to oppose in argument: contradict
A: ♣例  contravene the proposal with no reservation 毫无保留地反对这一提案
A: ♣近  breach, infringe, transgress, fracture, deny, contradict, gainsay, reject
A: ♣反  uphold, support, buttress 支持；comply, conform, observe 顺从
A: ♣派  contravention n. 反对；违反，触犯

Q:contrite  ['kɔntrait]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （因为有罪孽或过错而感到）后悔悲痛的：feeling or showing sorrow and remorse for a sin or shortcoming
A: ♣例  too late to feel contrite 现在后悔已为时已晚
A: ♣近  compunctious, regrettable, remorseful, apologetic, penitent, repentant, rueful
A: ♣反  impenitent, unrepentant 不知悔改的

Q:contrived  [kən'traivd]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不自然的，刻意的：lacking in natural or spontaneous quality
A: ♣例  We are bored with the contrived applause of a TV studio audience that has been told when to clap. 摄影棚中的观众会被告知什么时候鼓掌，这种经过精心指挥的掌声让我们倍感困倦。
A: ♣近  affected, assumed, bogus, factitious, feigned, plastic, pretended, pseudo, simulated, unnatural
A: ♣反  artless, natural, spontaneous, unaffected, uncontrived, unfeigned, unforced 真诚的，不虚伪的

Q:contumacious  [,kɔntju:'meiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不服从的，倔强的： stubbornly disobedient; rebellious
A: ♣例  Contumacious insurgents refuse to talk. 不愿服从命令的叛军拒绝对话
A: ♣近  balky, contumacious, defiant, insubordinate, intractable, obstreperous, rebellious, recalcitrant, refractory, restive, ungovernable, unruly, untoward, wayward, willful
A: ♣反  obedient, docile, ruly 顺从的
A: ♣派  contumacy n. 不服从，反抗

Q:conundrum  [kə'nʌndrəm]
A: ♠考法1  n.无法解决的问题，迷： a paradoxical, insoluble, or difficult problem; a dilemma
A: ♣例  a difficult conundrum even for the experts 一道即便是专家也束手无策的难题
A: ♣近  enigma, mystery, puzzlement, riddle, secret

Q:convalesce  [,kɔnvə'les]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 渐渐康复，渐愈： to recover health and strength gradually after sickness or weakness
A: ♣例  the time needed to convalesce after an operation 手术后需要用来康复的时间
A: ♣近  heal, recover, recuperate, recoup, snap back
A: ♣反  aggravate, deteriorate, intensify 恶化，加剧

Q:convene  [kən'vi:n]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 召开，召集： to bring together in assembly by or as if by command
A: ♣例  convened the members of the council for an emergency session 召集委员会的成员进入紧急议程
A: ♣近  assemble, call, convene, muster, summon
A: ♣反  disband, dispel, disperse, dissipate, dissolve, squander 驱散，驱逐
A: ♠考法2  vi. 聚集，集合： to come together in a body
A: ♣例  The students convened in the auditorium to hear the principal’saddress. 学生们在大礼堂集合，聆听校长的致辞。
A: ♣近  cluster, collect, concenter, concentrate, conglomerate, congregate, converge, gather, meet, rendezvous
A: ♣派  convention n. 集会，大会

Q:convenience  [kən'vi:njəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 便利，方便： fitness or suitability for performing an action or fulfilling a requirement
A: ♣例  the convenience of living in megacity 住在大城市的便利
A: ♣近  accommodation, amenity, ease, facility
A: ♣反  burden, millstone 负担
A: ♣派  convenient adj. 方便的，便捷的

Q:convention  [kən'venʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 常规，习俗： general agreement on or acceptance of certain practices or attitudes
A: ♣例  By convention, north is at the top of most maps. 按照常规，北方在大多数地图上指向上
A: ♣近  custom, ritual, manner
A: ♣反  deviation 背离习俗
A: ♠考法2  n. 公约，协议： a general agreement about basic principles or procedures
A: ♣例  Under this circumstance Geneva convention does not comply. 此情形下《日内瓦公约》无效
A: ♣近  treaty, agreement, compact, contract
A: ♠考法3  n. 大会，集会： a coming together of a number of persons for a specified purpose
A: ♣例  attended a convention of mathematicians in California 参加了加州数学家的一次集会
A: ♣近  assembly, congress, council, gathering
A: ♣派  conventional adj. 传统习俗上的

Q:converge  [kən'və:dʒ]
A: ♠考法1  v.汇集，交汇于一点： tending to move toward one point or one another
A: ♣例  the main streets converge on a central square 众主干道在中央广场交汇
A: ♣近  meet, focus, concentrate
A: ♣反  diverge, deviate, digress 分离，分岔
A: ♣派  convergent adj. 汇集的；convergence n. 汇集

Q:conversant  [kən'və:sənt]
