A: ♣例  conversant with the accounting system 熟知会计系统
A: ♣近  acquaint, aware, familiar, informed, versed
A: ♣反  ignorant, unfamiliar 无知的，不熟悉的
A: ♣派  conversance n. 熟知，造诣

Q:convert  [kən'və:t]
A: ♠考法1  n. 被改变宗教信仰的人： one that is converted
A: ♣近  proselyte
A: ♠考法2  vt.使改变信仰： to bring over from one belief, view, or party to another
A: ♣例  European missionaries converted thousands to Christianity. 欧洲传教士使成百上千的人改信了基督教
A: ♣近  persuade, proselytize, bring, lead
A: ♠考法3  vt. 改变，转化： to alter the physical or chemical nature or properties of especially in manufacturing
A: ♣例  convert water into ice 将水转化成冰
A: ♣近  alter, change, transform, transfigure
A: ♣派  converter n. 转换器；convertible adj. 可转变的; n. 敞篷跑车

Q:convex  [kɔn'veks]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 凸起的： having a surface or boundary that curves or bulges outward, as the exterior of a sphere
A: ♣例  A convex function has the property that a line joining any two points on its graph lies on or above the graph. 凸函数具有如下的性质：其图像上任何两点连线的任何部分都不低于连结两点的函数曲线
A: ♣近  bulging
A: ♣反  dent, concave 凹陷的

Q:convey  [kən'vei]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 运输： to take or carry from one place to another; transport
A: ♣例  goods conveyed by sea 海路运输的货物
A: ♣近  carry, transfer, ferry, transmit
A: ♠考法2  v. 传递，交流： to impart or communicate by statement, suggestion, gesture, or appearance
A: ♣例  struggling to convey his feelings 挣扎着表达他的情感
A: ♣近  conduct, communicate, impart, pass on
A: ♣反  withhold 隐瞒

Q:conviction  [kən'vikʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 深信，确信：the state of being convinced
A: ♣例  a warrior of strong conviction 一名信念坚定的战士
A: ♣近  assurance, certainty, certitude
A: ♣反  dubiety, incredulity; uncertainty, incertitude 怀疑；不确定性
A: ♠考法2  n. 证明有罪：state of being found or proved guilty
A: ♣例  evidence that led to the suspect's conviction 证明嫌疑犯有罪的证据
A: ♣近  sentence
A: ♣反  acquittal 宣告无罪
A: ♣派  convict v. 宣判有罪

Q:convoke  [kən'vəuk]
A: ♠考法1  v. 召集开会： to bring together by or as if by summons
A: ♣例  to convoke Parliament 召开国会
A: ♣近  assemble, convene, summon, muster
A: ♣反  adjourn 休会

Q:convoluted  ['kɔnvə,lu:tid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 复杂的，费解的： complicated; intricate
A: ♣例  a convoluted way of describing a simple mechanism 用令人费解的方法解释一个简单的原理
A: ♣近  complex, knotty, involved, sophisticated, twisted, tangled, labyrinthine
A: ♣反  straightforward 直截了当的

Q:convulsion  [kən'vʌlʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 痉挛（强烈的、无法控制的肌肉收缩）： an abnormal violent and involuntary contraction of the muscles
A: ♣例  Convulsions are usually accompanied by loss of consciousness. 痉挛常常伴随着失去意识
A: ♠考法2  n. 骚乱： a violent disturbance
A: ♣例  a regime in convulsion 动荡中的政权
A: ♣近  commotion, ferment, tumult, upheaval, clamor, tempest, uproar
A: ♣反  serenity, tranquility 宁静
A: ♣派  convulse v. 剧烈震动；痉挛

Q:coop  [ku:p]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 监禁，困于…之中： to confine in a restricted and often crowded area
A: ♣例  Those restless kids were cooped up in the house on a rainy. 雨天那些好动的孩子们被困在房子里
A: ♣近  box, cage, corral, encage, enclose, envelop, fence, hedge, immure, include, pen, wall
A: ♣反  free, liberate, release 释放

Q:copious  ['kəupiəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj.丰富的，大量的： large in quantity; abundant
A: ♣例  a copious harvest 大丰收
A: ♣近  plentiful, abundant, ample, gushing
A: ♣反  sparse, dearth, scant 稀少的，缺乏的

Q:coquette  [kɔ'ket]
A: ♠考法1  n. 调情的女子： a woman who makes teasing sexual or romantic overtures; a flirt
A: ♣例  A coquette though she might appear to be at first, Violetta from Verdi’s La Traviata is actually yearning for true love. 乍看之下，威尔第歌剧《茶花女》中的薇奥莱塔是一个轻浮的女子，但实际上她渴望真爱
A: ♣近  vamp, flirt
A: ♠考法2  v. 不认真对待： to deal with something playfully rather than seriously
A: ♣例  interested only in coquetting with her, not marrying her 只想与她保持暧昧关系，而不结婚
A: ♣近  trifle, dally, flirt, mess around
A: ♣派  coquet v. 不认真对待，调情；coquettish adj. 调情的

Q:cordon  ['kɔ:dən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 警戒线： a line or ring of police, soldiers, or vehicles preventing people from entering an area
A: ♣例  a cordon of police 警察围成的警戒线
A: ♣近  perimeter
A: ♠考法2  v. 围城一道防线： to form a protective or restrictive cordon around
A: ♣例  cordoned off the area around the explosion scene 在爆炸现场周边设置警戒线
A: ♣近  close, obstruct, block

Q:cornucopia  [,kɔ:nju'kəupjə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 大量：an overflowing store; an abundance
A: ♣例  a cornucopia of employment opportunities 大量的就业机会
A: ♣近  plentitude, plethora, wealth, profusion, affluence
A: ♣反  lack, pittance, deficiency 缺乏，少量

Q:coronation  [,kɔ:rə'neiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 加冕，加冕礼：the act or ceremony of crowning a sovereign or the sovereign's consort
A: ♣例  Two different musical pieces by Mozart (a piano concerto and a mass) are both titled “Coronation”. 莫扎特两部不同的音乐作品（一部钢琴协奏曲和一部弥撒）都被称作“加冕”
A: ♣近  enthronement, crowning
A: ♣反  abdication 退位
A: ♣派  coronate v. 加冕

Q:corporeal  [kɔ:'pɔ:riəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 肉体的： not spiritual
A: ♣例  corporeal suffering 肉体上的折磨
A: ♣近  bodily, carnal, corporal, somatic, physical, fleshly
A: ♣反  spiritual 精神上的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 有形的，实体的： not immaterial or intangible
A: ♣近  material, physical, substantial, sensible, tangible
A: ♣反  intangible, disembodied, immaterial 无形的，无实体的

Q:correlate  ['kɔ:rə,leit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使…相关联： to establish a mutual or reciprocal relation between
A: ♣例  a demanding father who always correlated success with hard work 一个总将成功和辛勤工作关联起来的严格父亲‖In this work, we correlate the simulation in the lab and the observation in the field to examine the validity of our theory. 本文中，我们将实验室的模拟结果和场地外的观测数据联系起来以验证理论的真实性。
A: ♣近  connect, identify, link, relate
A: ♣反  separate 分离
A: ♣派  correlation n. 关联，关系

Q:corroborate  [kə'rɔbə,reit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 用证据或权威证实： to support with evidence or authority; make more certain
A: ♣例  new evidence to corroborate the defendant's story 能证实被告的故事的新证据
A: ♣近  confirm, authenticate, justify, substantiate, validate, verify
A: ♣反  controvert, contradict, deny 反驳，否认
A: ♠考法2  vt. 提供证据，支持：to provide evidence or information for (as a claim or idea)
A: ♣例  My personal experience does not corroborate your faith in the essential goodness of people . 我的经历可不赞同你关于“人性本善”的信念
A: ♣近  back, bolster, buttress, reinforce, support
A: ♣派  corroboration n. 证实

Q:corrosive  [kə'rəusiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 腐蚀性的： tending to destroy slowly by chemical action
A: ♣例  Concentrated sulfur acid is highly corrosive. 浓硫酸有极强的腐蚀性
A: ♣近  erosive, caustic
A: ♣反  noncorrosive 无腐蚀性的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 讽刺性的： bitingly sarcastic
A: ♣例  corrosive satire 讽刺性的作品
A: ♣近  sarcastic, barbed, acerbic, satiric, acrid, barbed, mordant, tart
A: ♣派  corrosion n. 侵蚀

Q:corrugated  ['kɔruɡeitid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 褶皱的： shaped into a series of regular folds that look like waves
A: ♣例  corrugated paper 褶皱的纸
A: ♣近  wrinkled, creased, folded
A: ♣反  smooth 光滑的
A: ♣派  corrugation n. 褶皱，折痕

Q:cosmopolitan  [,kɔzmə'pɔlitən]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有世界性眼光的，包容的： having worldwide rather than limited or provincial scope or bearing
A: ♣例  a cosmopolitan traveler 云游四海的旅行者
A: ♣近  universal, catholic, global, worldwide
A: ♣反  insular, provincial 狭隘的
A: ♣派  cosmopolitism n. 世界主义，天下主义

Q:cosset  ['kɔsit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 宠爱： to treat as a pet; pamper
A: ♣近  caress, cuddle, dote, pet, mollycoddle
A: ♣反  slight 怠慢；abuse 虐待
A: ♣派  cosseted adj. 被宠坏的

Q:countenance  ['kauntənəns]
A: ♠考法1  v. 容忍： to put up with (something painful or difficult)
A: ♣例  The college administration will not countenance cheating. 大学管理部门决不容忍作弊的存在
A: ♣近  abide, endure, stand, stomach, wear
A: ♠考法2  v. 赞成，推崇： to have a favorable opinion of
A: ♣例  I don't countenance such behavior in children of any age. 对于任何年龄的孩子，我都不推崇那种行为
A: ♣近  accept, favor, subscribe
A: ♣反  disapprove, frown 表示反对
A: ♠考法3  n. 沉着，冷静： evenness of emotions or temper
A: ♣例  The doctor’s purposeful countenance was in stark contrast to everyone else's hysteria. 医生带有目的性的沉着与他人的歇斯底里形成了巨大的反差
A: ♣近  aplomb, calmness, composure, sangfroid, serenity
A: ♣反  agitation, discomposure, perturbation 急躁，焦虑

Q:counterfeit  ['kauntəfit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 仿制的，假冒的： made in imitation of something else with intent to deceive
A: ♣例  counterfeit money 假币
A: ♣近  forged, bogus, spurious, pseudo, feigned, artificial, phony
A: ♣反  authentic, genuine 真实的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 仿制： to make a fraudulent replica of
A: ♣例  counterfeit the signature 仿造签名
A: ♣近  copy, forge, imitate, simulate, mimic
A: ♠考法3  vt. 伪装成：to present a false appearance of
A: ♣例  to counterfeit a happy expression while visiting a sick friend 在看望患病的朋友时装出一副高兴的样子
A: ♣近  affect, assume, fake, pretend

Q:countermand  [,kauntə'mɑ:nd]

A: ♣例  countermand an order 撤销命令
A: ♣近  annul, repeal, rescind, revoke, cancel
A: ♣反  approve, permit, sanction 批准

Q:counterpart  ['kauntə,pɑ:t]
A: ♠考法1  n. （地位、功能）对等的人或物： one having the same function or characteristics as another
A: ♣例  She worked with her counterpart in the other office to get the job done. 她与另一个办公室的同职人员一起努力完成这项工作。‖U.S. presidents and his British counterpart 美国总统和英国首相
A: ♣近  coequal, compeer, coordinate, equivalent, fellow, like, match, parallel, peer, rival

Q:counterproductive  [,kauntəprə'dʌktiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 反效果的，阻碍预期目标的： not producing or tending to hinder the attainment of a desired goal
A: ♣例  Violence as a means to achieve an end is counterproductive. (W. E. Brock) 用暴力来实现目标往往是事与愿违的。——W. E. 布洛克‖His uncontrollable anger is very counterproductive to his attempt at saving his marriage. 他无法自控的愤怒只会对他拯救婚姻的企图起反作用。
A: ♣近  feckless, hamstrung, ineffective, ineffectual, inefficacious, inefficient, inexpedient
A: ♣反  effective, effectual, efficacious, efficient, expedient, operant 行之有效的

Q:court  [kɔ:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt./n. 追求，献殷勤：to seek the affections of
A: ♣例  court the young lady by bring her flowers every day 通过每天给年轻女孩送花追求女孩
A: ♣近  woo, pursue, invite
A: ♣反  spurn, snub 摒弃，怠慢
A: ♣派  courteous adj. 彬彬有礼的

Q:courteous  ['kə:tjəs]

A: ♣例  Their customer service department always gives courteous responses, even to rude people. 哪怕是对粗鲁的消费者，他们的客服部门总是用一种非常有礼貌的态度回复。
A: ♣近  civil, civilized, couth, genteel, gracious, mannerly, suave, urbane, well-bred
A: ♣反  discourteous, ill-bred, ill-mannered, impertinent, impolite, impudent, insolent, rude 粗鲁的，不礼貌的
A: ♣派  courtesy n. 礼貌，恭谦

Q:covert  ['kʌvət]

A: ♣近  concealment, hermitage, hideaway, nest, lair

A: ♣派  covet v. 觊觎，贪婪

Q:coy  [kɔi]

A: ♣例  Not wanting him to know that she was interested in him, she acted very coy at the dance. 她在舞会上故意装得很娇羞的样子，不想让他知道她喜欢他。
A: ♣近  coquettish, demure, kittenish
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不愿与人交往的，内向的： tending to avoid people and social situations
A: ♣例  She was modest without being coy. 她很低调，但又不至于内向。
A: ♣近  backward, bashful, diffident, introverted, modest, recessive, retiring, sheepish, shy, withdrawn
A: ♣反  extroverted, immodest, outgoing 外向的

Q:credence  ['kri:dəns]

A: ♣反  doubt, skepticism 怀疑

Q:credible  ['kredəbl]

A: ♣例  It’s not perfect, but is at least a credible explanation. 尽管还不算完美，但这好歹也算是可信的解释了。‖a credible account of an accident 事故的可靠报道

A: ♣反  implausible, improbable, incredible, unbelievable, unlikely 不可信的，难以置信的
A: ♣派  credibility n. 可靠性，公信力

Q:credit  ['kredit]

A: ♣例  I give full credit to this report on the prevalence of cheating among college students today. 我非常相信这则有关大学中作弊成风的报道。

A: ♣反  disbelief, doubt, dubiety, incertitude 不信任，不确定

A: ♣反  denunciation, excoriation, rebuke, reprimand, reproach, reproof, stricture 谴责，责难

Q:creep  [kri:p]

A: ♣反  scurry, run 快步走，跑

A: ♣近  crawl, grovel, slide, slither
A: ♣反  swagger 昂首阔步

Q:crescendo  [kri'ʃendəu]

A: ♣反  decrescendo （声音）渐弱
A: ♠考法2  n. （渐强之后到达的）顶峰：the peak of a gradual increase
A: ♣例  complaints about stifling smog conditions reach a crescendo 对于让人窒息的烟雾的抱怨到达了顶峰
A: ♣近  apex, acme, apogee, climax, peak, pinnacle, summit, zenith
A: ♣反  nadir 最低点

Q:crow  [krəu]

A: ♠考法2  vi. 自鸣得意： to praise or express pride in one's own possessions, qualities, or accomplishments often to excess
A: ♣例  He is already crowing over his victory. 他已经在那里为自己的胜利而自鸣得意了。
A: ♣近  blow, brag, swagger, vapor, vaunt

Q:cryptic  ['kriptik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 秘密的： secret or occult
A: ♣例  cryptic message 秘密的信息
A: ♣近  covert, furtive, secret, stealthy
A: ♣反  public, open 公开的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 含义模糊的： having or seeming to have a hidden or ambiguous meaning
A: ♣例  The senator made some cryptic explanations about the military operations. 参议员就军事行动给出了含糊其辞的解释
A: ♣近  ambiguous, equivocal, nebulous, obscure, unclear, vague
A: ♣反  clear, explicit, obvious, plain 清晰的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 超出理解能力的： being beyond one's powers to know, understand, or explain
A: ♣例  puzzled by the cryptic e-mail message left on his computer 被他电脑里让人费解的电子邮件而迷惑
A: ♣近  arcane, enigmatic, impenetrable, inscrutable, mystic, occult, uncanny
A: ♣反  comprehendible, understandable 可以理解的

Q:culpable  ['kʌlpəbl]

A: ♣例  culpable behaviors 值得谴责的行为
A: ♣近  blameworthy, censurable, guilty, reprehensible, sinful, reproachable
A: ♣反  inculpable, innocent 无罪的
A: ♣派  culpability n. 有罪

A: ♣例  cultivate vegetables 种植蔬菜
A: ♣近  grow, breed, produce, raise, develop, nurture
A: ♣反  balk, frustrate, thwart 阻碍
A: ♣派  cultivation n. 栽培

Q:cumbersome  ['kʌmbəsəm]

A: ♣例  a cumbersome piece of machinery 一件笨重的机器
A: ♣近  unhandy, ponderous, heavy, unwieldy, onerous ,thorny
A: ♣反  light, weightless 轻的；handy 容易处理的

Q:cunning  ['kʌniŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 狡猾的： marked by or given to artful subtlety and deceptiveness
A: ♣例  cunning tactics 狡猾的战术
A: ♣近  artful, crafty, devious, foxy, sly, tricky, wily
A: ♣反  artless, na?ve, unsophisticated 天真无邪的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （手工）灵巧的： skillful with the hands
A: ♣例  Only the most cunning cabinetmaker could have crafted such a beautifully proportioned chest of drawers. 只有手工超凡的家具工才能打造出如此精致协调的衣柜
A: ♣近  clever, deft, handy
A: ♣反  heavy-handed, ham-handed 笨拙的
A: ♠考法3  n. 欺诈，欺骗： the inclination or practice of misleading others through lies or trickery
A: ♣例  used cunning and subterfuge to work her way up the corporate ladder 通过欺骗在公司中步步攀升
A: ♣近  artifice, deception, fraud
A: ♣反  ingenuousness, sincerity 真诚

Q:curmudgeon  [kə:'mʌdʒən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 脾气坏的爱抱怨的人： an irritable and complaining person
A: ♣例  a terrible old curmudgeon 一个坏脾气老头
A: ♣近  crosspatch, fusser, griper, grouser, growler, grumbler, whiner
A: ♣反  agreeable person 令人愉快的人

Q:cursory  ['kə:səri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 匆忙的，不注意细节的： acting or done with excessive or careless speed
A: ♣例  a cursory glance at the headline 匆匆地瞥了一眼标题
A: ♣近  headlong, overhasty, pell-mell, precipitate, precipitous, rash
A: ♣反  fastidious, thorough, deliberate, unhurried, unrushed 极关注细节的，彻底的，不匆忙的

Q:curt  [kə:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 言词简略、直接（以至显得粗鲁）的： being or characterized by direct, brief, and potentially rude speech or manner
A: ♣例  his curt reply 他简略而略显粗鲁的回答
A: ♣近  abrupt, bluff, brusque, downright, unceremonious
A: ♣反  circuitous, mealymouthed 迂回的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 言简意赅的： marked by the use of few words to convey much information or meaning
A: ♣例  on a daily basis she e-mailed to her commanders curt reports on the situation 她每天向长官做简短汇报
A: ♣近  aphoristic, compendious, elliptical, laconic, pithy, sententious, succinct, terse
A: ♣反  diffuse, long-winded, prolix, verbose 冗长啰嗦的

Q:curtail  [kə:'teil]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 缩短，削减： to make less in extent or duration
A: ♣例  curtail your holiday 缩短你的假期
A: ♣近  abbreviate, abridge, syncopate, truncate, cut back
A: ♣反  elongate, protract, prolong, extend, lengthen 延长

Q:cynic  ['sinik]
A: ♠考法1  n. 愤世嫉俗者： a person who believes all people are motivated by selfishness.
A: ♣例  A cynic might think that the governor visited the hospital just to gain votes. 一个愤青认为州长去医院探视仅仅是为了拉票。
A: ♣近  misanthrope, naysayer, pessimist

Q:dabble  ['dæbl]
A: ♠考法1  v. 浅尝辄止： to work or involve oneself superficially or intermittently especially in a secondary interest
A: ♣例  dabble in arts 对艺术稍有涉猎
A: ♣反  dedicate, specialize 投入，专门研究
A: ♣派  dabbler vi. 涉猎者，浅尝辙止者： one not deeply engaged in or concerned with something
A: ♣例  He's not a dedicated musician, just a dabbler. 他并不是专门的音乐家, 只不过是个业馀爱好者
A: ♣反  specialist 专家

Q:daft  [dɑ:ft]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 神经错乱的： having or showing a very abnormal or sick state of mind
A: ♣例  The king was clearly daft, talking to trees and rocks. 国王俨然已经疯了，对着树和石头说话。
A: ♣近  bedlam, demented, deranged, lunatic, psychotic, unbalanced, unsound
A: ♣反  balanced, sane 头脑正常的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不明智的： showing or marked by a lack of good sense or judgment
A: ♣例  a daft plan, doomed to wretched failure and merciless ridicule 一个不明智的决定，最终难逃悲催的结局和无情的嘲讽的下场
A: ♣近  fatuous, featherheaded, nonsensical, preposterous, senseless
A: ♣反  judicious, prudent, sagacious, sapient, wise 明智的

Q:dais  ['deiis]
A: ♠考法1  n. 主席台， 嘉宾席： a raised platform, as in a lecture hall, for speakers or honored guests.
A: ♣例  the speaker took his place at the front of the dais 演讲者在主席台就坐
A: ♣近  podium, rostrum, tribune

Q:dally  ['dæli]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 虚度时光： to spend time doing nothing
A: ♣例  I kept dallying at my desk until I couldn't put off doing my work any longer. 我一直浪费时间直到作业不能再拖了。
A: ♣近  dawdle, loll, lounge, hang around
A: ♠考法2  v. 玩乐： to engage in activity for amusement
A: ♣例  he spent his college years dallying, seemingly determined to acquire as little knowledge as possible 他在大学里面尽情玩乐，不学习
A: ♣近  disport, frolic, recreate, rollick, sport
A: ♠考法3  v. 慢吞吞，磨磨蹭蹭： to move or act slowly
A: ♣例  don't dally on the way to the interview 别在去面试的路上磨磨蹭蹭
A: ♣近  crawl, creep, dillydally, drag, lag, linger, loiter, tarry
A: ♣反  dash, hasten, scoot, scurry

Q:damn  [dæm]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （在道德上）谴责： to declare to be morally wrong or evil
A: ♣例  a cleric who damned gambling and strong drink 一个严厉谴责赌博和酗酒的牧师
A: ♣近  anathematize, censure, decry, denounce, execrate, reprehend, reprobate
A: ♣反  bless, eulogize, exalt, extol, glorify, laud, praise 赞颂
A: ♠考法2  adv. 非常地，极其地： to a great degree
A: ♣例  Let's have a damn good party. 让我们尽情享乐狂欢吧。
A: ♣近  deadly, desperately, exceedingly, extremely, greatly, heavily, highly, incredibly, really, seriously, very
A: ♣反  little, negligibly, nominally, slightly, somewhat 一点点，稍微

Q:dampen  ['dæmpən]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （特指稍稍地）弄湿： to make or become slightly or moderately wet
A: ♣例  dampen a paper towel with water and use it to clean up the mess 把纸巾弄湿用来清扫
A: ♣近  bedew, damp, douse , drench, impregnate, saturate, soak, souse, steep
A: ♣反  dehydrate, desiccate, dry, parch, scorch, sear 使脱水，烤干
A: ♠考法2  vt. 抑制，压抑（感情，精力等），泼冷水： to check or diminish the feeling, activity or vigor of
A: ♣例  Nothing could dampen their enthusiasm. 没有什么能扼杀他们的激情。‖The oppressive heat dampened our spirits. 让人难以忍受的酷暑让我们精神不振。
A: ♣近  benumb, blunt, castrate, deaden, devitalize, enervate, geld, lobotomize, petrify
A: ♣反  brace, energize, enliven, invigorate, quicken, stimulate, vitalize, vivify 使充满活力

Q:damper  ['dæmpə]

A: ♣反  ameliorator 促进物

Q:dandy  ['dændi]

A: ♣反  atrocious, awful, execrable, lousy, pathetic, wretched

Q:daredevil  ['dεə,devəl]

A: ♣反  circumspect, guarded, heedful, prudent, wary 小心谨慎的

A: ♣近  foolhardy, irresponsible, harum-scarum
A: ♣反  responsible 负责任的

Q:dart  [dɑ:t]

A: ♣例  The dog darted across the street. 狗飞奔过马路。
A: ♣近  flicker, flitter, flutter
A: ♠考法2  n. 公开侮辱： an act or expression showing scorn and usually intended to hurt another's feelings
A: ♣例  The darts flew fast and furiously when the two former lovers bumped into each other at the party. 旧情人在party上偶遇，立马开始激烈的人身攻击。
A: ♣近  affront, barb, offense, sarcasm, slight, slur

Q:dashing  ['dæʃiŋ]

Q:dated  ['deitid]

A: ♣反  contemporary, current, modern, recent 当前的，现代的

Q:dawdle  ['dɔ:dl]

A: ♣近  gridlock, halt, impasse, logjam, stalemate, standoff, standstill
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使陷入僵局，使停顿： to bring or come to a deadlock

Q:deadpan  ['ded'pæn]

A: ♣近  catatonic, expressionless, impassive, inexpressive, stolid, vacant

Q:dearth  [də:θ]

Q:debark  [di'bɑ:k]

A: ♣近  land
A: ♣反  embark 上船，装货

Q:debase  [di'beis]

A: ♣例  our failure to win a single game completely debased 我们一场未胜的战绩彻底让我们的形象一落千丈
A: ♣近  abase, debauch, degrade, demean, demoralize, deprave, deteriorate, profane, subvert, vitiate
A: ♣反  aggrandize, canonize, deify, elevate, exalt, ennoble 使神圣

Q:debilitate  [di'biliteit]

A: ♣近  devitalize, enervate, enfeeble, prostrate, sap
A: ♣反  invigorate, fortify, strengthen, beef up 使有活力，加强

Q:debonair  [,debə'nεə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无忧无虑的，不在乎的： having or showing freedom from worries or troubles
A: ♣例  His debonair dismissal of my inquiry concerning his financial situation led me to believe that nothing was wrong. 对于我有关他个人理财的问题，他表现得毫不在乎，这使我相信没有问题。
A: ♣近  blithe, carefree, gay, insouciant, lighthearted, lightsome, slaphappy, unconcerned
A: ♣反  careworn 焦虑的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 风度翩翩的： having or showing very polished and worldly manners
A: ♣例  The debonair gentleman charmed all of the ladies in the room. 风度翩翩的绅士吸引了在场的所有女士。
A: ♣近  civilized, graceful, polished, refined, smooth, sophisticated, suave, svelte, urbane
A: ♣反  boorish, churlish, loutish, uncouth 粗鲁的，粗野的；clumsy, gauche, graceless 笨拙的

Q:debris  ['deibri:]

A: ♣近  dross, dust, litter, offal, refuse, effluvium junk

Q:debunk  [di:'bʌŋk]

A: ♣例  debunk a supposed miracle drug 揭穿所谓的灵丹妙药的真面目
A: ♣近  uncloak, uncover, undress, unmask, show up
A: ♣反  camouflage, cloak, disguise, mask 继续伪装，掩盖
A: ♠考法2  v. 证明为假： to prove to be false
A: ♣例  a Web site that assiduously debunks urban legends 一个不遗余力证明假传闻的网站
A: ♣近  belie, confound, confute, discredit, falsify, rebut, refute
A: ♣反  confirm, establish, validate, verify 证明为真

A: ♣反  farewell performance 告别演出

Q:decadence  ['dekədəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 衰落，颓废： a process, condition, or period of deterioration or decline, a change to a lower state or level
A: ♣例  The book condemns the decadence of modern society. 该书批判了现代社会的堕落。
A: ♣近  degeneracy, degeneration, degradation, deterioration, downfall, eclipse
A: ♣反  ascent, rise, upswing 提高，提升

Q:decadent  ['dekədənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 堕落的，腐败的： having or showing lowered moral character or standards
A: ♣例  Opponents of gambling casinos claim that gambling is a decadent form of entertainment. 赌场的反对者们宣称赌博是一种堕落腐化的娱乐形式。
A: ♣近  debased, debauched, degenerate, depraved, dissolute, perverse, perverted, reprobate, warped
A: ♣反  pure, uncorrupted 纯净的，未腐化的
A: ♠考法2  n. 放纵的人： a person whose life is devoted to luxury and sensual pleasures
A: ♣例  a decadent who squandered her once considerable family fortune 一个挥霍了大量的家族财富的人
A: ♣近  debauchee, hedonist, libertine, sensualist, sybarite, profligate
A: ♣反  ascetic 苦行者，禁欲者
A: ♠考法3  n. 道德上堕落的人： a person in a condition or process of mental or moral decay
A: ♣例  avant-garde artists who were scorned by the bourgeoisie as talentless decadents 被中产阶级鄙视为没有才华的堕落者的前卫艺术家
A: ♣近  deviate
A: ♣反  saint 圣人

Q:decant  [di'kænt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 轻轻倒出： to pour off (wine, for example) without disturbing the sediment
A: ♣例  The bottles were uncorked and the wine was decanted an hour before the meal. 瓶塞被打开，美酒在正餐前一小时倒出

Q:decipher  [di'saifə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 破译： to read or interpret (ambiguous, obscure, or illegible matter).
A: ♣例  we deciphered the hidden message to find out when we were supposed to meet 破解了暗语后，发现我们要碰头
A: ♣近  break, crack, decrypt, decode
A: ♣反  cipher, encipher, encode, encrypt 加密
A: ♠考法2  v. 有清晰想法，理解，解读： to have a clear idea of
A: ♣例  a convoluted thriller, the plot of which I was never able to actually decipher 一部错综复杂的恐怖电影，情节我一直没有理解
A: ♣近  apprehend, perceive, recognize, seize, sense, make out

Q:decode  [,di:'kəud]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 解码： to change (as a secret message) from code into ordinary language
A: ♣例  the agents worked into the night to decode the intercepted message from the enemy spy 情报人员夜以继日地破解从敌方间谍拦截的信息
A: ♣近  break, crack, decipher, decrypt
A: ♠考法2  v. 有清晰想法，理解,解读： to have a clear idea of
A: ♣例  a convoluted thriller, the plot of which I was never able to actually decipher 一部错综复杂的恐怖电影，情节我一直没有理解
A: ♣近  apprehend, perceive, recognize, seize, sense ,make out

Q:decorum  [di'kɔ:rəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 礼仪，得体： appropriateness of behavior or conduct; propriety
A: ♣例  high standards of decorum are usually required when attending the opera 去听歌剧的时候需要遵守高标准的礼节
A: ♣近  form, propriety
A: ♣反  impropriety, indecency 不得体
A: ♣派  decorous adj. 有礼貌的： marked by propriety and good taste
A: ♣例  decorous behavior 得体的举止
A: ♣反  mangy, unseemly 低贱的，不得体的
A: ♣派  indecorous 不合礼节的
A: ♣反  proper 适当的

Q:decrepit  [di'krepit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 虚弱的，衰老的，破旧的： weakened, worn out, impaired, or broken down by old age, illness
A: ♣例  a decrepit old man 一个虚弱的老年人
A: ♣反  vigorous, sturdy, sound, robust, hale 健壮的

Q:decry  [di'krai]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 强烈反对，否定： to express strong disapproval of
A: ♣例  Scientists were quick to decry the claims of the psychic. 通灵者的说法很快就遭到了科学家的反对。‖decry the excessive emphasis on sex 谴责对于性的过分重视
A: ♣近  belittle, denigrate, denounce, deprecate, depreciate, derogate, disapprove, dismiss, disparage, minimize
A: ♣反  acclaim, applaud, exalt, extol, glorify, laud, magnify, praise 表扬，称颂

Q:default  [di'fɔ:lt]
A: ♠考法1  v. 拖欠(债务)： to fail to pay financial debts, the nonperformance of an assigned or expected action
A: ♣例  default on a loan 拖欠贷款
A: ♣近  delinquency, dereliction, misprision, nonfeasance, oversight
A: ♣反  pay one's debt 偿还债务

Q:defer  [di'fə:]
A: ♠考法1  v. 推迟，延期： to put off; postpone; defer
A: ♣例  we agreed to defer a discussion of the issue 我们决定推迟问题的讨论
A: ♣近  delay, remit, shelve, hold off, hold over, lay over, put off
A: ♣反  exigent 紧急的
A: ♠考法2  vi. 遵从： to submit to another's wishes, opinion, or governance usually through deference or respect
A: ♣例  defer to her father’s wishes 听从她父亲的意愿

Q:deference  ['defərəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 尊崇，顺从： a readiness or willingness to yield to the wishes of others
A: ♣例  He is shown much deference by his colleagues. 他的同事很尊敬他。
A: ♣近  acquiescence, compliancy, docility, obedience, submissiveness
A: ♣反  contempt, defiance, disobedience, intractability, recalcitrance 轻视，不服从
A: ♣派  deferential adj. 表示尊重的，恭敬的：showing or expressing deference
A: ♣反  imperious, impudent 专横无礼的

Q:deficiency  [di'fiʃənsi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 缺乏，不足： the quality or state of being deficient: inadequate
A: ♣例  there is a deficiency of fresh food in the diet of many of the working poor 很多劳工阶层的饮食都缺乏新鲜食物
A: ♣近  want, dearth, deficit, famine, paucity, scantiness, scarcity
A: ♣反  surfeit, abundance, adequacy, amplitude, opulence, sufficiency 过度，充足

Q:defile  [di'fail]
A: ♠考法1  n.（山间）小道： a narrow passage or gorge
A: ♣例  They climbed up the mountain through a defile. 他们通过一条小路爬到山上。
A: ♠考法2  v. 亵渎： to treat (a sacred place or object) shamefully or with great disrespect
A: ♣例  art conservators were careful not to do anything that might defile the holy relic 公物管理员要防止任何玷污圣迹的行为
A: ♣近  profane, violate
A: ♠考法3  v. 不能被使用： to make unfit for use by the addition of something harmful or undesirable
A: ♣例  supplies of meat that had been defiled by maggots 肉已经生蛆了，不能再食用了
A: ♣近  befoul, foul, pollute, taint
A: ♣反  decontaminate, purify 使纯净

Q:deflect  [di'flekt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使偏斜，使转向： to turn aside especially from a straight course or fixed direction
A: ♣例  The goalie deflected the ball with his hands. 守门员用双手将球击出。‖They are trying to deflect the public attention from the troubled economy. 他们试图将公众的注意力从经济的困境中移开。
A: ♣近  divert, redirect, swing, veer, wheel, whip
A: ♣派  deflection n. 偏转，偏离

Q:defray  [di'frei]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 支付： to undertake the payment of
A: ♣例  The government has committed billions toward defraying the costs of the war. 政府为战争付出了成百上千亿元的代价。‖I don’t have sufficient fund to defray the expense. 我身上的现金还不够埋单。
A: ♣近  disburse, expend, pay
A: ♣反  acquire, earn, gain, garner, procure, realize, secure, win 获得，获取；charge 收取

Q:deft  [deft]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 灵巧的，熟练的： characterized by facility and skill
A: ♣例  He finished off the painting with a few deft strokes of the brush. 他简单熟练的几笔便完成了画作。
A: ♣近  cunning, adroit, dexterous, expert, masterful, virtuoso
A: ♣反  awkward, maladroit, ham-handed, amateur, artless, unprofessional, unskillful 笨拙的，不精通的

Q:defuse  [,di:'fju:z]

A: ♣例  defuse the crisis 平息危机
A: ♣反  foment 煽动

Q:defy  [di'fai]

A: ♣例  defy the court 蔑视法庭
A: ♣近  mock, rebel, oppose, confront
A: ♣反  acquiesce, obey, comply with, conform to 默默接受，遵守
A: ♣反  capitulate to, submit to, succumb to, surrender to, yield to 屈服

Q:dehydrate  [,di:'haidreit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 去除水分，（使）干燥： to remove water from; make anhydrous
A: ♣例  bought a dehumidifier in order to dehydrate the damp basement 买了一个减湿器来给地下室除湿
A: ♣近  dampen, desiccate, parch, scorch, sear
A: ♣反  hydrate, saturate with water, reconstitute 用水浸润
A: ♠考法2  v. 使失去活力或者味道： to deprive of vitality or savor
A: ♣例  years of being trapped in a loveless marriage had dehydrated his spirit 多年不幸的婚姻消磨了他的活力
A: ♣近  deaden, devitalize, enervate, petrify, sap
A: ♣反  brace, energize, enliven, invigorate, vitalize, vivify 使生机勃勃

Q:deify  ['di:ifai]
A: ♠考法1  v. 把…当作神来崇拜： to offer honor or respect to (someone) as a divine power
A: ♣例  some ancient pagans deified such objects of nature as trees and rivers 很多古代的异教徒拿一些自然事物比如树木，河流来崇拜
A: ♣近  glorify, revere, venerate
A: ♠考法2  v. 过分喜爱： to love or admire too much
A: ♣例  materialistic people who deify money 那些眼里只有钱的物质之人
A: ♣近  adore, adulate, canonize, dote
A: ♠考法3  v. 尊敬尊崇： to assign a high status or value to
A: ♣例  Valentino was virtually deified by legions of female fans. 瓦伦蒂诺被大批女粉丝崇拜。
A: ♣近  aggrandize, canonize, dignify, ennoble, glorify, magnify
A: ♣反  abase, degrade, demean, humble, humiliate 贬低，羞辱
A: ♣派  deification n. 崇拜
A: ♣反  debasement 贬低

Q:deign  [dein]
A: ♠考法1  vi. （不情愿地）屈尊，俯就： to condescend reluctantly and with a strong sense of the affront to one's superiority that is involved
A: ♣例  I would never deign to answer that absurd accusation. 我根本不屑于去解释那样一个荒谬的指责。
A: ♣近  condescend, stoop

Q:deject  [di'dʒekt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使沮丧： to lower the spirits of; dishearten
A: ♣例  nothing dejects a TV pundit more than the reality check that nobody cares what he thinks 没有什么比大家都漠不关心更让电视节目专家沮丧了
A: ♣近  oppress, sadden, weigh down, bum out
A: ♣反  brighten, buoy, lighten, rejoice, cheer up 使高兴

Q:delegate  ['deliɡət]

A: ♣例  The real estate developer sent a delegate to the town meeting to represent his interests. 房地产开发商派了一名能代表自己利益的代理前往镇上开会。‖the U.N. delegates from African countries 非洲国家的驻联合国代表
A: ♣近  agent, assignee, commissary, deputy, emissary, envoy, legate, minister, proxy, representative
A: ♠考法2  vt. 移交（权力，任务等）： to put (something) into the possession or safekeeping of another
A: ♣例  The manager is reluctant to delegate authority to subordinates while abroad. 经理不愿意在国外期间将自己的权力转交给下级。
A: ♣近  commit, confide, consign, deliver, entrust, repose, transfer, transmit, vest, give over, hand over, turn over
A: ♣反  hold, keep, retain 保持，持有
A: ♣派  delegation n. 代表团

Q:deleterious  [,deli'tiəriəs]

A: ♣近  adverse, baleful, baneful, detrimental, mischievous, nocuous, noxious, pernicious
A: ♣反  beneficial, salutary, salubrious, wholesome, benign, harmless, innocuous 有益的，安全无害的

A: ♣例  a deliberate decision 一个慎重的决定

A: ♣反  impetuous, haste, casual, unadvised, uncalculated, unconsidered, unstudied 随意的，未经过深思的

A: ♣近  dainty, delectable, kickshaw, tidbit
A: ♣反  crudity, husk, coarseness, roughness 粗糙

Q:delineate  [di'linieit]

A: ♣例  lights delineating the narrow streets 勾勒狭窄街道线条的路灯
A: ♣近  define, silhouette, sketch, trace
A: ♠考法2  vt. 描写，描绘： to describe, portray, or set forth with accuracy or in detail
A: ♣例  delineate the steps to be taken by the government 具体描述了政府所应该采取的措施‖The film does a remarkable job of delineating the emotions that immigrants feel upon their arrival in a strange country. 就描绘移民者踏上陌生国土时的心情而言，这部电影是相当成功的。
A: ♣近  depict, display, draw, image, limn, paint, picture, portray, render
A: ♣反  color, distort, falsify, garble, misrepresent, misstate, pervert, twist, warp 曲解，篡改本意
A: ♣派  delineation n. 描绘

Q:delirium  [di'liriəm]

A: ♣例  shoppers running around in a delirium the day before Christmas 购物者在圣诞节前夕疯狂扫货
A: ♣近  agitation, distraction, hysteria, rage, rampage, uproar

Q:deluge  ['delju:dʒ]

A: ♣反  drizzle 毛毛雨

A: ♣例  received a deluge of offers 收到了一大堆offer
A: ♣近  inundation, overflow, spate, torrent

Q:delusion  [di'lu:ʒən]

A: ♣反  truth, verity 真实
A: ♣派  delusive adj. 欺骗的：false, deceptive
A: ♣反  transparent 坦诚的

A: ♣近  probe, investigate, inquire into, look into, dig into

Q:demagogue  ['deməɡɔɡ]

A: ♣例  that politician is just a demagogue who preys upon people's fears and prejudices 那就是一个蛊惑民心的政客，利用民众的害怕和偏见来欺骗
A: ♣近  firebrand, fomenter, incendiary, instigator, kindler, provocateur

Q:demanding  [di'mɑ:ndiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 难取悦的，难满足的： not easily satisfied or pleased
A: ♣例  His mother could be demanding at times. 他母亲有时候很难取悦。
A: ♣近  exacting, fastidious, finical, finicking, fussy, picky
A: ♠考法2  adj. 费时间花心思的： requiring much time, effort, or careful attention
A: ♣例  the demanding assignment kept them working all night long 那项劳神的任务使得他们熬夜
A: ♣近  arduous, burdensome, challenging, exacting, grueling, killing, laborious, onerous, persnickety, taxing, toilsome
A: ♣反  light, unchallenging, undemanding 不费劲的，轻而易举的

Q:demolition  [,demə'liʃən]

A: ♣例  the demolition of dangerous buildings 危楼的拆毁
A: ♣近  annihilation, decimation, devastation, havoc, wreckage
A: ♣反  building, construction, erection, raising 建造

Q:demonstrate  ['demənstreit]
A: ♠考法1  v. （通过证据）证明，表明： to show or make clear by using examples
A: ♣例  the paleontologist hopes to demonstrate that dinosaurs once existed in central Peru by unearthing the fossil evidence 通过发掘化石，古生物学家试图证明恐龙曾经在秘鲁中部生活过
A: ♣近  exemplify, instance
A: ♣反  unable to prove 不能证明的
A: ♠考法2  v. 使明白易懂： to make plain or understandable
A: ♣例  a few striking facts should demonstrate the complex nature of our topic 一些显著的事实可以使我们话题的复杂本质变得好懂
A: ♣近  clarify, construe, demystify, elucidate, explicate, illuminate
A: ♣反  obscure 使模糊
A: ♠考法3  v. 表现，表露： to make known (something abstract) through outward signs
A: ♣例  the babysitter's actions during the emergency demonstrate beyond doubt her general dependability 保姆在紧急情况下的表现毋庸置疑地展示了她一贯的可靠性
A: ♣近  bespeak, betray, display, evince, manifest, reveal

Q:demoralize  [di'mɔrəlaiz]

A: ♣近  daunt, dishearten, dismay, dispirit, unnerve
A: ♣反  invigorate, cheer 鼓舞
A: ♠考法2  v. 贬低，堕落： to lower in character, dignity, or quality
A: ♣例  we refused to be demoralized by our humiliating defeat 我们拒绝由于这场屈辱的战败而被贬低
A: ♣近  abase, corrupt, debauch, degrade, demean
A: ♣反  elevate, ennoble, uplift 使崇高

Q:demote  [,di:'məut]

A: ♣例  The court-martial’s decision was to demote the officer responsible for the failed mission. 军事法庭决定对为此次失败任务负责的军官进行降职处理。

A: ♣反  advance, elevate, promote, raise 提升，晋升
A: ♣派  demotion n. 降职

A: ♣反  profound 深奥的

A: ♣近  degradation, downgrading, reduction
A: ♣反  elevation, promotion 晋升

Q:demur  [di'mə:]

A: ♣例  demur at the suggestion 反对提议
A: ♣近  challenge, exception, expostulation, fuss, kick, protest, remonstrance, stink
A: ♣反  accept, accede 接受
A: ♠考法2  n. 犹豫： hesitation (as in doing or accepting) usually based on doubt of the acceptability of something offered or proposed; qualm
A: ♣例  we accepted his offer to pay for our dinners without demur 我们毫不犹豫地同意了他买单

Q:denigrate  ['deniɡreit]

A: ♣例  denigrate one's opponents 诋毁某人的对手
A: ♣近  belittle, depreciate, derogate, dismiss, disparage
A: ♣反  honor, acclaim, applaud, exalt, extol, glorify, magnify 给以……荣誉，赞扬

Q:denouement  [deinu:'mɔŋ]
A: ♠考法1  n.（小说的）结局： the final resolution or clarification of a dramatic or narrative plot
A: ♣例  a surprising/ unexpected denouement 令人惊奇的、出人意料的结局

Q:denounce  [di'nauns]
A: ♠考法1  v. 公开指责： to express public or formal disapproval of
A: ♣例  the governor has denounced the court's decision and vows to press for a constitutional amendment 州长公开指责法庭决定不公，准备投票进行修宪
A: ♣近  condemn, objurgate, rebuke, reprimand, reproach, reprove
A: ♣反  cite, commend, endorse 支持，称赞
A: ♠考法2  v. 道德上错误、可耻的： to declare to be morally wrong or evil
A: ♣例  the church council denounced the bishop's teachings, officially declaring them to be heresy 该教理事会指责主教的布道可耻，声称它们是异端学说
A: ♣近  anathematize, censure, execrate, reprehend, reprobate
A: ♣派  denunciation n. 谴责：an act of denouncing especially : a public condemnation
A: ♣反  panegyric, accolade, eulogy 颂词

Q:dent  [dent]
A: ♠考法1  n. 凹陷，凹痕： a depression in a surface made by pressure or a blow
A: ♣例  a dent in the side of a car 汽车侧面一处凹陷
A: ♣近  cavity, depression, hollow, indenture, recess
A: ♣反  bulge, convexity, projection, protrusion, protuberance 凸起
A: ♠考法2  v. （数量、程度上）变小，变弱： to make smaller in amount, volume, or extent
A: ♣例  hopefully this vacation won't dent our bank account too much 但愿这次旅行不会让我们银行存款缩水太多
A: ♣近  abate, downscale, downsize, dwindle
A: ♣反  aggrandize, amplify, augment, boost, enlarge, escalate 增大，增强

Q:denude  [di'nju:d]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 脱去，使赤裸： to divest of covering; make bare
A: ♣例  Drought has completely denuded the hills of grass. 干旱脱去了山上的草使山变得光秃秃的。
A: ♣反  cover 遮盖

Q:dependable  [di'pendəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可靠的，值得信赖的： capable of being depended on
A: ♣例  a dependable source of income 可靠的收入来源‖He was a good friend and a dependable companion. 他是一个值得信赖的好伙伴。
A: ♣近  calculable, reliable, responsible, safe, secure, solid, trustable, trustworthy
A: ♣反  undependable, unreliable, unsafe, untrustworthy 不值得信赖的

Q:deplete  [di'pli:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 耗尽，使衰竭： to decrease the fullness of; to make complete use of
A: ♣例  miners depleted the vein of copper ore after only a few months 矿工们在短短几个月内就把一整片铜矿开采完了
A: ♣近  consume, devour, drain, exhaust, draw down, play out, use up
A: ♣反  enrich, renew, replace 使富有，更新

Q:deplorable  [di'plɔ:rəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可鄙的，可耻的： worthy of severe condemnation or reproach
A: ♣例  We will not tolerate such deplorable behavior in a house of worship. 我们绝不能容许这样一种可鄙的行为出现在礼拜堂中。
A: ♣近  despicable, dirty, grubby, lousy, mean, nasty, paltry, scurvy, wretched
A: ♣反  admirable, commendable, creditable, laudable, meritorious, praiseworthy 值得表扬的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 悲惨的，可悲的： of a kind to cause great distress
A: ♣例  Many of them work under deplorable conditions. 许多人的工作环境十分悲惨。
A: ♣近  distressful, distressing, grievous, heartbreaking, heartrending, lamentable, tragic, unfortunate, woeful

Q:deplore  [di'plɔ:]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 哀悼： to feel or express sorrow for
A: ♣例  a statement from the bishops deploring the loss of life in the war overseas 一份来自大主教的声明，对海外战争中遇难的生命表示沉痛哀悼
A: ♣近  mourn, bewail, grieve for, wail for
A: ♣反  delight, exult in, glory in, rejoice in 高兴

Q:deploy  [di:'plɔi]
A: ♠考法1  v.（有目的地）展开；调度： to spread out, utilize, or arrange for a deliberate purpose
A: ♣例  deploy a sales force 展开部署销售力量
A: ♣反  concentrate 集中

Q:deportation  [,di:pɔ:'teiʃən]

A: ♣例  deport all illegal immigrants 驱逐所有非法移民
A: ♣近  banishment, displacement, expatriation, expulsion, relegation

Q:depose  [di'pəuz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 发誓作证： to testify to under oath or by affidavit
A: ♣例  he was nervous when the time to depose before the jury finally arrived 他很紧张，在陪审团面前作证的时刻终于到来了
A: ♣近  attest, swear
A: ♣反  perjure 作伪证
A: ♠考法2  v. 废黜，罢免： to remove from a throne or other high position
A: ♣例  a military junta deposed the dictator after he had bankrupted the country 军阀罢黜了将国家分崩离析的独裁者
A: ♣近  defrock, deprive, oust, uncrown
A: ♣反  crown, enthrone 授予王权
A: ♠考法3  v. 摆放： to arrange something in a certain spot or position
A: ♣例  deposed her fan and gloves on the dressing table 把她的扇子和手套放在梳妆台上
A: ♣近  deposit, dispose, emplace, situate

Q:deposit  [di'pɔzit]
A: ♠考法1  n. 自然积累，沉积： a natural accumulation (as of iron ore, coal, or gas)
A: ♣例  rich deposits of oil and natural gas 丰富的石油、天然气
A: ♣近  dregs, precipitate, sediment, settlings, hoard, reserve
A: ♣反  process of eroding 腐蚀过程
A: ♠考法2  v. 存钱： to put in an account
A: ♣例  we quickly deposited the check in a bank account 我们火速把支票存入银行账户
A: ♣反  withdraw 取款

Q:depravity  [di'prævəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 道德败坏： immoral conduct or practices harmful or offensive to society
A: ♣例  He was sinking into a life of utter depravity. 他自甘堕落。
A: ♣近  debauchery, iniquitousness, licentiousness, perversion, turpitude, dissoluteness
A: ♣反  morality, virtue 美德

Q:deprecate  ['deprikeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 表达不喜欢： to hold an unfavorable opinion of
A: ♣例  deprecates TV sitcoms as childish and simpleminded 批评电视情景喜剧既幼稚又脑残
A: ♣近  deprecate, discountenance, disesteem, disfavor, frown (on or upon)
A: ♣反  approve, favor 喜欢
A: ♠考法2  vt. 贬低，轻视： to express scornfully one's low opinion of
A: ♣例  deprecate the comedy as the stupidest movie of the year 认为这部喜剧是年度最傻逼电影
A: ♣近  belittle, denigrate, dismiss, disparage, cry down
A: ♣反  acclaim, applaud, exalt, extol, glorify 赞扬
A: ♠考法3 vt. 降低重要性，低调： play down, to make little of
A: ♣例  She deprecated her facility for languages 她不炫耀自己对于语言的天赋。
A: ♣反  vaunt 自夸

Q:depreciate  [di'pri:ʃieit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 贬低价值： to lower the price or estimated value of
A: ♣例  New cars start to depreciate as soon as they are on the road. 新车一上路便开始贬值。
A: ♣近  cheapen, depress, devalue, downgrade, mark down
A: ♣反  appreciate, enhance, upgrade, mark up 提价，升值
A: ♠考法2  vt. 轻视：to lower in estimation or esteem
A: ♣例  dared to depreciate Shakespeare, saying his works have no relevance for modern audiences 胆敢贬低莎大人，说他的作品对于现代观众来说没有意义
A: ♣近  denigrate, disparage, play down, talk down
A: ♣反  acclaim, exalt, extol, glorify, magnify 赞扬

Q:depressed  [di'prest]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不开心，情绪不高的： feeling unhappiness
A: ♣例  I was depressed and didn't feel much like going to the party
A: ♣近  crestfallen, dejected, despondent, gloomy, low-spirited, wretched
A: ♣反  blissful, buoyant, gleeful, joyous, jubilant 情绪高的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 生活境况悲催的： kept from having the necessities of life or a healthful environment
A: ♣例  a depressed class of people whose living conditions are abominable even by third world standards 境况悲惨的一群人，即使用第三世界标准来看他们的生存条件也是很糟的
A: ♣近  disadvantaged, underprivileged
A: ♣反  advantaged, privileged 具有优势的、特权的

Q:deprivation  [,depri'veiʃən]

A: ♣例  serious sleep deprivation caused by long work hours 由长时间工作导致的严重睡眠不足
A: ♣反  fecundity 丰饶

Q:deracinate  [di'ræsineit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 根除： to pull out by the roots; uproot
A: ♣反  plant 种植

Q:derelict  ['derilikt]

A: ♣例  the guards were judged derelict in their duty 守卫们被判玩忽职守罪

A: ♣反  extremely careful, attentive, conscientious, nonnegligent 特别仔细的
A: ♠考法2  n. 被社会遗弃的人： a destitute homeless social misfit

A: ♣近  deserted, desolate, disused, forgotten, forsaken, rejected
A: ♣反  pillar of society 社会的栋梁

Q:deride  [di'raid]

A: ♣例  my brothers derided our efforts, but were forced to eat their words when we won first place 我的兄弟嘲笑我们的努力，但是当我们得了第一名以后不得不收回那些话
A: ♣近  gibe, jeer, mock, scout, shoot down, laugh at
A: ♣反  praise 赞美
A: ♣派  derision n. 嘲弄：contemptuous or jeering laughter; ridicule
A: ♣反  veneration 尊敬

Q:derivative  [di'rivətiv]

A: ♣反  original, innovative, precursory 原创的，先驱的

Q:descend  [di'send]

A: ♣例  the pathway descends to the river bank 通道一直向下延伸到河岸
A: ♣近  dip, fall, plunge, sink
A: ♣反  arise, ascend, climb, mount, upsweep, upturn
A: ♠考法2  v. 世代相传： to originate or come from an ancestral stock or source, to pass by inheritance
A: ♣例  The house has descended through four generations. 这座房子已经传了四代。a tradition descending from colonial days 殖民时期传递下来的一项传统

Q:descendant  [di'sendənt]

A: ♣反  forbears 祖先

Q:desecrate  ['desikreit]

A: ♣例  desecrate the shrine 亵渎圣地
A: ♣近  defile, profane, violate
A: ♣反  sanctify, revere, hallow 尊敬，视为神圣

Q:desiccate  ['desikeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使（食物）脱水以保存，使干燥： to preserve (a food) by drying
A: ♣例  add a cup of desiccated coconut to the mix 加一杯椰蓉进行搅拌
A: ♣近  dehydrate, parch, scorch, sear
A: ♣反  add water to, hydrate, drench 加水，浸透
A: ♣派  desiccant n. 干燥剂：a drying agent (as calcium chloride)
A: ♠考法2  v. 缺乏活力： to deprive of emotional or intellectual vitality
A: ♣例  that historian's dryasdust prose desiccates what is actually an exciting period in European history 那位历史学家枯燥无味的散文让欧洲一段扣人心弦的历史变得乏味单调
A: ♣近  brace, castrate, dampen, deaden, devitalize, enervate
A: ♣反  energize, enliven, invigorate, stimulate, vitalize 使生机勃勃

Q:designate  ['deziɡneit]

A: ♣近  denominate, dub, entitle, label, style, term, title

Q:desperate  ['despərət]

Q:despicable  ['despikəbl]

A: ♣例  even within the prison population, pedophiles are regarded as particularly despicable 即使在囚犯内部，恋童癖者也被认为极其让人鄙视的。
A: ♣近  contemptible, detestable, dishonorable
A: ♣反  admirable, commendable, creditable, meritorious, praiseworthy 值得赞扬的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不荣耀的，不得体的： not following or in accordance with standards of honor and decency
A: ♣例  the cad's despicable behavior toward women 公车售票员对女性不得体的举动
A: ♣近  currish, dirty, execrable, ignominious, sordid, wretched
A: ♣反  honorable, lofty, noble, upright, venerable, virtuous 崇高的

Q:despise  [di'spaiz]

A: ♣例  I despise anchovies on pizza, and I refuse to eat them. 我鄙视在披萨上的凤尾鱼，所以从来不吃。
A: ♣近  abhor, abominate, detest, execrate, loathe, disregard, flout
A: ♣反  love 喜欢

Q:despotic  [de'spɔtik]

A: ♣近  authoritative, dictatorial, imperious, overbearing, peremptory, tyrannous

Q:desultory  ['desəltəri]

A: ♣反  carefully planned, strictly methodical, assiduous 精心计划的，有系统的，勤勉的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 令人失望的： disappointing in progress, performance, or quality
A: ♣例  a desultory fifth place finish 让人失望的第五名

Q:detach  [di'tætʃ]

A: ♣例  Detach the white part of the application form and keep it. 撕下申请表的白色部分并予以保留。
A: ♣反  tether 束缚

A: ♣反  manumit 释放

Q:deter  [di'tə:]

A: ♣例  wouldn’t be deterred by threats 不被威胁吓住
A: ♣近  dissuade, inhibit
A: ♣反  spur, courage, persuade 激励
A: ♣派  deterrent adj/ n. 威慑力量，威慑的
A: ♣例  deterrent weapons 威慑性武器; a deterrent to theft 对偷窃的威慑
A: ♣反  inducement, incentive 引诱，刺激

A: ♣反  improvement, recovery, recuperation, rehabilitation, revitalization 改进，改善

Q:detour  [di'tuə]

A: ♣例  we'll regard this relapse as just a brief detour on your road to recovery from substance abuse 我们把这次旧病复发看成你戒瘾道路上的一个小偏离
A: ♣近  deflection, departure, deviation, divergency
A: ♠考法2  v. 改变方向或者路线： to change one's course or direction
A: ♣例  we had to detour for a few miles around the section of highway under construction 我们不得不绕远几公里为了避开正在维修的高速公路路段
A: ♣近  deviate, diverge, sheer, swerve, veer

Q:detract  [di'trækt]
A: ♠考法1  v. 贬低： to diminish the importance, value, or effectiveness of something
A: ♣例  It is wrong to detract from the achievements of other people in the same field. 贬低同行是不对的。
A: ♣近  belittle, depreciate, derogate, disparage, dispraise, write off
A: ♣反  extol, praise, eulogize, laud, panegyrize 赞美
A: ♠考法2  v. 使分心： to draw the attention or mind to something else
A: ♣例  Numerous typos in the text detract the reader's attention from the novel's intricate plot. 许多打印错误把读者分心，不关注复杂的情节了。
A: ♣近  divert, abstract, call off

Q:detritus  [di'traitəs]

A: ♣例  the detritus of war 战争的遗骸
A: ♣近  debris, residue, wreck
A: ♣反  valuable product 有用的物品

Q:devoted  [di'vəutid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 投入的，忠诚的： characterized by loyalty and devotion
A: ♣例  Good teachers are devoted to learning. 好老师会专心学习。
A: ♣近  constant, loyal, allegiant, dedicated, devout, loyal, pious, staunch, steadfast
A: ♣反  disloyal, faithless, perfidious, unfaithful 不忠诚的；recreant, traitorous, treacherous 背叛的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 示爱的，恩爱的： feeling or showing love
A: ♣例  a devoted couple will enjoy sharing their lives with one another. 一对恩爱的情侣喜欢和对方一起度过自己的人生。
A: ♣近  adoring, affectionate, fond, tender, tenderhearted
A: ♣反  unloving 无爱心的，冷漠的

Q:devout  [di'vaut]

A: ♣例  a devout Buddhist 虔诚的佛教徒
A: ♣近  pious, religious, sainted
A: ♣反  antireligious, impious 不虔诚的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 忠诚的： firm in one's allegiance to someone or something
A: ♣例  Devout Mavericks fans never lost faith in Nowitzki. 忠诚的小牛队球迷从来没有对诺维斯基失去信心。
A: ♣近  constant, loyal, allegiant, dedicated, devout, loyal, pious, staunch, steadfast
A: ♣反  disloyal, faithless, perfidious, unfaithful 不忠诚的；recreant, traitorous, treacherous 背叛的

Q:dexterous  ['dekstərəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 动作灵活的： ready and skilled in physical movements
A: ♣例  a dexterous surgeon 技术娴熟的外科医生 || The dexterous watchmaker was able to repair the antique watch's delicate gears and parts. 手巧的手表匠能够修理古董手表的精密的齿轮和部件。
A: ♣近  deft, handy
A: ♣反  ham-fisted, ham-handed, handless, heavy-handed, unhandy 手笨的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 头脑灵活的： mentally adroit and skillful: clever
A: ♣近  adroit, clever, cunning
A: ♣反  dull, foolish, silly, fatuous, unwise 傻的

Q:diabolic  ['daiə'bɔlik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 恶魔一般的： of, relating to, or characteristic of the devil
A: ♣例  The police quickly mobilized to track down the diabolical serial killer. 警察迅速调动起来来追查出这个恶魔般的连环杀人狂。
A: ♣近  demoniac, demonian, demonic, devilish, satanic
A: ♣反  angelic, seraphic 天使般的

Q:diaphanous  [dai'æfənəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 模糊的，非实在的： vague or insubstantial
A: ♣例  only a diaphanous hope of success 只有一丝成功的希望
A: ♣近  vague, obscure, unexplicit, insubstantial, immaterial
A: ♣反  substantial 实在的；clear, distinct 清晰的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （质地精致得）几乎透明的： of such fine texture as to be transparent or translucent
A: ♣例  The bride wore a diaphanous veil. 新娘戴着透明的面纱。
A: ♣近  transparent, translucent, transpicuous, gossamer
A: ♣反  opaque, impermeable of light 不透明的, 不透光的

Q:diatribe  ['daiətraib]
A: ♠考法1  n. 长篇抨击性演讲： a long angry speech or scolding
A: ♣例  He was forced to sit through a long diatribe. 他被迫耐着性子听完一个长篇抨击性演讲。
A: ♣近  tirade, harangue, jeremiad, philippic, rant
A: ♠考法2  n. 挖苦，讽刺的指责： ironic or satirical criticism
A: ♣例  The movie reviewer wrote a diatribe of the movie describing it as having excessive sex and violence. 那个影评人指责这个电影还有过多的色情和暴力。
A: ♣近  irony, satire
A: ♣反  encomium, eulogy, panegyric, tribute, laudatory piece of writing 颂词，赞赏作品

Q:dichotomy  [dai'kɔtəmi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 一分为二，分割： a division into two especially mutually exclusive or contradictory groups or entities
A: ♣例  a dichotomy between the academic world and the industrial world 学术界和工业界的割裂
A: ♣近  bifurcation, breakup, cleavage, division, fractionalization, partition, schism, scission, split, sundering
A: ♣反  unification, union 统一

Q:dictate  [dik'teit]
A: ♠考法1  n. 指令，命令： a command by one in authority
A: ♣例  followed the dictates of my conscience 遵从我的良心准则‖The army must abide by the dictates of the new government. 军队必须服从新政府的命令。
A: ♣近  behest, charge, commandment, decree, direction, directive, edict, imperative, injunction, instruction, order
A: ♠考法2  vt. （仗着地位、权力）下令： to request the doing of by virtue of one’s authority
A: ♣例  The general dictated that the terms of surrender be negotiated by his senior staff. 将军要求投降书中的若干条款交付手下的高级将领进行讨论。
A: ♣近  call, decree, direct, impose, mandate, ordain, order, prescribe
A: ♣反  cancel, countermand, rescind 撤销命令
A: ♣派  dictator n. 独裁者

Q:didactic  [di'dæktik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 喜欢说教的： designed or intended to teach
A: ♣例  Parents’ speech to their kids often seems to be painfully didactic. 父母对他们孩子的话都是让人痛苦的说教。
A: ♣近  homiletic, preachy, moralistic, sententious
A: ♣反  undidactic 不喜欢说教的

Q:diehard  ['daihɑ:d]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 顽固的，保守的/ n. 顽固的人，保守的人： strongly or fanatically determined or devoted/ someone who opposes change and refuses to accept new ideas
A: ♣例  Some diehard smokers belied the doctors’ suggestion. 一些顽固的烟民违背了医生们的建议。
A: ♣近  conservative, hidebound, old-fashioned, reactionary, ultraconservative
A: ♣反  liberal, nonconservative, open-minded, liberal 自由的，开放的

Q:diffident  ['difidənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不自信的： hesitant in acting or speaking through lack of self-confidence
A: ♣例  He is diffident to express his opinions in public. 他在公共场合表达自己的观点时有点害羞
A: ♣近  unassured, bashful, retiring, self-effacing, withdrawn
A: ♣反  confident, assured, self-assured, self-confident 自信的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 内向的： reserved in manner; unassertive
A: ♣例  She was diffident about stating her opinion. 她很内向，表达自己的观点的时候有点害羞。
A: ♣近  introverted
A: ♣反  extroverted, outgoing 外向的

Q:diffuse  [di'fju:s]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 罗嗦的： being at once verbose and ill-organized
A: ♣例  a diffuse report 冗长的报告
A: ♣近  circuitous, circumlocutory, long-winded, prolix, verbose, windy, rambling
A: ♣反  concise, pithy, succinct, terse, laconic 简洁的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不集中的，扩散的： not concentrated or localized
A: ♣例  diffuse lighting 散射光
A: ♣反  concentrated 集中的
A: ♠考法3  v. 扩展，散开： extend, scatter
A: ♣例  The photographer uses a screen to diffuse the light. 摄影师用一个屏幕来分散光线。
A: ♣近  spread, extend, disperse, disseminate, scatter
A: ♣反  concentrate, center, centralize, focus 集中

Q:digress  [dai'ɡres]
A: ♠考法1  v. 脱离主题： to turn aside especially from the main subject of attention or course of argument
A: ♣例  digress from her prepared subject 脱离她准备好的主题 || He digressed so often that it was hard to follow what he was saying. 他经常跑题，以至于我们很难跟上他说的内容。
A: ♣近  excurse, ramble, diverge, get off the subject
A: ♣派  digressive adj.偏离的
A: ♣近  discursive
A: ♣派  digression n. 题外话： the act or an instance of digressing in a discourse
A: ♣近  aside

Q:dike  [daik]
A: ♠考法1  n. 堤坝，水坝： a bank usually of earth constructed to control or confine water
A: ♣例  An elaborate system of dikes was built to protect the lowlands from the relentless onslaught of the sea. 建立了一套精密复杂的堤坝系统，使低地不再受到海水的无情侵袭。
A: ♣近  dam, embankment, levee
A: ♠考法2  n. 水沟，水渠： a long narrow channel dug in the earth
A: ♣例  Water flowed along the dike to the small pond. 水沿着沟渠流入小池塘。
A: ♣近  ditch, gutter, trench

Q:dilapidate  [di'læpideit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 使荒废： to bring into a condition of decay or partial ruin
A: ♣例  The house has been dilapidated by neglect. 由于没人照看，这个房子已经要荒废了。
A: ♣近  ruin, wreck
A: ♣反  be in use 还在使用；restore 恢复使用；mend, repair 修理；rejuvenate, renew, renovate 翻新

Q:dilate  [dai'leit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使膨胀，扩大： to enlarge or expand in bulk or extent；to become wide
A: ♣例  The cat dilated its eyes in the darkness. 猫在黑暗中睁大眼睛。|| The drug dilates the blood vessels. 药使血管膨胀。
A: ♣近  expand, amplify, enlarge
A: ♣反  contract 收缩；narrow 使变窄
A: ♠考法2  v. 详细表达： to express more fully and in greater detail
A: ♣例  He refused to dilate upon his plan for improving the economy in the event that he won the election. 他拒绝在他赢得选举的情况下透露更多关于振兴经济计划的细节。
A: ♣近  amplify, develop, elaborate on, flesh out, dilate on, enlarge on
A: ♣反  abbreviate, abridge, condense, shorten 删减，缩短

Q:dilatory  ['dilətəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 拖延的，磨蹭的： tending or intended to cause delay, characterized by procrastination
A: ♣例  dilatory tactics 拖延战术 || The homeowner is claiming that local firefighters were dilatory in responding to the call. 业主声称本地的消防队员对（火警）电话的有拖延。
A: ♣近  delaying, procrastinating, dragging, lagging, tardy
A: ♣反  rapid, fast, fleet, precipitate, rocketing, swift hasty, hurrying, scurrying 快速的

Q:dilettante  [,dili'tænti]
A: ♠考法1  n./ adj. 业余爱好者（对艺术或知识领域涉猎浅薄者）/ 缺乏专业技术的： a person having a superficial interest in an art/ lacking or showing a lack of expert skill
A: ♣例  Dilettante watch the scene of bustle, adept guard the entrance. 外行看热闹，内行看门道。|| Many dilettante efforts could be seen at the sidewalk art show. 街边艺术展上可以看到很多技术业余的作品
A: ♣近  dabbler, amateur, nonexpert, nonprofessional, cognoscente
A: ♣反  authority, expert, pro, professional, specialist 专家

Q:diligent  ['dilidʒənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 勤勉的，辛勤的： characterized by steady, earnest, and energetic effort: painstaking
A: ♣例  A new bride is diligent for three days. 新娶媳妇三日勤。|| a student who has been unceasingly diligent in pursuit of a degree in mathematics. 一个不断勤奋追求数学学位的学生
A: ♣近  assiduous, industrious, sedulous, engaged, hopping, tied-up
A: ♣反  idle, inactive, unbusy, unemployed, unoccupied 空闲的

Q:dilute  [dai'lju:t]
A: ♠考法1  v. 稀释： to make thinner or less concentrated by adding a liquid such as water/ of relatively low strength or concentration
A: ♣例  dilute a color 稀释色彩 || a dilute acid that's safe to handle in the classroom 稀释了的可以安全在教室处理的酸
A: ♣近  thin
A: ♣反  condense, densify, concentrate, thicken 使浓缩
A: ♠考法2  vt. 削弱： to diminish the strength, flavor, or brilliance of by admixture
A: ♣例  The hiring of the new CEO diluted the power of the company's president. 新的CEO削弱了董事长的权力。
A: ♣近  weaken
A: ♣反  fortify, strengthen 增强

Q:diminish  [di'miniʃ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 变小，减少： to become smaller or less
A: ♣例  diminish an army's strength 削弱军队力量 || The sound of the train diminished as our distance from it increased. 当我们距离火车的越远时，火车的声音就越小。
A: ♣近  abate, dwindle, lessen, lower, reduce, decline
A: ♣反  aggrandize, amplify, augment, boost, enlarge, escalate, expand, increase, raise, balloon 增加，增大
A: ♠考法2  v. 轻视，贬低： to lessen the authority, dignity, or reputation of : belittle
A: ♣例  diminish a rival's accomplishments 贬低对手的成就
A: ♣近  belittle, deprecate, depreciate, disparage
A: ♣反  acclaim, applaud, exalt, extol, glorify, laud, praise 赞美

Q:din  [din]
A: ♠考法1  n. 喧闹声，嘈杂声： a loud continued noise
A: ♣例  The din of the engines was deafening. 引擎的嘈杂声震耳欲聋。|| There's always a great din from the cafeteria during lunch. 午餐时间经常从咖啡店里传来很大的喧闹声。
A: ♣近  blare, bluster, cacophony, chatter, clamor, discordance, racket, rattle, roar
A: ♣反  quiet, silence, still 安静
A: ♠考法2  v. 重复： to say or state again
A: ♣例  Safety lessons dinned into us over and over. 我们一遍又一遍的进行安全教育。
A: ♣近  iterate, rehearse, reiterate

Q:dingy  [dindʒi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 昏暗的，肮脏的： darkened with smoke and grime; dirty or discolored.
A: ♣例  A dingy room is always Dickensian image of the poor. 一个肮脏而昏暗的房间经常作为狄更斯时代的穷人形象。|| The bed sheets were pretty dingy so we threw them in the laundry pile. 床单太脏了以至于我们把它扔进了脏衣服堆。
A: ♣近  darkened, dirty, bedraggled, bemired, besmirched, dusty, mucky, muddy, nasty, smudged, soiled, sordid, stained, sullied
A: ♣反  clean, cleanly, immaculate, spotless, stainless, unsoiled, unstained, unsullied 干净的

Q:diocesan  [dai'ɔsisən]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 主教管辖区的： of or relating to a diocese
A: ♣例  national or diocesan authority 国家或教区权利
A: ♣反  ecumenical 世界范围的

Q:diplomatic  [,diplə'mætik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 使用策略的，机智的： employing tact and conciliation especially in situations of stress
A: ♣例  be very diplomatic with awkward clients 总是有办法对付难缠的顾客
A: ♣近  diplomatic, politic
A: ♣反  gauche, impolitic, tactless, undiplomatic, untactful 笨拙的，不机智的

Q:dire  ['daiə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不吉利的，不祥的： being or showing a sign of evil or calamity to come
A: ♣例  a dire forecast of a plunge in stock prices 股市大跌不祥的预测
A: ♣近  baleful, direful, foreboding, ill-boding, inauspicious, menacing, minatory, portentous, sinister, threatening
A: ♣反  propitious , unthreatening 吉利的，吉祥的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 可怕的，恐怖的： causing fear
A: ♣例  a series of dire tremors that hinted at a volcanic eruption 一系列暗示火山爆发的恐怖的震动
A: ♣近  alarming, dire, direful, dread, dreadful, fearsome, forbidding, formidable, frightening, frightful, ghastly, hair-raising, horrendous, horrible, horrifying, intimidating, redoubtable, scary, shocking, terrible, terrifying
A: ♠考法3  adj. 迫切的：needing immediate attention; urgent
A: ♣例  There is a dire need for food and medicine in the famine-stricken country. 在闹饥荒的国家迫切需要食物和药品。
A: ♣近  immediate, burning, compelling, critical, crying, emergent, exigent, imperative, imperious, importunate, instant, necessitous, pressing, urgent
A: ♣反  nonurgent, noncritical 不迫切的
A: ♠考法4  adj. 悲惨的： causing or marked by an atmosphere lacking in cheer
A: ♣例

Q:dirge  [də:dʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 挽歌： a slow, solemn, and mournful piece of music
A: ♣例  This funeral dirge is for the dead friend. 这首葬礼挽歌是写给故去的朋友的。
A: ♣近  elegy, requiem

Q:disabuse  [,disə'bju:z]
A: ♠考法1  v. 打消错误念头，纠正：to free from error, fallacy, or misconception
A: ♣例  disabuse sb. of the notion that… 打消某人的…观点 || I must disabuse you of your feelings of grandeur. 我必须去消除你的傲气。
A: ♣近  disenchant, undeceive
A: ♣反  lead into error 导致错误；mislead 误导

Q:disaffected  [disə'fektid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不满的，叛逆的： discontented and resentful especially against authority; rebellious
A: ♣例  gangs of disaffected teenagers 一群叛逆的年轻人 || The soldiers were disaffected toward the government. 那些士兵对政府不满.
A: ♣近  discontented, dissatisfied, malcontent, rebellious, insubordinate, contumacious
A: ♣反  satisfied, contented 满足的
A: ♣派  disaffect v. 使不安，使不满： to fill with discontent and unrest
A: ♣近  dissatisfy, agitate, upset
A: ♣反  mollify 平息，抚慰

Q:disarm  [dis'ɑ:m]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 解除武装： to give up or reduce armed forces
A: ♣例  disarm the captured soldiers 解除被捕士兵的武装 || The defeated nation was disarmed so that it would never again be a threat to international order. 战败国被解除武装，这样一来它就不会再对国际秩序造成威胁了。
A: ♣近  demilitarize
A: ♣反  arm, militarize, put on guard 装备武器
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使息怒，平息抚慰： to lessen the anger or agitation of
A: ♣例  Her future father-in-law was totally disarmed by her words. 她未来的继父听了她的话彻底没脾气了。
A: ♣近  appease, assuage, conciliate, gentle, mollify, placate, propitiate
A: ♣反  anger, enrage, incense, inflame, enflame, infuriate, ire, madden, outrage 煽动激起
A: ♠考法3  v. 使无害： to make harmless
A: ♣例  disarm a bomb 拆除炸弹

Q:disarray  [,disə'rei]
A: ♠考法1  n. 混乱，无秩序： a lack of order or sequence
A: ♣例  The room was in disarray. 房间一片混乱。
A: ♣近  confusion, disarrangement, disorder, disorderliness, disorganization, havoc, mess, messiness, misorder, muddle, muss, shambles, jumble, welter
A: ♣反  order, orderliness 有序
A: ♠考法2  v. 使混乱： to undo the proper order or arrangement of
A: ♣例  Changing offices disarrayed my papers completely. 办公室搬迁，使我的文件全部乱套了.
A: ♣近  confuse, disarrange, discompose, dishevel, dislocate, disorganize, disrupt, disturb, hash, jumble, muddle, muss, rumple, scramble, upset, mess up, mix up
A: ♣反  arrange, array, dispose, order, organize, range, regulate, straighten up 使有序

Q:disavow  [,disə'vau]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 拒绝承认，否认： to disclaim knowledge of, responsibility for, or association with；to declare not to be true
A: ♣例  disavow the rumor 否认谣言 || She disavowed the testimony that she had given earlier in the trial. 她在审判中否认了自己之前的证词。
A: ♣近  deny, repudiate, disaffirm, disclaim, disconfirm, gainsay, negate
A: ♣反  acknowledge, avow, concede 承认

Q:discern  [di'sə:n]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 识别，辨别差异：to perceive with the eyes or intellect; detect
A: ♣例  discern the motives 辨识出动机 || too young to discern between right and wrong 太年轻了而辨别不了是非
A: ♣近  behold, descry, distinguish, espy, perceive, regard, differentiate, discriminate
A: ♣反  confuse, mix up 混淆
A: ♣派  discerning adj. 有洞察力的，洞悉的：showing insight and understanding
A: ♣例  a very discerning art critic 眼光敏锐有洞察力的艺术评论家 || She has a discerning palate. 她的味觉很敏锐。
A: ♣近  insightful, incisive
A: ♣反  myopic, shortsighted 目光短浅的；undiscerning 无辨别能力的
A: ♣派  discernible/ discernable adj. 可辨识的，可辨别的：perceptible
A: ♣例  a discernible mark 可辨别的痕迹
A: ♣近  perceptible, detectable, distinguishable
A: ♣反  indiscernible, imperceptible 不可辨识的

Q:discharge  [dis'tʃɑ:dʒ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 解雇： to dismiss from employment
A: ♣例  discharge a worker/soldier 开除员工/军籍
A: ♣近  fire, dismiss
A: ♣反  employ, engage, hire, take on, sign up or on 雇佣
A: ♠考法2  n. 不承担责任： a freeing from an obligation or responsibility
A: ♣例  a full discharge from responsibility for the accident 对事故完全不负有责任
A: ♣近  delivery, quietus, quittance
A: ♠考法3  v. 释放： to set free (as from slavery or confinement)
A: ♣例  discharged the prisoners upon the signing of the peace treaty 根据和约释放罪犯
A: ♣近  disenthrall, emancipate, enfranchise, liberate, loose, manumit, release, spring, unbind, uncage, unchain, unfetter
A: ♣反  bind, confine, enchain, fetter 监禁，束缚

Q:disciple  [di'saipl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 信徒，追随者： one who accepts and assists in spreading the doctrines of another, follower
A: ♣例  A circle of dedicated disciples who conscientiously wrote down everything the prophet said. 一圈忠实的信徒认真的记下了先知所说的话。
A: ♣近  acolyte, adherent, convert, epigone, partisan, votary
A: ♣反  leader, coryphaeus 领导者

Q:discombobulate  [diskəm'bɔbjuleit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 使不安，使混乱： upset, confuse
A: ♣例  invent cool new ways to discombobulate the old order 发明新的好方法打乱了旧秩序
A: ♣近  upset, addle, baffle, bamboozle, befog, befuddle, confound, fuddle, gravel, muddle, muddy, mystify, perplex, puzzle, vex
A: ♣反  compose, soothe, calm, pacify 使安定

Q:discomfit  [dis'kʌmfit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 使尴尬： to put into a state of perplexity and embarrassment
A: ♣例  He was discomfited by the awkward situation of having his ex-girlfriend meet his current one. 他的前女友看到他现任女友的情况让他很尴尬。
A: ♣近  embarrass, abash, faze, fluster, mortify, nonplus, rattle
A: ♠考法2  v. 阻碍： to prevent from achieving a goal
A: ♣例  Constant interruptions discomfited her in her attempt to finish the speech. 经常的打断她讲话使她无法完成演讲。
A: ♣近  balk, foil, thwart, baffle, checkmate
A: ♣反  advance, forward, foster, further, promote 推进，促进；encourage 鼓励

Q:discommode  [,diskə'məud]
A: ♠考法1  v. 打扰，使不便： to cause inconvenience to: trouble
A: ♣例  The breakdown of her car didn't discommode her seriously. 车的故障没有给他带来很大麻烦。
A: ♣近  disturb, trouble, incommode, put out
A: ♣反  accommodate, assist, oblige, favor 帮忙

Q:discompose  [,diskəm'pəuz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使不安： to disturb the composure or calm of; perturb
A: ♣例  GRE does not seem to discompose Jason; on the contrary, he looked rather relaxed. GRE没有使Jason感到慌乱，正相反，他看上去很轻松。
A: ♣近  agitate, bother, discomfort, disquiet, distemper, disconcert, disturb, perturb, upset, weird out
A: ♣反  calm, compose, quiet, settle, soothe, tranquilize 平息抚慰
A: ♠考法2  v. 使混乱： to undo the proper order or arrangement of
A: ♣例  The wind ruffled her hair and discomposed her carefully arranged papers. 风凌乱了她的头发，吹乱了她细心整理的纸张。
A: ♣近  disarrange, disarray, disorganize
A: ♣反  arrange, array, order, organize, range 使有序

Q:disconcert  [,diskən'sə:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使不安： to disturb the composure of
A: ♣例  We were disconcerted by the unexpected changes to the program. 我们对项目未预料到的变化感到不安。
A: ♣近  abash, discomfit, disconcert, discountenance, mortify, rattle
A: ♣反  calm, compose, quiet, settle, soothe, tranquilize 平息抚慰

Q:discord  ['diskɔ:d]
A: ♠考法1  n. 意见不一致，不和谐： lack of agreement or harmony (as between persons, things, or ideas)
A: ♣例  No discord, no concord. 不打不成交。
A: ♣近  conflict, disaccord, discordance, disharmony, dissension, dissidence, dissonance, disunion, disunity, division, friction, inharmony, schism, strife
A: ♣反  accord, agreement, concord, harmony, peace 和谐
A: ♣派  discordant adj. 不和谐的，刺耳的： disagreeable in sound; harsh or dissonant
A: ♣近  dissonant, cacophonous, disharmonic, disharmonious
A: ♣反  concordant, harmonious 和谐的

Q:discredit  [dis'kredit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 羞辱，使丧失名誉： to damage in reputation; disgrace.
A: ♣例  discredit his opponents 羞辱他的对手
A: ♣近  abase, debase, degrade, demean, disgrace, dishonor, humiliate, shame, sink, smirch, take down
A: ♣反  aggrandize 提高名誉；canonize, deify 神化；elevate 提升；exalt 赞扬
A: ♠考法2  v. 怀疑，不相信： to think not to be true or real
A: ♣例  I discredit the story that the old house is haunted. 我怀疑那个房子闹鬼不是真的。
A: ♣近  negate, doubt, distrust
A: ♣反  accept, believe, credit 接受，相信；confirm, prove, validate, verify 证实

Q:discreet  [dis'kri:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （言行）谨慎的： having or showing good judgment and restraint especially in conduct or speech
A: ♣例  He was very discreet, only saying what was necessary. 他是个十分谨慎的人，从来不说多余的话。
A: ♣近  intelligent, judicious, prudent
A: ♣近  imprudent, indiscreet, injudicious 不谨慎的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不易察觉的： not readily seen or noticed
A: ♣例  With a discreet gesture, she signaled to her husband that she was ready to leave the party. 她用一个不起眼的手势向丈夫暗示准备离开聚会。‖followed at a discreet distance 远远地跟踪
A: ♣近  inconspicuous, invisible, unnoticeable, unobtrusive
A: ♣近  apparent, conspicuous, distinct, evident, manifest, noticeable, obvious, patent, visible 明显的

Q:discrepancy  [dis'krepənsi]
A: ♠考法1  n. （在事实和宣称之间的）差异或矛盾： divergence or disagreement, as between facts or claims
A: ♣例  a large discrepancy between the ideal image and the reality 理想与现实之间的巨大差距
A: ♣近  contrast, disagreement, disparity, dissimilarity, distance, distinction, diversity
A: ♣反  converge concord consonant 一致，和谐；analogousness, community, resemblance, similarity 相似

Q:discrete  [dis'kri:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 离散的，不连续的：constituting a separate entity
A: ♣例  a discrete variable 离散变量
A: ♣近  detached, disconnected, unattached, unconnected, separate
A: ♣反  continuous 连续的；attached, connected, joined, linked 连接的

Q:discretion  [dis'kreʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 谨慎： the quality of being discreet; circumspection
A: ♣例  You must show discretion in choosing your teammates. 你选择队友时必须慎重。
A: ♣近  discreetness, prudence
A: ♣反  imprudence, indiscretion
A: ♣派  indiscretion n. 不谨慎，不符合社会道德规范： an act at variance with the accepted morality of a society
A: ♣例  resign because of financial indiscretions 因为财政方面的不检点而辞职
A: ♠考法2  n. 自制，节制： the checking of one's true feelings and impulses when dealing with others
A: ♣例  In that job you'll be expected to show discretion and act like a professional at all times. 那项工作要求你时刻自制节制，表现得像一个专业人士。
A: ♣近  continence, discipline, inhibition, refrainment, restraint, self-control, self-restraint
A: ♣反  disinhibition, incontinence, unconstraint 不自制，不节制

Q:discretionary  [dis'kreʃənəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 自主决定的： left to discretion : exercised at one's own discretion
A: ♣例  In many restaurants, discretionary tipping is being replaced by a standard service charge. 在很多饭店，标准的服务价格取代了随意支付的小费。
A: ♣近  elective, voluntary
A: ♣反  compulsory, mandatory, nonelective, nonvoluntary, obligatory, required 强制性的，非自愿的

Q:discriminate  [dis'krimineit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 区分： to perceive the distinguishing features of; recognize as distinct
A: ♣例  discriminate different kinds of animals 区分不同的动物
A: ♣近  differentiate, discern, distinguish
A: ♣反  confuse, mistake, mix up 混淆
A: ♠考法2  vi. 歧视： to make a difference in treatment or favor on a basis other than individual merit
A: ♣例  The new law discriminated against lower-paid workers. 这条新法律歧视低工资的工人。
A: ♣派  discriminatory adj. 差别对待的： marked by or showing prejudice; biased
A: ♣近  prejudiced, biased
A: ♣反  equitable, impartial, unbiased, impersonal, unprejudiced 公平的

Q:discursive  [dis'kə:siv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （谈话内容）杂乱的： moving from topic to topic without order
A: ♣例  a long, discursive article 冗长杂乱的文章 || The speaker's discursive style made it difficult to understand his point. 演讲者讲话杂乱，很难让人理解他的观点。
A: ♣近  desultory, digressional, excursive, meandering, rambling, wandering
A: ♣反  keen on title, concentrated 关注主题的，集中的

Q:disdain  [dis'dein]
A: ♠考法1  v. 轻视，鄙视： to look on with scorn
A: ♣例  disdain that man for snobbishness 鄙视那个势利小人
A: ♣近  contemn, disrespect, slight, sniff, snub, look down
A: ♣反  honor, respect 尊敬；treat favorably 亲切地对待

Q:disenchant  [,disin'tʃɑ:nt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使清醒： to free from illusion
A: ♣例  If you thought that you could pass this course without doing any work, let me be the first to disenchant you. 如果你觉得你不做任何功课也能及格，那就让我做第一个让你清醒的人。
A: ♣近  disabuse, undeceive
A: ♣反  beguile, cozen, delude, dupe, fool, gull, hoax, hoodwink, misguide, misinform, mislead 诱骗

Q:disengage  [,disin'ɡeidʒ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 分开： to set free from entanglement or difficulty
A: ♣例  Disengage the gears when you park the car. 当你停车的时候要把（传动）齿轮分开。|| seek to disengage myself from the embarrassing situation 试图把我自己从尴尬的气氛中解救出来
A: ♣近  disengage, disentangle, untangle
A: ♣反  embroil, entangle 卷入；mesh 啮合

Q:disgorge  [dis'ɡɔ:dʒ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 呕吐出： to discharge by the throat and mouth; vomit
A: ♣例  He cannot disgorge a fish bone without the doctor’s assistant. 没有医生的帮助他吐不出鱼刺来。|| The volcano disgorged lava. 火山喷出岩浆。
A: ♣近  belch, disgorge, eject, eruct, expel, jet, spew, spout
A: ♣反  swallow, ingest 吞下，咽下
A: ♠考法2  v. 放弃： to give up on request or under pressure
A: ♣例  The corrupt officials refused to disgorge his ill-gotten gains. 贪官们拒绝放弃赃款。

Q:disgruntle  [dis'ɡrʌntl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使发怒，使不满意：to make ill-humored or discontented
A: ♣例  be disgruntled with sb 对某人不满
A: ♣近  disaffect, displease, dissatisfy, disgruntle
A: ♣反  content, gratify, please, satisfy 使满意
A: ♠考法2  v. 使疏远，使不友好：to cause to change from friendly or loving to unfriendly or uncaring
A: ♣近  alien, alienate
A: ♣反  reconcile 调解，使和谐

Q:disguise  [dis'ɡaiz]
A: ♠考法1  v. 伪装（防止被认出）： to modify the manner or appearance of in order to prevent recognition
A: ♣例  He always disguises his true feelings. 他经常掩饰自己的真实感受。
A: ♣近  camouflage, costume, mask
A: ♣反  unmask 使露出真相
A: ♠考法2  v. 隐藏： to keep secret or shut off from view
A: ♣例  That investigative reporter usually does a good job of disguising her true motives for interviewing a person. 当采访时，那个调查记者经常很好地隐藏自己的真实目的
A: ♣近  belie, blanket, conceal, cover, curtain, occult, veil
A: ♣反  bare, disclose, display, divulge, expose, reveal, show, uncover, unmask, unveil 暴露，展现

Q:dishearten  [dis'hɑ:tən]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使沮丧，使失去信心： to cause to lose spirit or morale
A: ♣例  We were greatly disheartened by the news that our grandmother was seriously ill. 听到祖母病重的消息，我们都很沮丧。
A: ♣近  chill, daunt, demoralize, discourage, dismay, dispirit, frustrate, unnerve
A: ♣反  embolden, encourage, hearten, nerve, steel 使大胆，鼓励

Q:disinclination  [,disinkli'neiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 不喜欢，厌恶，不情愿： a lack of willingness or desire to do or accept something；a lack of willingness or desire to do or accept something
A: ♣例  showing a marked disinclination 表现出明显的不情愿
A: ♣近  aversion, disfavor, disliking, disrelish, mislike, unwillingness
A: ♣反  appetite, favor, fondness, liking, partiality, preference, relish, inclination 喜欢；willingness 情愿

Q:disinfect  [,disin'fekt]

A: ♣例  disinfect with bleaching powder 用漂白粉消毒
A: ♣近  sterilize
A: ♣反  infect, pollute, contaminate, taint 感染，污染

Q:disinter  [,disin'tə:]
A: ♠考法1  v. （从墓地里）掘出 ：to take out of the grave or tomb
A: ♣例  The Egyptian mummy was carefully disinterred in hopes that it would yield secrets about the Old Kingdom. 那个埃及木乃伊被小心地挖掘出来，人们希望它可以告诉我们关于这个古老王国的一些秘密。
A: ♣近  unbury, unearth
A: ♣反  bury, inter, tomb, inhume 埋葬

Q:disinterested  [dis'intristid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 公正的，无偏见的： free from selfish motive or interest: unbiased
A: ♣例  a disinterested decision 公正的决定
A: ♣近  equal, evenhanded, impartial, just, nonpartisan, dispassionate, objective, square, unbiased, unprejudiced
A: ♣反  biased, inequitable, nonobjective, one-sided, partial, partisan, prejudiced, unjust 不公正的，有偏见的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 没有兴趣的： having or showing a lack of interest or concern
A: ♣例  The city's philistines, naturally disinterested in art, voted to cut the museum's budget. 城市里对艺术本来就不感兴趣的俗人们，投票表决要缩进博物馆的预算。
A: ♣近  apathetic, incurious, insouciant, nonchalant, perfunctory, unconcerned
A: ♣反  concerned, interested 关心的，感兴趣的

Q:disjointed  [dis'dʒɔintid]

A: ♣例  a disjointed society 混乱的社会
A: ♣近  chaotic, disorderly
A: ♣反  orderly, regular, systematic 有序的，规律的，系统的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不连贯的： not clearly or logically connected
A: ♣例  a disjointed speech about a hodgepodge of things 关于一大堆杂事的不连贯的演讲
A: ♣近  disconnected, unconnected
A: ♣反  coherent, connected 连贯的

Q:disjunctive  [dis'dʒʌŋktiv]

A: ♣例  a disjunctive narrative sequence 分散的叙述顺序
A: ♣反  conjunctive,connective 连接的
A: ♣派  disjunction n. 分离

A: ♣例  dismantle a machine 分拆机器
A: ♣近  break down, knock down
A: ♣反  assemble, construct 组装

Q:dismay  [dis'mei]

A: ♣反  embolden, encourage, hearten, nerve 鼓励，使勇敢

A: ♣例  Parents became increasingly dismayed by their son's GPA. 父母对他们儿子的平均成绩非常焦虑。
A: ♣近  agitate, bother, discomfort, discompose, disquiet, distemper, distress, perturb, unsettle, upset
A: ♣反  calm, compose, quiet, soothe, tranquilize 平息抚慰

Q:disparage  [dis'pæridʒ]
