A: ♣例  use the past to disparage the present 借古讽今 || Voters don't like political advertisements in which opponents disparage one another.选民不喜欢看到贬低竞争对手的政治广告。
A: ♣近  belittle, denigrate, deprecate, depreciate, derogate, degrade
A: ♣反  acclaim, applaud, exalt, extol, glorify, laud 赞扬

Q:disparate  ['dispərət]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 迥然不同的：fundamentally distinct or different in kind; entirely dissimilar
A: ♣例  This couple of seemingly disparate topics have something in common. 这两个看似无关的主题其实有些相同之处。
A: ♣近  dissimilar, distinct, distinguishable, diverse, nonidentical, unalike
A: ♣反  alike, identical, indistinguishable, kindred, like, parallel, same, similar 相似的，相同的

Q:dispassionate  [dis'pæʃənət]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 客观公正的，不易被情绪或偏见影响的：devoid of or unaffected by passion, emotion, or bias
A: ♣例  Journalists should aim to be dispassionate observers. 记者们应该朝着成为一个公正的观察者努力。
A: ♣近  disinterested, equal, equitable, evenhanded, impartial, just, nonpartisan, objective, unbiased, unprejudiced
A: ♣反  biased, inequitable, nonobjective, one-sided, partial, partisan, prejudiced, unjust 有偏见的，不公正的

Q:dispatch  [dis'pætʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 迅速： promptness and efficiency in performance or transmission
A: ♣例  do sth. with dispatch 迅速的做某事
A: ♣近  alacrity, haste, swiftness, expedition, promptitude
A: ♣反  leisureliness, delay, procrastination 悠然，拖延
A: ♠考法2  v. 发送，运输： to cause to go or be taken from one place to another
A: ♣例  to dispatch a messenger with urgent news 发送一个紧急消息
A: ♣近  transfer, transmit, transport, pack off
A: ♣反  accept, receive 接收
A: ♠考法3  v. 使死亡： to deprive of life
A: ♣例  dispatch a criminal处决罪犯 || The man dispatched the termites with professional efficiency. 那个男人技术纯熟地杀死了白蚁。
A: ♣反  animate 使有生命
A: ♠考法4  v. 获胜： to achieve a victory over
A: ♣例  They dispatched the other team with breaking a sweat. 他们险胜其他的队。
A: ♣近  conquer, defeat, subdue, triumph over, prevail over
A: ♣反  lose to 输

Q:dispose  [dis'pəuz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使倾向： to give a tendency to: incline
A: ♣例  faulty diet disposes one to sickness 营养不全面导致疾病
A: ♣派  disposed adj. 喜欢的： willing or likely，inclined
A: ♣例  not feel disposed to argue with her 不喜欢与她争执
A: ♣近  willing, inclined, predisposed, prone
A: ♣反  disinclined, indisposed 不喜欢的
A: ♠考法2  vi. 处理掉（与of连用，dispose of）： to get rid of; throw out
A: ♣派  disposal n. 处理，不再利用： the act of getting rid of something that is no longer wanted or needed
A: ♣例  the permanent disposal of radioactive wastes 对放射性废物的永久处理
A: ♠考法3  v. 布置有序： to place, distribute, or arrange especially in an orderly way
A: ♣例  Dispose the surgical instruments in the exact order in which they would be needed. 把手术仪器按他们被需要的顺序放置。
A: ♣近  array, arrange
A: ♣反  disarrange, disarray, disorder, upset, mess up, muss up 使混乱

Q:disprove  [dis'pru:v]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 证伪，证明为假： to prove to be false or wrong
A: ♣例  Magellan’s circumnavigation of the globe disproved any lingering notions that the earth is flat. 麦哲伦的环球旅行彻底否认了任何残存的“地球是平的”的观念。
A: ♣近  belie, confound, confute, debunk, disconfirm, discredit, falsify, rebut, refute, shoot down
A: ♣反  confirm, establish, prove, validate, verify 证实，证明为真

Q:disregard  [disri'ɡɑ:d]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 漠视，不关注： to pay no attention to
A: ♣例  disregard the advice of his executives 漠视执行管理者的建议
A: ♣近  ignore, overlook, slight
A: ♣反  heed, mind, regard, attend to 关注
A: ♠考法2  n. 缺乏兴趣，缺乏关心： lack of interest or concern
A: ♣例  Revelers fired guns in the air with complete disregard for the possible consequences. 饮酒狂欢者一点也不关心后果的开枪。
A: ♣近  apathy, disinterestedness, incuriosity, nonchalance, torpor, unconcern
A: ♣反  concern, interest, regard 关心，感兴趣

Q:dissect  [di'sekt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 仔细分析： to examine, analyze, or criticize in minute detail
A: ♣例  dissect some basic problems in mathematics analysis 仔细分析一些数学分析的基本问题 || let's dissect the plot of this thriller to see what makes it thrilling. 让我们来仔细分析一下这个恐怖电影为什么恐怖。
A: ♣近  analyze
A: ♠考法2  vt. 切成片(尤其是为了解剖研究)： to cut apart or separate (tissue), especially for anatomical study
A: ♣例  dissect the brain of Einstein 解剖爱因斯坦的大脑
A: ♣近  anatomize, assay, break down

Q:dissemble  [di'sembl]
A: ♠考法1  v. 用假象隐藏真相，掩饰： to put on a false appearance
A: ♣例  dissemble fear with a smile 用微笑来掩饰恐惧 || He dissembled happiness at the news that his ex-girlfriend was getting married to someone else. 他对其他人假装高兴听到前女友结婚的消息。
A: ♣近  dissimulate, affect, assume, bluff, counterfeit, fake, sham
A: ♣反  behave honestly 表现诚恳

Q:disseminate  [di'semineit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 散播，传播： to spread abroad; promulgate
A: ♣例  disseminate Marxism-Leninism 传播马列主义 || The Internet allows us to disseminate information faster. 互联网允许我们更快的传播信息。
A: ♣近  broadcast, circulate, propagate
A: ♣反  gather, amass, garner 收集

Q:dissension  [di'senʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 意见不合：difference of opinion; disagreement
A: ♣例  Although we have dissension, we are friend all the same. 虽然我们意见不和，但我们还是朋友。|| There is a continued dissension among historians on the exact spot of Columbus's first landing. 关于哥伦布第一次的准确登陆地点这个问题，总是存在分歧。
A: ♣近  conflict, disaccord, discordance, discordancy, disharmony, dissent, dissidence, dissonance, disunion, disunity, division, friction, inharmony, schism, strife
A: ♣反  accord, agreement, concord, concordance, harmony, consensus, unanimity 不和谐，不一致

Q:dissent  [di'sent]
A: ♠考法1  v. 持异议，不同意： to differ in opinion
A: ♣例  I dissent from what you said. 我不同意你说的话。|| Anyone who dissented was encouraged to speak out while they had the chance. 谁有异议得到机会都可以发言。
A: ♣近  differ, disagree, nonconcur
A: ♣反  agree, assent, concur 同意
A: ♠考法2  n. 反对正统： departure from a generally accepted theory, opinion, or practice
A: ♣例  The church reacted to any form of dissent by promptly excommunicating its proponents. 教堂会立即开除任何反对正统教义的人。
A: ♣近  heterodoxy, nonconformity
A: ♣反  conformity 遵从；orthodoxy 正统
A: ♠考法3  n. 不和谐： a lack of agreement or harmony
A: ♣近  conflict, disaccord, discordance, discordancy, disharmony, dissent, dissidence, dissonance, disunion, disunity, division, friction, inharmony, schism, strife
A: ♣反  accord, agreement, concord, concordance, harmony, consensus, unanimity 不和谐，不一致

Q:dissipate  ['disipeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 驱散： to drive away; disperse.
A: ♣例  The wind finally dissipated the smoke. 风终于吹散了雾气。
A: ♣近  disband, dispel, disperse, scatter
A: ♣反  accumulate, gather, amass, cluster, assemble, concentrate, congregate 积聚
A: ♠考法2  vt. 浪费： to spend or expend intemperately or wastefully: squander
A: ♣例  dissipate too much time and effort 挥霍了太多的时间与精力
A: ♣近  waste, squander, lavish
A: ♣反  conserve 节省
A: ♠考法3  vi. 放纵： to indulge in the intemperate pursuit of pleasure, especially : to drink to excess
A: ♣近  indulge

Q:dissolute  ['disəlju:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 放荡的，无节制的： lacking moral restraint; indulging in sensual pleasures or vices.
A: ♣例  lead a dissolute life 过着放荡无节制的生活
A: ♣近  dissipated, libertine, rakish, reprobate
A: ♣反  abstinent, abstemious, temperate, ascetic, stoic, spartan, self-denying 自制节制的；pure, uncorrupt, uncorrupted 纯洁的，未堕落的

Q:dissolve  [di'zɔlv]
A: ♠考法1  v. 溶解，融化： to cause to pass into solution; to reduce (solid matter) to liquid form; melt
A: ♣例  Sugar dissolves in the water. 糖在水中溶解
A: ♣近  liquefy, melt
A: ♣反  coagulate, solidify, freeze 凝结，凝固，结冰
A: ♠考法2  vt. 解散： to break into component parts; disintegrate
A: ♣近  disintegrate, disband, break up
A: ♣反  consolidate, unify 使联合
A: ♠考法3  v. 消失： to cease to be visible; to cease to exist
A: ♣例  The mist dissolved in the morning sun. 雾消失在朝阳中。
A: ♣近  dematerialize, vanish
A: ♣反  appear 出现；materialize 使实物化
A: ♠考法4  v. 废除，撤销： to put an end to by formal action
A: ♣例  The king dissolved parliament. 国王废除了议会
A: ♣近  terminate, abrogate, annul, cancel, disannul, invalidate, negate, null, nullify, repeal, rescind

Q:dissonance  ['disənəns]
A: ♠考法1  n．不和谐，刺耳： a harsh, disagreeable combination of sounds; discord
A: ♣例  cognitive dissonance认识上的分歧 || Dissonance among the three partners doomed the project. 三个股东间的不调和注定了那计划的失败。
A: ♣近  conflict, disaccord, discordance, discordancy, disharmony, dissent, dissidence, dissonance, disunion, disunity, division, friction, inharmony, schism, strife
A: ♣反  accord, agreement, concord, concordance, harmony, consensus, unanimity 不和谐，不一致

Q:dissuade  [di'sweid]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 劝阻,反对： to deter (a person) from a course of action or a purpose by persuasion or exhortation
A: ♣例  dissuade sb. from (doing) sth 劝阻/反对某人做某事 || Her parents tried to dissuade her from her intention to drop out of college. 她的父母劝她不要退学。
A: ♣近  deter, dissuade, inhibit
A: ♣反  encourage 鼓励；persuade 说服

Q:distain  [dis'tein]
A: ♠考法1  v. 贬损，伤害名誉： loss of honor, respect, or reputation
A: ♣近  dishonor, belittle, denigrate, deprecate, depreciate, degrade
A: ♣反  praise, acclaim, applaud, exalt, extol, glorify, laud 赞扬
A: ♠考法2  v. 弄脏： to make dirty
A: ♣例  hands distained with blood 被血弄脏的手
A: ♣近  bemire, besmirch, daub, muddy, smirch, smudge, soil, stain, sully
A: ♣反  clean 使干净

Q:distal  [dis'təl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 远离中心的，（神经）末梢的： situated away from the point of attachment or origin or a central point
A: ♣例  the distal end of nerve 神经末梢
A: ♣反  proximal 接近中心的

Q:distend  [dis'tend]
A: ♠考法1  v. 膨胀：to swell out or expand from or as if from internal pressure
A: ♣例  The stomachs of starving people often distend. 饥民的肚子经常涨起来。
A: ♣近  expand, dilate, inflate, swell
A: ♣反  constrict, compress 收缩压缩

Q:distill  [dis'til]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 用蒸馏法提高纯度：to increase the concentration of, separate, or purify by or as if by distillation.
A: ♣例  distill the water before pouring it in the steam iron 在把水倒到熨斗里前蒸馏一下
A: ♣近  purify, filter, refine, fine
A: ♣派  distillate n. 蒸馏物，纯化物，本质：a purified form; an essence
A: ♠考法2  v. 渗出；滴下： to fall or let fall in or as if in drops
A: ♣例  The basement walls distill water every time it rains heavily. 地下室的墙壁每次下大雨都渗出水来。
A: ♣近  distill, dribble, drop, trickle

Q:distinctive  [dis'tiŋktiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 完全不同的： being not of the same kind
A: ♣例  She seems to alternate between two distinctive hairstyles. 她的发型似乎在两种截然不同的样式中交替。
A: ♣近  disparate, dissimilar, distant, distinct, distinguishable, diverse, unalike, unlike
A: ♣反  identical, indistinguishable, same 相同的；alike, analogous, kindred, like, parallel, similar 相似的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 特征性的，典型的： serving to identify as belonging to an individual or group
A: ♣例  She seems to alternate between two distinctive hairstyles. 她的发型似乎在两种截然不同的样式中交替。
A: ♣近  characteristic, classic, diagnostic, discriminating, distinguishing, identifying, peculiar, symptomatic, typical
A: ♣反  atypical, uncharacteristic, untypical 非典型的
A: ♣派  distinction n. 区别，差别

Q:distort  [dis'tɔ:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 扭曲，歪曲：to twist out of the true meaning or proportion
A: ♣例  A painter may exaggerate or distort shapes and forms. 画家可能夸张或扭曲形状。|| The coach's message was so distorted after passing through so many people that it was unintelligible. 教练的信息在经过许多人传递后已经被歪曲的很难看懂了。
A: ♣近  deform, misshape, torture, falsify, misinterpret, misrepresent, pervert, twist

Q:distract  [dis'trækt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 转移兴趣，使分心：to draw or direct (as one's attention) to a different object
A: ♣例  be distracted by a sudden noise 被突然的噪音分心
A: ♣近  abstract, divert, detract, call off
A: ♣派  distracted adj. 精力分散的
A: ♣反  rapt 全心投入的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使焦虑，使不安：to trouble the mind of; to make uneasy
A: ♣例  The students are easily distracted before the exam. 学生们在考试前很容易焦虑不安。
A: ♣近  agitate, bother, discomfort, discompose, dismay, disquiet, distress, perturb, upset
A: ♣反  calm, compose, quiet, soothe, tranquilize 平息抚慰
A: ♠考法3  adj. 疯狂的：insane, mad
A: ♣近  insane, delirious, hysterical

Q:distraught  [dis'trɔ:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 精神狂乱的，极疯狂的： deeply agitated, as from emotional conflict; insane
A: ♣例  Her distraught mother had spent all night waiting by the phone. 她母亲忧心如焚，在电话旁守了一个晚上。
A: ♣近  agitated, delirious, distracted, frenzied, hysterical
A: ♣反  collected, composed, recollected, self-collected, self-composed, self-possessed 镇静的，平静的

Q:diurnal  [dai'ə:nəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 白天发生或行动的： occurring or active during the daytime rather than at night
A: ♣例  diurnal animals 昼行性动物
A: ♣反  nocturnal 夜晚的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 每天的： occurring, done, produced, or appearing every day
A: ♣例  a love as constant and certain as the diurnal tides 像每天潮汐一样始终如一的爱情
A: ♣近  daily, day-to-day,
A: ♠考法3  adj. 期刊： a publication that appears at regular intervals
A: ♣例  A microfilm contains a collection of diurnals. 一个微缩胶片里包含很多期刊的合集。
A: ♣近  bulletin, magazine, periodical, review, serial, journal

Q:diverge  [dai'və:dʒ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 改变方向： to change one's course or direction
A: ♣例  The deer abruptly diverged from its intended path the moment it spied the waiting lion. 当那只鹿发现潜伏的狮子的时候就突然改变了自己原来的路线。
A: ♣近  detour, deviate, diverge, sheer, swerve, turn off
A: ♠考法2  vt. 散开： to go or move in different directions from a central point
A: ♣例  At that point the road and the railroad tracks diverge. 公路和铁路在那个点分叉了。
A: ♣近  branch out, divide, spread
A: ♣反  converge, join 会合
A: ♠考法3  v. 分歧： to become or be different in character or form: differ in opinion
A: ♣近  differ, disagree
A: ♣反  conform 遵从
A: ♠考法4  vt. 离题： to depart from a set course or norm; deviate
A: ♣近  excurse, ramble, diverge, get off the subject

Q:diversity  [dai'və:səti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 多样性： variety or multiformity
A: ♣例  the diversity of species 物种的多样性
A: ♣近  diverseness, multifariousness, multiplicity, variousness , miscellaneousness
A: ♠考法2  n. 分歧，不同点：the quality or state of being different
A: ♣例  There is no fundamental diversity between the two ideologies. 这两种思想意识之间并没有根本的分歧。
A: ♣近  contrast, disagreement, discrepancy, disparateness, disparity, dissimilarity, dissimilitude, distinction, otherness, unlikeness
A: ♣反  alikeness, analogy, likeness, resemblance, sameness, similarity 相同，相似

Q:divert  [dai'və:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使转向：to turn from one course or use to another: deflect
A: ♣例  divert traffic to a side street 使交通转至辅路
A: ♣近  deflect, redirect, swing, veer, wheel
A: ♣反  fix, set, settle 固定
A: ♠考法2  v. 使消遣：to cause (someone) to pass the time agreeably occupied
A: ♣例  A light comedy divert the tired business executive 一个轻松的喜剧让疲惫的企业主管人员得到了放松。
A: ♣近  disport, entertain, regale, solace
A: ♠考法3  v. 使分心：to draw the attention or mind to something else
A: ♣例  divert one’s attention 转移某人注意力 || The parents tried to divert the child with a toy while the doctor was giving her a shot. 当医生要给那个孩子打针的时候，孩子父母试图用玩具转移孩子的注意力。
A: ♣近  abstract, detract, call off

Q:divestiture  [dai'vestitʃə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 剥夺：the act of taking away from a person
A: ♣例  Melodramas were popular because they offered the audience a divestiture of neutrality. 情节剧之所有受到欢迎是因为他们给观众一个缺乏中立的（世界）。
A: ♣近  deprivation, dispossession
A: ♣反  acquisition 获得；endowment 捐赠

Q:divulge  [dai'vʌldʒ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 泄漏（秘密）：to make known (as a confidence or secret)
A: ♣例  refuse to divulge details of the negotiations 拒绝透露谈判的细节内容 || We tried to make him divulge the name of the winner, but he wouldn't budge. 我们试图让他透露胜利者的名字，但是他没有那样做。
A: ♣近  bare, disclose, discover, expose, uncover, unmask, unveil
A: ♣反  conceal, cover up, hide, mask, shroud, veil 保密，隐藏

Q:doctrinaire  [,dɔktri'nεə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 教条主义的，照本宣科的： given to or marked by the forceful expression of strongly held opinions
A: ♣例  A doctrinaire conservative, the columnist takes special delight in baiting liberals. 这个专栏作家是个谨遵教条的顽固保守主义者，他很享受挑衅那些自由主义者。
A: ♣近  dogmatic
A: ♣近  latitudinarian （宗教方面）能容纳不同意见的

Q:dodder  ['dɔdə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 蹒跚，颤巍巍地行进：to progress feebly and unsteadily
A: ♣例  He could only dodder along after the operation. 他手术后只能步履蹒跚的走。
A: ♣近  careen, lurch, teeter, totter, waddle

Q:dodge  [dɔdʒ]

A: ♣例  dodge a storm of bullets 躲避枪林弹雨 || He dodged the first punch but was hit by the second. 他躲过了第一次打击但是没有躲过第二次。
A: ♣近  avoid, escape, shirk, malinger, goldbrick, evade, parry, sidestep, circumvent, fence, hedge, avert, elude, shun, skirt, bilk, eschew, weasel

Q:doff  [dɔf]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 脱下： to take off; remove
A: ♣例  The blazing sun soon had the men doffing their jackets. 炙热的太阳很快就让男人们脱掉了夹克。
A: ♣近  put off, take off
A: ♣反  don, put on 穿上

Q:dogged  ['dɔgid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 坚持的，坚决的： continuing despite difficulties, opposition, or discouragement；showing no signs of slackening or yielding in one's purpose
A: ♣例  gain respect through sheer dogged determination 凭借单纯的坚决赢得了尊重 || A madman who spent his life in dogged pursuit of power 一个一生都坚持追求权力的疯子
A: ♣近  insistent, persevering, pertinacious, tenacious, determined
A: ♣反  easily discouraged 容易气馁的；yielded 屈服的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 固执的，任性的： sticking to an opinion, purpose, or course of action in spite of reason, arguments, or persuasion
A: ♣例  Your dogged adherence to a really lame argument is embarrassing. 你固执的坚持一个站不住脚的观点令人很尴尬。
A: ♣近  adamant, hardheaded, headstrong, inflexible, intransigent, mulish, obdurate opinionated, ossified, pertinacious, self-opinionated, self-willed stubborn, unbending, uncompromising, unrelenting, unyielding, willful
A: ♣反  acquiescent, amenable, compliant, complying, flexible, pliable, pliant, relenting, yielding 顺从的

Q:dogma  ['dɔɡmə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 教条，信条： a doctrine or body of doctrines concerning faith or morals formally stated and authoritatively proclaimed by a church
A: ♣例  People are beginning to question the old dogmas. 人们开始质疑旧的信条。|| The newspaper seeks to be independent of political dogma. 这份报纸力求不受政治信条影响。
A: ♣近  credo, doctrine, gospel
A: ♣反  heresy, heterodoxy 异端学说
A: ♣派  dogmatic 独断的，武断的： characterized by an authoritative, arrogant assertion of unproved principles
A: ♣例  a dogmatic critic 独断的评论家
A: ♣近  dictatorial, dictative, authoritarian, authoritative, magisterial

Q:doldrums  ['dɔldrəmz]
A: ♠考法1  n. 低迷，中断： a state or period of inactivity, stagnation, or slump
A: ♣例  August is a time of doldrums for many enterprises. 对于许多企业来说八月是一个低迷期‖The economy is in the doldrums. 经济低迷
A: ♣近  abeyance, dormancy, latency, quiescence, moratorium
A: ♣反  continuation 持续
A: ♠考法2  n. 情绪不佳：a state or spell of low spirits
A: ♣例  The team had been in the doldrums ever since losing the championship. 整个队伍自从输了锦标赛以来一直情绪不佳
A: ♣近  dejection, depression, desolation, despondence, dolefulness, gloom, melancholy, unhappiness
A: ♣反  bliss, ecstasy, elation, exhilaration, exuberance, exultation, jubilation, rapture, felicity

Q:dolorous  ['dɔlərəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 忧伤的： causing, marked by, or expressing misery or grief
A: ♣例  He lifted a pair of sapphire, dolorous eyes. 他抬起了一双忧郁的蓝宝石般的眼睛
A: ♣近  agonized, bemoaning, bewailing, deplorable, grievous ,miserable, plaintive, rueful, sorrowful, woeful
A: ♣反  happy, joyful, jovial, jubilant 高兴的

Q:dolt  [dəult]

A: ♣近  idiot, fool, moron, simpleton, dullard
A: ♣反  illuminati, intellectual 智者；genius 天才
A: ♣派  doltish adj. 愚笨的

Q:domicile  ['dɔmisail]

A: ♣例  an alternate domicile in emergency 紧急情况下的住所
A: ♣近  home, dwelling, habitation, abode, house, lodging

A: ♣近  accommodate, bestow lodge, harbor, put up
A: ♣反  banish, expel 驱逐

Q:dominant  ['dɔminənt]

A: ♣例  the dominant culture 主流文化
A: ♣近  ascendant, leading, outweighing, paramount, prevalent, principal, supreme
A: ♣反  subordinate （等级上）低的

A: ♣反  recessive 隐形的
A: ♣派  dominate v. 占主导地位，统治；dominance n. 主导，主流；（基因的）显性

Q:domineer  [,dɔmi'niə]

Q:don  [dɔn]

A: ♣近  assume, wear, put on
A: ♣反  doff 脱下

Q:donor  ['dəunə]

A: ♣近  donator, presenter, contributor, subscriber, patron, sugar daddy

Q:doodle  ['du:dl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. （无目的地）乱画： to scribble aimlessly, especially when preoccupied

A: ♣近  mess around

A: ♣例  I plan to spend the entire vacation just doodling. 我打算整个假期就随便做点事打发时间
A: ♣近  dawdle, trifle

Q:dormant  ['dɔ:mənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 静止的，不活跃的： in a state of rest or inactivity; inoperative; in abeyance
A: ♣例  volcanoes which have been dormant for thousand years 休眠了上千年的火山
A: ♣近  dead, latent, lurking, abeyant, quiescent, inert
A: ♣反  active, busy, operating 活跃的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （动物）冬眠的： having biological activity suspended
A: ♣例  The bears lay dormant in their den during the winter. 在冬季，熊在他们的穴里冬眠
A: ♣近  asleep, resting, napping, slumbering
A: ♣反  awake 清醒的
A: ♣派  dormancy n. 不活跃；冬眠

Q:dour  [duə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 闷闷不乐的,死气沉沉的： sullen, gloomy
A: ♣例  The captain’s dour look depressed us all. 船长闷闷不乐的脸色使我们倍感低落
A: ♣近  morose, sulky, surly, moody
A: ♣反  gay 欢快的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 严厉的： harsh and threatening in manner or appearance
A: ♣例  His dour criticism made us regret having undertaken the job. 他严厉的批评让我们后悔接下这活儿了
A: ♣近  strict, sharp, austere, exacting, fierce, gruff, intimidating, rough, stark, stern
A: ♣反  benign, gentle, mild, tender 温和的

Q:douse  [daus]

A: ♣例  douse a fire with water 用水熄灭火焰
A: ♣近  quench, extinguish, put out
A: ♣反  kindle, ignite, inflame 点燃
A: ♠考法2  n. 弄湿：to make wet
A: ♣例  The heavy rains thoroughly doused the tourists. 大雨把游客淋得透湿
A: ♣近  bathe, drench, soak, sodden, sop
A: ♣反  dehydrate, desiccate脱水；parch, scorch, sear 烧焦，烤焦

Q:downplay  ['daunplei]

A: ♣例  downplay the bad news 对坏消息轻描淡写
A: ♣近  de-emphasize, disregard, ignore, overlook, neglect, understate, play down
A: ♣反  address, emphasize, underscore 强调

Q:downpour  ['daunpɔ:]

A: ♣例  power failure due to the downpour 暴雨导致的电力中断
A: ♣近  deluge, downfall, cloudburst, rainstorm
A: ♣反  drizzle, sprinkle 细雨

Q:doyen  [dwɑ:'jæŋ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 有经验的人，资深人士： a person considered to be knowledgeable or uniquely skilled as a result of long experience in some field of endeavor
A: ♣例  a doyen in the industry 业界的元老
A: ♣近  authority, expert, master, maven, veteran, virtuoso
A: ♣反  amateur, layman 业余爱好者，门外汉；tyro, novice, neophyte, rookie, fledgling 新手
A: ♠考法2  n. （加入时间较长的）高级会员： the senior member of a group
A: ♣例  He's the doyen of the admission committee, and his opinion has considerable weight. 他是招生委员会里的老人了，所以他的话往往格外有分量
A: ♣近  elder, senior
A: ♣反  junior 新人

Q:doze  [dəuz]
A: ♠考法1  vi./n.小憩： to sleep lightly or briefly
A: ♣例  He dozed off during the lecture. 他在讲座上睡着了
A: ♣近  drowse, nap, wink, slumber
A: ♣反  wake 醒来

Q:drab  [dræb]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 单调的，无聊的： characterized by dullness and monotony
A: ♣例  The new city hall turned out to be another drab pile of masonry for the town. 新的市政大厅结果又是城镇里一座单调无趣的砖瓦堆积物。
A: ♣近  arid, dreary, drudging, humdrum, jading, jejune, monochromatic, monotonous, pedestrian, ponderous, stale, stodgy, tedious, tiresome, wearisome
A: ♣反  absorbing, engaging, engrossing, gripping, interesting, intriguing, involving, riveting 令人感兴趣的

Q:draconian  [drə'kəunjən]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 极其残酷的；十分严厉的： exceedingly harsh; very severe
A: ♣例  abolish a draconian legal code 废除一部严酷的法典
A: ♣近  rigid, ironhanded, strict, stringent
A: ♣反  mild, genial, lenient 温和的

Q:dramatic  [drə'mætik]
A: ♠考法1  adj.显著的，惹人注意的： striking in appearance or effect
A: ♣例  a dramatic drop in the temperature overnight 夜晚气温的显著下降
A: ♣近  arresting, bold, brilliant, catchy, conspicuous, flamboyant, prominent, remarkable, splashy, striking
A: ♣反  discreet, inconspicuous, invisible, subtle, unnoticeable, unobtrusive 不易引起注意的
A: ♣派  dramatically adv. 显著地

Q:drawl  [drɔ:l]
A: ♠考法1  v. 慢吞吞地说： to speak slowly with vowels greatly prolonged
A: ♣例  The old woman was drawling on and on. 老太太慢吞吞地说个没完
A: ♣近  extend, lengthen, prolong, protract, draw out
A: ♣反  drivel, gibber 快速（而模糊）地说

Q:dread  [dred]
A: ♠考法1  n. 恐惧： great fear especially in the face of impending evil
A: ♣例  We were filled with dread when we saw the rapids we would be rafting down. 当我们看到竹筏驶向的激流时，我们的内心被恐惧所占据。
A: ♣近  alarm, apprehension, consternation, fear, fright, horror, terror, trepidation
A: ♣反  bravery, courage, dauntlessness, fearlessness, fortitude, intrepidity, stoutness, valor 勇气，无畏
A: ♣派  dreadful adj. 令人恐惧的

Q:dreary  ['driəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 单调乏味的：having nothing likely to provide cheer, comfort, or interest
A: ♣例  The day is cold, rainy, and dreary. 天气寒冷，阴暗而沉闷
A: ♣近  desolate, gloomy, sullen, dull, monotone, pedestrian, somber
A: ♣反  jocund 令人欢乐的
A: ♠考法2  adj.令人不悦的： causing unhappiness
A: ♣例  decided to see a professional counselor in order to save their dreary marriage 决定咨询专业人士以拯救他们悲剧式的婚姻
A: ♣近  depressing, dismal, heartbreaking, mournful, pathetic, melancholy
A: ♣反  cheering 令人激动高兴的
A: ♣派  drearily adv. 令人厌烦地

Q:drench  [drentʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 湿透，浸透： to wet thoroughly
A: ♣例  The thunderstorm drenched us to the skin. 雷雨把我们浇了个透
A: ♣近  deluge, douse, soak, saturate, sodden, sop, wet
A: ♣反  dehydrate, desiccate, dry, parch, scorch, sear 干燥

Q:drivel  [drivəl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 胡言乱语： unintelligible or meaningless talk
A: ♣例  My roommate talks in her sleep, but it's just drivel. 我的室友会说梦话，但都是些没有意义的呓语
A: ♣近  abracadabra, nonsense, prattle, gabble, prattle
A: ♠考法2  v. 胡言乱语，说傻话： to talk stupidly and carelessly
A: ♣例  He always drivel on about his “distinguished” family. 他总是痴痴地说着他所谓的“名门”出身
A: ♣近  babble, gabble, gibber, jabber

Q:drizzle  ['drizl]
A: ♠考法1  vi./n. （下）细小、轻柔、似雾的雨，毛毛雨： a fine misty rain
A: ♣例  The intermittent drizzle was just heavy enough to spoil all of our outdoor activities. 断断续续的小雨恰好大岛让我们所有的户外活动都泡汤
A: ♣近  mist, sprinkle
A: ♣反  deluge, downpour 倾盆大雨
A: ♣派  drizzling adj. （雨）细小的

Q:droll  [drəul]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 古怪有趣的，离奇可笑的： amusingly odd or whimsically comical
A: ♣例  a droll man with a strong dialect 带着浓郁口音的有意思的人
A: ♣近  antic, comic, farcical, funny, hilarious, laughable, humorous, ridiculous, ludicrous, uproarious, whimsical
A: ♣反  lame, unamusing, uncomic, unfunny, unhumorous, unhysterical 不幽默的
A: ♣派  drollness n. 古怪

Q:drone  ['drəun]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 单调地说： to talk in a persistently dull or monotonous tone
A: ♣例  droning bees 嗡嗡作响的蜜蜂
A: ♣近  hum, buzz, bumble
A: ♠考法2  n.（昆虫振翅般）单调的声音： a monotonous sound like that of an insect in motion
A: ♣例  heard the drone of an helicopter overhead 听到了头顶直升机单调的声音
A: ♣近  burr, whir
A: ♠考法2  v. 混日子： to spend time doing nothing
A: ♣例  Instead of getting a job, he preferred to drone and live off his parents. 相对于找个工作来说，他更喜欢什么也不做，依靠他的父母过日子
A: ♣近  dally, dawdle, hang, laze, loll, lounge

Q:drudgery  ['drʌdʒəri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 苦工；单调、卑贱或无趣的工作： tedious, menial, or unpleasant work
A: ♣例  get away from the drudgery of their everyday lives 摆脱每日的单调无聊
A: ♣近  labor, slavery, toil, travail, grind
A: ♣反  sinecure 闲职，美差；fun, play 玩耍，娱乐

Q:dubious  ['dju:bjəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 充满不定性的，值得怀疑的： giving rise to uncertainty; questionable or suspect as to true nature or quality
A: ♣例  a dubious assertion 一个值得怀疑的论调
A: ♣近  debatable, doubtful, disputable, equivocal, problematic, questionable, shaky
A: ♣反  certain, incontestable, undeniable 确定的，毋庸置疑的；reliable 可靠的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （对事实等）持怀疑态度的： not feeling sure about the truth, wisdom, or trustworthiness of someone or something
A: ♣例  dubious about a diet that claims I can eat all I want and still lose weight 对于一份声称可以一边随心所欲地吃和一边减肥的节食方案表示怀疑
A: ♣近  distrustful, skeptical, suspicious, unsure
A: ♣反  convinced, positive, sure 表示肯定态度的，确信的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 迟疑不决的，不愿行动的： slow to begin or proceed with a course of action because of doubts or uncertainty
A: ♣例  I'm dubious about our plan to go hang gliding without having had any training. 我对于不做任何训练就去玩滑翔感到很迟疑
A: ♣近  undecided, disinclined, loath, reluctant, reticent
A: ♣反  disposed, inclined 倾向于……的
A: ♣派  dubiety n. 可疑，怀疑

Q:ductile  ['dʌktail]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可塑的，有延展性的： easily molded or shaped, malleable
A: ♣例  Gold is a kind of ductile metal. 金是一种有延展性的金属
A: ♣近  malleable, moldable
A: ♣反  inflexible 僵硬的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 易受影响的： easily led or influenced
A: ♣例  a ductile personality 易受他人影响的性格
A: ♣近  pliant, yielding, supple
A: ♣反  adamant, intractable, refractory, obdurate 倔强的，不易改变立场的

Q:dulcet  ['dʌlsit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 悦耳的，令人愉悦的： pleasing to the ear; melodious; generally pleasing or agreeable
A: ♣例  dulcet tones from harps and flutes 竖琴和长笛发出的悦耳音调
A: ♣近  sweet, agreeable, delightful, euphonic, mellifluous, tuneful, winsome
A: ♣反  cacophonous, grating 刺耳的

Q:dullard  ['dʌləd]
A: ♠考法1  n. 笨蛋：a stupid or unimaginative person
A: ♣近  moron, simpleton, idiot, fool
A: ♣反  wit 机智的人；genius 天才
A: ♣派  dull adj. 愚笨的

Q:dupe  [dju:p]
A: ♠考法1  n. 复制品，复刻： something that is made to look exactly like something else
A: ♣例  He built a dupe of the original model, which is locked in a vault. 他做了个保险柜里模型的复刻品
A: ♣近  clone, duplicate, facsimile, imitation, mock, replica
A: ♣反  archetype, original, prototype 原型
A: ♠考法2  n. 易受骗的人： one that is easily deceived or cheated
A: ♣例  The swindler was able to escape with all of the dupe's money. 骗子成功带着受骗人的财产逃跑了
A: ♣近  fool, victim, gull
A: ♣反  connoisseur 行家，鉴赏家
A: ♠考法3  vt. 欺骗： to deceive (an unwary person)
A: ♣例  The public is easily duped by extravagant claims in advertising. 大众极易被广告中夸大的介绍误导
A: ♣近  bamboozle, beguile, cheat, cozen, delude, gull, hoax, hoodwink
A: ♣派  dupable adj. 易受骗的

Q:duplicate  ['dju:plikət]
A: ♠考法1  n. 复制品： either of two things exactly alike and usually produced at the same time or by the same process
A: ♣例  a duplicate of a house key 房间钥匙的复制品‖Your computer is almost a duplicate of mine. 你的电脑和我的几乎一模一样。
A: ♣近  copy, dupe, duplication, facsimile, imitation, mock, reduplication, replica, replication, reproduction
A: ♣反  archetype, original, prototype 原型
A: ♠考法2  vt. 复制： to make a copy of
A: ♣例  A cell duplicates itself when it divides. 当一个细胞分裂时，它会完全按着自己的样子复制。‖Art students are trying to duplicate paintings in the museum’s collection as part of their training. 艺术生们努力地复刻博物馆中的作品，由此作为他们的训练。
A: ♣近  clone, copycat, imitate, reduplicate, render, replicate, reproduce
A: ♣反  originate 原创
A: ♠考法3  vt. 重复，反复： to do over or again often needlessly
A: ♣例  We were unable to duplicate the experiment with the same result in our own lab, so we’re suspicious. 我们不能在自己的实验室中重复之前的实验并得到相同的结果，因此我们很怀疑。
A: ♣近  redo, reiterate, renew, repeat
A: ♣派  duplicable adj. 可模仿的

Q:duplicity  [dju:'plisəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 欺骗，口是心非： deliberate deceptiveness in behavior or speech
A: ♣例  accidentally reveal their duplicity 不经意间暴露了他们的口是心非
A: ♣近  artifice, deceit, craft, cunning, fraudulence, guile
A: ♣反  honesty, artlessness, forthrightness, guilelessness, ingenuousness, sincerity 诚实，坦诚

Q:dwindle  ['dwindl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 逐渐减少： to become gradually less until little remains
A: ♣例  His vast fortune is dwindling away. 他的巨额财富正慢慢缩水
A: ♣近  abate, decrease, drop, diminish, reduce, shrink, taper, wane, knock down
A: ♣反  aggrandize, balloon, burgeon, increase 增加；accumulate 累积
A: ♣派  dwindling adj. 减少的

Q:dynamic  [dai'næmik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有力量的，有活力的： marked by usually continuous and productive activity or change; energetic
A: ♣例  He has become a dynamic new challenger for the title of champion. 他成为了有望夺的有活力的新选手。‖a dynamic speech expressing her goals and values 宣扬她的目标和理念的慷慨激昂的演讲
A: ♣近  brisk, energetic, flush, forceful, gingery, kinetic, lusty, peppy, robust, sprightly, vital, vivacious
A: ♣反  dull, lethargic, listless, sluggish, torpid 无精打采的

Q:dyspeptic  [dis'peptik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 脾气坏的：bad-tempered
A: ♣例  The sultry day makes us dyspeptic. 闷热潮湿的天气让我们变得脾气暴躁
A: ♣近  cantankerous, disagreeable, irritable, fretful, irascible, peevish, splenetic, surly
A: ♣反  amiable, easygoing, genial, good-humored, good-natured, good-tempered 随和的，和蔼的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 消化不良的：pertaining to, subject to, or suffering from dyspepsia
A: ♣派  dyspepsia n. 消化不良

Q:earnest  ['ə:nist]

A: ♣反  facetious, frivolous, flip, flippant, playful 轻浮的

A: ♣例  wait until he was out of earshot 等到他听不见的时候
A: ♣近  hail, hearing, sound

Q:earsplitting  ['iə,splitiŋ]

A: ♣反  gentle, soft （音乐）轻柔的

Q:eavesdrop  ['i:vzdrɔp]

Q:ebullient  [i'bʌljənt]

Q:eccentric  [ik'sentrik]

Q:eclat  [ei'kla:]

A: ♣近  fame, renown, brilliance, triumph
A: ♣反  debacle, fiasco 惨败

Q:eclectic  [e'klektik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 混合的，多元化的： composed of elements drawn from various sources
A: ♣例  The museum’s eclectic collection has everything from a giraffe skeleton to medieval musical instruments. 博物馆里的展品丰富多样，从长颈鹿的骨架到中世纪的乐器都有。
A: ♣近  assorted, diverse, heterogeneous, indiscriminate, magpie, mixed, motley, piebald, ragtag, varied
A: ♣反  homogeneous, uniform 同一性的

Q:eclipse  [i'klips]
A: ♠考法1  n. 下降，衰退： a change to a lower state or level
A: ♣例  the eclipse of the town from a grand seaside resort to a tacky tourist trap 从壮丽辉煌的海边旅游圣地退化成了俗气的坑人景点
A: ♣近  decadence, degeneration, degradation, deterioration, ebb, fall
A: ♣反  ascent, rise, upswing 上升，崛起
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使声望下降，使黯然失色： to obscure or diminish in importance, fame, or reputation
A: ♣例  Her score eclipsed the old record. 她的分数使旧的纪录黯然失色
A: ♣近  adumbrate, obscure, overshadow
A: ♠考法3  vt.（在数量、品质上）超越： to be greater, better, or stronger than
A: ♣例  The brilliant young pianist now eclipsed even his own mentor in musical artistry. 极富天赋的小钢琴家如今甚至已超越了他的音乐导师
A: ♣近  beat, exceed, excel, outshine, outstrip, surpass, transcend
A: ♣反  fall behind 落后

Q:ecstasy  ['ekstəsi]

A: ♣例  an ecstasy of rage 无法自控的愤怒
A: ♣近  mania, rhapsody
A: ♣反  self-control 自控，自制；composure, sangfroid 镇定
A: ♠考法2  n. 狂喜： intense joy or delight
A: ♣例  be in ecstasy over the offer from Harvard University 因被哈佛的录取而欣喜如狂
A: ♣近  delight, elation, euphoria, exhilaration, rapture, transport
A: ♣反  depression, melancholy 沮丧

Q:ecumenical  [,i:kju:'menikəl]

A: ♣近  catholic
A: ♣反  diocesan 主教管辖特定小教区的

A: ♣例  an ecumenical scope 国际视野
A: ♣近  universal, cosmopolitan, global, planetary, worldwide
A: ♣反  provincial, insular 狭隘的

Q:edible  ['edibl]

Q:edifice  ['edifis]

A: ♣近  building, erection, palace
A: ♣反  cottage 小棚舍

A: ♣例  The edifice of the argument is quite simple, once you get past the fancy language. 只要你看透了表面花哨的语言，你会发现这段论证的基本构架是非常简单的
A: ♣近  architecture, configuration, framework, skeleton, structure

Q:efface  [i'feis]
A: ♠考法1  v t. 擦掉，抹去；使不明显： to eliminate or make indistinct by or as if by wearing away a surface
A: ♣例  efface those unpleasant memories 抹去那些不快的记忆
A: ♣近  eradicate, erase, expunge, exterminate, extirpate, liquidate, eclipse, obliterate, wipe, root out
A: ♣反  blazon, decorate 装饰；emboss 使凸起，使显现
A: ♣派  self-effacing adj. 谦卑、低调的

Q:effervesce  [,efə'ves]

A: ♣例  effervescing with bubbles 冒气泡
A: ♣近  bubble, foam, froth
A: ♠考法2  vi. 兴奋，热情洋溢： to show high spirits or animation
A: ♣例  effervescing over the news of victory 因胜利的消息而兴奋
A: ♣近  rejoice, exult, jubilate, triumph
A: ♣反  grieve 感到极度悲伤
A: ♣派  effervescent adj. 热情洋溢的；effervescence n. 热情洋溢

Q:effete  [i'fi:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 衰弱的： depleted of vitality, force, or effectiveness
A: ♣例  an effete monarchy 奄奄一息的君主制
A: ♣近  consumed, debilitated, decadent, degenerate, depleted, drained, exhausted, feeble
A: ♣反  hale, sound, robust 强健的，充满活力的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 缺乏信念的，懦弱的： lacking strength of will or character
A: ♣例  The government is too effete to take out the powerful special interests that really ruin this state. 政府过于懦弱，不敢去摧毁那些祸害这个国家的特殊利益集团
A: ♣近  frail, invertebrate, nerveless, spineless
A: ♣反  backboned, firm, hard, strong, tough 刚毅的
A: ♣派  effetely adv. 衰弱地

Q:efficacious  [,efi'keiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有效的： having the power to produce a desired effect
A: ♣例  Taking break with a cup of coffee while studying is one of the most efficacious ways of rejuvenating the mind that I have ever discovered. 在紧张的学习中休息一会，喝杯咖啡，是我发现的最能提神的方法之一。
A: ♣近  effective, effectual, efficient, fruitful, operative, potent, productive
A: ♣反  bootless, fruitless, ineffective, ineffectual, inefficient, inoperative, unproductive, useless 无效的

Q:effluvium  [i'flu:vjəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 难闻的气味： an offensive exhalation or smell
A: ♣例  Repulsive effluvia made us vomit. 这恶臭让我们作呕
A: ♣近  malodor, stink, stench
A: ♣反  fragrance, aroma 芳香
A: ♠考法2  n. 没用的副产品，废品： a by-product especially in the form of waste
A: ♣例  With nothing but effluvia obtained, researchers decided to abandon this method. 由于得不到目标产物，研究者们决定放弃这种手段
A: ♣近  dross, refuse, rubbish, trash, waste
A: ♣派  effluvial adj. 恶臭的

Q:effrontery  [i'frʌntəri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 厚颜无耻，放肆大胆： flagrant disregard of courtesy or propriety and an arrogant assumption of privilege
A: ♣例  had the effrontery to insult her father 胆敢辱骂她的父亲
A: ♣近  audacity, brashness, brazenness, insolence, nerve, presumption, temerity
A: ♣反  decorum, propriety, courtesy, grace 得体；timidity 胆小

Q:effulgent  [i'fʌldʒənt]

A: ♣例  an effulgent sunset on the Atlantic 大西洋上壮丽辉煌的日落
A: ♣近  bright, beaming, glorious, luminous, radiant, splendid
A: ♣反  dim, murky, dull 模糊的，黯淡的
A: ♣派  effulgence n. 光辉

Q:effusive  [i'fju:siv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 感情泛滥溢于言表的；感情表达不节制和过度的；过分多情的： unrestrained or excessive in emotional expression
A: ♣例  The principal delivered an effusive address at the commencement ceremony. 校长在毕业典礼上做了充满感情的演讲
A: ♣近  emotional, expansive, demonstrative, gushy, passionate
A: ♣反  inhibited, reserved, restrained 节制的；undemonstrative, unemotional 不易动情的；numb, torpid 麻木不仁的
A: ♣派  effusion n. 流出，溢出

Q:egalitarian  [i,ɡæli'tεəriən]

A: ♣例  the egalitarian principle guiding his endeavor 引导他奋斗的平等主义原则

A: ♣反  inequitable, discriminating, unfair 有偏见的，不公平的
A: ♣派  egalitarianism n. 平等主义

Q:egoistic  [,i:ɡəu'istik]

A: ♣派  ego n. 自大，自我；egoism n. 利己主义；egoist n. 以自我为中心的人

Q:elaborate  [i'læbərət]

A: ♣例  an elaborate manual 内容详尽的使用手册
A: ♣近  circumstantial, complex, complicated, intricate, knotty, minute, particular, particularized, sophisticated
A: ♣反  sketchy, brief, compendious, summary 概要性的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 详细阐述： to expand something in detail
A: ♣例  The defense committee asked the PhD candidate to elaborate one critical assumption in his thesis. 答辩委员会要求答辩的博士进一步说明他毕业论文中的一个关键假设
A: ♣近  develop, expand, amplify, explain
A: ♣反  abstract, abbreviate, condense, simplify 简化；downplay, ignore, neglect, overlook 忽视，忽略

Q:elastic  [i'læstik]

A: ♣例  elastic rubber band 弹性橡胶圈
A: ♣近  bouncy, flexible, malleable, resilient, stretchable, supple
A: ♣反  rigid, stiff 僵化的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 能（迅速从伤痛中）恢复的： capable of recovering quickly especially from depression or disappointment
A: ♣例  owe her success to an elastic optimistic nature 将她的成功归因于能迅速走出悲伤的乐观品质
A: ♣近  adaptable, adjustable, buoyant, pliable, volatile
A: ♣反  established, fixed, immutable 不变的
A: ♣派  inelastic adj. 无弹性的，非弹性的

Q:elate  [i'leit]

A: ♣近  cheer, excite, exhilarate, inspire, stimulate
A: ♣反  depress, dishearten, sadden 使沮丧
A: ♣派  elated adj. 高兴的；elation n. 高兴

Q:eleemosynary  [,elii:'mɔsinəri]

A: ♣近  benevolent, charitable, humane, humanitarian, philanthropic
A: ♣反  parsimonious 吝啬的

Q:elegy  ['elidʒi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 哀歌（诗），挽歌（诗）： a song or poem expressing sorrow or lamentation
A: ♣例  an moving elegy played at the funeral 葬礼上演奏的催人泪下的挽歌
A: ♣近  dirge, lamentation, requiem
A: ♣反  ode 颂歌，颂词

Q:elephantine  [,eli'fæntain]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 巨大的： having enormous size or strength
A: ♣例  an elephantine meteor crate 巨大的陨石坑
A: ♣近  huge, colossal, enormous, gargantuan, gigantic, massive, prodigious, tremendous
A: ♣反  microscopic, minute, tiny , infinitesimal 细微的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 笨拙的： clumsy, ponderous
A: ♣例  elephantine movements 笨拙的行动
A: ♣近  awkward, graceless, maladroit
A: ♣反  graceful 优雅的

Q:elevate  ['eliveit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 道德、智力、文化水平的提升： to improve morally, intellectually, or culturally
A: ♣例  a novel that both entertains and elevates readers 一本寓教于乐的小说
A: ♣近  advance, boost, enhance, ennoble, raise, upgrade
A: ♣反  abase, debase, demote, degrade 贬低
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使兴奋： to raise the spirits of
A: ♣例  one of the most elevating moments in their lives 生命中最让人兴奋的时刻之一
A: ♣近  elate, enrapture, exhilarate, intoxicate, transport
A: ♣反  depress 使沮丧
A: ♣派  elevation n. 提升；喜悦

Q:elicit  [i'lisit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 激起，唤起： to draw forth or bring out
A: ♣例  The king’s speech elicited lasting cheer and applause. 国王的演讲激起了持续的欢呼和掌声
A: ♣近  arouse, evoke, excite, inspire, provoke, raise
A: ♣反  appease, placate, mollify, pacify 平息

Q:elliptical  [i'liptik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 含糊不清的： of or relating to deliberate obscurity (as of literary or conversational style)
A: ♣例  give an elliptical response to the inquiry 就问题给出一个含糊其辞的回答
A: ♣近  ambiguous, arcane, cryptic, enigmatic, equivocal, inscrutable, murky, nebulous, occult, opaque, vague
A: ♣反  clear, explicit, unambiguous, unequivocal 清晰明确的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 椭圆的：of, relating to, or shaped like an ellipse
A: ♣近  oval, ovate
A: ♣反  circular, round 圆形的
A: ♣派  ellipse n. 椭圆

Q:elucidate  [i'lu:si,deit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 阐明： to make lucid especially by explanation or analysis
A: ♣例  elucidate an abstruse equation in quantum mechanics 阐明一个深奥难懂的量子力学方程
A: ♣近  clarify, clear, construe, explain, explicate, expound, illustrate
A: ♣反  confuse, obfuscate, obscure使困惑；garble 曲解
A: ♣派  elucidation n. 阐释，阐明

Q:elude  [i'lju:d]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 躲闪，躲避： to avoid adroitly
A: ♣例  managed to elude capture 成功躲过了追捕‖The millionaire had been eluding his fair share of taxes for years before getting caught. 在被逮捕之前，这名富翁逃税已经有若干年了。
A: ♣近  avoid, dodge, duck, eschew, evade, finesse, scape, shirk, shun, sidestep, weasel
A: ♣反  confront 直面，面对
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使无法理解，使困惑： to escape the perception, understanding, or grasp of
A: ♣例  a metaphor that eluded them 一个让他们无法理解的比喻
A: ♣近  baffle, befog, befuddle, bewilder, confound, discombobulate, disorient, maze, mystify, perplex, puzzle, vex
A: ♣反  clarify, elucidate, explicate, expound, illuminate, illustrate 解释，阐明
A: ♣派  elusive adj. 隐秘的；难懂的

Q:emaciate  [i'meisieit]

A: ♣例  become emaciated by long illness 因长年累月的病痛而消瘦
A: ♣反  fatten 变胖
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使虚弱： to make feeble
A: ♣例  His hesitation emaciated the force of his argument. 他的迟疑削弱了他论证的力度
A: ♣近  droop, flag, sag, decay, enfeeble, enervate, languish, wane, wither
A: ♣反  invigorate 使充满活力
A: ♣派  emaciation n. 虚弱

Q:emancipate  [i'mænsipeit]

Q:embark  [em'bɑ:k]

A: ♣反  disembark 下车，下船

A: ♣近  begin, commence, launch, initiate, start,
A: ♣反  conclude, end, finish, terminate 结束

Q:embarrass  [im'bærəs]

A: ♣反  aid, facilitate 促进
A: ♣派  embarrassing adj. 令人窘迫的；embarrassment n. 尴尬

Q:embroider  [im'brɔidə]

A: ♣例  embroider the story of his adventures in the army 细说他服役时惊险的经历

Q:enamel  [i'næməl]

Q:enamored  [en'æməd]

A: ♣反  criticism 批评；abuse, invective, vituperation 辱骂

Q:encompass  [in'kʌmpəs]

A: ♣例  a plan that encompasses multiple aims 一项包含了多个目标的计划

A: ♣反  exclude 排除
A: ♠考法2  v. 包围： envelop

A: ♣近  circle, embrace, enclose, environ, surround

Q:encumber  [in'kʌmbə]

A: ♣例  Don't encumber your pack animal so much that it can hardly move. 别让你的牲畜驮这么多东西，它都走不动了
A: ♣近  burden, laden, lumber, saddle
A: ♣反  unload 卸下

Q:endeavor  [in'devə]

A: ♠考法2  vt. 努力做…，拼搏： to devote serious and sustained effort
A: ♣例  endeavor to improve the quality of life in the inner city 努力改善市内的生活质量‖They endeavored to create a government that truly serves its people. 他们在努力地创立一个一心为人民服务的政府。
A: ♣近  assay, drudge, hustle, moil, plod, slave, strain, strive, sweat, seek, toil, travail, tug
A: ♣反  drop, quit 放弃

A: ♣反  exotic, foreign, nonindigenous, nonnative 国外的，外来的

Q:enervate  ['enə:veit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使衰弱： to weaken or destroy the strength or vitality of
A: ♣例  His constitution was enervated by lustful lifestyle. 他荒淫无度的生活习惯已使他身体虚弱
A: ♣近  debilitate, disable, enfeeble, fatigue, sap
A: ♣反  fortify, strengthen 强化；energize, invigorate, vitalize 注入活力
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使麻木： to deprive of emotional or intellectual vitality
A: ♣例  A lifetime of working in dreary jobs had enervated his very soul. 一生忙于无聊的工作让他变得无比麻木
A: ♣近  dampen, deaden, petrify
A: ♣反  brace, energize, enliven, invigorate, vitalize, vivify 使充满活力
A: ♣派  enervation n. 虚弱

Q:enfranchise  [in'fræntʃaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 给予权利（例如选举权）： to endow with the rights of citizenship, especially the right to vote
A: ♣例  Slaves in US were emancipated in 1863 but were not enfranchised until the Fifteenth Amendment went into effect in 1870. 尽管在美国奴隶于1863年就获得了解放，但他们直到1870年《第五修正案》正式生效才获得选举权
A: ♣反  disenfranchise, disempower 剥夺权利
A: ♠考法2  vt. 解放：to set free (as from slavery)
A: ♣例  In a way, modern labor-saving appliances enfranchised people, giving them much more leisure time. 从某种意义上来说，那些节省劳动力的现代设备将人们解放出来，给予更多的休闲时间
A: ♣近  discharge, emancipate, free, liberate, manumit, rescue, unfetter
A: ♣反  bind, confine, enfetter 束缚；subjugate, subdue; enthrall 使臣服；使成为奴隶

Q:engender  [in'dʒendə]

A: ♣例  Her latest book has engendered a lot of controversy. 她的新书引发了很多争议
A: ♣近  beget, cause, catalyze, generate, induce, invoke, produce, spawn
A: ♠考法2  vt. 产生，出现： to come into existence
A: ♣例  Feelings of confidence and independence that were only just beginning to engender within her. 她的自信和独立的感觉才刚刚产生
A: ♣近  actualize, appear, arise, form, materialize, spring
A: ♣反  cease 停止；disappear, perish 消逝，死亡；eradicate; quash; terminate 根除；平息；终止

Q:engross  [in'ɡrəus]

A: ♣派  engrossed adj. 全神贯注的

Q:enigma  [i'niɡmə]

A: ♣例  The smile on Da Vinci’s masterpiece Mona Lisa has been an enigma for hundred years. 数百年来，达芬奇名作《蒙娜丽莎》上的微笑一直是个不解之谜
A: ♣近  mystery, conundrum, puzzle, riddle
A: ♣派  enigmatic adj. 谜一般的

Q:enlighten  [in'laitən]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使知道： to give information to; inform or instruct
A: ♣例  enlightened us about the thorny problem 启发我们思考这个棘手的问题
A: ♣近  apprise, instruct
A: ♣反  bewilder, confuse, confound, perplex 使疑惑
A: ♠考法2  vt.（在道德上）进行教育： to provide (someone) with moral or spiritual understanding
A: ♣例  Many people around the world have been enlightened by the teachings of Gautama Buddha. 释迦摩尼的说教启迪了世界上许许多多的人的灵魂
A: ♣近  edify, educate, illuminate, nurture
A: ♣派  enlightening adj. 具有启发性的

Q:enmity  ['enməti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 敌意： positive, active, and typically mutual hatred or ill will
A: ♣例  an unspoken enmity between two factions 两个派系间心照不宣的仇恨
A: ♣近  animosity, animus, antagonism, antipathy, feud, gall, hostility, rancor
A: ♣反  amity, comity 友好；concord 和睦

Q:ennoble  [i'nəubl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使尊贵： to make noble
A: ♣例  Her skill and talent ennoble her profession. 技能和天赋使她成为业界领军人物。
A: ♣近  aggrandize, canonize, deify, dignify, glorify, magnify
A: ♣反  debase, abase, degrade, demean, humble, humiliate 贬低

Q:ennui  ['ɔnwi:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 倦怠；缺乏兴趣： listlessness and dissatisfaction resulting from lack of interest
A: ♣例  the kind of ennui that comes from having too much time on one's hands and too little will to find something productive to do 倦怠来自于手上有大把时间却没有有益的事可做
A: ♣近  doldrums, listlessness, restlessness, tedium, weariness
A: ♣反  keen interest, energy, enthusiasm, exuberance 强烈的兴趣，生气盎然

Q:ensconce  [in'skɔns]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 安置： to settle (oneself) securely or comfortably
A: ♣例  ensconce in a new job 在一个新职位安定下来
A: ♣近  install, lodge, nestle, perch, roost, settle
A: ♣反  unsettle, dislodge, displace 使从安置好的地方移开，驱逐
A: ♠考法2  v. 隐藏： to put in a hiding place
A: ♣例  ensconced the spare house key in a place where no thief would think to look 把备用钥匙藏在小偷根本不会注意的地方
A: ♣近  bury, cache, conceal, secrete
A: ♣反  display, exhibit 展示

Q:ensemble  [ɔŋ'sɔŋblə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 合唱，合奏曲： a work for two or more vocalists or instrumentalists
A: ♣例  The actor performed an ensemble piece. 该演员参与了合唱。
A: ♣反  solo 独唱

Q:ensue  [in'sju:]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 紧随其后： take place afterward or as a result
A: ♣例  A brief but embarrassing silence ensued. 一阵短暂且令人尴尬的沉默随之而来。
A: ♣反  anterior 先前的

Q:entangle  [in'tæŋɡl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 卷入，纠缠： to twist together into a usually confused mass
A: ♣例  we managed to entangle the string of lights into a hopeless mess of wires 我们将小灯泡的线纠缠成了一堆
A: ♣近  interlace, intertwist, knot, snarl, tangle
A: ♠考法2  v. 使变复杂或困难： to make complex or difficult
A: ♣例  the history of Alexander the Great is entangled by variant accounts of his exploits 亚历山大大帝的生平历史被不同版本的记录搞得很纠结
A: ♣近  complexify, perplex, sophisticate
A: ♣反  simplify, streamline 简化

Q:enthrall  [in'θrɔ:l]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （像用魔咒般）吸引： to hold the attention of as if by a spell
A: ♣例  Enthralled by the flickering aurora in the sky, we lost all track of time. 我们被夜空里变化莫测的极光深深地吸引，以至于忘却了时间。
A: ♣近  absorb, arrest, bedazzle, enchant, engross, fascinate, grip, hypnotize, immerse, mesmerize, spellbind
A: ♣反  bore, jade, pall, tire, weary 使厌恶
A: ♣派  enthralling adj. 吸引人的

Q:enthusiasm  [in'θju:ziæzəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 热情，兴趣： urgent desire or interest
A: ♣例  in my enthusiasm to get going, I forgot to pack any foul-weather clothing 在强烈的出游热情下，我忘记带上防备坏天气的衣服了
A: ♣近  ardor, avidity, desirousness, impatience, keenness, lust, thirst
A: ♣反  apathy, indifference 无动于衷，漠不关心
A: ♣派  enthusiastic adj. 热情的
A: ♣反  halfhearted 心不在焉的

Q:entice  [in'tais]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 诱使： to attract artfully or adroitly or by arousing hope or desire: tempt; lure
A: ♣例  entice sb into doing sth 诱使某人做某事
A: ♣近  allure, bait, beguile, decoy, seduce, solicit, tempt, lead on
A: ♣派  enticing adj. 诱人的
A: ♣反  formidable 可怕的

Q:entrance  ['entrəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 进入权，进入许可： the means or right of entering or participating in
A: ♣例  entrance to the club is by invitation only 该俱乐部只接受受邀入会
A: ♣近  access, admission, admittance, gateway, ingress, passport, ticket
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使入迷： to fill with delight, wonder, or enchantment
A: ♣例  be entranced by the view 陶醉于景色
A: ♣近  enrapture, enthrall, ravish, transport, carry away
A: ♣反  bore, disappoint, disgust, repel, repulse 使厌烦
A: ♣派  entrancing adj. 使人欣喜的
A: ♣反  unprepossessing 不讨人喜欢的

Q:entrap  [in'træp]

A: ♣例  a string of inconsistent statements finally entrapped the witness 一系列不一致的陈述最终蒙骗了目击者
A: ♣近  ensnare, ensnarl, entoil, mesh, net, snare, catch up
A: ♣反  disentangle, untangle

Q:entreat  [in'tri:t]

A: ♣例  entreated his boss for another chance 恳求老板再给一次机会
A: ♣近  beseech, besiege, conjure, implore, importune, solicit, supplicate, plead to, appeal to

Q:enunciate  [i'nʌnsieit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 清晰地说： to utter articulate sounds
A: ♣例  enunciate your words, and then you won't have to repeat them so often 把话说清楚，你就不用经常重复了
A: ♣近  articulate
A: ♠考法2  v. 公开宣布，宣称： to make known openly or publicly
A: ♣例  today the President enunciated a new foreign policy 总统在今天宣布了一项新的对外政策
A: ♣近  annunciate, broadcast, declare, herald, proclaim, promulgate, publicize, release, give out

Q:ephemeral  [i'femərəl]

A: ♣例  ephemeral pleasures 暂时的压力
A: ♣近  evanescent, fleeting, impermanent, temporary, transient, transitory, fugacious, fugitive
A: ♣反  eternal, permanent, perpetual, enduring, everlasting, ceaseless, immortal, undying 永久的

Q:epic  ['epik]

A: ♣例  his genius was epic 他聪明过人
A: ♣近  august, grandiose, imposing, magnificent, majestic, monumental
A: ♣反  humble, unheroic, unimpressive, modest 适度的，印象不深的

Q:epicure  ['epi,kjuə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 美食家： one with sensitive and discriminating tastes especially in food or wine
A: ♣例  Thomas Jefferson was one of America's first great epicures 托马斯?杰斐逊算得上是美国早期美食家一枚
A: ♣近  bon vivant, gastronomist, gourmand, gourmet

Q:epigram  ['epiɡræm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 机智的短诗，警句： a short, witty poem expressing a single thought or observation
A: ♣例  Benjamin Franklin's most famous epigram, “Remember that time is money” 本杰明?富兰克林最著名的警句就是，时间就是金钱
A: ♣近  adage, aphorism, apothegm, byword, maxim, proverb

Q:epilogue  ['epilɔɡ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 文学作品的结局： a concluding section that rounds out the design of a literary work
A: ♣反  preface 序文
A: ♠考法2  n. 戏剧的收场白： the final scene of a play that comments on or summarizes the main action
A: ♣近  coda

Q:epithet  ['epiθet]
A: ♠考法1  n. 外号，绰号： a descriptive or familiar name given instead of or in addition to the one belonging to an individual ；a disparaging or abusive word or phrase
A: ♣例  King Richard I of England was given the very laudatory epithet “the Lion-Hearted” 英王理查一世因英勇大胆被赞誉为“狮心理查”
A: ♣近  alias, cognomen, sobriquet

Q:epitomize  [i'pitəmaiz]
A: ♠考法1  v. 摘要： to make into a short statement of the main points (as of a report)
A: ♣例  his personal code of behavior on the playing field is epitomized by his favorite saying, Nice guys finish last. 他在赛场上的座右铭是：好男坚持到底。
A: ♣近  abstract, digest, encapsulate, outline, recapitulate, synopsize, sum up
A: ♠考法2  v. 代表，体现，是…的典型范例： to represent in visible form, to be a typical example of
A: ♣例  the Parthenon in Athens epitomizes the ancient Greek ideal of architectural beauty 雅典的巴特农神庙体现了古希腊对于建筑美感的理念 || behavior that epitomizes selfishness 典型的自私行为
A: ♣近  body, express, externalize, incarnate, incorporate, instantiate, manifest, materialize, substantiate

Q:equable  ['ekwəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （脾气、性情）温和的： not easily disturbed; serene
A: ♣例  equable temperament 温和的性情
A: ♣近  balmy, genial, gentle, moderate, temperate
A: ♣反  harsh, inclement, intemperate, severe 严厉的
A: ♣派  equanimity n.温和
A: ♣反  agitation, excitability 激动

Q:equilibrium  [,i:kwi'libriəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 均势，平衡： a condition in which opposing forces are equal to one another
A: ♣例  We must find an equilibrium between commercial development and conservation of our natural treasures. 我们必须在发展经济和保护自然资源之间找到一个平衡点。
A: ♣近  counterpoise, equilibration, equipoise, poise, stasis
A: ♣反  disequilibration, disequilibrium, imbalance, nonequilibrium, unbalance 不平衡
A: ♠考法2  n. （感情上的）平静： evenness of emotions or temper
A: ♣例  That stunning insult left me speechless, and several minutes passed before I recovered my equilibrium. 那个令人震惊的侮辱弄得我哑口无言，我花了好几分钟才使心情得以平静。
A: ♣近  aplomb, calmness, composure, countenance, imperturbability, placidity, repose, sangfroid, serenity, tranquillity
A: ♣反  agitation, discomposure, perturbation 不安，焦躁

Q:equity  ['ekwəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 不偏不倚，公平： lack of favoritism toward one side or another
A: ♣例  the lower wages paid to women for equal work violated the notion of equity 同等工作付给女性更低的报酬违背了公平的理念
A: ♣近  disinterestedness, equity, evenhandedness, fairness, impartiality, neutrality, nonpartisanship
A: ♣反  bias, favoritism, nonobjectivity, one-sidedness, partiality, partisanship, prejudice 歧视，偏见
A: ♣派  equitable a.公平的
A: ♣反  biased, discriminatory 偏袒的，差别对待的

Q:equivalent  [i'kwivələnt]
A: ♠考法1  adj./n. 等价的，相等的： equal in force, amount, or value
A: ♣例  that huge mansion is the equivalent of five ordinary houses 那栋巨大的公馆有五套一般户型的房子那么大
A: ♣近  coequal, coordinate, counterpart, peer, rival, parallel

Q:equivocate  [i'kwivəkeit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. （带有欺骗目的地）模棱两可地说，说谎话： to use equivocal language especially with intent to deceive
A: ♣例  When asked about his tax plan, the candidate didn't equivocate. 当被问到税收方案时，候选人直言不讳。
A: ♣近  fudge, hedge, weasel, prevaricate, palter
A: ♣反  communicate straightforwardly 直率地说
A: ♣派  equivocal adj. 模棱两可的： open to two or more interpretations and often intended to mislead; ambiguous.
A: ♣派  equivocation n. 模棱两可的话
A: ♣反  clarity 清楚

Q:erode  [i'rəud]

A: ♣例  flooding eroded the hillside 洪水冲刷着山岭 || inflation eroding buying power 通货膨胀导致购买力下降
A: ♣近  corrode, fret, gnaw, nibble, bite at

Q:errant  ['erənt]

A: ♣例  the errant gunslinger as a standard character in western novels 在西部题材小说中，叛逆的持枪歹徒是经典形象
A: ♣近  ambulant, fugitive, nomadic, perambulatory, roaming, roving, vagabond, vagrant, wandering
A: ♠考法2  adj. 误入歧途的，犯错误的： straying from the proper course or standards
A: ♣例  errant youngsters 误入歧途的青少年♣近  misbehaving, mischievous
A: ♣反  behaved, behaving, nice, orderly 行为规矩的

Q:erratic  [i'rætik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 善变的： not staying constant
A: ♣例  business at the fast-food restaurant has been so erratic lately that the manager never knows how much staff to have on hand 快餐店的生意最近非常起伏以至于经理也不清楚需要多少人手
A: ♣近  changing, fluctuating, irregular, unequal, unstable, unsteady, varying
A: ♣反  changeless, constant, stable, steady, unchanging, unvarying 不变的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 异常的，不同寻常的： different from the ordinary in a way that causes curiosity or suspicion
A: ♣例  the key to the code was the erratic punctuation the killer used 解开密码的关键是杀手使用的不同寻常的标点符号
A: ♣近  bizarre, eccentric, offbeat, outlandish, out-of-the-way, peculiar, quaint, queer, remarkable, screwy, spaced-out, way-out, weird

Q:erroneous  [i'rəuniəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 错误的，不正确的： containing or characterized by error
A: ♣例  The news article about the new drug was filled with much erroneous information. 有关新药的新闻报道里充斥着大量的错误信息。
A: ♣近  inaccurate, incorrect, inexact, invalid, mistaken, unsound, untrue, untruthful, wrong
A: ♣反  accurate, correct, errorless, exact, precise, right, sound, true, valid, veracious 正确的，准确的

Q:erudite  ['eru:dait]

A: ♣例  an erudite scholar 渊博的学者
A: ♣近  knowledgeable, learned, lettered, literate, scholarly, well-read
A: ♣反  ignorant, unlettered, benighted, illiterate, uneducated, unscholarly 无知的

Q:eschew  [is'tʃu:]

A: ♣近  dodge, elude, evade, shirk, shun, weasel out of
A: ♣反  embrace, greet, welcome, habitually indulge in, seek 乐于接受，寻觅

Q:escort  ['eskɔ:t]

A: ♣近  attendant, companion, guard, guide

A: ♣例  Asenior student from the college escorted my parents and me on our tour of the campus. 来自学院的一个师兄陪同我和我父母参观了校园。‖a VIP escorted by an army of bodyguards and journalists 被一群保镖和记者包围的重要人物
A: ♣近  accompany, attend, chaperone, companion, company, convoy, squire
A: ♣反  abandon, desert, ditch, dump, forsake 抛弃，不顾

Q:esoteric  [,esəu'terik]

A: ♣反  common accepted, generally known, open, public 公开的，普遍接受的

A: ♣近  alienate, disaffect, disgruntle, sour
A: ♣反  reconcile 和好

Q:etch  [etʃ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 蚀刻： to produce (as a pattern or design) on a hard material by eating into the material's surface (as by acid or laser beam)
A: ♣例  the artist etched his landscape on a copper plate 艺术家将风景画刻在铜盘上
A: ♣近  grave, incise, inscribe
A: ♠考法2  v. 留下深刻印象，铭记： to produce a vivid impression of
A: ♣例  in just a few pages the writer etched an unforgettable portrait of one of the more remarkable First Ladies 仅用数页，作者刻画出了一位杰出的第一夫人令人难忘的形象
A: ♣近  impress, imprint, infix, ingrain

Q:eternal  [i'tə:nəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 永恒的： having infinite duration; everlasting; perpetual
A: ♣例  eternal love 永恒的爱
A: ♣近  ageless, everlasting, immortal, imperishable, perennial, perpetual, undying
A: ♣反  ephemeral 短暂的

Q:ethereal  [i'θiəriəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 轻巧精致的： resembling air in lightness, highly refined; delicate
A: ♣例  the bakery's scrumptious pastries have a wonderfully ethereal consistency 面包师可口的糕点有着一种奇妙的蓬松轻巧的质感
A: ♣近  fluffy, gossamer, light
A: ♣反  heavy, leaden, ponderous 沉重的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 天国的： of, relating to, or suggesting heaven
A: ♣例  a land of ethereal beauty and tranquility 具有缥缈的美感和宁静的一片土地
A: ♣近  elysian, empyreal, heavenly, supernal
A: ♣反  chthonic, hellish, infernal, Tartarean 地狱的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 非物质的，精神（上）的： not of this world; spiritual; not composed of matter
A: ♣例  that ethereal attribute that every performer should have—charisma 每位演奏者都应该具有一种精神上的特质——那就是个人魅力
A: ♣近  bodiless, formless, incorporeal, insubstantial, nonmaterial, nonphysical, spiritual
A: ♣反  bodily, corporeal, material, physical, substantial 物质的，有实体的

Q:ethics  ['eθiks]
A: ♠考法1  n. 道德规范： rules or standards governing the conduct of a person or the members of a profession
A: ♣例  an old-fashioned work ethic 传统的工作行为规范
A: ♣近  ethos, morality, morals, norms, principles, standards

Q:ethos  ['i:θɔs]

A: ♣例  Rigorous self-discipline was central to the ethos of the ancient Spartans. 严格的自律是古代斯巴达人所尊崇的核心道德准则。
A: ♣近  ethics, morality, morals, norms, principles, standards

Q:eulogize  ['ju:lədʒaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 称赞；颂扬： to speak or write in high praise of
A: ♣例  He was eulogized at his funeral as a caring husband and a good father. 他在悼词中被称赞为一个好丈夫、一个好爸爸。
A: ♣反  defame, pan, stricture 诬蔑，指责

Q:euphemism  ['ju:fimizəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 婉言，委婉的说法： the substitution of an agreeable or inoffensive expression for one that may offend or suggest something unpleasant
A: ♣例  using “eliminate” as a euphemism for “kill” “杀死”的委婉说法是“灭掉”

Q:euphonious  [ju:'fəuniəs]

A: ♣近  mellifluous, melodious, canorous, harmonizing, symphonious, tuneful
A: ♣反  cacophonous, discordant, disharmonious, dissonant, tuneless, unmelodious 刺耳的

Q:euphoria  [ju:'fɔ:riə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 感觉极其愉快： a state of overwhelming usually pleasurable emotion
A: ♣例  The initial euphoria following her victory in the election has now subsided. 选举成功带来的最初的欢愉感现在已经消失。
A: ♣近  elation, exhilaration, intoxication, transport, rapture, rhapsody
A: ♣反  depression 沮丧

Q:evacuate  [i'vækjueit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 撤空： to empty or remove the contents of
A: ♣例  were ordered to evacuate the building 被命令搬出大楼
A: ♣近  clear, vacate, void
A: ♣反  fill up, occupy, load 填满
A: ♠考法2  vt. 撤退： to remove especially from a military zone or dangerous area
A: ♣例  During World War II, children were evacuated from London to the country. 二战期间，伦敦市的儿童被撤离到郊区。
A: ♣反  conquer 占领

Q:evanescent  [,i:və'nesənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 逐渐消失的，短暂的： tending to vanish like vapor
A: ♣例  Beauty is as evanescent as a rainbow. 容颜易老，年华易逝。
A: ♣近  ephemeral, fleeting, impermanent, temporary, transient, transitory
A: ♣反  ceaseless, endless, enduring, eternal, everlasting, immortal, permanent, perpetual, timeless, undying, unending, abiding, lasting, perpetual 持久的

Q:evasive  [i'veisiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 难以发现、捕捉、分离的；含糊其词的： hard to find, capture, or isolate; equivocal
A: ♣例  an evasive statement 模棱两可的陈述
A: ♣近  fugitive, slippery
A: ♣反  unequivocal 明确的

Q:everlasting  [,eveə'lɑ:stiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 永恒的，持久的： lasting forever; eternal
A: ♣例  To his everlasting credit, he never once gave in to temptation. 他人品非常好，从来没有受到诱惑。
A: ♣近  ageless, enduring, eternal, immortal, imperishable, perennial, perpetual, undying
A: ♣反  impermanent, mortal, temporary, transient, ephemeral 短暂的

Q:evict  [i'vikt]

A: ♣例  Her landlord has threatened to evict her if she doesn't pay the rent soon. 她的房东威胁说如果再不交房租就要把她赶出去。
A: ♣反  harbor 收容

Q:evince  [i'vins]

A: ♣例  evince a strong desire 明显地表现出强烈的欲望
A: ♣近  bespeak, betray, declare, demonstrate, expose, manifest, reveal, give away,
A: ♣反  conceal, keep hidden 隐藏

Q:evoke  [i'vəuk]

A: ♣例  evoke memories 唤起回忆
A: ♣近  elicit, inspire, raise

Q:exacerbate  [ek'sæsəbeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使加剧, 使恶化： to make more violent, bitter, or severe
A: ♣例  a heavy rainfall that exacerbated the flood problems 大雨恶化了洪水问题
A: ♣近  aggravate, complicate, worsen
A: ♣反  allay, alleviate, assuage, mitigate, relieve, palliate 缓和

Q:exacting  [iɡ'zæktiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 严格的，苛求的： making severe demands; rigorous
A: ♣例  an exacting instructor 一位严苛的导师
A: ♣近  choosy, demanding, fastidious, finical, fussy, pernickety, persnickety, picky
A: ♣派  exact v. 强求，索取： to force the payment or yielding of
A: ♣例  exact tribute from a conquered people 从征服的人民手中强取贡品
A: ♣反  condone, forgive 赦免免除债务
A: ♠考法2  adj. 费时间花心思的： requiring much time, effort, or careful attention
A: ♣例  editing and proofreading will always be an exacting task 编辑和校对是花时间花心思的工作
A: ♣近  arduous, burdensome, challenging, grueling, killing, laborious, onerous, taxing, toilsome
A: ♣反  light, unchallenging, undemanding 要求不高的

Q:exalt  [iɡ'zɔ:lt]

A: ♣例  popular support and media hype have exalted Super Bowl Sunday to the level of a national holiday 大众广泛的支持和媒体的大肆宣传已然将超级碗杯星期天变成了一个全民狂欢的大节日
A: ♣近  aggrandize, canonize, deify, dignify, elevate, ennoble, magnify
A: ♣反  abase, degrade, demean ,humble, lower in status 贬抑，降低身份
A: ♠考法2  vt. 赞扬： to glorify, praise, or honor.
A: ♣近  emblazon, extol, glorify, laud, magnify
A: ♣反  condemn 谴责

Q:exasperate  [iɡ'zæspəreit]

Q:excruciate  [ik'skru:ʃieit]

A: ♣反  attribute guilt, inculpate, indict, criminate, incriminate 归罪，控告

Q:excursive  [iks'kə:siv]

Q:execrate  ['eksikreit]

A: ♣反  bless 保佑

A: ♣近  abhor, abominate, despise, detest, loathe
A: ♣反  love 爱

Q:exemplary  [iɡ'zempləri]

A: ♣派  exemplify v. （通过榜样）示范，显示： to show or illustrate by example
A: ♠考法2  adj. 作为警告的： serving as or offering a warning
A: ♣例  armies have traditionally used public execution as an exemplary punishment for the crime of desertion 军队通常将公开处决作为玩忽职守罪的惩罚，以儆效尤
A: ♣近  admonishing, admonitory, monitory, premonitory, warning

Q:exterminate  [ik'stə:mineit]

A: ♣近  annihilate, decimate, efface, eradicate, expunge, extirpate, liquidate, obliterate, raze, sweep, wipe out
A: ♣反  conserve, preserve, protect 保护；rescue, save 拯救
A: ♣派  extermination n. 消灭

Q:extinguish  [ik'stiŋɡwiʃ]

A: ♣反  ignite, rekindle 点燃
A: ♠考法2  v. 终止： to bring to a complete end the physical soundness, existence, or usefulness of
A: ♣例  a fatal blunder that extinguished all hope that the team would actually win the play-offs 一个致命的失误使得队伍赢得季后赛的希望完全破灭
A: ♣近  annihilate, decimate, demolish, desolate, devastate, pulverize, ruin, shatter, smash, tear down, pull down, rub out
A: ♣反  build, construct, erect, raise, rear, set up, put up 建立

Q:extraneous  [ek'streinjəs]

A: ♣近  accidental, adventitious, alien, external, foreign
A: ♣反  essential, inherent, innate, intrinsic 本质的，核心的

Q:extrapolate  [ek'stræpəleit]

A: ♣例  We can extrapolate from past economic recessions the probable course of the current one. 通过以往经济衰退的原因我们可以推断出本次危机的可能起源。
A: ♣近  conclude, decide, deduce, derive, gather, judge, reason, understand
A: ♣反  conjecture, guess, speculate, surmise （无根据地）猜测，揣测
A: ♣派  extrapolation n. 推论

Q:extravagant  [ik'strævəɡənt]

A: ♣例  has always been extravagant with her money 挥金如土
A: ♣近  profligate, spendthrift, squandering, thriftless, unthrifty, wasteful
A: ♣反  frugal, conserving, economical, penny-pinching, scrimping, skimping, thrifty 节省的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 过度的，不必要的： going beyond a normal or acceptable limit in degree or amount
A: ♣例  the book doesn't quite merit the extravagant praise that it has received 这本书被盛赞过度
A: ♣近  baroque, exorbitant, immoderate, inordinate, lavish, overdue, overmuch, overweening, plethoric, unconscionable, unmerciful
A: ♣反  middling, moderate, modest, reasonable, temperate 适当适度的

A: ♣近  disengage, disentangle, free, liberate, release, untangle
A: ♣反  enmesh, entangle, embroil 卷入

Q:exuberant  [iɡ'zju:bərənt]

A: ♣例  Exuberant crowds rushed to greet the returning national champions. 激动的人群争先恐后地向凯旋归来的全国冠军表示问候
A: ♣近  ebullient, effervescent, frolic, buoyant, bouncy, vivacious
A: ♣反  austere 克制的；sullen 闷闷不乐的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 大量的，充分的： produced in extreme abundance
A: ♣例  an exuberant imagination 丰富的想象力
A: ♣近  ample, lavish, lush, luxuriant, opulent, plentiful, prodigal, profuse, riotous
A: ♣反  meager, scant, sparse 匮乏的

Q:exude  [iɡ'zju:d]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 分泌，流出：to flow forth slowly through small openings
A: ♣例  a sticky resin exuded from the bark 从树皮中分泌出来的带有恶臭的树脂
A: ♣近  bleed, ooze, seep
A: ♣反  absorb 吸收

Q:exult  [iɡ'zʌlt]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 感到欢喜： to rejoice especially with feelings or display of triumph or self-satisfaction
A: ♣例  exult in a triumph 沉浸在胜利的喜欢当中
A: ♣近  delight, glory, jubilate, joy, rejoice, triumph
A: ♣反  lament, mourn 哀悼；bemoan 叹息，悲伤
A: ♣派  exultant adj. 狂喜的

Q:fable  ['feibl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 寓言故事： a story intended to teach a basic truth or moral about life
A: ♣例  This classic Christmas film is essentially a fableshowing how every person's life has meaning. 这部经典的基督教电影本质上来说是一个寓言，它告诉我们每个人的生命都是有意义的
A: ♣近  apologue, parable
A: ♠考法2  n. 神话，传说： a legendary story of supernatural happenings
A: ♣例  According to an ancient fable, the waters of the mountain spring are the tears of a woman weeping for her lost children. 根据一个古老的传说，这条山中的泉水是一名失去孩子的母亲所流下的眼泪
A: ♣近  legend, mythos, tale
A: ♠考法3  n. 谎言： a statement known by its maker to be untrue and made in order to deceive
A: ♣例  The stories of lost cities of gold may have been fables deliberately concocted by Native Americans to dupe the Spanish. 所谓的“失落的黄金之都”的故事也许只是美洲土著们杜撰出来忽悠西班牙人的
A: ♣近  fabrication, falsehood, lie, mendacity, prevarication, story
A: ♣反  fact 事实；truth 真相
A: ♣派  fabulous adj. 寓言般的，难以置信的

Q:fabricate  ['fæbrikeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 捏造： to make up for the purpose of deception
A: ♣例  be accused of fabricating evidence 被指控有捏造证据的行为
A: ♣近  concoct, coin, devise, forge, fake, feign, invent
A: ♠考法2  vt. 搭建，组建；打造： to bring into being by combining, shaping, or transforming materials
A: ♣例  The house was essentially fabricated at the factory and then shipped to the site for assembly. 这间房屋的核心主体在工厂内建好之后，它被运往目的地直接进行组装‖All the key parts are fabricated from high quality titanium alloy. 所有的关键零件都是由上好的钛合金打造的
A: ♣近  assemble, construct, erect, frame, fashion, manufacture, produce, rear, set up
A: ♣反  demount, disassemble, dismantle, dismember 拆解，拆毁
A: ♣派  fabrication n. 组建；虚构的事物

Q:fabulous  ['fæbjuləs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 传说中的： based on, described in, or being a fable
A: ♣例  The city of Phoenix is named after a fabulous bird that every 500 years destroys itself with fire, only to rise again from its own ashes. 凤凰城的名字来源于传说中的一种鸟，它每隔500年会在火焰中毁灭，然后再从灰烬中重生。
A: ♣近  fabled, legendary
A: ♠考法2  adj. 幻想中的，不真实的： not real and existing only in the imagination
A: ♣例  a story of a fabulous land where the people know nothing of war and live together in perfect harmony 一个有关世外桃源的故事，当地的居民不知道战争为何物，和谐融洽地生活在一起
A: ♣近  chimerical, dreamy, illusory, phantom, unreal, visionary
A: ♣反  actual, existent, existing, real 真实存在的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 令人惊讶的，令人称奇的： causing wonder or astonishment
A: ♣例  the fabulous endurance of a marathon runner 马拉松参赛者令人惊讶的耐力
A: ♣近  amazing, astonishing, astounding, miraculous, portentous, prodigious, staggering, stunning, stupendous, sublime, wonderful
A: ♣反  common, ordinary 平常的，普通的
A: ♠考法4  adj. 极好的： extremely pleasing or successful
A: ♣例  We had a fabulous time on our vacation. 我们的假期赞极了。
A: ♣近  awesome, divine, fantastic, heavenly, marvelous, noble, prime, s

Q:facetious  [fə'si:ʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 喜欢开玩笑的，轻浮的： joking or jesting often inappropriately
A: ♣例  Stop being facetious! This is the life-and-death moment. 别开玩笑了！这可是生死攸关的时刻
A: ♣近  humorous, jocose, jocular, waggish, witty
A: ♣反  earnest, sincere 真挚的，真诚的；lugubrious 哀怨的

Q:facile  ['fæsail]
A: ♠考法1  adj.表面的，浅尝辄止的：having or showing a lack of depth of understanding or character
A: ♣例  propose a facile solution to a complex problem 给一个复杂的问题提议一个肤浅的解决方案
A: ♣近  cursory, shallow, simplistic, superficial
A: ♣反  deep, profound 深刻的；comprehensive, exhaustive 全面的，详尽的
A: ♠考法2  adj.容易的，唾手可得的： easily accomplished or attained
A: ♣例  a facile victory 一场轻松易得的胜利
A: ♣近  cheap, easy, effortless, painless, royal
A: ♣反  arduous, demanding, difficult, formidable, hard, laborious, toilsome, tough 费力的，困难的

Q:facilitate  [fə'siliteit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使变容易，促进： to make easy or easier
A: ♣例  The new airport will facilitate the development of tourism. 新建机场促进了旅游业的发展。
A: ♣近  ease, expedite, forward, further, help
A: ♣反  check, hamper, handicap, hinder, impede, obstruct, thwart, retard 阻碍，阻止；complicate 复杂化
A: ♣派  facility n. 设施；容易，方便

Q:faction  [fækʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 派系： a party or group (as within a government) that is often contentious or self-seeking
A: ♣例  affiliated with one faction 附属于某个党派‖North-Ocean Faction 北洋派
A: ♣近  bloc, body, clique, coalition, sect, wing
A: ♣派  factional adj.派系的，派别的

Q:fad  [fæd]
A: ♠考法1  n. （短暂的）流行，时尚： a practice or interest that is very popular for a short time
A: ♣例  Once the fad for that kind of music had passed, nobody would have been caught dead listening to it. 一旦那种流派的音乐流行风刮过之后，就没有人会来听它出丑了。
A: ♣近  buzz, craze, enthusiasm, fashion, trend, vogue
A: ♣反  classic 经典；standard 标准

Q:fail-safe  ['feilseif]
A: ♠考法1  n. 保险措施： a measure taken to preclude loss or injury
A: ♣例  There are so many fail-safes built into the system that a highly unlikely series of mistakes would have to be made before failure could occur. 系统中嵌入了大量的保险措施，因此在系统崩溃之前，必须要发生一系列几乎不可能出现的错误
A: ♣近  caution, palladium, preventive, safeguard
A: ♠考法2  adj. 万无一失的： having no chance of failure
A: ♣例  a fail-safe device 自动防故障装置‖Men have traditionally regarded flowers as the fail-safe gift for Valentine's Day. 男士们长期以来认为鲜花是情人节永远不会错的礼物
A: ♣近  certain, foolproof, sure, unfailing
A: ♣反  fallible 容易犯错的

Q:fallacious  [fə'leiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 谬误的，不合逻辑的： containing or based on a fallacy
A: ♣例  the once-common fallacious claim that girls just weren't any good at math 曾经广为流传的一个谬论：女孩子无论如何就是学不好数学
A: ♣近  illogical, invalid, irrational, mad, reasonless, sophistic, unreasonable
A: ♣反  sound 论证有力的；valid 合乎逻辑的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 欺骗性的： tending to deceive or mislead
A: ♣例  fallacious testimony 不真实的证词
A: ♣近  beguiling, deceiving, deceptive, deluding, delusive, delusory, false, fraudulent, misleading
A: ♣反  authentic, veritable 真实的
A: ♣派  fallacy n.逻辑谬误

Q:fallible  ['fæləbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可能出错的： tending or likely to be erroneous or capable of making an error
A: ♣例  They are only human and all too fallible. 他们都是人类，因此难免犯错。‖a hasty, fallible generalization 有可能出错的匆促总结
A: ♣近  errant
A: ♣反  fail-safe, foolproof, infallible, unfailing 万无一失的，不可能出错的
A: ♣派  fallibility n. 易错

Q:fallow  ['fæləu]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 休耕的： left untilled or unsown after plowing
A: ♣例  The field was lying fallow. 那田地正在休耕中
A: ♣近  untilled, uncultivated
A: ♠考法2  adj. 闲置的： not being in a state of use, activity, or employment
A: ♣例  The coal mine has been lying fallow since the drop in prices made it unprofitable. 自从煤价下跌造成亏损，这个煤矿就一直处于停工状态
A: ♣近  dead, dormant, inert, inoperative, latent, unused, vacant
A: ♣反  functioning, occupied, operative, running, working使用中的；active 活跃的

Q:falsehood  ['fɔ:lshud]
A: ♠考法1  n. 谎言： a statement known by its maker to be untrue and made in order to deceive
A: ♣例  Truth always rise above falsehood, as oil rise above water. 油脂水面浮，真理胜谎言
A: ♣近  deception, fable, lie, mendacity, prevarication, untruth
A: ♣反  truth, verity 真相，实话

Q:falter  ['fɔ:ltə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 蹒跚： to walk unsteadily
A: ♣近  lurch, stagger, stumble, teeter, totter, wobble
A: ♠考法2  vi. 犹豫，踌躇： to be unsteady in purpose or action, as from loss of courage or confidence
A: ♣例  Mr. Garrison never once faltered in his demand that slavery be unconditionally abolished. 盖瑞森先生从不对他废除奴隶的要求存有任何的犹豫
A: ♣近  balance, halt, hesitate, vacillate, waver
A: ♣派  faltering adj. 犹豫的

Q:fanatic  [fə'nætik]
A: ♠考法1  n. 狂热者： a person marked or motivated by an extreme, unreasoning enthusiasm, as for a cause.
A: ♣例  a soccer fanatic 一个足球迷
A: ♣近  bigot, devotee, enthusiast, fiend, freak, maniac, partisan, zealot
A: ♣反  nonfan 非爱好者
A: ♠考法2  adj. 狂热的；盲信的： marked by excessive enthusiasm and often intense uncritical devotion
A: ♣例  They are fanatic about sadomasochism. 他们对SM十分狂热
A: ♣近  extreme, rabid, radical, revolutionary, ultra
A: ♣反  conservative 保守的；rational 理性的
A: ♣派  fanatical adj. 狂热的；盲信的

Q:fanciful  ['fænsiful]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 幻想中的，不真实的： not real and existing only in the imagination
A: ♣例  a fanciful tale of a monster in the woods 一个有关栖息在丛林中的怪兽的传说故事
A: ♣近  chimerical, fabulous, fantastic, fictional, fictitious, ideal, invented, mythical, notional, phantom, visionary
A: ♣反  actual, existent, existing, real 真实存在的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不切实际的，荒谬的： conceived or made without regard for reason or reality
A: ♣例  She harbors the fanciful notion that she has a talent for singing. 她怀着一个不切实际的空想：她有着歌唱家的天赋。
A: ♣近  absurd, bizarre, crazy, foolish, insane, nonsensical, preposterous, unreal, wild
A: ♣反  realistic, reasonable 现实的，有理的

Q:fantasy  ['fæntəsi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 幻想： imaginative fiction featuring especially strange settings and grotesque characters
A: ♣例  indulge in a fantasy 沉迷于幻想
A: ♣近  chimera, conceit, daydream, delusion, dream, hallucination, illusion, vision
A: ♣反  actuality, fact, reality, truth 事实，现实
A: ♠考法2  vt. 产生幻想： to form a mental picture of
A: ♣例  He regularly fantasies romantic encounters that he knows will never happen. 他会定期意淫一些永远不可能发生的浪漫邂逅
A: ♣近  dream, envisage, envision, fantasize, imagine, picture
A: ♣派  fantastic adj. 梦幻般的，极好的

Q:farce  [fɑ:s]
A: ♠考法1  n. （带有嘲讽元素的）滑稽戏： a light dramatic composition marked by broadly satirical comedy and improbable plot
A: ♣近  burlesque, caricature, parody, sham, travesty
A: ♣反  serious play 正剧
A: ♠考法2  n. 闹剧： ridiculous or empty show
A: ♣例  The enforcement of this law became a farce. 这条法律的执行过程成了一场闹剧
A: ♣近  joke, mockery, nonsense
A: ♣派  farcical adj. 荒谬的

Q:fascinate  ['fæsineit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 强列吸引，使入迷： to hold an intense interest or attraction for
A: ♣例  toys that fascinate infants 吸引婴儿们的玩具
A: ♣近  allure, arrest ,attract, bewitch, captivate, charm, enchant, enthrall, grip
A: ♣反  disgust, repel 使厌恶，使反感
A: ♣派  fascinating adj. 引人入胜的

Q:fast  [fɑ:st]
A: ♠考法1  n. 绝食；斋戒： an act of abstaining from food
A: ♣例  fast to death 绝食而死
A: ♣近  hunger strike
A: ♠考法2  adj. 快速的： characterized by quick motion, operation, or effect
A: ♣例  The fast pace of construction resulted in our new house being done ahead of schedule. 极快的施工使得我们的新房提前竣工
A: ♣近  brisk, expeditious, fleeting, hasty, quick, rapid, speedy, swift
A: ♣反  slow 慢的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 忠诚的： firm in one's allegiance to someone or something
A: ♣例  The two girls soon became fast and inseparable friends. 这两个女孩子很快成为了忠于彼此的形影不离的好伙伴
A: ♣近  constant, dedicated, devoted, devout, loyal, pious
A: ♣反  disloyal, perfidious 不忠诚的；treacherous 背叛的
A: ♠考法4  adj. 稳固的，难以拆卸的： firmly positioned in place and difficult to dislodge
A: ♣例  The rusty, old screws are so fast in the fitting that there's no hope of getting them out. 这颗生锈的老铁钉已经钉得太死了，根本不可能将其取出
A: ♣近  firm, frozen, lodged, secure, stable, staunch, strong, stuck
A: ♣反  loose, shaky 松动的；insecure 不稳定的
A: ♣派  fasten v. 系紧

Q:fastidious  [fæs'tidiəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 挑剔的，极仔细的，追求完美的： possessing or displaying careful, meticulous attention to detail
A: ♣例  be fastidious about personal hygiene and appearance 极其注意个人卫生和外表
A: ♣近  demanding, exacting, fussy, hypercritical, squeamish
A: ♣反  undemanding 不挑剔的；cursory 粗略的，敷衍的；indiscriminate, uncritical 不加区分的

Q:fateful  ['feitful]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 意义重大的： involving momentous consequences
A: ♣例  make a fateful decision to declare war 做出了宣战的重大决定
A: ♣近  critical, crucial, important, momentous, significant
A: ♣反  inconsequential, insignificant, petty, paltry, trivial, unimportant 不重要的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 带来灾难的，毁灭性的： bringing death or disaster
A: ♣例  a fateful journey 一趟致命的旅行
A: ♣近  calamitous, cataclysmic, catastrophic, deadly, destructive, disastrous, fatal, ruinous

Q:fathom  ['fæðəm]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 测量（深度）： to measure the depth of (as a body of water) typically with a weighted line
A: ♣例  The pilot had to continually fathom the river, which drought conditions had lowered to unprecedented levels. 舵手不得不时刻注意河水深度，因为干旱已经使水深下降到了前所未有的程度
A: ♣近  plumb
A: ♠考法2  vt. 彻底理解，弄懂： to penetrate and come to understand
A: ♣例  unable to fathom the what he was talking about 无法弄懂他在说什么
A: ♣近  apprehend, cognize, comprehend, grasp, know, understand
A: ♣反  misunderstand 误解
A: ♣派  fathomable adj. 可测量的；可知晓的

Q:fatigue  [fə'ti:ɡ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 疲惫： weariness or exhaustion from labor, exertion, or stress
A: ♣例  The day-long battle against the blaze left firefighters in a state of utter fatigue. 与大火一整天的斗争使得消防员们处于极度疲惫的状态
A: ♣近  collapse, exhaustion, lassitude, tiredness, weariness
A: ♣反  refreshment, rejuvenation, revitalization 恢复活力
A: ♠考法2  n. （让人厌倦的）苦差事： something, such as tiring effort or activity, that causes weariness
A: ♣例  Although he had joined the army for action and adventure, much of his day seemed to be devoted to mindless fatigues. 尽管当初参军是为了上战场冒险的，但我生活的大部分时间似乎都耗费在了没意思的苦差上
A: ♣近  drudge, drudgery, grind, labor, sweat, toil, travail
A: ♣反  fun, play 玩耍；sinecure 美差，闲职

Q:fatuous  ['fætjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 愚笨的： complacently or inanely foolish
A: ♣例  Emperor Yang in the Sui Dynasty is not only a rare fatuous tyrant but also an outstanding poet. 隋炀帝不仅仅是少有的昏暴之君，在文学上还是一位杰出的诗人
A: ♣近  asinine, brainless, foolish, obtuse, silly, simple, stupid, unwitty, witless
A: ♣反  sagacious, sapient 聪明的，睿智的；judicious, prudent, sensible, wise 谨慎的，明智的

Q:faultfinder  ['fɔ:ltfaində]
A: ♠考法1  n. 吹毛求疵的人： one who is given to petty criticism and constant complaint
A: ♣例  No sooner had we finished decorating the church than the parish faultfinder decided that she didn't like it. 我们一完成教堂的装修工作，教区里挑剔的人就说她不喜欢
A: ♣近  carper, castigator, caviler, censurer, critic, disparager, hypercritic, nitpicker

Q:favorable  ['feivərəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 赞许的：expressing approval
A: ♣例  Favorable reviews for the movie were few . 关于电影的正面评价极少
A: ♣近  admiring, applauding, commendatory, complimentary, positive
A: ♣反  adverse, disapproving, negative 否定的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 有利的：tending to promote or facilitate
A: ♣例  mild climate favorable to his health 有利于他健康的温和气候
A: ♣近  advantageous, benefic, beneficial, favoring, good, helpful, salutary
A: ♣反  unfavorable, disadvantageous, untoward, unpropitious 不利的

Q:favoritism  ['feivəritizəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 偏爱，偏袒： the showing of special favor
A: ♣例  Favoritism blinded the administrator to the benefits of the proposed system for distributing work. 偏袒使得经理无法意识到这一待讨论的分配系统所带来的收益。
A: ♣近  favor, one-sidedness, partiality, prejudice, tendentiousness
A: ♣反  impartiality, neutrality, objectivity, open-mindedness, unbiasedness 公平，公正

Q:fawn  [fɔ:n]

A: ♣例  fawn on one's superior 向上司谄媚
A: ♣近  cower, cringe, flatter, grovel, toady, truckle
A: ♣反  domineer 统治；专横跋扈
A: ♣派  fawning adj. 阿谀奉承的，讨好的

Q:faze  [feiz]

A: ♣例  Nothing can faze her. 没有什么可以使她气馁
A: ♣近  abash, annoy, bother, disconcert, dismay, disturb, discomfit, embarrass, fluster, rattle
A: ♣反  calm, lull 使平静，使镇定

Q:featureless  ['fi:tʃəlis]

A: ♣例  the featureless landscape of the steppe 大草原上缺乏特色的地貌
A: ♣近  beige, characterless, faceless, indistinctive, neutral, noncommital, vanilla
A: ♣反  diagnostic, discriminating, distinct, distinctive, distinguishing, identifying, peculiar, typical 特征的

Q:feckless  ['feklis]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无成果的，没有价值的： having no real worth or purpose
A: ♣例  years of feckless negotiations 长达数年的毫无成果的谈判
A: ♣近  bootless, fruitless, futile, meaningless, purposeless, useless, worthless
A: ♣反  effective, effectual, efficacious 有成效的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 粗心不负责任的： careless and irresponsible
A: ♣例  The young man was feckless and irresponsible. 这个年轻人既粗心又没有责任感
A: ♣近  careless, heedless, inadvertent, irresponsible, slipshod, sloppy
A: ♣反  careful, cautious, circumspect, discreet, wary 谨慎小心的

Q:fecund  ['fikənd]
