A: ♣例  fecund black soil 肥沃的黑土地
A: ♣近  cornucopian, fertile, fruitful, lush, luxuriant, productive, prolific, rich
A: ♣反  barren, infertile, sterile 贫瘠的
A: ♣派  fecundity n. 多产

Q:feeble  ['fi:bl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 衰弱的： markedly lacking in strength
A: ♣例  The heartbeat was feeble and irregular. 心跳虚弱而不规则
A: ♣近  debilitated, effete, enervated, faint, fragile, frail, infirm, languid, sapped
A: ♣反  mighty, powerful, robust, stalwart, stout, strong 强壮的，强健的
A: ♣派  enfeeble vt. 使衰弱

Q:feign  [fein]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 制造假象，装出…的样子： to give a false appearance of
A: ♣例  I would never feign illness just to postpone a test. 我绝不会为了缓考而装病
A: ♣近  affect, assume, counterfeit, dissemble, pretend, profess, sham, simulate
A: ♣派  unfeigned adj. 没有伪装的，真诚的

Q:felony  ['feləni]
A: ♠考法1  n. 重罪： one of several grave crimes, such as murder, rape, or burglary, punishable by a more stringent sentence than that given for a misdemeanor
A: ♣例  a felony punishable by life imprisonment 可被判处无期徒刑的重罪
A: ♣近  crime
A: ♣反  misdemeanor, peccadillo 轻罪

Q:fender  ['fendə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 缓冲装置： a cushioning device, such as a bundle of rope or a piece of timber, used on the side of a vessel or dock to absorb impact or friction
A: ♣例  a fender on the SUV 运动越野车的一个防护板
A: ♣近  buffer, bumper, cocoon, cushioning, pad

Q:feral  ['fiərəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 野生的： not domesticated or cultivated
A: ♣例  Animal experts discourage homeowners from trying to adopt feral animals as pets. 动物专家们不建议户主们将野生动物收养为宠物
A: ♣近  undomesticated, untamed, wild
A: ♣反  cultivated 人工培养的；domestic, tame 家养的，被驯化的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 动物性的：having or showing the nature and appetites of a lower animal
A: ♣例  The movie reveals just how thin the veneer of civilization is and how feral we are at bottom. 这部电影展示了所谓文明只不过是薄薄的一层纱，而内心深处我们仍然是野兽
A: ♣近  animalistic, beastly, brutal
A: ♣反  rational 理性的

Q:ferocious  [fə'rəuʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 极端的，剧烈的： marked by unrelenting intensity
A: ♣例  Ferocious heat wave kept people indoor. 剧烈的热浪使人不能出门。
A: ♣近  dreadful, excruciating, explosive, fearsome, fierce, intensive, profound, vehement, violent
A: ♣反  light, moderate, soft 轻柔的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 激烈的，爆发性的： marked by bursts of destructive force or intense activity
A: ♣例  Ferocious forest fires threatened to destroy hundreds of homes in the scrubland. 肆虐的森林大火威胁着灌木丛中数百户居民的住所。
A: ♣近  cyclonic, explosive, furious, paroxysmal, rabid, stormy, tempestuous, tumultuous, turbulent, volcanic
A: ♣反  nonviolent, peaceable, peaceful 平静的，平和的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 凶猛的，残暴的： violently unfriendly or aggressive in disposition
A: ♣例  captured and slaughtered by the ferocious tribesmen 被残暴的部落居民所抓获并惨遭屠杀
A: ♣近  feral, grim, savage, vicious
A: ♣反  gentle, mild, unaggressive 温和的，不具攻击性的
A: ♣派  ferocity n. 凶猛，残暴

Q:fertilize  ['fə:tilaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使肥沃，使多产： to make fertile
A: ♣例  Reading will fertilize vocabulary. 阅读丰富词汇
A: ♣近  enrich, manure
A: ♣反  deplete, drain, exhaust 消耗，耗尽
A: ♣派  fertilizer n. 化肥

Q:fervent  ['fə:vənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 充满感情的，热情洋溢的： exhibiting or marked by great intensity of feeling
A: ♣例  a fervent speech that called for tolerance and compassion for those who are physically challenged 一个充满感情的演说，它呼吁人们对残疾人持有一颗包容和同情的心
A: ♣近  ardent, demonstrative, fervid, flaming, glowing, impassioned, incandescent, passionate, perfervid, torrid, vehement, zealous
A: ♣反  cold, cool, dispassionate, emotionless, impassive, unemotional 冷漠的

Q:fervid  ['fə:vid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 酷热的： having a notably high temperature
A: ♣例  set out when the fervid heat subsides 当酷热消散之后才出发
A: ♣近  boiling, hot, scorching, searing, sultry, sweltering, torrid
A: ♣反  arctic, chilling, cold, freezing, frigid, frozen, glacial, icy 冰冷的，寒冷的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 热情的： marked by great passion or zeal
A: ♣例  a fervid patriot 热情洋溢的爱国者
A: ♣近  ardent, fervent, impassioned, passionate, perfervid
A: ♣反  cold, cool, dispassionate, emotionless, impassive, unemotional 淡定的，不为所动的

Q:fervor  ['fə:və]
A: ♠考法1  n. 热情，狂热： great warmth and intensity of emotion
A: ♣例  A blind patriotic fervor is called chauvinism. 盲目的爱国热情就被称为沙文主义
A: ♣近  ardor, enthusiasm, passion, zeal, zealotry
A: ♣反  apathy, indifference, impassiveness, unconcern 冷漠

Q:fester  ['festə]

A: ♣例  A dirty wound will probably fester. 伤口弄脏了有可能会化脓
A: ♣近  corrupt, decompose, putrefy, rot, spoil
A: ♣反  heal, cure 愈合

Q:fetid  [fetid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 恶臭的： having a heavy offensive smell
A: ♣例  Ammonia has a fetid odor that sickened the people. 氨气有着令人作呕的气味
A: ♣近  foul, fusty, malodorous, noisome, reeking, smelly, stinky, strong
A: ♣反  ambrosial, aromatic, balmy, fragrant, redolent, scented 芳香的

Q:fetter  ['fetə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 枷锁，限制： something that limits one's freedom of action or choice
A: ♣例  a fetter that prevents us from trying something new 阻碍我们尝试新事物的枷锁
A: ♣近  circumscription, constraint, curb, limitation, restraint, stricture
A: ♠考法2  v. 束缚： to restrain from motion, action, or progress
A: ♣例  be fettered by family responsibilities 被家庭责任所束缚
A: ♣近  chain, clog, enfetter, hamper, manacle, restrain, shackle, trammel
A: ♣反  enfranchise, free, liberate, unbind, unfetter, unshackle 解放；facilitate 促进
A: ♣派  enfetter v. 束缚

Q:fiasco  [fi'æskəu]

A: ♣例  The Hitler's plot ended in a fiasco. 希特勒的阴谋最终以失败告终
A: ♣近  catastrophe, debacle, disaster, failure
A: ♣反  blockbuster, éclat, success 成功

Q:fickle  ['fikl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 易变的： likely to change frequently, suddenly, or unexpectedly
A: ♣例  a fickle lover 感情善变的情人
A: ♣近  capricious, fluid, mercurial, mutable, temperamental, volatile
A: ♣反  constant, immutable, invariable, stable, steady 稳定的，不变的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不忠诚的： not true in one's allegiance to someone or something
A: ♣例  When the family's fortune disappeared, so did their fickle friends. 当这个家庭的财富消逝殆尽时，他们的那些虚伪的朋友也无影无踪了
A: ♣近  disloyal, perfidious, recreant, traitorous, treacherous, unfaithful
A: ♣反  faithful, loyal 忠诚的

Q:fictitious  [fik'tiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 虚构的： not real and existing only in the imagination
A: ♣例  His wartime exploits turned out to be entirely fictitious, as he had never even been in the military. 他吹嘘的战时英勇行为是彻底虚构的，因为他根本就没有参过军
A: ♣近  chimerical, fabricated, fabulous, fictional, imagined, invented
A: ♣反  actual, existing, real 事实的

Q:fidelity  [fi'deliti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 忠诚： the quality or state of being faithful
A: ♣例  They have never wavered in their fidelity to the cause of liberation. 他们从不动摇对于解放事业的忠诚
A: ♣近  adherence, allegiance, commitment, devotion, faith, loyalty, piety
A: ♣反  disloyalty, infidelity, perfidy 不忠； treachery 背叛
A: ♣派  infidel n. 异教徒

Q:figment  ['fiɡmənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 虚构的事物，幻觉： something made up or contrived
A: ♣例  Unable to find any tracks in the snow the next morning, I was forced to conclude that the shadowy figure had been a figment of my imagination. 第二天一早，我没有在雪地上发现任何足迹，由此我不得不相信昨晚幽灵一样的物体只是我的空想。‖Thus far, the invisible human being has been nothing more than a figment of fantasy writers. 到目前为止，隐形人还仅仅只是玄幻小说笔下的构想。
A: ♣近  chimera, conceit, daydream, delusion, dream, fancy, fantasy, hallucination, illusion, phantasm, vision
A: ♣反  fact, materiality, reality 客观存在的事物

Q:figurative  ['fiɡjurətiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 比喻的： expressing one thing in terms normally denoting another with which it may be regarded as analogous
A: ♣例  The word here is used in its figurative sense. 这个词在这里取它的比喻义
A: ♣近  extended, metaphorical
A: ♣反  literal 字面上的，逐字逐句的

Q:figurine  ['fiɡjuri:n]
A: ♠考法1  n. 小雕塑： a small statue
A: ♣例  His collection of figurines includes toy soldiers from every war that America has fought. 他收藏的小雕塑包括了所有美国参与过的战争中的兵人模型
A: ♣近  figure, statuette
A: ♣反  colossus 巨像

Q:filibuster  ['filibʌstə]
A: ♠考法1  n./v. 拖延议事： the use of obstructionist tactics, especially prolonged speechmaking, for the purpose of delaying legislative action
A: ♣例  The Senator used a filibuster to stop the bill. 参议员拖延了草案的实施
A: ♣近  delay, hindrance, impediment, obstruction, postponement ,procrastination

Q:filter  [filtə]
A: ♠考法1  v. 过滤： to pass through a filter
A: ♣例  steep the tea and then filter it to get rid of the leaves 浸泡茶叶，再将其过滤以去除废渣
A: ♣近  screen
A: ♠考法2  v. 去除杂质： to remove(usually visible) impurities from
A: ♣例  After frying the chicken, we filtered the oil and kept it in the refrigerator to use again. 在炸完鸡肉之后，我们将滤去了杂质的油保存起来以供日后使用
A: ♣近  clear, distill, garble, purify
A: ♣反  adulterate 掺杂；contaminate 污染

Q:finale  [fi'nɑ:li]
A: ♠考法1  n. 终场，结局： the closing part, scene, or number in a public performance
A: ♣例  Didier Drogba pulled one back for Chelsea in a finale. 德罗巴在终场结束时为切尔西扳回一球。
A: ♣近  close, coda, conclusion, end
A: ♣反  prologue 开场白； overture 序曲

Q:finesse  [fi'nes]
A: ♠考法1  n. 娴熟技巧： mental skill or quickness
A: ♣例  The musician shows wonderful finesse. 那位音乐家展现出了非凡的技艺
A: ♣近  adeptness, adroitness, cleverness, dexterity, proficiency
A: ♣反  awkwardness, ineptitude, gaucherie, ungainliness 笨拙
A: ♠考法2  v. 精心策划： to plan out usually with subtle skill or care
A: ♣例  finesse the schedule 精心安排日程
A: ♣近  contrive, frame, machinate, maneuver, manipulate
A: ♠考法3  v.（巧妙地）躲避： to get or keep away from (as a responsibility) through cleverness or trickery
A: ♣例  He tried to finesse the blame for the foreign policy fiasco, even though he was secretary of state at the time. 他竭尽所能躲避因失败的对外政策而可能遭到的指责，尽管他是时任国务卿
A: ♣近  avoid, dodge, eschew, evade, shun
A: ♣反  confront 直面

Q:finicky  ['finiki]

A: ♣例  have a reputation for being finicky eater 有着挑食的名声
A: ♣近  demanding, exacting, fastidious, fussy, nice, particular
A: ♣反  undemanding, unfussy 不挑剔的

Q:fitful  ['fitful]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无规律的，缺乏周期的： having an erratic or intermittent character
A: ♣例  He drifted off into a fitful sleep. 他慢慢地陷入了时睡时醒的状态。
A: ♣近  aperiodic, casual, discontinuous, episodic, erratic, intermittent, irregular, occasional, sporadic, unsteady
A: ♣反  constant, continuous, incessant 持续不断的；periodic, regular, repeated 定期的

Q:flaccid  ['flæksid]

A: ♣例  flaccid muscles 松弛的肌肉
A: ♣近  droopy, floppy, lank, loose, slack, yielding
A: ♣反  stiff, sturdy 结实的，坚硬的；resilient 有弹性的

Q:flag  [flæɡ]

A: ♣例  We respect the flag of our fathers. 我们尊敬父辈们的旗帜
A: ♣近  banner, ensign, pendant, pennant
A: ♠考法2  v. 变得衰弱： to become unsteady, feeble, or spiritless
A: ♣例  We flagged as we neared the end of the long mountain trail. 当我们终于快到达漫长山路的终点时，已经筋疲力尽
A: ♣近  decay, decline, deteriorate, emaciate, fade, fail, languish, sag, waste, wilt, wither
A: ♣反  thrive 繁荣；revitalize, revive 恢复活力
A: ♣派  unflagging adj. 坚持不懈的

Q:flamboyant  ['flæm'bɔiənt]

A: ♣例  Las Vegas showgirls wearing flamboyant headdresses 打扮花哨的拉斯维加斯舞女
A: ♣近  flaring, florid, garish, ornate, ostentatious, showy
A: ♣反  natural 自然的；conservative, quiet, understated 低调的
A: ♣派  flamboyance n. 炫目，炫耀

Q:flatter  ['flætə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 拍马屁，奉承，讨好： to praise excessively especially from motives of self-interest
A: ♣例  Friends who flatter you to your face are not true friends. 当面拍你马屁的朋友都不是真正的朋友
A: ♣近  adulate, blandish, compliment, court, massage, overpraise, stroke, wheedle
A: ♣反  abuse 辱骂；censure, criticize 批评
A: ♠考法2  vt. 自我感觉良好： to think highly of (oneself)
A: ♣例  Don't flatter yourself that no one has ever thought of that idea before.不要自欺欺人地认为别人没有考虑过那个想法
A: ♣近  pique, plume
A: ♠考法3  vt. 使显得更漂亮： to show off becomingly or advantageously
A: ♣例  Orange flatters those with golden skin tones. 橙色让黄肤色的人显得更漂亮
A: ♣近  become, enhance, suit
A: ♣反  mar, spoil 破坏
A: ♣派  flattering adj.令人满足的，令人迷恋的

Q:flaw  [flɔ:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 瑕疵，缺点： an imperfection, often concealed, that impairs soundness
A: ♣例  The absence of flaw in beauty is itself a flaw. 完美无瑕本身就是瑕疵
A: ♣近  blight, blotch, defect, fault, imperfection, mar, scar, spot
A: ♠考法2  v. 降低，破坏，使不完美： to reduce the soundness, effectiveness, or perfection of
A: ♣例  That crack has flawed the vase to the extent that its value in the antiques market is greatly reduced. 那道裂缝让这个花瓶在古董市场上大大地掉价
A: ♣近  blemish, break, compromise, cripple, harm, hurt, impair, injure, spoil, vitiate
A: ♣反  fix, mend, repair, revamp 修复，改造
A: ♣派  flawed adj. 有瑕疵的；flawless adj. 完美无瑕的

Q:fledgling  ['fledʒliŋ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 新手： a person who is just starting out in a field of activity
A: ♣例  At hockey he's still a fledgling and needs to work on his basic skating skills. 在冰球场上他还是一个菜鸟，还需要在基本的滑冰技术上加强练习
A: ♣近  apprentice, beginner, freshman, neophyte, novice, tyro, recruit, rookie
A: ♣反  veteran 老兵，身经百战的人
A: ♣派  fledge v. 鸟类长羽毛

Q:fleet  [fli:t]

A: ♣近  armada, caravan, cavalcade, motorcade

A: ♣例  He was fleet as a deer. 他如小鹿般敏捷
A: ♣近  brisk, expeditious, fast, hasty, nimble, quick, rapid, rattling, speedy, swift
A: ♣反  slow 缓慢的
A: ♠考法3  vi. 快速通过： to move or pass swiftly
A: ♣近  dart, flit, hurry, hustle
A: ♣反  plod 沉重而缓慢地走
A: ♣派  fleeting adj. 稍纵即逝的

Q:fleeting  ['fli:tiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 稍纵即逝的，短暂的： lasting only for a short time; passing swiftly
A: ♣例  They have been waiting for more than 4 hours but caught only a fleeting glimpse of the movie star. 他们苦等了至少四个小时，却最终只短短地瞟到了电影明星一眼。
A: ♣近  brief, ephemeral, evanescent, flash, fugitive, impermanent, passing, temporary, transient, transitory
A: ♣反  ceaseless, deathless, eternal, everlasting, immortal, lasting, permanent, perpetual, timeless 永恒的

Q:flexible  ['fleksibl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 灵活的，可变的： capable of being readily changed
A: ♣例  Our schedules are highly flexible. 我们的计划是非常灵活的
A: ♣近  adaptable, adjustable, alterable, changeable, elastic, fluid, malleable, modifiable, pliable, variable
A: ♣反  fixed, immutable, inflexible, invariable 确定的，不可变的；stiff, rigid 僵化的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 易受影响的： susceptible to influence or persuasion
A: ♣例  Their boss was flexible and lenient. 他们的老板既好说话，又很仁慈
A: ♣近  docile, manageable, tractable
A: ♣反  adamant, headstrong, intractable, mulish, recalcitrant, refractory, stubborn, obstinate 倔强的
A: ♣派  flexibility n. 灵活性

Q:flinch  [flintʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 畏缩；退缩： to draw back in fear, pain, or disgust
A: ♣例  He met my gaze without flinching. 他毫不畏缩地与我对视
A: ♣近  cringe, quail, recoil, shrink, wince
A: ♣反  face, meet 面对；confront 直面

Q:flippancy  ['flipənsi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 轻率，无礼： unbecoming levity or pertness especially in respect to grave or sacred matters
A: ♣例  The flippancy of your answer annoyed me. 你轻率的回答让我很恼火
A: ♣近  facetiousness, flightiness, frivolousness, frothiness, levity, silliness
A: ♣反  earnestness, gravity, seriousness, soberness, solemnity, solemnness 严肃，认真

Q:flirt  [flə:t]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 调情： to behave amorously without serious intent
A: ♣例  The waitress at that restaurant flirts with all single male customers. 这家餐厅的女服务员对所有的男性单身顾客都暗送秋波
A: ♣近  coquet, dally, frivol, toy, trifle
A: ♠考法2  vi. 无规则地快速运动： to make an irregular series of quick, sudden movements
A: ♣例  lazily watched the butterflies flirting among the wildflowers 慵懒地看着蝴蝶在野花丛中乱舞
A: ♣近  dance, dart, fleet, flick, flit, flutter, hurry, rush, zip

Q:flit  [flit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 快速或突然地经过：to pass quickly or abruptly from one place or condition to another
A: ♣例  Memories of the evening flitted through her mind. 关于那一晚的记忆在她脑海中一掠而过。
A: ♣近  dance, dart, fleet, flick, flirt, flutter, hurry, rush, zip
A: ♣反  plod 沉重缓慢地走

Q:flock  [flɔk]
A: ♠考法1  n. 人群，兽群： a great number of persons or creatures massed together
A: ♣例  a flock of ill-disposed reporters at the press conference 新闻发布会上一群不怀好意的记者
A: ♣近  army, drove, herd, legion
A: ♠考法2  vi. 聚集，集体行动： to congregate or travel in a flock or crowd
A: ♣例  Vacationers flocked to the towns along the shore in order to escape the August heat. 度假的人们一起涌向海岸，以躲避八月里的热浪
A: ♣近  mob, swarm, throng

Q:florid  ['flɔ:rid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 辞藻华丽的，花哨的： full of fine words and fancy expressions
A: ♣例  gave a florid speech to attract attention 做了个辞藻华丽的演说以吸引眼球
A: ♣近  bombastic, flowery, grandiloquent, magniloquent, rhetorical
A: ♠考法2  adj. 装饰华丽的： elaborately and often excessively decorated
A: ♣例  a florid architectural style 华丽的建筑风格
A: ♣近  baroque, bedizened, flamboyant, fussy, luscious, ornate
A: ♣反  austere, plain, severe, stark, unadorned 朴素的，简单的

Q:flounder  ['flaundə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 笨拙地行动，挣扎： to proceed or act clumsily or ineffectually
A: ♣例  flounder through the desert 步履蹒跚地穿越沙漠
A: ♣近  blunder, fumble, lumber, plod, struggle, trudge
A: ♣反  glide, slide 滑行；breeze, waltz 轻松地行动

Q:flourish  ['flauriʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 茂盛；繁荣： to grow luxuriantly; to achieve success
A: ♣例  The program will flourish once it receives adequate funding. 这个项目只要有足够的资金就能大获成功
A: ♣近  bloom, burgeon, prosper, thrive
A: ♣反  languish, wane 变得衰弱，衰败；fail 失败
A: ♠考法2  n. 装饰： an embellishment or ornamentation
A: ♣例  a bedroom with cute little flourishes 一间带有可爱小装饰的卧室‖Her writing style is simple and clear, without unnecessary flourishes. 她的文风很简单清新，没有那些不必要的修饰
A: ♣近  adornment, decoration, embellishment, ornamentation

Q:flout  ['flaut]

A: ♣例  flout the academic norm by plagiarizing 通过抄袭来蔑视学术规范
A: ♣近  despise, disregard, gibe, sneer, taunt
A: ♣反  respect, revere, venerate 尊敬

Q:fluctuate  ['flʌktjueit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 波动，无规则地变动： to shift back and forth uncertainly
A: ♣例  Stock prices fluctuate wildly.股票价格大幅波动‖Samples of ice cores collected from Antarctica suggested that the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide has been fluctuating periodically. 南极冰芯样本表明，大气中的二氧化碳浓度存在周期性的涨落
A: ♣近  mutate, shift, swing, oscillate, vacillate, vary, waver
A: ♣反  stabilize 保持稳定；plateau 到达稳定状态
A: ♣派  fluctuation n. 涨落，波动

Q:fluent  ['flu(:)ənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 表达流利的： able to express oneself clearly and well
A: ♣例  a very fluent speaker who always communicates his points well 一个总能明确指出要点的流利演说家
A: ♣近  eloquent, silver-tongued, well-spoken
A: ♣反  inarticulate, ineloquent, unvocal 说话不清的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不费力的： involving minimal difficulty or effort
A: ♣例  a fluent performance of one of the oldest magic tricks in the book 一场毫不费力的魔术，表演的是书本上最老的魔术之一
A: ♣近  effortless, facile, fluid, painless, ready, simple, smooth
A: ♣反  arduous, demanding, exacting, formidable, grueling, hard, laborious, murderous, rough, toilsome, tough
A: ♣派  fluency n. 流畅，流利

Q:fluky  ['flu:ki]

A: ♣例  a fluky coincidence that kept me safely at home when the blizzard hit 一个偶然的巧合让我在暴风雪来袭时安全地待在家里
A: ♣近  fortuitous, lucky, providential
A: ♣反  hapless, unfortunate, unlucky, ill-fated 不幸的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 偶然的： happening by or depending on chance
A: ♣近  casual, chance, inadvertent, incidental, unintended, unintentional
A: ♣反  calculated, deliberate, intended, intentional, planned, premeditated 蓄意的，有预谋的
A: ♣派  fluke n. 侥幸，偶然

Q:flush  [flʌʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （肤色）健康红润的： having a healthy reddish skin tone
A: ♣近  blooming, florid, glowing, red, rosy, rubicund, sanguine
A: ♣反  ashen, doughy, livid, pale, pallid, wan 苍白的，病态的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 富有的： having goods, property, or money in abundance
A: ♣例  She's very flush now that she has her inheritance. 自从继承了那份遗产，她变得十分富有
A: ♣近  affluent, loaded, opulent, wealthy
A: ♣反  destitute, impoverished, indigent, needy, impecunious 贫穷的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 大量的： marked by abundance
A: ♣例  a field flush with flowers 充满了鲜花的原野
A: ♣近  abounding, abundant, awash, fraught, lousy, replete, swarming, teeming, thronging
A: ♣反  inadequate, insufficient, scant, scarce, short 匮乏的，不足的
A: ♠考法4  vi. 冲洗： to pour liquid over or through in order to cleanse

A: ♣近  irrigate, rinse, sluice, wash

Q:foolproof  ['fu:l,pru:f]

A: ♣例  Anything foolproof is impossible and what truly counts is probability. 没有万无一失的事情，真正的问题在于概率
A: ♣近  guaranteed, infallible, safe, unfailing, fail-safe
A: ♣反  fallible 容易出错的

A: ♣派  frailty n. 虚弱，（意志）脆弱

Q:friction  ['frikʃən]

A: ♣近  disagreement, conflict, contention, dissidence, schism, war
A: ♣反  accord, harmony, peace, concord 和谐
A: ♣派  frictional adj. 产生摩擦的

Q:frigid  ['fridʒid]

A: ♣近  cold, arctic, chilling, freezing, frosty, glacial
A: ♣反  roasting, scalding, scorching, searing, seething, sizzling, sultry, sweltering, torrid 炎热的

A: ♣例  a formal but frigid welcome 一个正式但冷漠的招呼
A: ♣近  indifferent, cold, emotionless, passionless, unresponsive
A: ♣反  ardent, amorous, cordial 饱含感情的
A: ♣派  frigidity n. 严寒；冷漠

Q:fringe  [frindʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 边缘： something that resembles such a border or edging
A: ♣例  “Don’t act on the fringes of the law,” warns the customs officer. 海关人员警告说：“不要打法律的擦边球”
A: ♣近  border, boundary, circumference, edge, margin, perimeter, periphery, skirt
A: ♣反  center, core 中心，核心
A: ♠考法2  v. 接壤： to be adjacent to
A: ♣近  abut, border, neighbor, skirt, verge

Q:frivolous  ['frivələs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 轻浮的： marked by unbecoming levity
A: ♣例  a frivolous young woman 一个举止轻浮的年轻女子
A: ♣近  giddy, shallow, superficial
A: ♣反  earnest, sober, serious 严肃的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不重要的： of little weight or importance
A: ♣例  The frivolous comment was soon forgotten. 那个不值一提的评论很快就被遗忘了
A: ♣近  trivial, flimsy, light, petty, trifling
A: ♣反  consequential, eventful, meaningful, momentous, weighty 重要的
A: ♣派  frivolity n. 轻浮，轻佻

Q:frosty  ['frɔsti]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 寒冷的： having a low or subnormal temperature
A: ♣例  a frosty autumn that was a sign of the brutal winter that followed 一个极为寒冷的秋天，它象征着随之而来的、可能更加残暴的冬季
A: ♣近  algid, arctic, bitter, chilling, coldish, cool, freezing, frigid, gelid, glacial, icy, nippy, numbing, polar, snappy
A: ♣反  ardent, blazing, burning, fervent, fervid, molten, roasting, scalding, scorching, searing, sultry, sweltering, torrid 炎热的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无强烈感情的，冷淡的： lacking in friendliness or warmth of feeling
A: ♣例  She gave the telemarketer on the phone a frosty “No, thank you” and hung up. 她向电话那头的推销员冷冷地说了一句“不，谢谢”之后就挂掉了电话。
A: ♣近  antiseptic, apathetic, brittle, chilly, cold-blooded, frozen, indifferent, unfriendly, unsympathetic, wintry
A: ♣反  cordial, friendly, genial, hearty, sympathetic, warm, warm-blooded, warmhearted 友善的，热心的

Q:frothy  ['frɔθi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 用轻薄材料制作的：made of light thin material
A: ♣例  a frothy laptop made of carbon fiber and alloys 碳纤维以及合金制造的轻薄型笔记本电脑
A: ♣近  delicate, gossamer, light
A: ♣反  weighty 重的；sturdy 结实的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （内容等）欢乐轻佻、不严肃的： gaily frivolous or light in content or treatment
A: ♣例  a frothy movie 一部有喜感的电影
A: ♣近  flighty, frivolous, puerile
A: ♣反  earnest, serious, sober 严肃的

Q:frowsy  ['frauzi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 邋遢的： having a slovenly or uncared-for appearance
A: ♣例  frowsy hair 邋遢的头发
A: ♣近  slovenly, unkempt, untidy
A: ♣反  dapper, neat, tidy, spruce 整洁的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 味道难闻的： having an unpleasant smell
A: ♣例  The abandoned house was dank and frowsy and barely fit for human habitation. 这座废房子光线又暗，气味又难闻，几乎无法供人居住
A: ♣近  fetid, noisome, smelly, stinky
A: ♣反  ambrosial, aromatic, fragrant, redolent 芳香的

Q:frugal  ['fru:ɡəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 节约的： characterized by or reflecting economy in the use of resources
A: ♣例  be frugal in her expenditures 节约她的开销
A: ♣近  sparing, economical, provident, stingy
A: ♣反  extravagant, prodigal, sumptuous 奢侈浪费的
A: ♣派  frugality n. 节俭

Q:frustrate  [frʌs'treit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 挫败，阻挠： to prevent from accomplishing a purpose or fulfilling a desire
A: ♣例  frustrated their scheme in time 及时挫败了他们的阴谋
A: ♣近  ruin, baffle, balk, circumvent, foil, thwart
A: ♣反  abet 帮助，鼓舞，教唆 accomplish, fulfill 实现
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使沮丧： to lessen the courage or confidence of
A: ♣例  frustrated by his failure 为他的失败感到沮丧
A: ♣近  chill, daunt, dishearten, dismay, dispirit
A: ♣反  embolden, encourage, nerve, steel 鼓舞
A: ♣派  frustration n. 沮丧；阻挠；frustrated adj. 沮丧的

Q:full-bodied  ['ful'bɔdid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 重要的： having importance, significance, or meaningfulness
A: ♣例  a full-bodied study of genetic engineering 一项基因工程的重要研究
A: ♣近  important, consequential, momentous, significant, weighty
A: ♣反  trivial 不重要的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 味道浓烈的： having richness and intensity of flavor or aroma
A: ♣例  full-bodied perfume in the cabin 车厢内浓郁的香水味
A: ♣近  strong, concentrated
A: ♣反  insipid 平淡无奇的

Q:fulminate  ['fʌlmineit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 大声斥责： to issue a thunderous verbal attack or denunciation
A: ♣例  fulminate the so-called curricular reform痛斥所谓的课程改革
A: ♣近  criticize, blame, censure, condemn, denounce, denunciate, lambaste, reprehend, reprobate
A: ♣反  applaud, compliment, praise 赞美
A: ♣派  fulmination n. 训斥

Q:fumble  ['fʌmbl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 笨拙地做： to make awkward attempts to do or find something
A: ♣例  fumbled in his pocket for a coin 从口袋里笨拙地摸出一枚硬币
A: ♣近  botch, flounder, mess, stumble
A: ♠考法2  n. （无意识的）失误： an unintentional departure from truth or accuracy
A: ♣例  played the entire piano piece without a single fumble 完美地演绎了整首钢琴曲
A: ♣近  blunder, fault, gaffe, lapse, misstep, mistake

Q:furor  ['fju:rɔ:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 喧闹，激动，狂热：a state of intense excitement or ecstasy
A: ♣例  The decision to raise tax has caused a great furor among the working class. 提高税收的决定引起了工人阶级的强烈反响
A: ♣近  delirium, frenzy, fever, fury, hysteria, outrage, rage, uproar, wrath
A: ♣反  serenity, tranquility 平静，宁静
A: ♣反  delight, pleasure 愉悦

Q:furtive  ['fə:tiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 鬼鬼祟祟的；秘密的： done by stealth
A: ♣例  a furtive glance at her 朝她投去的隐秘一瞥
A: ♣近  secret, clandestine, covert, stealthy, surreptitious
A: ♣反  aboveboard 光明正大的；candid, forthright 坦率的
A: ♣派  furtively adv. 秘密地

Q:fury  ['fjuəri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 暴怒： intense, disordered, and often destructive rage
A: ♣例  The gods unleashed their fury on the offending mortal. 诸神将怒火降在了对那些对神明不敬的凡人身上
A: ♣近  anger, indignation, ire, mad, rage, wrath
A: ♣反  forbearance 容忍；delight, pleasure 快乐，愉悦
A: ♣派  furious adj. 狂暴的，暴怒的

Q:fussy  ['fʌsi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 谨慎的： taking, showing, or involving great care and effort
A: ♣例  a fussy actuarial problem 需要谨慎处理的保险计算问题
A: ♣近  careful, exact, meticulous, punctilious
A: ♣反  careless 粗心大意的
A: ♠考法2  adj.过分雕琢的： elaborately and often excessively decorated
A: ♣例  The room, with its rococo furniture and its overabundance of knickknacks, is just too fussy for my taste. 这房间里洛可可式的家具和过量的小饰品，让我觉得装修得有点过分以至于无法接受
A: ♣近  bedizened, florid
A: ♣反  austere, plain, stark 朴素的，朴实无华的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 挑剔的： hard to please
A: ♣例  It is widely known that cats are fussy eaters. 众所周知猫对食物很挑剔
A: ♣近  choosy, delicate, demanding, exacting, fastidious, nice, particular, persnickety, picky
A: ♣反  undemanding, unfussy 不挑剔的

Q:fusty  ['fʌsti]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 过时的： rigidly old-fashioned or reactionary
A: ♣例  fusty old carpets 过时的旧地毯
A: ♣近  antiquated, archaic, bygone, moldy, outdated
A: ♠考法2  adj. 腐臭的： saturated with dust and stale odors
A: ♣例  the fusty odor of a damp cellar 潮湿的地下室里的腐臭味道
A: ♣近  malodorous, fetid, musty, noisome, smelly, stale
A: ♣反  ambrosial, aromatic, fragrant, perfumed, redolent, savory, scented, sweet 有香味的，芳香的

Q:futile  ['fju:tail]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无效的，无用的： serving no useful purpose; completely ineffective
A: ♣例  It would be an undoubtedly futile effort to persuade him. 想说服他毫无疑问是徒劳的
A: ♣近  abortive, bootless, fruitless, ineffective, useless, vain
A: ♣反  effectual, efficacious 有效的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不严肃的： lacking in seriousness or maturity
A: ♣例  the futile chatter of gossip columnists about the comings and goings of Hollywood celebrities 八卦的专栏作家们对于好莱坞名人来来往往的随意闲谈
A: ♣近  flighty, frivolous, frothy
A: ♣反  earnest, serious 严肃认真的
A: ♣派  futility n. 徒劳，无益

Q:gadfly  ['ɡædflai]
A: ♠考法1  n. 刺激物： one that acts as a provocative stimulus
A: ♣近  goad, impetus, impulse, incentive, irritant, spur, stimulus
A: ♣反  balm 安抚，慰藉
A: ♠考法2  n. 令人反感的人： a person who stimulates or annoys especially by persistent criticism
A: ♣例  a tactless gadfly during post-game interviews with the losing team 在赛后采访败北方时一个令人讨厌的不懂人情世故的人
A: ♣近  annoyer, bother, persecutor, teaser, pest

Q:gaffe  [ɡæf]
A: ♠考法1  n. （社交上）失礼，失态： a social or diplomatic blunder
A: ♣例  A gaffe is when a politician tells the truth. —— Michael Kinsley 所谓出丑，就是政治家说真话的时候（迈克?金斯利）
A: ♣近  impropriety, indecorum, indiscretion
A: ♣反  decency, decorum, propriety 举止得体
A: ♠考法2  n. 明显的错误，错误判断： a blatant mistake or misjudgment
A: ♣例  so-called debates, which were mainly about seeing which candidate made the most gaffes 所谓的辩论，其实主要就是看哪个选手犯了最多的错误
A: ♣近  blunder, lapse, misstep, oversight

Q:gainsay  [ɡein'sei]
A: ♠考法1  v. 否认： to declare false
A: ♣近  deny, contradict, contravene, naysay
A: ♣反  acknowledge, admit, avow, concede 承认；affirm 证实
A: ♠考法2  vt. 反对： to oppose, especially by contradiction
A: ♣例  No one dare to gainsay him. 没人敢反驳他
A: ♣近  disagree, refute, reject, repudiate
A: ♣反  concur 同意

Q:gall  [ɡɔ:l]
A: ♠考法1  vt.（使）焦躁，激怒： irritate, vex
A: ♣例  The sarcastic applause from the audience galled her. 观众反讽的掌声激怒了她
A: ♣近  aggravate, exasperate, grate, inflame, provoke, pique, roil
A: ♣反  appease, assuage, calm, lull, pacify, placate 使平静，使平息
A: ♠考法2  n.深深的敌意： a deep-seated ill will
A: ♣例  Her kindly feelings turned to gall when she found out her nephew only wanted her money. 当她发现她的侄子只想要钱时，她之前友好的感情变成了憎恨与厌恶
A: ♣近  animosity, animus, antagonism, antipathy, hostility, rancor
A: ♣反  amity 友好
A: ♠考法3  n.大胆，无耻： shameless boldness
A: ♣例  I can't believe he had the gall to ask me how much I weigh. 我不敢相信他居然胆敢问我有多重
A: ♣近  audacity, brass, nerve, presumptuousness, temerity

Q:gallant  ['ɡælənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 英勇的： brave, spirited; nobly chivalrous and often self-sacrificing
A: ♣例  Gallant paratroopers jumped out of the plane without hesitation. 英勇的伞兵们毫不犹豫地跳出了飞机
A: ♣近  bold, courageous, dauntless, heroic, stouthearted, valorous
A: ♣反  craven, pusillanimous 胆小的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 高贵的，慷慨的： having, characterized by, or arising from a dignified and generous nature
A: ♣例  The members of that service club are known for their gallant service to the community. 那个服务社的成员因为他们对社区的慷慨贡献而为人所知
A: ♣近  chivalrous, elevated, loft, magnanimous, sublime
A: ♣反  base, debased, degenerate, ignoble 卑鄙的
A: ♣派  gallantly adv. 英勇地

Q:galvanize  ['ɡælvənaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （好似被用电击）刺激： to stimulate or excite as if by an electric shock
A: ♣例  an issue that would galvanize public opinion 激起大众评论的问题
A: ♣近  provoke, agitate, excite, intoxicate, motivate, stimulate, pump up
A: ♣反  allay, lull, pacify 使平静
A: ♣派  galvanizing adj. 刺激的

Q:gamble  ['ɡæmbl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 赌博，孤注一掷： to bet on an uncertain outcome, as of a contest
A: ♣例  gambled on the train being late 赌火车晚点
A: ♣近  bet, adventure, chance, risk, stake, venture
A: ♠考法2  vi. 使受到威胁： to place in danger
A: ♣例  You don't want to gamble with your life, so buckle up. 你不会想拿命来开玩笑的，所以系好安全带
A: ♣近  compromise, hazard, imperil, jeopardize, threaten
A: ♣派  gambling n. 赌博

Q:gambol  ['ɡæmbəl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 欢跳，雀跃： to leap about playfully
A: ♣例  young lambs gamboling in the meadow 小羊羔在原野里欢快地跳跃
A: ♣近  frolic, caper, cavort
A: ♣反  plod, trudge 沉重缓慢地走

Q:gangly  ['ɡæŋɡli]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 身材瘦长的： awkwardly tall or long-limbed
A: ♣例  The suspect is a gangly high school boy. 嫌犯是一个瘦高的中学生
A: ♣近  gangling, lanky, rangy, spindling, spindly
A: ♣反  stalwart 壮实的

Q:garble  ['ɡɑ:bl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 曲解，篡改，混淆（以至使无法理解）： to mix up or distort to such an extent as to make misleading or incomprehensible
A: ♣例  The summary totally garbles the results of the investigation. 这份摘要完全曲解了调查的结果
A: ♣近  misrepresent, belie, color, distort, falsify, twist, warp
A: ♣反  clarify, elucidate 阐明
A: ♠考法2  vt. 筛选，除杂： to remove usually visible impurities from
A: ♣例  Garbled spices are less likely to contaminate a recipe. 经过筛选的香料应该就不会影响食谱了
A: ♣近  clear, distill, filter, purify
A: ♣反  adulterate, contaminate 掺杂，污染

Q:gargantuan  [ɡɑ:'ɡæntjuən]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 巨大的： tremendous in size, volume, or degree
A: ♣例  a gargantuan waterfall in the rainforest 热带雨林中的巨大瀑布
A: ♣近  huge, astronomical, colossal, elephantine, enormous, gigantic, immense, mammoth, monstrous, titanic
A: ♣反  infinitesimal, minuscule 微小的

Q:garish  ['ɡεəriʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 过于鲜艳的，过于张扬的： marked by strident color or excessive ornamentation
A: ♣例  With garish makeup on, she looks exceedingly frivolous. 浓妆艳抹之下的她显得格外轻佻
A: ♣近  gaudy, blatant, brazen, flamboyant, glaring, ostentatious
A: ♣反  dim, gloomy, murky, somber 黯淡的；conservative, quiet 不张扬的

Q:garment  ['ɡɑ:mənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 衣服： an article of clothing
A: ♣例  pack all garments 给所有衣服打包
A: ♣近  apparel, attire, costume, dress, suit

Q:garrulous  ['ɡærjuləs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 啰嗦的，话多得令人厌烦的： given to excessive and often trivial or rambling talk; tiresomely talkative
A: ♣例  garrulous traveling companions 多话的旅伴
A: ♣近  talkative, chatty, loquacious, verbose, voluble
A: ♣反  laconic, reserved, reticent, taciturn 缄默的
A: ♣派  garrulity n. 啰嗦

Q:gash  [ɡæʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 砍得很深的伤口： a long deep cut
A: ♣例  got a gash in his knee that required four stitches 膝盖伤得很深，需要缝针
A: ♣近  incision, laceration, rent, rip, tear
A: ♠考法2  v. 砍： to make a gash in
A: ♣例  Her face had been gashed by the rocks as she tumbled down the embankment. 当她从堤岸上摔下来时脸上被刮了一道口
A: ♣近  cut, incision, piercing, slash, slice, slit
A: ♣反  sew 缝合

Q:gasification  [,ɡæsifi'keiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 气化： conversion into gas
A: ♣例  gasification of coals 煤的气化
A: ♣近  evaporation, sublimation
A: ♣反  solidification 固化；liquefaction 液化
A: ♣派  gasify v. 气化

Q:gauche  [ɡəuʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 笨拙的，缺乏社交经验的： lacking social experience or grace
A: ♣例  It would be gauche to mention the subject. 提到这个话题是很无礼的
A: ♣近  awkward, clumsy, crude, inept, maladroit, rustic, tactless
A: ♣反  graceful 优雅的；polished, refined, urbane 有教养的
A: ♣派  gaucheness n. 笨拙

Q:gaudy  ['ɡɔ:di]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 俗丽的： ostentatiously or tastelessly ornamented, excessively showy
A: ♣例  gaudy movie posters 俗丽的电影海报
A: ♣近  blatant, brazen, flashy, garish, glaring, meretricious, tawdry
A: ♣反  austere, homely, plain 朴素的；conservative, understated, unflamboyant, unflashy 不张扬的

Q:gauge  [ɡeidʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 测量标准： a measurement (as of linear dimension) according to some standard or system
A: ♣例  polls as a gauge of voter satisfaction 用以衡量选民满意度的选票结果
A: ♣近  standard, benchmark, criterion, measure, touchstone, yardstick
A: ♠考法2  vt. 判定： to determine the capacity or contents of
A: ♣例  It is hard to gauge his mood. 要判断他的情绪很困难
A: ♣近  assess, determine, evaluate, figure, measure, scale

Q:gawky  ['ɡɔ:ki]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （举止）笨拙的： having or showing an inability to move in a graceful manner
A: ♣例  The pathetic gawky woman was once a lithe ballerina but got severely injured in a car accident. 这个可怜的步态笨拙的妇女本来是一名轻巧优雅的芭蕾舞女，但是在一次车祸中受了重伤。
A: ♣近  awkward, clumsy, gawkish, graceless, uncoordinated, ungainly
A: ♣反  agile, graceful, lithe, nimble 灵巧的，敏捷的；elegant 优雅的
A: ♣派  gawkiness n. 笨拙

Q:gear  [ɡiə]
A: ♠考法1  v. 调整（以配合）： to adjust or adapt so as to make suitable
A: ♣例  geared the speech towards a conservative audience 调整演讲以适应保守的观众
A: ♣近  adapt, adjust, fit, suit, tailor

Q:genial  ['dʒi:njəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 和蔼亲切的： having an easygoing and pleasing manner especially in social situations
A: ♣例  a genial host who makes a point of speaking personally to each and every guest 一个强调与每个客人私下交流的亲切的主人
A: ♣近  affable, agreeable, gracious, mellow, nice, pleasant, sweet
A: ♣反  caustic, mordant 尖酸刻薄的；truculent 凶残的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 友好的，热心的： having or showing kindly feeling and sincere interest
A: ♣近  amicable, companionable, cordial, warmhearted
A: ♣反  antagonistic, hostile 有敌意的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 温暖的： marked by temperatures that are neither too high nor too low
A: ♣例  genial sunshine in winter 冬日的暖阳
A: ♣近  balmy, equable, gentle, mild, moderate, soft, temperate
A: ♣反  harsh, inclement, intemperate, severe 严峻的
A: ♣派  geniality n. 和蔼

Q:genteel  [dʒen'ti:l]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有教养的，不粗俗的： free from vulgarity or rudeness
A: ♣例  Her genteel behaviors at the ball make others conjecture that she must come from a distinguished noble family. 舞会上她极有教养的举止让他人纷纷猜测她一定来自名门望族
A: ♣近  courteous, decent, decorous, mannerly, polite, polished, respectable, urbane, couth, cultured, refined
A: ♣反  churlish 粗暴的；loutish 蠢笨的

Q:germane  [dʒə:'mein]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有关的，适当的： being at once relevant and appropriate
A: ♣例  details not germane to the discussion 与讨论无关的细节
A: ♣近  applicable, apropos, apposite, pertinent, relevant
A: ♣反  extraneous, irrelevant 无关的；inappropriate 不适当的

Q:germinate  ['dʒə:mineit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 发芽： to begin to grow
A: ♣例  Some seed varieties germinate very quickly. 有一些种子的变异体能够迅速发芽。
A: ♣近  burgeon, shoot, sprout
A: ♣反  fade, flag, wilt, wither 枯萎
A: ♠考法2  vi. 出现： to come into being
A: ♣例  A truly marvelous proof of this theorem germinated in his mind. 这个定理的一种绝妙证明方法浮现在他的脑海之中。
A: ♣近  develop, evolve, grow
A: ♣反  disappear, vanish 消逝，消失
A: ♣派  germination n. 萌芽

Q:gibe  [dʒaib]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 嘲弄： to deride or tease with taunting words
A: ♣例  gibe at the umpire 嘲弄裁判员
A: ♣近  deride, jeer, ridicule, mock, scoff, sneer, taunt
A: ♣反  respect, revere, venerate 尊敬

Q:giddy  ['ɡidi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 轻浮不严肃的： lacking in seriousness or maturity
A: ♣例  teach a bunch of giddy Girl Scouts how to make a fire 教一群漫不经心的女童子军如何生火
A: ♣近  flighty, frivolous, frothy
A: ♣反  grave, serious 严肃的；earnest 认真的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 喜悦的： joyfully elated
A: ♣例  He's clearly giddy at the news that his ailing grandfather will be fine. 听到他祖父的病将无大恙，他的喜悦之情溢于言表
A: ♣近  elated, elevated, euphoric, exhilarated, exultant, intoxicated, rapturous
A: ♣反  depressed, melancholy 忧郁的

Q:gild  [gild]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （带欺骗性地）修改，润色： to give an often deceptively attractive or improved appearance to
A: ♣例  Any further retouch would be gilding the lily. 任何形式的润色都会是画蛇添足
A: ♣近  polish, refine, smooth

Q:gist  [dʒist]
A: ♠考法1  n. 要点： the main point or part
A: ♣例  the gist of the argument 论证的要点
A: ♣近  core, essence, kernel, pivot, quintessence, substance
A: ♣反  divergence 偏离主旨

Q:glacial  ['ɡleisjəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 极冷的：extremely cold
A: ♣例  The air from the sea felt glacial. 海上的空气冷极了。
A: ♣近  algid, arctic, bitter, chilling, coldish, cool, freezing, frigid, frosty, gelid, icy, nippy, numbing, polar, snappy
A: ♣反  ardent, blazing, burning, fervent, fervid, molten, roasting, scalding, scorching, searing, sultry, sweltering, torrid 炎热的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 冷漠的，无感情的： devoid of warmth and cordiality
A: ♣例  The Duchess gave him a glacial look and moved on. 公爵夫人冷冷地看了他一眼，然后就继续上路了。
A: ♣近  antiseptic, apathetic, brittle, chilly, cold-blooded, frozen, indifferent, unfriendly, unsympathetic, wintry
A: ♣反  cordial, friendly, genial, hearty, sympathetic, warm, warm-blooded, warmhearted 友善的，热心的

Q:gladiator  ['ɡlædieitə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 角斗士： a person engaged in a fight to the death as public entertainment for ancient Romans
A: ♣例  He comes to Rome as a gladiator to seek revenge. 他化成角斗士来到罗马寻求复仇
A: ♣近  fighter, belligerent, combatant
A: ♠考法2  n. 参与打斗或辩论的人： a person engaging in a public fight or controversy
A: ♣近  boxer

Q:glaze  [ɡleiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 给…上釉，妆点： to coat with or as if with a glaze
A: ♣例  The storm glazed trees with ice. 暴风雨给树木镀上了一层冰装
A: ♣近  adorn, bedeck, decorate, embellish, garnish
A: ♣反  strip, uncover 剥去
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使平滑： to give a smooth glossy surface to
A: ♣近  polish, burnish, furbish, shine
A: ♣反  rumple 弄皱

Q:glib  [ɡlib]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 流利圆滑的（常含有不真诚或欺诈的成分），油腔滑调的： marked by ease and fluency in speaking or writing often to the point of being insincere or deceitful
A: ♣例  a glib politician 油嘴滑舌的政客
A: ♣近  nonchalant, oily
A: ♣反  taciturn 沉默寡言的；awkward 笨拙的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 缺乏深度的，肤浅的： lacking depth and substance
A: ♣例  glib solutions to the knotty problem 对复杂难解问题的肤浅的解决方案
A: ♣近  cursory, shallow, superficial
A: ♣反  abstruse, deep, profound 深奥的，深刻的

Q:glide  [ɡlaid]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 轻松地行动，轻松地通过： to move or proceedsmoothly, continuously, and effortlessly
A: ♣例  swans gliding over the lake 在湖面悠然划水的天鹅‖looking for a college course that he could just glide through 正在寻找一门很容易就能通过的课程
A: ♣近  bowl, breeze, brush, coast, cruise, drift, roll, sail, skim, slide, slip, stream, sweep, whisk
A: ♣反  flounder, struggle 挣扎

Q:glisten  ['ɡlisən]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 闪光： to shine by reflection with a sparkling luster
A: ♣例  The calm sea glistened in the sunlight. 日光下平静的海面波光粼粼
A: ♣近  flash, scintillate, sparkle, twinkle, winkle
A: ♣反  dim 变得黯淡

Q:glitch  [ɡlitʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n.小故障： a minor malfunction, mishap, or technical problem
A: ♣例  postponement due to a glitch in a spacecraft's fuel cell 宇宙飞船燃料电池故障引起的推迟发射
A: ♣近  bug, defect, fault, lapse, imperfection, peccadillo
A: ♣反  fatal error 致命错误

Q:gloat  [ɡləut]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 自鸣得意： a feeling of great, often malicious, pleasure or self-satisfaction
A: ♣例  gloat over his enemy's misfortune 为敌人的不幸而自鸣得意
A: ♣近  crow, relish, triumph
A: ♣反  mourn 哀悼

Q:gloomy  ['ɡlu:mi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 黯淡无光的： being without light or without much light
A: ♣近  black, dark, dim, dimmed, murky, obscure, stygian, pitch-dark
A: ♣反  bright, luminous, lucent, lucid 明亮的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 忧郁的： low in spirits
A: ♣例  feel gloomy about future career 就未来的职业生涯倍感忧心
A: ♣近  sullen, dejected, dour, melancholy, morose, saturnine, surly
A: ♣反  frothy 欢乐轻挑的；buoyant, cheerful, jubilant 高兴的

Q:gloss  [ɡlɔs]
A: ♠考法1  n. 简短解释： a brief explanation of a difficult or obscure word or expression
A: ♣近  abstract, annotation, brief, epitome, synopsis
A: ♣反  amplification 详解
A: ♠考法2  n. （欺骗性的）光鲜外表： a deceptively attractive external appearance
A: ♣例  used a computer to give her astrological predictions the gloss of real science 用计算机来给他的占星预测结果套上科学的外衣
A: ♣近  fa?ade, mask, veneer
A: ♠考法3  v. 敷衍潦草做事（甚至忽略）： to deal with (a subject or problem) too lightly or not at all
A: ♣例  gloss over the problems 不怎么理会这些问题
A: ♣近  disregard, ignore, neglect, overlook
A: ♣反  scrutinize 仔细研究
A: ♠考法4  v. 开脱（罪名）： to make (something) seem less bad by offering excuses
A: ♣例  I don't want to gloss over her misbehavior, but keep in mind that she's been under a lot of stress lately. 我不想为她的行为辩护，但是别忘了她最近压力很大
A: ♣近  excuse, extenuate
A: ♣派  glossary n. 术语表

Q:glossy  ['ɡlɔsi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 平滑的，有光泽的： having a smooth, shiny, lustrous surface
A: ♣例  glossy surface of the floor 平整光亮的地板
A: ♣近  lustrous, burnished, glistening, polished, shining
A: ♣反  coarse 粗糙的；dull, dim 无光泽的

Q:glower  [ɡləuə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 怒目而视： to look or stare with sullen annoyance or anger
A: ♣例  Baseball fans glowering at their TVs as they watched their favorite team lose. 看着他们支持的球队输球，棒球迷们恶狠狠地盯着电视屏幕。‖He just glowered without speaking. 他一言不发地怒视着我。
A: ♣近  glare, gloom, lower, scowl
A: ♣反  beam, grin, smile 笑

Q:glut  [ɡlʌt]
A: ♠考法1  v. 使过量，使充满： to fill beyond capacity, especially with food
A: ♣例  glut himself with Sushi 吃寿司吃撑了
A: ♣近  cloy, cram, fill, satiate, surfeit, oversupply, sate
A: ♣反  lack 缺乏
A: ♣派  glutted adj. 饱和的

Q:glutinous  ['ɡlu:tinəs]

A: ♣例  glutinous liquid 胶状液体
A: ♣近  adherent, adhesive, cloggy, gluey, sticky, tenacious, viscid
A: ♣反  fluid 流体的

Q:glutton  ['ɡlʌtən]

A: ♣例  a glutton for work 工作狂
A: ♣近  gorger, gourmand
A: ♣派  gluttony n. 暴饮暴食

Q:goad  [ɡəud]

A: ♣例  goad someone to do something 激励某人做某事
A: ♣近  urge, abet, exhort, instigate, prod, prompt, propel, spur, stimulate
A: ♣反  check, curb 阻止；lull 使安静

Q:gobble  ['ɡɔbl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 狼吞虎咽： to swallow or eat greedily
A: ♣例  Lions gobble their prey. 狮子狼吞虎咽地啃食它们的猎物
A: ♣近  devour, gorge, guzzle, quaff, raven, swill
A: ♣反  nibble 小口咬

Q:goggle  ['ɡɔɡl]

A: ♣例  goggled at the characters on the stele 凝视碑文的字眼
A: ♣近  blink, gawk, gaze, peer, stare
A: ♣反  glance, glimpse 瞥视

Q:goldbrick  ['ɡəuldbrik]

A: ♣例  goldbrick his duty as a citizen 逃避他作为公民的义务
A: ♣近  idle, parry, parry, shirk, sidestep
A: ♣反  dedicate, devote 致力于

Q:gorge  [ɡɔ:dʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 峡谷： a narrow steep-walled canyon or part of a canyon
A: ♣例  Wenchuan earthquake is said to have no detrimental effect on Three-Gorge dam. 汶川地震据称对三峡大坝没有破坏性影响
A: ♣近  gap, gulch, notch, ravine
A: ♠考法2  vi. 狼吞虎咽： to eat greedily or to repletion
A: ♣例  gorge himself at the party 在聚会上狼吞虎咽
A: ♣近  cram, devour, gobble, guzzle, loaf, quaff, sate, swill
A: ♣反  nibble 小口咬
A: ♣派  gorgeous adj. 壮观的

Q:gossamer  ['ɡɔsəmə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 虚无飘渺的东西： something light, delicate, or insubstantial
A: ♣例  the gossamer of youth's dreams 年少时飘渺的梦想
A: ♣近  ether, delicacy
A: ♣反  substance, entity 实体
A: ♠考法2  adj. 轻薄的： extremely light, delicate, or tenuous
A: ♣例  a gossamer explanation 站不住脚的解释
A: ♣近  diaphanous ,ethereal, filmy, light, insubstantial, tenuous
A: ♣反  heavy, leaden, ponderous 沉重的

Q:gourmand  ['ɡuəmənd]
A: ♠考法1  n. 嗜食者，大胃王： one who is excessively fond of eating and drinking
A: ♣例  the kind of gourmand who swallows food without even pausing to taste it 不尝味道就下咽的那种嗜食者
A: ♣近  gorger, glutton

Q:gourmet  ['ɡuəmei]

A: ♣例  a gourmet of Chinese food 中餐美食家
A: ♣近  bon vivant ,connoisseur, epicure
A: ♣反  layman 门外汉

Q:graft  [ɡrɑ:ft;]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 移植，移接： to implant (living tissue) surgically or as if surgically
A: ♣例  The top layer of skin has to be grafted onto the burns. 顶层的皮肤需要被移植到烧伤的伤口上。‖graft old traditions onto the new ones 把老传统移植到新的习俗之上
A: ♣近  implant, transplant

Q:grandeur  ['ɡrændʒə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 高尚，重要： nobility or greatness of character
A: ♣例  the glory that was Greece and the grandeur that was Rome 希腊的荣耀和罗马的辉煌
A: ♣近  magnificence, augustness, brilliance, glory, majesty, nobility, resplendence, splendor
A: ♣反  frivolousness 无关紧要
A: ♣派  grand adj. 宏伟壮观的

Q:grandiloquent  [ɡræn'diləkwənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （语言等）浮夸的： a lofty, extravagantly colorful, pompous, or bombastic style, manner, or quality especially in language
A: ♣例  feel disgusted with his grandiloquent speech 对他浮夸的演讲表示厌恶
A: ♣近  rhetorical, bombastic, inflated, magniloquent, pretentious
A: ♣反  secretive 低调的，隐秘的；simple 简单的
A: ♣派  grandiloquence n. 夸张的话语

Q:grandiose  ['ɡrændiəus]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 自命不凡的： characterized by feigned or affected grandeur
A: ♣例  grandiose words 自命不凡的话语
A: ♣近  extravagant, flamboyant, pompous, pretentious
A: ♣反  humble 谦逊的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 宏大的： characterized by greatness of scope or intent
A: ♣例  a grandiose hydroelectric project 宏伟的水利工程
A: ♣近  august, glorious, grand, imposing, magnificent, monumental, splendid
A: ♣反  trivial 微不足道的；humble, unimposing, unimpressive 平凡的
A: ♣派  grandiosity n. 自命不凡

Q:grandstand  ['ɡrændstænd]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 为了给人留下印象而表演，哗众取宠： to play or act so as to impress onlookers
A: ♣例  to grandstand on the stage 在舞台上哗众取宠
A: ♣近  act, perform, pretend

Q:grate  [ɡreit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 刮擦（以发出刺耳的声音）： to make a rasping sound
A: ♣例  The sled grated along the bare pavement. 雪橇与裸露的路面刮擦发出刺耳声
A: ♣近  abrade, rasp, scratch, scrape
A: ♠考法2  vt. 骚扰，惹恼：to irritate or annoy persistently
A: ♣例  a noise that grates on one's nerves 使人烦躁的噪音
A: ♣近  irritate, aggravate, gall, nettle, peeve, plague, provoke, vex
A: ♣反  soothe 使平静，安抚
A: ♣派  grating adj. 刺耳的

Q:gratify  ['ɡrætifai]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使满足： to give what is desired to, to please or satisfy
A: ♣例  gratify her curiosity 满足她的好奇心‖Her praise will gratify all who worked so hard to earn it. 他的表扬会使所有辛勤工作的人们高兴
A: ♣近  appease, cater, content, satisfy
A: ♣反  displease 使不满；grieve 使悲痛
A: ♣派  gratification n. 满意

Q:gratuitous  [ɡrə'tju:itəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无根据的，无理由的： unnecessary or unwarranted
A: ♣例  a dubious request based on a gratuitous assumption 基于无根据假设的可疑要求
A: ♣近  unfounded, unjustified, unreasonable, baseless, groundless
A: ♣反  justified, warranted 有理有据的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无报酬的，免费的： given or granted without return or recompense
A: ♣例  a gratuitous ticket 免费的门票
A: ♣近  free, complimentary, unearned, voluntary
A: ♣反  merited 应得的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 多余的： not needed by the circumstances or to accomplish an end
A: ♣近  dispensable, inessential, needless, redundant, superfluous, surplus
A: ♣反  critical, essential, pivotal, vital 关键的
A: ♣派  gratuity n.报酬，小费

Q:green  [ɡri:n]

A: ♣例  lead a squad of green recruits 带领一队没有经验的新兵
A: ♣近  inexperienced, callow, fresh, raw, unfledged, young
A: ♣反  experienced, versed 经验丰富的

Q:gregarious  [ɡri'ɡεəriəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 爱社交的：likely to seek or enjoy the company of others
A: ♣近  convivial, extroverted, genial, outgoing, sociable, outgoing
A: ♣反  aloof 疏远的；antisocial 不合群的；introverted, reclusive 内向的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 群居的： tending to group with others of the same kind
A: ♣例  ecologically define human as gregarious carnivore 从生态学上将人类定义为群居类肉食动物
A: ♣近  social
A: ♣反  solitary 独自的

Q:grieve  [ɡri:v]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 感到悲伤： to feel deep sadness or mental pain
A: ♣例  we all grieved over the lost cat 看到他这副样子真让我痛苦
A: ♣近  agonize, anguish, suffer，bemoan, bewail, deplore
A: ♣反  delight, exult in, glory in, joy, rejoice in

Q:grimace  [ɡri'meis]
A: ♠考法1  v./n. 因痛苦而面部扭曲： a sharp contortion of the face expressive of pain, disgust or disapproval
A: ♣例  she made a grimace when she tasted the medicine 她尝了一口药，然后做了一个鬼脸
A: ♣近  frown, moue, pout, scowl

Q:grin  [ɡrin]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 咧嘴笑： to express an emotion (as amusement) by curving the lips upward
A: ♣例  The boss grinned his approval. 老板咧嘴一笑表示赞许。
A: ♣近  beam
A: ♣反  pout 噘嘴生气

Q:gripe  [ɡraip]
A: ♠考法1  v. 抱怨： to express dissatisfaction, pain, or resentment usually tiresomely
A: ♣例  All workers were griping about the new regulations. 所有的工人都在抱怨新规章。
A: ♣近  carp, fuss, grouch, grouse, grumble, wail
A: ♣反  crow, delight, rejoice 欢快，喜悦
A: ♠考法2  v. 通过连续让人讨厌的举动激怒，惹怒： to disturb the peace of mind of (someone) especially by repeated disagreeable acts
A: ♣例  constant complaints from the customers griped her to the point where she started snapping back 顾客持续的抱怨让她也到了爆点
A: ♣近  aggravate, annoy, bother, chafe, exasperate, nettle, peeve, pique, rile, ruffle, vex

Q:grisly  ['ɡrizli]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 令人反感的，令人恐惧的： inspiring repugnance; gruesome
A: ♣例  a series grisly murders 一系列令人恐惧的谋杀
A: ♣近  appalling, dreadful, ghastly, gruesome, hideous, horrifying, macabre

Q:grit  [ɡrit]
A: ♠考法1  n. （面对困难时所表现出来的）毅力： the strength of mind that enables a person to endure pain or hardship
A: ♣例  She was an athlete with true grit, continuing her training despite bad weather and an injury. 她是真正一个有着惊人毅力的运动员，即便是在受了伤外加天气恶劣的情况下仍然坚持训练。
A: ♣近  backbone, constancy, fiber, grittiness, guts, intestinal fortitude, pluck, spunk
A: ♣反  cowardliness, cravenness, gutlessness, pusillanimity, spinelessness 懦弱

Q:groggy  ['ɡrɔɡi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 虚弱的，（走路）不稳的： weak and unsteady on the feet or in action
A: ♣例  She was feeling a bit groggy when I saw her. 当我看到她的时候她显得有些走路不稳。
A: ♣近  rickety, rocky,shaky, unbalanced, unsound, unstable, unsteady, wobbly
A: ♣反  balanced, stable, steady, sound 平衡的，稳定的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无法思考的，头脑不清的： not able to think or move normally because of being tired, sick, etc.
A: ♣例  I'm still a little groggy from my nap. 我还没完全从睡梦中清醒过来。‖The medicine sometimes makes patients groggy. 这种药偶尔会让病人产生醉酒一样的麻醉感。
A: ♣近  dazed, dopey, muddleheaded, muzzy, punch-drunk, punchy, stupefied, zonked, zonked-out
A: ♣反  clearheaded, unconfused 头脑清楚的

Q:groove  [ɡru:v]
A: ♠考法1  v. 享受，极其满意，过得快活： to take pleasure in
A: ♣例  thrill-seekers who groove on skiing will love snowboarding 那些乐在滑雪中的追求刺激的人们也会喜欢滑雪板的 || just sitting around, grooving on the music 随便坐坐，在音乐中享受一下
A: ♣近  adore, fancy, savor, relish, get off on, rejoice in, revel in, delight in

Q:grotesque  [ɡrəu'tesk]

A: ♣例  that bloody Halloween mask is grotesque 那个血腥的万圣节面具丑死了
A: ♣近  hideous, homely, ill-favored, monstrous, unappealing, unattractive, uncomely, unsightly
A: ♣反  aesthetic, attractive, beautiful, bonny, comely, fetching, gorgeous, knockout, ravishing, seemly, sightly, stunning, taking, well-favored 悦目的，吸引人的

Q:grovel  ['ɡrɔvəl]

A: ♣近  cringe, creep, slither, wriggle
A: ♣派  groveler n. 卑躬屈膝者：the one who lies with the body prostrate in token of subservience or abasement

Q:grudge  [ɡrʌdʒ]

A: ♣例  There has been a grudge between the two families for years. 两家之间积怨已深。‖He has had a deep grudge against her ever since she snubbed him at the dance. 自从她在舞会上对他不理不睬之后，他就对她怀有深深的怨念。
A: ♣近  animosity, animus, antagonism, antipathy, bitterness, gall, hostility, jaundice, malice, rancor, resentment
A: ♣反  amity 和睦，友好

Q:grueling  ['ɡruəliŋ]

A: ♣近  arduous, burdensome, laborious, onerous, taxing, toilsome
A: ♣反  effortless, light, unchallenging, undemanding, undemanding, facile 不费力气的

Q:grumble  ['ɡrʌmbl]

A: ♣例  The governed will always find something to grumble about. (Crane Brinton) 被统治者总能找到发牢骚的理由。——瑞恩?布林顿
A: ♣近  carp, croak, fuss, gripe, grouch, grouse, grump, moan, murmur, mutter, repine
A: ♣反  crow, delight, rejoice 感到高兴

A: ♣反  artlessness, forthrightness, ingenuousness, sincerity 朴实
A: ♣派  guileless adj. 朴实的：free of guile; artless
A: ♣反  manipulative 操纵的

Q:guilt  [ɡilt]

Q:gull  [ɡʌl]

A: ♣近  bamboozle, beguile, cozen, delude, dupe, fake out, gaff, hoax, hoodwink, snooker, string along, take in
A: ♣反  undeceive 使醒悟

Q:hack  [hæk]

A: ♣近  address, contend with, cope with, manage, maneuver, manipulate

A: ♣近  abide, bide, brook, countenance, endure, handle, stand, stomach, sustain, tolerate

A: ♣近  drain, fag, fatigue, outwear, tire, tucker out, wear out, knock out, burn out,

Q:hard-bitten  ['hɑ:d'bitən]

A: ♣近  hardened, sturdy, tough, cast-iron, inured, rugged, stout, vigorous, hardy
A: ♣反  delicate, nonhardy, soft, tender, weak 柔弱的

Q:harsh  [hɑ:ʃ]

Q:havoc  ['hævək]

A: ♣近  disarrangement, disarray, dishevelment, muddle, muss, tumble, welter
A: ♣反  order, orderliness 有序
A: ♠考法2  n. 大范围破坏： the state or fact of being rendered nonexistent, physically unsound, or useless
A: ♣例  the powerful hurricane wreaked havoc all along the coast 威力巨大的飓风摧毁着沿岸的一切
A: ♣近  annihilation, decimation, demolishment, desolation, devastation, extermination, extinction, obliteration, ruin, wreckage
A: ♣反  building, construction, erection, raising 建设

A: ♣反  deliberate, unhurried, unrushed 深思熟虑的

Q:heckle  ['hekl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 起哄，使难堪： to harass and try to disconcert with questions, challenges, or gibes
A: ♣例  a controversial player who was constantly heckled by the fans 一个时常被粉丝起哄的有争议的歌手‖Several protesters were heckling the speaker at the rally. 不少示威者在集会上起哄让发言者难堪。
A: ♣近  badger, bait, hassle, haze, hector, needle, ride, taunt

Q:hedonism  ['hi:dəunizəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 享乐主义： the doctrine that pleasure or happiness is the sole or chief good in life
A: ♣例  their spring break trip to Mexico became an exercise in heedless hedonism 他们春季的墨西哥之行成为了一次未加注意的享乐之旅
A: ♣近  carnality, debauchery, sybaritism, voluptuousness
A: ♣反  abstinence, asceticism, sobriety, temperance 禁欲，节制

Q:hegemony  [hi'ɡeməni]
A: ♠考法1  n. 霸权，统治权： preponderant influence or authority over others
A: ♣例  battled for hegemony in Asia 争夺在亚洲地区的霸权地位
A: ♣近  ascendancy, dominance, dominion, predominance, preeminence
A: ♣反  lack of authority 缺少权利

Q:heinous  ['hainəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可憎的，十恶不赦的： hatefully or shockingly evil, abominable
A: ♣例  a heinous crime 十恶不赦的罪行
A: ♣反  commendable 值得赞美的

Q:herald  ['herəld]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 告知： to make known openly or publicly
A: ♣例  herald the great tidings to all the world 将重大消息告知全世界
A: ♣近  annunciate, broadcast, declare, enunciate, proclaim, promulgate
A: ♠考法2  v. 预示，预兆： to give a slight indication of beforehand
A: ♣例  the reshuffle of the company's management heralded the sweeping changes to come 公司管理层的重新洗牌预示着即将到来的巨大变革
A: ♣近  adumbrate, forerun, harbinger, prefigure

Q:heresy  ['herəsi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 异教，和普遍观点相悖： a controversial or unorthodox opinion or doctrine, departure from a generally accepted theory, opinion, or practice
A: ♣例  the heresy of asserting that Shakespeare was not a great writer 声称莎士比亚不是伟大作家的非主流观点
A: ♣近  dissent, dissidence, heterodoxy, nonconformity
A: ♣反  dogma, conformity, orthodoxy 正教

Q:heretical  [hi'retikəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 异教的，异端的： departure from established beliefs or standards
A: ♣例  the belief that women should be allowed to have careers outside the home was once considered heretical 女人应该拥有自己的事业这一观点一度被认为是异端想法
A: ♣近  heterodox, nonconformist, unconventional, unorthodox
A: ♣反  conforming, conformist, conventional, orthodox 正统的

Q:hermetic  [hə:'metik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 深奥的： relating to or characterized by occultism or abstruseness
A: ♣例  wrote hermetic poetry 写晦涩难懂的诗歌
A: ♣近  abstruse, arcane, esoteric, recondite
A: ♣反  easily comprehended, shallow, superficial 容易理解的，肤浅的

Q:hesitance  ['hezitəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 犹豫，不情愿： the quality or state of being hesitant, reluctance
A: ♣例  sales figures for the month were up, as consumers began to overcome their hesitance about purchasing big-ticket items 月销售额有所上涨，因为消费者对于大件商品的购买由观望转向消费
A: ♣近  faltering, indecision, irresolution, vacillation, wavering, wobbling
A: ♣反  alacrity, impetuosity, inclination, willingness 冲动，乐意

Q:heterodox  ['hetərəudɔks]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 非正统的，异端的： holding unorthodox opinions or doctrines, not rigidly following established form, custom, or rules
A: ♣例  her heterodox approach to teaching science initially met with some resistance from her peers 她对于教学的一些非正统方法最开始受到了同辈的抵触
A: ♣近  dissenting, out-there, unconventional, unorthodox
A: ♣反  conforming, conventional, orthodox, regular, routine 正常的，正统的

Q:hew  [hju:]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 遵守： confirm, adhere, to hold to something firmly as if by adhesion
A: ♣例  hew to tradition 遵守传统
A: ♣近  adhere, cling, conform
A: ♠考法2  v. 支持： to give steadfast support to
A: ♣例  no longer was able to hew to the party line and so he switched political parties 不再赞同该党的纲领，他投奔了另一个党
A: ♣近  cling to, keep to, stand by, stick to
A: ♣反  defect from 脱离，叛变

Q:hidebound  ['haidbaund]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 死板的，极度保守的： tending to favor established ideas, conditions, or institutions
A: ♣例  the hidebound innkeeper refused to see the need for a Web site 死板的酒馆老板坚决不肯装宽带
A: ♣近  archconservative, brassbound, die-hard, old-fashioned, standpat, ultraconservative
A: ♣反  broad-minded, large-minded, liberal, nonconservative, nonconventional, nonorthodox, nontraditional, open-minded, progressive 进步的，开放包容的

Q:hideous  ['hidiəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 非常丑陋的： exceedingly ugly
A: ♣例  wearing a hideous Halloween mask that made the kids all jump with fright 戴着一个丑陋的万圣节面具把小孩子全都吓跑了
A: ♣近  homely, ill-favored, monstrous, uncomely, unsightly
A: ♣反  pulchritudinous, aesthetic, attractive, comely, gorgeous, handsome, knockout, ravishing, seemly, stunning, taking, well-favored 美丽的，有吸引力的
A: ♣派  hideousness 丑陋
A: ♣反  affinity 吸引力

Q:hie  [hai]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 匆匆忙忙： to go quickly, hasten
A: ♣例  we had best hie home before the rain gets worse 我们最好在雨下大之前赶快回家
A: ♣近  bustle, dash, hustle, scoot, scurry, scuttle, shoot, trot
A: ♣反  dawdle, crawl, creep, poke 闲荡，爬行

Q:hierarchical  [,haiə'rɑ:kikəl]

A: ♣例  the traditional hierarchical system of military organization 军队中传统的等级制度
A: ♣近  graded, graduated, ranked
A: ♣派  hierarchy n. 等级制度

Q:hike  [haik]

A: ♣例  hike rents 涨租金
A: ♣近  boost, elevate, heighten, hoist, upraise
A: ♣反  backset, drop, lower 倒退，下降

Q:hilarious  [hi'lεəriəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 非常好笑的： marked by or causing hilarity: extremely funny
A: ♣例  hilarious cartoons that the whole family can enjoy 适合全家观看的搞笑动画片
A: ♣近  hysterical, ludicrous, ridiculous, screaming, sidesplitting, uproarious
A: ♣反  humorless, lame, unamusing, uncomic, unfunny 不好笑的

Q:histrionic  [,histri'ɔnik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 戏剧的，演员的： of or relating to actors, acting, or the theater
A: ♣例  a penchant for dish throwing, door slamming, and other histrionic displays of temper 有倾向做出一些砸盘子、摔门和其他一些电视剧里的经典生气动作
A: ♣近  melodramatic, operatic, stagy, theatrical
A: ♣反  undramatic

Q:hive  [haiv]
A: ♠考法1  n. 忙碌之地： a place swarming with activity
A: ♣例  The house was a hive of activity as we prepared for the party. 我们筹备派对时，房子里很是熙熙攘攘。
A: ♠考法2  v. 储备，积累： to store up; accumulate

Q:hoard  [hɔ:d]
A: ♠考法1  v. 贮藏，秘藏： to keep hidden or private
A: ♣例  he's been hoarding empty yogurt containers all winter 他整个冬天都在攒空酸奶瓶
A: ♣近  cache, stash, stockpile, store, squirrel, stockpile
A: ♣反  lavish 挥霍

Q:hoary  ['hɔ:ri]

A: ♣例  hoary legends 上古的传说故事
A: ♣近  aged, antique, dateless, immemorial, antediluvian
A: ♣反  modern, new, recent 新的

Q:hoax  [həuks]
A: ♠考法1  n./v. 欺骗： to cause to believe what is untrue
A: ♣例  a skilled forger who hoaxed the art world into believing that the paintings were long-lost Vermeers 一个老道的骗子成功让艺术界相信那些画作是遗失多年的维米尔的真迹
A: ♣近  bamboozle, beguile, bluff, con, cozen, delude, dupe, fake out, gull, hoodwink, take in

Q:hobble  ['hɔbl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 跛行，蹒跚而行： to walk or move along haltingly or with difficulty
A: ♣例  She picked up her cane and hobbled across the room. 她拿起了一根手杖，一拐一拐地穿过了房间。
A: ♣近  falter, halt, limp, stagger, totter
A: ♣反  stride 大步走
A: ♠考法2  vt. 阻碍，妨碍： to hamper the action or progress of
A: ♣例  We were hobbled by the snowstorm from getting out to do some Christmas shopping. 暴雪阻碍了我们圣诞购物的计划。
A: ♣近  encumber, fetter, handicap, hamper, hinder, impede, inhibit, manacle, obstruct, shackle, stymie, trammel
A: ♣反  aid, assist, facilitate 帮助

Q:hodgepodge  ['hɔdʒpɔdʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 大杂烩： a mixture of dissimilar ingredients; a jumble
A: ♣例  a hodgepodge of styles 混搭风格 || the exhibit was a hodgepodge of mediocre art, bad art, and really bad art 整场展览就是中庸、烂和非常烂的艺术作品的大杂烩
A: ♣近  agglomeration, assortment, collage, medley, mishmash, pastiche, potpourri

Q:homage  ['hɔmidʒ]

A: ♣例  Homage to Catalonia 向加泰罗尼亚致敬
A: ♣近  commendation, eulogy, hymn, paean, panegyric, salutation, tribute, dithyramb
A: ♣反  disrespect 不尊敬

Q:homely  ['həumli]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 其貌不扬的，朴素简单的： not attractive or good-looking
A: ♣例  homely truth 朴素的真理
A: ♣近  hideous, unappealing, unattractive, uncomely, unsightly
A: ♣反  pulchritudinous, aesthetic, attractive, beautiful, comely, gorgeous, handsome, knockout, lovely, pretty, ravishing, seemly, sightly, stunning, taking, well-favored 美丽的

Q:homily  ['hɔmili]
A: ♠考法1  n. 冗长乏味的道德讲演或训诫： an idea or expression that has been used by many people
A: ♣例  a TV movie filled with the usual hokey homilies about people triumphing over life's adversities 一档说教性质的、充满了介绍逆境中的人们如何成就自我的电视节目
A: ♣近  banality, bromide, chestnut, cliché, groaner, platitude, shibboleth

Q:homogenize  [hɔ'mɔdʒənaiz]
A: ♠考法1  v. 使统一化： to make agree with a single established standard or model
A: ♣例  plans to homogenize the science curriculum in public high schools throughout the state 计划将全州的公立高中的课程安排统一化
A: ♣近  formalize, homogenize, normalize, regularize

Q:hone  [həun]
A: ♠考法1  v. 磨快： to sharpen or smooth with a whetstone
A: ♣例  honed the knife's blade to razor-like sharpness 把小刀磨得像剃刀一样锋利 || honed his crossword-puzzle skills by reading the dictionary 通过背字典把填词游戏的水平练得炉火纯青
A: ♣近  edge, grind, strop, whet
A: ♣反  blunt, dull 弄钝

Q:hoodwink  ['hudwiŋk]

A: ♣例  Don't let yourself be hoodwinked into buying things you don't need. 别被忽悠着去买用不着的东西。
A: ♣近  beguile, con, delude, dupe, fool, hoax, humbug
A: ♣反  disabuse 消除错误念头

Q:hortative  ['hɔ:tətiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 鼓励的： giving exhortation

Q:hovel  ['hɔvəl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 茅屋： a small, wretched, and often dirty house
A: ♣近  cabin, camp, hooch, hut, hutch, hutment, shanty

Q:hubris  ['hju:bris]
A: ♠考法1  n. 狂妄自大： exaggerated pride or self-confidence
A: ♣例  His failure was brought on by his hubris. 就是他的狂妄自大才导致了失败。
A: ♣反  humility 谦逊

Q:humble  ['hʌmbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 谦逊的： marked by meekness or modesty in behavior, attitude, or spirit; not arrogant or prideful
A: ♣例  a medical scientist who remained remarkably humble even after winning the Nobel Prize 获得诺贝尔奖之后仍然保持谦逊的医学家
A: ♣近  modest, unassuming, unpretentious, demure, down-to-earth
A: ♣反  arrogant, bumptious, conceited, egotistic, haughty, high-and-mighty, imperious, lordly, overweening, peremptory, pompous, presuming, presumptuous, pretentious, self-assertive, supercilious, superior, toplofty, uppish, uppity 傲慢的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 顺从的，谦卑的： showing, expressing, or offered in a spirit of humility or unseemly submissiveness
A: ♣例  please accept my humble thanks 请接受我的卑微的感谢
A: ♣近  base, humble, menial, servile, slavish

Q:humdrum  ['hʌmdrʌm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 千篇一律，单调： a tedious lack of variety
A: ♣例  She has been loathing the humdrum of daily life in a small town for a long time. 一直以来她很反感于小城镇里一成不变的生活。
A: ♣近  monotone, monotonousness, sameness
A: ♣反  diversity, variety 多样性
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无聊的，乏味的： lacking variety or excitement
A: ♣例  trapped in a humdrum but well-paid job 陷于无聊但是收入可观的工作之中
A: ♣近  arid, drab, dreary, drudging, jading, jejune, monochromatic, monotonous, pedestrian, ponderous, stale, stodgy, tedious, tiresome, wearisome
A: ♣反  absorbing, engaging, engrossing, gripping, interesting, intriguing, involving, riveting 令人感兴趣的

Q:humiliate  [hju:'milieit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 羞辱，使丧失尊严： to reduce to a lower position in one’s own eyes or others’ eyes
A: ♣例  No student feels humiliated for not having the “right” clothes because everyone is wearing a school uniform. 因为所有学生都统一穿着学校的校服，所以没有人会因为“不正确”的衣着而感觉尊严扫地。‖He humiliated me in front of my parents and I swear to retaliate. 他在我的父母面前让我难堪，我发誓要报复他。
A: ♣近  abase, chasten, cheapen, debase, degrade, demean, discredit, disgrace, dishonor, shame, sink, smirch
A: ♣反  aggrandize, canonize, deify, elevate, exalt 使崇高
A: ♣派  humiliation n. 羞辱，蒙羞

Q:humility  [hju:'miləti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 谦卑，谦逊： the absence of any feelings of being better than others
A: ♣例  Haughtiness invites disaster; humility receives benefit. 满招损，谦受益
A: ♣近  demureness, humbleness, lowliness, meekness, modesty
A: ♣反  arrogance, assumption, bumptiousness, hauteur, pomposity, presumption, superciliousness 傲慢，自大

Q:humor  ['hju:mə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 幽默，令人发笑的事物： something that is or is designed to be comical or amusing
A: ♣例  The speech is full of wit and humor. 演讲妙趣横生
A: ♣近  comedy, comic, drollery, drollness, funniness, hilariousness
A: ♣反  pathos 令人伤感的事物
A: ♠考法2  v. 迎合，迁就： to comply with the wishes or ideas of
A: ♣例  Parents need to know how to humor kids when they are upset. 父母需要知道当孩子烦躁的时候怎么哄孩子
A: ♣近  cater, gratify, indulge

Q:hurricane  ['hʌrikən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 飓风： a violent rotating storm or system of winds
A: ♣例  The hurricane struck the coast early today. 飓风今晨袭击了海岸
A: ♣近  storm, typhoon
A: ♣反  calm 风平浪静
A: ♠考法2  n. 飓风般的事物，引起动荡的事物： something resembling a hurricane especially in its turmoil
A: ♣例  economic news that unleashed a hurricane on the trading floor 在交易大厅掀起轩然大波的经济新闻
A: ♣近  disturbance, furor, pandemonium, tumult, turmoil, uproar

Q:husband  ['hʌzbənd]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 节俭，勤俭持家： to use sparingly or economically
A: ♣例  Husbanding precious resources was part of rural life. 节俭使用珍贵的资源就是农村生活的一部分
A: ♣近  budget, conserve, economize
A: ♣反  dissipate, lavish, prodigalize, squander, waste 挥霍，浪费
A: ♣派  husbandly adj. 节俭的；husbandry n. 节俭

Q:husk  [hʌsk]
A: ♠考法1  n.（果类或谷物的）外壳： a usually dry or membranous outer covering (as a pod or one composed of bracts) of various seeds and fruits (as barley and corn)
A: ♣例  a grey squirrel nibbling on a peanut husk 一个啃着花生壳的灰松鼠
A: ♣近  bark, chaff, hull, shell
A: ♣反  core, kernel 核
A: ♠考法2  v. 剥去： to remove the natural covering of
A: ♣例  the tedious task of husking coconuts 无聊的任务——剥花生
A: ♣近  bark, flay, hull, shell, shuck, skin

Q:husky  ['hʌski]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （尤指声音）沙哑的，粗糙的： hoarse or rough in quality
A: ♣例  a voice husky with emotion 富有感情的沙哑声音
A: ♣近  coarse, grating, gravelly, harsh, rasping, rusty, scratchy, throaty
A: ♣反  mellifluous （声音）甜蜜的，甜美的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 高大威猛的： big and muscular
A: ♣例  a very husky young man, built like a football player 一个体格像橄榄球运动员一样的高大的男孩
A: ♣近  beefy, burly, hefty, muscular, powerful, strapping, rugged
A: ♣反  dwarf 矮小的

Q:hybrid  ['haibrid]
A: ♠考法1  n. 杂交品种，混合品种： something of mixed origin or composition
A: ♣例  a hybrid of medieval and Renaissance styles 中世纪和文艺复兴的混搭风
A: ♣近  amalgam, bastard, compound, mixture, mule
A: ♠考法2  adj. 杂交的： being offspring produced by parents of different races, breeds, species, or genera
A: ♣例  a hybrid rose called “American Beauty” 一种被称为“美国丽人”的杂交玫瑰
A: ♣近  crossbred, mongrel
A: ♣反  purebred 纯种的

Q:hymn  [him]
A: ♠考法1  n. 赞歌，赞美诗： a song of praise or joy
A: ♣例  They sang a hymn of praise to God. 他们唱赞歌赞美上帝
A: ♣近  eulogy, homage, hymn, ode, paean, panegyric, psalm, salutation, tribute
A: ♣反  dirge, elegy 哀诗，挽歌
A: ♠考法2  v. 赞美： to proclaim the glory of
A: ♣例  During the honeymoon following the inauguration, newspaper articles seemed to hymn the president's every move. 在上任后的“蜜月期”之中，报纸新闻似乎在赞美总统的每一项措施
A: ♣近  bless, carol, celebrate, emblazon, exalt, extol, glorify, laud, magnify, resound
A: ♣反  blame, censure, reprehend, reprobate 责难，职责

Q:hyperbole  [hai'pə:bəli]
A: ♠考法1  n. 夸张： a figure of speech in which exaggeration is used for emphasis or effect
A: ♣例  The debate was carried on with increasing rhetorical hyperbole. 随着辩论的进行，双方修辞当中的夸张越来越多
A: ♣近  coloring, embellishment, embroidering, exaggeration, magnification, overstatement
A: ♣反  understatement 有节制的陈述

Q:hypnotic  [hip'nɔtik]
A: ♠考法1  adj.催眠的： tending to cause sleep
A: ♣例  Her eyes soon grew heavy from the hypnotic rhythm of the train's wheels. 伴随着催眠的铁轨声，她很快就有了睡意
A: ♣近  drowsy, narcotic, opiate, sleepy, slumberous, soporific
A: ♣反  stimulating 刺激性的；refreshing 使人精神焕发的

Q:hypocritical  [,hipə'kritikl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 虚伪的： not being or expressing what one appears to be or express
A: ♣例  It's hypocritical to say mean things behind someone's back, and then to act nice when you want something from her. 这种在背后说别人坏话、而有求于人时又装出另一副样子的人就是虚伪
A: ♣近  artificial, backhanded, feigned, mealy-mouthed, phony, pretended, unctuous
A: ♣反  artless, candid, genuine, honest, sincere, undesigning, unfeigned 真诚的，诚实的
A: ♣派  hypocrite n. 虚伪的人，伪君子

Q:hypothetical  [,haipəu'θetikəl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 假设，前提条件： something taken as being true or factual and used as a starting point for a course of action or reasoning
A: ♣例  He believes that predictions of the extinction of certain species as the result of global warming are based upon too many hypotheticals. 他认为所谓全球变暖会导致某些物种灭绝的说法基于过多的假设。
A: ♣近  assumption, given, postulate, premise, presumption, presupposition, supposition
A: ♣反  conclusion, consequence, deduction, induction, inference 结论
A: ♠考法2  adj. 假定的： existing only as an assumption or speculation
A: ♣例  We talked about what we would do in various hypothetical emergencies. 我们讨论了在假定的各种紧急情况下的对策。
A: ♣近  conjectural, speculative, supposed, suppositional
A: ♣反  actual, factual, real 事实的

Q:iconoclast  [ai'kɔnəuklæst]
A: ♠考法1  n. 特立独行的人： a person who does not conform to generally accepted standards or customs
A: ♣例  He was an iconoclast who refused to be bound by tradition. 他是个不愿被传统所束缚的叛逆者
A: ♣近  bohemian, deviant, heretic, maverick, non-conformer
A: ♣反  conformer, conformist 循规蹈矩的人
A: ♣派  iconoclastic adj. 特立独行的

Q:idiosyncrasy  [,idiə'siŋkrəsi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 独特而奇怪的习惯： an odd or peculiar habit
A: ♣例  His only idiosyncrasy is his inveterate wearing of sneakers, even with business suits. 他唯一的怪癖就是无时无刻都穿着运动鞋——哪怕身上是西装革履。
A: ♣近  crotchet, eccentricity, individualism, mannerism, oddity, peculiarity, quirk, singularity, trick, twist
A: ♣反  conformity, sameness 合乎（礼节等），千篇一律

Q:idle  ['aidl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 闲置的，未使用的： not turned to normal or appropriate use
A: ♣例  The car was idle for two weeks while they went on vacation. 因为他们出去旅行了，他们的车闲置了两周。
A: ♣近  dead, dormant, fallow, free, inert, inoperative, latent, unused, vacant
A: ♣反  active, alive, employed, functioning, operative, running, working 使用中的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 懒散的： shiftless, lazy
A: ♣例  an idle employee who always seems to be either on break or at lunch 这个懒散的员工似乎不是在休息就是在吃饭
A: ♣近  indolent, lazy, shiftless, slothful
A: ♣反  diligent, industrious 勤奋的
A: ♠考法3  vi. 懒散度日，无所事事： to pass (time) without working or while avoiding work
A: ♣例  idle the afternoon away 打发下午的时光
A: ♣近  dally, dillydally, drone, laze, loaf, loll, lounge
A: ♣反  drudge, grind, hustle, labor, moil, plod, slave, sweat, toil, travail, work （辛苦地）干活，工作
A: ♣派  idlly adv. 懒散地

Q:idolatrize  [ai'dɔlətraiz]
A: ♠考法1  v.（通常盲目）崇拜： admires intensely and often blindly
A: ♣例  Some teenagers idolatrized Hitler more than their own parents. 曾经有一些青少年崇拜希特勒超过自己的父母
A: ♣近  adore, adulate, canonize, deify, dote, worship
A: ♣反  abhor, abominate, detest, dislike, hate, loathe 痛恨，憎恶
A: ♣派  idolatry n. 崇拜

Q:idyll  ['idil]
A: ♠考法1  n. 无忧无虑的生活： a carefree episode or experience
A: ♣例  a summer idyll on the coast of the Mediterranean 地中海岸的悠闲夏日
A: ♣近  frisk, frolic, gambol, revel, lark

Q:ignite  [iɡ'nait]
A: ♠考法1  vt.点燃： to cause to burn; to set fire to
A: ♣例  The bombs ignited a fire which destroyed some 60 houses. 炸弹引发的大火摧毁了大约60间房屋
A: ♣近  enkindle, fire, inflame, kindle, light, torch
A: ♣反  douse, extinguish, quench, put out 熄灭
A: ♠考法2  vt. 激起，唤起（感情等）： to arouse the passions of
A: ♣例  The insults ignited my anger. 那些侮辱让我倍感愤怒
A: ♣近  arouse, incite, instigate, pique, spark, stimulate, stir
A: ♣反  appease, assuage, calm, conciliate, mollify, pacify, placate, propitiate, soothe 平息怒火，安抚

Q:ignominy  ['iɡnəmini]
A: ♠考法1  n. 耻辱： the state of having lost the esteem of others
A: ♣例  He spent the remainder of his life in ignominy after being involved in a bribery scandal. 因为卷入了受贿丑闻当中，他在耻辱中度过余生
A: ♣近  discredit, disesteem, dishonor, disrepute, infamy, obloquy, odium, opprobrium, reproach, shame
A: ♣反  glory, honor 荣耀；esteem, respect 敬意
A: ♣派  ignominious adj. 可鄙的

Q:ill-bred  ['il'bred]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 没有教养的，没有礼貌的： badly brought up or showing bad upbringing: impolite
A: ♣例  Only an ill-bred, conceited person would demand that everyone cater to their whims. 只有一个没有教养、狂妄自大的人才会要求所有人都去迎合他的想法。
A: ♣近  discourteous, disrespectful, impertinent, impolite, inconsiderate, rude, uncivil, ungracious, unmannerly
A: ♣反  civil, considerate, courteous, genteel, gracious, mannerly, polite, urbane, well-bred 有礼貌的，得体的

Q:illiteracy  [i'litərəsi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 文盲： the condition of being unable to read and write
A: ♣例  a nationwide campaign against illiteracy 全国扫盲运动
A: ♣近  ignorance
A: ♣反  learning, literacy 受过教育
A: ♣派  illiterate adj. 不识字的

Q:illuminate  [i'lju:mineit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 照明： to make luminous or shining
A: ♣例  to illuminate with a spotlight 用聚光灯照亮
A: ♣近  bathe, beacon, emblaze, illume, illumine, irradiate, lighten
A: ♣反  blacken, darken, obfuscate 使黯淡，使昏暗
A: ♠考法2  vt. 阐明： to make plain or understandable
A: ♣例  Roosevelt′s New Deal illuminates what the role of government is in Keynesian Economics. 罗斯福新政阐明了在凯恩斯主义中政府的作用
A: ♣近  clarify, clear, construe, demonstrate, demystify, elucidate, explicate, expound, illustrate, interpret
A: ♣反  obscure 使费解
A: ♠考法3  vt. 启迪，启发： to provide (someone) with moral or spiritual understanding
A: ♣例  how man is illuminated by a higher spirit 人们是如何被更高境界的思想开化的
A: ♣近  edify, educate, enlighten, inspire, nurture
A: ♣反  confuse, perplex, puzzle 使困惑
A: ♣派  illumination n. 照明；启迪

Q:illuminati  [i,lu:mi'nɑ:ti:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 智者： persons who claim to be unusually enlightened
A: ♣近  clerisy, intellectual, intelligentsia, literati
A: ♣反  fool, dolt, dullard, idiot, simpleton 傻子
A: ♠考法2  n. 精英： individuals carefully selected as being the best of a class
A: ♣例  a book launching party to which only New York's cultural illuminati were invited 一个只邀请了纽约上层文化精英的新书发布会
A: ♣近  aristocracy, elite, upper crust

Q:illusory  [i'lju:səri]
