A: ♣例  the illusory definition of nationhood 国家的虚幻定义
A: ♣近  chimerical, fanciful, fantastic, fictional, fictitious, imaginary, suppositious, supposititious, unreal
A: ♣反  factual 事实的
A: ♣派  illusion n. 幻觉

Q:illustrious  [i'lʌstriəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 著名的，杰出的： well known and very distinguished
A: ♣例  the most illustrious scientists of the century 本世纪最为杰出的科学家
A: ♣近  distinguished, luminous, noble, notable, noteworthy, outstanding, preeminent, prestigious, redoubtable, signal
A: ♣反  average, inferior, mediocre 平凡的，较差的

Q:imbibe  [im'baib]
A: ♠考法1  v. 喝水，摄取水分： to take in (something liquid) through small openings
A: ♣例  Plants can imbibe water through their roots. 植物可以通过它们的根摄取水分
A: ♣近  drink, guzzle, hoist, quaff, sip, sponge
A: ♣反  urinate 排尿

Q:imbroglio  [im'brəuljəu]
A: ♠考法1  n. 困境，复杂的局面： an intricate or complicated situation
A: ♣例  What investor would willingly become involved in this imbroglio? 怎样的投资者才会像这样明知山有虎，偏向虎山行呢？
A: ♣近  complexity, complication, embarrassment, entanglement, involvement, misunderstanding, quandary
A: ♠考法2  n. 纷争： an often noisy or angry expression of differing opinions
A: ♣例  an imbroglio involving some big names in the entertainment industry 一场涉及娱乐圈数位明星的纷争
A: ♣近  altercation, controversy, disagreement, dispute, fight, quarrel, squabble, wrangle
A: ♣反  harmony 和谐

Q:imitation  [,imi'teiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 仿制品： something that is made to look exactly like something else
A: ♣例  usually wore imitations of her costly jewels 通常只戴她那些贵重珠宝的复刻品
A: ♣近  clone, copy, dupe, duplication, facsimile, mock, reduplication, replica, replication, reproduction
A: ♣反  archetype, original, prototype 原型
A: ♣派  imitating adj. 仿制的

Q:immaculate  [i'mækjulət]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 干净的，纯净的： free from dirt or stain; free from any trace of the coarse or indecent
A: ♣例  an immaculate soul 一个纯净的灵魂
A: ♣近  antiseptic, chaste, clean, decent, modest, pristine, pure, spotless, stainless, virgin
A: ♣反  coarse, indecent, obscene, vulgar 粗俗的,下流的；besmirched, dirty, filthy, foul, spotted, stained, sullied 有污点的，不干净的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 完美的，没有任何错误的： being entirely without fault or flaw
A: ♣例  an immaculate rendering of the Queen of the Night ’s aria （《魔笛》中）夜后咏叹调的完美演绎
A: ♣近  absolute, faultless, flawless, impeccable, indefectible, irreproachable, perfect, seamless, unblemished
A: ♣反  amiss, defective, faulty, flawed, imperfect 有错误的，有误差的

Q:immanent  ['imənənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 内在的： being a part of the innermost nature of a person or thing
A: ♣例  Beauty is not something imposed but something immanent. 美丽是内在的品格而非外加的东西
A: ♣近  constitutional, essential, inborn, inbred, indigenous, ingrained, innate, integral, intrinsic, natural
A: ♣反  adventitious, extrinsic, extraneous 外在的，非本源的

Q:immaterial  [,imə'tiəriəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 非实体的： not composed of matter
A: ♣例  It is only possible to study immaterial forces like gravity by observing their effects on the physical world. 要研究那些非实体的作用力——例如万有引力，只能观察它们对于现实世界的影响
A: ♣近  ethereal, formless, incorporeal, insubstantial, nonmaterial, spiritual
A: ♣反  bodily, corporeal, material, physical, substantial 实体的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无关的，不重要的： of no importance or relevance
A: ♣例  While undoubtedly upsetting, that story is immaterial to the question of why you are late. 尽管那个故事的确很让人遗憾，但是和你为什么迟到没有半点关系
A: ♣近  extraneous, impertinent, inapplicable, inapposite, irrelevant
A: ♣反  applicable, apposite, apropos, germane, pertinent, relevant 相关的；crucial, important, significant 重要的

Q:immature  [,imə'tjuə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 未完全发展的，未发育成熟的： lacking complete growth, differentiation, or development
A: ♣例  immature frogs are called “tadpoles” 为发育成熟的青蛙被称为“蝌蚪”
A: ♣近  adolescent, juvenile, youngish, youthful
A: ♠考法2  adj. （思维、举止）不够成熟的： lacking in adult experience or maturity
A: ♣例  Many high school students are still too immature to foresee the consequences of their actions. 很多高中生还是不够成熟，不能意识到他们的行为所带来的后果
A: ♣近  green, inexperienced, puerile, raw, unfledged, unripe
A: ♣反  adult, experienced, mature, ripe 成年的，成熟的

Q:immemorial  [,imi'mɔ:riəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 古老的： dating or surviving from the distant past
A: ♣例  a modern version of an immemorial myth 一个远古传说的现代版本
A: ♣近  aged, age-old, antediluvian, antique, dateless, hoary, old, venerable
A: ♣反  contemporary, modern 当代的，现代的；recent 近来的

Q:immune  [i'mju:n]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不易被感染的，有免疫力的： of, relating to, or having resistance to infection
A: ♣例  The blood test will tell whether you are immune to the disease. 验血可以判断你是否对这种疾病免疫
A: ♣近  resistant
A: ♣反  susceptible, vulnerable 易感染的，易受攻击的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不受影响的： not affected by a given influence
A: ♣例  immune to persuasion 不听劝
A: ♣近  insusceptible, unaffected, unresponsive
A: ♣反  ductile, pliable, pliant, yielding 易受影响的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 不受约束的： not subject to an obligation imposed on others
A: ♣例  immune from taxation 免税
A: ♣近  exempt, free
A: ♣反  liable, responsible 负有责任的
A: ♣派  immunity n. 免疫性

Q:immure  [i'mjuə]
A: ♠考法1  v. 监禁，禁闭： to confine within or as if within walls
A: ♣例  immure oneself for GRE 闭门苦读GRE
A: ♣近  bastille, confine, constrain, incarcerate, intern, jail, imprison
A: ♣反  discharge, release释放；enfranchise, free, liberate 解放

Q:immutable  [i'mju:təbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不可变的： not capable of changing or being changed
A: ♣例  One of the immutable laws of television is that low ratings inevitably lead to cancellation. 电视行业中一个不变的原则就是：低收视率的节目必然会被撤掉
A: ♣近  constant, fixed, inalterable, inflexible, invariable, unalterable, unchangeable
A: ♣反  alterable, changeable, elastic, flexible, mutable, variable 可变的
A: ♣派  immutability n. 不变性

Q:impassive  [im'pæsiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 冷漠的，无感情的： giving no sign of feeling or emotion
A: ♣例  She remained impassive as the officers informed her of her son's death. 她面不改色地听着警官宣读她儿子的死讯
A: ♣近  affectless, apathetic, cold-blooded, deadpan, emotionless, numb, phlegmatic, stoic, undemonstrative
A: ♣反  demonstrative, emotional, fervent, fervid, impassioned, passionate, vehement充满感情的

Q:impeccable  [im'pekəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无罪的： free from sin, guilt or blame
A: ♣例  the belief that there can be no such thing as an impeccable soul 不相信存在无罪的灵魂
A: ♣近  blameless, clear, guiltless, inculpable, pure, sinless
A: ♣反  guilty, sinful 有罪的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无瑕的，无可挑剔的： free from fault or blame
A: ♣例  She had impeccable taste in clothes. 她有着无可挑剔的穿衣品味
A: ♣近  absolute, faultless, flawless, immaculate, indefectible, irreproachable, perfect, seamless, unblemished
A: ♣反  amiss, defective, faulty, flawed, imperfect 有错误的，有误差的

Q:impecunious  [,impi'kju:njəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 贫穷的： having very little or no money
A: ♣例  They were so impecunious that they couldn't afford to give one another even token Christmas gifts. 他们穷到了连象征性的圣诞礼物都互送不起的地步
A: ♣近  beggared, destitute, impoverished, indigent, necessitous, needy, penniless, penurious, threadbare
A: ♣反  affluent, flush, opulent, rich, wealthy 富有的

Q:impede  [im'pi:d]
A: ♠考法1  v. 妨碍，阻碍： to interfere with or slow the progress of
A: ♣例  Storms at sea impeded our expedition. 海上的风暴阻碍了我们的远征
A: ♣近  clog, embarrass, encumber, fetter, hinder, inhibit, obstruct, retard, shackle, stymie, trammel
A: ♣反  aid, assist, facilitate, help 促进，帮助
A: ♣派  impediment n. 障碍，阻碍

Q:impending  [im'pendiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 即将发生的： being soon to appear or take place
A: ♣例  an impending celebration of the 100th anniversary of the college's founding 即将来临的百年校庆
A: ♣近  approaching, coming, imminent, nearing, pending, proximate, upcoming, around the corner
A: ♣反  late, recent 最近发生的；distant, remote 遥远的

Q:impenetrable  [im'penitrəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不可渗透的，不可穿透的： impossible to get through or into
A: ♣例  The ancient temple was surrounded by vast stretches of impenetrable jungle. 包围着古老的神庙的是密不透风的灌木丛
A: ♣近  impassable, impermeable, impervious, impregnable
A: ♣反  passable, penetrable, permeable, pervious 可通过的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 难以理解的： incapable of being comprehended
A: ♣例  The textbook's language is completely impenetrable, at least to me. 至少在我看来，这个教材就是天书
A: ♣近  arcane, cryptic, enigmatic, incomprehensible, inscrutable, unfathomable, ungraspable, unintelligible
A: ♣反  fathomable, intelligible, understandable 可以理解的

Q:impenitent  [im'penitənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不悔悟的： not feeling or expressing humble or regretful pain or sorrow for sins or offenses
A: ♣例  remain impenitent about her criminal past 对她过去所犯罪行执迷不悟
A: ♣近  remorseless, regretless, shameless, unashamed, unrepentant
A: ♣反  contrite, regretful, remorseful, rueful, penitent 感到悔恨的

Q:imperative  [im'perətiv]
A: ♠考法1  n. 命令： a statement of what to do that must be obeyed by those concerned
A: ♣例  a secretary of defense who was fond of issuing harshly worded imperatives 一个很喜欢发布措辞严厉的命令的国防部长
A: ♣近  command, decree, dictate, direction, directive, instruction, order, word
A: ♠考法2  adj. 命令的，强制性的：forcing one's compliance or participation by or as if by law
A: ♣例  requests that grew more and more imperative 命令性越来越强的请求
A: ♣近  compulsory, forced, involuntary, obligatory, peremptory, required
A: ♣反  optional 可选择的；voluntary 志愿性的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 迫切的： needing immediate attention
A: ♣例  an imperative need for medical supplies in the earthquake-ravaged country 地震灾区国家对于医疗物资的迫切需求
A: ♣近  clamant, compelling, critical, crying, emergent, exigent, imperious, importunate, pressing, urgent
A: ♣反  noncritical, unimportant 不重要的
A: ♠考法4  adj. 必要的： impossible to do without
A: ♣例  Proper equipment is imperative for the success of this chemical experiment. 合适的仪器是这个化学实验成功必不可少的条件
A: ♣近  indispensable, necessary, necessitous, requisite, vital
A: ♣反  dispensable, inessential, needless, unneces

Q:imperial  [im'piəriəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 帝国的，帝王的： of, relating to, or suggestive of an empire or a sovereign, especially an emperor or empress
A: ♣例  Imperial College London 帝国理工学院
A: ♣近  kingly, queenly, regal, royal
A: ♠考法2  adj. 巨大的，令人惊叹的： large and impressive in size, grandeur, extent, or conception
A: ♣例  envisioned an imperial city that would rival the capitals of Europe for beauty and magnificence 幻想着一个比欧洲各国首都更为动人和壮丽的巨大城市
A: ♣近  august, epic, glorious, grand, imposing, magnificent, monumental, noble, splendid
A: ♣反  common, humble, inferior, low 低下的，平凡的

Q:imperious  [im'piəriəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 爱发号施令的： fond of ordering people around
A: ♣例  an imperious little boy who liked to tell the other scouts what to do 一个爱发号施令的小男孩，总是喜欢指挥别的童子军做事
A: ♣近  authoritarian, autocratic, despotic, dictatorial, domineering, masterful, tyrannical
A: ♠考法2  adj. 傲慢的，专横的： arrogantly domineering or overbearing
A: ♣例  an imperious movie star who thinks she's some sort of goddess 一个把自己当成某种女神的傲慢的影星
A: ♣近  arrogant, bumptious, haughty, lofty, lordly, peremptory, pompous, presumptuous, supercilious, superior
A: ♣反  humble, lowly, modest 谦逊的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 迫切的： intensely compelling
A: ♣例  As war casualties mounted, the need for trained nurses became imperious. 随着战争伤亡人数的攀升，对于受训护士的需求变得愈发迫切
A: ♣近  clamant, compelling, critical, crying, dire, emergent, exigent, imperative, importunate, pressing, urgent
A: ♣反  noncritical, unimportant 不重要的

Q:imperishable  [im'periʃəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不能被摧毁的： impossible to destroy; not subject to decay
A: ♣例  Energy is imperishable. 能量本身是不能被毁灭的。
A: ♣近  inextinguishable
A: ♣反  destructible, extinguishable, perishable 可被毁灭的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不朽的，永恒的： enduring or occurring forever
A: ♣例  My memories are within me, imperishable. 我的回忆已经和我融为一体，不可改变。
A: ♣近  ageless, continuing, eternal, everlasting, immortal, lasting, perennial, perpetual, timeless, undying
A: ♣反  emphemeral, evanescent, fleeting, transient, transitory 稍纵即逝的

Q:impertinent  [im'pə:tinənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无关紧要的： not having a clear decisive relevance to the matter in hand
A: ♣例  Your résumé needlessly lists extracurricular experiences that are impertinent to the PhD program for which you are applying. 你的简历里列出的一些课外活动和你申请的博士项目是毫不相关的
A: ♣近  extraneous, immaterial, inapplicable, inapposite, irrelevant
A: ♣反  germane, pertinent, relevant 相关的；crucial, important, significant 重要的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 粗鲁无礼的，大胆的： given to or characterized by insolent rudeness
A: ♣例  I don't like strangers who ask impertinent questions. 我很讨厌那些问无礼问题的陌生人
A: ♣近  audacious, bold, brash, brassbound, brassy, brazen, impudent, insolent
A: ♣反  meek, mousy, retiring, shy, timid 内敛的，胆小的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 不守礼节的，不为他人着想的： showing a lack of manners or consideration for others
A: ♣例  impertinent salesmen who telephone people during the dinner hour 在就餐时间打电话骚扰别人的无礼销售员
A: ♣近  discourteous, disrespectful, inconsiderate, rude, thoughtless
A: ♣反  civil, courteous, genteel, gracious, mannerly, polite 有礼貌的；considerate 为他人着想的

Q:imperturbable  [,impə'tə:bəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj.沉着冷静的，淡定的： marked by extreme calm, impassivity, and steadiness
A: ♣例  The chef was absolutely imperturbable—even when the kitchen caught on fire. 这个厨师可谓淡定到了极致——他连厨房着火的时候都依然沉着
A: ♣近  collected, composed, cool, disimpassioned, nonchalant, unflappable, unruffled
A: ♣反  choleric, touchy 暴躁的，易怒的

Q:impervious  [im'pə:viəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不可渗透的，不可穿透的： not allowing entrance or passage
A: ♣例  The material for this coat is supposed to be impervious to rain. 这件大衣的材料应该是能防雨的
A: ♣近  impassable, impenetrable, impermeable, impregnable
A: ♣反  passable, penetrable, permeable, pervious 可渗透的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不能被破坏的： not capable of being damaged or harmed
A: ♣例  a carpet impervious to rough treatment 耐用的地毯
A: ♣近  bulletproof, imperishable, indestructible, inextinguishable, invulnerable
A: ♣反  delicate, sensitive, vulnerable 脆弱的，敏感的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 不为所动的： not capable of being affected or disturbed
A: ♣例  These sailors are impervious to fear. 这些水手无所畏惧
A: ♣近  immune, insusceptible, unaffected, unresponsive
A: ♣反  ductile, pliable, pliant, yielding 易受影响的

Q:impetuous  [im'petjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 冲动的，性急的，轻率的： marked by impulsive vehemence or passion
A: ♣例  He is young and impetuous. 他年轻易冲动
A: ♣近  ardent, hasty, headlong, impassioned, impulsive, passionate, rash, vehement
A: ♣反  cautious, circumspect, wary 谨慎的，小心的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 剧烈的，猛烈的： marked by force and violence of movement or action
A: ♣例  an impetuous wind 猛烈的风
A: ♣近  abrupt, hasty, hurried, precipitate, precipitous, rushing, sudden, violent
A: ♣反  calm, halcyon, placid, quiet 风平浪静的
A: ♣派  impetus n. 推动力

Q:impious  ['impiəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj.不敬神的： lacking reverence for holy or sacred matters
A: ♣例  made impious remarks about the church 对教会做出不敬的评论
A: ♣近  blasphemous, irreverent, profane, sacrilegious
A: ♣反  pious 虔诚的；reverent 敬神的
A: ♣派  impiety n. （对神的）不敬

Q:implacable  [im'plækəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 固执的： sticking to an opinion, purpose, or course of action in spite of reason, arguments, or persuasion
A: ♣近  adamant, dogged, headstrong, intransigent, mulish, obdurate, pertinacious, stubborn, unyielding
A: ♣反  acquiescent 倾向于默认的；compliant, flexible, pliable, pliant, yielding 易受影响的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无法平息的： not capable of being appeased, significantly changed, or mitigated
A: ♣例  an implacable enemy 无法与之和解的敌人
A: ♣近  determined, grim, relentless, unappeasable
A: ♣反  placable 可平息的，可缓和的

Q:implement  ['implimənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 工具： a device used in the performance of a task
A: ♣例  gardening implements such as hoes, spades, and pruners 诸如锄头、铲子和修枝剪一类的园艺工具
A: ♣近  apparatus, device, instrument, tool, utensil
A: ♠考法2  v. 执行，实施： to put into practical effect; carry out
A: ♣例  implement the new online application procedures 实行新的网申程序
A: ♣近  administer, apply, effect, enforce, execute, invoke, perform
A: ♣反  cancel, repeal, rescind, revoke 撤销
A: ♣派  implementation n. 执行，履行

Q:implicit  [im'plisit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不言而喻的，心照不宣的： capable of being understood from something else though unexpressed
A: ♣例  The implicit agreement among members of the outing club is that everyone pays his or her own way on all trips. 野外俱乐部成员之间一条心照不宣的约定就是：沿途所有开销都AA。
A: ♣近  implied, unexpressed, unspoken, unvoiced, wordless
A: ♣反  explicit, expressed, spoken, stated, voiced 明确声明的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无疑问的，无保留的： being without doubt or reserve
A: ♣例  Members of the expedition must have implicit trust in their leaders. 远征的队员必须百分之百地信任他们的领队。
A: ♣近  assured, clear, confident, doubtless, positive, sanguine, sure
A: ♣反  doubtful, dubious, uncertain, unsure 不确定的，存有疑惑的

Q:implode  [im'pləud]
A: ♠考法1  v. 剧烈收缩，坍缩，内爆： to collapse inward violently
A: ♣例  The flask imploded during the vacuum distilling. 做低压蒸馏的时候烧瓶发生了内爆
A: ♣近  buckle, founder, tumble, yield
A: ♣反  explode 外爆，爆炸

Q:importune  [im'pɔ:tju:n]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 恳求，迫切请求： to make a request to (someone) in an earnest or urgent manner
A: ♣例  beggars importuning passers-by 在恳求着过路人的乞丐
A: ♣近  appeal,beseech, besiege, conjure, entreat, impetrate, implore, petition, plead, pray, solicit, supplicate
A: ♣反  demand 要求，强求

Q:imposing  [im'pəuziŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 宏伟壮丽的： impressive in size, bearing, dignity, or grandeur
A: ♣例  The corporation's imposing headquarters were designed by one of the nation's cutting-edge architects. 这家公司宏伟壮丽的总部是由该国最优秀的建筑师设计的
A: ♣近  august, epic, glorious, grand, imperial, magnificent, monumental, noble, splendid
A: ♣反  common, humble, inferior, low 低下的，平凡的

Q:imposter  [im'pɔstə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 冒名顶替者，骗子： one that assumes false identity or title for the purpose of deception
A: ♣例  The man who claimed to be my townsman turned out to be an impostor. 那个自称是我老乡的人结果是个骗子。
A: ♣近  charlatan, fake, fraud, hoaxer, humbug, mountebank, phony, pretender, quack, quacksalver, ringer, sham

Q:impostor  [im'pɔstə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 冒充者： one that assumes false identity or title for the purpose of deception
A: ♣例  The man who claimed to be a prince turned out to be an impostor. 那个自称是王子的人原来是冒充的
A: ♣近  charlatan, fake, fraud, hoaxer, mountebank, phony, pretender, quack, sham

Q:impotent  ['impətənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无生育能力的： unable to produce fruit or offspring
A: ♣例  Most mules are impotent. 绝大多数的骡子都无法生育
A: ♣近  barren, fruitless, infertile, unfruitful
A: ♣反  fecund, fertile, fruitful, productive 高产的，硕果累累的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无力的，无能的： lacking in power, strength, or vigor
A: ♣例  an impotent ruler who was just a figurehead 一个无能的傀儡统治者
A: ♣近  hamstrung, handcuffed, helpless, impuissant, paralyzed, weak
A: ♣反  mighty, potent, powerful, puissant, strong 强大的，有能力的

Q:imprecise  [,impri'sais]

A: ♣例  incomplete and imprecise satellite data 既不完整又不精确的卫星数据
A: ♣近  approximate, inaccurate, loose, squishy
A: ♣反  accurate, exact, precise, veracious 精确的，准确的
A: ♣派  imprecision n. 不准确，不精确

Q:impromptu  [im'prɔmptju:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 即席的表演： something, such as a speech, that is made or done extemporaneously
A: ♣近  improvisation, extemporization
A: ♠考法2  adj. 即席的，即兴的：composedwithout previous preparation
A: ♣例  Our dinner guest thanked us with an impromptu song. 客人们即兴高歌一首以表达谢意
A: ♣近  ad-lib, extemporary, improvised, offhand, unplanned, unpremeditated, unprepared, unrehearsed
A: ♣反  considered, planned, premeditated, prepared, rehearsed 事先有所准备的

Q:improvise  ['imprəvaiz]
A: ♠考法1  v. 即兴而作： to invent, compose, or perform with little or no preparation
A: ♣例  Since the award was a complete surprise, I improvised an acceptance speech. 因为那个奖项完全是个惊喜，所以我即兴发表了一个获奖演说
A: ♣近  ad-lib, extemporize
A: ♣反  plan, premeditate 计划，预先考虑

Q:imprudent  [im'pru:dənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不明智的： lacking discretion, wisdom, or good judgment
A: ♣例  an imprudent investment ha made many years ago 他许多年前做的一笔不明智的投资
A: ♣近  impolitic, inadvisable, indelicate, injudicious, tactless, undiplomatic, unwise
A: ♣反  advisable, politic, prudent, tactical, wise 明智的

Q:impudent  ['impjudənt]

A: ♣例  Some children were well behaved, while others were impudent. 一些孩子表现得很得体，另一些则很无礼
A: ♣近  audacious, barefaced, bold, brash, brazen, impertinent, insolent, shameless
A: ♣反  courteous, genteel, mannerly, polite, proper 举止得体的
A: ♣派  impudencen. 放肆无礼

Q:impugn  [im'pju:n]

A: ♣例  impugn a political opponent's character 就政治对手的人品发难
A: ♣近  attack, assail, contradict, contravene, cross, disaffirm, deny, gainsay, negate, negative, traverse
A: ♣反  advocate, back, support, uphold 支持；authenticate 证实，证明

Q:impuissance  [im'pju:isəns]

A: ♣近  impotence, powerlessness, weakness
A: ♣反  clout, potency, power, puissance 权势
A: ♣派  impuissant adj. 无权无势的，无能的

Q:impunity  [im'pju:nəti]

A: ♣例  She mistakenly believed that she could insult people with impunity. 她错误地认为她可以肆无忌惮地羞辱他人。
A: ♣近  exemption, immunity
A: ♣反  liability 责任

Q:inadvertent  [,inəd'və:tənt]

A: ♣例  an inadvertent encounter with a rattlesnake 偶遇响尾蛇
A: ♣近  casual, fluky, incidental, unintentional, unplanned, unpremeditated, unwitting
A: ♣反  calculated, deliberate, intended, intentional, planned, premeditated 有计划的，有预谋的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 疏忽的，不留意的： marked by unintentional lack of care
A: ♣例  The military has said it was an inadvertent error. 军方表示这是个疏忽大意的错误
A: ♣近  careless, feckless, heedless, irreflective, thoughtless, uncaring
A: ♣反  advertent, careful, heedful, mindful 留意的，小心的

Q:inalienable  [in'eiljənəbl]

A: ♣反  alienable 可与让的

A: ♣近  empty, insubstantial, pointless, senseless

Q:inanimate  [in'ænimət]

Q:inaugurate  [i'nɔ:ɡjureit]

A: ♣派  inauguration n. 就职，开始

Q:incandescent  [,inkæn'desənt]

A: ♣反  dim, dull, lackluster 黯淡的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 热情饱满的： characterized by glowing zeal
A: ♣例  It makes me incandescent with fury. 它让我愤怒不已
A: ♣近  ardent, demonstrative, emotional, fervid, impassioned, passionate, torrid, vehement
A: ♣反  cold, cool, dispassionate, emotionless, impassive, unemotional 无感情的，漠然的

Q:incantation  [,inkæn'teiʃən]

A: ♣例  Hovering over the sick child, the witch doctor muttered mysterious incantations. 巫医在生病的小孩子身边走来走去，嘴里念着神秘的咒语
A: ♣近  abracadabra, bewitchment, charm, conjuration, enchantment, glamour, hex, invocation

Q:incarnate  [in'kɑ:neit]

A: ♣例  He referred to her as devil incarnate. 他把她视作恶魔的化身
A: ♣近  embodied, materialized, personified, typified

A: ♣例  the general view that Hitler incarnated extreme egotism 通常认为希特勒代表了极端的以自我为中心
A: ♣近  epitomize, incorporate, manifest, materialize, personalize, personify, substantiate, symbolize
A: ♣反  disembody 使（灵魂等）脱离躯体
A: ♣派  incarnation n. 化身

Q:incendiary  [in'sendjəri]

A: ♣近  agitational, instigative, provocative, seditious
A: ♣反  conciliatory, pacific 安抚性的

Q:incense  ['insens]
A: ♠考法1  n. 芳香： a sweet or pleasant smell
A: ♣例  the heavenly incense of spring flowers 春天花朵发出的美妙芳香
A: ♣近  aroma, balm, bouquet, fragrancy, perfume, redolence, scent, spice
A: ♣反  fetor, malodor, reek, stench, stink 恶臭
A: ♠考法2  vt. 激怒： to cause to be extremely angry
A: ♣例  This proposal will certainly incense female activists. 这个提案肯定会激怒女权主义者
A: ♣近  aggravate, enrage, exasperate,inflame, infuriate, ire, madden, outrage, rankle, rile, roil
A: ♣反  delight, gratify, please 取悦；appease, conciliate, mollify, pacify, placate, propitiate, soothe 缓和

Q:incentive  [in'sentiv]
A: ♠考法1  n. 刺激，诱因： something that incites or has a tendency to incite to determination or action
A: ♣例  The handsome reward for the missing wallet was an incentive for me to start looking. 找到丢失钱包的可观报酬激励我展开搜寻。‖A little bonus will give employees an incentive to work harder. 一点点奖金就可以刺激雇员更加努力地工作。
A: ♣近  boost, goad, impetus, incitement, instigation, momentum, motivation, motive, provocation, spur, stimulant, stimulus, yeast
A: ♣反  deterrent, disincentive 抑制剂，阻碍物

Q:inception  [in'sepʃən]

A: ♣例  This seemed like a good program at its inception, but it isn't working out as planned. 一开始这像是个不错的项目，但是它没有按照我们的预期发展
A: ♣近  beginning, birth, commencement, dawn, genesis, kickoff, launch, nascence, onset, outset, start, threshold
A: ♣反  close, conclusion, end, termination,omega 结束，终止
A: ♣派  inceptive adj. 开端的，初生的

Q:incessant  [in'sesənt]

A: ♣例  The incessant noise from an outside repair crew was a real distraction during the test. 窗外维修工发出的持续不断的噪音着实让人在考试里分心
A: ♣近  ceaseless, continual, nonstop, perpetual, running, unbroken, unceasing, uninterrupted, unremitting
A: ♣反  interrupted 中断的；discontinuous, intermittent有间断的

Q:inch  [intʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 少量，很短的距离： a very small distance or degree
A: ♣例  give them aninch, and they'll take a mile 得寸进尺‖Inch by inch, we're making progress toward our fund-raising goal. 我们在慢慢地接近筹款的目标
A: ♣近  ace, hairbreadth, skip, neck, step
A: ♠考法2  v. 慢慢移动： to move or cause to move slowly or by small degrees
A: ♣例  The car inched carefully across the snow-covered bridge. 汽车慢慢地通过被大雪覆盖的桥梁
A: ♣近  crawl, creak, creep, limp, plod, slouch, snail
A: ♣反  dart, fleet, flit, scurry 飞奔，疾行

Q:inchoate  [in'kəuit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 新生的： in an initial or early stage
A: ♣例  inchoate feelings of affection for a man 刚刚产生的好感
A: ♣近  aborning, beginning, inceptive, incipient, initial, nascent
A: ♣反  adult, full-blown, full-fledged, mature, ripe 成熟的，成型的；moribund 将死的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 未完全成型的： imperfectly formed or developed
A: ♣例  a vague, inchoate notion 模糊而不成形的想法
A: ♣近  amorphous, formless, shapeless, undeveloped, unformed, unshaped

Q:incinerate  [in'sinəreit]

A: ♣例  The government is trying to stop farmers incinerating their own waste. 政府开始阻止农民们焚烧垃圾的行为
A: ♣近  burn, carbonize
A: ♣反  douse, extinguish, quench, put out 扑灭
A: ♣派  incineration n. 焚化

A: ♣例  an incipient economic recovery 刚刚出现的经济复苏
A: ♣近  aborning, beginning, inceptive, inchoate,initial, nascent
A: ♣反  adult, full-blown, full-fledged, mature, ripe 成熟的，成型的；moribund 将死的

Q:incite  [in'sait]

A: ♣例  inciting workers to strike 煽动工人罢工
A: ♣近  arouse, abet, foment, instigate, pick, provoke, raise, stir
A: ♣反  dampen, deter, discourage, dishearten, dissuade 劝阻

Q:inclement  [in'klemənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （天气等）恶劣的： lacking mildness
A: ♣例  inclement weather conditions 恶劣的气象条件
A: ♣近  bleak, harsh, severe, stormy, tempestuous
A: ♣反  bright, clear, cloudless, fair, sunny, sunshiny, unclouded 天气晴好的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无情的，严酷的： showing no clemency; unmerciful
A: ♣近  bitter, brutal, intemperate, rigorous
A: ♣反  charitable, clement, lenient, merciful 仁慈的
A: ♣派  inclemency n. 严酷无情

Q:incogitant  [in'kɔdʒitənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 考虑不周的，不体谅的： thoughtless; inconsiderate
A: ♣例  an incogitant litterbug 不体谅人的乱扔垃圾者
A: ♣近  discourteous, disrespectful, ill-mannered, impertinent, inconsiderate, rude, thoughtless, ungracious
A: ♣反  civil, considerate, courteous, genteel, gracious, thoughtful 体谅他人的，举止得体的

Q:incongruent  [in'kɔŋɡruənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不一致的： not conforming to the circumstances or requirements of a situation
A: ♣例  Two triangles are incongruent. 两个三角形不全等。
A: ♣近  conflicting, discordant, discrepant, dissonant, incompatible, incongruous, inconsonant
A: ♣反  congruent, congruous, consistent 一致的

Q:inconsequential  [,inkɔnsi'kwenʃəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不合逻辑的： not using or following good reasoning
A: ♣例  an inconsequential line of argument 不合逻辑的论述
A: ♣近  fallacious, illogical, invalid, irrational, unreasonable, unsound, weak
A: ♣反  logical, rational, reasonable, sound, valid, well-founded, well-grounded 有理的，论证有力的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不重要的： of no significance
A: ♣例  That's an inconsequential problem compared to the other issues. 和其他问题相比，这就是个无关痛痒的小事
A: ♣近  fiddling, frivolous, inconsiderable, insignificant, minor, minute, negligible, nugatory, petty, slight, trivial
A: ♣反  consequential, eventful, important, meaningful, momentous, significant, substantial, weighty 重要的

Q:incontrovertible  [,inkɔntrə'və:tibl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无可争议的： not open to question
A: ♣例  incontrovertible facts 无可非议的事实
A: ♣近  certain, inarguable, incontestable, indisputable, indubitable, positive, sure, undeniable, unquestionable
A: ♣反  arguable, controversial, debatable, disputable, problematic, questionable, refutable 有争议的
A: ♣派  incontrovertibility n. 无可争议

Q:incorrigible  [in'kɔridʒəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不可救药的，积习难改的： incapable of being corrected or amended
A: ♣例  an incorrigible criminal deserving death penalty 一个应该被判死刑的恶习难改的罪犯
A: ♣近  incurable, irrecoverable, irredeemable, irremediable, irretrievable, unrecoverable, unredeemable
A: ♣反  curable, reclaimable, recoverable, redeemable, remediable, retrievable, savable 可以拯救的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无法管制的： difficult or impossible to control or manage
A: ♣例  an incorrigible, spoiled child 被宠坏了的难管的孩子
A: ♣近  headstrong, intractable, obstinate, refractory, stubborn, unmanageable, unruly, willful
A: ♣反  compliant, docile, manageable, obedient, submissive, tractable 顺从的

Q:incriminate  [in'krimineit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 归罪于： to accuse of a crime or other wrongful act
A: ♣例  incriminate innocent people 诬陷好人
A: ♣近  charge, criminate ,impeach, indict
A: ♣反  absolve, acquit, exculpate, exonerate, vindicate 免罪

Q:incubate  ['inkjubeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 孵化： to cover and warm eggs as the young inside develop
A: ♣例  The hen incubated her eggs for two weeks. 母鸡孵蛋两周
A: ♣近  brood, hatch, sit
A: ♠考法2  vt. 帮助，培养，促进： to cause or aid the development of
A: ♣例  Hopefully, these youthful visits to the museum will incubate an enduring love of art. 我们希望年轻时参观博物馆能够培养他们对于艺术的持久热爱
A: ♣近  advance, cultivate, encourage, forward, further, nourish, nurse, nurture, promote
A: ♣反  check, discourage, frustrate, hinder, impede, inhibit, obstruct, retard, shackle 妨碍，阻碍
A: ♣派  incubator n. 恒温箱；incubation n. 孵化，孵卵

Q:inculpate  ['inkʌlpeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt.归罪于： incriminate
A: ♣近  charge, criminate, inculpate, indict
A: ♣反  absolve, acquit, exculpate, exonerate, vindicate 免罪

Q:incumbent  [in'kʌmbənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 义不容辞的，必须的： imposed as an obligation or duty
A: ♣例  It is incumbent upon individuals to sacrifice for their country when it is in danger. 当国家受难时，个人应该义不容辞地为国做出牺牲。‖It is incumbent upon the press to act not in its own best interests, but in society's best interests. 对于媒体来说，为社会的利益（而非自身利益）服务是其应尽的义务。
A: ♣近  compulsory, forced, imperative, incumbent, involuntary, necessary, obligatory, peremptory, required
A: ♣反  elective, optional, voluntary 可选择的

Q:incursion  [in'kə:ʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n.入侵： a hostile entrance into a territory
A: ♣例  homes damaged by the incursion of floodwater 被洪水入侵破坏的房屋
A: ♣近  foray, inroad, invasion, irruption, raid
A: ♣反  retreat, withdrawal 撤退

Q:indecorous  [in'dekərəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不合乎礼节的，不得体的： conflicting with accepted standards of good conduct or good taste
A: ♣例  How can you make such an indecorous joke for a solemn moment in the marriage ceremony ? 你怎么能在庄严肃穆的结婚典礼上开那样一个不得体的玩笑呢？
A: ♣近  amiss, graceless, improper, inapposite, infelicitous, malapropos, perverse, unbecoming, unfit, unseemly, unsuitable, wrong
A: ♣反  appropriate, becoming, befitting, decorous, felicitous, fit, genteel, meet, proper, seemly, suitable 得体的，合乎礼节的

Q:indelible  [in'deləbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （印记等）无法擦除的： impossible to remove, erase, or wash away
A: ♣例  indelible ink 难以擦拭的墨水
A: ♣近  ineffaceable, ineradicable, inerasable, ingrained
A: ♣反  eradicable, erasable, removable, washable 可抹去的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无法忘怀的： not easily forgotten
A: ♣例  most indelible experiences 最难以磨灭的经历
A: ♣近  impressive, memorable, unforgettable
A: ♣反  forgettable 容易被忘记的

Q:indemnity  [in'demnəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. （损害、伤害等的）保险补偿： compensation for damage, loss, or injury suffered
A: ♣例  The widow now lives on a pension and an indemnity from her late husband's company. 这个寡妇如今依靠社保和前夫公司的保险赔偿过日
A: ♣近  compensation, indemnification, quittance, recompense, redress, remuneration, reparation, requital

Q:indict  [in'dait]

A: ♣例  indict the mayor for fraud and embezzlement. 起诉市长受贿和挪用公款
A: ♣近  charge, criminate, impeach, incriminate
A: ♣反  absolve, acquit, exculpate, exonerate, vindicate 免罪

Q:indifferent  [in'difərənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 公平的： marked by impartiality
A: ♣例  They believed their art teacher could offer an indifferent judgment on their works' merits. 他们相信艺术老师会对他们作品的价值做出公正的评价
A: ♣近  disinterested, equal, impartial, just, nonpartisan, objective, unbiased, unprejudiced
A: ♣反  biased, one-sided, partial, prejudiced 有偏好的；unjust 不公平的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （质量、档次等）中规中矩的，一般的： of average to below average quality
A: ♣例  an indifferent but drinkable cup of coffee 一杯尚可入口的咖啡
A: ♣近  average, common, fair, intermediate, mediocre, medium, moderate, ordinary, passable, so-so
A: ♣反  exceptional, extraordinary 极好的；inferior, poor 低档次的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 不感兴趣的，冷漠的： marked by a lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern for something
A: ♣例  indifferent about the result of CET-4 对四级成绩不感兴趣
A: ♣近  aloof, apathetic, detached, incurious, nonchalant, numb, pococurante, remote, unconcerned, uninterested
A: ♣反  attentive, concerned, interested 关切的，有兴趣的
A: ♣派  indifference n. 漠然

Q:indigenous  [in'didʒinəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 土产的，本地的： originating and living or occurring naturally in an area or environment
A: ♣例  the culture of the indigenous people of that country 那个国家原著民的文化
A: ♣近  aboriginal, endemic, native
A: ♣反  exotic, extraneous, foreign外来的；nonnative 非本地的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 与生俱来的，先天的： being a part of the innermost nature of a person or thing
A: ♣例  The drive to create is indigenous to humanity. 人类创造的动力是与生俱来的
A: ♣近  constitutional, essential, immanent, inborn, inbred, ingrained, innate, integral, intrinsic, natural
A: ♣反  adventitious, extrinsic 外在的；acquired, studied 后天习得的

Q:indigent  ['indidʒənt]

A: ♣例  indigent people who require some outside assistance 需要外来援助的贫苦人民

A: ♣反  affluent, opulent, rich, wealthy 富裕的
A: ♣派  indigence n. 贫穷

Q:indispensable  [,indis'pensəbl]

A: ♣近  critical, crucial, imperative, necessary, necessitous, needed, required, requisite, vital
A: ♣反  dispensable 可替代的；redundant, superfluous, surplus 多余的

Q:indoctrinate  [in'dɔktrineit]

A: ♣近  educate, instruct, lesson, teach, train, tutor

Q:indolent  ['indələnt]

A: ♣近  lazy, idle, shiftless, slothful, sluggish
A: ♣反  diligent, industrious 勤奋的
A: ♣派  indolence n. 懒惰

Q:inducement  [in'dju:smənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 动机，刺激源： a motive or consideration that leads one to action
A: ♣例  offered an expensive watch as an inducement to ratify the proposal 赠送名贵手表以求计划得到批准
A: ♣近  goad, impulse, incentive, motive, spur, stimulus
A: ♣反  deterrent 抑制物
A: ♠考法2  n.劝说，游说： the act of reasoning or pleading with someone to accept a belief or course of action
A: ♣例  He gave up smoking only after a prolonged inducement by all the other family members. 在所有家庭成员坚持不懈的劝说之下，他终于愿意戒烟了
A: ♣近  conversion, convincing, persuading, suasion
A: ♣派  induce v. 导致，产生

Q:indulgent  [in'dʌldʒənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （对己）放纵的，（对他人）纵容的： showing, characterized by, or given to indulgence
A: ♣例  indulgent aristocrats 生活放纵的贵族
A: ♣近  decadent, forbearing, lenient, luxurious, tolerant, sybaritic
A: ♣反  ascetic 禁欲的；draconian 严酷的
A: ♣派  indulgence n. 放纵

Q:indurate  ['indjuəreit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 铁石心肠的，冷酷无情的： having or showing a lack of sympathy or tender feelings
A: ♣例  an indurate heart that admits no love or mercy 一颗不认可爱或仁慈的冷酷心灵
A: ♣近  affectless, callous, heartless, inhumane, merciless, obdurate, pitiless, ruthless, unsparing, cold-blooded
A: ♣反  charitable, compassionate, humane, kindhearted, merciful, tender 仁慈的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使变硬： to become physically firm or solid
A: ♣例  Great heat indurates clay. 高温使黏土变硬
A: ♣近  concrete, congeal, firm, freeze, set, solidify
A: ♣反  liquefy 液化；soften 柔化
A: ♠考法3  vt. 使习惯于：使习惯于，如艰苦或尴尬之境况： to make able to withstand physical hardship, strain, or exposure
A: ♣例  Such a brutal upbringing could only callous his soul and indurate his heart to the suffering of others. 这样一种残暴的培养方式只会让他的灵魂变得麻木，让他的心灵对于他人所受的折磨无动于衷
A: ♣近  fortify, inure, season, steel, strengthen, toughen
A: ♣反  enfeeble, weaken, undermine 弱化，使虚弱

Q:industrious  [in'dʌstriəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 勤勉的： constantly, regularly, or habitually occupied, diligent
A: ♣例  The industrious PhD spends all his summer holiday in the laboratory. 勤奋的博士整个暑假都在做实验
A: ♣近  assiduous, busy, diligent, sedulous
A: ♣反  indolent, lazy, slothful 懒惰的
A: ♣派  industriousness n. 勤奋

Q:ineffable  [in'efəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 难以表达的： incapable of being expressed
A: ♣例  ineffable ecstasy 无法用语言表达的狂喜
A: ♣近  indefinable, indescribable, inexpressible, unspeakable, unutterable
A: ♣反  communicable 可传达的；expressible 可描述的
A: ♣派  ineffability n. 不可描述性

Q:ineluctable  [,ini'lʌktəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj.无法逃避的，必然的： not to be avoided, changed, or resisted
A: ♣例  Although death is an ineluctable fate for any and every individual organism, it lays the foundation of the metabolism that perpetuates the planetary ecosystem. 尽管死亡对于任何单个的有机体而言是不可避免的宿命，但它奠定了能使整个行星生态系统永不衰竭的新陈代谢的基础
A: ♣近  certain, inescapable, inevasible, inevitable, unavoidable
A: ♣反  avoidable, evadable 可避免的；uncertain, unsure （结果等）不确定的
A: ♣派  ineluctability n. 不可避免

Q:inept  [i'nept]
A: ♠考法1  adj.愚笨的，荒谬的： displaying a lack of judgment, sense, or reason
A: ♣例  an inept and irresponsible remark on his paper 对他文章的荒谬而不负责任的评论
A: ♣近  absurd, foolish, fatuous, preposterous, stupid, witless, unwise
A: ♣反  judicious, prudent sagacious, sapient, smart, wise 聪明的，明智的
A: ♠考法2  adj.不恰当的，不合时宜的： not appropriate for a particular occasion or situation
A: ♣近  amiss, graceless, improper, inapposite, infelicitous, malapropos, perverse, unseemly, unsuitable
A: ♣反  appropriate, becoming, felicitous, fitting, genteel, proper, seemly, suitable 恰当的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 不称职的，无能力的： generally incompetent
A: ♣例  a hopelessly inept defense attorney 严重不靠谱的辩护律师
A: ♣近  incapable, inexpert, unfitted, unskillful, unqualified
A: ♣反  capable, competent 有能力的；proficient, masterful 精通的，技艺精湛的
A: ♣派  ineptitude n. 不合适

Q:inert  [i'nə:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （人）懒惰缺乏活力的；（物品）惰性的： sluggish in action or motion; deficient in active properties
A: ♣例  inert ingredients in drugs 药品中的惰性成分
A: ♣近  dead, dormant, lethargic, idle, inactive, passive, torpid
A: ♣反  active, dynamic 充满活力的；passionate 饱含激情的
A: ♣派  inertia n. 惰性

Q:inevitable  [in'evitəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不可避免的，必然的： incapable of being avoided or evaded
A: ♣例  The impact of the scandal on the election was inevitable. 丑闻对于选举的冲击是不可避免的
A: ♣近  certain, ineluctable, inescapable, inevasible, sure, unalterable, unavoidable
A: ♣反  evitable, avoidable 可避免的；uncertain, unsure 不确定的
A: ♣派  inevitability n. 必然性

Q:inexorable  [in'eksərəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无法劝阻的，不为所动的： not to be persuaded, moved, or stopped
A: ♣例  the seemingly inexorable rise in unemployment 看起来无法阻止其高攀的失业率
A: ♣近  inflexible, adamant, obdurate, relentless, rigid, unyielding
A: ♣反  flexible 易受影响的；yielding 屈服的
A: ♣派  inexorably adv. 势不可挡地

Q:infamous  ['infəməs]

A: ♣例  an infamous city for smuggling and prostitution 因走私而和卖淫而臭名昭著的城市
A: ♣近  notorious, opprobrious
A: ♣反  distinguished, esteemed, prestigious, reputable 声名显赫的，受尊敬的
A: ♣派  infamy n. 声名狼藉

Q:infatuate  [in'fætjueit]

A: ♣反  disgust 使反感
A: ♣派  infatuation n. 迷恋

Q:infelicitous  [,infi'lisitəs]

A: ♣例  an infelicitous moment 不幸的时刻
A: ♣近  hapless, ill-fated, luckless, unfortunate, unhappy
A: ♣反  happy 幸运的，令人高兴的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不适当的，不合时宜的： not appropriate or well-timed
A: ♣例  made a very infelicitous remark 做出极不恰当的评价
A: ♣近  inappropriate, indecorous, inept, malapropos, unfit, unseemly
A: ♣反  apt, appropriate, becoming, proper 合适的
A: ♣派  infelicity n. 不恰当

Q:inferno  [in'fə:nəu]
A: ♠考法1  n. 大火： an intense fire
A: ♣例  A raging inferno posed a serious threat to the downwind villages. 肆虐的大火给下风向的村庄带来了严重的威胁
A: ♣近  conflagration, holocaust
A: ♠考法2  n. 地狱： a place or a state that resembles or suggests hell
A: ♣例  the inferno of war 地狱般的战场
A: ♣近  hell, underworld
A: ♣反  paradise, heaven, nirvana 天堂，乐土

Q:infiltrate  ['infiltreit]

A: ♣例  The intelligence staff had been infiltrated by spies. 情报工作人员已经被间谍渗透了
A: ♣近  creep, insinuate, penetrate, sneak, slip
A: ♣反  abscond 潜逃
A: ♣派  infiltration n. 潜入，渗透

Q:infinite  ['infinət]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无尽的，无限的： having no boundaries or limits
A: ♣例  the idea of an infinite universe 无限宇宙的概念
A: ♣近  endless, boundless, limitless, immeasurable, unfathomable
A: ♣反  finite 有限的；bounded, circumscribed, confined, definite, limited, restricted 有界限的，受限的
A: ♣派  infinity n. 无限

Q:infirm  [in'fə:m]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 虚弱的： weak in body, especially from old age or disease
A: ♣例  her aging, infirm husband 她上了年纪、身体虚弱的丈夫
A: ♣近  debilitated, effete, enervated, feeble, frail, languid, sapped, unsubstantial
A: ♣反  hale, mighty, powerful, rugged, stalwart, stout, strong 强壮的，有力的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不果断的，优柔寡断的： lacking firmness of will, character, or purpose
A: ♣例  She has little patience with the “infirm of purpose”. 她对那些优柔寡断的人没什么耐心
A: ♣近  faltering, irresolute, vacillating, wavering
A: ♣反  resolute 果断的

Q:inflame  [in'fleim]
A: ♠考法1  v. 点燃： to set on fire
A: ♣例  A carelessly tossed cigarette inflamed the papers in the trash can. 一只被随意丢弃的香烟点燃了垃圾桶中的纸
A: ♣近  enflame, enkindle, fire, ignite, kindle, light, torch
A: ♣反  douse, extinguish, quench, put out 熄灭，扑灭
A: ♠考法2  v. 使加剧：to make more violent
A: ♣例  Retaliation served only to inflame the feud. 冤冤相报何时了
A: ♣近  aggravate, enrage, exacerbate, intensify, ire, irritate, provoke, rile, vex
A: ♣反  assuage, mitigate, mollify, pacify, placate, subdue 平息

Q:influx  ['inflʌks]
A: ♠考法1  n. 涌入： a coming in
A: ♣例  They anticipated an influx of tourists next month. 他们预期下个月会有大批游客涌入
A: ♣近  affluence, flux, income, inflow, inpouring, inrush
A: ♣反  exodus 大批离去；outflow, outpouring 流出

Q:infraction  [in'frækʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 违背，违犯： a failure to uphold the requirements of law, duty, or obligation
A: ♣例  Speeding is only a minor infraction, but vehicular homicide is a serious felony. 超速只是小的违章，但是用机动车故意杀人就是重罪了。
A: ♣近  breach, contravention, infringement, transgression, trespass, violation
A: ♣反  observance 遵守

Q:infuriate  [in'fjuərieit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 激怒： to make furious
A: ♣例  be infuriated by the deliberate insults 被蓄意的中伤激怒
A: ♣近  aggravate, enrage, exasperate, incense, ire, madden, umbrage
A: ♣反  appease, assuage, pacify, placate, propitiate 平息，安抚；delight, gratify, please 取悦，讨好
A: ♣派  infuriated adj. 被激怒的

Q:infuse  [in'fju:z]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 灌输，使…充满： to fill or cause to be filled with something
A: ♣例  New members infused enthusiasm into the club. 新队员为俱乐部注入了激情
A: ♣近  endue, imbue, implant, ingrain, instill, permeate, suffuse, steep
A: ♣反  extract 提取
A: ♠考法2  vt. 鼓舞： inspire, animate
A: ♣例  a sense of purpose that infuses scientific researchers 给科学研究者打鸡血一般的使命感
A: ♣近  animate, exalt, motivate, stimulate
A: ♣派  infusion n. 注入

Q:ingenious  [in'dʒi:njəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 聪明的，有创造才能的： marked by originality, resourcefulness, and cleverness in conception or execution
A: ♣例  Ingenious designers soon came up with a solution to the battery problem. 聪明的设计者们很快便提出了电池问题的解决方案
A: ♣近  artful, clever, imaginative, innovative, inventive, original
A: ♣反  awkward 笨拙的；uncreative, unimaginative 无创造力或想象力的

Q:ingenuity  [,indʒi'nju:əti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 独创性，创新性： inventive skill or imagination
A: ♣例  There is little ingenuity in his articles. 他的文章鲜有独创性
A: ♣近  creativeness, innovativeness, inventiveness, originality
A: ♣反  banality, cliché 陈词滥调
A: ♣派  ingenuous 真挚的

Q:ingenuous  [in'dʒenjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 天真淳朴的： lacking in cunning, guile, or worldliness
A: ♣例  Photographs captured the ingenuous smiles of young children at play. 摄影家捕捉到了演出中孩子们天真无邪的笑脸
A: ♣近  artless, innocent, guileless, na?ve, simple, unaffected, unpretending, unsophisticated
A: ♣反  artful, cunning, sly 狡猾的；assuming, hypocritical 虚伪做作的；sophisticated, worldly 世故的，老练的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 坦白的： openly straightforward or frank
A: ♣例  her ingenuous thirst for knowledge 她对知识毫不掩饰的渴望
A: ♣近  candid, frank, open, plain, unconcealed
A: ♣反  ambiguous, equivocal, evasive 含糊其辞的

Q:ingest  [in'dʒest]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 摄入，咽下： to take into the body by the mouth for digestion or absorption
A: ♣例  claims that the average person ingests considerably more calories than is necessary or desirable 宣称每个人平均摄取的卡路里大大超出了所需或者适当的范围
A: ♣近  eat, consume, devour, intake
A: ♣反  evacuate, expel 排出；vomit 呕吐
A: ♣派  ingestion n. 摄取

Q:ingrained  [,in'ɡreind]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 本质的，根深蒂固的： forming a part of the essence or inmost being; firmly established
A: ♣例  ingrained prejudice against foreigners 对外国人根深蒂固的偏见
A: ♣近  constitutional, immanent, inborn, indigenous, inherent, innate, intrinsic
A: ♣反  adventitious 外来的，偶然的；extraneous, extrinsic 非本质的，外在的
A: ♣派  ingrain 灌输，使根深蒂固

Q:ingratiating  [in'ɡreiʃieitiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 讨人喜欢的： capable of winning favor
A: ♣例  They adopted the orphan who had a most ingratiating smile. 他们收养了那名有着最惹人喜欢的笑容的孤儿
A: ♣近  disarming, endearing, insinuating, winsome
A: ♣反  disagreeable 令人厌恶的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 逢迎的，意在奉承的： intended or adopted in order to gain favor
A: ♣例  an repulsive ingratiating smile 令人反感的阿谀奉承的微笑
A: ♣近  adulatory, deferential, fawning, flattering, toady
A: ♣派  ingratiate v. 讨好

Q:inherent  [in'hiərənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 内在的，本质的： involved in the constitution or essential character of something
A: ♣例  a disposition inherent in human nature 人性内在的倾向
A: ♣近  constitutional, elemental, essential, inborn, ingrained, innate, intrinsic
A: ♣反  adventitious 外来的，偶然的；extraneous, extrinsic 外在的
A: ♣派  inherently adv. 内在地

Q:inimical  [i'nimikəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 带有敌意的： reflecting or indicating hostility
A: ♣例  a cold, inimical voice 冰冷而不友好的声音
A: ♣近  antagonistic, hostile, opposing, unfriendly
A: ♣反  amiable, amicable, friendly, hospitable 友好的；amenable 服从的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 危及某人利益的，不利的： opposed to one's interests
A: ♣例  Laws were designed to enhance national security but some regard as inimical to cherished freedoms. 法律旨在维护国家安全，但有人认为它危及了人们最为珍贵的权力——自由
A: ♣近  counter, disadvantageous, negative, prejudicial, unfavorable
A: ♣反  advantageous, favorable, positive, supportive, well-disposed 有利的，利好的

Q:inimitable  [i'nimitəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无法仿效的，独特的： not capable of being imitated
A: ♣例  her own inimitable style 她特立独行的作风
A: ♣近  incomparable, matchless, peerless, unique, unparalleled
A: ♣反  commonplace, ordinary 平凡的
A: ♣派  inimitability n. 独特性

Q:iniquity  [i'nikwəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 邪恶，不公正： gross immorality or injustice
A: ♣例  The use of illegal narcotics is not only a destroyer of personal health but also an iniquity that undermines our society. 非法的毒品不仅仅摧残着个人健康，还是一颗危害社会的毒瘤
A: ♣近  corruption, depravity, debauchery, evil, infamy, sin, unfairness, wickedness
A: ♣反  integrity, rectitude 正直；virtue 美德；disinterestedness 公正

Q:initiate  [i'niʃieit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 创始，发动促进： to cause or facilitate the beginning of
A: ♣例  a chain reaction initiated by UV irradiation 紫外光激发引起的连锁反应
A: ♣近  begin, start, commence, inaugurate, introduce, launch
A: ♣反  terminate 终止
A: ♠考法2  n. 刚入门的新手： a person who is undergoing or has undergone an initiation
A: ♣近  apprentice, beginner, novice, rookie, tyro
A: ♣反  veteran 身经百战的人
A: ♣派  initiative 主动性，首创精神

Q:inkling  ['iŋkliŋ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 轻微暗示，小提示： a slight indication or suggestion
A: ♣例  They hadn't given us an inkling of what was going to happen. 他们不给我们任何暗示将会发生什么
A: ♣近  clue, cue, hint
A: ♠考法2  n. 略知： a slight knowledge or vague notion
A: ♣例  not have even the faintest inkling of what the project was all about 对这个项目与什么有关毫不知情
A: ♣近  glimmer
A: ♣反  insight 深刻理解

Q:innocuous  [i'nɔkjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无害的： producing no injury
A: ♣例  The government enacted a more strict regulation on innocuous preservatives. 政府对无害防腐剂制定了更为严格的规定
A: ♣近  anodyne, benign, harmless, inoffensive, nontoxic, safe
A: ♣反  damaging, detrimental, harmful, injurious, noxious, pernicious 有害的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 乏味的，不会引起敌意的： not likely to give offense or to arouse strong feelings or hostility
A: ♣例  He made an innocuous remark to avoid conflict. 为了避免冲突，他做了一个中庸的评价
A: ♣近  bland, inoffensive, insipid, neutral, sapless
A: ♣反  provoking 刺激性的

Q:innovative  ['inəuveitiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 创新性的： characterized by, tending to, or introducing innovations
A: ♣例  an innovative macro-economic strategy 创新性的宏观经济战略
A: ♣近  creative, ingenious, inventive, original
A: ♣反  conservative, hidebound 保守的
A: ♣派  innovation n. 创新

Q:inquisitive  [in'kwizətiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 过分好奇的： inordinately or improperly curious about the affairs of others
A: ♣例  big sunglasses to frustrate inquisitive journalists 让狗仔队企图无法得逞的大墨镜
A: ♣近  curious, inquiring, investigative, prying
A: ♣反  indifferent , unconcerned, uninterested 不感兴趣的；incurious 无好奇心的
A: ♣派  inquisitiveness n. 好奇

Q:insensible  [in'sensəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无知觉的： having lost consciousness, especially temporarily
A: ♣例  The security guard was knocked insensible by a sudden blow. 保安被突如其来的一击敲晕了
A: ♣近  anesthetic, insensate, senseless, unfeeling, unconscious
A: ♣反  conscious 神志清醒的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 漠不关心的： not emotionally responsive
A: ♣例  insensible to workers’ requests对工人的要求无动于衷
A: ♣近  apathetic, bloodless, callous, dull, impassive, indifferent, nonchalant, phlegmatic
A: ♣反  concerned 关切的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 粗俗的，没品味的： lacking in refinement or good taste
A: ♣例  She married an insensible brute upon whom the niceties of life were completely lost.她嫁给了一个毫无品味的凡夫俗子，从此她的生活再无任何情趣
A: ♣近  crass, crude, incult, lowbred, tasteless, uncouth, uncultivated, uncultured, unpolished, unrefined, vulgar
A: ♣反  civilized, cultivated, cultured, genteel, polished, refined, smooth, tasteful 有品位的

Q:insensitive  [in'sensətiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 缺乏机智圆滑的，缺乏社交技巧的： lacking tact
A: ♣例  so insensitive as to laugh at someone in pain 如此缺乏社交技巧以至于嘲笑处于悲痛中的人
A: ♣近  gauche, impolite, insensible, tactless
A: ♣反  considerate 为他人着想的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不敏感的，麻木的： not responsive or susceptible
A: ♣例  insensitive to either criticism or commendation 对批评和表扬都不在乎
A: ♣近  anesthetized, dead, numb, senseless, unfeeling
A: ♣反  sensitive, tender 敏感的

Q:insentient  [in'senʃiənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无感觉，无知觉的： lacking perception, consciousness, or animation
A: ♣例  He refused to believe that the universe as we know it evolved from the random interactions of insentient particles of matter. 他拒绝相信我们所知的宇宙是经由无生命的粒子间的相互作用演化而来的
A: ♣近  impassive, insensate, insensible, senseless, unresponsive
A: ♣反  perceiving, sensible, sensitive 有知觉的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 一知半解的，略懂的： not having or showing a deep understanding of something
A: ♣例  an insentient therapist who failed to see what the teenager's real problem was 一个对这名青少年的真正问题所在一知半解的医生
A: ♣近  impercipient, unwise
A: ♣反  discerning, insightful 深邃的，有洞察力的； sagacious, sage, sapient 睿智的

Q:insight  ['insait]
A: ♠考法1  n. 深刻的理解： an instance of apprehending the true nature of a thing, especially through intuitive understanding
A: ♣例  an insight into the global-scale environmental problems 对于全球性环境问题的深刻理解
A: ♣近  discernment, insight, perception, sagacity, sapience
A: ♣反  glimmer, inkling 略懂，略知一二
A: ♣派  insightful adj. 有洞察力的

Q:insipid  [in'sipid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （食品）清淡无味的： lacking flavor or zest; not tasty
A: ♣例  a rather insipid soup 味道清淡的汤
A: ♣近  flat, flavorless, mild, sapless, savorless, tasteless
A: ♣反  piquant 辛辣的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 平淡的，无聊的： lacking in qualities that interest, stimulate, or challenge
A: ♣例  an insipid story of the prince and the princess一个关于王子和公主的无聊故事
A: ♣近  banal, bland, driveling, prosaic, tedious, uninteresting, vapid
A: ♣反  enchanting 引人入胜的

Q:insolent  ['insələnt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 粗野的，无礼的： audaciously rude or disrespectful
A: ♣例  an insolent child with no respect or regard for anyone 对他人不敬的无礼的小孩
A: ♣近  arrogant, audacious, bold, haughty, supercilious, impertinent, impudent
A: ♣反  courteous, polite 有礼貌的；respectful 恭敬的；meek, mousy, timid 胆小的
A: ♣派  insolence n. 无礼

Q:insouciant  [in'su:sjənt]

A: ♣例  an insouciant shrug 无所谓地耸耸肩
A: ♣近  carefree, casual, indifferent, nonchalant, unconcerned
A: ♣反  anxious, careworn 焦虑的；concerned, worried 关注的，担心的
A: ♣派  insouciance n. 不在乎

Q:instate  [in'steit]

A: ♣例  The new Secretary of the Treasury was instated on Monday. 新的财政部长于星期一被任命
A: ♣近  appoint, designate, inaugurate, induct, install, nominate
A: ♣反  dismiss, oust 罢免

Q:instigate  ['instiɡeit]

A: ♣例  This incident is instigated by a small group of people with ulterior motives. 此次事件是被少数别有用心的人煽动起来的
A: ♣近  abet, arouse, excite, foment, goad, incite, inflame, provoke, stir
A: ♣反  assuage, allay, mitigate, mollify, pacify, soothe 平息，缓和
A: ♣派  instigation n. 煽动

Q:instill  [in'stil]

A: ♣例  instill medication into the infected eye 将药物滴入患者受感染的眼中
A: ♣近  inject
A: ♣反  extract 抽取
A: ♠考法2  v. 灌输： to impart gradually
A: ♣例  instill a sense of responsibility to the young 向年轻人灌输一种责任感
A: ♣近  breed, enroot, implant, inculcate, infix, infuse, ingrain, plant, sow
A: ♣反  remove 移除
A: ♣派  instillation n. 滴入

Q:institute  ['institjut]

A: ♣例  institute a new department 创建一个新的部门
A: ♣近  begin, constitute, create, found, inaugurate, launch, start, set up
A: ♣反  abrogate, efface, rescind 废除；close, shut 关闭；phase out 淘汰
A: ♠考法2  n. 机构： an organization for the promotion of a cause

A: ♣近  association, institution, society
A: ♣派  institution n. 习俗，制度

Q:insubordinate  [,insə'bɔ:dinət]

A: ♣例  Insubordinate soldiers are court-martialed. 抗命的士兵被送上了军事法庭
A: ♣近  balky, contumacious, intractable, mutinous, recalcitrant, rebellious, refractory
A: ♣反  amenable, docile, obedient, ruly, submissive, tractable 顺从的

Q:insular  ['insjulə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （观念、想法等）孤立狭隘的： being, having, or reflecting a narrow provincial viewpoint
A: ♣例  the insular thinking of peasant communities 农民阶级的狭隘思想
A: ♣近  confined, local, narrow, parochial, provincial, regional, restricted
A: ♣反  cosmopolitan, ecumenical 有国际视野的；catholic （兴趣等）广泛的；receptive 善于接受的

Q:insulate  ['insjuleit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使绝缘，使隔离： to place in a detached situation
A: ♣例  greenhouse gas that insulates ground infrared radiation 能阻碍地表红外辐射的温室气体
A: ♣近  block, insolate, quarantine, seclude, segregate, separate, sequester
A: ♣反  connect, link, unite 连结；integrate 使成一体
A: ♣派  insulation n. 隔绝，绝热

Q:insurgent  [in'sə:dʒənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 叛乱分子： one who breaks with or opposes constituted authority or the established order
A: ♣例  Insurgents armed with assault rifles and grenades ambushed a US convoy, resulting in heavy casualties. 持有突击步枪和手榴弹的叛乱分子偷袭了美军车队，造成重大伤亡
A: ♣近  rebel, anarchist, antagonist, malcontent, mutineer
A: ♣派  insurgency n. 叛乱

Q:intangible  [in'tændʒəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无法感知的，无形的： incapable of being perceived by the senses
A: ♣例  intangible value of a good reputation 良好声誉的无形价值
A: ♣近  impalpable, imperceptible, imponderable, inappreciable, indiscernible, insensible, invisible
A: ♣反  corporeal 肉体的，有形的；palpable, tactile, tangible, touchable 可感知的

Q:integral  ['intiɡrəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 构成整体所必需的： essential to completeness
A: ♣例  an integral part of the undergraduate curriculum 本科生课程的必修部分
A: ♣近  critical, essential, indispensable, necessary, requisite, vital
A: ♣反  redundant, superfluous, surplus 多余的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 完整的： not lacking any part or member that properly belongs to it
A: ♣例  the belief that athletics are essential to an integral life 坚信运动是完整的人生所不可或缺的一部分
A: ♣近  comprehensive, entire, full, grand, intact, perfect, plenary, total, whole
A: ♣反  imperfect, incomplete 不完美的，不完整的；partial 部分的

Q:integrity  [in'teɡrəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 正直： steadfast adherence to a strict moral or ethical code, devotion to telling the truth
A: ♣例  After a thorough investigation into “Climategate”, the panel concluded that the integrity of scientific community is still sound. 经过对“气候门事件”的彻底调查，专家组认为学术界的信誉和道德仍然是值得信赖的
A: ♣近  conscience, honesty, incorruptibility, rectitude, righteousness, scrupulousness
A: ♣反  baseness 卑鄙；deceit, deceitfulness, dishonesty, lying, mendacity, untruthfulness 欺骗
A: ♠考法2  n. 完整性： the quality or condition of being whole or undivided
A: ♣例  trying to maintain the integrity of the falling empire 尽力维持日趋西山的帝国的统一
A: ♣近  completeness, entireness, perfection, wholeness

Q:intelligible  [in'telidʒəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可理解的： capable of being understood
A: ♣例  military codenames intelligible only to those high-rank commanding officers 只有高级指挥官才能理解的军事暗号
A: ♣近  accessible, apprehensible, comprehensible, fathomable, lucid, understandable
A: ♣反  abstruse, recondite, inscrutable, insensible 难以理解的
A: ♣派  intelligibility n. 可理解性

Q:intemperate  [in'tempərət]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无节制的，极端的，不温和的： not temperate or moderate
A: ♣例  The tone of the article is very intemperate. 文章的论调很极端
A: ♣近  excessive, extreme, immoderate, inordinate, overindulgent, unrestrained
A: ♣反  equable 温和的；bridled, checked, constrained, controlled, curbed, governed, hampered, hindered, trammeled 受限制的，节制的

Q:intensify  [in'tensifai]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 加强，激化： to make intense or more intensive
A: ♣例  Both companies intensified their efforts to win the contract. 为了获得这份合同，两家公司都加大了投入
A: ♣近  accentuate, aggravate, amplify, deepen, enhance, magnify, redouble, strengthen
A: ♣反  abate, assuage, attenuate, mitigate, moderate 减缓，减低（程度）
A: ♣派  intensity n. 强度

Q:inter  [in'tə:]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 埋葬： to place in a grave or tomb
A: ♣例  The infamous terrorist leader Bin Laden was interred at sea. 臭名昭著的恐怖分子本拉登被葬于海中
A: ♣近  bury, entomb, inhume
A: ♣反  dig, disinter, excavate, exhume, unearth 掘出

Q:intercessor  [,intə'sesə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 调停者： one that mediates
A: ♣例  attend the meeting as the intercessor 作为调停人出席会议
A: ♣近  broker, buffer, conciliator, intermediate, mediator, peacemaker
A: ♣反  flame-fanner 煽风点火的人
A: ♣派  intercession n. 调停，斡旋

Q:interdict  [,intə'dikt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 禁止： to forbid in a usually formal or authoritative manner
A: ♣例  Though not interdicted by law, such an action is morally wrong. 尽管这种行为不被法律所禁止，但是道德上来说是不对的
A: ♣近  ban, forbid, prohibit, proscribe
A: ♣反  authorize 授权；allow, permit, suffer 允许；approve, endorse, ratify, sanction 批准
A: ♠考法2  vt. 阻止： to stop, seize, or interrupt while in progress or on course
A: ♣例  Federal agents are able to interdict only a small percentage of the narcotic shipments into the country. 联邦调查员们只能阻止一小部分流入国内的毒品
A: ♣近  bar, block, check, hinder, intercept, impede, obstruct
A: ♣反  expedite 促进，加速
A: ♣派  interdiction n. 禁止，封锁

Q:interim  ['intərim]
A: ♠考法1  n. 中间过渡时期，间隔： an interval of time between one event, process, or period and another
A: ♣例  Richard Wagner’s operas usually require an interim of more than 30 minutes for performers to have a break. 理查德?瓦格纳的歌剧通常需要长达30多分钟的幕间休息时间以供演员调整
A: ♣近  breach, break, gap, interruption, interval, interlude, parenthesis
A: ♣反  continuation, continuity 持续
A: ♠考法2  adj. 暂时的： serving in a position for the time being
A: ♣例  an interim government to maintain social stability 维持社会稳定的临时政府
A: ♣近  acting, provisional, temporary
A: ♣反  eternal, permanent 永恒的

Q:interlock  [,intə'lɔk]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 连锁： to become united or joined closely, as by hooking or dovetailing
A: ♣例  The branches of the trees interlock to form a natural archway. 树枝相互缠绕在一起，形成了天然的拱门
A: ♣近  associate, connect, join, link, unite
A: ♣反  sunder 拆散
A: ♣派  interlocking adj. 连锁的

Q:interminable  [in'tə:minəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无尽头的： having or seeming to have no end
A: ♣例  A large audience fell asleep during the interminable sermon. 许多观众都在冗长的布道演说上睡着了
A: ♣近  continual, ceaseless, endless, everlasting, perpetual
A: ♣反  completed 完成的

Q:intermittent  [,intə'mitənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 间歇的，断断续续的： coming and going at intervals, not continuous
A: ♣例  intermittent rain in June 六月里断断续续的梅雨
A: ♣近  episodic, erratic, occasional, periodical, recurrent, recurring
A: ♣反  constant, continuous, incessant, unceasing 持续不断的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不定期的： lacking in steadiness or regularity of occurrence
A: ♣例  The husband’s intermittent employment put the family in a difficult position financially. 丈夫不稳定的工作使得全家陷入了经济上的困境
A: ♣近  aperiodic, casual, catchy, discontinuous, irregular, occasional, spasmodic, sporadic, unsteady
A: ♣反  habitual 习惯的，惯常的；periodic, regular, repeated 定期的，有规律的，重复的

Q:interregnum  [,intə'reɡnəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 过渡期： break in continuity
A: ♣例  The democratic regime proved to be a short-lived interregnum between dictatorships. 这个民主政权被证明只不过是两个独裁政权之间的短暂过渡罢了
A: ♣近  breach, break, gap, interim, interruption, interval, interlude, parenthesis
A: ♣反  continuation, continuity 持续

Q:interrogate  [in'terəuɡeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 质问，审问： to question formally and systematically
A: ♣例  interrogate the prisoner of war for valuable intelligence 审问战俘以获取有价值的情报
A: ♣近  ask, grill, inquire, milk, question
A: ♣反  answer, reply, respond 回答，回复
A: ♣派  interrogation n. 审讯

Q:intimate  ['intimət]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有紧密联系的，亲密无间的： marked by very close association, contact, or familiarity
A: ♣例  intimate friends since childhood 孩童时期以来的密友
A: ♣近  familiar, close, confidential
A: ♣反  distant, remote 疏远的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不为人知的： not known or meant to be known by the general populace
A: ♣例  They broke up after she shared intimate information with all 500 of her closest friends. 在她把那些不为人知的消息告诉了她500个朋友之后，他们分手了
A: ♣近  confidential, esoteric, nonpublic, secret
A: ♣反  open, public 公开的
A: ♠考法3  n. 密友： a person who has a strong liking for and trust in another
A: ♣例  Usually quite aloof in public, he's actually quite relaxed with his intimates. 通常他在大众面前显得比较孤傲，但和好朋友在一起时他却是个很放松的人
A: ♣近  acquaintance, amigo, comrade, confidant, friend, insider, mate
A: ♣反  stranger 陌生人；enemy, foe敌人
A: ♠考法4  v. 迂回地交流，间接地沟通： to communicate delicately and indirectly
A: ♣例  intimate a wish to leave 暗示想离开
A: ♣近  allude, connote, hint, imply, indicate, infer, suggest
A: ♣反  articulate 清晰明确地说

Q:intimidate  [in'timideit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 威吓： to make timid or fearful, frighten
A: ♣例  refused to be intimidated by the manager 对经理的恐吓不为所动
A: ♣近  browbeat, bully, coerce, cow, frighten, hector, terrify
A: ♣反  blandish, cajole, coax 用花言巧语讨好
A: ♣派  intimidation n. 恐吓

Q:intoxicant  [in'tɔksikənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 使人陶醉的东西（尤指酒精饮料）： an agent that intoxicates, especially an alcoholic beverage
A: ♣近  alcohol, liquor, stimulant
A: ♣反  refresher 使人清醒的东西
A: ♣派  intoxicating adj. 使人陶醉的

Q:intransigent  [in'trænsidʒənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不妥协的，固执的： characterized by refusal to compromise or to abandon an extreme position
A: ♣例  an intransigent attitude 不妥协的态度
A: ♣近  adamant, headstrong, intractable, obstinate, pertinacious, stubborn, uncompromising, unyielding
A: ♣反  compliant, pliable 易受影响的；tractable, yielding 容易驾驭的
A: ♣派  intransigence n. 顽固

Q:intrepid  [in'trepid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无畏的： characterized by resolute fearlessness, fortitude, and endurance
A: ♣例  an intrepid explorer 无畏的探险家
A: ♣近  audacious, brave, bold, courageous, dauntless, fearless, gallant, valiant, valorous
A: ♣反  apprehensive 恐惧的；cowardly, craven, gutless, pusillanimous, timorous 怯懦的，胆小的
A: ♣派  intrepidity n. 无所畏惧

Q:intrigue  [in'tri:ɡ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 阴谋： a secret plan for accomplishing evil or unlawful ends
A: ♣例  The intrigue was quickly discovered, and the would-be assassins were arrested. 随着阴谋的迅速识破，未得手的刺客被逮捕了
A: ♣近  conspiracy, design, intrigue, machination, scheme
A: ♠考法2  vt. 激起…的兴趣： to arouse the interest, desire, or curiosity of
A: ♣例  The children are apparently intrigued by the tale. 孩子们很明显被这个传奇故事吸引了
A: ♣近  appeal, attract, enthrall, entice, excite, fascinate, interest, occupy
A: ♣反  ennui, pall 使厌倦
A: ♣派  intriguing adj. 有趣的

Q:intrinsic  [in'trinsik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 固有的，内在的： of or relating to the essential nature of a thing
A: ♣例  the intrinsic worth of a gem 宝石的内在价值
A: ♣近  congenial, constitutional, immanent, inborn, inherent, innate, native, natural
A: ♣反  adventitious, extraneous, extrinsic 外在的

Q:intuitive  [in'tju:itiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 直觉的： knowing or perceiving by intuition
A: ♣例  The twins have an intuitive awareness of each other's feelings. 这对双胞胎天生就能感知彼此的感受
A: ♣近  instinctive
A: ♣反  acquired 后天习得的
A: ♣派  intuition n. 直觉

Q:inundate  ['inʌndeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 淹没： to cover with or as if with flood
A: ♣例  inundated with trash e-mails 被垃圾邮件所淹没
A: ♣近  avalanche, deluge, drown, engulf, overflow, overwhelm, submerge
A: ♣反  drain 排空
A: ♣派  inundation n. 淹没

Q:inure  [i'njuə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使习惯接受不好的东西： to accustom to accept something undesirable
A: ♣例  children inured to violence 习惯了暴力的孩子们
A: ♣近  accustom, familiarize, habituate
A: ♣派  inured adj. 习惯的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使坚强： to make able to withstand physical hardship, strain, or exposure
A: ♣例  The hardship of army training inured her to the rigors of desert warfare. 军营里的艰苦训练把她打造成了能适应沙漠艰苦战事的女兵
A: ♣近  fortify, indurate, season, steel, strengthen, toughen
A: ♣反  enfeeble, soften, weaken, undermine 弱化，使虚弱

Q:invective  [in'vektiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 侮辱性的： of, relating to, or characterized by insult or abuse
A: ♣例  invective comments on female activists 对女权主义者的侮辱性评论
A: ♣近  abusive, opprobrious, scurrile, scurrilous, truculent, vitriolic, vituperative
A: ♣反  adulatory, flattery 阿谀奉承的；complimentary 称赞的

Q:inveigh  [in'vei]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 激烈抗议，表示强烈不满： to protest or complain bitterly or vehemently
A: ♣例  inveighed against the bank industry 对银行业表示强烈不满
A: ♣近  gripe, grouse, object, protest, remonstrate, repine
A: ♣反  support 支持；delight, rejoice 感到高兴

Q:inveigle  [in'veiɡl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 诱骗： to win over by coaxing, flattery, or artful talk
A: ♣例  inveigle consumers into buying the item 诱骗顾客购买商品
A: ♣近  allure, bait, decoy, entice, entrap, seduce, tempt
A: ♣反  demand 强求
A: ♣派  inveigling adj. 诱骗性的

Q:inventory  ['invəntəri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 存货清单： a detailed, itemized list, report, or record of things in one's possession, especially a periodic survey of all goods and materials in stock
A: ♣例  The dealership has an unusually large inventory of pre-owned vehicles. 销售商手中有着一份巨大的二手车库存单
A: ♣近  budget, pool, repertoire, reservoir, stock
A: ♠考法2  n. （写有要点的）简介： a short statement of the main points
A: ♣例  They decided to offer the public an informative inventory of everything that is known about the virus at this time. 他们决定向公众提供一份极富价值的报告，它涵盖了目前为止关于这种病毒的所有认识
A: ♣近  abstract, brief, epitome, outline, résumé, summarization, synopsis

Q:inveterate  [in'vetərət]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 积习的： firmly established by long persistence
A: ♣例  the inveterate tendency to overlook the obvious 总是忽视显而易见事物的习惯
A: ♣近  chronic, entrenched, ingrained, rooted, settled, hard-cored
A: ♣反  adventitious 偶然的

Q:invidious  [in'vidiəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 惹人反感的： tending to cause discontent, animosity, or envy
A: ♣例  the invidious task of arbitration 令人反感的仲裁任务
A: ♣近  abhorrent, detestable, obnoxious, odious, repugnant, repellent
A: ♣反  agreeable, gratifying, pleasant 令人高兴的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 羡慕嫉妒恨的： having or showing mean resentment of another's possessions or advantages
A: ♣例  Inevitably, his remarkable success attracted the invidious attention of the other sales representatives. 不可避免地，他巨大的成功引来了其他销售代表羡慕嫉妒恨的眼光
A: ♣近  covetous, envious, jaundiced, jealous, resentful, green-eyed

Q:invigorate  [in'viɡəreit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使精神，使强壮，鼓舞激励： to impart vigor, strength, or vitality to
A: ♣例  news that invigorates the public 给大众打鸡血的新闻
A: ♣近  animate, energize, fortify, reinforce, strengthen, vitalize
A: ♣反  dampen, deaden, debilitate, emaciate, sap 使衰弱；demoralize 使士气衰落
A: ♣派  invigorated adj. 精力充沛的

Q:invincible  [in'vinsəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不可战胜的，不可超越的： incapable of being conquered, overcome, or subdued
A: ♣例  The soccer team proved to be invincible. 这支球队证明了自己是不可战胜的
A: ♣近  bulletproof, impregnable, invulnerable, unbeatable, unconquerable
A: ♣反  conquerable 可被征服的；surmountable 可超越的；vulnerable 脆弱的，敏感的
A: ♣派  invincibility n. 无敌

Q:invoke  [in'vəuk]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 实施： to put into effect or operation
A: ♣例  New train timetable has been invoked. 新的火车时刻表已经生效
A: ♣近  enforce, effect, execute, implement, perform
A: ♣反  suspend 暂停，搁置
A: ♠考法2  vt. 产生，造成： to be the cause of (a situation, action, or state of mind)
A: ♣例  We should be prepared for the possibility that any solution may invoke another set of problems. 我们必须要为这样一种可能做好心理准备：任何解决方案都可能带来一系列新的问题
A: ♣近  beget, bring, catalyze, cause, create, engender, generate, induce, produce, result

Q:irascible  [i'ræsəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 易怒的： marked by hot temper and easily provoked anger
A: ♣例  The new boss is so irascible that several employees have resigned. 由于新老板太容易发飙，许多员工已经递交了辞呈
A: ♣近  choleric, irritable, peevish, petulant
A: ♣反  affable 和蔼的

Q:irate  [ai'reit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 极其愤怒的： extremely angry
A: ♣例  an irate taxpayer 极为愤怒的纳税人
A: ♣近  aggravated, apoplectic, choleric, enraged, exasperated, infuriated, ireful, mad, wrathful
A: ♣反  calm, halcyon 平静的；delighted, pleased 高兴的，满意的

Q:iridescent  [,iri'desənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 五颜六色的： displaying a play of lustrous colors like those of the rainbow
A: ♣例  an iridescent soap bubble 一个五颜六色的肥皂泡
A: ♣近  nacreous, opalescent, pearlescent
A: ♣反  monochromatic 单色的
A: ♣派  iridescence n. 五彩斑斓

Q:irk  [ə:k]
A: ♠考法1  n. 令人烦恼的事物： something that is a source of irritation
A: ♣例  One of the prof's major irks is a cell phone that rings during a lecture. 课堂上突然响起的手机铃声是最让教授火大的事情之一
A: ♣近  aggravation, bother, exasperation, frustration, headache, irritant, nuisance, vexation
A: ♠考法2  v. 使烦恼，使厌倦： to be irritating, wearisome, or vexing to
A: ♣例  She irked her friends by chewing her gum loudly during the movie. 她因为看电影时嚼口香糖弄出声响而惹怒了她的朋友们
A: ♣近  annoy, bother, fret, gall, provoke, ruffle, vex
A: ♣反  appease, assuage, pacify, placate, propitiate, soothe 安抚，平息
A: ♣派  irksome adj. 令人厌烦的

Q:ironclad  ['aiənklæd]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 非常坚固的，坚不可摧的： so firm or secure as to be unbreakable
A: ♣例  pride on their ironclad fleet 对他们坚不可摧的舰队感到自豪
A: ♣近  firm, invulnerable, secure, sound, tenacious, tough
A: ♣反  fragile 脆弱的

Q:irradicable  [i'rædikəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不能根除的： impossible to uproot or destroy
A: ♣例  Smoking has become an irradicable bad habit for him. 吸烟已成了他不能根除的恶习
A: ♣近  entrenched, ineradicable, ingrained, inveterate, rooted
A: ♣反  eradicable 可根除的

Q:irreducible  [,iri'dju:səbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （数）不可约分的： incapable of being factored into polynomials of lower degree with coefficients in some given field (as the rational numbers) or integral domain (as the integers)
A: ♣例  irreducible integrals 质数
A: ♣反  factorable 可约分的

Q:irrigate  ['iriɡeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 灌溉： to supply (dry land) with water by means of ditches, pipes, or streams; water artificially
A: ♣例  irrigate crops periodically 定期灌溉农作物
A: ♣近  water
A: ♠考法2  vt. 冲洗： to flush (a body part) with a stream of liquid (as in removing a foreign body or medicating)
A: ♣例  irrigate the wound 冲洗伤口
A: ♣近  flush, rinse, wash
A: ♣派  irrigation n. 灌溉

Q:irritate  ['iriteit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 刺激，惹恼： to provoke impatience, anger, or displeasure in
A: ♣例  His rude interruptions really irritated her. 他粗鲁的打断激怒了她
A: ♣近  aggravate, annoy, exasperate, gall, inflame, nettle, peeve, provoke, rile, roil
A: ♣反  appease, assuage, pacify, placate, propitiate, soothe 安抚，平息
A: ♣派  irritant n. 刺激物

Q:issue  ['iʃju:]
A: ♠考法1  n. （有争议的）话题，议题： a matter that is in dispute between two or more parties
A: ♣例  focused on economic and political issues 重点关注经济和政治话题
A: ♣近  nut, problem, question
A: ♠考法2  vi. 发布（期刊等）： to produce and release for distribution in printed form
A: ♣例  plans to issue a monthly newsletter 计划发布新闻月刊
A: ♣近  print
A: ♠考法3  vi. 流出： to go, come, or flow out
A: ♣例  strange sound issued from the abandoned house 废弃房中传来的奇怪声音
A: ♣近  discharge, emit, exude, release, vent
A: ♣反  withdraw 撤回

Q:jabber  ['dʒæbə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 快而不清楚地说： to talk rapidly, indistinctly, or unintelligibly
A: ♣例  monkeys jabbering at each other in their cages 在笼子里唧唧歪歪的猴子
A: ♣近  babble, blabber, drivel, gabble, gibber, jabber, mumbo jumbo
A: ♣反  speak slowly 慢慢地说

Q:jaded  ['dʒeidid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 疲惫的： depleted in strength, energy, or freshness
A: ♣例  After that long bar exam, I'm too jaded for anything but a nap. 律师资格考试结束后，我累得只想睡觉
A: ♣近  drained, exhausted, fatigued, prostrate, spent, wearied, worn-out
A: ♠考法2  adj. 厌倦的，没兴趣没热情的： having one's patience, interest, or pleasure exhausted
A: ♣例  Even jaded sci-fi fans are finding this new space adventure fresh and exciting. 即使是见多识广、口味很挑的科幻小说忠粉也觉得这次的太空探险非常新鲜有趣
A: ♣近  bored, tired, wearied, fed up
A: ♣反  absorbed, engaged, engrossed, interested, intrigued, rapt 有兴趣的

Q:jape  [dʒeip]
A: ♠考法1  v. 嘲弄： to say or do something jokingly or mockingly
A: ♣例  The characters in Oscar Wilde's plays jape with a sophistication that is rarely encountered in real life. 奥斯卡?王尔德戏剧作品中的角色用一种十分世故的态度进行嘲讽，而这种态度在真实生活当中是很少见的
A: ♣近  jest, quip, wisecrack, banter, chaff, gag, jive, jolly, josh
A: ♣反  revere 尊敬

Q:jargon  ['dʒɑ:ɡən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 行业术语： the specialized or technical language of a trade, profession, or similar group
A: ♣例  medical jargon that the layman cannot understand 外行不理解的医学术语
A: ♣近  argot, cant, dialect, jive, lingo, patois

Q:jarring  ['dʒɑ:riŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 刺耳的： harsh or discordant
A: ♣例  the final chord of that song is too jarring for me 那首歌最后的合声部分太刺耳了
A: ♣近  astounding, blindsiding, jolting, startling, stunning
A: ♣反  melodious 音调优美的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 震惊的： causing a strong emotional reaction because of unexpectedness
A: ♣例  the jarring news that major financial institutions were on the verge of collapse 有消息称主要的几个金融机构处于倒闭的边缘，真是让人震惊
A: ♣近  amazing, astonishing, astounding, blindsiding, dumbfounding, flabbergasting, jaw-dropping, jolting, shocking, startling, stunning

Q:jaundice  ['dʒɔ:ndis]
A: ♠考法1  n. （因嫉妒或厌世而产生的）偏见： to affect with the negativity or bitterness of jaundice; bias
A: ♣例  the jaundice in the eyes of the two feuding neighbors 两个有积怨的邻居之间的偏见
A: ♣近  animosity, animus, antagonism, antipathy, gall, hostility, rancor
A: ♣反  amity 和睦，好感

Q:jaunty  ['dʒɔ:nti]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 轻快的，活泼的： sprightly in manner or appearance: lively
A: ♣例  a jaunty stroll 轻快的散步
A: ♣近  animate, brisk, energetic, frisky, perky, racy, spirited, vivacious
A: ♣反  staid, dead, inactive, inanimate, lackadaisical, languid, languishing, leaden, limp, listless, spiritless, vapid 无生气的

Q:jejune  [dʒi'dʒu:n]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无趣乏味的： not interesting; dull
A: ♣例  jejune lectures 无聊的讲座
A: ♣近  arid, drab, dreary, leaden, monotonous, ponderous, tedious, weary
A: ♣反  absorbing, engaging, engrossing, gripping, interesting, intriguing, involving, riveting, thought provoking 促人深思的，吸引人的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 幼稚的： having or showing the annoying qualities (as silliness) associated with children
A: ♣例  an essay filled with jejune, simplistic opinions about international politics 充满着有关国际政治的幼稚、简单看法的文章
A: ♣近  adolescent, immature, infantile, juvenile, kiddish, puerile
A: ♣反  adult, grown-up, mature 成熟的

Q:jeopardy  ['dʒepədi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 危险： risk of loss or injury; peril or danger
A: ♣例  the city's firefighters routinely put their lives in jeopardy 消防队员们早就把生命置之度外了
A: ♣近  distress, endangerment, imperilment, peril
A: ♣反  safeness, safety, secureness, security 安全

A: ♣例  spoken in jest 戏谑地说
A: ♣近  butt, derision, mockery
A: ♣反  solemnity, solemn utterance 严肃

A: ♣反  dove, pacifist, peacenik 反战派人士

A: ♣反  aplomb, calm, composure, equanimity, imperturbability, self-possession, tranquility 镇定，冷静

Q:knotty  ['nɔti]

A: ♣近  baroque, byzantine, complicated, convoluted, intricate, involved, labyrinthine, sophisticated, tangled
A: ♣反  easy, effortless, plain, simple 容易的，明显的

Q:kudos  ['kju:dəuz]

A: ♣例  Employees enjoy the kudos that the job brings as much as the financial rewards. 正如同喜欢工作带来的经济回报一样，雇员们也很享受工作所带来的名声和荣誉
A: ♣近  credit, distinction, homage, honor, laurels
A: ♣反  infamy, notoriety 不好的名声
A: ♠考法2  n. 夸奖，赞扬： acclaim or praise for exceptional achievement
A: ♣例  The attorney did pro bono work because it was the right thing to do, and not for any future kudos that it might bring. 这名律师之所以为慈善机构和穷人所提供免费服务，是因为他觉得这是正确的事情，而非为了任何可能因此而产生的赞扬
A: ♣近  acclaim, accolade, applause, credit, distinction, homage, honor, laud, laurels
A: ♣反  belittlement, denigration, deprecation, derogation, diminishment, disparagement 贬损

A: ♣近  capricious, fluctuating, fluid, inconstant, mercurial, temperamental, unsettled, unsteady, variable, volatile
A: ♣反  constant, immutable, invariable, stable, stationary, steady 稳定的

Q:laborious  [lə'bɔ:riəs]

A: ♣近  baroque, byzantine, complicate, complicated, convoluted, intricate, involved, knotty, sophisticated, tangled
A: ♣反  easy, effortless, plain, simple 容易的，明显的

Q:laconic  [lə'kɔnik]

A: ♣例  His mentor’s comment tends to be laconic but very much to the point. 他导师的点评很简短，但是却总能说到点子上
A: ♣近  apothegmatic, brief, capsule, compact, compendious, curt, pithy, succinct, summary, telegraphic, terse
A: ♣反  circuitous, circumlocutory, diffuse, prolix, rambling, verbose, windy, wordy 冗长的

Q:lag  [læɡ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 最终的，最后的： following all others of the same kind in order or time
A: ♣例  We're now in the lag end of the project. 现在我们到了项目的尾声阶段。
A: ♣近  bottommost, closing, concluding, final, hindmost, last, latest, rearmost, terminal, terminating, ultimate
A: ♣反  beginning, earliest, first, foremost, inaugural, initial, maiden, opening, original, pioneer, primary 最初的
A: ♠考法2  vi. 缓慢行走： to proceed or develop with comparative slowness
A: ♣例  The tired puppy was lagging behind the rest of the pack. 疲倦的小狗在队伍的后面缓缓地走着。
A: ♣近  crawl, creep, dally, dawdle, dillydally, linger, loiter, mope, poke, tarry
A: ♣近  blast, bolt, bustle, careen, career, dash, fly, hustle, rush, rustle, speed, whirl 疾行，快速行走
A: ♠考法3  vi. 萎靡，失去活力： to lose bodily strength or vigor
A: ♣例  During the fourth quarter the whole team seemed to lag. 到了第四节整支队伍似乎都已经精疲力竭了。
A: ♣近  decay, droop, emaciate, fade, fail, languish, sink, waste, wilt, wither
A: ♣反  convalesce, rally, rebound, recover, recuperate 康复，复原
A: ♣派  lagging n. 延迟

A: ♣近  bemoan, deplore, grieve, moan, mourn, wail

Q:lance  [lɑ:ns]

A: ♣近  javelin, pike, shaft, spear
A: ♠考法2  vt. 刺穿，刺破： to penetrate or hold (something) with a pointed object
A: ♣例  Doctors used to lance infected sores, so that they could drain clean. 以前医生会刺破受感染的疮，从而使脓液流出。
A: ♣近  gore, harpoon, jab, pierce, puncture, spike, stab, stick
A: ♣派  lancer n. 枪骑兵

Q:languid  ['læŋɡwid]

A: ♣反  animated, energetic, vehement, vivacious 有精力的；mighty, powerful, stalwart, stout, strong 强壮的

Q:languish  ['læŋɡwiʃ]

A: ♣例  languishing during the prolonged heat wave 在持续的热浪下变得虚弱
A: ♣近  decay, droop, emaciate, fade, fail, flag, sag, wither
A: ♣反  burgeon, flourish, thrive, prosper 旺盛生长

Q:languor  ['læŋɡə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 懒惰： physical or mental inertness
A: ♣例  He enjoyed the languor brought on by a hot summer afternoon. 他很享受夏日午后的慵懒
A: ♣近  collapse, exhaustion, frazzle, lassitude, listlessness, stupor, torpor, prostration
A: ♣反  verve, vim,animation,vitality 有活力
A: ♠考法2  n. 衰弱： weakness or weariness of body or mind
A: ♣例  The tropical heat sapped our strength, leaving us in a state of unaccustomed languor. 热带的炎热气候消磨着我们的力量，让我们感到一阵虚弱的不适
A: ♣近  debilitation, enervation, enfeeblement, fragility, infirmity
A: ♣反  robustness, strength, vivacity 强壮，有力

Q:lank  [læŋk]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 细长瘦弱的： long, straight, and limp; not stiff in structure
A: ♣例  a woman with long, lank hair 有着长而稀疏头发的女子
A: ♣近  emaciated, lean, slender, svelte, tenuous, thin
A: ♣反  fat, fleshy, gross, obese 肥胖的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不僵硬的，柔软松弛的： not stiff in structure
A: ♣例  Right after a shower, her lank hair hung down to her shoulders. 刚出浴的她柔软的头发搭在她的肩上
A: ♣近  droopy, flaccid, floppy, lank, yielding
A: ♣反  inflexible, rigid, stiff, sturdy, tense 僵硬的；resilient 有弹性的

Q:lapse  [læps]
A: ♠考法1  n. 小过失： a slight error typically due to forgetfulness or inattention
A: ♣例  a lapse in table manner 餐桌礼仪的小过错
A: ♣近  blunder, fumble, gaffe, miscue, oversight, peccadillo
A: ♠考法2  v. 结束，终止： to come to an end
A: ♣例  The contract will lapse at the end of the year. 合同将于年底到期
A: ♣近  cease, conclude, die, end, expire, finish, stop, terminate
A: ♣反  continue, persist, hang on 持续

Q:largesse  [lɑ:'dʒes]
A: ♠考法1  n. 捐赠物： something given to someone without expectation of a return
A: ♣例  The alumna's huge bequest was an unexpected largess. 校友们的巨额遗赠是一笔意料之外的财富
A: ♣近  bestowal, donation, giveaway, present
A: ♠考法2  n. 慷慨： liberality in giving or willingness to give
A: ♣例  be noted for his largesse 因慷慨而闻名
A: ♣近  bountifulness, generosity, munificence, openhandedness, philanthropy
A: ♣反  miserliness, parsimony, penury, stinginess 小气

Q:lash  [læʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 击打： a hard strike with a part of the body or an instrument
A: ♣例  suddenly felt the lash of her drunken husband's hand on her cheek 突然感觉到脸颊被醉酒的丈夫扇了一耳光
A: ♣近  bang, bash, bat, beat, clap, hit, knock, punch, slam, slap, smash, stinger, stroke, swat
A: ♠考法2  v. 猛击，撞击： to strike against with force or violence
A: ♣例  All night long a barrage of rain lashed the windows. 倾盆大雨整夜敲击着窗户
A: ♣近  baste, hammer, lace, lambaste, punch
A: ♠考法3  vt. 捆扎： to bind with or as if with a line
A: ♣例  Secure the anchor by lashing it to the rail. 通过将锚绑在栏杆上使其稳固。
A: ♣反  unbind 解开

Q:lassitude  ['læsitju:d]
A: ♠考法1  n. 乏力，没精打采： a state or feeling of weariness, diminished energy, or listlessness
A: ♣例  Symptoms of anaemia include general fatigue and lassitude. 贫血的通常症状包括体虚和乏力
A: ♣近  collapse, exhaustion, frazzle, languor, listlessness, stupor, torpor, prostration
A: ♣反  verve, vim,animation,vitality 有活力

Q:latent  ['leitənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 潜在的，不活跃的： present or potential but not evident or active
A: ♣例  a latent infection 潜伏性传染病‖He has a latent talent for acting that he hasn't had a chance to express yet. 他有着表演的天赋，只不过他还没有机会来表现这一才能
A: ♣近  dormant, fallow, inert, inoperative
A: ♣反  apparent, evident, manifest, obvious, plain 明显的；active 活跃的
A: ♣派  latency n. 潜伏期

Q:latitude  ['lætitju:d]
A: ♠考法1  n. （行动或言论）自由： freedom from normal restraints, limitations, or regulations
A: ♣例  Students are allowed considerable latitude in choosing courses. 学生在选课时被给予相当大的自由度
A: ♣近  authorization, license, freedom, leeway, free hand
A: ♣反  limitation 限制；custody 监护，拘留

Q:laudatory  ['lɔ:dətəri]
