A: ♣例  a laudatory review of the new play 对新剧目的赞扬性的评论
A: ♣近  adulatory, commendatory, complimentary, extolling, eulogistic, panegyric
A: ♣反  derogatory, depreciatory, disparaging, pejorative 贬低的
A: ♣派  laudable adj. 值得赞扬的

Q:lavish  ['læviʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 奢侈大量的： characterized by or produced with extravagance and profusion
A: ♣例  lavish buffet 奢侈的自助餐
A: ♣近  copious, exuberant, gushing, lush, luxuriant, opulent, profuse, riotous
A: ♣反  moderate, modest, reasonable, temperate 适度的，合理的
A: ♠考法2  v. 挥霍，浪费： to give readily and in large quantities; to use up carelessly
A: ♣例  a great actor who lavished his talent in lousy movies 将才华浪费在低劣电影上的影星
A: ♣近  blow, dissipate, fritter, misspend, squander, waste
A: ♣反  conserve 节约

Q:lax  [læks]

A: ♣例  exercises to improve lax muscles 锻炼松弛的肌肉‖The guidelines for the essay contest were fairly lax, permitting a wide variety of topics. 本次作文大赛的要求相对比较宽松，允许写多种类型的主题。
A: ♣近  flabby, flaccid, insecure, loose, loosened, relaxed, slackened, unsecured
A: ♣反  taut, tense, tight 紧固的，牢固的；hard, harsh, rigid, rigorous, severe, stern, strict 严格的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 懈怠的，漫不经心的： failing to give proper care and attention
A: ♣例  The university has been lax about enforcing these rules. 学校对于这些规定的施行显得漫不经心。
A: ♣近  careless, derelict, disregardful, heedless, lazy, neglectful, neglecting, negligent, remiss, slack
A: ♣反  attentive, careful, cautious, conscientious, heedful, mindful, vigilant, wary 注意的，留心的

Q:leaven  ['levn]

A: ♣例  He needs to leaven his speeches with more humor. 他需要在演讲中再加入点幽默元素。
A: ♣近  imbue, infuse, ingrain, inoculate, inspire, permeate, steep, suffuse
A: ♣反  extract 抽取

Q:leer  [liə]

A: ♣近  squint
A: ♣反  gape, gaze, glare, goggle, stare 盯着看

Q:leery  ['liəri]

Q:legacy  ['leɡəsi]

Q:legend  ['ledʒənd]
A: ♠考法1  n. 传奇，传说： a popular myth of recent origin
A: ♣例  Some ancient civilizations had legends about spirits that inhabited trees and rocks. 许多古老的文明都有着关于寄居于树木、岩石之中的灵魂的传说
A: ♣近  fable, myth, mythos
A: ♠考法2  n. 图例： an explanatory list of the symbols on a map or chart
A: ♣例  The legend in the science textbook indicated that the accompanying picture had been enlarged by 1000%. 科学课本上彩图的图例告诉我们这幅图片被放大了十倍
A: ♣近  cutline
A: ♣派  legendary adj. 如传奇般闻名的

Q:legion  ['li:dʒən]

A: ♣近  army, battalion, flock, herd, horde, mob, swarm, throng

A: ♣例  The problems are legion. 问题不计其数
A: ♣近  beaucoup, multifold, multitudinous, numerous
A: ♣反  few, lack in number 少量的

Q:lenient  ['li:njənt]

Q:lethal  ['li:θəl]

A: ♣近  baleful, deadly, deathly, fatal, mortal, murderous, pestilent, terminal, vital
A: ♣反  innocuous 无害的； healthy, salubrious, wholesome 有益健康的

Q:lethargic  [le'θɑ:dʒik]

A: ♣例  a big nice meal always makes me feel lethargic and sleepy 一顿大餐吃完总是让我既慵懒又想睡
A: ♣近  dull, inert, quiescent, sluggish, torpid
A: ♣反  dynamic, energetic, robust, vigorous 有精力的；active 活跃的

Q:levelheaded  ['levəl'hedid]

A: ♣近  informed, justified, logical, rational, reasonable, sensible, sober, valid, well-founded
A: ♣反  foolish 愚蠢的；groundless, invalid, unfounded, unjustified, unsound 没有根据的，理由不充分的

Q:levity  ['levəti]

Q:liability  [,laiə'biləti]

A: ♣近  burden, debit, drawback, handicap, hurdle, incommodity, manacle, saddle, trammel
A: ♣反  advantage, asset, edge, plus 优点，优势

Q:liberal  ['libərəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 思想前卫的： not bound by traditional ways or beliefs
A: ♣例  parents who take a very liberal attitude toward letting their children stay out late 思想开放，同意让他们的小孩晚归的家长们
A: ♣近  nonconventional, nonorthodox, nontraditional, open-minded, progressive, radical
A: ♣反  conservative, conventional, hidebound, old-fashioned, stodgy, traditional 守旧的，传统的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 慷慨的，大方的： marked by generosity
A: ♣例  a doctor who has been very liberal in dispensing low-cost care to patients who could not otherwise afford it 一个慷慨的医生，愿意帮助无法支付低额药费的病人
A: ♣近  charitable, munificent, unselfish, unsparing, unstinting
A: ♣反  closefisted, miserly, niggardly, parsimonious, stingy, tightfisted 吝啬的

Q:libertine  ['libəti:n]
A: ♠考法1  n. 放荡不羁者： one who acts without moral restraint; a dissolute person
A: ♣例  The legend of Don Juan depicts him as a playboy and libertine. 有关唐璜的传说把他描绘成一个放荡不羁的花花公子
A: ♣近  backslider, debaucher, decadent, deviate, pervert, profligate
A: ♣反  ascetic 禁欲者

Q:license  ['laisəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 许可，认可： the approval by someone in authority for the doing of something
A: ♣例  The company is seeking license to operate several more power plants in the state. 公司正在寻求在国内建造更多电厂的许可。‖A restaurant owner has to get a license to serve food and drink. 餐厅营业者必须要获得食物和饮品的销售许可。
A: ♣近  allowance, authorization, clearance, concurrence, consent, empowerment, granting, sanction, warrant
A: ♣反  interdiction, prohibition, proscription 禁止
A: ♠考法2  n. 自由： the right to act or move freely
A: ♣例  Military commanders on the ground must be granted considerable license, as wars cannot be micromanaged by people back in Washington. 战地指挥官应该被赋予相当大的自由，因为一场战争只靠华盛顿的人是不可能打赢的。
A: ♣近  freedom, latitude, liberty
A: ♣反  confinement, custody, imprisonment 拘留，囚禁
A: ♠考法3  n. 放荡： disregard for standards of personal conduct
A: ♣例  a night of drinking and license at the nightclub 夜店里放纵饮酒取乐的一夜
A: ♣近  debauchery, hedonism, libertinage, libertinism, licentiousness, profligacy, voluptuousness
A: ♣反  abstinence, asceticism, sobriety, temperance 节制，克制
A: ♠考法4  vt. 准许，授权使用： to permit

Q:licentious  [lai'senʃəs]

A: ♣例  a moralist who decried what she regarded as the licentious and corrupt culture of the entertainment industry 一个公开谴责在她看来无比堕落和放荡的娱乐圈文化的道德家

A: ♣反  frigid, undersex 性冷淡的
A: ♣派  licentiousness n. 放荡

Q:liken  ['laikən]

A: ♣近  analogize, bracket, equate, equalize
A: ♣反  contrast 对比，对照以产生反差

Q:limber  ['limbə]

A: ♣例  She shaped the basket out of limber branches. 她用柔软的树枝编了一个筐
A: ♣近  flexible, lissome, lithesome, pliable, pliant, supple
A: ♣反  inflexible, rigid, stiff, stiffened 僵硬的

Q:limp  [limp]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 柔软的，松散的： lacking firm texture, substance, or structure
A: ♣例  Her hair hung limp about her shoulders. 她的头发软沓沓地垂在肩上
A: ♣近  droopy, flaccid, floppy, lank, yielding
A: ♣反  firm, stiff, sturdy, tense 坚硬的；resilient 有弹性的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 软弱的，没有精神的： lacking strength or firmness; weak or spiritless
A: ♣例  The team's limp performance has many people calling for the head coach's resignation. 队伍不给力的表现让许多人呼吁教练下课
A: ♣近  enervated, lackadaisical, languid, languishing, languorous, spiritless
A: ♣反  ambitious, enterprising 有雄心壮志的； animated, energetic, motivated 精力充沛的，有积极性的
A: ♠考法3  vi. 跛行，艰难地行走： to move or proceed haltingly or unsteadily
A: ♣近  The project limped along with half its previous funding. 项目靠着之前一半的资金艰难地进展
A: ♣近  blunder, bumble, lumber, plod, struggle, stumble, trudge

Q:limpid  ['limpid]

A: ♣例  limpid streams 清澈的小溪
A: ♣近  crystal, clear, lucent, pellucid, transparent
A: ♣反  cloudy, murky, opaque, unclear, turbid 模糊不清的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 镇定的，淡定的： free from emotional or mental agitation

A: ♣近  collected, composed, cool, level, peaceful, placid, possessed, sedate, serene, smooth, tranquil
A: ♣反  agitated, discomposed, disturbed, flustered, perturbed 焦躁的

A: ♣反  hurry, run, rush 飞奔
A: ♣派  lingering adj. 闲荡的

A: ♣反  abase, degrade, demean, humble, humiliate 贬低，瞧不起

Q:lissome  ['lisəm]

A: ♣例  Rattan is such a lissome material that it can be used for all manner of furniture and baskets. 藤是一种非常柔软而有韧性的材料，因此可以被用于形形色色的家具和篮子之中
A: ♣近  flexible, limber, lithe, pliable, pliant, supple
A: ♣反  solid 坚硬的；inflexible, rigid, stiff, stiffened 僵硬的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 敏捷的，轻盈的： having the ability to move with ease; limber
A: ♣例  a lissome ballerina 身姿矫捷的女芭蕾舞演员
A: ♣近  agile, featly, feline, gracile, lithesome, nimble
A: ♣反  awkward, clumsy, graceless, ungainly 笨拙的

Q:list  [list]

A: ♣反  solid 坚硬的；inflexible, rigid, stiff, stiffened 僵硬的

Q:loath  [ləuθ]

A: ♣近  disinclined, indisposed, reluctant, reticent
A: ♣反  eager 渴望的；disposed, inclined 有意向的

Q:loathe  [ləuð]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 厌恶： to dislike someone or something greatly; abhor
A: ♣例  I loathe having to do this. 我鄙视不得不这样做。
A: ♣近  abhor, abominate, despise, detest, execrate
A: ♣反  adore, love 热爱
A: ♣派  loathsome adj. 令人讨厌的

Q:lofty  ['lɔfti]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 崇高的： elevated in character and spirit, noble
A: ♣例  lofty ideals 崇高的理想
A: ♣近  chivalrous, elevated, greathearted, high-minded, magnanimous, sublime
A: ♣反  base, debased, ignominious, mean 可耻的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 高的： rising to a great height
A: ♣例  lofty mountains 高耸的山峰‖the ever-increasing lofty heights of the world's skyscrapers 不断攀升的摩天大楼的高度
A: ♣近  altitudinous, tall, towering
A: ♣反  low 低的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 自大的： having a feeling of superiority that shows itself in an overbearing attitude
A: ♣例  She acts all lofty and superior just because she went to Stanford University. 她之所以表现得这么自大和不可一世，只因为她考进了斯坦福
A: ♣近  assumptive, bumptious, haughty, lordly, peremptory, pompous, presumptuous, supercilious, superior
A: ♣反  humble, lowly, modest 谦逊的，低调的

Q:loll  [lɔl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 懒洋洋地行动： to act or move in a lax, lazy, or indolent manner
A: ♣例  He lolled back in his comfortable chair. 他懒洋洋地倚在他舒适的椅子上
A: ♣近  slouch, lounge
A: ♠考法2  vi. 偷懒，打发时间： to spend time doing nothing
A: ♣例  Some members of the decorating committee were hard at work, and others were just lolling about. 装修队的一部分人在很努力的工作，另一些则在偷懒
A: ♣近  dally, dawdle, drone, laze

Q:lopsided  ['lɔp'saidid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 歪的，倾斜的： leaning to one side
A: ♣例  The portrait in the foyer was lopsided. 门厅里的画像挂歪了
A: ♣近  askew, aslant, crazy, listing, oblique, pitched, skewed, slanted, tipping, uneven
A: ♣反  even, level, straight 平的
A: ♠考法2  adj.不平衡的，不协调的： lacking in balance, symmetry, or proportion
A: ♣例  The arrangement of the furniture was lopsided. 家具的摆放太不协调了‖a lopsided score of 4-0 四比零的压倒比分
A: ♣近  asymmetric, disproportional, irregular, off-balance, unbalanced, unequal
A: ♣反  balanced 平衡的；symmetrical 对称的

Q:loquacious  [ləu'kweiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 话多的： given to fluent or excessive talk
A: ♣例  Sometimes the loquacious talk show host barely lets her guests get a word in. 有时候多话的脱口秀主持人让她的客人一句话都插不进来
A: ♣近  chatty, conservational, gabby, garrulous, talkative, voluble
A: ♣反  laconic, reserved, reticent, taciturn, uncommunicative 话少的
A: ♣派  loquaciousness, loquacity n.话多

Q:loutish  ['lautiʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 粗鲁的： having the characteristics of a lout; awkward, stupid, and boorish
A: ♣例  a boy with a loutish air 一个举止粗鲁的男孩
A: ♣近  boorish, churlish, clumsy, crude, discourteous, uncouth, uncivilized, uncultured, unrefined
A: ♣反  courteous, civilized, genteel, graceful, polished, refined, urbane有教养的
A: ♣派  lout n. 举止粗鲁的人

Q:lubricate  ['lubrikeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使润滑： to coat (something) with a slippery substance in order to reduce friction
A: ♣例  lubricate the gears 给齿轮打润滑油
A: ♣近  grease, oil, slick, smooth, wax
A: ♣派  lubricant n.润滑剂

Q:lucid  ['lju:sid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有光亮的： suffused with light
A: ♣例  Those lucid bands that spread across the arctic sky are known as aurora borealis, or the northern lights. 那些蔓延在北极的天空中光带就是北极光
A: ♣近  beaming, brilliant, dazzling, glowing, incandescent, lucent, luminous, lustrous, radiant, refulgent, splendid
A: ♣反  dim, dull, lackluster 黯淡无光的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 神志清醒的： having full use of one's mind and control over one's actions
A: ♣例  decided to make out her will while she was still lucid 决定趁着她神志还清醒，列出她的遗愿
A: ♣近  balanced, clearheaded, normal, right, sane, stable
A: ♣反  brainsick, crazy, insane, lunatic, mad, maniac 疯狂的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 表达清晰的, 简单易懂的： easily understood
A: ♣例  The teaching assistant tried to make his instructions as lucid as possible so that everyone would understand what to do. 助教努力使自己的指令容易理解，从而让所有人都知道应该要干什么
A: ♣近  apprehensible, clear, comprehensible, intelligible, palpable, patent, pellucid, plain, understandable
A: ♣反  ambiguous, enigmatic, equivocal, indistinct, obfuscated, obscure, unclear 模糊不明确的

Q:ludicrous  ['lju:dikrəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 荒唐的，可笑的： meriting derisive laughter or scorn as absurdly inept, false, or foolish
A: ♣例  He made a ludicrous and easily detected attempt to forge his father’s signature on a note to school. 他试图在要上交学校的纸条上伪造父亲的签名，这实在是既可笑又容易被发现的花招。
A: ♣近  absurd, comical, derisive, derisory, farcical, laughable, ridiculous, pathetic, preposterous, risible, silly
A: ♣反  logical, rational, reasonable, sensible 有道理的

Q:lug  [lʌɡ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 拖动，拉动： to cause to follow by applying steady force on
A: ♣例  lugged the lawn mower out into the backyard 把割草机拖进院子
A: ♣近  drag, draw, hale, pull, tow, tug
A: ♣反  drive, propel, push 推动
A: ♠考法2  vt. 费力搬运： to carry laboriously
A: ♣例  I don't understand why he's always lugging all of his books around when his locker is right over there. 我真搞不懂为什么他总是明明在有锁柜的情况下还随身扛着所有的书
A: ♣近  bear, cart, convey, ferry, haul, lug, pack, tote, transport

Q:lugubrious  [lu:'ɡju:briəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （故作夸张的）悲哀的： mournful, dismal, or gloomy, especially to an exaggerated or ludicrous degree
A: ♣例  his lugubrious tear-stained face他忧郁而带着泪痕的脸庞
A: ♣近  deploring, doleful, dolorous, lamentable, melancholy, morose, plaintive, rueful, saturnine, sullen, woeful
A: ♣反  cheerful, delighted, jocund, jovial 快乐的

Q:lull  [lʌl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 相对平静时期，间隙： a momentary halt in an activity
A: ♣例  the lull before the storm 暴风雨前的平静
A: ♣近  break, breath, interruption, recess
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使镇静，使安心： to free from distress or disturbance
A: ♣例  The absence of attacks for such an extended period had lulled the nation into a false sense of security. 长期以来没有遭受攻击让这个国家产生了一种错误的安全感
A: ♣近  allay, balm, becalm, compose, lullaby, quiet, salve, settle, soothe, still, tranquilize
A: ♣反  agitate, discompose, disquiet, disturb, perturb, upset, vex 打扰，扰乱

Q:lullaby  ['lʌləbai]
A: ♠考法1  n. 催眠曲： a song to quiet children or lull them to sleep
A: ♣例  sang a lullaby to the baby every night 每晚都给孩子唱摇篮曲
A: ♣近  berceuse, cradlesong
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使镇静，使安心： to free from distress or disturbance
A: ♣例  reclining peacefully on the deck, lullabied by the gentle motion of the ship 躺卧在甲板上，随着船轻轻的颠簸放松下来
A: ♣近  allay, balm, becalm, compose, lull, quiet, salve, settle, soothe, still, tranquilize
A: ♣反  agitate, discompose, disquiet, disturb, perturb, upset, vex 打扰，扰乱

Q:lumber  ['lʌmbə]

A: ♣例  A huge amount of lumber will be needed to build the house. 建这栋房子需要大量的木材
A: ♣近  timber, wood
A: ♠考法2  vi. 笨拙地行动： to walk or move with heavy clumsiness
A: ♣例  The elephant lumbered through the jungle. 大象缓缓地穿越丛林
A: ♣近  flounder, plod, stumble, trudge
A: ♣反  glide, slide 轻松地滑动
A: ♠考法3  vi. 使负担（从而拖累）： to place a weight or burden on
A: ♣例  lumber the expedition with unnecessary equipment and supplies 不必要的仪器和补给品给此次远征徒增了许多负担
A: ♣近  burden, encumber, freight, lade, laden, saddle, weight
A: ♣反  disburden, discharge, disencumber, unlade, unload 卸下，解脱

Q:luminary  ['lju:minəri]

A: ♣例  Buddhist luminary 佛学大师‖Luminaries from the worlds of sports, entertainment, and politics were at the gala. 全球体育界、娱乐圈和政界的名人都出席了此次盛会
A: ♣近  celebrity, eminence, figure, icon, notability, star, superstar
A: ♣反  nobody, nonentity 小人物

Q:luminous  ['lju:minəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 发光的，有光泽的： emitting or reflecting usually steady, suffused, or glowing light
A: ♣例  The luminous moon bathed the snow-covered fields with a pearly glow. 在明亮的月光下，雪地仿佛被罩上了一层珍珠般的光晕。
A: ♣近  beaming, bright, candescent, dazzling, effulgent, glowing, incandescent, lambent, lucent, lucid, lustrous, radiant, refulgent, shiny, splendid
A: ♣反  dim, dull, lackluster 黯淡无光的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 杰出的，重要的： standing above others in rank, importance, or achievement
A: ♣例  some of the most luminous writers in the nation’s history 该国历史上最杰出的一批作家
A: ♣近  astral, brilliant, distinguished, illustrious, notable, noteworthy, preeminent, prestigious, redoubtable, signal
A: ♣反  average, inferior, mediocre 一般的，中庸的
A: ♣派  luminosity n. 发光；亮度

Q:lurch  [lə:tʃ]

A: ♣近  careen, dodder, falter, reel, stagger, stumble, teeter, totter, waddle
A: ♣反  progress smoothly 平稳前进；march, stride, swagger 游行，大步走

Q:lurid  ['ljuərid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 恐怖的，令人反感的： causing horror or revulsion
A: ♣例  We quickly drove past the lurid scene of the crash. 我们迅速驶过了可怕的车祸现场。
A: ♣近  appalling, atrocious, dreadful, frightful, ghastly, gruesome, hideous, horrid, horrific, macabre, monstrous, nightmarish
A: ♣近  agreeable, appealing, delicious, delightful, enjoyable, enticing, inviting, pleasant, satisfying 令人愉悦的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 面色苍白的，病态的： wan and ghastly pale in appearance
A: ♣例  The doctor was alarmed by the patient's lurid complexion. 病人惨白的面色给医生敲响了警钟。
A: ♣近  ashen, ashy, blanched, cadaverous, doughy, livid, mealy, paled, pallid, pasty, peaked, wan
A: ♣近  blooming, florid, flush, full-blooded, glowing, rosy, rubicund, ruddy, sanguine 红润的，健康的

Q:lurk  [lə:k]

A: ♣近  ambush, snake, steal
A: ♣反  appear, come out 出来

Q:lush  [lʌʃ]

A: ♣例  lush grass 茂盛的草
A: ♣近  booming, exuberant, flourishing, lively, luxuriant, rampant, thriving, verdant, vivacious
A: ♣反  blighted, faded, sere, withered 干枯的，凋谢的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 多产的： producing abundantly
A: ♣例  His lush fields were the envy of neighboring farmers. 他富饶多产的土地让邻居羡慕嫉妒恨
A: ♣近  cornucopian, fecund, fruitful, productive, prolific, rich
A: ♣反  barren, dead, infertile, sterile, unproductive 贫瘠的
A: ♠考法3  adj. （声音、味道）优美的，令人愉悦的： appealing to the senses
A: ♣例  the lush sounds of the orchestra 管弦乐队奏出的悦耳声音

A: ♣反  flat, flavorless, insipid, stale, tasteless 乏味的

Q:lustrous  ['lʌstrəs]

A: ♣近  brilliant, burnished, gleaming, glistening, glossy, polished, refulgent, rubbed, shining, sleek, splendid
A: ♣反  dim, dull, lackluster, lusterless 昏暗的

Q:luxurious  [lʌk'zjuəriəs]

A: ♣例  squandered his family fortune in the relentless satisfaction of his luxurious tastes 为满足他奢侈的品味而挥霍家族的财产
A: ♣近  decadent, indulgent, overindulgent, self-indulgent, sybaritic
A: ♣反  abstemious, abstinent 克制的
A: ♣派  luxury n. 豪华；奢侈，奢侈品

Q:lyric  ['lirik]
A: ♠考法1  n. （可以哼唱的）小曲： a short musical composition for the human voice often with instrumental accompaniment
A: ♣例  The guitarist improvised and sang a gentle lyric while playing. 吉他手在弹奏的过程中即兴创作并哼唱了一首小曲
A: ♣近  ballad, ditty, jingle, vocal
A: ♠考法2  adj. 如诗歌般流畅甜美的： having a pleasantly flowing quality suggestive of poetry or music
A: ♣例  The film's lyric photography really enhanced its romantic mood. 电影中如诗歌般的图像效果着实增强了浪漫的氛围
A: ♣近  euphonious, lyrical, mellifluous, mellow, melodious, musical, poetical
A: ♣反  prosaic, prose 无聊乏味的
A: ♣派  lyrics n. 歌词

Q:macabre  [mə'kɑ:brə]

A: ♣例  Impressively, Plants vs. Zombies presented a supposedly macabre themeinsuch anenjoyableway. 令人难忘的是，《植物大战僵尸》将一个本应该十分恐怖的主题用一种如此欢乐的方式呈现出来
A: ♣近  appalling, atrocious, dreadful, ghastly, gruesome, hideous, horrific, nightmarish, terrific
A: ♣反  agreeable, delightful, enjoyable, pleasant 令人愉悦的

Q:macerate  ['mæsəreit]

A: ♣近  drench, drown, impregnate, saturate, sodden, sop, souse, steep
A: ♣反  wring 拧干；dehydrate, desiccate, parch, sorch, sear 烤干，烤焦

Q:machination  [,mæki'neiʃən]

A: ♣例  The incredibly complicated machination to assassinate the president inevitably failed. 刺杀总统的诡计极其复杂，以至于不可避免地失败了。
A: ♣近  conspiracy, design, intrigue, plot, scheme

Q:maculate  ['mækjuleit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 使有斑点，弄脏： to spot, blemish
A: ♣例  Her reputation was maculated after the affair with a married man. 自从被指与一个已婚男士有染之后，她的名声受到了影响
A: ♣近  besmirch, dot, dirty,soil, spot,stain
A: ♣反  clean, cleanse, purify, wash 清洗，弄干净
A: ♣派  maculated adj. 有斑点的

Q:madcap  ['mædkæp]
A: ♠考法1  n. 热爱冒险的人： a person who seeks out very dangerous or foolhardy adventures with no apparent fear
A: ♣例  an incorrigible madcap who loves drag racing and white-water rafting 一个热爱飙车和激流竹筏的无药可救的冒险狂
A: ♣近  daredevil, madman
A: ♠考法2  adj. 大胆的，鲁莽的： behaving or acting impulsively or rashly;foolishly adventurous or bold
A: ♣例  They switched from one madcap scheme to another. 他们从一个鲁莽的方案换到了另一个。
A: ♣近  audacious, bold, brash, daredevil, overbold, overconfident, reckless, temerarious
A: ♣反  careful, cautious, circumspect, guarded, heedful, prudent, wary 谨慎的，小心的

Q:maelstrom  ['meilstrɔm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 漩涡： a powerful often violent whirlpool sucking in objects within a given radius
A: ♣例  Their raft got caught in a maelstrom. 他们的筏被一个漩涡卷住了
A: ♣近  gulf, vortex, whirlpool
A: ♠考法2  n. 混乱、动荡的局势： a violent or turbulent situation
A: ♣例  the maelstrom of war 战争带来的乱世
A: ♣近  chaos, disorder, pandemonium, tulmult, turmoil, upheaval, uproar
A: ♣反  calm 风平浪静

Q:magnificent  [mæɡ'nifisənt]

A: ♣例  a magnificent cathedral 宏伟壮观的大教堂
A: ♣近  august, epic, glorious, grand, imperial, imposing, massive, monumental, noble, regal, splendid
A: ♣反  humble, unimpressive 平凡的
A: ♣派  magnificence n. 壮丽，壮观

Q:magnitude  ['mæɡnitju:d]

A: ♣例  The magnitude of the issue is severely underestimated. 这个事件的重要性被严重低估了。

A: ♣反  insignificance, littleness, puniness, slightness, smallness, triviality 不重要
A: ♠考法2  n. 巨大： greatness in size or extent
A: ♣例  The mountain's sheer magnitude usually leaves tourists speechless. 巨大的山脉往往让旅游者哑口无言。
A: ♣近  enormousness, giantism, gigantism, hugeness, immenseness, massiveness, prodigiousness, vastness
A: ♣反  diminutiveness, minuteness, tininess 微小

Q:maladroit  [,mælə'drɔit]

A: ♣反  adroit,ambidexterous, deft, dexterous, handy 灵巧的

Q:malaise  [mæ'leiz]

A: ♣近  debility, decrepitude, disease, feebleness, infirmity, infirmness, sickliness, unhealthiness

Q:malcontent  ['mælkən,tent]
A: ♠考法1  n. 不满分子： one who is in active opposition to an established order or government
A: ♣例  The chaos was caused by a handful of malcontents. 混乱是由一小撮不满分子引起的
A: ♣近  complainer, faultfinder, grouch, rebel
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不满的： dissatisfied with the existing state of affairs
A: ♣例  The film follows three malcontent teenagers around Paris. 电影围绕着三个不满现实的青少年在巴黎展开
A: ♣近  discontented, discontent, disgruntled, displeased, dissatisfied, ungratified
A: ♣反  contented, fulfilled, gratified, pleased, satisfied 满意的

Q:malevolent  [mə'levələnt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 恶意的，恶毒的： having, showing, or arising from intense often vicious ill will, spite, or hatred
A: ♣例  The novel grossly oversimplified the conflict as a struggle between relentlessly malevolent villains on one side and faultless saints on the other. 小说把这场斗争彻底简化成凶残恶毒的坏人和完美无暇的圣人间的纠纷。
A: ♣近  cruel, despiteful, evil, malicious, malign, malignant, mean, nasty, spiteful, vicious, virulent
A: ♣反  benevolent, benign, benignant 善意的，和善的
A: ♣派  malevolence n. 恶意，恶毒

Q:malicious  [mə'liʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 恶意的： given to, marked by, or arising from malice; deliberately harmful
A: ♣例  spread malicious gossips 散播恶意的流言蜚语
A: ♣近  bad, cruel, despiteful, evil, malevolent, malign, mean, nasty, spiteful, vicious, virulent, wicked
A: ♣反  benevolent, benign, benignant, charitable, kind, kindly 善良的，仁慈的

Q:malign  [mə'lain]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 恶意的： having or showing a desire to cause someone pain or suffering for the sheer enjoyment of it
A: ♣例  Both parties to the divorce showed a malign desire to make each other's future life utterly miserable. 离婚双方都表露出了恶毒的愿望，希望对方未来的生活陷入彻底的悲剧之中
A: ♣近  bad, cruel, despiteful, evil, malevolent, malicious, mean, nasty, spiteful, vicious, virulent, wicked
A: ♣反  benevolent, benign, benignant, charitable, kind, kindly 善良的，仁慈的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 诽谤： to utter injuriously misleading or false reports about: speak evil of
A: ♣例  the belief that it is possible to win an election without maligning anyone 一种信念，那就是要赢得一场选举就不得不诽谤他人
A: ♣近  asperse, blacken, calumniate, defame, libel, smear, traduce, vilify
A: ♣反  acclaim, applaud, eulogize, extol, laud, praise 赞美；defend, vindicate 辩护

Q:malignant  [mə'liɡnənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 恶毒的，邪恶的： having or showing a desire to cause someone pain or suffering for the sheer enjoyment of it; disposed to do evil
A: ♣例  She has a malignant wish to poison everyone who was smarter, richer, or better-looking than she was. 她有着一个恶毒的愿望，那就是毒死所有比她聪明、有钱或者是比她更漂亮的人。
A: ♣近  atrocious, brutal, cruel, despiteful, malevolent, malicious, malign, mean, nasty, spiteful, vicious, virulent
A: ♣反  benevolent, benign, benignant 慈善的，和蔼的；merciful 仁慈的

Q:malinger  [mə'liŋɡə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 装病以逃避工作： to pretend or exaggerate incapacity or illness (as to avoid duty or work)
A: ♣例  He claims he's ill, but I think he's just malingering. 他声称他病了，但我觉得他是装的
A: ♣近  goldbrick, shirk
A: ♣反  confront, face, meet 面对
A: ♣派  malingerer n. 装病以逃避工作的人

Q:malleable  ['mæliəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可塑的： capable of being extended or shaped by beating with a hammer or by the pressure of rollers
A: ♣例  a malleable metal 有延展性的金属
A: ♣近  moldable, waxy
A: ♠考法2 adj. 易控制的： capable of being altered or controlled by outside forces or influences
A: ♣例  The cult leader took advantage of the malleable, compliant personalities of his followers. 这个头目利用了他的信徒们容易被控制和顺从的特征
A: ♣近  ductile, elastic, fluid, modifiable, plastic, pliable, pliant, supple, variable
A: ♣反  adamant, intractable, recalcitrant, refractory, ungovernable, unmanageable, unruly 难管制的

Q:malodorous  [mæl'əudərəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 恶臭的： having an unpleasant smell
A: ♣例  American musteline will eject amalodorous fluid when startled. 美洲鼬科动物受惊吓时会喷出有恶臭味的液体
A: ♣近  fetid, foul, frowsy, funky, fusty, musty, noisome, rank, reeky, smelly, stinking, stinky
A: ♣反  ambrosial, aromatic, fragrant, perfumed, redolent, savory, scented, sweet 芳香的，有香味的
A: ♣派  malodorn. 恶臭

Q:mandatory  ['mændətəri:]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 强制的： forcing one's compliance or participation
A: ♣例  GRE test is mandatory for all students, regardless of their nationality, who wish to apply for graduate schools in the United States. GRE是每个申请美国研究生院的学生（无论国籍）所必须参加的考试
A: ♣近  compulsory, forced, imperative, incumbent, involuntary, necessary, obligatory, peremptory, required
A: ♣反  elective, optional, voluntary 可自由选择的，选修的

Q:maneuver  [mə'nu:və]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 巧妙地操纵： to guide with adroitness and design or to bring about or secure as a result of skillful management
A: ♣例  They maneuvered him into signing the contract. 他们巧妙地诱使他签下合同。‖The host maneuvered the conversation so as to avoid the touchy subject of her divorce. 主人巧妙地控制着对话的内容，以避免触及有关她离婚的敏感话题。
A: ♣近  contrive, finagle, finesse, frame, machinate, manipulate, mastermind, negotiate, wangle
A: ♣反  botch, bungle, fumble, mishandle, muff, scamp, mess up 弄砸

Q:mangle  ['mæŋɡl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 损毁，使伤残： to injure with deep disfiguring wounds by cutting, tearing, or crushing
A: ♣例  His body was mangled beyond recognition. 他的尸体已经被损毁到无法辨认的程度了
A: ♣近  batter, deform, disfigure, distort, lacerate, mutilate, rend, wreck
A: ♣反  cure, heal, rehabilitate 治愈，康复
A: ♠考法2  vt. 弄砸： to ruin or spoil through ineptitude or ignorance
A: ♣例  The orchestra had completely mangled Bach’s music. 乐队彻底演砸了巴赫的音乐
A: ♣近  blow, bumble, bungle, butcher, fumble , mar, mess, ruin, foul up, screw up

Q:mangy  ['meindʒi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 卑劣的： mean; contemptible
A: ♣例  a mangy trick 卑鄙的手段
A: ♣近  base, contemptible, debased, despicable, detestable, execrable, mean, sordid, squalid
A: ♣反  lofty, noble, upright, venerable, virtuous 正直的，有道德的

Q:mania  ['meiniə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 热衷，狂热： an excessively intense enthusiasm, interest, or desire; a craze
A: ♣例  a mania for neatness 强烈的洁癖
A: ♣近  ardor, craze, enthusiasm, fervor, obsession, passion, preoccupation, prepossession, zeal
A: ♣反  apathy, indifference, nonchalance, torpor 冷漠，麻木
A: ♣派  manic adj.疯狂的

Q:manifest  ['mænifest]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 显然的，明显易懂的： clearly apparent to the sight or understanding; obvious
A: ♣例  He is a manifest poseur. 他显然是个装模作样的人
A: ♣近  apparent, clear, distinct, evident, lucid, obvious, palpable, patent, perspicuous, plain, transparent
A: ♣反  cryptic, enigmatic, indistinct, mysterious, obfuscated, obscure, unclear 晦涩的，难懂的
A: ♠考法2  v. 显现，显露： to make evident or certain by showing or displaying
A: ♣例  His frustration is often manifested by a minor facial tic. 他的沮丧通常会从脸部的细微抽搐中表现出来
A: ♣近  bespeak, betray, demonstrate, display, evince, expose, reveal
A: ♣反  conceal, hide 隐藏
A: ♣派  manifesto n. 宣言，声明

Q:manipulate  [mə'nipjuleit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 巧妙操作： to move, arrange, operate, or control by the hands or by mechanical means, especially in a skillful manner
A: ♣例  manipulate a foreign language 熟练地掌握外语
A: ♣近  handle, finesse, manage
A: ♣反  bungle, fumble 笨拙地做
A: ♠考法2  vt. 暗中操控： to influence or manage shrewdly or deviously
A: ♣例  He manipulated public opinion in his favor. 他巧妙地将大众观点导向了有利于他的一边
A: ♣近  machinate, maneuver
A: ♣派  manipulation n.操纵，控制

Q:mannered  ['mænəd]

A: ♣例  a mannered speech 做作的演讲
A: ♣近  affected, artificial, assumed, factitious, fake, feigned, pretended, pseudo, sham, spurious
A: ♣反  natural 自然的；artless, genuine, unfeigned 真诚的

Q:manumit  [,mænju'mit]

A: ♣近  free, emancipate, enfranchise, liberate, loose, release, unbind, unchain, unshackle
A: ♣反  detain 拘留；enchain, enfetter, enslave 奴役

Q:mar  [mɑ:]

A: ♠考法2  vt. 破坏，削弱： to impair the soundness, perfection, or integrity of; spoil
A: ♣例  The once flatroad surface is now marred by numerous potholes. 曾经平整的路面如今被坑洞所破坏‖an election marred by sexual scandal 被性丑闻蒙上阴影的选举
A: ♣近  blemish, compromise, cripple, damage, deface, disfigure, harm, hurt, impair, injure, spoil, vitiate
A: ♣反  doctor, fix, mend, patch, renovate, repair 修补；adorn, beautify, bedeck, embellish, garnish 装饰

Q:marginal  ['mɑ:dʒinəl]

A: ♣例  Marginal locations in the open-air market are a bit cheaper. 露天市场边缘的地段通常都要便宜些。
A: ♣近  frontier
A: ♣反  interior 内在的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不重要的： not of central importance
A: ♣例  regards violence as a marginal rather than a central problem 并不把暴力问题当作重要的核心问题来看
A: ♣近  inconsequential, inconsiderable, insignificant, minor, minute, negligible, nugatory, slight, trifling, trivial
A: ♣反  consequential, eventful, important, meaningful, momentous, significant, substantial, weighty 重要的

Q:marsh  [mɑ:ʃ]

A: ♣近  bog, fen, marshland, mire, moor, morass, quagmire, slough, swamp, wetland
A: ♣派  marshy adj.潮湿的

A: ♣近  flash, miracle, phenomenon, prodigy, splendor

A: ♣近  lachrymose, mawkish, mushy, overemotional, sentimental, tearful
A: ♣反  blithe,cheerful, jocund, jovial, jubilant高兴的；apathetic,impassive, indifferent 冷漠的

Q:maverick  ['mævərik]

A: ♣例  Some mavericks believe that both gravity and light are electromagnetic forces. 一些特立独行的人认为，重力和光都是电磁力
A: ♣近  bohemian, deviant, heretic, iconoclast, nonconformist
A: ♣反  conformer, conformist, conventionalist 遵从传统的人
A: ♠考法2  adj. 标新立异的，不合常规的： deviating from commonly accepted beliefs or practices
A: ♣例  a maverick view on marriage 关于婚姻的非传统看法
A: ♣近  dissentient, dissenting, dissident, heterodox, iconoclastic, unorthodox
A: ♣反  conforming, conventional, orthodox 遵从传统的

Q:mean  [mi:n]

A: ♣例  a mean trick to play on a credulous person 耍在一个轻信别人的人身上的卑劣诡计

A: ♣近  closefisted, mingy, miserly, niggardly, parsimonious, penurious, tightfisted, ungenerous

A: ♣近  connote, denote, express, import, signify, spell
A: ♣派  meaningful adj. 有意义的

Q:menial  ['mi:niəl]

A: ♣例  Immigrants to that country faced fierce prejudice and could expect to find work only as menials. 前往那个国家的移民遭到了严重的歧视，他们也许只能找到像仆人一类的工作。

A: ♣近  base, humble, lowly, servile, slavish, subservient
A: ♣反  arrogant, haughty, imperious, lordly, supercilious, superior 自大的，狂妄的

A: ♣近  coach, counsel, lead, pilot, shepherd, show, tutor
A: ♣反  comply, follow, observe 遵从

Q:mercenary  ['mə:sinəri]

A: ♣例  hire a mercenary army to protect the VIP 雇佣了一支佣兵来保护重要人物
A: ♣近  hack
A: ♠考法2  adj. 唯利是图的，贪婪的： motivated solely by a desire for monetary or material gain
A: ♣例  Virtue flies from the heart of a mercenary man. 唯利是图的人没有美德可言
A: ♣近  acquisitive, avaricious, avid, covetous, grasping, greedy, moneygrubbing, rapacious
A: ♣反  benevolent, generous, liberal, philanthropic, munificent 慷慨的

Q:mercurial  [mə:'kjuəriəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （情绪）善变的： characterized by rapid and unpredictable changeableness of mood
A: ♣例  his mercurial temperament 他善变的脾气
A: ♣近  capricious, changeful, fluctuating, fluid, mutable, temperamental, uncertain, variable, volatile
A: ♣反  certain, constant, immutable, invariable, settled, stable, steady, unvarying稳定的，不变的

Q:meretricious  [,meri'triʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 艳俗的，俗气的： attracting attention in a vulgar manner
A: ♣例  The paradise they found was no more than a meretricious wasteland of casinos and bars. 他们所发现的所谓“天堂”只不过是一块有着赌场和酒吧的俗气不堪的荒漠罢了。
A: ♣近  flamboyant, flaring, flashy, garish, gaudy, glaring, loud, ostentatious, tawdry
A: ♣反  conservative, quiet, understated, unflamboyant 低调的，不张扬的

Q:merited  ['meritid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 应得的，理所当然的： being what is called for by accepted standards of right and wrong
A: ♣例  a merited bonus 应得的奖金‖The punishment, although harsh, was entirely merited. 虽然惩罚很严厉，但的确是应得的
A: ♣近  condign, deserved, due, fair, justified, right, warranted
A: ♣反  undeserved, undue 不应得的；gratuitous, unjustified, unwarranted没有根据的，无正当理由的

Q:mesh  [meʃ]

A: ♣例  Dolphins sometimes become meshed in fishnets. 有时海豚也会被渔网缠住
A: ♣近  enmesh, ensnare, ensnarl, entoil, entrap, net, snare, tangle, trap
A: ♣反  disentangle, untangle 解开，使解脱

Q:mesmeric  [mez'merik]

A: ♣近  hynoptic
A: ♣反  awaking 觉醒的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 令人着迷的，难以抗拒的： attracting and holding interest as if by a spell
A: ♣例  the mesmeric recital 迷人的独奏
A: ♣近  attractive, alluring, captivating, charming, drawing, enchanting, riveting
A: ♣反  disgusting, loathesome, repellent, repulsive 令人厌恶的；unappealing, unattractive没有吸引力的
A: ♣派  mesmerism n. 催眠术，难以抗拒的魅力；mesmerize v. 催眠

Q:metamorphose  [,metə'mɔ:fəuz]

A: ♣近  alchemize, transfigure, transform, transmute, transpose, transubstantiate
A: ♣反  remain 保持

Q:metaphysical  [,metə'fizikəl]

A: ♣例  a work that deals with such metaphysical questions as the very nature of knowledge 一部探讨诸如“知识的本性是什么”的理论问题的著作
A: ♣近  conceptual, ideal, ideational, notional, theoretical
A: ♣反  concrete 具体的，实实在在的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 非尘世的： of, relating to, or being part of a reality beyond the observable physical universe
A: ♣例  a metaphysical world beyond the one in which we live 在我们居住的世界之上的“超然世界”
A: ♣近  ethereal, heavenly, otherworldly, paranormal, preternatural, transcendental, unearthly, unworldly
A: ♣反  mundane 世俗的；natural 自然界的

Q:meteoric  [,mi:ti'ɔrik]

A: ♣例  a meteoric rise to fame 一夜成名
A: ♣近  ephemeral, evanescent, fleeting, momentary, rapid, transient, transitory
A: ♣反  enduring, lasting, permanent, prolonged 持久的

Q:methodical  [mi'θɔdikəl]

A: ♣近  neat, orderly, organized, regular, systematic, systematized
A: ♣反  disorganized, haphazard, irregular, unsystematic 杂乱的，混乱无序的

Q:meticulous  [mi'tikjuləs]

A: ♣反  careless, feckless, heedless, thoughtless 疏忽大意的

Q:mettle  ['metl]

A: ♣反  cowardice, cravenness, gutlessness, pusillanimity, spinelessness 胆小，怯懦
A: ♠考法2  n. 毅力，耐力： staying quality: stamina

Q:mime  [maim]

A: ♣近  ape, copy, copycat, emulate, mimic, simulate

Q:mimic  ['mimik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 仿真的，仿造的： being such in appearance only and made with or manufactured from usually cheaper materia
A: ♣例  Police were concerned that the mimic gun, although intended only as a toy, might be confused with the real thing in certain situations. 尽管仿真枪只是玩具，但警方担忧在某些情况下它会被误认为是真枪
A: ♣近  artificial, bogus, factitious, fake, false, imitative, mock, sham, simulated, substitute, synthetic
A: ♣反  genuine, natural, real 真实的
A: ♠考法2  v. 做滑稽的模仿（以取笑）： to copy or exaggerate (someone or something) in order to make fun of
A: ♣例  The comedian was famous for mimicking the President's distinctive lisp. 这个演员因能滑稽地模仿总统特有的口齿不清而闻名
A: ♣近  burlesque, caricature, do, imitate, mock, parody, send up, spoof, travesty
A: ♠考法3  v. 模仿： to use (someone or something) as the model for one's speech, mannerisms, or behavior
A: ♣例  began to learn their language by mimicking the sounds they made 通过模仿发音来学习语言
A: ♣近  ape, copy, copycat, emulate, mimic, simulate
A: ♣派  mimicry n. 模仿

Q:minimize  ['minimaiz]

A: ♠考法2  vt. 刻意低估： to underestimate intentionally
A: ♣例  minimize losses in our own company while maximize those of the rival 低估我方损失而高估对手损失
A: ♣近  underestimate, underrate, undervalue
A: ♣反  overestimate 高估；exaggerate 夸张，夸大
A: ♠考法3  vt. 表示鄙夷： to express scornfully one's low opinion of

A: ♣近  adaptable, fluid, inconstant, mercurial, mutable, protean, unstable, unsteady, variable, versatile
A: ♣反  fixed, steadfast, stable 稳定的，不变的
A: ♣派  mobility n. 可移动性；mobilize v. 动员

Q:mockery  ['mɔkəri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 鄙视，嘲弄： scornfully contemptuous ridicule
A: ♣例  Her deliberate mockery triggered a fierce fight. 她的蓄意嘲弄引起了一场激烈的打斗
A: ♣近  derision, joke, mock, ridicule, scoffing
A: ♣反  respect, reverence, veneration 尊敬
A: ♠考法2  n. 以嘲笑为目的的模仿： a false, derisive, or impudent imitation
A: ♣例  arbitrary methods that make a mockery of justice 嘲讽司法公正的仲裁体系
A: ♣近  burlesque, caricature, farce, parody, sham, travesty
A: ♣派  mock v. 愚弄，嘲弄

Q:moderate  ['mɔdərət]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使缓和： to lessen the intensity or extremeness of
A: ♣例  Sopranos and tenors moderates their voices to fit the size of the theater. 女高音和男高音们根据剧场的大小调节他们的声音以创造合适的效果
A: ♣近  abate, diminish, dwindle, ease, lessen, lower, modulate, subside, taper, temper, wane
A: ♣反  escalate, enhance, expand, heighten, intensify 扩大，升级，增强
A: ♠考法2  adj. 适度的，中庸的： being within reasonable limits; not excessive or extreme
A: ♣例  The new proposals regarding defense budget were met with only moderate enthusiasm. 关于国防预算的新提案只得到了平淡的回应
A: ♣近  average, conservative, fair, intermediate, mediocre, modest, reasonable, temperate
A: ♣反  exorbitant, excessive 过分的；extreme, radical 极端的
A: ♣派  immoderate adj. 不适度的

Q:modicum  ['mɔdikəm]

A: ♣例  a modicum of food quota 极少量的食物配额
A: ♣近  atom, iota, mite, molecule, particle
A: ♣反  abundance, affluence 大量

A: ♣近  exfoliate, exuviate, shed

A: ♣反  inconsequential, negligible, slight, trifling, trivial 无关紧要的

A: ♣近  arid, dreary, drudging, dull, jejune, monotonous, pedestrian, ponderous, stale, stodgy, tiresome

Q:monotonous  [mə'nɔtənəs]

A: ♣反  absorbing, engaging, engrossing, gripping, interesting, intriguing, involving, riveting 吸引人的

A: ♣近  antiquated, archaic, dated, fossilized, moth-eaten, outdated, outworn, rusty

Q:murky  ['mə:ki]

A: ♣近  ambiguous, arcane, cloudy, equivocal, muddy, nebulous, obscure, occult, vague

Q:murmur  ['mə:mə]

A: ♣近  carp, fuss, gripe, grizzle, grouch, grouse, grumble, moan, repine, whine
A: ♣反  crow, delight, rejoice 欢呼，高兴

A: ♣例  Some chromosomes started to mutate after exposure to X-Ray. 经X光照射之后部分染色体发生了变异

A: ♣反  remain 保持不变；plateau, stabilize 使稳定
A: ♣派  mutation n. 改变；变异

Q:mute  [mju:t]

A: ♣例  He always remained mute no matter how much we pleaded for an answer 不论我们怎么恳求回答，他总是保持沉默

A: ♣反  sharpen 锐化

A: ♣反  amplify, magnify 增强，放大
A: ♣派  muted adj. 消声的，静音的

A: ♣反  acme, apex, climax, meridian, peak, pinnacle, summit, top, zenith 最高点

Q:naive  [nɑ:'i:v]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 天真纯朴的： lacking worldly experience and understanding, simple and guileless
A: ♣例  a child with a na?ve charm 天真无邪的孩子
A: ♣近  artless, guileless, ingenuous, innocent, natural, simple, unaffected, unsophisticated
A: ♣反  sophisticated, worldly 世故的；affected, artful, assuming, dishonest, dissembling, guileful 虚伪、做作的
A: ♣派  naivety n. 天真

Q:narcissism  [nɑ:'sisizəm]

A: ♣例  In his narcissism, he just assumed that everyone else wanted to hear the tiny details of his day. 在他自恋的眼中，所有人仿佛都想要听他日常生活里的细枝末节
A: ♣近  egocentricity, egotism, self-absorption
A: ♣反  self-hatred 自我憎恨
A: ♣派  narcissistic adj. 自恋的

Q:nascent  ['næsənt]

A: ♣近  beginning, emerging, inceptive, inchoate, incipient, initial, introductory
A: ♣反  full-blown, full-fledged, mature, ripe 成熟的；moribund 将死的
A: ♣派  nascence n. 新生的状态

A: ♣反  frowsy, sloppy, slovenly 邋遢的

Q:negotiate  [ni'ɡəuʃieit]

A: ♣反  break down （谈判等）失败，破产
A: ♠考法2  vi. 谋划： plan out usually with subtle skill or care
A: ♣例  The prisoners negotiated their escape by using Morse code to tap messages to each other through the walls. 犯人们通过敲击墙壁来传达莫尔斯电码，从而密谋了他们的逃跑计划
A: ♣近  contrive, finesse, frame, machinate, maneuver, manipulate, mastermind, wangle
A: ♣派  negotiable adj. 可商量的；negotiation n. 谈判

A: ♣近  chimera, conceit, daydream, delusion, fancy, figment, hallucination, illusion, phantasm, unreality, vision

Q:notoriety  [,nəutə'raiəti]

A: ♣近  figure, icon, luminary, megastar, name, notable, personage, standout, star, superstar
A: ♣反  nobody, noncelebrity 不知名的人
A: ♠考法2  n. 坏名声： the quality or condition of being notorious; ill fame
A: ♣例  She gained notoriety when nude photographs of her appeared in a magazine. 她的裸照出现在杂志上让她声名远播。‖His comment about the President has given him a notoriety that he enjoys very much. 他对于总统的评论让他获得了很让他满意的名声。
A: ♣近  infamy, obloquy, odium, opprobrium
A: ♣反  anonymity, oblivion, obscurity 不知名，默默无闻；celebrity, fame, renown, repute 好名声

A: ♣近  advance, cultivate, encourage, forward, further, incubate, promote
A: ♣反  discourage, frustrate, hinder, inhibit 阻碍，妨碍

A: ♣反  banal, timeworn, familiar, hackneyed, time-honored, tired, warmed-over 陈腐的

Q:noxious  ['nɔkʃəs]

A: ♣近  unwholesome, baneful, deleterious, detrimental, nocuous, pernicious, wicked
A: ♣反  beneficial, salubrious, anodyne, benign, harmless, hurtless, innocent, innocuous, inoffensive, safe 有益的，无害的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 产生强烈厌恶的： causing intense displeasure, disgust, or resentment
A: ♣例  a noxious new breed of horror movie in which graphic depictions of torture are presented as entertainment 在一部新的恐怖电影中，对于酷刑生动的描述被当做是娱乐
A: ♣近  abhorrent, abominable, appalling, awful, disgusting, distasteful, dreadful, foul, fulsome, gross, hideous, horrid, loathsome, nasty, nauseating, noisome, obnoxious, odious, repellent, repugnant, repulsive, revolting, scandalous

Q:nuance  ['nju:ɑ:ns]

A: ♣反  patent difference, lack of subtlety, sharp distinction, patency 明显的差别

Q:nudge  [nʌdʒ]

A: ♣例  accidentally nudged me as he squeezed past 他过去的时候不小心用肘碰到了我
A: ♠考法2  vt. 说服某人做某事： to try to persuade (someone) through earnest appeals to follow a course of action
A: ♣例  the car salesman nudged me into taking a test-drive 汽车销售员说服我进行试驾
A: ♣近  encourage, exhort, goad, press, prod, prompt

Q:nugatory  ['nju:ɡətəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无关紧要的： of little or no consequence; inconsequential
A: ♣例  the book is entertaining, but its contributions to Shakespearean scholarship are nugatory 这本书娱乐性不错，但是对于莎士比亚研究的贡献微不足道
A: ♣近  incidental, inconsequential, inconsiderable, insignificant, negligible, trifling, trivial
A: ♣反  consequential, eventful, important, major, meaningful, momentous, significant, substantial, unfrivolous, weighty 重要的

Q:nullification  [,nʌlifi'keiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. （尤指法律条文等正式的）废除，废弃： the doing away with something by formal action
A: ♣例  the nullification of a treaty 废除条约
A: ♣近  abolishment, abrogation, annulment, cancellation, invalidation, negation, repeal, rescindment, voiding
A: ♣反  enactment, legislation 立法；establishment, founding, institution 建立

Q:numb  [nʌm]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 失去感觉的： devoid of sensation especially as a result of cold or anesthesia
A: ♣例  I have been sitting in the same position for too long and now my feet are numb. 我一个姿势坐得太久，以至于双腿都发麻了。
A: ♣近  asleep, benumbed, dead, insensitive, numbed, torpid, unfeeling
A: ♣反  feeling, sensible, sensitive 有感觉的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 麻木的，无感情的： devoid of emotion
A: ♣例  Apparently in shock, he answered the police officer’s questions with a numb expression on his face. 她显然是受到了惊吓，以至于在回答警官的问题时一脸茫然。‖Years of physical and emotional abuse had rendered the woman numb and withdrawn. 常年累月的肉体和精神上的折磨已让她麻木而寡言。
A: ♣近  affectless, apathetic, catatonic, deadpan, emotionless, impassible, passionless, phlegmatic, stoic, stolid
A: ♣反  demonstrative, emotional, fervent, fervid, impassioned, passionate, vehement 充满感情的

Q:nurture  ['nə:tʃə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 提供营养： to supply with nourishment
A: ♣例  nurtured her children through the winters with home-cooked soup 一整个冬天都给孩子们喂自制的汤
A: ♣反  withhold sustenance from 停止提供营养物
A: ♠考法2 vt. 培育，培养： to provide (someone) with moral or spiritual understanding
A: ♣例  he feels that his lifelong practice of reading the Bible daily has nurtured him in ways he cannot describe 一生中每天都阅读圣经在潜移默化中影响了他
A: ♣近  edify, illuminate, inspire
A: ♣反  impede, stunt, disregard 阻碍，漠视

Q:oaf  [əuf]
A: ♠考法1  n. 愚蠢的人： a stupid person
A: ♣例  Anyone who took him for an oaf and tried to cheat him would be in for a nasty surprise. 任何把他当成傻子然后想借机欺骗他的人就等着大吃一惊吧。
A: ♣近  airhead, dolt, dope, dullard, dumbhead, fool, idiot, imbecile, moron, simpleton
A: ♣反  brain, intellectual, sage, wit 智者；genius, prodigy 天才

Q:oath  [əuθ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 誓言： a solemn, formal declaration or promise to fulfill a pledge
A: ♣例  an oath to defend the nation 保卫祖国的誓言
A: ♣近  pledge, troth, vow, word

Q:obdurate  ['ɔbdjurət]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 固执的： resistant to persuasion or softening influences
A: ♣例  She is known for her obdurate determination. 她以坚定不移著称。
A: ♣近  adamant, hard-nosed, headstrong, inflexible, intransigent, pertinacious, stubborn, unbending, uncompromising, unrelenting, unyielding, willful
A: ♣反  acquiescent, agreeable, amenable, compliant, complying, flexible, pliable, pliant, relenting, yielding 温顺的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 冷酷无情的： having or showing a lack of sympathy or tender feelings
A: ♣例  the obdurate refusal of the crotchety old man to let the neighborhood kids retrieve their ball from his backyard 那个怪老头冷酷无情地拒绝了孩子们进他后院找球的请求
A: ♣近  affectless, callous, compassionless, hard-hearted, heartless, indurate, inhuman, insensate, ironhearted, merciless, remorseless, ruthless, unsparing
A: ♣反  charitable, compassionate, humane, kindhearted, kindly, merciful, softhearted, sympathetic, tender, warmhearted 同情的，有爱的

Q:obedient  [əu'bi:diənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 服从的，顺从的： submissive to the restraint or command of authority
A: ♣例  that girl is so obedient that she does everything the first time she is asked 这个妹子如此顺从，叫她做事随叫随到
A: ♣近  amenable, compliant, submissive, tractable
A: ♣反  contumacious, imperial, balky, contrary, contumacious, defiant, disobedient, froward, incompliant, insubordinate, intractable, noncompliant, obstreperous, rebel, rebellious, recalcitrant, refractory, restive, unamenable, ungovernable, unruly, untoward, wayward, willful 顽固的，不服从的

Q:obeisance  [əu'beisəns]

A: ♣例  makes obeisance to her mentors 向她的导师们致敬
A: ♣派  obeisant 恭敬的
A: ♣反  impertinent, impudent, imperious 不敬的，无礼的

Q:obfuscate  [ɔb'fʌskeit]

A: ♣例  obfuscate the reader 让读者困惑
A: ♣近  becloud, befog, blur, cloud, fog, muddy
A: ♣反  demystify, elucidate, illuminate, clarify, explain clearly 澄清，阐明
A: ♣派  obfuscated 模糊的
A: ♣反  lucid 清晰的

Q:obligatory  ['ɔbliɡətəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 强制性的： of the nature of an obligation; compulsory
A: ♣例  obligatory military service 强制性的服军役
A: ♣近  compulsory, imperative, involuntary, peremptory, required
A: ♣反  discretionary, selective, elective, optional, voluntary 自由选择的，志愿的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （见得多以至于）无聊的：used or heard so often as to be dull
A: ♣例  the obligatory cliff-hanger endings for season finales of TV shows 电视剧总是以恶俗的惊心动魄的结局作为完季
A: ♣近  banal, cliché, commonplace, hack, hackneyed, moth-eaten, musty, shopworn, stereotyped, threadbare, timeworn, trite, well-worn
A: ♣反  fresh, new, novel, original, unclichéd, unhackneyed 新奇的

Q:obliging  [ə'blaidʒiŋ]

A: ♣例  an obliging concierge used his pull to get us reservations at the town's hottest restaurant 一个好心的看房人利用他的影响力帮我们在镇上最火爆的餐厅订到了座
A: ♣近  accommodative, friendly, indulgent

Q:oblique  [ə'bli:k]

A: ♣近  askew, cant, inclined, leaning, listing, slanted, sloping, tilted
A: ♣反  direct, even, level, straight 笔直的

Q:obliterate  [ə'blitəreit]

A: ♣例  the March snowstorm obliterated our hopes for an early spring 三月的暴风雪摧毁了我们对于一个早春的念想
A: ♣近  efface, eradicate, expunge, expurgate, exterminate, extirpate, wipe out

Q:oblivious  [ə'bliviəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不知道的，不知情的： lacking conscious awareness; not informed about or aware of something
A: ♣例  He seemed oblivious to the fact that he had hurt her. 他似乎并不在意他伤害了她.
A: ♣近  incognizant, insensible, unaware, unconscious, uninformed, unwitting
A: ♣反  mindful, vigilant, acquainted, cognizant, conscious, conversant, grounded, informed, knowing, mindful, witting 留意的，机警的

Q:obloquy  ['ɔbləkwi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 谩骂，诽谤： abusively detractive language or utterance; calumny
A: ♣例  she unleashed a torrent of obloquy on her opponent 她滔滔不绝地辱骂了对手一顿
A: ♣近  billingsgate, fulmination, invective, scurrility, vitriol, vituperation
A: ♣反  adulation 极度谄媚
A: ♠考法2  n. 恶名，耻辱： the state of having lost the esteem of others
A: ♣例  the accused murderer was condemned to live out his days in perpetual obloquy 凶手终将在骂名中度过余生
A: ♣近  discredit, disesteem, dishonor, disrepute, ignominy, infamy, odium, opprobrium, reproach, shame
A: ♣反  esteem, honor, respect 敬重，好名声

Q:obscure  [əb'skjuə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 含义模糊的： not clearly understood or expressed; having an often intentionally veiled or uncertain meaning
A: ♣例  a fantasy writer who likes to put lots of obscure references in her tales of wizards and warlocks 一个喜欢在巫师故事中添加很多含义模糊的引用的魔幻小说作家
A: ♣近  ambiguous, arcane, enigmatic, equivocal, fuliginous, inscrutable, opaque
A: ♣反  explicit, manifest, clear, certain, accessible, nonambiguous, obvious, plain, unambiguous, unequivocal 明晰的，没有歧义的
A: ♠考法2 adj. 平凡的，不知名的： not prominent or famous
A: ♣例  an obscure poet 无名的诗人
A: ♣近  noteless, uncelebrated, unfamous, unknown, unrecognized, unsung
A: ♣反  legendary, celebrated, famed, famous, noted, notorious, prominent, renowned, well-known 有名的
A: ♣派  obscurity 无名之辈
A: ♣反  celebrity 名人
A: ♠考法3  v. 使模糊： to make dark, dim, or indistinct
A: ♣例  when it isn't obscured by smog, the view of the city from the observatory can be spectacular 如果在晴朗的天气，从天文台看出去的城市全景非常赞
A: ♣近  blear, blur, darken, dim, overshadow, shroud
A: ♣反  elucidate, brighten, illuminate, light up, lighten 阐明

Q:obsequious  [əb'si:kwiəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 谄媚的，奴性的： marked by or exhibiting a fawning attentiveness
A: ♣例  She's constantly followed by obsequious assistants who will do anything. 她总是有一群谄媚的跟班，原意为她赴汤蹈火。
A: ♣反  supercilious 目中无人的

Q:observant  [əb'zə:vənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 警惕的，警觉的： paying close attention usually for the purpose of anticipating approaching danger or opportunity
A: ♣例  Good reporters are keenly observant of everything around them. 优秀的记者应该对身边所有的事情都保持高度的警惕。‖If you were more observant, you would perceive that something is troubling her deeply. 如果你能再警觉一些的话，你就会发现她正被某些东西困扰。
A: ♣近  alert, attentive, awake, cautious, sharp, vigilant, watchful
A: ♣反  careless, heedless, inattentive, unmindful, unthinking, unwary 不谨慎的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 严格遵守（规章、制度或原则）的： diligent in observing a law, custom, duty, or principle
A: ♣例  observant of the speed limit 严格遵守速度限制‖pious and religiously observant families 虔诚而严守教规的家庭
A: ♣近  law-abiding
A: ♣派  observance n. 遵守（规定）

Q:obsess  [ɔb'ses]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 迷住，使困扰： to haunt or excessively preoccupy the mind of
A: ♣例  The war obsesses her—she talks about nothing else. 她被战争彻底迷住了，张口闭口都谈这个。
A: ♣反  intense disgust 极度厌恶

Q:obsolete  ['ɔbsəli:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 过时的，被淘汰的： no longer in use or no longer useful
A: ♣例  I was told my old printer is obsolete and I can't get replacement parts. 我被告知我的打印机已经被淘汰了，因此无法更换配件。‖an obsolete word 一个已经废弃不用的单词
A: ♣近  antiquated, archaic, dated, fossilized, medieval, moribund, moth-eaten, outdated, outmoded, outworn, prehistoric, rusty
A: ♣反  contemporary, current, modern, recent 当前的，现代的

Q:obstinate  ['ɔbstinit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 固执的： perversely adhering to an opinion, purpose, or course in spite of reason, arguments, or persuasion
A: ♣例  obstinate resistance to change 坚决抵制改变
A: ♣近  adamant, headstrong, intransigent, stubborn, uncompromising, unyielding, willful
A: ♣反  acquiescent, agreeable, amenable, compliant, complying, flexible, pliable, pliant, relenting, yielding 顺从服从的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 难于减轻或治愈的： not easily subdued, remedied, or removed
A: ♣例  obstinate fever 高烧不退 || an obstinate headache 难以治愈的头痛

Q:obstreperous  [əb'strepərəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 难驾驭的，任性的： stubbornly resistant to control; unruly; given to resisting authority or another's control
A: ♣例  the club's president was at his wits' end with obstreperous members who refused to cooperate 俱乐部主席拿那些不合作的会员一点办法都没有
A: ♣近  balky, defiant, incompliant, insubordinate, intractable, rebellious, recalcitrant, refractory
A: ♣反  disciplined, amenable, biddable, compliant, conformable, docile, obedient, ruly, submissive, tractable 守纪律的，顺从的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 吵闹的： engaging in or marked by loud and insistent cries especially of protest
A: ♣例  an obstreperous crowd protesting the government's immigration policy 一堆吵闹的民众游行抗议政府的移民政策
A: ♣近  blatant, clamant, clamorous, squawking, vociferant

Q:obstruct  [əb'strʌkt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 妨碍，制造困难： to impede, retard, or interfere with; hinder; to create difficulty for the work or activity of
A: ♣例  He was charged with obstructing justice by lying to investigators. 他被指控向检察官说谎，妨碍司法。
A: ♣近  encumber, fetter, handicap, hinder, impede, inhibit, stymie, interfere with
A: ♣反  facilitate, abet, aid, assist 促进，帮助
A: ♠考法2  vt. 阻挡： to prevent passage through by filling with something
A: ♣例  an unobstructed view 无阻碍的视野
A: ♣近  occlude 堵塞
A: ♣反  clear, free, open up, unblock, unclog, unplug, unstop

Q:obtuse  [əb'tju:s]

A: ♣例  Are you being deliberately obtuse? 你是故意装笨吗?
A: ♣近  dumb, fatuous, mindless, oafish, opaque, senseless, unintelligent, vacuous
A: ♣反  insightful, apt, brainy, bright, brilliant, clever, fast, intelligent, keen, nimble, quick, quick-witted, sharp, sharp-witted, smart 有洞察力的，智慧的

Q:obviate  ['ɔbvieit]

A: ♣例  The new treatment obviates the need for surgery. 新的疗法使手术不再是必须的。
A: ♣近  avert, forestall, preclude, stave off, head off

Q:occult  ['ɔkʌlt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 难以理解的： not easily apprehended or understood : abstruse, mysterious
A: ♣例  an occult reference in the text that has puzzled scholars 文章中一处晦涩的难倒了学者们的引注
A: ♣近  ambiguous, arcane, equivocal, inscrutable, opaque, impenetrable
A: ♣反  bare, manifest, patent, readily fathomable 暴露的，可理解的
A: ♠考法2  v. 使隐藏或神秘： to keep secret or shut off from view
A: ♣例  occulted their house from prying eyes by planting large trees around it 在住所周围种满大树防止别人偷窥 || the actor's private life had long been occulted by a contrived public persona 演员的私人生活被一个精心打造的公众形象所遮掩
A: ♣近  belie, blanket, cloak, conceal, cover, curtain, disguise, enshroud, mask, obscure, screen, shroud, suppress, veil, blot out, paper over
A: ♣反  bare, disclose, display, divulge, expose, reveal, show, uncloak, uncover, unmask, unveil 暴露

Q:odium  ['əudiəm]

A: ♣近  ignominy, infamy, obloquy, opprobrium
A: ♣反  esteem, honor, respect, hankering, infatuation 尊敬，渴望，着迷

Q:off-key  ['ɔfki:]

Q:offbeat  ['ɔfbi:t]

A: ♣近  extraordinary, peculiar, queer, unaccustomed, uncommon, uncustomary, out-of-the-way
A: ♣反  conventional, bathetic, hackneyed, common, ordinary, plain, usual 传统陈腐的，平常普通的

Q:offhand  ['ɔfhænd]

A: ♣反  considered, planned, premeditated, prepared, rehearsed 事先谋划的

Q:officious  [ə'fiʃəs]

A: ♣例  an officious little man who was always telling everyone else how to do their jobs 一个多管闲事的人，总喜欢对他人的事情指手画脚
A: ♣近  interfering, intruding, meddlesome, obtrusive, presuming, prying, snoopy
A: ♣反  unobtrusive 不引人注目的

Q:offish  ['ɔfiʃ]

A: ♣近  aloof, detached, distant, remote, unbending, unsociable
A: ♣反  sociable, cordial, friendly, social, warm 热情的

Q:ominous  ['ɔminəs]

A: ♣近  baleful, foreboding, inauspicious, portentous, sinister, threatening, minatory
A: ♣反  auspicious, unthreatening 吉兆的，不具有威胁的

Q:omniscient  [ɔm'nisiənt]

A: ♣反  vacuous 无知的

Q:onerous  ['ɔnərəs]

A: ♣近  arduous, burdensome, challenging, exacting, grueling, taxing, toilsome
A: ♣反  requiring little effort, light, nondemanding, unchallenging, undemanding 轻松的，不费劲的

Q:onset  ['ɔnset]

A: ♣近  aggression, assault, charge, offense, onslaught, raid, rush, strike
A: ♣反  defense 防御
A: ♠考法2  n. 起始，开始： the point at which something begins
A: ♣例  If you take enough vitamin C at the onset of a cold, you'll probably recover faster. 如果你感冒刚一开始就服用足量的维他命C，你可能会康复得更快。
A: ♣近  alpha, baseline, commencement, dawn, genesis, inception, kickoff, launch, nascence, outset, threshold
A: ♣反  close, conclusion, end, ending, omega, termination 结束

Q:opaque  [əu'peik]

A: ♣近  blurry, dim, misty, murky, obscure, shadowy, unclear

A: ♣近  ambiguous, arcane, enigmatic, equivocal, inscrutable, occult
A: ♣反  clear, accessible, obvious, plain, unambiguous, unequivocal 清晰易懂的

Q:opine  [əu'pain]

A: ♣近  comment, editorialize, note, observe, reflect, weigh in

Q:opportune  ['ɔpətju:n]

A: ♣近  seasonable, well-timed
A: ♣反  inconvenient, untimely, inappropriate, unseasonable 不合适的

Q:opprobrious  [ə'prəubriəs]

A: ♣例  opprobrious language 脏话
A: ♣近  scurrilous, vitriolic, vituperative, contumelious
A: ♠考法2  adj. 臭名昭著的，令人鄙视的: bringing disgrace; shameful or infamous
A: ♣例  opprobrious conduct 令人鄙视的行为
A: ♣近  discreditable, disgraceful, dishonorable, ignominious, infamous, notorious, shameful, unrespectable
A: ♣反  irreproachable, honorable, reputable, respectable 无可指责的，受人尊敬的
A: ♣派  opprobrium 恶名
A: ♣反  good repute 好名声

Q:oration  [ɔ:'reiʃən]

A: ♣近  address, declamation, harangue, peroration

Q:ordeal  [ɔ:'di:l]
A: ♠考法1  n. 严峻的考验： a severe trial or experience
A: ♣例  The hikers were finally rescued after a three-day ordeal in the wilderness. 在野外度过了三天的严峻考验之后，登山者终于获救了。
A: ♣近  calvary, crucible, fire, gauntlet
A: ♣反  delight, enjoyment, pleasure 令人愉快的事物

Q:orient  ['ɔ:riənt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 确定方向，使熟悉或适应： to set or arrange in any determinate position especially in relation to the points of the compass; to make familiar with or adjusted to facts, principles, or a situation
A: ♣例  orient students toward a career in medicine 指导学生从事医学的职业道路
A: ♣近  accustom, familiarize, initiate, introduce, orientate
A: ♣反  confuse 使迷惑

Q:original  [ə'ridʒənəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 创新的： independent and creative in thought or action :inventive
A: ♣例  The car has a highly original design. 这车的设计很新颖
A: ♣近  ingenious, innovative, inventive
A: ♣反  commonplace, banal, trite, familiar, hackneyed, time-honored, tired, warmed-over 陈腐的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 最初的，最早的： coming before all others in time or order
A: ♣例  the original plan had to be discarded when the situation changed drastically 当环境发生剧烈变化时，最初的计划就该被放弃
A: ♣近  earliest, foremost, headmost, inaugural, initial, leadoff, maiden, pioneer, premier, virgin
A: ♣反  final, last, latter, terminal, ultimate 最终的

Q:orthodox  ['ɔ:θədɔks]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 传统的： following or agreeing with established form, custom, or rules
A: ♣例  He believes in the benefits of both orthodox medicine and alternative medicine. 他既相信传统药物又相信替代药物的效用。
A: ♣近  ceremonial, conventional, regular, routine
A: ♣反  casual, freewheeling, informal, irregular, unceremonious, unconventional, unorthodox 不常见的

Q:oscillate  ['ɔsileit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 振动，摇晃： to swing backward and forward like a pendulum
A: ♣反  remain static 静止
A: ♠考法2  v. 犹豫，变化： vary between opposing beliefs, feelings, or theories

Q:ossify  ['ɔsifai]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 硬化，僵化： to become hardened or conventional and opposed to change
A: ♣例  a disease that ossifies the joints 一种会使关节僵化的疾病
A: ♣反  make pliant, transcend conventions, amenable to change 使柔软，超越传统

Q:ostensible  [ɔs'tensəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 表面上的，佯装的： appearing to be true on the basis of evidence that may or may not be confirmed
A: ♣例  It must be the ostensible reason for their visit while their actual motives may be malignant 这肯定只是他们上门拜访的表面原因，他们背后的动机说不定恶劣至极。
A: ♣近  apparent, assumed, evident, ostensive, presumed, putative, reputed, seeming, supposed, prima facie
A: ♣反  actual, real 真实的
A: ♣派  ostensibly adv. 表面上地

Q:ostentatious  [,ɔsten'teiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 炫耀卖弄的： marked by or fond of conspicuous or vainglorious and sometimes pretentious display
A: ♣例  wears an ostentatious diamond ring on her finger 她手指上戴着一枚巨大的钻戒
A: ♣近  flamboyant, flaring, flashy, splashy
A: ♣反  modest, artless, austere, unpretentious, conservative, quiet, understated, unflamboyant, unflashy 谦让的，朴素的，保守地

Q:ostracize  ['ɔstrəsaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 驱逐： to exclude from a group
A: ♣例  He was ostracized from the scientific community for many years because of his radical political beliefs. 他因激进的政治理想被驱逐出了科学界很多年。
A: ♣近  banish, bounce, chase, dismiss, expel, extrude, oust, boot out, cast out, run off, drum out, kick out, throw out, turf out
A: ♣反  take in, include, embrace, welcome 接纳

Q:oust  [aust]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 免职： to remove from a position of prominence or power (as a throne)
A: ♣例  be ousted from power 被赶下台
A: ♣近  deprive, displace, uncrown, unthrone
A: ♣反  instate, crown, enthrone, throne 任命
A: ♠考法2  v. 驱逐： to drive or force out
A: ♣例  she was ousted from her job after it was proven she'd been pilfering company supplies 她贪污公司财物这事被证实后，她被驱逐了
A: ♣近  banish, boot out, cast out, chase, dismiss, drum out, expel, extrude, kick out, throw out, turf out, turn out

Q:outgoing  ['aut,ɡəuiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 友好的，外向的： openly friendly and responsive: extroverted
A: ♣例  a salesman whose aggressively outgoing personality could sometimes be overbearing 一个销售员如果过于热情会让人不能忍
A: ♣近  companionable, extroverted, gregarious, sociable
A: ♣反  antisocial, introverted, nongregarious, reclusive, unsociable, unsocial 不合群的，不善交际的

Q:outgrowth  ['autɡrəuθ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 结果，后果： a condition or occurrence traceable to a cause
A: ♣例  Crime is often an outgrowth of poverty. 犯罪往往可以归因于贫穷。‖A predictable outgrowth of the suburb’s ever growing population will be the need for more schools. 郊区人口攀升所导致的一个可以预见的后果就是需要更多的学校。
A: ♣近  aftereffect, aftermath, consequence, fate, fruit, outcome, precipitate, product, result, sequel, sequence
A: ♣反  antecedent, cause, occasion, reason 原因；origin, root, source 源头

Q:outlandish  [aut'lændiʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 古怪的，奇异的：strikingly out of the ordinary: bizarre
A: ♣例  an outlandish costume 奇装异服
A: ♣近  bizarre, cranky, eccentric, erratic, offbeat, peculiar, remarkable
A: ♣反  conventional, familiar, nonexotic, nonglamorous, plain-Jane, unglamorous, unromantic 常规的，平凡的

Q:outmaneuver  [,autmə'nu:və]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 以策略取胜： to overcome (an opponent) by artful, clever maneuvering
A: ♣例  outmaneuvered his congressional opponent 以计谋战胜了国会的对手
A: ♣近  outfox, outslick, outsmart, outthink, outwit
A: ♣反  yield 屈服

Q:outmoded  ['aut'məudid]

A: ♣例  outmoded computers that can be recycled 可供回收的废旧电脑
A: ♣近  antiquated, archaic, demoded, fossilized, moribund, moth-eaten, obsolete, outworn, prehistoric , rusty
A: ♣反  contemporary, current, modern 现代的，当代的

Q:outset  ['autset]

A: ♣例  I wish you'd mentioned this problem at the outset. 我希望你开门见山就提到这个问题。
A: ♣近  alpha, commencement, genesis, inception, incipience, nascence
A: ♣反  termination, close, conclusion, end, ending, omega 终止

Q:outwit  [,aut'wit]

A: ♣例  a plan to outwit their opponents at their own game 在擅长的领域智取对手的计划
A: ♣近  outfox, outmaneuver, outslick, outsmart, outthink

Q:overbearing  [,əuvə'bεəriŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 专横傲慢的： domineering in manner; arrogant
A: ♣例  Her husband's overbearing manner made her miserable. 她的丈夫专横傲慢，让她痛不欲生。
A: ♣近  authoritative, despotic, dictatorial, imperious, masterful, peremptory
A: ♣反  meek, unassuming 谦逊的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 压倒一切的，在力量或重要性上势不可挡的；支配的，显著的： overwhelming in power or significance; predominant, coming before all others in importance
A: ♣例  the overbearing problem in our nation's schools 我国中小学教育的最突出的问题
A: ♣近  capital, cardinal, central, chief, dominant, key, leading, master, number one, overmastering, overriding, paramount, predominant, preeminent, premier, primary, prior, sovereign, supreme

Q:overlap  [,əuvə'læp]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 重叠，重复： to occupy the same area in part
A: ♣例  Baseball season overlaps football season in September. 棒球赛季和橄榄球赛季在九月有时间重合。
A: ♣近  lap, overlay, overlie, overspread

Q:override  [,əuvə'raid]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 不顾： to set aside
A: ♣例  The Congress overrode the President’s veto and passed the law. 国会不顾总统的否决，强行通过了那项法令。‖He overrode all opposition to his plans. 他对所有的反对意见不闻不问。
A: ♣近  disregard, ignore, neglect, overlook, overpass, pass over
A: ♣反  comply, observe 遵守

Q:overshadow  [,əuvə'ʃædəu]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使变黯淡： to make dark, dim, or indistinct
A: ♣例  Large trees overshadow the yard and darken the house for much of the day. 大树为院子遮挡了阳光，并使屋子里一天之中的大多数时候都很昏暗。‖Her mother's illness overshadowed her childhood. 她母亲的疾病让她的童年缺乏亮色。
A: ♣近  becloud, befog, blacken, blear, blur, darken, dim, fog, haze, mist, obscure, overcast, overcloud, shroud
A: ♣反  brighten, illuminate, illumine, lighten 照明，照亮
A: ♠考法2  vt. （在重要性上）超越，超过： to exceed in importance
A: ♣例  The forward’s outstanding performance should not overshadow the achievements of the rest of the team. 其他队员的贡献不应该因前锋的精彩表现而被忽略。
A: ♣近  eclipse, outrank, outshine, outstrip, overbalance, overweigh
A: ♣反  fall behind 落后

Q:overt  ['əuvə:t]

A: ♣例  overt hostility 公然的敌意
A: ♣反  shadowy 模糊的

Q:overture  ['əuvə,tjuə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 前言： an introductory section or part, as of a poem; a prelude
A: ♣近  preamble, preliminary, prologue, warm-up, curtain-raiser
A: ♠考法2  n. 序曲： an instrumental composition intended especially as an introduction to an extended work, such as an opera or oratorio
A: ♣例  the parade down Main Street served as the overture for a weekend of fun and festivities 主干道上的游行活动拉开了一周节日活动的序幕
A: ♣反  coda 结尾

Q:overwhelm  [,əuvə'hwelm]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 淹没： to cover with or as if with a flood
A: ♣例  That spring the massive runoff from melting snows overwhelmed the valley. 那个春天，整个村庄被融雪形成的洪流吞没了。
A: ♣近  deluge, drown, engulf, inundate, overflow, submerge, submerse, swamp
A: ♣反  drain 抽干
A: ♠考法2  vt. （感情上、精神上）使无所适从，使难以承受： to subject to incapacitating emotional or mental stress
A: ♣例  Just the thought of how much work there is to do overwhelms me. 仅仅是想想还有多少工作没完成就几乎让我喘不过气了。
A: ♣近  devastate, oppress, overcome, overmaster, overpower, prostrate, whelm
A: ♣反  relieve 使舒缓
A: ♣派  overwhelming adj. 势不可挡的，无法抗拒的

Q:overwrought  [,əuvə'rɔ:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 十分激动的，非常不安的： being in a state of increased activity or agitation
A: ♣例  She became overwrought when she heard that her child was missing. 当她得知自己孩子失踪的消息后变得极其激动和不安。
A: ♣近  agitated, excited, frenzied, heated, hectic, hyperactive, overactive
A: ♣反  calm, collected, composed, placid, serene, tranquil 冷静的，沉着的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （装饰）过分华丽的： elaborately and often excessively decorated
A: ♣例  The author's prose is overwrought with purple passages and florid metaphors. 这个作者的散文里充满了词藻华丽的段落和比喻，显得有些过分。
A: ♣近  baroque, bedizened, flamboyant, florid, fussy, gingerbreaded, ornate, overdecorated
A: ♣反  austere, plain, severe, stark, unadorned 朴素的

Q:oxymoron  [,ɔksi'mɔ:rɔn]
A: ♠考法1  n. 矛盾修饰法： a combination of contradictory or incongruous words
A: ♣例  The phrase “cruel kindness” is an oxymoron. “残酷的仁慈”就是矛盾修饰法的一个例子。|| The phrase “Broadway rock musical” is an oxymoron. Broadway doesn't have the nerve to let the really hard stuff in the house. “百老汇的摇滚音乐剧”是个反讽。百老汇才不会允许吵吵闹闹的东西在里面演出。

Q:pacify  ['pæsifai]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使平静，安慰： to ease the anger or agitation of
A: ♣例  pacify a crying child 安抚一个哭泣的孩子
A: ♣近  appease, assuage, conciliate, mollify, placate, propitiate
A: ♣反  incite, rankle, tantrum, vex, discompose, truculent 煽动激起

Q:padding  ['pædiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 夸张，废话： the representation of something in terms that go beyond the facts
A: ♣例  that feature writer is sometimes guilty of padding, but he keeps it from getting out of hand 这作者有时候夸夸其谈，但是保持了适度
A: ♣近  caricature, coloring, elaboration, embellishment, embroidery, hyperbole, magnification, overstatement, stretching
A: ♣反  meiosis, understatement 轻描淡写

Q:paean  ['pi:ən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 欢乐颂： a joyous song or hymn of praise, tribute, thanksgiving, or triumph
A: ♣例  her retirement party featured many paeans for her long years of service to the company 她的退休派对满是对她多年在公司辛勤工作的赞颂
A: ♣近  accolade, citation, dithyramb, eulogium, eulogy, hymn, panegyric, tribute

Q:painstaking  ['peinz,teikiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 煞费苦心的： taking pains: expending, showing, or involving diligent care and effort
A: ♣例  It took months of painstaking research to write the book. 这本书的写作耗费了几个月的苦心研究。
A: ♣近  careful, conscientious, fussy, meticulous, scrupulous
A: ♣反  slipshod, cursory, careless 漫不经心的，草率的

Q:palatable  ['pælətəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 感到愉悦满足的： giving pleasure or contentment to the mind or senses
A: ♣例  I always associate the palatable aroma of roasting turkey with Thanksgiving. 我总是把香喷喷的烤火鸡的味道和感恩节联系起来
A: ♣近  agreeable, blessed, congenial, delectable, delightful, delightsome, dreamy, dulcet, enjoyable, felicitous, grateful, gratifying, heavenly, jolly, luscious, pleasurable, satisfying, savory
A: ♣反  disagreeable, pleasureless, unpalatable, unpleasant, unwelcome 不愉悦的

Q:palatial  [pə'leiʃəl]

A: ♣近  deluxe, lavish, luxuriant, opulent, sumptuous
A: ♣反  ascetic, austere, humble, no-frills, spartan

Q:palaver  [pə'lævə]

A: ♣例  seemingly endless palaver between the negotiating parties 谈判双方之间看似没有尽头的对话
A: ♣近  argument, colloquy, conference, consult, council, counsel, debate, dialogue, parley
A: ♠考法2  vi. 闲聊： to talk profusely or idly
A: ♣例  Mothers were palavering and drinking coffee while watching their children play. 母亲们一边看着她们的孩子玩耍，一边喝着咖啡闲谈。
A: ♣近  babble, chatter, converse, gabble, jabber, prate, prattle, rattle, twitter

Q:pall  [pɔ:l]

A: ♣例  His humor began to pall on us. 他的幽默开始使我们生腻了。

Q:palliate  ['pælieit]

A: ♣例  palliative drug 缓解剂
A: ♣近  allay, alleviate, assuage, mitigate, mollify, palliate, relieve, soothe
A: ♣反  aggravate, exacerbate, worsen, increase intensity 加剧，恶化

Q:pallid  ['pælid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无生气的，缺乏活力的： lacking in radiance or vitality; dull
A: ♣例  The movie is a pallid version of the classic novel. 这部经典小说改编的电影很苍白无力。
A: ♣反  piquant 兴奋的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 苍白无血色的： having an abnormally pale or wan complexion
A: ♣例  a pallid girl who looked as though she'd never seen the sun 一个面色苍白的姑娘，仿佛从来没有晒过太阳
A: ♣近  ashen, ashy, blanched, pasty, wan
A: ♣反  rubicund, blooming, florid, flush, full-blooded, glowing, ruddy, sanguine 红润的

Q:palmy  ['pɑ:mi]

Q:palpable  ['pælpəbl]

A: ♣反  impalpable, intangible
A: ♠考法2  adj. 明显的，易觉察的： easily perceived; obvious
A: ♣例  a palpable difference 易觉察的差别
A: ♣近  apprehensible, detectable, discernible, distinguishable, sensible
A: ♣反  imperceptible, inappreciable, indistinguishable, insensible, undetectable 隐晦的，细微的

Q:palpitation  [,pælpi'teiʃən]

A: ♣例  a palpitation of the blood vessels 血管有节奏的舒张收缩
A: ♣近  beat, beating, pulse, throb

Q:palter  ['pɔ:ltə]
