A: ♣例  Canadian Prairie 加拿大大草原地区
A: ♣近  grassland, meadow, plain, savanna

Q:prate  [preit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 闲聊，空谈： to talk long and idly
A: ♣例  They have been prating on the phone for hours. 他们已经煲了几个小时的电话粥了。
A: ♣近  babble, chat, chatter, converse, gabble, jabber, prattle, twitter
A: ♣派  prater n. 闲聊的人

Q:preach  [pri:tʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 传道，布道： to deliver a sermon
A: ♣例  a minister who loves to preach 一个爱布道的牧师
A: ♣近  discourse, sermonize
A: ♣派  preacher n. 布道者

Q:precarious  [pri'kεəriəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 危险不稳定的： dangerously lacking in security or stability
A: ♣例  a precarious livelihood 不稳定的生计
A: ♣近  delicate, fragile, sensitive, touchy, unstable
A: ♣反  firm, stable 稳定的；safe, secure 安全的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 可疑的，不明确的： dependent on uncertain premises
A: ♣例  His entire argument relies on a precarious assumption. 他的整篇论证都建立在一个可疑的假设之上。
A: ♣近  ambiguous, doubtful, dubious, equivocal, uncertain, unfounded
A: ♣反  indubitable, unambiguous, unequivocal, unquestionable 明确的，毋庸置疑的

Q:precedent  [pri'si:dənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 先例，前例： an earlier occurrence of something similar
A: ♣例  There has not been any precedent so far. 到目前为止还没有先例。‖a landmark decision that set a legal precedent 在法律上首开先河的重大决议
A: ♣近  example, instance, model, paradigm, pattern, standard
A: ♠考法2  adj. 先前的： prior in time, order, arrangement, or significance
A: ♣例  Her violent behaviors may be explained by some precedent events in her troubled life. 她的暴力行径或许可以由她之前苦难生活中遭遇到的一些事件来解释。
A: ♣近  antecedent, anterior, former, preceding, previous, prior
A: ♣反  ensuing 继而发生的
A: ♣派  unprecedented adj. 前所未见的

Q:precipice  ['presipis]
A: ♠考法1  n. 悬崖峭壁： a very steep or overhanging place
A: ♣例  a precipice too steep to climb 过于陡峭而无法攀爬的悬崖
A: ♣近  bluff, cliff, crag, escarpment, palisade
A: ♣反  ridge 山脊
A: ♣派  precipitous adj. 陡峭的

Q:precipitate  [pri'sipitit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 匆忙的： acting or done with excessive or careless speed
A: ♣例  the army's precipitate withdrawal from the field of battle 匆忙将军队从战场上撤下
A: ♣近  cursory, flying, headlong, hurried, overhasty, precipitous, rash, rushed
A: ♣反  deliberate 慎重考虑的；leisurely, unhurried, unrushed 从容不迫的，不慌不忙的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 促使，导致： to cause to happen, especially suddenly or prematurely
A: ♣例  to precipitate an international crisis 产生国际危机
A: ♣近  accelerate, escalate, expedite, hasten, impel, speed, trigger
A: ♣反  check, encumber, enfetter, hamper, handicap, hinder, manacle, obstruct, retard, trammel 阻碍
A: ♣派  precipitation n. 急促；沉淀；降水

Q:precipitation  [pri,sipi'teiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 沉积物，尤指降水： something precipitated as a deposit on the earth of hail, mist, rain, sleet, or snow
A: ♣例  The storm brought several inches of precipitation. 风暴带来的降水量高达数英尺。
A: ♣近  deposit, sediment
A: ♠考法2  n. 仓促： excited and often showy or disorderly speed
A: ♣例  I fear that I may have acted with some precipitation on this matter, so I would like to reconsider. 我害怕自己在这个事情上考虑得太仓促了，因此我想再想想。
A: ♣近  haste, hastiness, hustle, precipitousness, rush
A: ♣反  deliberation 深思熟虑

Q:precipitous  [pri'sipitəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 非常陡峭的：very steep, perpendicular, or overhanging in rise or fall
A: ♣例  a precipitous gorge 险峻的峡谷
A: ♣近  abrupt, arduous, precipitate, sheer, steep
A: ♣反  flat, level 平坦的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 匆忙的： acting or done with excessive or careless speed
A: ♣例  They soon regretted their precipitous actions in international affairs 他们很快就为他们在国际事务中的匆忙举动感到后悔。
A: ♣近  cursory, flying, headlong, hurried, overhasty, precipitate, rash, rushed
A: ♣反  deliberate 慎重考虑的；leisurely, unhurried, unrushed 从容不迫的，不慌不忙的

Q:preclude  [pri'klu:d]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 预先阻止： to make impossible, as by action taken in advance
A: ♣例  Age alone will not preclude him from standing as a candidate. 年龄并没有阻止他成为候选人。
A: ♣近  avert, deter, forestall, obviate, prevent, stave off
A: ♠考法2  vt. 排斥 ：to exclude or prevent (someone) from a given condition or activity
A: ♣例  He refused to preclude the subject from discussion . 他拒绝将这个话题排出讨论范围。
A: ♣近  bar, exclude, except
A: ♣反  enclose 圈入
A: ♣派  preclusive adj. 预先阻止的

Q:precursor  [pri:'kə:sə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 先驱者，先导： one that precedes and indicates the approach of another
A: ♣例  18th-century lyric poets like Robert Burns were precursors of the Romantics. 十八世纪的抒情诗人（如罗伯特?彭斯）是浪漫主义的先驱。
A: ♣近  foregoer, forerunner, harbinger, herald, outrider
A: ♣反  sequela, successor 后继者；descendant 后代
A: ♣派  precursory adj. 先驱性的，开创性的

Q:predecessor  ['pri:disesə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 前任，先辈： a person who has previously occupied a position or office to which another has succeeded
A: ♣例  a political legacy left by his predecessor 他的前任留下来的政治遗产
A: ♣近  ancestor, antecedent, foregoer, forerunner, precursor
A: ♣反  successor 继任者；descendant 后代

Q:predestine  [pri:'destin]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 预先注定： to determine the fate of in advance
A: ♣例  Our victory in the tournament was seemingly predestined. 我们在锦标赛中的胜利似乎是注定好了的
A: ♣近  doom, fate, foredoom, foreordain, ordain, predestine, predetermine, preordain
A: ♣派  predestination n. 命中注定

Q:predilection  [,pri:di'lekʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 爱好，偏袒：a partiality or disposition in favor of something
A: ♣例  a predilection for travel 热爱旅行
A: ♣近  affection, affinity, bias, disposition, inclination, leaning, penchant, predisposition, propensity, tendency
A: ♣反  aversion, loathing, nausea, repugnance, repulsion, revulsion 反感

Q:preeminent  [pri'eminənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 优秀的，重要的：having paramount rank, dignity, or importance
A: ♣例  The writer's style is brilliant and his command of words, preeminent. 作者的文风和用词都十分出色
A: ♣近  distinguished, illustrious, incomparable, notable, outstanding, peerless, superb, supreme, unmatchable
A: ♣反  negligible, trivial 不重要的
A: ♣派  preeminence n. 杰出

Q:preempt  [pri'empt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 预先占有： to appropriate, seize, or take for oneself before others
A: ♣例  The naughty children had preempted front-row seats that were reserved for the guests of honor. 调皮的孩子们把前排留给贵客的座位占了。
A: ♣近  appropriate, arrogate, commandeer, convert, expropriate, preempt, press, seize, usurp
A: ♠考法2  v. 替换：to replace with something considered to be of greater value or priority: take precedence over
A: ♣例  The special newscast preempted the usual television program. 特别新闻取代了常规节目。
A: ♣近  displace, replace, supersede, supplant
A: ♣派  preemptive adj. 先发制人的

Q:preen  [pri:n]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 整理（羽毛）：to smooth or clean (feathers) with the beak or bill
A: ♣近  plume
A: ♣反  rumple 弄皱
A: ♠考法2  vt. 打扮修饰： to dress or groom (oneself) with elaborate care
A: ♣例  She always preen herself in an elaborate suit before going to the opera. 她去听歌剧之前总要精心打扮一番，穿上最豪华的服装。
A: ♣近  groom, plume, primp
A: ♠考法3  vt. 自满： to take pride or satisfaction in (oneself)
A: ♣例  He always preen himself on his ancestry. 他总是因为他的血统而洋洋得意
A: ♣近  gloat, plume, pride
A: ♣反  efface 表现出谦卑

Q:preface  ['prefis]
A: ♠考法1  n. 序言：a preliminary statement or essay introducing a book that explains its scope, intention, or background and is usually written by the author
A: ♣例  An informal brunch served as a preface to the three-day conference. 一顿非正式的便餐作为为期三天的会议的序曲。
A: ♣近  exordium, foreword, introduction, overture, preamble, prelude, prologue
A: ♣反  epilogue 尾声
A: ♣派  prefatory adj. 序言的

Q:pregnant  ['preɡnənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 重要的，意味深长的： weighty or significant; full of meaning
A: ♣例  the pregnant phrases of the Bible 《圣经》中充满哲理的话语
A: ♣近  eloquent, meaningful, momentous, profound, revelatory, significant, suggestive
A: ♣反  inane 空洞的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 怀孕的：containing a developing embryo, fetus, or unborn offspring within the body
A: ♣例  Being pregnant represents great news, but it comes with a lot of responsibilities. 怀孕是件大好事，但是它也带来了许多的责任。
A: ♣近  enceinte, expectant, expecting, gravid
A: ♣派  pregnancy n. 怀孕

Q:premeditate  [pri'mediteit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 预谋： to think about and revolve in the mind beforehand
A: ♣例  carefully premeditating each step of his plan of campaign 仔细地计划着竞选计划中的每一个步骤
A: ♣近  forethink, precogitate, predetermine
A: ♣反  disregard, ignore, overlook, slight 忽略
A: ♣派  premeditated adj. 有预谋的

Q:preoccupation  [pri:,ɔkju'peiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 非常关心，全神贯注： extreme or excessive concern with something
A: ♣例  He kept sinking back into gloomy preoccupation. 他陷入了深深的忧虑之中。
A: ♣近  absorption, engagement, engrossment, immersion
A: ♣反  apathy, indifference, nonchalance, unconcern 漠不关心
A: ♣派  preoccupied adj. 全神贯注的

Q:preponderant  [pri'pɔndərənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 占优势的，更重要的： having superior weight, force, importance, or influence
A: ♣例  a preponderant misconception 一个影响甚广的错误概念
A: ♣近  dominant, paramount, predominant, prevalent, overruling
A: ♣反  secondary, subsidiary 次要的
A: ♣派  preponderance n. 优势地位

Q:prepossessing  [,pri:pə'zesiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 给人好感的：serving to impress favorably
A: ♣例  He was fascinated by her prepossessing appearance at first sight. 他第一眼就被她迷人的外表吸引了。
A: ♣近  alluring, attractive, appealing, captivating, charming, enchanting, pleasing, riveting
A: ♣反  abhorrent, appalling, disgusting, hideous, loathsome, repellent, repulsive 令人反感的
A: ♣派  unprepossessing adj. 不吸引人的

Q:preposterous  [pri'pɔstərəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 荒谬的，不符合常理的： contrary to nature, reason, or common sense
A: ♣例  a preposterous conclusion of quantum mechanics 量子力学里有悖于常理的结论
A: ♣近  absurd, asinine, fallacious, fatuous, lunatic, ludicrous, insane, irrational, unreasonable
A: ♣反  commonsensical 常识性的；reasonable, sensible 有道理的

Q:prerequisite  ['pri:'rekwizit]
A: ♠考法1  n. 先决条件，前提： something that is necessary to an end or to the carrying out of a function
A: ♣例  Competence is prerequisite to promotion. 能力是提升的必要条件。‖I don’t think a large dwelling place is a prerequisite for a happy life. 我并不认为大的住所就能带来幸福的生活。
A: ♣近  condition, essential, must, necessity, precondition, requirement, requisite, sine qua non

Q:prerogative  [pri'rɔɡətiv]
A: ♠考法1  n. 特权，权力： an exclusive or special right, power, or privilege
A: ♣例  It is your prerogative to refuse to attend religious services. 你有权力不参加宗教活动。
A: ♣近  appanage, birthright, entitlement, privilege, right

Q:presage  ['presidʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 征兆： something believed to be a sign or warning of a future event
A: ♣例  The sight of the first robin is always a welcome presage of spring. 第一只知更鸟的出现总是迎接春天到来的象征
A: ♣近  augury, auspice, boding, foreboding, foreshadowing, portent, prefiguring
A: ♠考法2  vt. 预示，预言： to foretell or predict
A: ♣例  The incident may presage war. 这个事件可能是战争的征兆
A: ♣近  adumbrate, augur, forecast, foretell, portend, predict, prognosticate, prophesy

Q:prescience  ['presiəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 预知，先见： knowledge of actions or events before they occur
A: ♣例  Most believers would probably agree that complete prescience is one of God's attributes. 所有的信徒大概都会同意上帝能够预见未来
A: ♣近  foresight, forethought, providence
A: ♣反  improvidence, myopia, shortsightedness 目光短浅

Q:prescription  [pris'kripʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 规定，传统的规矩： something prescribed as a rule; especially an inherited or established way of thinking, feeling, or doing
A: ♣近  convention, custom, decree, law, regulation, rule
A: ♣派  prescribe v. 开药方；设立规定

Q:preservative  [pri'zə:vətiv]
A: ♠考法1  n. 防腐剂： an additive used to protect against decay, discoloration, or spoilage
A: ♣例  containing no chemical preservative 不含化学防腐剂
A: ♣派  preserve v. 保存

Q:prestige  [pre'sti:ʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 声望，威望： the level of respect at which one is regarded by others
A: ♣例  The prestige of the university has been irrevocably impaired by the plagiarism scandal. 这所大学的声望已经因剽窃丑闻而受到了不可挽回的损失。
A: ♣近  credit, fame, influence, reputation
A: ♣反  infamy 坏名声
A: ♣派  prestigious adj. 有名望的

Q:presumptuous  [pri'zʌmptjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 放肆的，冒昧的： overstepping due bounds (as of propriety or courtesy)
A: ♣例  Under such a circumstance his demand for attention was utterly presumptuous. 在那种情况下他要求被关注是极其冒昧的
A: ♣近  audacious, bold, brash, impertinent, impudent, insolent, pompous, presuming
A: ♣反  courteous, decorous, genteel, gracious, urbane 举止得体的，有礼貌的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 傲慢的： having a feeling of superiority that shows itself in an overbearing attitude
A: ♣例  The presumptuous doctor didn't even bother to explain to me the treatment that I would be receiving. 傲慢的医生连给我说明我会接受何种治疗的耐性都没有。
A: ♣近  assumptive, bumptious, cavalier, haughty, imperious, lofty, overweening, peremptory, supercilious
A: ♣反  humble, modest 谦卑的

Q:pretense  [pri'tens]
A: ♠考法1  n. 虚假，伪装： the act of pretending; a false appearance or action intended to deceive
A: ♣例  There is too much pretense in his piety. 他的虔诚大多都是伪装。
A: ♣近  affectation, camouflage, deceit, disguise, imposture, mask, masquerade
A: ♣反  sincerity 真诚
A: ♠考法2  n. 自大，优越感： an exaggerated sense of one's importance that shows itself in the making of excessive or unjustified claims
A: ♣近  assumption, hauteur, imperiousness, loftiness, lordliness, pomposity, superciliousness, superiority
A: ♣反  humility, modesty 谦逊

Q:preternatural  [,pri:tə'nætʃərəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 超乎寻常的： surpassing the normal or usual
A: ♣例  They exhibited preternatural courage in face of danger. 他们在危险面前显示出了超乎寻常的勇气。
A: ♣近  aberrant, abnormal, anomalous, extraordinary, phenomenal, magical, miraculous, unearthly
A: ♣反  common, ordinary, prosaic 平凡的

Q:prevail  [pri'veil]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 盛行，战胜： to be greater in strength or influence
A: ♣例  a custom that still prevails 依然盛行的传统
A: ♣近  conquer, dominate, overcome, reign, triumph
A: ♣反  yield 屈服；lose 失败
A: ♣派  prevailing adj. 盛行的

Q:prevalent  ['prevələnt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 流行的，普遍的： widely or commonly occurring, existing, accepted, or practiced
A: ♣例  The kinds of accidents are frequently seen in places where snowmobiles are prevalent. 这种类型的事故在摩托雪橇盛行的地区是很常见的。
A: ♣近  conventional, dominant, common, popular, predominant, preponderant, prevailing, rife
A: ♣反  absent, rare 缺少的，稀少的；unusual 与众不同的
A: ♣派  prevalence n. 流行，遍及

Q:prevaricate  [pri'værikeit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 支吾其词，撒谎： to stray from or evade the truth
A: ♣例  During the hearings the witness did his best to prevaricate. 听证会上证人在竭尽全力地支吾其词。
A: ♣近  equivocate, fabricate, falsify, lie, palter
A: ♣派  prevarication n. 支吾其词

Q:primordial  [prai'mɔ:djəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 原始的，最初的： being or happening first in sequence of time
A: ♣例  primordial forms of life 最原始的生命形态
A: ♣近  ancient, early, primal, primeval, primitive
A: ♣反  late, recent 最近的

Q:primp  [primp]
A: ♠考法1  v. 精心打扮： to dress, adorn, or arrange in a careful or finicky manner
A: ♣例  She primps for hours before a date. 她出门约会前要花数小时打扮。
A: ♣近  preen, dress up

Q:principal  ['prinsəpəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 主要的，重要的： first, highest, or foremost in importance, rank, worth, or degree
A: ♣例  The region's principal city is getting hammered by a series of terrorist attacks. 该地区的中心城市正在被一系列恐怖袭击攻击。
A: ♣近  capital, cardinal, chief, dominant, grand, main, major, paramount, predominant, preeminent, primary
A: ♣反  secondary, subordinate 次要的

Q:pristine  ['pristain]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 纯净的，质朴的，未被文明腐蚀的： remaining in a pure state; uncorrupted by civilization. remaining free from dirt or decay; clean
A: ♣例  a pristine forest 一片未被文明影响的森林
A: ♣近  immaculate, spotless, stainless, unsoiled, unstained, unsullied
A: ♣反  tainted, squalid, contaminated, besmirched ,corrupted by civilization 污染的，被文明腐蚀的

Q:privation  [prai'veiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 缺乏，穷困： lack of what is needed for existence
A: ♣例  the constant privation of sleep was starting to affect his work 长期以来的睡眠不足开始影响他的工作
A: ♣近  deprivation, loss
A: ♣反  repletion 充满

Q:probe  [prəub]
A: ♠考法1  v./n. 深入调查： a penetrating or critical investigation
A: ♣例  probe into his background 深入调查他的背景
A: ♣近  delving, disquisition, exploration, inquisition

Q:probity  ['prəubiti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 正直： faithfulness to high moral standards
A: ♣例  a person of indisputable probity should head the disciplinary panel 一个绝对正直的人应该来领导纪律委员会
A: ♣近  honesty, integrity, rectitude, righteousness, uprightness
A: ♣反  unscrupulousness, shiftiness, baseness, dishonor, lowness 肆无忌惮，欺骗

Q:proclaim  [prəu'kleim]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 宣告，使…公之于众： to declare publicly, typically insistently, proudly, or defiantly and in either speech or writing
A: ♣例  wearing a button that proclaimed my choice for president 身上挂着一个纽扣，它能够彰显我支持谁当总统‖He launched a coup and proclaimed himself president. 他发动了一场政变，然后宣称自己已成为总统。
A: ♣近  advertise, announce, blare, blazon, broadcast, declare, enunciate, herald, promulgate, publicize, publish, release, trumpet
A: ♣反  conceal, hide 隐藏；silence, suppress 压制（观点的发表）

Q:proclivity  [prəu'kliviti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 癖性，偏好： a natural propensity or inclination; predisposition
A: ♣例  showed artistic proclivities at an early age 在很小的时候就表现除了对艺术的喜好
A: ♣近  aptitude, disposition, leaning, partiality, penchant, predilection, propensity
A: ♣反  aversion, antipathy, disinclination 厌恶，反感

Q:procrastinate  [prəu'kræstineit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. （因为懒散）拖延： to put off doing something, especially out of habitual carelessness or laziness
A: ♣例  She procrastinated and missed the submission deadline. 她一直拖拖拉拉，导致错过了截止日期。

Q:procure  [prəu'kjuə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 获得，取得： to get possession of
A: ♣例  procured the prisoner's release 得到了释放囚犯的许可
A: ♣近  acquire, attain, garner, knock down, pull down, bring in
A: ♣反  relinquish, forfeit, lose 放弃

Q:prod  [prɔd]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 促使……行动： to try to persuade (someone) through earnest appeals to follow a course of action
A: ♣例  The strike may prod the government into action. 罢工也许会迫使政府采取行动。
A: ♣近  encourage, exhort, goad, nudge, prompt, spur, egg on
A: ♣反  rein 抑制

Q:prodigal  ['prɔdiɡəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 挥霍的： recklessly spendthrift
A: ♣例  prodigal outlays for her clothes 买衣服时挥金如土
A: ♣近  extravagant, profligate, squandering, unthrifty, wasteful
A: ♣反  frugal, parsimonious, conserving, economical, economizing, penny-pinching, scrimping, skimping, thrifty 节省的，吝啬的
A: ♣派  prodigality 浪费挥霍
A: ♣反  penury, husbandry 贫困，节约
A: ♠考法2  n. 败家子： someone who spends money freely or foolishly
A: ♣例  The million-dollar lottery winner was such a prodigal that his windfall was exhausted after only a few years. 靠彩票中了百万的赢家是个败家子，几年之内就把这笔意外之财全部花完了。
A: ♣近  fritterer, high roller, profligate, spender, spendthrift, squanderer, waster, wastrel
A: ♣反  economizer, penny-pincher 吝啬的人

Q:prodigious  [prəu'didʒəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 巨大的： impressively great in size, force, or extent; enormous
A: ♣例  a prodigious supply of canned food kept in the basement 地下室贮存着大量罐头食品
A: ♣近  colossal, elephantine, enormous, gigantic, titanic, tremendous
A: ♣反  slight 微小的
A: ♣派  prodigy n. 天才，神童
A: ♠考法2  adj. 惊人的，了不起的： causing wonder or astonishment
A: ♣例  stage magicians performing prodigious feats for rapt audiences 舞台魔术师在全神贯注的观众们面前表演
A: ♣近  amazing, astonishing, astounding, awesome, fabulous, miraculous, portentous, staggering, stunning, stupendous, sublime, surprising

Q:profane  [prəu'fein]
A: ♠考法1  v. 亵渎： to treat (something sacred) with abuse, irreverence, or contempt
A: ♣例  invading troops profaned the altar by playing poker on it 侵略军亵渎了祭坛，竟然在上面打扑克
A: ♣近  defile, violate
A: ♣派  profaned 被亵渎的
A: ♣反  unviolated, inviolable 未被亵渎的，不可亵渎的
A: ♠考法2  v. 滥用： to put to a bad or improper use
A: ♣例  profaned his considerable acting talents by appearing in some wretched movies 在一些烂俗的电影里面出现简直就是浪费表演才华
A: ♣近  abuse, misemploy, misuse, pervert, prostitute

Q:proffer  ['prɔfə]
A: ♠考法1  v./n. 献出，提供： to offer for acceptance; tender
A: ♣例  proffered her assistance in helping the two sides reach a compromise 她在斡旋双方达成妥协过程中尽了力
A: ♣近  extend, give, proffer, tender, trot out
A: ♣反  retain, withhold 保留

Q:proficient  [prəu'fiʃənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 熟练的，精通的： having or marked by an advanced degree of competence, as in an art, vocation, profession, or branch of learning
A: ♣例  proficient in translating foreign languages 精通外语翻译
A: ♣近  accomplished, complete, expert, skilled, versed, virtuoso
A: ♣反  inept, incompetent, amateur, inexperienced, inexpert, jackleg, unprofessional, unseasoned, unskilled 无能的

Q:profligate  ['prɔfliɡət]
A: ♠考法1  adj./n. 挥金如土的，挥霍的： recklessly wasteful; wildly extravagant
A: ♣例  leading a profligate life 过着骄奢淫逸的生活
A: ♣近  extravagant, high-rolling, spendthrift, squandering, thriftless, unthrifty, wasteful
A: ♣反  parsimonious, provident, thrift, economical, frugal, conserving 吝啬的，节俭的
A: ♠考法2  n. 败家子： someone who spends money freely or foolishly
A: ♣例  profligate who could not really afford the grand style he maintained at Monticello, Jefferson died deeply in debt 再也支撑不了在蒙蒂塞洛之时的大手大脚的作风，败家子杰斐逊最终深陷债务危机
A: ♣近  fritterer, high roller, spender, spendthrift, squanderer, waster, wastrel
A: ♣反  economizer, penny-pincher 吝啬的人
A: ♠考法3  n. 堕落的人： a person who has sunk below the normal moral standard
A: ♣例  a drunken profligate, he was given to wretched excess in every aspect of his life 一个喝醉的堕落的人，在生活的方方面面都日趋堕落
A: ♣近  backslider, debauchee, debaucher, decadent, deviate, libertine, perv, pervert, profligate, rake, rakehell, rip

Q:profundity  [prəu'fʌndəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 深奥，深刻： something profound or abstruse
A: ♣例  His books are a mixture of playfulness and profundity. 他的作品都是搞笑和深刻的结合体。
A: ♣近  deepness, profoundness
A: ♣反  superficiality 肤浅

Q:profusion  [prəu'fju:ʒən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 丰富，大量： the state of being profuse; abundance
A: ♣例  snow falling in profusion 雪量很大
A: ♣近  abundance, mass, plentitude, scads, volume, wealth
A: ♣反  paucity 极小量
A: ♣派  profuse 丰富的
A: ♣反  scanty 缺乏的
A: ♠考法2  n. 挥霍，浪费： the quality or fact of being free or wasteful in the expenditure of money
A: ♣例  in giving gifts to his girlfriend, he was generous to the point of profusion 对于给女朋友的礼物支出一项，他慷慨到了几乎奢侈的地步
A: ♣近  extravagancy, lavishness, prodigality, wastefulness
A: ♣反  economy, frugality, penny-pinching

Q:prohibitive  [prəu'hibitiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 禁止的；阻止的： tending to prohibit or restrain
A: ♠考法2  adj. （价格高得）抑制购买的： so high or burdensome as to discourage purchase or use
A: ♣例  prohibitive prices 抑制购买的高价

Q:project  ['prɔdʒekt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 方案，计划： a specific plan or design
A: ♣例  an ambitious project to develop the city’s underground transport 一项开发城市地下交通系统的雄心勃勃的计划
A: ♣近  arrangement, blueprint, design, plan, program, scheme, strategy, system, road map
A: ♠考法2  vi. 凸出： to extend outward beyond a usual point
A: ♣例  Some boulders projected dangerously out above the trail. 一些巨石非常危险地在道路上凸了出来。
A: ♣近  balloon, beetle, billow, bunch, jut, overhang, poke, pouch, pout, protrude, swell
A: ♠考法3  vt. 预测，预计： to calculate, estimate, or predict (something in the future), based on present data or trends
A: ♣例  projecting next year’s expenses 预测明年的开销
A: ♣近  augur, estimate, extrapolate, forecast, predict, predetermine, presage
A: ♣派  projected adj. 计划的；projection n. 凸起物；投影

Q:proliferate  [prəu'lifəreit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 快速繁殖，激增： to grow or multiply by rapidly producing new tissue, parts, cells, or offspring
A: ♣例  rumors about the accident proliferated on the Internet 关于事故的小道消息在网上迅速扩散
A: ♣近  balloon, boom, build up, escalate, expand, mushroom, snowball
A: ♣反  decrease in amount, dwindle, contract, decrease, diminish, dwindle, lessen, recede, wane 数量减少，缩小

Q:prolix  ['prəuliks]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 罗嗦的，冗长的： tending to speak or write at excessive length
A: ♣例  habitually transforms brief anecdotes into prolix sagas that exhaust his listeners 总是将简短的小趣事变成冗长的传说故事，让听众很疲倦
A: ♣近  diffuse, garrulous, rambling, verbose, windy
A: ♣反  pithy, taciturn, terse, succinct, concise, extreme brief 精炼的，寡言的

Q:prologue  ['prəulɔɡ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 序言： the preface or introduction to a literary work
A: ♣例  the burglary, which he committed while still a teen, was but a prologue to a wasted life of crime 他青少年时犯过的入室抢劫拉开了他偷盗生涯的序幕
A: ♣近  exordium, foreword, preamble, preface, prelude, proem, prolusion
A: ♣反  epilogue 结尾

Q:prolong  [prə'lɔŋ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 延长，拖延： to lengthen in extent, scope, or range
A: ♣例  Additives are used to prolong the shelf life of packaged food. 添加剂被用来延长包装食品的保存期限。
A: ♣近  elongate, lengthen, outstretch, protract, stretch, drag (out), draw out
A: ♣反  abbreviate, abridge, curtail, cut, cut back, shorten , truncate 截短

Q:promulgate  ['prɔməlɡeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 正式宣布： to make known openly or publicly
A: ♣例  The law was promulgated in June 1988. 法律在1988年6月出台。
A: ♣近  annunciate, declare, enunciate, proclaim, publicize, herald
A: ♣反  keep secret 保密

Q:proofread  ['pru:f,ri:d]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 校对： to read (copy or proof) in order to find errors and mark corrections
A: ♣例  She proofread the paper carefully. 她仔细把论文校对了。

Q:propagate  ['prɔpəɡeit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 繁殖： to cause to continue or increase by sexual or asexual reproduction
A: ♣例  the dams along the river are interfering with the salmon's ability to propagate 河上的大坝影响了大马哈鱼的繁殖
A: ♣近  breed, multiply, reproduce
A: ♣反  fail to multiply 根除，繁殖失败
A: ♠考法2  vt. 传播，宣传： to cause to spread out and affect a greater number or greater area: extend
A: ♣例  the various ways in which churches can propagate the faith 不同的宣传教义的方法
A: ♣近  broadcast, circulate, disseminate
A: ♣反  check 阻止

Q:propensity  [prəu'pensiti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 倾向，癖好： an often intense natural inclination or preference
A: ♣例  a neighbor who has an unfortunate propensity for snooping 好管闲事的邻居
A: ♣近  affinity, aptitude, bent, partiality, penchant, predilection, predisposition, proclivity
A: ♣反  aversion 厌恶

Q:prophetic  [prəu'fetik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 预言的，预示的： foretelling events：predictive
A: ♣例  those lower-than-expected sales numbers were a prophetic indicator of the financial trouble the company would soon be in 那些低于预期的销售数字就是公司即将陷入的金融危机的先兆
A: ♣近  predictive

Q:propitiate  [prəu'piʃieit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 慰抚，劝解： to conciliate (an offended power); appease
A: ♣例  the temple was built to honor the gods in times of plenty and to propitiate them in times of trouble 该庙宇的作用是，丰收之时感谢神明，有难之时安抚神明
A: ♣近  appease, assuage, conciliate, disarm, mollify, placate
A: ♣反  enrage, incense, inflame, infuriate, ire, madden, outrage, antagonize, arouse hostility 激怒

Q:propitious  [prəu'piʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 吉祥的： favorably disposed: pointing toward a happy outcome
A: ♣例  propitious sign 吉祥的征兆
A: ♣近  auspicious, encouraging, fair, heartening, optimistic, promising, upbeat
A: ♣反  dim, discouraging, disheartening, futureless, hopeless, inauspicious, unfavorable, unpromising, unpropitious 不吉利的

Q:proponent  [prəu'pəunənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 建议者，支持者： one who argues in support of something; an advocate
A: ♣例  a proponent of the use of electric-powered cars 电动能源汽车的支持者
A: ♣近  advocate, apostle, champion, expounder, espouser, friend, promoter, supporter, protagonist
A: ♣反  adversary, antagonist, opponent , detractor 诋毁者，反对者

Q:proprietary  [prəu'praiətəri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 所有权： ownership
A: ♣近  dominion, ownership, possession, property, proprietorship
A: ♠考法2  adj. 私营的： privately owned and managed and run as a profit-making organization
A: ♣例  a proprietary hospital 私人医院
A: ♣近  private
A: ♣反  public 政府提供的；state-owned 国有的

Q:propriety  [prəu'praiəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 礼节： conformity to what is socially acceptable in conduct or speech
A: ♣例  When attending a wedding, there are certain proprieties that must be followed. 参加婚礼时，有一些礼节需要遵守。
A: ♣近  decorum, form, etiquette
A: ♣反  impropriety, indecency, indecorum
A: ♠考法2  n. 适当得体： the quality or state of being especially suitable or fitting
A: ♣例  I'm not sure about the propriety of serving champagne in these glasses. 我不确定在这种杯子里倒香槟是否得体。
A: ♣近  appositeness, aptness, felicity, fitness, properness, rightness, seemliness, suitability
A: ♣反  improperness, impropriety, inappositeness, inappropriateness, inaptness, infelicity, unfitness, unseemliness, unsuitability, wrongness 不得体

Q:prosaic  [prəu'zeiik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 单调的，常见的： being of the type that is encountered in the normal course of events
A: ♣例  prosaic advice 老掉牙的建议
A: ♣近  commonplace, everyday, routine, unexceptional, unremarkable, workaday
A: ♣反  abnormal, exceptional, extraordinary, odd, out-of-the-way, strange, exciting, preternatural, ingenious, imaginary 不寻常的，有独创性的

Q:proscribe  [prəus'kraib]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 禁止，排斥： to prohibit; forbid
A: ♣例  acts proscribed by law 被法律禁止的行为
A: ♣近  ban, enjoin, interdict, outlaw, prohibit
A: ♣反  sanction, permit, allow, let, suffer 允许

Q:prosecution  [,prɔsi'kju:ʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 实行，执行： the doing of an action
A: ♣例  oversaw the prosecution of the president's foreign policy 监督总统对外政策的执行情况
A: ♣近  accomplishment, achievement, discharge, enactment, execution, fulfillment, implementation, performance, perpetration, pursuance
A: ♣反  nonfulfillment, nonperformance 不履行，不完成

Q:proselytize  ['prɔsilitaiz]
A: ♠考法1  v. 改变信仰： to persuade to change to one's religious faith
A: ♣例  The efforts of early missionaries to proselytize the Native Americans of Minnesota were largely unproductive. 早期传教士对于明尼苏达的土著人的改变信仰的努力大多无功而返。
A: ♣近  convert

Q:prospect  ['prɔspekt]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 探查，勘探： to go into or range over for purposes of discovery
A: ♣例  people had arrived in the valley to prospect it for gold 人们来到山谷淘金
A: ♣近  hunt, probe, search, skirr
A: ♠考法2  n. 期待，被期望的某物： the act or state of looking forward to some occurrence
A: ♣例  The prospect of a quiet, restful Sunday ended when our basement flooded. 对一个宁静休闲的周日的期待被地下室涨水打破了。
A: ♣近  anticipation, contemplation, expectancy

Q:prosperous  ['prɔspərəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 成功的，繁盛的： marked by vigorous growth and well-being especially economically
A: ♣例  The company had a prosperous year. 公司今年业绩斐然。
A: ♣近  booming, flourishing, halcyon, lush, palmy, roaring, thriving
A: ♣反  depressed, impecunious 萧条的，贫穷的

Q:prostrate  ['prɔstreit]

A: ♣例  He was lying prostrate on the bed. 他平躺在床上。
A: ♣近  debilitated, effete, enervated, enfeebled, languid, sapped
A: ♣反  erect, upright 直立的
A: ♠考法2  adj./v. 衰弱的/使衰竭： to reduce to extreme weakness or incapacitation
A: ♣例  illness that prostrated an entire family 将整个家庭拖垮的疾病
A: ♣近  debilitate, devitalize, enervate, enfeeble, etiolate, sap, tire
A: ♣反  fortify, strengthen, beef up

Q:protean  [prəu'ti:ən]

A: ♣例  He loved to show off his protean talent. 他喜欢炫耀自己多样的才华.
A: ♣近  adaptable, universal, all-around
A: ♣反  static 固定的

Q:protocol  ['prəutəkɔl]

A: ♣例  a breach of protocol 社交礼仪的破坏

Q:prototype  ['prəutətaip]

A: ♣近  archetype
A: ♣反  copy, imitation, replica, reproduction 复制品

Q:protract  [prə'trækt]

A: ♣近  elongate, lengthen, prolong, stretch, drag out, draw out,
A: ♣反  curtail, abridge, abbreviate, shorten, cut back 缩减

Q:protrude  [prəu'tru:d]

A: ♣例  a handkerchief protruding from his breast pocket 手帕从他的上衣口袋里突出出来
A: ♣近  bulge, overhang, poke, project, stand out, stick out
A: ♣反  concave 凹陷

Q:protuberant  [prəu'tju:bərənt]

A: ♣例  protuberant eyes 暴鱼眼
A: ♣反  depressed 下陷的
A: ♣派  protuberance 隆起
A: ♣反  concavity 凹陷

Q:provident  ['prɔvidənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 节俭的： frugal; economical
A: ♣例  it is possible to be provident without being miserly 人可以做到节俭但不吝啬
A: ♣近  economical, sparing, thrifty, farsighted, provident, scrimping
A: ♣反  profligate 挥霍的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 有远见的： having or showing awareness of and preparation for the future
A: ♣例  her provident measures kept us safe while we waited out the hurricane 她之前有远见的准备让我等待飓风结束的期间安全无恙
A: ♣近  farseeing, farsighted, forehanded, foreseeing, forethoughtful, prescient, proactive, visionary
A: ♣反  half-baked, half-cocked, improvident, myopic, shortsighted 目光短浅的

Q:providential  [,prɔvi'denʃəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 天意的，幸运的： happening as if through divine intervention
A: ♣例  a providential escape 幸运的逃脱
A: ♣近  lucky, fluky, fortuitous
A: ♣反  unfortunate, mishap, hapless, ill-fated, ill-starred, luckless, star-crossed 不幸的

Q:provincial  [prəu'vinʃəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj./n. 狭隘的： limited in perspective; narrow and self-centered
A: ♣例  an artist who has been criticized for being provincial 一个被批评非常狭隘的艺术家
A: ♣近  illiberal, insular, parochial, sectarian, narrow-minded
A: ♣反  ecumenical, broad-minded, catholic, cosmopolitan, liberal, open, open-minded, receptive, tolerant 世界范围的，开放包容的

Q:provisional  [prəu'viʒənəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 临时的： provided or serving only for the time being; temporary
A: ♣例  he was appointed provisional executor of the industrialist's vast estate 他被任命为庞大工业帝国的临时执行官
A: ♣近  impermanent, interim, provisionary, short-term
A: ♣反  long-term, permanent 永久的

Q:provisory  [prəu'vaizəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有附带条件的，临时的： depending on a proviso; conditional; serving in a position for the time being
A: ♣例  a provisory permit to block off the street while movie scenes were being shot 一个同意在电影拍摄期间封锁道路的临时许可
A: ♣近  interim, provisional, provisionary, provisory
A: ♣反  unconditional, long-term, permanent 无条件的，永久的

Q:provoke  [prəu'vəuk]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 激怒： to incite to anger or resentment
A: ♣例  his teasing finally provoked her to anger 他的调戏最终把她激怒了
A: ♣近  arouse, excite, incite, instigate, pique, stimulate, stir, fire up
A: ♠考法2  vt. 驱使，激起： to stir to action or feeling
A: ♣例  rankings that are sure to provoke an argument among film critics 排名必将引发影评家们的争论
A: ♣近  abet, ferment, foment, instigate, stir up, whip up

Q:prowess  ['prauis]
A: ♠考法1  n. 英勇，勇敢： superior strength, courage, or daring, especially in battle
A: ♣例  his prowess on the football field 他在球场上过人的勇气
A: ♣近  bravery, courageousness, daring, gallantry, guts, intrepidity
A: ♣反  timid, cowardice, cravenness, dastardliness, poltroonery, spinelessness 胆怯

Q:prowl  [praul]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 潜行，巡游以猎取食物： to roam through stealthily, as in search of prey or plunder
A: ♣例  I prowled the shop looking for sales. 我在商店里转悠，寻找打折商品。

Q:prude  [pru:d]
A: ♠考法1  n. 过分正经的人：一个过分关心自己是否是或显得得体、谦逊或正确的人： a person who is greatly concerned with seemly behavior and morality especially regarding sexual matters
A: ♣例  the racy sitcom frequently satirizes exactly the sort of prude who would like to see the show taken off the air
A: ♣近  bluenose, moralist, puritan
A: ♣反  immoralist 不道德的人

Q:prudent  ['pru:dənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 明智的： marked by wisdom or judiciousness; wise
A: ♣例  prudent advice 明智的建议
A: ♣近  advisable, desirable, judicious, politic, tactical, intelligent
A: ♣反  fool 傻的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 小心谨慎的，审慎的： marked by circumspection

Q:prudish  ['pru:diʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 过分守礼的： marked by prudery
A: ♣例  By the prudish standards of the 19th century, any depiction of the nude was scandalous. 根据19世纪的保守标准，任何对裸露的刻画描述都是下流无耻的。
A: ♣近  nice-nelly, prim, puritanical

Q:prune  [pru:n]
A: ♠考法1  n. 梅干： a plum dried or capable of drying without fermentation
A: ♠考法2  vt. 修剪： to cut off or remove dead or living parts or branches of (a plant, for example) to improve shape or growth
A: ♣例  The students were asked to prune their essays. 学生们被要求修改文章。
A: ♣近  shave, shear, snip, trim

Q:pry  [prai]
A: ♠考法1  v. 刺探： to look or inquire closely, curiously, or impertinently
A: ♣例  don't go prying into other people's business 别去打探别人的事
A: ♣近  interlope, intermeddle, intrude, nose, obtrude, snoop

Q:pseudonym  ['psju:dənim]
A: ♠考法1  n. 假名，笔名： a fictitious name
A: ♣例  Mark Twain is the pseudonym of the American writer Samuel L. Clemens. 马克?吐温是美国作家塞缪尔?L?克莱蒙斯的笔名。
A: ♣近  alias, nom de guerre

Q:psychology  [psai'kɔlədʒi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 心理学： the science that deals with mental processes and behavior
A: ♣例  She studied psychology in college. 她大学专业是心理学。
A: ♠考法2  n. 心理战术： subtle tactical action or argument used to manipulate or influence another
A: ♣例  He used poor psychology on his employer when trying to make the point. 他表达观点时，对老板用了拙劣的心理战术。

Q:pucker  ['pʌkə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 撅（嘴），使收缩： to become gathered, contracted, and wrinkled
A: ♣例  pucker my lips 撅起嘴

Q:puckish  ['pʌkiʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 淘气的，顽皮的： mischievous; impish
A: ♣例  She had a puckish smile on her face. 她脸上挂着顽皮的笑容。
A: ♣近  devilish, impish, prankish, rascally, waggish
A: ♣反  sober, grave, staid 严肃的

Q:puerile  ['pjuərail]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 幼稚的，不成熟的： immature; lacking in adult experience or maturity
A: ♣例  puerile remarks 幼稚的评论
A: ♣近  adolescent, green, immature, puerile, unfledged, unformed, unripened
A: ♣反  adult, experienced, grown-up, mature, ripe, sagacious 睿智的，成熟的

Q:puissance  ['pju:isəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 权力： power; might
A: ♣例  the president pledged to put the full puissance of the nation into the war effort 总统下令全国进入战争状态
A: ♣近  force, might, potency, strength, vigor, sinew
A: ♣反  powerlessness, impotence, weakness 无力

Q:pulchritude  ['pʌlkritju:d]
A: ♠考法1  n. 美丽： great physical beauty and appeal
A: ♣反  ugliness, homeliness, hideousness 丑陋，平庸

Q:pulverize  ['pʌlvəraiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 研磨成粉： to bring to a complete end the physical soundness, existence, or usefulness of
A: ♣例  Bits of pulverized rock filled the air. 被碾碎的岩石碎片充斥在空气里。
A: ♣反  solidify, build, construct, erect, put up, raise, rear, set up 硬化，构建

Q:pun  [pʌn]
A: ♠考法1  n. 双关语： the usually humorous use of a word in such a way as to suggest two or more of its meanings or the meaning of another word similar in sound
A: ♣例  He's a skillful pilot whose career has—no pun intended—really taken off. 她是个技术娴熟的飞行员，飞行生涯——没有别的意思——真正腾飞了。

Q:punctilious  [pʌŋk'tiliəs]

A: ♣近  decorous, proper, starchy, stilted
A: ♣反  remiss, slipshod, casual, easygoing, informal, laid-back, unceremonious 粗心的

Q:pundit  ['pʌndit]

A: ♣例  the new laptop has gotten a thumbs-up from industry pundits 新出的笔记本电脑受到了业界专家的一致好评
A: ♣近  savant, scholar

Q:pungent  ['pʌndʒənt]

A: ♣例  pungent language 辛辣讽刺的语言
A: ♣近  acerbic, acid, acrid, caustic, mordant, sardonic, scalding, scathing

Q:puny  ['pju:ni]

A: ♣例  I wouldn't mess with him—he makes bodybuilders look puny in comparison. 我不敢招惹他——其他健身的人和他比起来都像小孩。
A: ♣近  diminutive, dwarfish, slight, subnormal
A: ♣反  enormous, considerable, grand, husky, king-size, outsize, overscale, substantial, whacking, whopping 巨大的

Q:purity  ['pjuəriti]

A: ♣例  struggling to live a life of purity while surrounded by wickedness 即使周围充满邪恶，也要使自己生命纯粹、完美
A: ♣近  chasteness, immaculacy, innocence, modesty
A: ♣反  impurity, unchasteness, unchastity 堕落，没有节操
A: ♣派  impurity n. 杂质
A: ♣派  purist n. 纯粹主义者

Q:purlieu  ['pə:lju:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 常去的地方： a place for spending time or for socializing
A: ♣例  The restaurant, the preferred purlieu of the theatergoing crowd, is always packed an hour or two before showtime. 观剧的人群经常去的那间餐厅，总是在演出开始前1-2小时爆满。
A: ♣近  haunt, purlieu, rendezvous, resort, stamping ground, stomping ground
A: ♠考法2  n. 临近的地区： an adjoining region or space
A: ♣例  We stopped at one of the several pubs in the purlieus of the stadium. 我们在体育馆附近的一间酒吧停下来。
A: ♣近  backyard, neighborhood, purlieus, vicinage, vicinity

Q:purloin  [pə:'lɔin]

A: ♣近  appropriate, filch, pilfer, snitch, thieve

Q:pusillanimous  [,pju:si'læniməs]

A: ♣例  pusillanimous politicians who vote according to whichever way the political wind is blowing 胆小懦弱的政客，舆论风向倒向谁就投票给谁
A: ♣近  craven, dastardly, gutless, poltroon, recreant, spineless
A: ♣反  brave, courageous, daring, dauntless, doughty, gallant, gutsy, intrepid, lionhearted, stalwart, stout, stouthearted, valiant, valorous 勇敢的

Q:quack  [kwæk]

A: ♣例  don't bother to see that guy, as I've heard he's a quack with no actual training 别再找他看病了，我听说他就是个没有真才实学的江湖郎中
A: ♣近  charlatan, fake, fraud, hoaxer, mountebank, phony
A: ♣反  honest practitioner 诚实从业者

Q:quaff  [kwɑ:f]

Q:quail  [kweil]

A: ♣近  blench, cringe, recoil, shrink, wince
A: ♣反  become resolute, give bold 变得坚决、大胆

A: ♣反  unreserved, absolute, categorical 无保留的，不受限制的

A: ♣近  equip, fit, prepare, ready, season, train

Q:quandary  ['kwɔndəri]

A: ♣反  state of complete certainty 胸有成竹

Q:quench  [kwentʃ]

A: ♣近  assuage, quench, sate, satiate, slake

Q:quibble  ['kwibl]

A: ♣例  My only quibble about the trip was that it rained a lot. 我对旅行唯一的小不满就是下雨有点多。

Q:rabble  ['ræbl]

Q:racy  ['reisi]

A: ♣近  animate, brisk, frisky, jaunty, perky, spirited, vivacious
A: ♣反  tame, dead, inactive, inanimate, lackadaisical, languid, languorous, leaden, lifeless, limp, listless, spiritless, vapid 乏味的，死气沉沉的

Q:raffish  ['ræfiʃ]

Q:ragged  ['ræɡid]

A: ♣例  A ragged coat may cover an honest man. 不能以衣著取人。

A: ♣反  kempt, neat, trim 整洁的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 凹凸不平的，不光滑的： not having a level or smooth surface
A: ♣例  She cut herself on the ragged edge of the tin can's lid. 她被罐头盖的锋利边缘割伤了。
A: ♣近  broken, bumpy, coarse, irregular, jagged, lumpy, pebbly, rough, roughened, rugged, scraggy
A: ♣反  even, flat, level, plane 平整的；smooth 光滑的

Q:rail  [reil]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 怒骂，猛烈抨击： to revile or scold in harsh, insolent, or abusive language
A: ♣例  We could hear the cook in the kitchen railing against his assistant and wondered if we'd ever get our food. 我们可以听到厨师在厨房怒斥他的助手，由此我们怀疑我们点的菜还能不能做好。
A: ♣近  baste, berate, castigate, chastise, hammer, lambaste, rebuke, reprimand, reproach, upbraid
A: ♣反  accredit, applaud, commend, eulogize, extol, laud, praise 表扬，赞扬
A: ♣派  raillery n. 善意的打闹

Q:rakish  ['reikiʃ]
