A: ♣派  rake n. 行为不检点的人，放荡的人

Q:ramble  ['ræmbl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 漫步，漫游： to move aimlessly from place to place
A: ♣例  rambling under the starlight 在星光下漫步‖rambling around Beijing for a week 在北京四处漫游一周
A: ♣近  amble, cruise, drift, float, meander, perambulate, roam, saunter, stroll, traipse, wander
A: ♠考法2  vi. 漫谈；长篇大论（并经常离题）地说或写： to talk at length without sticking to a topic or getting to a point
A: ♣例  rambling on about dating, homework, movies, and the local football team 扯了一些关于约会、作业、电影以及本地橄榄球队的闲谈
A: ♣近  blather, chat, chatter, drivel, maunder, patter, prattle

Q:rambunctious  [ræm'bʌŋkʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 喧闹的，骚乱的： being rough or noisy in a high-spirited way
A: ♣例  That beach is often taken over by packs of rambunctious young people, so don't go there expecting peace and quiet. 那个海滩经常被一帮吵闹的年轻人占领，所以不要指望过去能享受到平静和安宁。
A: ♣近  boisterous, clamorous, raucous, riotous, rowdy, tumultuous, turbulent
A: ♣反  orderly 有秩序的；calm, noiseless, peaceful, placid, quiet, serene, silent, soundless, tranquil 安静的

Q:rampant  ['ræmpənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （植物）生长茂盛的： growing thickly and vigorously
A: ♣例  a rampant growth of weeds in the neglected yard 被遗忘的院子里杂草疯长
A: ♣近  lush, luxuriant, prosperous, weedy
A: ♣反  sparse 稀疏的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 猖獗的，不受限制的： occurring without restraint and frequently, widely, or menacingly
A: ♣例  Mayor promised to put a stop to the rampant crime that plagued the city. 市长承诺要采取措施，消灭那些扰乱城市治安的猖獗的犯罪活动。‖rampant corruption in city government 市政府中猖獗的腐败
A: ♣近  abandoned, intemperate, runaway, unbounded, unbridled, unchecked, uncontrolled, unhampered, unhindered, unrestrained
A: ♣反  bridled, checked, constrained, controlled, curbed, governed, hampered, hindered, restrained, temperate 受制约的

Q:ramshackle  ['ræm,ʃækl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 摇摇欲坠的： appearing ready to collapse; rickety
A: ♣例  a ramshackle cabin in the woods 树林中摇摇欲坠的小木屋
A: ♣近  rickety, shaky, tottering
A: ♣反  concrete, firm, solid, sturdy 坚固的；stable稳定的

Q:rancor  ['ræŋkə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 敌意，深仇： a bitter deep-seated ill will
A: ♣例  A good man terminates a friendship without rancor. 君子绝交不记仇。
A: ♣近  animosity, animus, antagonism, antipathy, bitterness, gall, grudge, hostility, jaundice
A: ♣反  amity, harmony, goodwill, rapport, rapprochement 和睦，友好；friendship 友谊

Q:random  ['rændəm]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 随机的，随意的： lacking a definite plan, purpose, or pattern
A: ♣例  We received several answers and picked one at random. 我们收到了若干答案，并随机抽取了一个。
A: ♣例  aimless, arbitrary, desultory, erratic, haphazard, scattered, slapdash, stray
A: ♣反  methodical, orderly, organized, regular, systematic, systematized 井然有序的，系统化的
A: ♣派  randomly adv. 随机地；randomize v. 随机挑选、排列

Q:rankle  ['ræŋkl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 激怒： to cause anger, irritation, or deep bitterness
A: ♣例  It rankles me when some schools can't even afford paper and pencils for the students. 当我获悉有些学校连纸张和铅笔都无法提供给学生时，我感到十分愤怒。
A: ♣近  aggravate, enrage, exasperate, incense, inflame, infuriate, ire, madden, rile, roil
A: ♣反  delight, gratify, please 使愉悦；appease, assuage, conciliate, mollify, placate, propitiate 安抚

Q:rant  [rænt]
A: ♠考法1  n. （尤指长时间的）训斥，责骂： a long angry speech or scolding
A: ♣例  After complaining about the hotel’s lousy service, the woman went off on another rant about the condition of her room. 在抱怨完旅店差劲的服务之后，她继续对房间的条件开骂。
A: ♣近  castigation, diatribe, harangue, lambasting, philippic, reprimand, reproach, vituperation
A: ♣反  encomium, eulogy, panegyric, rhapsody, tribute 赞美之词
A: ♠考法2  vi. 怒吼： to speak or write in a noisy, angry or violent manner
A: ♣例  The old expert ranted that nobody paid any attention to his opinion. 老专家怒气冲冲的叫嚷说没人听他的观点。
A: ♣近  bluster, fulminate, huff, rave, roar, spout
A: ♣反  grumble, murmur, mutter 低声抱怨

Q:rapacious  [rə'peiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 食量大的，贪食的： having a huge appetite
A: ♣例  The manager at the buffet restaurant was apparently astonished by a team of rapacious professional basketball players. 自助餐厅的经理很明显被那一队胃口巨大的职业篮球队员们震惊到了。
A: ♣近  edacious, esurient,gluttonous, greedy, ravenous, voracious
A: ♠考法2  adj. 过度贪婪的： excessively grasping or covetous
A: ♣例  Some companies is rapacious and hardly looking for the long-term value. 有些公司十分贪婪，而且不考虑长期利益。
A: ♣近  acquisitive, avaricious, avid, coveting, covetous, grasping, mercenary, moneygrubbing
A: ♣反  content, sated, satiated, satisfied 心满意足的
A: ♣派  rapaciousness n. 贪婪

Q:rapport  [ræ'pɔ:t]
A: ♠考法1  n. 和睦，友好： a friendly relationship marked by ready communication and mutual understanding
A: ♣例  His good rapport with his students was one of the reasons why the school board named him Teacher of the Year. 他和学生的关系和睦是他被提名为“年度教师”的原因之一。
A: ♣近  amity,communion, concord, fellowship, harmony, rapprochement
A: ♣反  animosity, antagonism, antipathy, bitterness, enmity, hostility, jaundice, rancor 敌意

Q:rapprochement  [,rɑ:prɔʃ'mɔŋ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 和睦，友好： establishment of or state of having cordial relations
A: ♣例  an era of rapprochement betweenChina and Russia 中俄两国睦邻友好关系的新纪元
A: ♣近  amity,communion, concord, fellowship, harmony, rapport
A: ♣反  animosity, antagonism, antipathy, bitterness, enmity, hostility, jaundice, rancor 敌意

Q:rapscallion  [ræp'skæljən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 流氓，恶棍：a mean, evil, or unprincipled person
A: ♣例  an unsafe place frequented by drunkards and rapscallions 一个酒鬼和流氓经常造访的不安全的地方
A: ♣近  brute, devil, evildoer, fiend, knave, miscreant, rascal, reprobate, rogue, savage, scamp, varlet, wretch
A: ♣反  saint 圣人；cavalier, chevalier （尤指对女士）彬彬有礼的绅士

Q:rapt  [ræpt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 狂喜的： experiencing or marked by overwhelming usually pleasurable emotion
A: ♣例  a rock band that still attracts rapt crowds 一个仍然拥有者狂热粉丝的乐队
A: ♣近  elated, elevated, enraptured, entranced, euphoric, exhilarated, intoxicated, rapturous, rhapsodic
A: ♣反  crestfallen, dejected, depressed 沮丧的；doleful, gloomy, melancholy, mournful, woeful 哀伤的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 全神贯注的：deeply absorbed; engrossed
A: ♣例  With a mixture of delight and awe, the rapt children stared at the chick in the incubator breaking out of its shell. 怀着愉快和敬畏的复杂心理，孩子们全神贯注地盯着孵化箱中的小鸡破壳而出。
A: ♣近  absorbed, concentrated, deep, engrossed, enthralled, focused, immersed, intent, observant
A: ♣反  absent, abstracted, distracted, inattentive 不专心的；apathetic, disinterested, unconcerned 冷漠的，不关心的

Q:rarefy  ['rεərifai]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使稀薄： to make rare, thin, porous, or less dense: to expand without the addition of matter
A: ♣例  rarefy the air 使空气变得稀薄
A: ♣近  attenuate, dilute, thin
A: ♣反  concentrate, condense 使稠密，浓缩
A: ♣派  rarefaction n. 稀薄，稀疏

Q:rash  [ræʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 草率的，仓促的： marked by or proceeding from undue haste or lack of deliberation or caution
A: ♣例  That was too rash a move: for now you've lost your bishop and probably the whole chess game. 那一招棋着实是太草率了，现在你丢掉了象，很有可能会输掉整场比赛。
A: ♣近  cursory, gadarene, headlong, hurried, overhasty, precipitate, precipitous, rushed
A: ♣反  deliberate 慎重考虑的；leisurely, unhurried, unrushed 从容不迫的，不慌不忙的
A: ♣派  rashly adv. 草率地，仓促地

Q:raspy  ['rɑ:spi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 声音刺耳的： harsh and dry in sound
A: ♣例  The dying man was speaking in a raspy and barely discernible voice. 将死的人在用一种沙哑刺耳且难以听清的语调说话。
A: ♣近  cacophonous, coarse, croaky, harsh, grating, gravelly, gruff, husky, rasping, rusty, scratchy, throaty
A: ♣反  mellifluous, sweet 声音甜美的；gentle, soft, tender 声音轻柔的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 容易生气的： easily irritated or annoyed
A: ♣例  Overwork tends to make him raspy. 过度的工作让他变得烦躁易怒。
A: ♣近  choleric, fiery, grouchy, irascible, peevish, pettish, petulant, prickly, ratty, testy
A: ♣反  agreeable, amiable, good-natured, good-tempered, well-disposed 脾气性格好的

Q:ratify  ['rætifai]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （官方地）认可，批准： to give official acceptance of as satisfactory
A: ♣例  Lincoln's home state of Illinois was the first to ratify the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, which provided for the abolition of slavery. 林肯的老家——伊利诺伊是美国第一个通过《宪法第十三修正案》的州，该决案提供了废除奴隶制的法律基础。
A: ♣近  accredit, approbate, authorize, certify, endorse, finalize, formalize, pass, sanction, validate, warrant
A: ♣反  decline, deny, disallow, disapprove, negative, reject, veto 否决
A: ♣派  ratification n. 正式批准

Q:ratiocination  [,rætiɔsi'neiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 推理： the thought processes that have been established as leading to valid solutions to problems
A: ♣例  As an expert in ratiocination, the detective Sherlock Holmes has few rivals. 作为推理专家，大侦探福尔摩斯可谓无人能及。
A: ♣近  deduction, intellection, reason, reasoning, sense

Q:ration  ['ræʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 定额供应量，配给量： an amount allotted or made available especially from a limited supply
A: ♣例  The meat ration was down to one pound per person per week. 肉的人均供给量降至了每周一磅。
A: ♣近  allotment, allowance, apportionment, portion, provision, quota, share
A: ♠考法2  vt. 按比例分配： to give as a share or portion
A: ♣例  The region has had to ration water during times of drought. 干旱时该地区不得不按比例分配水资源。
A: ♣近  allocate, allot, allow, apportion, assign, distribute, lot
A: ♣反  keep, retain, withhold 扣留，拒接给予

Q:rational  ['ræʃənəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 合乎逻辑的： consistent with or based on reason; logical
A: ♣例  He insisted there was a rational explanation for the strange creaking noises and that there were no such things as ghosts. 他坚持认为奇怪的咯吱声一定有一个合理的解释，而不是所谓的鬼在作怪。
A: ♣近  analytic, coherent, consequent, logical, reasonable, sensible, sound, valid, well-founded, well-grounded
A: ♣反  illogical, incoherent, inconsequent, invalid, irrational, unreasonable, unsound, weak 不合逻辑的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 理性的： based on sound reasoning or information
A: ♣例  Betting all of your savings on the lottery is not a rational move. 把你所有的存款赌在彩票上可不是一个理智的决定。
A: ♣近  commonsensical, firm, informed, just, justified, levelheaded, sober, solid
A: ♣反  groundless, unfounded, unjustified 无理由的，无根据的
A: ♣派  rationalize v. 使合理化；找借口

Q:rave  [reiv]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 狂热赞扬： to make an exaggerated display of affection or enthusiasm
A: ♣例  Critics raved about the new play. 新剧得到了评论家们的热烈赞扬。
A: ♣近  drool, effuse, enthuse, fuss, rhapsodize, slobber
A: ♣反  blame, censure, condemn, criticize, denounce, pan, reprehend 批评，指责
A: ♠考法2  vi. （发疯般地）怒吼： to talk irrationally and wildly in or as if in delirium
A: ♣例  a man standing outside the city hall,raving like a lunatic about his tax bill 站在市政大厅外、像疯子一样叫嚷着自己税单的人
A: ♣近  bluster, fulminate, huff, rant, roar, spout
A: ♣反  grumble, murmur, mutter 小声抱怨

Q:ravel  ['rævəl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 解开，松开： to separate the various strands of
A: ♣例  Since the sweater is too small, you could ravel the yarnout and make something else with it. 既然这个毛衣太大，你可以把它拆了然后织些新的东西。
A: ♣近  disentangle, extricate, unbraid, unsnarl, untwine, unweave
A: ♣反  braid, knit, plait, weave 编织
A: ♠考法2  vt. 阐明： to clarify by separating the aspects of
A: ♣近  clarify, clear, elucidate, untangle, unravel
A: ♣反  complex, complicate, entangle, perplex, sophisticate, snarl, tangle 使复杂化
A: ♠考法3  vt. 使纠缠，使复杂化： to tangle or complicate
A: ♣例  a ravelled story 一个复杂的故事
A: ♣近  complex, complicate, entangle, perplex, sophisticate, snarl, tangle
A: ♣近  clarify, clear, elucidate, untangle, unravel 阐明

Q:ravenous  ['rævənəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 食量大的，贪食的： having a huge appetite
A: ♣例  He had moderated his ravenous appetite. 他克制了自己的食欲。‖ravenous for power 渴望权力
A: ♣近  edacious, esurient, gluttonous, greedy, rapacious, voracious
A: ♣反  content, sated, satiated, satisfied 心满意足的

Q:ravish  ['ræviʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使陶醉，使沉迷： to overcome with emotion (as wonder or delight)
A: ♣例  I was completely ravished by those marvelous pictures taken by HST. 那些哈勃太空望远镜拍摄的壮观图片让我彻底的陶醉了。
A: ♣近  captivate, enchant, enrapture, enthrall, rapture, transport
A: ♣反  disenchant, sober 使清醒
A: ♣派  ravishing adj. 极美丽的

Q:raze  [reiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 摧毁，粉碎： to destroy completely by or as if by knocking down or breaking to pieces
A: ♣例  Excavators were began to raze old school building. 挖土机开始夷平学校的老建筑。‖An entire city block razed by a terrible fire. 大火摧毁了整个街区。
A: ♣近  annihilate, decimate, demolish, devastate, level, nuke, pulverize, ruin, smash, vaporize, wreck, tear down
A: ♣反  build, construct, erect, raise, rear, set up 建造
A: ♣派  razor n. 剃须刀

Q:react  [ri'ækt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 做出反应： to act or behave in response (as to a stimulus or influence)
A: ♣例  didn't know how to react to the cheers of the crowd 不知如何对人群的欢呼声做出回应
A: ♣近  answer, reply, respond
A: ♣派  reaction n. 反应；reactant n. （化学反应当中的）反应物

Q:reactionary  [ri'ækʃənəri]
A: ♠考法1 adj. 反对变革的，极保守的： characterized by reaction, especially opposition to progress or liberalism; extremely conservative
A: ♣例  reactionary rulers 保守的统治者
A: ♣近  brassbound, conservative, die-hard, hidebound, traditionalistic, ultraconservative
A: ♣反  liberal 允许变革的；progressive 进步的；radical, aggressive 激进的

Q:ream  [ri:m]
A: ♠考法1  v. 怒斥，训斥：to criticize (someone) severely or angrily especially for personal failings
A: ♣例  You are so going to get reamed out when the boss learns that you wrecked the company car. 要是老板知道你把公司的车弄坏了，你肯定会挨骂的。
A: ♣近  baste, berate, castigate, chastise, hammer, lambaste, rail, rebuke, reprimand, reproach, upbraid
A: ♣反  accredit, applaud, commend, eulogize, extol, laud, praise 表扬，赞扬

Q:reap  [ri:p]
A: ♠考法1  v. 收割，收获： to collect (a crop or natural resource) or to receive as return for effort
A: ♣例  As you sow, so shall you reap. 唯有付出，才有回报。‖She reaped large profits from her patents. 她的专利给她带来了丰厚的回报。
A: ♣近  acquire, attain, capture, harvest, gain, garner, obtain, procure, secure
A: ♣反  plant, seed, sow 种植，播种；forfeit, lose 丧失，没收
A: ♣派  reaper n. 收割机；死神

Q:reassure  [,ri:ə'ʃuə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使安心，打消疑虑： to restore to confidence
A: ♣例  I tried to reassure her that the dog would come back home by nightfall. 我尽力让她安心，说夜幕降临之前小狗一定会回家的。
A: ♣近  assure, cheer, console, solace, soothe
A: ♣反  distress, torment, torture, trouble 使忧虑，折磨
A: ♣派  reassurance n. 消除疑虑

Q:rebuff  [ri'bʌf]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 严词拒绝： to reject or criticize sharply
A: ♣例  rebuffed an invitation from her colleagues 回绝了同事们的邀请‖She rebuffed him when he asked her for a date. 她拒绝了他约会的邀请。
A: ♣近  decline, deny, refuse, reject, repudiate, repulse, snub, spurn
A: ♣反  accept 接受；approve 赞同；welcome 欢迎

Q:recalcitrant  [ri'kælsitrənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 顽抗的，不顺从的： marked by stubborn resistance to and defiance of authority or guidance
A: ♣例  a recalcitrant teenager 执拗的少年‖The manager worried that the recalcitrant employee would try to undermine his authority. 经理担心那些不听命的员工会削弱它的权威。
A: ♣近  balky, contumacious, defiant, incompliant, insubordinate, intractable, obstreperous, rebellious, refractory, unruly
A: ♣反  amenable, compliant, conformable, docile, governable, obedient, ruly, submissive, tractable 服从的，顺从的
A: ♣派  recalcitrance n. 固执，不服从命令

Q:recant  [ri'kænt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 撤回，放弃，改变： to withdraw or repudiate (a statement or belief) formally and publicly
A: ♣例  The man has refused after torture to recant his heresy. 这个人在受折磨后依旧拒绝放弃他的异教信仰。
A: ♣近  abjure, abnegate, forswear, renege, renounce, repeal, repudiate, retract, withdraw
A: ♣反  adhere, insist, maintain, stick 坚持
A: ♣派  recantation n. 改变论调

Q:recessive  [ri'sesiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （基因等）隐性的，由隐形基因控制的： of, relating to, or designating an allele that does not produce a characteristic effect when present with a dominant allele
A: ♣例  a recessive disease 阴性基因控制的疾病
A: ♣反  dominant 显性的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 内向的，内敛的： not comfortable around people
A: ♣例  For such a recessive genius, the most comfortable thing is working alone in his lab. 对于这样一个内向的天才而言，最舒服的事情就是一个人在实验室里干活。
A: ♣近  backward, bashful, coy, demure, diffident, introverted, modest, retiring, self-effacing, sheepish, withdrawn
A: ♣反  extroverted, immodest, outgoing 外向的；gregarious, sociable 好交际的
A: ♣派  recession n. 后退，衰退

Q:recidivate  [ri'sidiveit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 回到原先的习惯，尤指重新犯罪： to return to a previous pattern of behavior, especially to return to criminal habits
A: ♣例  The suspect has recidivated for several times. 这个嫌犯是个惯犯了
A: ♣近  regress, relapse, retrogress, revert
A: ♣近  habilitate, reclaim, redeem, regenerate, rehabilitate 洗心革面
A: ♣派  recidivism n. 再犯，重犯；recidivist n. 再次犯罪的人

Q:reciprocate  [ri'siprəkeit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 往复运动： to move forward and backward alternately
A: ♣例  According to Marx’s economic principle, the average price of a certain product should be reciprocating over its value. 根据马克思的经济学理论，商品的平均价格应该在它的价值周边波动。
A: ♣近  fluctuate, oscillate, sway, swing, vacillate
A: ♠考法2  vt. 报答，回报： to return in kind or degree
A: ♣例  reciprocated the favor by driving their neighbor to the airport 开车送邻居去机场以还人情
A: ♣近  recompense, repay, requite, retaliate, return
A: ♣反  owe 欠（钱、人情等）
A: ♣派  reciprocal adj. 相互之间的，互惠的

Q:reckless  ['reklis]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不考虑后果的，大胆鲁莽的： careless of consequences; foolishly adventurous or bold
A: ♣例  His reckless driving accounted for the accident. 他鲁莽的开车行为导致了这场事故。
A: ♣近  audacious, bold, brash, brassy, brazen, careless, daredevil, rash, madcap, temerarious
A: ♣反  careful, cautious, circumspect, guarded, heedful, prudent, wary 慎重的，小心的

Q:recluse  [ri'klu:s]
A: ♠考法1  n. 隐士： a person who lives away from others
A: ♣例  He was sick of cities and crowds, so he decided to go live by himself in the woods as a recluse. 他厌倦了城市和拥挤的人群，因此他决定像隐士一样遁隐山林。
A: ♣近  anchorite, eremite, hermit, isolate, solitary
A: ♠考法2  adj. 隐居的，不爱社交的： marked by withdrawal from society
A: ♣例  a recluse poet who left a large amount of literature legacies 一个留下了大量文学遗产的隐居诗人‖My neihgbor is so recluse that I only see him about once a year. 我的邻居太神秘了，一般我一年只能见他一面。
A: ♣近  cloistered, hermetic, secluded, secluse, seclusive, sequestered
A: ♣反  gregarious, social 好交际的
A: ♣派  reclusive adj. 隐居的

Q:recoil  [ri'kɔil]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 退却，畏缩： to shrink back, as under pressure or in fear or repugnance
A: ♣例  recoil from the snake 因为害怕蛇而畏缩不前‖She recoiled from his touch. 她因害怕与他接触而退缩
A: ♣近  blench, cringe, flinch,quail, shrink, squinch, wince
A: ♣反  confront, meet 面对

Q:reconcile  ['rekənsail]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使和解，协调： to restore to friendship or harmony
A: ♣例  Historians have never been able to reconcile the two eyewitness accounts of the battle. 历史学家们一直以来都无法协调这场战役两种记载之间的矛盾。
A: ♣近  accommodate, attune, conciliate, conform, coordinate, harmonize, key
A: ♣反  disharmonize 使不和谐；estrange 离间
A: ♣派  reconciliation n. 协调

Q:recondite  [ri'kɔndait]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 深奥的，难解的： difficult or impossible for one of ordinary understanding or knowledge to comprehend
A: ♣例  I think Quantum Mechanics and Random Process arethe two most recondite courses in our curriculum this semester. 我觉得量子力学和随机过程是这学期课表中最难的两门课程
A: ♣近  abstruse, arcane, deep, enigmatic, esoteric, hermetic, occult, profound
A: ♣反  facile, shallow, superficial 肤浅的；easy, simple 简单的

Q:reconnoiter  [,rekə'nɔitə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 侦察，勘查： to make a preliminary inspection of, especially in order to gather military information
A: ♣例  The wide utilization of unmanned aerial vehicles makes it much less risky to reconnoiter a certain area. 无人飞行器的广泛运用大大减少了军事侦察的风险
A: ♣近  probe,scout, survey
A: ♣派  reconnaissance n. 侦察

Q:reconstitute  [,ri:'kɔnstitju:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 重建，（尤其是通过加水）使复原： to constitute again or anew; to restore to a former condition, especiallyby adding water
A: ♣例  reconstitute dried coffee powder冲咖啡‖Slowly Jewish communities ravaged by Nazi Germany were reconstituted and life began anew.被纳粹德国摧残的犹太人社区慢慢得以重建，新的生活开始了。
A: ♣近  reconstruct, reorder, reorganize, reshuffle, retool
A: ♣近  annihilate, decimate, demolish, devastate, level, nuke, pulverize, ruin, smash, vaporize, wreck 摧毁
A: ♣派  reconstitution n. （加水）复原

Q:reconvene  [,ri:kən'vi:n]
A: ♠考法1  v. 重新集合，重新召集：to gather, call together, or summon again, especially for a formal meeting
A: ♣例  The leaders will reconvene tomorrow. 明天领导们会再次召开会议。
A: ♣近  reassemble
A: ♣反  adjourn, suspend 休会

Q:rectitude  ['rektitju:d]
A: ♠考法1  n. 正直： the quality or state of being straight; moral integrity
A: ♣例  The principal encouraged the graduates to go on to live lives of rectitude. 校长鼓励毕业生们在今后的生活中做一个正直的人。
A: ♣近  honesty, integrity, probity, righteousness, scrupulousness, uprightness, virtue, virtuousness
A: ♣反  badness, evil, immorality, iniquity, sin, villainy, wickedness 邪恶，罪恶

Q:recumbent  [ri'kʌmbənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 躺着的： lying down, especially in a position of comfort or rest
A: ♣例  lying recumbent on the floor 躺在地板上势
A: ♣近  decumbent, procumbent, prone, prostrate, reclining, supine
A: ♣反  erect, upright 直立的

Q:recuperate  [ri'kju:pəreit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 恢复（健康或力量），康复： to recover health or strength
A: ♣例  He is gradually recuperating from a serious back injury. 他正渐渐地从严重的背部损伤中恢复过来。
A: ♣近  convalesce, heal, rally, recoup, recover, rehabilitate
A: ♣反  deteriorate, flag, wane, weaken 衰退，变得衰弱；die, expire, perish, pass away 死亡
A: ♣派  recuperative adj. 有助于康复的

Q:redeem  [ri'di:m]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 实践，履行（诺言等）： to do what is required by the terms of
A: ♣例  The coach redeemed his promise to take the players out for ice cream if they improved their fielding over the season. 教练履行了他的诺言，那就是如果球员们能够在赛季中提升防守能力的话，他就请他们吃冰淇淋。
A: ♣近  answer, complete, comply, fill, fulfill, keep, meet, satisfy
A: ♣反  breach, break, transgress, violate 违反，违背
A: ♠考法2  vt. 改过自新： to make better in behavior or character
A: ♣例  The unfaithful husband made a determined effort to redeem himself in the eyes of his wife and children. 在妻子和孩子的监督下，不忠的丈夫下定决心要改过自新。
A: ♣近  habilitate, reclaim, redeem, regenerate, rehabilitate
A: ♣派  redeemable adj. 可赎回的，可挽救的

Q:redolent  ['redəulənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 芳香的： having or emitting fragrance
A: ♣例  be redolent with the aroma of baking bread 充满了烤面包的香味
A: ♣近  ambrosial, aromatic, fragrant, perfumed, savory, scented, sweet
A: ♣反  unscented 没有香味的；fetid, foul, malodorous, noisome, rancid, reeky, stinky 恶臭的，腐臭的
A: ♣派  redolence n. 芳香，香味

Q:redoubtable  [ri'dautəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 杰出的，值得尊敬的： worthy of respect or honor
A: ♣例  a surprising discovery by one of the most redoubtable figures in Egyptian archaeology 埃及考古学领域最值得敬重的人物之一所做出的一个惊人发现
A: ♣近  bright, distinguished, illustrious, luminous, notable, noteworthy, outstanding, preeminent, prestigious
A: ♣反  average, inferior, mediocre 平庸的，中等偏下的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 可怕的： arousing fear or awe
A: ♣例  His next opponent would be by far the most redoubtable adversary the young boxer had ever faced. 年轻的拳击手的下一个对手将会是迄今为止他见过的最可怕的敌人
A: ♣近  direful, dreadful, fearsome, formidable, frightening, ghastly, horrifying, intimidating, scary, terrifying
A: ♣反  calming, comforting, consoling, lulling, pacifying, quieting, reassuring, relaxing, soothing 令人放松的

Q:redundant  [ri'dʌndənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 多余的，冗余的： exceeding what is necessary or normal
A: ♣例  This area is already chockablock with shopping malls; another one would be redundant. 这个地区已经是商场扎堆了，再建一个完全是多此一举。
A: ♣近  excess, extra, supererogatory, superfluous, supernumerary, surplus
A: ♣反  deficient, inadequate, insufficient, meager, niggardly, scant, scarce, short, sparse 缺乏，稀疏
A: ♣派  redundancy n. 过剩，过多

Q:reel  [ri:l]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 感到眩晕： to be in a confused state as if from being twirled around
A: ♣例  My head reeled with the facts and figures. 我的头脑被这些事实和数据给弄晕了。‖His mind reeled upon hearing the news that his employer had been indicted for fraud. 当他听到雇主因为欺诈而被起诉时，他顿觉天旋地转。
A: ♣近  spin, swirl, turn, whirl
A: ♣反  calm 保持镇定
A: ♠考法2  vi. 蹒跚地走路： to move forward while swaying from side to side
A: ♣例  The drunkard reeled down the alley. 醉汉蹒跚地沿着小巷走去
A: ♣近  careen, dodder, falter, lurch, stagger, stumble, teeter, totter, waddle

Q:referee  [,refə'ri:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 仲裁者；裁判员： a person who impartially decides or resolves a dispute or controversy
A: ♣例  served as the unofficial referee in disputes over the family business 作为一个非官方协调员，解决家庭事务中的纠纷
A: ♣近  adjudicator, arbiter, arbitrator, judge, umpire
A: ♠考法2  vt. （就纠纷或争议）给出意见： to give an opinion about (something at issue or in dispute)
A: ♣例  Their father usually ends up refereeing any disputes concerning use of the big TV. 最后往往是他们的父亲决定该看什么电视频道，从而解决了相关争执。
A: ♣近  adjudge, adjudicate, arbitrate, decide, determine, settle
A: ♣反  consult 咨询

Q:refine  [ri'fain]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 提纯，精炼：to free (as metal, sugar, or oil) from impurities or unwanted material
A: ♣例  Oil is refined so as to remove naturally occurring impurities. 原油通过精炼可去除其中天然存在的杂质。
A: ♣近  filter, garble, purify, winnow
A: ♣反  adulterate, contaminate, pollute 掺杂，污染
A: ♠考法2  vt. 改善，改进： to improve or perfect by pruning or polishing
A: ♣例  You’d better refine your backhand before the big tennis match if you want to throne. 如果你想获得冠军的话，你最好在网球大赛开赛前再提升一下反手的技术。
A: ♣近  ameliorate, amend, better, enhance, enrich, help, meliorate, perfect, polish, upgrade
A: ♣反  deteriorate, worsen 恶化，降低
A: ♣派  refined adj. （物品）精雕细琢的，（人）彬彬有礼的；refinery n. 炼油厂

Q:reflect  [ri'flekt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 反射： to prevent passage of and cause to change direction
A: ♣例  The color of an objective is largely determined by what light it reflects. 物体的颜色很大程度上是由它能反射的光所决定的。‖Mirrors indiscriminately reflect all visible lights. 镜子不加区分地反射所有的可见光。
A: ♣反  absorb吸收
A: ♠考法2  vt. 反映，显露： to make manifest or apparent: show
A: ♣例  Her book clearly reflects her religious beliefs. 她的书反映了她的宗教信仰。‖Where you come fromcould be easily reflected in your accent. 你的口音可以轻易地暴露你来自哪里。
A: ♣近  bespeak, betray, demonstrate, evince, manifest, reveal, show
A: ♣反  conceal, cover, hide, mask, obscure, occlude, veil 隐藏
A: ♠考法3  vi. 思考： to think seriously
A: ♣例  I reflected on my path as an undergraduate and my future as a PhD candidate. 我思考了我作为一名本科生的成长足迹以及我读博士的未来。
A: ♣近  consider, cogitate, contemplate, deliberate, meditate, muse, ponder, ruminate, think
A: ♣派  reflective adj. 思考的，深思熟虑的

Q:refractory  [ri'fræktəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 倔强的，不顺从的： resisting control or authority
A: ♣例  Refractory players will be ejected from the game. 不服从裁判命令的球员将会被驱逐出场。
A: ♣近  balky, contumacious, defiant, incompliant, insubordinate, intractable, obstreperous, rebellious, refractory, unruly
A: ♣反  amenable, compliant, conformable, docile, governable, obedient, ruly, submissive, tractable 服从的，顺从的

Q:refreshing  [ri'freʃiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 令人心身振奋的，提神的： having a renewing effect on the state of the body or mind
A: ♣例  A glass of cold water is very refreshing on such a hot day. 大热天里的一杯冰水真是让人心旷神怡。‖It is refreshing to hear some good news about him. 能听到他的好消息真是让人振奋。
A: ♣近  bracing, cordial, invigorating, rejuvenating, restorative, reviving, stimulating, stimulative, vitalizing
A: ♣反  deadening, debilitating, draining, enervating, enfeebling, exhausting, sapping, wearying 令人虚弱的

Q:refulgent  [ri'fʌldʒənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 辉煌的，灿烂的： shining radiantly; resplendent
A: ♣例  Refulgent sunlight broke through the clouds, creating huge swaths of light in the valley below us. 耀眼的阳光穿透了云层，在我们脚下的峡谷中投下了一块巨大的光斑
A: ♣近  beaming, brilliant, dazzling, incandescent, lucid, luminous, lustrous, radiant, resplendent, splendid
A: ♣反  dim, dull, lackluster 黯淡无光的
A: ♣派  refulgence n. 灿烂，光芒四射

Q:refute  [ri'fju:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 否认： to declare not to be true
A: ♣例  While the speak woman was publicly refuting rumors of a merger, behind the scenes the CEO was working to effect that very outcome. 尽管女发言人一再公开否认合并的谣言，首席执行官却在幕后为这一目标而努力。
A: ♣近  contradict, disaffirm, disavow, disclaim, disconfirm, deny, gainsay, negate, negative, reject, repudiate
A: ♣反  acknowledge, admit, avow, concede, confirm 承认
A: ♠考法2  vt. 证明为假，证伪： to prove wrong by argument or evidence: show to be false or erroneous
A: ♣例  The triumph of Chinese athlete Liu Xiang in the 2004 Olympics effectively refuted the views that Asians are physically inferior to others. 中国运动员刘翔在2004年雅典奥运会上的胜利有效地驳斥了亚洲人在体格上不如其他人种的观点。
A: ♣近  belie, confute, debunk, discredit, falsify, rebut, shoot down
A: ♣反  confirm, prove, validate, verify 证明为真，证实
A: ♣派  refutable adj.可辩驳的

Q:regenerate  [ri'dʒenəreit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使重获新生，使焕然一新： to bring back to life, practice, activity or a former condition of vigor
A: ♣例  The lizard is able to regenerate its tail. 蜥蜴能够重新长出断尾。‖The whole community was regenerated thanks to a government grant for repairing all the old buildings. 多亏了政府用于维修老楼的专项拨款，整个社区焕然一新。
A: ♣近  recharge, refresh, rejuvenate, rekindle, renew, restore, resurrect, resuscitate, revitalize, revivify
A: ♣反  degenerate, deteriorate, worsen 衰退，恶化
A: ♠考法2  vi./vt. （使）洗心革面： to make better in behavior or character
A: ♣例  Every time he made a mistake, he would promise to regenerate. 每次犯错他都会保证洗心革面，下次不再犯。
A: ♣近  habilitate, reclaim, redeem, rehabilitate
A: ♣派  regeneration n. 复兴

Q:regimen  ['redʒimen]
A: ♠考法1  n. （政治上的）统治： lawful control over the affairs of a political unit (as a nation)
A: ♣例  A new party will have regimen over the nation and, hopefully, bring some much-needed change. 一个新的政党将要上台，希望他们能带来一些迫切的改革。
A: ♣近  administration, authority, governance, jurisdiction, regime

Q:regress  [ri'ɡres]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 后退： to go back; move backward
A: ♣例  To stand still is to regress.不进则退。
A: ♣近  retrogress, return, revert
A: ♣反  advance, develop, evolve, progress 前进，发展
A: ♠考法2  vi. 退化，恶化： to become worse or of less value
A: ♣例  The annual celebration has regressed to the point where it's nothing more than an excuse to get drunk. 年度的庆祝活动已经堕落成一个尽情喝醉的借口了。
A: ♣近  atrophy, crumble, decay, decline, degenerate, descend, deteriorate, ebb, retrograde, rot, sink, worsen
A: ♣近  ameliorate, improve, meliorate 改善
A: ♣派  regressive adj. 后退的，退化的；regression n. 后退，退化

Q:rehabilitate  [,ri:hə'biliteit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使复原，使康复： to restore to a former state (as of efficiency, good management, or solvency) or a healthy condition
A: ♣例  new policies in hopes of rehabilitating the national economy 被指望能振兴国家经济的新政策‖She decided to undergo physical therapy to help rehabilitate her broken elbow. 她决定采取理疗来治疗受伤的手肘。
A: ♣近  cure, fix, mend, rejuvenate, resuscitate, revitalize, revive, set up
A: ♣近  debilitate, enervate, enfeeble, weaken 使虚弱；relapse 旧病复发
A: ♠考法2  vi./vt. （使）洗心革面： to make better in behavior or character
A: ♣例  an organization that rehabilitates criminals so they can reenter society 一个让罪犯洗心革面的机构，以便让他们能重返社会
A: ♣近  habilitate, reclaim, redeem, regenerate
A: ♣派  rehabilitation n. 康复，复原

Q:rehearsal  [ri'hə:səl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 排练，彩排： the act of practicing in preparation for a public performance
A: ♣例  We made a few mistakes in rehearsal, but we were pretty sure that we'd be OK on opening night. 彩排过程中我们犯了几个错误，但正式开幕式当晚我们有信心做得很好。
A: ♣近  practice, trial, dry run
A: ♣反  extemporization, impromptu, improvisation （无准备的）即兴表演

Q:reign  [rein]
A: ♠考法1  n. 统治权： the right or means to command or control others
A: ♣例  A healthy nation should be governed by the reign of law and not by the will of its chief executive. 一个健康的国家应该是法制的，而非由最高领导人的意志统领。‖They accused him of carrying out a reign of terror. 他们指责他搞独裁暴政。
A: ♣近  arm, authority, clutch, command, control, dominion, grip, hold, mastery, sway
A: ♣反  impotence, impotency, powerlessness 无权，无能
A: ♠考法2  vi. 占统治地位或盛行：to be predominant or prevalent
A: ♣例  Chaos reigned in the classroom. 整个教室充满了混乱。‖Panic reigned as the fire spread. 随着大火的扩散，恐慌也迅速蔓延。
A: ♣近  dominate, domineer, prevail, predominate, rule

Q:rein  [rein]
A: ♠考法1  n. 抑制，限制： the act or practice of keeping something (as an activity) within certain boundaries
A: ♣例  The oversight committee called on the corporation to keep a much tighter rein on the activities of its contractors. 监督委员会要求这个公司对其承包商的行为采取更为严格的管控。
A: ♣近  circumscription, confinement, limitation, stint
A: ♠考法2  vi. 抑制，控制： to keep from exceeding a desirable degree or level (as of expression)
A: ♣例  A good man knows how to rein in his temper. 君子知道如何按捺住火气。
A: ♣近  bridle, check, constrain, contain, curb, govern, hold, inhibit, keep, measure, regulate, restrain, rule, tame
A: ♣反  liberate,loose, loosen,unleash 释放，不再加以管束

Q:reiterate  [ri:'itəreit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 重申： to say or state again
A: ♣例  Let me reiterate our stance. 让我来重述我们的立场。‖I want to reiterate that under no circumstances are you to leave the house. 我想再次重申：无论如何你都不能离开这间房子。
A: ♣近  chime, din, iterate, recapitulate, rehearse, repeat

Q:rejoice  [ri'dʒɔis]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 欣喜，喜悦： to feel joy or great delight
A: ♣例  We rejoiced over our unexpected victory on the soccer field. 我们为预料之外的足球胜利而感到欢喜。
A: ♣近  crow, delight, exuberate, glory, jubilate, joy, kvell, triumph
A: ♣反  bemoan, bewail, deplore, grieve, lament, moan, mourn, regret, weep 感到伤感，痛苦或遗憾
A: ♣派  rejoiced adj. 高兴的

Q:relapse  [ri:'leæps]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 故态复萌，再犯： to slip or fall back into a former worse state
A: ♣例  The patient wondered whether his illness would relapse. 病人想知道他的病会不会复发。
A: ♣近  recidivate, regress, retrogress, revert
A: ♣近  habilitate, reclaim, redeem, regenerate 变好，洗心革面；convalesce, rehabilitate 康复

Q:release  [ri'li:s]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 排放： to throw or give off
A: ♣例  We bought an air freshener that releases a pleasing scent into the room. 我们买了一个能向房间里释放怡人香味的空气净化机。
A: ♣近  cast, exhale, expel, irradiate, issue, vent
A: ♣反  absorb 吸收
A: ♠考法2  vt. 释放，使获得自由： to set free from restraint, confinement, or servitude
A: ♣例  The government was asked to release the prisoners immediately. 政府被要求立即释放囚犯。
A: ♣近  discharge, disenthrall, emancipate, enfranchise, liberate, loose, loosen, manumit, unchain, unfetter
A: ♣反  bind, confine, enchain, fetter, restrain 限制自由
A: ♠考法3  vt. 解雇： to let go from office, service, or employment
A: ♣例  They released the workers who couldn't handle the new technology. 他们解雇了所有不能掌握新技术的工人。
A: ♣近  bounce, cashier, dismiss, fire, remove, retire, sack, terminate
A: ♣反  employ, engage, hire 雇用

Q:relentless  [ri'lentlis]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 残酷的，无情的： showing or promising no abatement of severity, intensity, strength, or pace
A: ♣例  He was the most teacher enemy I have ever known. 他是我所知的最狠的老师。
A: ♣近  grim, inexorable, ironfisted, merciless, mortal, ruthless, unrelenting
A: ♣反  charitable, clement, merciful, lenient 仁慈的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 固执的，不肯妥协的： showing no signs of slackening or yielding in one's purpose
A: ♣例  The team's offense was relentless in trying to score. 进攻球员毫不妥协地努力得分。
A: ♣近  adamant, dogged, headstrong, mulish, obdurate, pertinacious, rigid, uncompromising, unyielding
A: ♣反  acquiescent, amenable, compliant, complying, flexible, pliable, pliant, relenting, yielding 易屈服的

Q:relevant  ['reləvənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有关系的，重要的： having a bearing on or connection with the matter at hand
A: ♣例  Make sure your answers during the interview are short and relevant. 确保你在面试时的回答简短而恰当。‖You need to bring all the relevant certificates with you. 你需要携带所有的相关证明。
A: ♣近  applicable, apposite, apropos, germane, material, pertinent, pointed, relative
A: ♣反  extraneous, immaterial, impertinent, inapplicable, inapposite, irrelevant, pointless 无关的
A: ♣派  relevance n. 关联

Q:religion  [ri'lidʒən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 宗教，信仰： a body of beliefs and practices regarding the supernatural and the worship of one or more deities
A: ♣例  The Jewish religion has followers in many parts of the globe. 犹太教在全球范围内有大量信徒。
A: ♣近  credo, creed, cult, faith, persuasion
A: ♠考法2  n. （对于宗教信仰的）忠诚，虔诚： belief and trust in and loyalty to God
A: ♣例  Without his religion, he would not have been able to survive all the difficulties he has faced over the years. 如果不是他的虔诚，他是不可能渡过这些年来一直面临的难关的。
A: ♣近  devotion, piety
A: ♣反  atheism, godlessness 无神论
A: ♣派  religious adj. 宗教的，忠诚的

Q:relinquish  [ri'liŋkwiʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 放弃（职位、权力等）： to give up (as a position of authority) formally
A: ♣例  She relinquished his position to the company's vice president with very mixed feelings. 怀着十分复杂的情感，她放弃了公司副总裁的职位。
A: ♣近  abnegate, cede, renounce, resign, surrender
A: ♣近  inaugurate 就职；usurp 篡位
A: ♠考法2  vt. 移交，交出： to give (something) over to the control or possession of another usually under duress
A: ♣例  The boy reluctantly relinquished the illegal fireworks to the police officer. 小男孩不情愿地把非法的焰火交给了警察。‖The court ordered him to relinquish custody of his child. 法庭要求他交出孩子的监护权。
A: ♣近  deliver, render, yield, turn in, turn over
A: ♣反  keep, retain, withhold 保留，不给予

Q:relish  ['reliʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 喜好，偏好： an appetite for something; a strong appreciation or liking
A: ♣例  She has great relish for early morning walks, which she takes nearly every day. 她对早晨散步有格外的喜好——几乎每天早上她都会如此。
A: ♣近  appetite, fancy, favor, fondness, like, love, partiality, preference, taste
A: ♣反  aversion, disfavor, disgust, dislike, distaste, hatred, loathing 反感，厌恶感
A: ♠考法2  n. （愿望达成时的）高兴，满足感： the feeling experienced when one's wishes are met
A: ♣例  He ate the bowl of ice cream with relish. 他高兴地吃着冰淇淋。
A: ♣近  content, delectation, delight, enjoyment, gladness, gratification, happiness, satisfaction
A: ♣反  discontent, displeasure, dissatisfaction, unhappiness 不满，不悦
A: ♠考法3  vt. 享受，喜欢： to take keen or zestful pleasure in
A: ♣例  He is so hungry that he will relish even plain food. 他是如此的饥饿，以至于普通的食物也能让他满意。
A: ♣近  adore, enjoy, like, love, rejoice, revel, savor
A: ♣反  abhor, abominate, detest, dislike, hate, loathe 厌恶，讨厌

Q:reluctant  [ri'lʌktənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不情愿的，反感的： feeling or showing aversion, hesitation, or unwillingness
A: ♣例  I'm reluctant to let him borrow my CDs since he never gives back anything I lend him. 我很不愿意把我的CD借给他，因为他借了我东西从来不还。
A: ♣近  averse, disinclined, indisposed, loath, unwilling
A: ♣反  willing 乐意的；disposed, inclined 倾向于做某事的；eager 渴望的
A: ♣派  reluctance n. 不愿意，不情愿

Q:remiss  [ri'mis]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 疏忽的，不留心的： exhibiting carelessness or slackness
A: ♣例  I would be remiss if I didn't tell you how much I appreciated the lovely gift. 如果我不告诉你我是多么的喜欢这个可爱的礼物的话，那我就太疏忽大意了。
A: ♣近  careless, derelict, disregardful, heedless, lax, lazy, neglectful, neglecting, slack
A: ♣反  attentive, careful, conscientious, meticulous, painstaking, scrupulous 细致的，仔细的

Q:remnant  ['remnənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 残余，剩余物： something left over
A: ♣例  a remnant of his past glory 他辉煌过去的一丝残余‖The shop is selling remnants of cloth at half price. 商店在半价抛售剩余的衣物。
A: ♣近  debris, remainder, remains, residue, vestige

Q:remodel  [,ri:'mɔdəl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 改造，改变结构： to alter the structure of
A: ♣例  We decided to remodel the warehouse into a museum displaying the products of the company. 我们决定把仓库改造成展览我们公司产品的博物馆。
A: ♣近  alter, modify, recast, redo, refashion, remake, revamp, revise, rework, vary
A: ♣反  fix, freeze, set, stabilize 固定

Q:remonstrance  [ri'mɔnstrəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 抗议，抱怨： an expression of protest, complaint, or reproof, especially a formal statement of grievances
A: ♣例  She seems deaf to her son’s remonstrances. 她似乎对儿子的抗议充耳不闻。‖Aggravated by the noisy metro construction, many residents wrote letters of remonstrance to city officials. 许多被地铁建设的噪音激怒的居民向市政府投去了抗议信。
A: ♣近  challenge, complaint, demur, difficulty, fuss, objection, protest, question, remonstration, stink
A: ♣反  acceptance, acquiescence, agreement, approval, assent, sanction 同意，接受

Q:remorse  [ri'mɔ:s]
A: ♠考法1  n. 懊悔，悔恨： moral anguish arising from repentance for past misdeeds; bitter regret
A: ♣例  He felt a deep remorse for having neglected his family over the years. 他为多年来忽略家人的行为表示懊悔。
A: ♣近  contriteness, contrition, penitence, regret, remorsefulness, repentance, rue, self-reproach, shame
A: ♣反  impenitence, remorselessness 不知悔改
A: ♣派  remorseful adj. 懊悔的，悔恨的

Q:remunerate  [ri'mju:nəreit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 支付报酬或补偿： to pay an equivalent to for a service, loss, or expense
A: ♣例  He promptly remunerated the repair company for fixing the satellite TV. 他迅速地支付了维修公司修卫星电视所应得的酬劳。
A: ♣近  compensate, indemnify, recompense, recoup, redress, remedy, repay, requite
A: ♣派  remunerative adj. 有报酬的

Q:rend  [rend]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 撕裂，猛拉： to tear or split apart or into pieces violently
A: ♣例  Wolves rend a game to pieces. 狼群会把猎物撕成碎片。‖pain that rends the heart 撕心般的痛
A: ♣近  cleave, lacerate, ribbon, rip, rive, rupture, shred, split, tatter, tear
A: ♣反  associate, coalesce, combine, conjoin, conjugate, connect, fuse, interfuse, join, link, unify 联合

Q:renegade  ['reniɡeid]
A: ♠考法1  n. 背教者，叛徒： one who rejects a religion, cause, allegiance, or group for another; a deserter
A: ♣例  A band of renegades who had deserted their infantry units were making their way to Mexico. 一支背叛了他们所属的步兵编队的士兵朝着墨西哥前进。
A: ♣近  apostate, betrayer, defector, deserter, recreant, traitor, turncoat
A: ♣反  adherent, loyalist, partisan忠诚者

Q:renege  [ri'ni:ɡ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 放弃，摒弃： to solemnly or formally reject or go back on (as something formerly adhered to)
A: ♣例  She refused to renege the principles by which she had always lived her life, even if it resulted in losing her business. 尽管有可能使她失去她的事业，但她仍然拒绝放弃她在生命中所坚持的那些原则。
A: ♣近  abnegate, forswear, recant, renounce, repeal, repudiate, retract, withdraw
A: ♣反  adhere 坚持
A: ♣派  renegade n. 叛徒

Q:renounce  [ri'nauns]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （正式地）放弃： to give up, refuse, or resign usually by formal declaration
A: ♣例  renounce his nationality 退出国籍
A: ♣近  abnegate, cede, relinquish, resign, surrender
A: ♣近  inaugurate 就职；usurp 篡位
A: ♠考法2  vt. 宣布与…决裂： to refuse to follow, obey, or recognize any further
A: ♣例  renounce the authority of the church 宣布与教廷彻底决裂
A: ♣近  forswear, recant, renege, repeal, repudiate, retract, withdraw
A: ♣反  adhere, stick 坚持，忠于
A: ♣派  renunciation n. 放弃

Q:renovate  ['renəuveit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 修复，维修： to restore to a former better state (as by cleaning, repairing, or rebuilding)
A: ♣例  We will have to renovate the house extensively before we can move in. 在入住之前我们必须大规模翻修一下这栋房子。
A: ♣近  doctor, fix, patch, recondition, repair, revamp
A: ♣反  blemish, break, damage, deface, disfigure, harm, hurt, impair, injure, mar, ruin, vandalize, wreck 破坏
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使重获新生，使焕然一新：to bring back to life, practice, activity or a former condition of vigor
A: ♣例  The church was renovated by a new ecumenical spirit. 新的宗教领袖的到来让教堂焕发新生。
A: ♣近  recharge, refresh, rejuvenate, rekindle, renew, restore, resurrect, resuscitate, revitalize, revivify
A: ♣反  degenerate, deteriorate, worsen 衰退，恶化

Q:repartee  [,repɑ:'ti:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 机智的回答： a quick witty response
A: ♣例  That repartee to the reporter's question drew laughs from the bystanders. 对记者问题的那个机智回答引来了旁观者的笑声。
A: ♣近  comeback, riposte
A: ♠考法2  n. 打趣，善意的玩笑： good-natured teasing or exchanging of clever remarks
A: ♣例  Repartee is harder to do with text messaging. 用短信开起玩笑来困难多了。
A: ♣近  backchat, badinage, chaff, jesting, joshing, persiflage, raillery

Q:repatriate  [ri:'pætrieit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 遣返： to restore or return to the country of origin, allegiance, or citizenship
A: ♣例  As soon as the war ends, the government will start to repatriate war refugees. 只要战争一结束，政府就会开始遣返战争难民。
A: ♣反  banish, deport, expatriate 放逐，驱逐

Q:repeal  [ri'pi:l]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 撤销，废除（法律等）： to rescind or annul by authoritative act
A: ♣例  In 1933, Congress passed the 21st Amendment which repealed the Prohibition Amendment of 1919 thus making the sale distribution and use of alcohol legal once again. 1933年，国会通过了《第二十一修正案》，该法案废除了于1919年制订的《禁酒法》，从而使得酒的买卖、配送和使用再次合法化。
A: ♣近  abort, abrogate, annul, cancel, disannul, invalidate, negate, null, nullify, rescind, revoke, vacate, void
A: ♣反  continue, keep 继续执行；enact, establish, legislate 立法，制订
A: ♠考法2  vt. 宣布与…决裂： to refuse to follow, obey, or recognize any further
A: ♣例  If I find that you have been lying about this, I'll instantly repeal every promise I made to you. 只要我发现在这个问题上你对我撒了谎，那我们之间的承诺就彻底断裂了。
A: ♣近  forswear, recant, renege, renounce, repudiate, retract, withdraw
A: ♣反  adhere, stick 坚持，忠于

Q:repel  [ri'pel]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 抵制： to fight against; resist
A: ♣例  Self-discipline ensures that you can repel the things that induce you. 自律可以保证你抵制那些诱惑你的事物。‖I repelled the temptation to stay out late and call in sick the next day. 我抵住了晚上玩通宵然后第二天谎称生病的诱惑。
A: ♣近  buck, defy, fight, oppose, resist, withstand
A: ♣反  capitulate, submit, succumb, surrender, yield, give in 屈服
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使厌恶： to cause aversion in: disgust
A: ♣例  Evil odors always repel me. 臭味总是让我恶心。
A: ♣近  disgust, nauseate, repulse, revolt, sicken
A: ♣反  allure, attract, bewitch, captivate, charm, enchant, entice, fascinate, lure, seduce, tempt 吸引，诱惑
A: ♣派  repelling adj. 令人厌恶的

Q:repertoire  ['repətwɑ:]
A: ♠考法1  n. （技术、设备或原料等的）详单： the complete list or supply of skills, devices, or ingredients used in a particular field, occupation, or practice
A: ♣例  The chef's repertoire of specialties seems to be limited, with several of the dishes appearing over and over again in slightly varied guises. 这个厨师的所有拿手好戏看来是很有限的，因为上来的几盘菜看起来只是稍微换了一下装饰而已。
A: ♣近  budget, fund, inventory, pool, reservoir, stock

Q:repine  [ri'pain]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 抱怨，表达不满： to feel or express discontent or dejection
A: ♣例  There is no use repining over a love that's been long lost. 抱怨早已失去的爱情是没有用的。
A: ♣近  carp, complain, fuss, gripe, grouch, grouse, growl, grumble, inveigh, moan, murmur, mutter, wail, whine
A: ♣反  crow, delight, rejoice 高兴
A: ♠考法2  vi. 渴望： to long for something
A: ♣例  During the deep cold of winter, I repine for warm tropical beaches. 在寒冬，我渴望温暖的热带海滩。
A: ♣近  ache, covet, crave, desiderate, hunger, itch, long, lust, pine, salivate, thirst, want, wish, yearn
A: ♣反  abhor, abominate, detest, dislike, hate, loathe 厌恶，讨厌

Q:replenish  [ri'pleniʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 补充： to fill or make complete again; add a new stock or supply to
A: ♣例  He went to replenish her glass. 他去续杯了。
A: ♣近  refill, reload
A: ♣反  consume, drain, empty, exhaust 清空，耗尽

Q:replete  [ri'pli:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 彻底吃饱了的： having one's appetite completely satisfied
A: ♣例  Everyone is completely replete after the huge meal. 在大餐之后，每个人都吃撑了。
A: ♣近  sated, satiate, satiated, stuffed, surfeited
A: ♣反  empty, famished, hungry, starved, starving 挨饿的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 充满…的，富于…的： possessing or covered with great numbers or amounts of something specified
A: ♣例  a scholar replete with knowledge 博学的学者
A: ♣近  abounding, abundant, awash, flush, fraught, lousy, swarming, teeming, thick, thronging
A: ♣反  depleted, drained, exhausted 耗竭的；deficient, incomplete, insufficient, short 缺乏的
A: ♣派  repletion n. 装满

Q:replicate  ['replikit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 复制，复刻： to make an exact likeness of
A: ♣例  replicated the famous painting in our art class 在艺术课上复刻一幅名画
A: ♣近  clone, copy, copycat, duplicate, imitate, reduplicate, render, reproduce
A: ♣反  originate 原创
A: ♠考法2  vt. 重复，反复： to make or do again
A: ♣例  I cannot replicate your results when I do the experiment myself. 我自己的实验里无法重复你的结果。
A: ♣近  redo, reiterate, renew, repeat
A: ♣派  replicable adj. 可复制的，能复现的

Q:repose  [ri'pəuz]
A: ♠考法1  n. （劳作后的）休息： a state of resting after exertion or strain
A: ♣例  The doctor ordered a period of repose for the patient suffering from insomnia. 医生要求正在饱受失眠折磨的病人好好休息一阵。
A: ♣近  ease, leisure, relaxation
A: ♣反  exertion, labor, toil, work 劳动，工作
A: ♠考法2  n. 平静，宁静： a state of freedom from storm or disturbance
A: ♣例  We enjoyed the repose of a summer evening on a remote island. 我们在遥远的小岛上共享了夏日傍晚的片刻安宁。
A: ♣近  calmness, hush, peace, placidity, quietness, restfulness, serenity, still, tranquility
A: ♣反  commotion, pandemonium, tumult, turmoil, unrest, uproar 骚乱，动乱
A: ♠考法3  vi. 休息： to take a rest
A: ♣例  They have to repose on couches because all beds have been occupied. 因为所有的床都有人占了，他们不得不在沙发上休息。
A: ♣近  idle, loll, lounge, relax, rest
A: ♣反  drudge, hustle, moil, strive, struggle, sweat, travail 努力工作
A: ♠考法4  vt. 放置，交给他人： to put (something) into the possession or safekeeping of another
A: ♣例  The Constitution reposes the power to declare war to Congress, and to that body alone. 宪法将宣战的权力交给了国会单独保管。
A: ♣近  consign, delegate, deliver, entrust, leave, pass, trans

Q:reprehend  [,repri'hend]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 谴责，责难，批评： to express one's unfavorable opinion of the worth or quality of
A: ♣例  Without exception, book reviewers reprehended the novel's trite plot. 毫无例外的，小说缺乏新意的故事情节收到了评论家们的责难。
A: ♣近  berate, blame, castigate, censure, condemn, denounce, dispraise, fault, knock, lambaste, pan, upbraid
A: ♣近  extol, laud, praise 表扬
A: ♣派  reprehensible adj. 应受谴责的

Q:repress  [ri'pres]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 镇压： to put down by force, usually before total control has been lost; quell
A: ♣例  Military quickly repressed the rebellion in the city and restored order. 军方迅速平息了市内的暴乱，恢复了秩序。
A: ♣近  crush, quash, quell, silence, squash, squelch, subdue, suppress
A: ♣反  foment, incite, instigate, provoke, stir 煽动，激起
A: ♠考法2  vt. 阻止（正常的表达、活动或发展等）： to prevent the natural or normal expression, activity, or development of
A: ♣例  You can't repress your feelings forever, so tell her that you love her. 你不可能永远压抑自己的感受，所以大胆地跟她表白吧。
A: ♣近  bridle, check, curb, muffle, smother, stifle, strangle, swallow
A: ♣反  express, loose, release, take out, unleash, vent （情感等的）表达，宣泄
A: ♣派  repression n. 阻止，镇压

Q:reprieve  [ri'pri:v]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 暂缓处刑，免罪： to postpone or cancel the punishment of
A: ♣例  Fourteen people, waiting to be hanged for the murder of a former prime minister, have been reprieved 十四个因为谋杀前首相而等待绞刑的人获得了缓刑。
A: ♣近  absolve, acquit, amnesty, condone, excuse, forgive, pardon, remit, respite, spare
A: ♣反  penalize, punish 惩罚
A: ♠考法2  vt. 维持运行： to prevent (something) from being closed, destroyed, etc., for a period of time
A: ♣例  The library has been reprieved and will remain open for at least another year. 图书馆的状况得到了缓解，还将继续开放一年。
A: ♣近  deliver, rescue, save

Q:reproach  [ri'prəutʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 令人羞愧的事物，耻辱： one that causes shame, rebuke or blame
A: ♣例  a reproach to this entire school 整个学校的耻辱
A: ♣近  dishonor, opprobrium, reflection, spot, scandal, stain, stigma, taint
A: ♣反  credit, honor 荣誉
A: ♠考法2  vt. 批评，责备： to express disapproval, criticism, or disappointment in (someone)
A: ♣例  reproached by their mother for untidiness 因为邋遢而被他们的母亲批评
A: ♣近  admonish, berate, castigate, chide, condemn, denounce, lambaste, rebuke, reprimand, reprove, upbraid
A: ♣反  commend, eulogize, extol, laud, praise 表扬
A: ♣派  irreproachable adj. 无可指责的

Q:reprobate  ['reprəubeit]
A: ♠考法1  n. 堕落者，道德败坏的人：a morally unprincipled person
A: ♣例  The program rehabilitates reprobates and turns them into hard-working, law-abiding citizens. 这个项目让那些堕落的人改过自新，并将他们变成勤劳守法的好公民。
A: ♣近  brute, devil, fiend, miscreant, rapscallion, rascal, villain
A: ♣反  saint 圣人
A: ♠考法2  adj. 堕落的，放荡的： morally corrupt
A: ♣例  He is a reprobate judge who could be bribed, and often with astonishing ease. 他是一个堕落的法官，极其容易就被贿赂了。
A: ♣近  debased, debauched, degraded, depraved, dissipated, dissolute, libertine, perverse, perverted, rakish
A: ♣反  good, moral, righteous, virtuous 有道德的；pure, uncorrupted 纯净的，未受污染的
A: ♠考法3  vt. 谴责，痛斥： to condemn strongly as unworthy, unacceptable, or evil
A: ♣例  He reprobated his son's unconventional lifestyle. 他怒斥他儿子不遵循传统的生活习惯。
A: ♣近  blame, criticize, censure, condemn, denounce, denunciate, reprehend
A: ♣反  commend, eulogize, extol, laud, praise 表扬
A: ♠考法4  vt. 拒绝，不提供： to be unwilling to grant
A: ♣例  The government will most likely reprobate the request for parole. 政府很有可能会拒绝假释的要求。
A: ♣近  decline, disallow, disapprove, negative, nix, refuse, re

Q:reproof  [ri'pru:f]
A: ♠考法1  n. 批评，反对： criticism for a fault, rebuke
A: ♣例  The head teacher speaks in tones of gentle reproof. 校长的话语中带有隐晦的批评。
A: ♣近  commination, condemnation, denunciation, excoriation, rebuke, reprimand, reproach, stricture
A: ♣反  commendation, eulogy, praise 赞扬；endorsement 同意

Q:reprove  [ri'pru:v]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 温和地责备，警告： to scold or correct usually gently or with kindly intent
A: ♣例  My piano teacher often reproves me for slouching while playing, observing that good posture helps one play better. 我的钢琴老师常常会因为懒散的坐姿而批评我，他认为良好的坐姿能让我弹得更好。
A: ♣近  admonish, blame, chide, criticize, reprimand, reproach
A: ♣反  lambaste 严厉地责备；commend, eulogize, extol, laud, praise 表扬
A: ♠考法2  vt. 不欣赏，不喜欢： to hold an unfavorable opinion of
A: ♣例  The older generation has always reproved the younger generation's taste in music. 老一代的人总是不喜欢新一代的音乐品味。
A: ♣近  deprecate, discountenance, disesteem, disfavor, dislike, frown
A: ♣反  adore, approve, endorse, enjoy, favor, like 支持，喜欢

Q:repudiate  [ri'pju:dieit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 否认： to declare not to be true
A: ♣例  She repudiated the charge that she had lied on her résumé. 她否认了她在简历中作假的指控。
A: ♣近  contradict, disaffirm, disavow, disclaim, disconfirm, disown, gainsay, negate, negative, refute, reject
A: ♣反  acknowledge, admit, allow, avow, concede, confirm 承认
A: ♠考法2  vt. 拒绝接受： to show unwillingness to accept, do, engage in, or agree to
A: ♣例  We didn't like the terms, so we repudiated the contract. 我们没有接受这份合同，因为我们对其中的条款表示不满。
A: ♣近  balk, deselect, disapprove, negative, nix, refuse, reprobate, spurn
A: ♣反  accept, agree, approve 接受，承认
A: ♣派  repudiation n. 拒绝，否认

Q:repugnant  [ri'pʌɡnənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 令人厌恶的： arousing disgust or aversion
A: ♣例  The idea of moving again became repugnant to her. 又要搬家的想法让她感到厌恶。
A: ♣近  abhorrent, abominable, awful, disgusting, distasteful, hideous, loathsome, noisome, obnoxious, repulsive
A: ♣反  innocuous, inoffensive 无害的；agreeable, delightful, enjoyable, gratifying, pleasing 令人愉悦的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不和谐的，不协调的： not being in agreement or harmony
A: ♣例  Technically speaking, it may not be a violation, but it is certainly repugnant to the spirit of the law. 技术上来说这还算不上违法，但是这肯定违背了法律的精神。
A: ♣近  conflicting, discordant, incompatible, incongruous, inconsonant, inharmonious, mutually exclusive
A: ♣反  accordant, agreeing, compatible, concordant, conformable, congruent, congruous, consistent, consonant, harmonious 和谐的
A: ♣派  repugnance n. 厌恶；不一致

Q:repulse  [ri'pʌls]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （使）厌恶，排斥： to rebuff or reject with rudeness, coldness, or denial
A: ♣例  The scenes of violence in the film may repulse some viewers. 电影中某些暴力场景可能会使观众反感。
A: ♣近  disgust, nauseate, repel, revolt, sicken
A: ♣反  allure, attract, bewitch, captivate, charm, enchant, entice, fascinate, lure, seduce, tempt 吸引，诱惑
A: ♣派  repulsion n. 排斥

Q:repute  [ri'pju:t]
A: ♠考法1  n. （尤指好的）名声，名誉： a good reputation
A: ♣例  Before his national bestseller, he was a writer of little repute. 在他的畅销书出来之前，他是个没什么名声的作家。
A: ♣近  celebrity, fame, name, renown, reputation
A: ♣反  infamy, notoriety 坏名声
A: ♣派  reputable adj. 有好名声的

Q:requisite  ['rekwizit]
A: ♠考法1  n. 必需品： something necessary, indispensable, or unavoidable
A: ♣例  Calculus is a requisite for modern physics. 微积分是学习近代物理的必要知识。
A: ♣近  condition, demand, necessity, need, requirement
A: ♠考法2  adj. 必不可少的，必备的： essential, necessary
A: ♣例  Oxygen is requisite for human to survive. 氧气是维持人类生命的必要条件。
A: ♣近  critical, compulsory, imperative, indispensable, mandatory, necessary, obligatory, required, vital
A: ♣反  needless, unnecessary 不必要的；dispensable, optional 可替换的，可选择的

Q:requite  [ri'kwait]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 酬谢，报答： to make repayment or return for
A: ♣例  requited her love with hatred 恩将仇报
A: ♣近  indemnify, reciprocate, recompense, recoup, reimburse, remunerate, repay
A: ♠考法2  vt. 报仇： to punish in kind the wrongdoer responsible for
A: ♣例  The future writer would later requite the abuse he suffered at the hands of his classmates by creating scathing portraits of them in his novels. 未来的作家会把在同学那受的委屈的帐算清的——他会在小说中把他们描绘成恶人。
A: ♣近  avenge, redress, retaliate, revenge
A: ♣反  absolve, condone, forgive, pardon 饶恕，宽恕

Q:rescind  [ri'sind]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 废除，取消： to make void
A: ♣例  The government refused to rescind the order of curfew. 政府拒绝撤销宵禁的决定。
A: ♣近  abolish, abrogate, annul, cancel, invalidate, negate, null, nullify, recall, repeal, revoke, void
A: ♣反  establish, enact 建立；continue, keep 维持，保持

Q:reserved  [ri'zə:vd]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 内向的，缄默的： restrained in words and actions
A: ♣例  too reserved to offer a spontaneous criticism 过于缄默而不愿意发表真实的看法
A: ♣近  closemouthed, constrained, laconic, reticent, restrained, silent, taciturn.
A: ♣反  communicative, expansive, talkative 健谈的；garrulous, loquacious 话多的
A: ♣派  unreserved adj. 无保留的，外向的

Q:residual  [ri'zidjuəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 剩余的，残存的： of, relating to, or characteristic of a residue
A: ♣例  residual radiation from nuclear tests 核试验所遗留下来的残余辐射
A: ♣近  leftover, remaining, vestigial
A: ♣反  comprehensive, entire, full, integral, total, whole 全部的，完整的

Q:residue  ['rezidju:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 剩余物： something that remains after a part is taken, separated, or designated
A: ♣例  In the race of nature, there is no residue left for the late. 在大自然的竞争中，总是早起的鸟儿才有虫吃。
A: ♣近  debris, remainder, remnant
A: ♣派  residual adj. 剩余的

Q:resign  [ri'zain]

A: ♣例  resigned her position at the university 自动放弃她在大学的职位
A: ♣近  abnegate, cede, relinquish, renounce, surrender, step down
A: ♣反  assume, inaugurate 就职，承担（责任）；usurp 篡位

Q:resilience  [ri'ziliəns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 弹力： the property of a material that enables it to resume its original shape or position after being bent, stretched, or compressed
A: ♣近  elasticity, flexibility, malleability, pliability
A: ♣反  inelasticity n. 无弹性
A: ♠考法2  n. 恢复能力： the ability to recover quickly from illness, change, or misfortune
A: ♣例  Her mental resilience helped her promptly walk out of the shadow of her father’s death. 她的精神恢复能力让她迅速地走出了父亲去世的阴影当中。
A: ♣近  adaptability
A: ♣派  resilient adj. 有弹性的；能迅速恢复的

Q:resolute  ['rezəlju:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 坚定的： marked by firm determination
A: ♣例  We are glad to have such a resolute ally. 我们很高兴能拥有这样一个坚定的盟友。
A: ♣近  bound, decided, faithful, resolved, unwavering
A: ♣反  faltering, hesitant, indecisive, irresolute, jittery, vacillating, wavering 犹豫的，踌躇的
A: ♣派  resolution n. 坚定的决心

Q:resonant  ['rezənənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （声音）洪亮的，共鸣的： strong and deep in tone
A: ♣例  A deep resonant voice rang out. 传来了洪亮的声音。
A: ♣近  consonant, orotund, plangent, resounding, reverberant, sonorous, vibrant
A: ♣反  faint, low, muffled, muted, smothered, soft, weak 声音模糊的，低声的
A: ♣派  resonance n. 洪亮

Q:resourceful  [ri'sɔ:sful]

A: ♣例  a resourceful man capable of dealing with difficult situations 一个能巧妙解决困局的能人
A: ♣近  able, adroit, competent, talented
A: ♣派  resourcefulness n. 能解决困难的能力

Q:respire  [ri'spaiə]

A: ♣例  unable to respire due to heart attack 因心脏病发作而无法呼吸
A: ♣近  breathe, inhale
A: ♣反  smother, stifle, suffocate 停止呼吸，窒息
A: ♣派  respiration n. 呼吸

Q:respite  ['respait]

A: ♣例  to toil without respite 埋头苦干‖In the middle of each semester there came a short respite. 在每个学期的期中，会有一个短暂的休假。
A: ♣近  break, lull, intermission, recess, pause, rest
A: ♣反  resumption 继续进行；exertion, labor, toil, work 劳动，工作

Q:resplendent  [ri'splendənt]

A: ♣例  Geography teacher showed us a picture of the resplendent aurora borealis. 地理老师给我们展示了一张壮丽的北极光的照片。
A: ♣近  brilliant, glorious, gorgeous, grand, magnificent, splendid, sublime, superb
A: ♣反  dim, dull, lackluster 黯淡无光的
A: ♣派  resplendence n. 辉煌

Q:responsive  [ri'spɔnsiv]

A: ♣近  prompt, sensible, sensitive, susceptible
A: ♣反  dispassionate 无动于衷的；detached, indifferent 冷漠的
A: ♣派  responsiveness n. 敏感

Q:restitution  [,resti'tju:ʃən]

A: ♣例  The victims are demanding full restitution. 受害者要求全额补偿。
A: ♣近  damages, indemnity, quittance, recompense, recoupment, redress, remuneration, reparation, reprisal, requital

Q:restive  ['restiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 急躁的，忧虑的： marked by impatience or uneasiness
A: ♣例  I spent a restive night worrying about the next day's exam. 我度过了忧虑的一晚，担心明天的考试。
A: ♣近  restless, nervy, uneasy, uptight
A: ♣反  imperturbable 沉着的；phlegmatic 冷静的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 难以管束的： stubbornly resisting control
A: ♣例  Tired soldiers grew restive. 疲惫的士兵变得越来越难以管理。
A: ♣近  balky, contumacious, defiant, insubordinate, intractable, obstreperous, obstinate, perverse, recalcitrant, refractory
A: ♣反  amenable, biddable, compliant, conformable, docile, obedient, ruly, submissive, tractable 服从的
A: ♣派  restiveness n. 不安，躁动

Q:restless  ['restlis]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不平静的： marked by or causing a lack of quiet, repose, or rest
A: ♣例  The patient felt restless from pain. 病人因疼痛而无法平静。
A: ♣近  agitating, anxious, distressful, disturbing, fraught, restive, perturbed, uneasy, unquiet, unsettled
A: ♣反  halcyon, peaceful, serene, tranquil 平静的，安宁的

Q:restrain  [ri'strein]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 限制，控制： to limit, restrict, or keep under control
A: ♣例  The old lady restrained the child from picking the flowers. 老妇人不准孩子们采摘花朵。
A: ♣近  bridle, check, constrain, curb, inhibit, measure, prevent, refrain, withhold
A: ♣反  discharge, release 释放
A: ♣派  restrained adj. 受限制的

Q:resurgence  [ri'sə:dʒəns]

A: ♣近  reanimation, rebirth, regeneration, rejuvenation, renewal, resurrection, resuscitation, revitalization
A: ♣反  decay, degradation, deterioration, downfall, ebb, fall 衰落
A: ♣派  resurgent adj. 正在复兴的

Q:resurrect  [,rezə'rekt]

A: ♣例  believed that his body would be resurrected 相信他的身体将会复活‖Attempts are being made by both parties to resurrect the stalled arms negotiations. 双方正在努力重启受阻的武装谈判。
A: ♣近  reanimate, recharge, regenerate, rejuvenate, rekindle, renew, resuscitate, revitalize, revive, revivify
A: ♣反  kill 杀死
A: ♣派  resurrection n. 重生，复苏

A: ♣反  faint 昏迷
A: ♣派  resuscitation n. 复活，复兴；resuscitated adj. 复活的

Q:retainer  [ri'teinə]

A: ♣例  Knights are dressed for battle by their retainers. 骑士们在上战场之前是由他们的家仆帮助着装打扮的。
A: ♣近  menial, servant
A: ♣反  lord, master 主人

Q:retaliate  [ri'tælieit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 报复，反击： to pay back（as an injury）in kind
A: ♣例  We swear to retaliate for our losses. 我们发誓要以牙还牙。
A: ♣近  avenge, redress, requite, revenge
A: ♣反  absolve, condone, forgive, pardon 饶恕，宽恕
A: ♣派  retaliation n. 报复

Q:retard  [ri'tɑ:d]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 减速，延迟： to cause to move or proceed slowly; delay or impede
A: ♣例  Language barriers retarded their negotiating progress. 语言障碍让谈判进程受阻。
A: ♣近  bog, brake, decelerate, delay, detain, hamper, impede, mire, slacken
A: ♣反  accelerate, catalyze, expedite, hasten, precipitate 加速，促进

Q:retentive  [ri'tentiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 记性好的： having the ability or capacity to retain knowledge or information with ease
A: ♣例  Her retentive memory helped her sail through the history test. 她的好记性帮助她顺利通过了历史考试。
A: ♣反  absentminded, forgetful, oblivious 健忘的
A: ♣派  retentiveness n. 好记性

Q:reticent  ['retisənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 沉默不语的： inclined to be silent or uncommunicative in speech
A: ♣例  He was reticent about his plans. 他对他的计划三缄其口。
A: ♣近  closemouthed, constrained, laconic, reserved, restrained, silent, taciturn
A: ♣反  communicative, expansive, talkative 健谈的；garrulous, loquacious 话多的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不愿意的： slow to begin or proceed with a course of action because of doubts or uncertainty
A: ♣例  Understandably, she's reticent about becoming involved with another religious sect. 不难理解，她不愿意被牵扯另一个宗教派别之中。
A: ♣近  cagey, disinclined, dubious, indisposed, loath, reluctant
A: ♣反  willing 乐意的；disposed, inclined 倾向于做某事的；eager 渴望的

Q:retinue  ['retinju:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 随行人员： a group of retainers or attendants
A: ♣例  The premier inspected the factory with his retinue. 总理与随同人员一起视察了工厂。
A: ♣近  associates, entourage, followers, posse, retainers
A: ♣反  leader 领导者

Q:retort  [ri'tɔ:t]
A: ♠考法1  n. （尤指机智的）回应，回答： something spoken or written in reaction especially to a question, especially a quick, witty, or cutting reply
A: ♣例  She responded to the heckler with a scathing but hilarious retort that instantly won over the audience. 面对故意起哄捣乱的人，她那严厉但不失幽默的回答立刻得到了观众的肯定。
A: ♣近  comeback, rejoinder, repartee, reply, response, return, riposte
A: ♣反  inquiry, query, question 问题，问询

Q:retouch  [,ri:'tʌtʃ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 润饰，改进： to improve or change (a photographic negative or print)
A: ♣例  She was retouching her painting before the deadline. 在截止日期到来之前，她一直在润色她的画作。
A: ♣近  ameliorate, enhance, furbish, meliorate, perfect, polish, refine, upgrade
A: ♣反  deteriorate, downgrade, worsen 恶化，降低

Q:retract  [ri'trækt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 收回，否认： to take back
A: ♣例  The newspaper had to retract its allegations against the mayor. 报纸不得不收回针对市长的谣言。
A: ♣近  abjure, abnegate, disavow, forswear, recall, recant, renounce, repeal, repudiate, withdraw
A: ♣反  tender 提出（建议，想法）；adhere, stick 坚持
A: ♣派  retractable adj. 可收回的

Q:retrench  [ri'trentʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 削减开支： to curtail expenses
A: ♣例  Declining business forced the company to retrench. 衰减的业务迫使公司削减开支。
A: ♣近  economize, reduce, cut down
A: ♣反  enlarge, expand 扩大，扩张
A: ♣派  retrenchment n. 削减开销

Q:retribution  [,retri'bju:ʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 报偿，报应： the dispensing or receiving of reward or punishment especially in the hereafter
A: ♣例  The neighborhood is being torn apart by an endless cycle of gang violence and retribution. 这个社区正在被帮派间斗争和仇恨的恶性循环割裂。
A: ♣近  avengement, payback, recompense, reparation, repayment, requital, retaliation, revenge, vengeance
A: ♣派  retributive n. 报应的

Q:retrieve  [ri'tri:v]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 寻回，找回： to get back again
A: ♣例  I needed to retrieve the book from my friend so I could return it to the library. 我需要先把书从朋友那里拿回来才能还给图书馆。
A: ♣近  reacquire, recapture, reclaim, re-collect, recoup, recover, regain, repossess, retake
A: ♣近  lose, mislay, misplace 丢失

Q:retrograde  ['retrəuɡreid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 倒退的： moving or tending backward
A: ♣例  This is a retrograde step and you will regret it. 这是后退的一步，你以后肯定会后悔的。
A: ♣近  backward, receding, regressive, reversed, withdrawing
A: ♣反  progressive 前进的
A: ♠考法2  v. 退步，退化： to decline to a worse condition
A: ♣例  The Dark Ages is the period following the fall of the Roman Empire when Western civilization seriously retrograded. “黑暗时代”指的是罗马帝国崩溃之后，西方文明严重退步的一个历史时期。
A: ♣近  atrophy, crumble, decay, decline, degenerate, descend, deteriorate, ebb, regress, rot, sink, worsen
A: ♣近  ameliorate, improve, meliorate 改善

Q:retrospective  [,retrəu'spektiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 回顾的： looking back on, contemplating, or directed to the past
A: ♣例  a retrospective glance at my youth 朝我少年时代投去的回顾性一瞥
A: ♣近  backward
A: ♣反  anticipatory 预想的；prospective 预期的，未来的

Q:revelry  ['revəlri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 狂欢，喧闹的作乐： noisy partying or merrymaking
A: ♣例  They were exhausted after the night of revelry. 一夜狂欢后大家都筋疲力尽
A: ♣近  conviviality, festivity, gaiety, jollity, merriment, rejoicing, revel, whoopee
A: ♣反  gloom, grief, melancholy, misery, mournfulness, sorrow, woe 悲哀，哀痛

Q:revenge  [ri'vendʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 报复，复仇： an act or instance of retaliating in order to get even
A: ♣例  Both sides were determined to get revenge for losses and showed little interest in ending the feud. 双方都下定决心要为失去的东西报仇，对于结束他们之间的世仇毫无兴趣。‖The bombing was in revenge for the assassination of their leader. 此次轰炸是对暗杀他们领袖的报复行动。
A: ♣近  avengement, payback, reprisal, requital, retaliation, retribution, vengeance
A: ♣反  forgiveness, pardon 饶恕，原谅
A: ♠考法2  vt. 复仇： to avenge (as oneself) usually by retaliating in kind or degree
A: ♣例  He finally revenged the death of his brother. 他终于为兄弟的死报了仇。
A: ♣近  avenge, redress, requite, retaliate
A: ♣反  absolve, condone, forgive, pardon 原谅，宽恕

Q:reverberate  [ri'və:bəreit]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 回荡，回响： to continue or be repeated in a series of reflected sound waves
A: ♣例  The sound of thunder reverberated from one end of the mountain pass to the other. 打雷的声音在山间不断回荡。
A: ♣近  echo, reecho, resonate, resound
A: ♣派  reverberation n. 回响，回音

Q:revere  [ri'viə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （尤指对神的）尊崇，尊敬： to offer honor or respect to (someone) as a divine power
A: ♣例  He is revered for his valor. 他因为他的英勇而受到尊敬。‖In some cultures people revere their ancestors, even leaving food offerings for them. 在一些文化当中，人们非常敬重先人，甚至将一些食物留下来供他们享用。
A: ♣近  adore, deify, glorify, esteem, regard, respect, venerate, worship
A: ♣反  blaspheme, desecrate, profane, violate 亵渎
A: ♣派  reverence n. 尊重；reverent adj. 恭敬地，虔诚的

Q:revise  [ri'vaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 更改，修正： to look over again in order to correct or improve
A: ♣例  There are many problems involved in revising a dictionary. 修正字典会牵涉到诸多问题。‖With the snow, we'll need to revise our travel plans. 因为下雪了，我们不得不更改旅游计划。
A: ♣近  amend, correct, emend, polish, redraft, refine, rework, upgrade
A: ♣反  discard 丢弃，抛弃
A: ♣派  revision n. 修改

Q:revive  [ri'vaiv]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 恢复意识： to return to consciousness or life, become flourishing again
A: ♣例  successfully revived him with artificial respiration 用人工呼吸使成功他恢复意识
A: ♣近  come around
A: ♣反  faint, black out 昏迷，失去知觉
A: ♠考法2  v. 再获新生： become active or flourishing again
A: ♣例  Around midnight, I usually need to revive myself with a cup of strong coffee. 在午夜时分，我需要一杯浓咖啡来提神。‖The success of the movie has revived her career. 这部电影的成功让他的事业焕发第二春。
A: ♣近  reanimate, recharge, refresh, rejuvenate, rekindle, renew, resurrect, resuscitate, revitalize, revivify
A: ♣反  degenerate, deteriorate, worsen 衰退，恶化
A: ♣派  revival n. 复苏

Q:revoke  [ri'vəuk]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 撤回，宣告无效： to annul by recalling or taking back
A: ♣例  to revoke a will 废除遗嘱
A: ♣近  abolish, abrogate, annul, cancel, invalidate, negate, null, nullify, recall, repeal, revoke, void
A: ♣反  establish, enact 建立；continue, keep 维持，保持
A: ♣派  revocation n. 撤销，废除

Q:revolt  [ri'vəult]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使厌恶，反感： to fill with disgust or abhorrence
A: ♣例  The smell of seafood revolts him. 他对海鲜的腥味十分反感。
A: ♣近  disgust, nauseate, repel, repulse, sicken
A: ♣反  allure, attract, bewitch, captivate, charm, enchant, entice, fascinate, lure, seduce, tempt 吸引，诱惑
A: ♠考法2  vi. 反叛： to renounce allegiance or subjection (as to a government)
A: ♣例  The revolted against the dictator by burning his palace. 他们通过焚烧宫殿来对抗独裁者。
A: ♣近  defy, insurrect, mutiny, oppose, rebel, resist
A: ♣反  obey, submit 遵从，服从
A: ♣派  revolter n. 反叛者

Q:rhetorical  [ri'tɔrikəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 语言上的，文字上的： of or relating to words or language
A: ♣例  The next war that those two nations fight won't be rhetorical - it will be with bombs and bullets. 两国之间的下一场战争可不会是斗嘴皮了——他们会来真格的。
A: ♣近  lexical, linguistic, vocabular, wordy
A: ♠考法2  adj. 言辞华丽（却往往无内涵的）： full of fine words and fancy expressionsbut mostly meaningless words and phrases
A: ♣例  You can skip over the rhetorical passages and still get the gist of the essay. 你可以跳过那些词藻华丽的段落，直接获取文本的主旨。‖The new governor delivered a long rhetorical speech about our state's bright future but laid out no specific programs for ensuring it. 新的执政官发表了词藻华丽的演说，畅谈国家的美好未来，但却没有提出实现这一目标的具体措施。
A: ♣近  bombastic, flatulent, florid, fustian, gaseous, gassy, grandiloquent, oratorical, orotund, purple, windy
A: ♣反  prosaic 平凡无奇的；plain, simple 简单的

Q:ribald  ['ribəld]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 举止、言语下流粗俗的： characterized by or indulging in vulgar, lewd humor
A: ♣例  entertained the guests with ribald jokes 用荤段子来取悦客人
A: ♣近  bawdy, blue, coarse, crude, dirty, filthy, gross, indecent, nasty, obscene, pornographic, profane, vulgar
A: ♣反  decent, proper, seemly 恰当的，得体的

Q:rickety  ['rikəti]

A: ♣例  The rickety coalition may break at any moment. 脆弱的联盟随时都可能破裂。
A: ♣近  insecure, precarious, shaky, unsound, unsteady, weak
A: ♣反  firm, sound, stable, sturdy 稳定的，稳固的

Q:rider  ['raidə]

A: ♣近  horseman, knight
A: ♣反  pedestrian, walker 行人，步行者
A: ♠考法2  n. 附件： a clause appended to a legislative bill to secure a usually distinct object
A: ♣近  addendum, appendix, attachment, supplement

Q:ridicule  ['ridikju:l]

A: ♣例  always ridiculed everything she said 总是嘲笑她说的话‖The term “big bang theory” was originally coined to ridicule the belief that the universe was created by a giant explosion. “大爆炸理论”期初是为了嘲笑一种观点而创造的，这种观点认为宇宙源自一场巨大的爆炸。
A: ♣近  deride, gibe, jape, jeer, lout, mock, taunt
A: ♣反  commend, praise 表扬
A: ♣派  ridiculous adj. 荒谬的

Q:rife  [raif]

A: ♣例  a video game rife with violence and abuse 充满暴力与虐待的电子游戏
A: ♣近  abounding, abundant, awash, flush, fraught, lousy, replete, swarming, teeming, thick, thronging
A: ♣反  deficient, incomplete, insufficient, short 缺乏的

Q:rift  [rift]

A: ♣近  crack, fissure, fracture, schism
A: ♣反  reconciliation, rapprochement 调和
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使开裂： to cause to split open or break

A: ♣近  cleave, divide, rip, split, sunder, tear
A: ♣反  associate, coalesce, combine, conjugate, join, link 接合

Q:rigmarole  ['riɡmərəul]

A: ♣例  The security guard gave me some kind of rigmarole about passes and authorizations. 保安不知所云地跟我说了一些关于通关和授权的话。
A: ♣近  abracadabra, babble, drivel, gabble, gibber, jabber, nonsense, prattle

Q:rile  [rail]

A: ♣近  aggravate, annoy, enrage, exasperate, grate, inflame, infuriate, irritate, nettle, peeve, pique, provoke, roil
A: ♣反  allay, alleviate, assuage, ease, mitigate, mollify, palliate, relieve, soothe 平息，缓和

Q:roil  [rɔil]

A: ♣例  He roiled the brook with his wood stick. 他用他的木棍将溪水搅浑。‖Financial markets have been roiled by the banking crisis. 银行业的危机搅乱了金融市场的秩序。
A: ♣近  disarray, disorder, disrupt, disturb, mess, muddle, rile
A: ♣反  arrange, array, order, organize, regulate 整理，使有序
A: ♠考法2  vt. 激怒： to displease or disturb
A: ♣例  Some of his roommate’s habits began to roil him. 他室友的某些习惯开始让他恼火。
A: ♣近  aggravate, enrage, exasperate, incense, inflame, infuriate, irritate, provoke, rile, vex
A: ♣反  delight, gratify, please 使愉快

A: ♣反  ashen, pale, pallid, wan 苍白的，虚弱的

Q:rudimentary  [,ru:di'mentəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 初始的，未发展的： being in the earliest stages of development

A: ♠考法2  adj. 最根本的，基础的： consisting in first principles: fundamental
A: ♣例  The dropout had only a rudimentary knowledge of science. 这个辍学的孩子对科学知识只有最基本的一些了解。
A: ♣近  basic, elemental, essential, fundamental, rudimental, underlying
A: ♣反  advanced, higher 进阶的，高等级的

Q:rue  [ru:]

A: ♣反  impenitence, remorselessness 不知悔改
A: ♣派  rueful adj. 后悔的

Q:ruffle  ['rʌfl]

A: ♣近  rumple, wrinkle
A: ♣派  ruffled adj. 有褶裥边修饰的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使粗糙： to destroy the smoothness or evenness of

A: ♣近  abrade, chafe, erode, roughen, rub, wear
A: ♣反  glaze, smooth 使平滑
A: ♠考法3  vt. 扰乱，打扰：to disturb the peace of mind of (someone) especially by repeated disagreeable acts
A: ♣例  The stream of minor complaints finally ruffled him into snapping, “If you don’t like the way I’m doing it, do it yourself!” 一系列的抱怨终于让他爆发：“如果你不喜欢我做事的方法，你就自己去做！”
A: ♣近  annoy, bother, chafe, frost, gall, grate, itch, nettle, peeve, persecute, pique, rasp, rile, vex
A: ♣反  allay, alleviate, assuage, ease, mitigate, mollify, palliate, relieve, soothe 平息，缓和

A: ♣派  rumpled adj. 褶皱的

Q:rustic  ['rʌstik]

A: ♣例  a rustic who was awed by the prices that city dwellers had to pay 一个被大城市房价所吓到的乡里人

A: ♣例  We went to a rustic area that is devoid of skyscrapers and shopping malls. 我们去了一个没有摩天大楼和购物中心的乡村原野。

A: ♣反  urban 都市的

Q:sabotage  ['sæbətɑ:ʒ]

A: ♣例  sabotage of the project by government officials 被政府官员阻止的项目
A: ♣近  damage, impairment, subversion, undermining
A: ♣反  assistance 支援
A: ♠考法2  vt. 从事破坏活动，阻止：to practice sabotage on
A: ♣例  He sabotaged his opponent's campaign with rumors. 他用谣言来破坏对手的竞选活动。‖My ex-wife deliberately sabotages my access to the children. 我的前妻故意想方设法阻止我和我的孩子们见面。
A: ♣近  disrupt, foil, frustrate, obstruct, undermine
A: ♣反  assist, support 支持；advance, cultivate, forward, foster, further, nurture, promote 促进

Q:saccharine  ['sækərain]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 像糖一样的，有甜味的： of, relating to, or resembling that of sugar
A: ♣例  a powdery substance with a saccharine taste 有甜味的粉状物质
A: ♣近  cloying, sugary
A: ♣反  bitter 苦涩的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 做作的，矫情的： appealing to the emotions in an obvious and tiresome way
A: ♣例  The movie was funny, but it had a saccharine ending in which everyone lives happily ever after. 电影还是很有意思的，但是结局太做作了——所有人从此都幸福地生活在了一起。
A: ♣近  fruity, maudlin, mawkish, mushy, sentimental, sugarcoated
A: ♣反  unsentimental 不动感情的

Q:sacrilege  ['sækrilidʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 亵渎圣物： desecration, profanation, misuse, or theft of something sacred
A: ♣例  To play Mozart's music on a kazoo is sacrilege. 用小木笛演奏莫扎特的音乐是对它的一种亵渎。
A: ♣近  blasphemy, defilement, desecration, irreverence, impiety, profanation, violation
A: ♣反  adoration, glorification, respect, reverence 爱慕，尊敬
A: ♣派  sacrilegious adj. 不敬的，亵渎神明的

Q:sacrosanct  ['sækrəusæŋkt]

A: ♣例  The teacher's book of grades is sacrosanct, and someone could be expelled for changing anything in it. 老师记录的成绩小册子是极为神圣的，任何篡改它的人可能受到被退学的惩罚。
A: ♣近  hallowed, holy, inviolable, sacred, unassailable, untouchable
A: ♣反  blasphemous, irreverent, profane, sacrilegious 亵渎的

Q:sage  [seidʒ]

A: ♣反  dolt, fool, idiot, simpleton 傻子
A: ♣派  sagacious adj. 睿智的；sagacity n. 聪慧

Q:salient  ['seiljənt]

A: ♣例  The most salient feature of the book is its papyrus cover. 该书最明显的特点就是莎草纸的封面。
