A: ♣反  inconspicuous, unnoticeable 不明显的
A: ♣派  salience n. 突出，特点

Q:salubrious  [sə'lju:briəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有益健康的： favorable to or promoting health or well-being
A: ♣例  Every year I go to Kunming to enjoy its cool and salubrious climate. 每年我都会去昆明享受它那凉爽宜人的气候。
A: ♣近  good, healthy, restorative, salutary, tonic, wholesome
A: ♣反  debilitating, deleterious, noxious, virulent 有害的，有毒的

Q:salutary  ['sæljutəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有益健康的： beneficial, promoting health
A: ♣例  a salutary warning 善意的警告
A: ♣近  good, healthy, restorative, salubrious, tonic, wholesome
A: ♣反  debilitating, deleterious, noxious, virulent 有害的，有毒的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 有利的，利好的： promoting or contributing to personal or social well-being
A: ♣例  The low interest rates should have a salutary effect on business. 低利率对于商业而言应该是有利的。
A: ♣近  advantageous, benefic, beneficent, benignant, favorable, friendly, helpful, kindly, profitable
A: ♣反  bad, disadvantageous, unfavorable, unfriendly, unhelpful, unprofitable 不利的

Q:salutation  [,sælju:'teiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 致敬，打招呼（表示欢迎和礼貌）： a polite expression of greeting or goodwill
A: ♣例  The veteran stepped forward, raising his hand in salutation. 老兵向前一步，举起手致敬。
A: ♣近  greeting, regards, salute
A: ♣反  farewell, bon voyage （离别时的）再见，一路顺风
A: ♠考法2  n. 表扬： a formal expression praise
A: ♣例  The speaker introduced the evening's honored guest with a lavish salutation. 主持人用大量表扬的话介绍了今晚的嘉宾。
A: ♣近  accolade, citation, commendation, eulogium, eulogy, homage, hymn, paean, panegyric, tribute
A: ♣派  salute v. 敬礼，致敬

Q:salvage  ['sælvidʒ]
A: ♠考法1  v. （从灾难中）抢救： to save from loss or destruction
A: ♣例  salvaged the torpedoed vessel 拯救被鱼雷击中的舰艇
A: ♣近  rescue, retrieve, save
A: ♣反  abandon, desert, forsake 放弃，抛弃
A: ♣派  salvageable adj. 可以挽回的

Q:salve  [sælv]
A: ♠考法1  v. 减轻，缓解： quiet, assuage
A: ♣例  The company give him a raise in salary to salve his feelings. 公司决定给他加薪以安抚他的感情
A: ♣近  allay, balm, becalm, compose, lull, lullaby, quiet, settle, soothe, still, tranquilize
A: ♣反  agitate, discompose, disquiet, disturb, perturb, upset, vex 打扰，扰乱

Q:sanctify  ['sæŋktifai]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使神圣，敬为神： to make holy
A: ♣例  The Constitution sanctified the rights of the people. 宪法认为人权是至高无上的。
A: ♣近  consecrate, hallow
A: ♣反  desecrate, profane 亵渎
A: ♣派  sanctification n. 敬为神明

Q:sanctimonious  [,sæŋkti'məuniəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 假装虔诚的： hypocritically pious or devout
A: ♣例  a sickening sanctimonious smile 令人厌恶的伪善的笑容
A: ♣近  canting, deceiving, hypocritical
A: ♣反  devout, religious, pious 虔诚的

Q:sanction  ['sæŋ,kʃən]
A: ♠考法1  v. 批准，同意，认可： to make valid or binding usually by a formal procedure (as ratification)
A: ♣例  The President sanctioned covert operations. 总统批准了秘密行动‖The administration will sanction almost any field trip with educational value. 基本上任何有教育意义的实地考察都可以得到批准。
A: ♣近  accredit, approbate, authorize, certify, confirm, finalize, formalize, license, ratify, warrant
A: ♣反  interdict, prohibit, proscribe 禁止；decline, deny, disallow, disapprove, negative, reject, veto 否决
A: ♠考法2  n. 制裁： an economic or military coercive measure adopted usually by several nations in concert for forcing a nation violating international law to desist or yield to adjudication
A: ♣例  Another trade sanction is in effect. 又一项贸易制裁生效了。
A: ♣近  penalty, punishment

Q:sanctuary  ['sæŋktju'ri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 避难所： a place of refuge and protection
A: ♣例  In earlier times a criminal could use a church as a sanctuary. 在早期，犯罪分子可以将教堂当作避难所。
A: ♣近  asylum, cover, harbor, haven, port, refuge, shelter

Q:sand  [sænd]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 磨光： to make smooth by friction
A: ♣例  Be sure to sand before you paint the shelf. 在上漆之前一定要先磨光。
A: ♣反  buff, file, hone, rasp, rub

Q:sanguine  ['sæŋɡwin]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 乐观的，确信的： having or showing a mind free from doubt
A: ♣例  I'm reasonably sanguine about the adoption of the latest proposal. 我非常看好最新的那项提议获得通过。
A: ♣近  assured, confident, doubtless, implicit, positive
A: ♣反  doubtful, dubious, uncertain, unsure 怀疑的，不确信的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 面色红润的： having a healthy reddish skin tone
A: ♣例  a baby with a sanguine complexion is more likely to leave the hospital early than a sickly-looking one 面色红润的新生儿比病怏怏的能更早出院
A: ♣近  blooming, florid, flush, glowing, rosy, rubicund
A: ♣反  ashy, doughy, livid, lurid, mealy, pale, pallid, pasty, peaky, sallow, wan 面色苍白的

Q:sanitary  ['sænitəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 健康的，清洁的： of or relating to health
A: ♣例  sanitary measures 保健的手段
A: ♣近  aseptic, germfree, hygienic, sterile
A: ♣反  noxious 有毒的

Q:sap  [sæp]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 削弱： to weaken or exhaust the energy or vitality of
A: ♣例  Weeks of hard work had sapped hum and left him exhausted. 连续几周辛苦工作让他筋疲力尽。
A: ♣近  debilitate, devitalize, enervate, enfeeble, etiolate, prostrate
A: ♣反  bolster, fortify, invigorate, beef up 增强，使有活力
A: ♠考法2  n. 健康，活力： active strength of body or mind
A: ♣例  a child full of sap and vivacity 活力满满的孩子
A: ♣近  dynamism, energy, esprit, get-up-and-go, gusto, verve, vim, vitality
A: ♣反  lethargy, listlessness, sluggishness, torpidity 无精打采

Q:sapient  ['seipiənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 聪明的，有洞察力的： having or showing deep understanding and intelligent application of knowledge
A: ♣例  a man who is always good for valuable insights and some sapient advice 一个以见解深刻、建议明智著称的男人
A: ♣近  discerning, insightful, perceptive, prudent, sagacious, sage
A: ♣反  foolish, unperceptive, unwise 愚蠢的，不明智的

Q:sarcasm  ['sɑ:kæzəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 讽刺，轻蔑： a sharp and often satirical or ironic utterance designed to cut or give pain
A: ♣例  a voice full of sarcasm 充满轻蔑的言论
A: ♣近  affront, barb, indignity, offense, slap, slight, slur
A: ♣反  praise 表扬

Q:sartorial  [sɑ:'tɔ:riəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 裁缝匠的，裁缝的： of or relating to a tailor or tailored clothes
A: ♣例  poor sartorial taste 很烂的穿衣品位

Q:sate  [seit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使饱足，充分满足： to glut; to satisfy (an appetite) fully
A: ♣例  The information sated her curiosity. 这个消息满足了她的好奇心。
A: ♣近  cram, glut, stuff, surfeit, satiate
A: ♣反  starve 饿

Q:satiate  ['seiʃieit]
A: ♠考法1  v./adj. 饱足，过分满足： to satisfy fully or to excess
A: ♣例  A long drink of water satiated my thirst. 一顿痛饮之后我的口渴得到了缓解
A: ♣近  replete, sate, stuff, surfeit
A: ♣反  tantalize 挑逗，不去满足

Q:satire  ['sætaiə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 讽刺诗，讽剌文学： a literary work holding up human vices and follies to ridicule or scorn
A: ♣例  a satire about the music industry in which a handsome but untalented youth is turned into a rock star 一部关于一个长得帅却没才华的年轻人如何被打造成一个摇滚巨星的讽刺文学作品
A: ♣近  lampoon, pasquinade

Q:satirize  ['sætəraiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 讽刺： to ridicule or attack by means of satire
A: ♣例  The movie satirizes contemporary life. 这部电影讽刺当下生活。

Q:saturate  ['sætʃəreit]
A: ♠考法1  v./adj. 使饱和，浸透： to wet thoroughly with liquid
A: ♣例  Saturate the sponge with water. 将海绵浸透
A: ♣近  bathe, douse, drench, soak, souse, bedraggle
A: ♣反  wring out

Q:saturnine  ['sætə(:)nain]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 忧郁的，阴沉的： causing or marked by an atmosphere lacking in cheer
A: ♣例  The men awaiting interrogation by the police shared a saturnine silence. 等待警察审问的人们脸色阴沉，沉默不语。
A: ♣近  bleak, depressive, dismal, dreary, miserable, solemn
A: ♣反  jovial, bright, cheerful, comforting, cordial, festive, heartwarming, sunshiny 欢乐的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 讥讽的： having a sardonic aspect
A: ♣例  a saturnine smile 讥讽的笑容
A: ♣反  genial 友善的

Q:saunter  ['sɔ:ntə]

A: ♣例  sauntered slowly down the street 在街上闲逛
A: ♣近  amble, ramble, range, stroll, wander, perambulate

Q:savant  ['sævənt]

A: ♣例  a savant in the field of medical ethics 医学伦理方面的专家
A: ♣近  pundit, scholar
A: ♣反  unlearned person 没有学问的人

Q:savory  ['seivəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 口感好的，味道好的： appetizing to the taste or smell
A: ♣例  cedar is one of the most savory of all woods 雪松是所有树木中味道最好闻的
A: ♣近  ambrosial, appetizing, dainty, palatable, scrumptious
A: ♣反  noisome, fetid, foul, malodorous, putrid, rancid, reeking, smelly, stenchy, stinky 难闻的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 令人愉悦的： giving pleasure or contentment to the mind or senses
A: ♣例  having to fire someone was not a task that the manager found at all savory 经理发现不得不开除某人是件非常不讨好的事
A: ♣近  agreeable, blessed, congenial, delectable, delicious, delightful, dulcet, enjoyable, felicitous, grateful, gratifying, heavenly, jolly, luscious, palatable, pleasurable, satisfying, tasty, welcome
A: ♣反  disagreeable, pleasureless, unpalatable, unpleasant, unwelcome 讨厌的，不受欢迎的

Q:savvy  ['sævi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 老练，机智： knowledge gained by actually doing or living through something
A: ♣例  political savvy 政治上的老脸精明
A: ♣近  chops, expertise, proficiency, know-how
A: ♣反  simplicity, tactlessness, inexperience 单纯，缺乏经验
A: ♠考法2  v. 明确了解： to have a clear idea of
A: ♣例  The man growled, “Don't ever date my daughter again—you savvy?” 那男人咆哮道，“你丫以后不准再见我女儿，你的明白？”
A: ♣近  appreciate, apprehend, assimilate, behold, catch on, cognize, compass, conceive, decipher, decode, discern, grasp, perceive, recognize, register, seize, tumble to
A: ♣反  miss 不理解
A: ♠考法3  adj. 有见识，精明能干的： having or showing a practical cleverness or judgment
A: ♣例  a particularly savvy investor, he was among the first to see the potential in tech stocks 一个有卓识远见的投资者，是第一批看到科技类股票升值潜力的人
A: ♣近  astute, canny, clear-eyed, clear-sighted, hard-boiled, hardheaded, heady, sharp, sharp-witted, smart
A: ♣反  unknowing 无知的

Q:scads  [skædz]

A: ♣近  abundance, plenitude, profusion, slew, spate, wealth
A: ♣反  paucity 极小量

Q:scant  [skænt]

A: ♣近  exiguous, niggardly, scarce, sparse, stingy
A: ♣反  considerable, copious, voluminous, profuse, myriad 大量的，相当多的

Q:scathing  ['skeiðiŋ]

A: ♣近  acerbic, acid, acrid, pungent, scalding, snarky, tart
A: ♣反  polite, calm compliment 客气的，平静的称赞

A: ♣近  conflict, discordance, disharmony, dissidence, dissonance, disunion, friction, strife
A: ♣反  accord, agreement, concord, harmony, peace 一致

Q:scintillate  ['sintileit]

A: ♣例  diamond ring scintillated in the sunlight 钻戒在阳光下闪闪发光
A: ♣近  gleam, glimmer, glisten, glister, luster, sparkle, winkle
A: ♣派  scintillating 才气横溢的：brilliantly lively, stimulating, or witty
A: ♣例  a scintillating conversation
A: ♣反  dull, foolly 迟钝的

Q:scion  ['saiən]

A: ♣例  scion of a railroad empire 铁路大王的后代
A: ♣反  ancestor 前辈

Q:scission  ['siʒən]

A: ♣例  The scission of the labor union will compromise the workers' bargaining power 工会内部的分裂会削弱工人讨价的力量
A: ♣近  bifurcation, cleavage, dissolution, division, partition, schism, sundering
A: ♣反  unification, union 统一

Q:scoff  [skɔf]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 嘲笑： to treat or address with derision: mock
A: ♣例  scoffed at the idea 对这个提议不屑一顾
A: ♠考法2  v. 狼吞虎咽： to swallow or eat greedily
A: ♣例  scoffed dinner before running off to the basketball game 风卷残云般把晚饭消灭了，就直奔向篮球场
A: ♣近  cram, devour, glut, gorge, gormandize, gulp, ingurgitate, inhale, raven

Q:scorch  [skɔ:tʃ]

A: ♣例  scorching sun 火辣辣的太阳
A: ♣近  dehydrate, desiccate, parch, sear, singe
A: ♣反  dampen, hydrate, wash, water, wet 使潮湿

Q:scorn  [skɔ:n]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 轻蔑，鄙视，不屑： reject or dismiss as contemptible or unworthy
A: ♣例  They were scorned as fanatics. 他们被指责为狂热分子。
A: ♣近  despise, disregard, flout, contemn, disdain, slight, look down (on or upon)
A: ♣反  adulate; venerate, honor, respect, revere 谄媚；尊敬

Q:scotch  [skɔtʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 停止： to put an abrupt end to
A: ♣例  The prime minister scotched the rumors of her illness. 首相出面澄清了关于她死亡的谣言。
A: ♣近  hinder, thwart

Q:scour  ['skauə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 用力擦洗： to clean, polish, or wash by scrubbing vigorously
A: ♠考法2  vt. 搜查： to look through (as a place) carefully or thoroughly in an effort to find or discover something
A: ♣例  the police scoured the city for the criminal 警方全城搜索罪犯
A: ♣近  comb, dig through, dredge, hunt through, rake, ransack, rifle, rummage, sort through, troll

Q:scourge  [skə:dʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 祸害： a source of harm or misfortune
A: ♣例  The sheer ubiquity of food seems to be the scourge of humanity, as evidenced by the obesity epidemic. 无所不在的食品似乎要成为人类的罪恶之源了，这一点可以从肥胖病的泛滥得以佐证。
A: ♣近  affliction, bane, curse, nemesis
A: ♣反  benefit, blessing, boon, felicity, godsend, manna, windfall 恩赐，福音

Q:scowl  [skaul]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 皱眉（表现出不高兴）： to contract the brow in an expression of displeasure
A: ♣例  scowled down at the misbehaving child 对淘气的孩子皱起了眉
A: ♣近  frown, pout, glare, gloom, glower, lower
A: ♣反  beam, grin, smile 微笑（表示高兴）

Q:scrap  [skræp]
A: ♠考法1  n. 废料，废物： discarded or useless material
A: ♣例  The rest of this stuff is just scrap, so sweep it up and throw it away. 剩下的这堆东西都是没用的，把它们打扫一下就扔了吧。
A: ♣近  chaff, debris, dreck, dross, dust, effluvium, junk, litter, offal, offscouring, raffle, refuse, riffraff, rubbish, waste
A: ♠考法2  vt. 抛弃： to get rid of as useless or unwanted
A: ♣例  We've decided to scrap the first car. 我们决定丢弃第一辆车。
A: ♣近  ditch, dump, jettison, junk, toss, throw away
A: ♣反  retrieve 找回
A: ♠考法3  v. 终止，放弃原计划： to put an end to (something planned or previously agreed to)
A: ♣例  We scrapped our plans to go to Paris, and set out the next day for Prague. 我们取消了去巴黎的计划，第二天启程奔赴布拉格。
A: ♣近  abandon, abort, drop, recall, repeal, rescind, revoke, call off, cry off
A: ♣反  continue, keep 继续，持续

Q:scrappy  ['skræpi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 好斗的，好吵架的： having an aggressive and determined spirit，quarrelsome
A: ♣例  She was a scrappy girl despite—or, perhaps, because of—her small size. 这个妹子好打斗，但是身材娇小，不过这很可能是原因
A: ♣近  aggressive, assaultive, combative, militant, pugnacious, truculent
A: ♣反  nonaggressive, nonbelligerent, pacific, peaceful, unbelligerent, uncombative,, timorous 胆小的，爱好和平的

Q:scrawl  [skrɔ:l]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 乱涂，潦草地写： to write or draw awkwardly, hastily, or carelessly
A: ♣例  scrawled a quick note, stuck it in their mailbox, and hurried off 草草写了张便条，塞进他们的信箱然后匆匆跑了
A: ♣近  scratch, squiggle
A: ♣反  write carefully 仔细地写

Q:screen  [skri:n]
A: ♠考法1  n. 掩护物，屏障： something that shelters, protects, or hides
A: ♣例  The target will be difficult to reach as it is behind a screen of anti-aircraft batteries. 目标在防空炮火的掩护之下难以靠近。‖Please keep away from the screen door. 请不要倚靠屏蔽门。
A: ♣近  aegis, ammunition, armor, cover, guard, protection, safeguard, security, shield, wall, ward
A: ♠考法2  vt. 保护，使…免受攻击： to drive danger or attack away from
A: ♣例  Gunships were called in to help screen the troops from further attacks. 武装直升机被呼叫对步兵进行支援，使之免受进一步的攻击。
A: ♣近  defend, fence, fend, forfend, protect, secure
A: ♣反  assail, assault, attack 攻击
A: ♠考法3  vt. 掩护，遮蔽： to keep secret or shut off from view
A: ♣例  Bushes screened the swimming pool from passersby on the street. 灌木丛将游泳池和外面的行人隔绝开来。
A: ♣近  belie, cloak, conceal, curtain, disguise, enshroud, mask, obscure, occult, shroud, veil
A: ♣反  disclose, expose, reveal, uncloak, uncover, unmask, unveil 揭露

Q:scribble  ['skribl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 潦草地书写，乱写： to cover with scribbles, doodles, or meaningless marks
A: ♣例  Students scribbled furiously as the teacher lectured. 老师一边讲，学生们一边狂抄笔记。
A: ♣近  scratch, scrawl, squiggle

Q:scrimp  [skrimp]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 节俭： to avoid unnecessary waste or expense
A: ♣例  They had to scrimp and save for years in order to be able to afford a house. 他们不得不节俭度日才能攒够钱买房。
A: ♣近  conserve, economize, husband, pinch, save, skimp, spare
A: ♣反  dissipate, lavish, squander, waste 浪费

Q:scruple  ['skru:pl]
A: ♠考法1  n. （良心上的）不安： an uneasy feeling about the rightness of what one is doing or going to do
A: ♣例  The survey showed that many students had few scruples about cheating on papers or exams. 调查显示很多学生对于在考试时作弊没有丝毫的愧疚。
A: ♣近  compunction, misgiving
A: ♣反  assurance, certainty, certitude, confidence, conviction, sureness 确信

Q:scrupulous  ['skru:pjuləs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 正直的： guided by or in accordance with one's sense of right and wrong; principled
A: ♣例  Less scrupulous companies find ways to evade the law. 道德程度略低的公司钻法律的空子。
A: ♣近  conscionable, ethical, honest, honorable, moral, principled
A: ♣反  cutthroat, dishonest, dishonorable, immoral, unconscionable, unethical, unjust, unprincipled 不道德的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 一丝不苟的： taking, showing, or involving great care and effort
A: ♣例  The task requires scrupulous attention to detail. 这项任务需要对细节一丝不苟。
A: ♣近  careful, conscientious, fussy, meticulous

Q:scrutable  ['skru:təbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可以理解的： capable of being understood through study and observation; comprehensible.
A: ♣例  Her machinations and motives are all too scrutable to us who know her. 她的阴谋和动机对于了解她的我们来说非常昭然若揭
A: ♣近  accessible, apprehensible, comprehensible, fathomable, legible
A: ♣反  mysterious, incoherent, incomprehensible, inscrutable, insensible 神秘而不可知的

Q:scrutinize  ['skru:tinaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 仔细检查： to examine or observe with great care
A: ♣例  I closely scrutinized my opponent's every move. 我仔细注意着对手的每一个举动。
A: ♣近  examine, review, scan, survey, plumb, check (out)
A: ♣反  casually glance, gloss over 随意一瞥，敷衍处理

Q:scuff  [skʌf]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 磨损： to become scratched, chipped, or roughened by wear
A: ♣例  a countertop that won't scuff 一块不易磨损的厨房台面
A: ♣近  abrade, graze, scratch
A: ♠考法2  v. 脚步拖沓： to move heavily or clumsily
A: ♣例  The miners scuffed past in heavy boots. 矿工们脚着厚重的靴子，步履蹒跚。
A: ♣近  barge, clomp, clump, flog, flounder, lump, plod, pound, shamble, slog, slough, stamp, stomp, stumble, stump, tramp, tromp, trudge
A: ♣反  breeze, coast, glide, slide, whisk 滑行

Q:scurrilous  ['skʌriləs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 说粗话的： given to the use of vulgar, coarse, or abusive language
A: ♣例  scurrilous attacks on the senator 对参议院粗俗的攻击
A: ♣近  contumelious, invective, opprobrious, truculent, vitriolic, vituperative

Q:scurvy  ['skə:vi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 下流，让人鄙视的： mean; contemptible
A: ♣例  She was beset by a whole scurvy swarm of con artists. 她被一群下流的骗子艺术家蜂拥围攻。
A: ♣近  deplorable, despicable, grubby, lousy, scummy, wretched
A: ♣反  admirable, commendable, creditable, laudable, meritorious, praiseworthy 让人称赞的

Q:seamy  ['si:mi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 肮脏的，堕落的： sordid; base
A: ♣例  the seamy side of urban life 城市生活的肮脏面
A: ♣近  sordid, base
A: ♣反  decent and respectable 适当而值得尊敬的

Q:secede  [si'si:d]

A: ♣例  They threatened to secede from the coalition. 他们以退出联盟相要挟。
A: ♣近  demit, disaffiliate, quit, withdraw
A: ♣反  enlist, enroll, join, sign up 加入

Q:secluded  [si'klu:did]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 隐僻的，隐蔽的： screened or hidden from view
A: ♣例  secluded monks 隐居的僧人
A: ♣近  cloistered, covert, isolated, remote, retired, sheltered

Q:secrete  [si'kri:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 隐藏： to conceal in a hiding place; cache
A: ♣例  The police found the weapon secreted under the driver's seat of the getaway car. 警方在逃逸车辆驾驶座下发现了隐藏的武器。
A: ♣近  bury, cache, conceal, ensconce
A: ♣反  divulge, display, exhibit 泄密，展示
A: ♠考法2  vt. 分泌： to generate and separate (a substance) from cells or bodily fluids
A: ♣反  absorb 吸收

Q:sectarianism  [sek'tεəriənizəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 宗派主义，顽固： stubborn or intolerant adherence to one's opinions or prejudices
A: ♣例  An ideological sectarianism prevented the political party from ever being anything more than a fringe group. 意识形态上的顽固和保守使得这个政党只能成为一个边缘团体。
A: ♣近  dogmatism, illiberalism, intolerance, narrow-mindedness, partisanship, small-mindedness
A: ♣反  broad-mindedness, liberalism, open-mindedness, tolerance 开明

Q:secular  ['sekjulə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 世俗的，尘世的： of or relating to the worldly or temporal
A: ♣例  That’s an issue for the secular authorities, not the church. 这个问题和宗教无关，是一个世俗事务。
A: ♣近  carnal, earthborn, earthbound, fleshly, material, mundane, sublunary, temporal, terrene, terrestrial, worldly
A: ♣反  heavenly, unearthly, unworldly 非尘世间的；spiritual 精神上的；religious 宗教的

Q:sedate  [si'deit]

A: ♣例  She remained sedate under pressure. 她在压力下仍保持镇静。
A: ♣近  collected, composed, self-possessed, serene, tranquil, undisturbed, unperturbed, unruffled
A: ♣反  agitated, discomposed, disturbed, flustered, perturbed, upset 不淡定的，狂乱的

Q:sedentary  ['sedəntəri]

A: ♣例  a sedentary lifestyle 很宅的生活方式
A: ♣反  migratory, peripatetic 流动的，巡游的

Q:seduce  [si'dju:s]

A: ♣例  The other firm seduced him with a better offer. 另一家公司用更高的待遇想挖他墙脚。
A: ♣近  allure, decoy, entice, solicit, tempt, lead on
A: ♣反  repulse, ward off 厌恶，不被吸引

Q:sedulous  ['sedjuləs]

A: ♣例  a sedulous student 一个勤奋地学生
A: ♣近  assiduous, diligent, industrious, laborious, occupied, tied-up
A: ♣反  idle, inactive, unbusy, unemployed, unoccupied 懒惰的

Q:seemly  ['si:mli]
A: ♠考法1  adv. 得体的，遵守礼节的： following the established traditions of refined society and good taste
A: ♣例  a young lady of seemly appearance, robust health, and keen intelligence 一个打扮得体、身体健康、头脑敏锐的姑娘

A: ♣反  uncouth, ribald, indecorous, improper, inappropriate, indecent, indelicate, unbecoming, ungenteel, unseemly 粗俗的，不礼貌的

Q:segment  ['seɡmənt]

A: ♣近  member, partition, portion, section

Q:self-abasement  ['selfə'beismənt]

A: ♣反  self-asserting 自信

Q:self-absorbed  ['selfəb'sɔ:bd]

A: ♣例  a self-absorbed man who seems utterly oblivious to the social problems of his own urban neighborhood 一个超级自私的人，对于街坊的事情完全视而不见
A: ♣近  narcissistic, self-centered, self-infatuated, self-obsessed, self-oriented, self-preoccupied
A: ♣反  self-forgetting, selfless, unselfish 无私的

Q:seminal  ['seminəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有发展性的： containing or contributing the seeds of later development
A: ♣反  hampering further development 阻碍进一步发展
A: ♠考法2  adj. 创新的： of, relating to, or having the power to originate; creative
A: ♣例  a seminal novel 新颖的小说
A: ♣反  derivative 派生的

Q:sensation  [sen'seiʃən]

A: ♣例  We felt just the smallest sensation of warmth when we leaned against the radiator. 当我们靠着取暖器的时候，我们也仅仅感到了一点点的温度。
A: ♣反  anesthesia, numbness 麻木
A: ♠考法2  n. 轰动事件： a state of intense public interest and excitement
A: ♣例  the rookie hitting sensation of the American League 这个菜鸟的表现轰动了整个全美大联盟
A: ♣近  flash, marvel, miracle, phenomenon, portent, prodigy, splendor
A: ♣反  unnoticed event 不知名的小事

Q:sensitive  ['sensitiv]

A: ♣近  susceptible, vulnerable, subject (to)
A: ♣反  numb 麻木的

Q:sentinel  ['sentinəl]

Q:sepulchral  [si'pʌlkrəl]

A: ♣近  depressing, desolate, dismal, dreary, morose, sullen, tenebrous
A: ♣反  merry, bright, cheery, comforting, cordial, festive, heartwarming, sunshiny 欢快的

Q:sequel  ['si:kwel]

Q:sequester  [si'kwestə]

Q:sere  [siə]

A: ♣近  arid, droughty, thirsty, waterless
A: ♣反  lush, damp, dank, humid, moist, wet 葱绿的，湿润的

A: ♣例  They found each other by pure serendipity. 他俩的相识属于缘分天注定。

Q:serene  [si'ri:n]

A: ♣例  a serene vacation spot 一处宁谧的度假胜地
A: ♣近  arcadian, calm, hushed, peaceful, placid, restful, still, tranquil
A: ♣反  boisterous, clamorous, clattery, deafening, raucous, roistering, romping, rowdy, tumultuous, unquiet, uproarious
A: ♠考法2  adj. 稳重的，镇静的： unaffected by disturbance; calm and unruffled
A: ♣例  a serene man who was everyone's source of support 一个沉着镇静的男人，他是所有人的精神支柱
A: ♣近  collected, composed, possessed, recollected, undisturbed, unperturbed, unruffled
A: ♣反  agitated, discomposed, disturbed, flustered, perturbed, unhinged, unstrung, upset 暴躁的，不安的
A: ♣派  serenity n. 平静 the quality or state of being serene
A: ♣反  havoc, pandemonium, tumult, bedlam, riot, furor 混乱，骚动

Q:sermon  ['sə:mən]

A: ♣近  brutal, excruciating, grievous, onerous, oppressive, tough, trying

Q:shackle  ['ʃækl]

A: ♣近  clog, cramp, encumber, fetter, hinder, impede, inhibit, interfere with, manacle, obstruct, short-circuit, stymie, tie up, trammel
A: ♣反  aid, assist, facilitate, help 促进，帮助

Q:shadow  ['ʃædəu]

A: ♣例  shadowing the suspect to see what he was up to 尾随嫌犯行踪
A: ♣近  chase, course, pursue, trace, track, trail
A: ♣派  shadowy 模糊的：faintly perceptible: indistinct
A: ♣例  He had only a shadowy idea of what they wanted him to do. 他对要做的事只有一个模糊的想法。

Q:shallow  ['ʃæləu]

A: ♣近  facile, one-dimensional, skin-deep
A: ♣反  profound 深刻的，有深度的

Q:sham  [ʃæm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 欺瞒： the quality of deceitfulness; empty pretense
A: ♣例  condemned the rigged election as a total sham 指责这次有作弊的选举是彻头彻尾的骗局
A: ♣反  debunk 揭穿真相
A: ♠考法2  v. 掩饰，假装： to present a false appearance of
A: ♣例  shammed a most unconvincing limp just to get sympathy 非常拙劣地假装自己腿脚不便，以博得同情
A: ♣近  act, affect, bluff, counterfeit, dissemble, fake, simulate, pretend, profess, put on, pass for
A: ♠考法3  adj. 虚假的： not genuine; fake
A: ♣例  street vendors selling sham designer handbags to gullible tourists 街头小贩向易上当的游客兜售山寨的设计师手包
A: ♣近  bogus, forged, phony, spurious, unauthentic
A: ♣反  genuine, authentic, bona fide, real, unfaked 真正的

Q:shift  [ʃift]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 改变…的位置： to change the place or position of
A: ♣例  She shifted the vase closer to the wall so that it wouldn't get knocked over. 她把花瓶靠墙挪动了一点，从而防止它被碰倒。
A: ♣近  budge, dislocate, displace, disturb, relocate, remove, reposition, transfer, transpose
A: ♣反  anchor, fix, freeze, secure, set 使固定
A: ♠考法2  vi. 改变，变化： to pass from one form, state, or level to another
A: ♣例  She watched the aurora in fascination as its colors shifted from green to blue. 她着迷地看着极光的色彩从绿变成蓝。
A: ♣近  fluctuate, mutate, snap, vary
A: ♣反  plateau, stabilize 达到稳定点，不变
A: ♠考法3  vt. 交换： to give up (something) and take something else in return
A: ♣例  My father and I shifted seats just before takeoff so that I could sit by the window. 起飞前我和我父亲交换了座位，这样我就可以靠窗坐了。
A: ♣近  commute, exchange, shift, substitute, swap, switch, trade

Q:shiftless  ['ʃiftlis]

A: ♣例  shiftless spongers who never thought to do anything for themselves 无志气的弃民们，从来没有想过改变自己
A: ♣近  idle, indolent, slothful
A: ♣反  industrious 勤奋的

Q:shifty  ['ʃifti]

A: ♣例  shifty practices such as turning back the odometers on used cars 一些欺骗性的花招，比如把旧车的里程表调零‖He had a shifty face so I won’t trust him. 他看起来贼目鼠眼的，我不会相信他。
A: ♣近  crooked, deceitful, deceptive, duplicitous, fraudulent, guileful, rogue, shady, sharp, underhanded
A: ♣近  aboveboard, honest, straight 正派的，光明正大的

Q:shipshape  ['ʃipʃeip]

A: ♣近  antiseptic, kempt, orderly, prim, uncluttered, well-groomed
A: ♣反  disheveled, disordered, disorderly, messy, sloven, unkempt, untidy

Q:shoal  [ʃəul]

A: ♣例  shoal waters of the bay 海湾附近的浅水区
A: ♣反  deep 深的

Q:shopworn  ['ʃɔpwɔ:n]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 陈旧的： worn-out, as from overuse; trite
A: ♣例  the shopworn suggestion to job applicants to “just be yourself” 老掉牙的让应征者“做你自己”的提议
A: ♣近  banal, cliché, commonplace, hackneyed, trite, well-worn
A: ♣反  new, fresh, novel, original, unclichéd, unhackneyed 新的

Q:shred  [ʃred]

A: ♣例  He struggled to retain a shred of his dignity. 他勉强挽救了一点尊严。
A: ♣近  crumb, driblet, mite, scintilla, spark, speck, sprinkling, tad

Q:shrewd  [ʃru:d]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 精明的，机敏的： having or showing a practical cleverness or judgment
A: ♣例  He's shrewd about his investments. 他是个精明的投资人。
A: ♣近  crafty, cunning, devious, sly, subtle, wily, astute, savvy, sharp
A: ♣反  foolish, na?ve, unknowing 愚蠢的，幼稚的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 刺骨的，强烈的： causing intense discomfort to one's skin
A: ♣例  She pulled her coat tighter against the shrewd breeze whipping down the alley. 巷子里挂着刺骨的风，她拉紧了大衣。
A: ♣近  biting, bitter, keen, penetrating, piercing, raw, sharp, stinging

Q:shrink  [ʃriŋk]
A: ♠考法1  v. 在数量或价值方面变低；减小： to become reduced in amount or value; dwindle:
A: ♣例  His savings quickly shrank. 他的存款急剧减少。
A: ♣近  compress, condense, constrict
A: ♣反  balloon, expand, snowball, swell
A: ♠考法2  v. 本能性地退却（如因遇到使人惊恐的某物）；退缩： to draw back instinctively, as from something alarming; recoil
A: ♣例  shrinking back from the approaching flames 对着燃烧的火焰望而却步
A: ♣近  blench, cringe, quail, recoil, squinch, wince
A: ♠考法3  v. 表示出不情愿；犹豫： to show reluctance; hesitate:
A: ♣例  shrink from making such a sacrifice 对做出这样的牺牲犹豫不决

Q:shroud  [ʃraud]
A: ♠考法1  n. 隐蔽物，可起隐藏、保护或屏护作用的某物： something that conceals, protects, or screens:
A: ♣例  under a shroud of fog 在迷雾的掩护下
A: ♠考法2  v. 将…从视线中隔离，遮蔽： to shut off from sight; screen
A: ♣例  shrouded the fact that the child had been adopted 将孩子是领养的这个事实隐藏起来
A: ♣近  belie, blanket, cloak, conceal, cover, curtain, disguise, mask, occult, screen, veil, blot out, paper over
A: ♣反  bare, disclose, display, divulge, expose, reveal, show 展示，暴露

Q:shrug  [ʃrʌɡ]
A: ♠考法1  v. 轻视，忽略： to dismiss as of little importance
A: ♣例  The administration was willing to shrug off the problem. 当局有意忽略这个问题。
A: ♣近  disregard, gloss, ignore, minimize, overlook, overpass, slight, slur, wink
A: ♣反  attend, heed, mind 留心，注意
A: ♠考法2  v. 脱下（衣物等）： to rid oneself of (a garment)
A: ♣例  She shrugged off her coat and hung it up neatly. 她脱下了她的大衣，将其整齐地挂好。
A: ♣近  doff, douse, put off, take off
A: ♣反  don, put on 穿上

Q:shun  [ʃʌn]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 避开，避免： to avoid deliberately; keep away from
A: ♣例  After his divorce he found himself being shunned by many of his former friends. 自从他离婚以来，他发现许多曾经的朋友都刻意躲着他。
A: ♣近  avoid, dodge, duck, elude, eschew, evade, finesse, scape, shirk
A: ♣反  accept, embrace, welcome 接受，欢迎；pursue, seek 追寻

Q:sidestep  ['saidstep]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （通过逃避而）不遵守： to avoid having to comply with (something) especially through cleverness
A: ♣例  The eager enlistee sidestepped the regulations by lying about his age. 急切的应募者通过谎报自己的年龄躲过了规定的限制。
A: ♣近  beat, bypass, dodge, shortcut, skirt
A: ♣反  comply, follow, keep, obey, observe 遵守

Q:signal  ['siɡnəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （在重要性、成就方面）非同寻常的： standing above others in rank, importance, or achievement
A: ♣例  The Louisiana Purchase is cited by many historians as one of the most signal events in American history. 从法国手中购买路易斯安那被许多历史学家认为是美国历史上最重要的事件之一。‖a signal feat 一项非同寻常伟业
A: ♣近  distinguished, illustrious, luminous, notable, noteworthy, outstanding, preeminent, prestigious, redoubtable
A: ♣反  average, inferior, mediocre 一般的，低下的；insignificant, minor, unimportant 不重要的
A: ♠考法2  v. 给出信号： to direct or notify by a movement or gesture
A: ♣例  They signaled at me to come over to their table. 他们向我打招呼要我到他们那桌去。‖A lock on the suitcase might signal that there's something of value inside. 手提箱上的锁可能意味着其中有贵重物品。
A: ♣近  beckon, flag, gesture, wave

Q:simile  ['simili]
A: ♠考法1  n. 明喻： a figure of speech comparing two unlike things that is often introduced by like or as
A: ♣例  Even though both similes and metaphors are forms of comparison, similes indirectly compare the two ideas and allow them to remain distinct in spite of their similarities, whereas metaphors compare two things directly. For instance, a simile that compares a person with a bullet would go as follows: "Chris was a record-setting runner as fast as a speeding bullet." A metaphor might read something like, "When Chris ran, he was a speeding bullet racing along the track." 尽管明喻和暗喻都是比喻的手法，明喻会间接地对两个对象进行比较，同时允许差异的存在，而暗喻则直接对两者进行比较。比如说，用明喻来把一个人比作子弹会这样说：“克里斯是一个不断打破记录的选手，他跑得就和高速子弹一样快。”而暗喻可能会说：“当克里斯奔跑的时候，他就是一颗在赛场上高速飞行的子弹。”
A: ♣反  metaphor 暗喻

Q:simpleton  ['simpltən]
A: ♠考法1  n. （缺乏常识的）笨蛋： a person lacking in common sense; a stupid person
A: ♣例  His silly antics at office parties have earned him a reputation as a simpleton. 他在办公室聚会上愚蠢的古怪行为让他被人认为是个蠢货。
A: ♣近  airhead, dolt, donkey, dullard, fool, idiot, moron
A: ♣反  intellectual, sage, wit 智者；genius, prodigy 天才

Q:simulate  ['simjuleit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 假装，模仿： to have or take on the appearance, form, or sound of; imitate
A: ♣例  cosmetics that simulate a suntan 用来模仿晒黑效果的化妆品
A: ♣近  act, affect, assume, counterfeit, dissemble, fake, imitate, pretend, profess, sham
A: ♠考法2  v. 模拟： to create a representation or model of (a physical system or particular situation)
A: ♣例  carrying out an experiment to simulate weightlessness 进行了模拟失重状态的实验

Q:sin  [sin]
A: ♠考法1  n. 罪恶的事： an action that is or is felt to be highly reprehensible; morally unacceptable
A: ♣例  It's a sin to waste food when people are starving. 当有人还在挨饿时浪费食物是一种罪过。
A: ♣近  bad, evildoing, ill, immorality, iniquity, villainy, wrong
A: ♣反  good, morality, right, virtue 美德，美好的行为
A: ♣派  sinful adj. 罪恶的，有罪的

Q:sincere  [sin'siə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 真诚的，不做作的： being without hypocrisy or pretense; true
A: ♣例  She offered a sincere apology for her angry outburst. 她为她先前的盛怒表示诚挚的歉意。
A: ♣近  artless, genuine, heartfelt, honest, ingenuous, innocent, natural, real, true, unaffected, unfeigned
A: ♣反  affected, artful, artificial, assuming, dissembling, fake, guileful, insincere, phony, pretentious 做作的，假装的

Q:sinecure  ['saini,kjuə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 美差： an office or position that requires little or no work and that usually provides an income
A: ♣例  a lucrative sinecure in a big law firm 在大法律公司高报酬的美差
A: ♣反  drudge, drudgery, moil, sweat, toil, travail 艰苦的工作，苦活

Q:sinew  ['sinju:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 活力，力量： vigorous strength; muscular power
A: ♣例  Money is the sinew of love as well as war. 爱情和战争都要用金钱来保证。
A: ♣近  energy, firepower, force, horsepower, might, muscle, potency, power, puissance, strength, vigor
A: ♣反  impotence, impotency, powerlessness, weakness 无力，虚弱

Q:singe  [sindʒ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 轻微烧焦： to burn superficially or lightly
A: ♣例  The iron is too hot, and you'll singe the nightdress. 熨斗太烫了，你会把睡衣烫坏的。‖The marshmallows got a bit singed over the campfire, but we like them that way. 棉花糖因为营火而有些许烧焦，但我们还是很喜欢它的味道。
A: ♣近  char, scorch, sear
A: ♣反  incinerate 烧成灰烬

Q:sinuous  ['sinjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 蜿蜒的，迂回的： marked by a long series of irregular curves; not direct
A: ♣例  The river flowed in a sinuous path through the lush valley. 蜿蜒曲折的河流流过茂密的山谷。‖Thirty-year-old men are novel, rich in content and sinuous in plots. 三十岁的男人是小说，内容丰富，情节曲折。
A: ♣近  bending, curling, curved, curving, devious, serpentine, tortuous, twisted, winding, windy
A: ♣反  straight, straightaway 直的，直接的

Q:sip  [sip]

A: ♣例  slowly sipping the hot soup 慢慢地喝着热汤‖She sipped her coffee while she watched the sun rise. 她一边看着日出，一边喝着她的咖啡。
A: ♣近  gulp, guzzle, hoist, imbibe, quaff, swill
A: ♣反  vomit, throw up 呕吐

Q:skeleton  ['skelitən]

A: ♣例  Only the charred skeleton of the house remained after the fire. 大火过后整个房子只剩下被烧焦的骨架了。‖We saw a skeleton of the report before it was published. 在报告发表之前，我们看到了他的整体框架。
A: ♣近  architecture, configuration, edifice, fabric, framework, framing, infrastructure, shell, structure

Q:skeptic  ['skeptik]
A: ♠考法1  n. 怀疑者： one who instinctively or habitually doubts, questions, or disagrees with assertions or generally accepted conclusions
A: ♣例  You can either be a skeptic or not, but I believe it anyway. 至于你信不信，我反正信了。
A: ♣近  disbeliever, doubter, questioner, unbeliever
A: ♣反  dupe, gull, pigeon 容易上当受骗的人
A: ♣派  skeptical adj. 持怀疑态度的；skepticism n. 怀疑论

Q:skimp  [skimp]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 缺乏的，不足的： less plentiful than what is normal, necessary, or desirable
A: ♣例  The dieter complained about skimp meals that were served at the fat farm. 这个节食者抱怨说减肥疗养地的伙食少得可怜。
A: ♣近  exiguous, meager, niggardly, poor, scant, scanty, scarce, skimpy, slender, slim, sparing, sparse, stingy
A: ♣反  abundant, ample, bountiful, copious, generous, liberal, plenteous, plentiful大量的，丰富的
A: ♠考法2  vi. 节省花费，吝啬： to give insufficient or barely sufficient attention or effort to or funds for
A: ♣例  We must skimp and save if we are going to afford a vacation this summer. 要是我们这个夏天要出去旅行，那么就得开始节省出一些钱了。
A: ♣近  pinch, save, scrimp, spare, stint
A: ♣反  dissipate, lavish, prodigalize, squander, waste 浪费，挥霍

Q:skirmish  ['skə:miʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 小冲突，争论： a minor or preliminary conflict or dispute
A: ♣例  They had a skirmish over the rules before the debate began. 在辩论开始之前他们就规则而吵了起来。
A: ♣近  altercation, controversy, disagreement, dispute, hassle, imbroglio, quarrel, spat, squabble, tiff, wrangle
A: ♣近  amity, concord, harmony, rapport, rapprochement 和睦，友好

Q:skirt  [skə:t]
A: ♠考法1  n. 界限，边界： the line or relatively narrow space that marks the outer limit of something
A: ♣例  an old shack on the skirts of the town 城镇边界上的一座老房子
A: ♣近  borderline, boundary, circumference, compass, confines, edge, frame, fringe, margin, perimeter, periphery, verge
A: ♣反  center, core, kernel 核心
A: ♠考法2  vt. 绕行，避开： to go around or keep away from in order to avoid danger or discovery
A: ♣例  skirted the construction zone 绕开建筑工地‖The new bill would make it harder for companies toskirt environmental regulations. 新的规定会增加公司逃脱环境监管的难度。
A: ♣近  bypass, circumvent, detour, shortcut, sidestep
A: ♣反  pursue, seek 追寻

Q:skittish  ['skitiʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 容易受到惊吓的，胆小的： easily frightened
A: ♣例  The kitty is skittish around people she doesn't know. 小猫看到不认识的人就会显得特别胆小害怕。
A: ♣近  fainthearted, fearful, fearsome, mousy, scary, timid, timorous, tremulous
A: ♣反  adventuresome, adventurous, audacious, bold, daring, dashing, gutsy, venturesome, venturous 大胆的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 容易激动的： easily excited by nature
A: ♣例  The skittish colt leapt up when we approached. 一看到我们靠近，小马驹就激动地猛跳起来。
A: ♣近  flighty, fluttery, hyper, hyperactive, hyperkinetic, jittery, jumpy, nervous, skittery, spasmodic, spooky
A: ♣反  imperturbable, nerveless, unexcitable, unflappable, unshakable 不为所动的，沉着的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 善变的，多变的： likely to change frequently, suddenly, or unexpectedly
A: ♣例  The skittish housing market had both buyers and sellers on edge. 变幻莫测的房市让买家和卖家都坐立不安。
A: ♣近  capricious, changeful, flickery, fluctuating, fluid, inconstant, mercurial, mutable, temperamental, uncertain, unstable, unsteady, volatile
A: ♣反  changeless, constant, immutable, invariable, settled, stable, stationary, steady, unvarying 不变的

Q:slack  [slæk]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 松弛的： not tightly fastened, tied, or stretched
A: ♣例  The rope is too slack. 绳子太松了。
A: ♣近  insecure, lax, loosened, relaxed, slackened, unsecured
A: ♣反  taut, tense, tight 拉紧的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 疏忽的，大意的： failing to give proper care and attention
A: ♣例  This building contractor is known mainly for his firm's slack workmanship and slipshod construction. 这个建筑承包商因其手下公司不负责任的粗糙做工和马虎建造的建筑物而闻名。
A: ♣近  careless, derelict, disregardful, lax, lazy, neglectful, neglecting, negligent, remiss
A: ♣反  attentive, careful, conscientious 专心的；alert, heedful, mindful, observant, regardful, vigilant, wary, watchful 警惕的

Q:slake  [sleik]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使满足： to satisfy (a craving); quench
A: ♣例  Mountain climbing has largely slaked my desire for adventure. 登山很大程度上满足了我对探险的渴望。
A: ♣近  assuage, quench, sate, satiate, satisfy
A: ♣反  tantalize, tease 诱惑，挑逗；arouse, excite, pique, stimulate 激起，唤起

Q:slant  [slɑ:nt]
A: ♠考法1  n. （看待问题、思考的）角度，看法： a way of looking at or thinking about something
A: ♣例  an interesting slant on the problem of underage drinking 在青少年饮酒这个问题上一个有趣的视角
A: ♣近  angle, outlook, perspective, standpoint, viewpoint
A: ♠考法2  adj. 倾斜的： running in a slanting direction
A: ♣例  The computer keyboard has a slightly slant surface so that typing is more comfortable for the wrists. 电脑键盘有一个微小的倾斜角，因此打字不会使手腕感到不适。
A: ♣近  canted, graded, inclined, leaning, listing, oblique, pitched, raked, slanted, sloping, tilting
A: ♣反  perpendicular, plumb, vertical 垂直的；horizontal, level 水平的
A: ♠考法3  vt. 歪曲（事实等）： to change so much as to create a wrong impression or alter the meaning of
A: ♣例  Reporters slanted the truth in order to push a political agenda. 为了推动政治进程，记者们歪曲了事实。
A: ♣近  bend, color, distort, falsify, misinterpret, misrelate, misrepresent, misstate, pervert, twist, warp
A: ♣反  clarify, clear, elucidate, illuminate, illustrate 澄清，阐明

Q:slate  [sleit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 列入名单，计划，安排： to put (someone or something) on a list
A: ♣例  You've been slated for a three o'clock interview. 你的面试被安排在三点。
A: ♣近  catalog, enroll, enter, index, inscribe, record, register, schedule
A: ♣反  delete, erase 删除，除名

Q:slew  [slu:]

Q:slight  [slait]

A: ♠考法2 adj. 轻微的： small in degree
A: ♣例  only a slight chance of success 只有很小的成功概率‖If you have even the slightest doubt, then don't do it. 只要你有一点点疑惑，那就不要去做了。
A: ♣近  fragile, frail, negligible, outside, slim, small, tiny
A: ♣反  distinct 显著的
A: ♠考法3  vt. 轻蔑，看不起： to treat with disdain or indifference
A: ♣例  Those snobbish music critics slight any style of music that doesn't fit their personal taste. 那帮自命不凡的音乐评论家看不起所有不符合他们个人口味的音乐。

A: ♣反  esteem, honor, respect, revere, venerate 尊敬
A: ♠考法4  vt. 忽略，疏忽： to fail to give proper attention to
A: ♣例  She slighted several major authors in her survey of 20th-century fiction. 她在调查20世纪幻想文学时中忽略了几个重要的作家。
A: ♣近  b

Q:slippery  ['slipəri]

A: ♣反  coarse, rough 粗糙的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 隐秘的： given to acting in secret and to concealing one's intentions
A: ♣例  a bar where a lot of slippery characters were known to hang out 一个有许多秘密人物出没的酒吧
A: ♣近  furtive, shady, shifty, sly, sneaking, stealthy

A: ♣近  ambiguous, elusive, equivocal, evasive, fugitive, obscure, unintelligible, vague
A: ♣反  apparent, clear, distinct, evident, manifest, obvious, palpable, patent, plain, unambiguous, unequivocal 明确的

Q:slipshod  ['slipʃɔd]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 粗心的，随意的： marked by carelessness or indifference to exactness, precision, and accuracy
A: ♣例  a slipshod piece of research 一项随意的研究‖The hotel had always been run in a slipshod way. 酒店总是在以一种随意的状态运营。
A: ♣近  botchy, careless, messy, slapdash, sloppy, slovenly, untidy
A: ♣反  fastidious, meticulous 极仔细的；accurate, exact, precise 准确的

Q:sloppy  ['slɔpi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 邋遢的，不整洁的： lacking neatness in dress or person
A: ♣例  a sloppy child who always seems to have spilled something on his clothes 一个外表邋遢的小孩子，他的衣服似乎总被沾上了什么东西
A: ♣近  blowsy, dowdy, frowsy, slovenly, unkempt, untidy
A: ♣反  dapper, dashing, sharp, smart, spruce 外表整洁的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 混乱的： lacking in order, neatness, and often cleanliness
A: ♣例  dumped the papers in a sloppy pile on the desk 把纸张随意地叠放在书桌上
A: ♣近  chaotic, disarranged, disarrayed, disheveled, disorderly, jumbled, littered, rumpled, tousled, tumbled
A: ♣反  bandbox, crisp, kempt, neat, orderly, organized, shipshape, snug, tidy, trim 有序的

Q:sloth  [slɔθ]

A: ♣例  Sloth is the mother of poverty. 懒惰是贫穷的原因。
A: ♣近  idleness, indolence, inertia, languor, laziness, lethargy, shiftlessness, sluggishness, torpor
A: ♣反  assiduity, diligence, industry 勤奋
A: ♣派  slothful adj. 懒惰的

Q:slouch  [slautʃ]

A: ♣例  is no slouch when it comes to cooking 做起饭来可一点也不懒
A: ♣近  deadbeat, drone, idler, loafer, slug, sluggard
A: ♣反  doer, hummer, hustler, rustler 活跃的人，精力充沛的人
A: ♠考法2  vt. 缓慢行走： to go or move slowly or reluctantly
A: ♣例  He slouched towards the church as if going to his own funeral. 他缓缓地向教堂走去，仿佛是要去参加自己的葬礼一般。
A: ♣近  creep, drag, inch, limp, nose, ooze, plod, poke, snail
A: ♣反  fly, race, speed, whiz, zip 快走

Q:slovenly  ['slʌvənli]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 邋遢的，不整洁的： lacking neatness in dress or person
A: ♣例  For the sake of their image, the band members transformed themselves from clean-cut lads to slovenly rockers. 为了他们自身的形象，乐队成员从健康向上的青年变成了邋遢的摇滚乐手。
A: ♣近  blowsy, dowdy, frowsy, sloppy, unkempt, untidy
A: ♣反  dapper, dashing, neat, sharp, smart, spruce, trim 外表整洁的

Q:sluggard  ['slʌɡəd]
A: ♠考法1  n. 懒人： an habitually lazy person
A: ♣例  The teacher tried to wake up the sluggards who were still sleeping at that late hour. 老师尝试去叫醒那些还在睡觉的懒鬼们。
A: ♣近  deadbeat, drone, idler, loafer, slouch, slug
A: ♣反  doer, hummer, hustler, rustler 活跃的人，精力充沛的人

Q:sluggish  ['slʌɡiʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 缓慢的，迟缓的： markedly slow in movement, flow, or growth
A: ♣例  The sluggish pace of the project is worrisome. 项目进展缓慢让人担忧。
A: ♣近  crawling, creeping, dallying, dilatory, dragging, lagging, languid, leisurely, snaillike, tardy, unhurried
A: ♣反  bolting, brisk, fast, fleet, hasty, lightning, meteoric, quick, racing, rapid, rocketing, speedy, swift 快速的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 迟钝的，反应慢的： slow to respond (as to stimulation or treatment)
A: ♣例  Reptiles are naturally sluggish at low temperatures. 在低温下爬行动物的生理机能自然会趋于迟缓。
A: ♣近  dull, indolent, inert, lethargic, quiescent, sleepy, torpid
A: ♣反  active, animated, bouncing, dynamic, energetic, kinetic, spirited, vigorous, vital, vivacious 有活力的

Q:slumber  ['slʌmbə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 睡着： to be in a state of sleep
A: ♣例  She slumbered for hours while the train rolled on. 她在火车行进过程中睡了四个小时。
A: ♣近  catnap, doze, nap, rest, sleep, snooze
A: ♣反  arouse, awake, waken 醒来

Q:slur  [slə:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 耻辱： a mark of guilt or disgrace
A: ♣例  Your drunken behavior at the wedding has cast a slur on this family. 你在婚礼上醉酒后的行为给整个家族都带来了耻辱。
A: ♣近  blot, brand, onus, smirch, smudge, spot, stigma, taint
A: ♣反  award, credit, glory, honor 荣誉，荣耀
A: ♠考法2  vt. 含糊地发音： to pronounce indistinctly
A: ♣例  If you slur your words, the visa officer will have a hard time following you. 如果你说话含糊不清，签证官就很难听懂你的话。
A: ♣近  mumble, murmur,mutter
A: ♣反  articulate, enunciate 清楚地表达
A: ♠考法3  v. 疏忽，忽略： to slide or slip over without due mention, consideration, or emphasis
A: ♣例  This documentary slurs over certain important facts as it offers a very biased case for a conspiracy theory. 这部纪录片忽略了许多重要的客观事实，而只给出了带有偏见的阴谋论解释。
A: ♣近  bypass, disregard, forget, ignore, overlook, overpass, slight
A: ♣反  attend, heed, mind 留心，注意

Q:sly  [slai]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 狡猾的： clever or cunning, especially in the practice of deceit.
A: ♣例  The movie pairs a sly, dissembling ex-con with an upstanding, straight-arrow cop. 电影把一个狡猾、善于骗人的出狱犯和正直、坦率的警察搭配在了一起。
A: ♣近  beguiling, cagey, crafty, cunning, designing, devious, foxy, guileful, scheming, shrewd, subtle, tricky, wily
A: ♣反  artless, guileless, ingenuous, innocent, undesigning 天真纯朴的，无伪装的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 隐秘的，偷偷的： given to acting in secret and to concealing one's intentions
A: ♣例  took a sly look at the letter on the table 偷偷地看了一眼桌上的信
A: ♣近  furtive, shady, shifty, slippery, sneaking, stealthy
A: ♣反  aboveboard 光明正大的

Q:smarmy  ['smɑ:mi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 虚情假意的，过分恭维的： hypocritically, complacently, or effusively earnest
A: ♣例  He is slightly smarmy and eager to impress. 他有点虚伪，急于给人留下印象。
A: ♣近  fulsome, oily, slick, soapy, unctuous
A: ♣反  artless, earnest, genuine, heartfelt, sincere, unaffected 真诚的，真挚的

Q:smart  [smɑ:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 反应敏捷的，聪颖的： characterized by sharp quick thought
A: ♣例  a smart child who could do well in school 一个能在学校取得良好成绩的聪明孩子
A: ♣近  alert, brainy, bright, brilliant, clever, exceptional, fast, intelligent, keen, nimble, quick, sharp
A: ♣反  airheaded, brainless, doltish, dumb, fatuous, mindless, obtuse, senseless, simple, stupid, vacuous, witless 愚钝的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 整洁的： being strikingly neat and trim in style or appearance
A: ♣例  Dressed in their smart new uniforms, the cadets proudly paraded around the grounds of the military school. 穿着整洁的制服，军校的学员们骄傲地在训练场上游行。
A: ♣近  dapper, natty, neat, sharp, snappy, spruce, trim
A: ♣反  disheveled, frowsy, sloppy, slovenly, unkempt 不整洁的
A: ♠考法3  vi. 感到疼痛，感到痛苦： to suffer acutely, as from mental distress, wounded feelings, or remorse
A: ♣例  The injection only smarted for a moment. 打针只会痛一小会儿。‖He is still smarting over criticism of his clumsy performance. 那些对他笨拙表演的批评仍然让他感到痛苦。
A: ♣近  ache, hurt, pain, suffer
A: ♣反  allay, alleviate, assuage, ease, mitigate, mollify, palliate, relieve, soothe 缓和

Q:smattering  ['smætəriŋ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 浅薄的知识： superficialor piecemeal knowledge
A: ♣例  a smattering of Greek grammar 略懂希腊语语法
A: ♣反  erudition 博学；insight 深刻的见解
A: ♠考法2  n. 少量： a small scattered number or amount
A: ♣例  Only a smattering of spectators presented. 只有少数几个观看者出席了。
A: ♣反  ace, bit,driblet, glimmer, handful, hint, mite, mouthful, nip, ounce, pittance,sprinkle, trace
A: ♣近  abundance,bundle, dozen, multiplicity, myriad, plentitude, profusion, scad, shipload, slew, volume, wealth 大量

Q:smirk  [smə:k]
A: ♠考法1  vi. （自鸣得意地）笑： to smile in an affected, often offensively self-satisfied manner
A: ♣例  She tried not to smirk when they announced the winner. 当他们宣布她获得了胜利时，她尽可能地保持不露出笑容。
A: ♣近  grin, simper
A: ♣反  cry, weep 哭泣；groan, moan, sigh 叹息

Q:smother  ['smʌðə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使窒息： to be or cause to be killed by lack of breathable air
A: ♣例  Children should never be leftin cars alone because they could become trapped and smothered. 小孩子不应该被单独留在车中，因为他们很容易因而被困并且窒息死亡。
A: ♣近  asphyxiate, choke, smother, stifle, strangle, suffocate
A: ♠考法2  vt. 抑制（表达、说出），压制： to refrain from openly showing or uttering
A: ♣例  He quickly smothered his inappropriate laughter at the funeral ceremony. 他很快就控制住了自己在葬礼上不适当的笑声。‖Management smothered the true facts of the case. 管理层隐瞒了案件的真相。
A: ♣近  bridle, check, choke, control, curb, muffle, quash, quell, repress, squelch, suppress
A: ♣反  unleash, vent （感情的）爆发，宣泄；express 表达

Q:smug  [smʌɡ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 自大的，自鸣得意的： having too high an opinion of oneself
A: ♣例  The winner was so smug that he lost the support of the crowd. 胜利者过于自大，以至于失去了群众的支持。
A: ♣近  complacent, egoistic, overweening, pompous, proud, self-satisfied, vain
A: ♣反  egoless, humble, modest 谦逊的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 整洁的，有序的： being clean and in good order
A: ♣例  The suburb's smug lawns and tree-lined streets bespeak a comfortable affluence. 郊区整齐有序的草坪和种满树木的街道，代表着其间的舒适和财富。
A: ♣近  dapper, kempt, orderly, shipshape, spruce, tidy, trim, uncluttered, well-groomed
A: ♣反  disheveled, disordered, messy, slovenly, unkempt, untidy 邋遢的，混乱的

Q:smuggling  ['smʌgliŋ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 走私，私运： secret importation or exportation contrary to the law and especially without paying duties imposed by law
A: ♣例  He was arrested for smuggling drugs into the country. 他因为向境内走私毒品而被逮捕。
A: ♣近  bootlegging, contraband

Q:snare  [snεə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 无法逃脱的困境： something that catches and holds
A: ♣例  Someday you'll find that your lies are a snare from which you can't escape. 总有一天你会发现，你所说过的谎话都会变成你无法逃脱的困境。‖caught in the snare of drug addiction 处于吸毒上瘾的困境之中
A: ♣近  entanglement, mesh, morass, net, noose, quagmire, quicksand, toil, trap
A: ♠考法2  vt. 捕捉： to capture by or as if by use of a snare
A: ♣例  They snared a rabbit earlier in the day. 今天的早些时候他们捕获了一只兔子。‖The car salesman successfully snared three potential customers. 汽车销售员成功地让三个潜在的客户上钩了。
A: ♣近  catch, enmesh, ensnare, ensnarl, entrap, tangle
A: ♣反  disentangle 解开；free, liberate 释放

Q:snarl  [snɑ:l]
A: ♠考法1 v. 纠缠，纠结： to twist together into a usually confused mass
A: ♣例  You'll be awfully sorry if you snarl your fishing line. 要是你把渔网给缠在一起，你肯定会非常后悔的。‖The new regulation has succeeded in nothing but snarling up rush-hour traffic throughout the city. 新的政策只将全城高峰时期的交通变得更为复杂难解。
A: ♣近  entangle, ensnarl, interlace, intertwine, intertwist, interweave, knot, ravel, tangle
A: ♣反  disentangle, extricate, unravel, unsnarl, untwine, untwist 解开
A: ♠考法2 vi. 咆哮，怒吼： to give vent to anger in surly language
A: ♣例  She snarled at me after I kept badgering her with questions. 在我不断用问题骚扰她之后，她终于忍不住爆发了。
A: ♣近  bark, fulminate, rant, roar, scream, shout, storm, vent
A: ♣反  calm 冷静下来

Q:sneer  [sniə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （轻蔑地）嘲笑： to speak in a scornful, contemptuous, or derisive manner
A: ♣例  They would invariably sneer every time they passed the hapless nerds. 每次经过那个不幸的书呆子身边时，他们总是会报以不变的嘲笑。
A: ♣近  deride, gibe, laugh, jeer, jibe, mock, ridicule
A: ♣反  esteem, honor, respect, revere, venerate 尊敬

Q:snobbish  ['snɔbiʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 谄上傲下的，自大的： being or characteristic of a person who has an offensive air of superiority and tends to ignore or disdain anyone regarded as inferior
A: ♣例  I expected her to be snobbish but she was warm and friendly. 我本以为她会是个自大的人，结果她非常热心和友好。
A: ♣近  aristocratic, bumptious, elitist, haughty, imperious, persnickety, pompous, presumptuous, supercilious
A: ♣反  egoless, humble, modest 谦逊的，不自大的

Q:snub  [snʌb]
A: ♠考法1  v. 轻视，不理睬： to treat with contempt or neglect
A: ♣例  The snob in town always snubbed anyone she thought was beneath her. 镇上那个自命不凡的人总是对那些她认为不如她的人不屑一顾。
A: ♣近  contemn, disdain, disrespect, slight, look down
A: ♣反  esteem, honor, respect, revere, venerate 尊敬

Q:soak  [səuk]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使…湿透： to make thoroughly wet or saturated by or as if by placing in liquid
A: ♣例  That downpour soaked my hair, and now I look like a sight. 那场大雨把我的头发淋湿了，所以我现在看起来格外滑稽。‖We ran for home as soon as the rain started, but our clothes still ended up soaked. 我们一发觉下雨就开始往家里跑，但我们的衣服还是湿透了。
A: ♣近  douse, drench, drown, impregnate, macerate, saturate, sodden, sop, souse, steep
A: ♣反  dehydrate, dry, desiccate 脱水；parch, sear, scorch 烤干，烧焦；wring 拧干

Q:sober  ['səubə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 严肃的： marked by seriousness, gravity, or solemnity of conduct or character
A: ♣例  She made a sober reply to what was only a teasing comment. 她很严肃地回复了那个恶搞的评论。‖Illness is a sober reminder of our mortality. 疾病是死亡给我们发出的严肃警告。
A: ♣近  earnest, grave, humorless, sedate, severe, sober, solemn, staid, weighty
A: ♣反  facetious, flip, flippant, humorous, jesting, jocular, joking, playful 轻佻的，幽默有趣的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 节制的： given to or marked by restraint in the satisfaction of one's appetites
A: ♣例  decided to live a sober life after bankruptcy 破产以后决定过有节制的生活
A: ♣近  abstentious, abstinent, continent, self-denying, temperate
A: ♣反  hedonistic, licentious, self-indulgent, sensual, sybaritic, voluptuary 纵欲的，享乐主义的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 有理有据的： based on sound reasoning or information
A: ♣例  a sober assessment of the situation 关于局势有理有据的分析
A: ♣近  firm, informed, justified, levelheaded, logical, rational, reasonable, sensible, solid, valid, well-founded
A: ♣反  groundless, illogical, invalid, unfounded, uninformed, unjustified, unreasonable, unsound 没有道理的

Q:sodden  ['sɔdən]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 湿透的： containing, covered with, or thoroughly penetrated by water
A: ♣例  We stripped off our sodden clothes and wrung them dry. 我们脱下湿透了的衣服并将它们拧干。
A: ♣近  awash, bathed, doused, drenched, logged, saturated, soaked, watered, waterlogged
A: ♣反  arid, dry干燥的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使…湿透： to wet thoroughly with liquid
A: ♣例  Soldiers' boots were soddened by endless hours in muddy trenches. 长时间身处泥泞的战壕使得士兵的靴子湿透了。
A: ♣近  douse, drench, drown, impregnate, macerate, saturate, soak, sop, souse, steep
A: ♣反  dehydrate, dry, desiccate 脱水；parch, sear, scorch 烤干，烧焦；wring 拧干

Q:solace  ['sɔləs]
A: ♠考法1  n. 安慰： comfort in sorrow, misfortune, or distress
A: ♣例  The kind words brought a little solace to the grieving widow. 这些同情的话语给痛苦的寡妇带来了些许安慰。
A: ♣近  consolation, relief
A: ♠考法2  vt. 安慰，安抚： to comfort, cheer, or console, as in trouble or sorrow
A: ♣例  I did their my to solace those bereaved children. 我尽力去安抚那些失去双亲的孩子们。
A: ♣近  cheer, comfort, console, soothe
A: ♣反  agonize, distress, harrow, torment, torture, trouble 使痛苦，折磨

Q:solder  ['sɔldə]
A: ♠考法1  v. 连接，联合： to join or unite
A: ♣例  Wires are soldered onto the circuit board. 电线被焊接在电路板上。‖The agreement soldered the factions into an alliance. 两个派系因这份协议而结成同盟。
A: ♣近  associate, coalesce, combine, conjoin, conjugate, connect, couple, fuse, interfuse, join, link, marry, unify
A: ♣反  disassociate, disconnect, disjoin, divide, sever, split, sunder 分开

Q:solemnity  [sə'lemnəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 严肃： the quality or condition of being solemn
A: ♣例  Solemnity is a trick of the body to hide the fault of the mind. 一本正经的态度，是肉体为了掩饰精神上的缺陷而耍的花招。‖The coronation ceremony requires absolute solemnity. 加冕典礼需要绝对的庄严肃穆。
A: ♣近  earnest, graveness, gravity, intentness, seriousness, sobriety, solemnness, staidness
A: ♣反  facetiousness, flightiness, flippancy, frivolity, frivolousness, levity, lightheartedness, play 轻挑，欢快

Q:solicitous  [sə'lisitəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 为他人操心的，体谅他人的： given to or made with heedful anticipation of the needs and happiness of others
A: ♣例  The solicitous husband had already cleaned the house and cooked dinner by the time his wife returned home from work. 这个十分体谅妻子的好丈夫在他妻子回家之前就把家里清理干净，还把晚餐都做好了。
A: ♣近  attentive, considerate, kind
A: ♣反  heedless, inconsiderate, thoughtless, unthinking 不关心的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 迫切的，渴望的： showing urgent desire or interest
A: ♣例  The family is solicitous to put this whole unfortunate affair behind them and to move on with their lives. 这个家庭迫切希望能忘记那些不幸的事情，开始崭新的生活。
A: ♣近  agog, anxious, ardent, avid, desirous, eager, enthusiastic, greedy, hungry, keen, thirsty, voracious, wild
A: ♣反  apathetic, indifferent, uneager, unenthusiastic无所谓的
A: ♣派  solicitude n. 关切，挂念

Q:solid  ['sɔlid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 固态的，坚固的： having a consistency that does not easily yield to pressure
A: ♣例  The ice cream is too solid to scoop right now. 冰淇淋现在太硬了，根本舀不动。
A: ♣近  compact, hard, rigid, stiff, unyielding
A: ♣反  flabby, soft, spongy, squashy, squishy 柔软的，容易挤压的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 有理有据的： based on sound reasoning or information
A: ♣例  the only solid conclusion that the jury could have reached 陪审团唯一可能做出的合理结论
A: ♣近  firm, informed, justified, levelheaded, logical, rational, reasonable, sensible, sober, valid, well-founded
A: ♣反  groundless, illogical, invalid, unfounded, uninformed, unjustified, unreasonable, unsound 没有道理的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 坚定的，不迟疑的： not showing weakness or uncertainty
A: ♣例  Some people see a solid handshake as a sign of strong character. 有人认为握手毫不迟疑的人有着很强势的性格。
A: ♣近  forceful, hearty, iron, lusty, robust, stout, strong, sturdy, vigorous
A: ♣反  uncertain, weak 迟疑的
A: ♣派  solidify vt. 使固化

Q:soliloquy  [sə'liləkwi]
A: ♠考法1  n. （尤指自言自语的）独白： a dramatic or literary form of discourse in which a character talks to himself or herself or reveals his or her thoughts without addressing a listener
A: ♣例  A soliloquy always reveals the character’s thoughts and feeling. 一段独白经常反映出人物的思想和感情。
A: ♣近  monologue
A: ♣反  chorus, ensemble 合唱

Q:solitude  ['sɔlitju:d]
A: ♠考法1  n. 孤独，避世： the quality or state of being alone or remote from society
A: ♣例  He sought the kind of solitude where his thoughts would be his only companions. 他在寻找一种孤独感，只有他的思想陪伴着他。‖She wished to work on her novel in solitude. 她想一个人安静地完成小说。
A: ♣近  aloneness, insulation, privacy, seclusion, segregation, separateness, sequestration, solitariness
A: ♣反  camaraderie, companionship, company, comradeship, fellowship, society 陪伴

Q:solvent  ['sɔlvənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有偿付能力的： able to pay all legal debts
A: ♣例  They're going to have to prove that the company is now solvent. 接下来他们必须要证明公司的偿贷能力。
A: ♣反  bankrupt破产的
A: ♠考法2  n. 溶剂： a substance in which another substance is dissolved, forming a solution
A: ♣例  Some organic solvents, such as benzene, pyridine, furan, are poisonous to human’s reproductive system. 一些有机溶剂（比如苯、吡啶、呋喃）对人体的生殖系统有毒性。
A: ♣反  solute 溶质

Q:somatic  [səu'mætik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 肉体的： of the body, especially as distinguished from a body part, the mind, or the environment
A: ♣例  a somatic disorder that was once thought to be “all in the patient’s head” 曾被认为“全是病人头脑中的问题”的生理机能紊乱
A: ♣近  animal, bodily, carnal, corporal, corporeal, fleshly, material, physical
A: ♣反  mental, spiritual 精神上的；nonmaterial, nonphysical 非肉体的

Q:somber  ['sɔmbə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 昏暗的，无光的： so shaded as to be dark and gloomy
A: ♣例  The prison's somber interrogation room has the desired effect of striking fear and despair into the prisoner. 牢房中阴暗的问讯间有着能让囚犯感到恐惧和绝望的效果。
A: ♣近  black, caliginous, dark, dim, gloomy, lightless, murky, obscure, pitch-dark, rayless, stygian
A: ♣反  bright, brilliant, illuminated, lit, lightsome, lucent, lucid, luminous 光亮的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 悲伤的，不愉快的： causing or marked by an atmosphere lacking in cheer
A: ♣例  Her death put us in a somber mood. 她的死让我们陷入了悲伤沮丧的情绪之中。
A: ♣近  depressing, dire, dismal, funereal, lugubrious, melancholy, miserable, morbid, morose, saturnine, sullen
A: ♣反  cheerful, delighted, festive, gay, jocund, jovial 快乐的

Q:somnolence  ['sɔmnələns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 瞌睡，嗜睡： the quality or state of desiring or needing sleep
A: ♣例  Somnolence is likely to be the most typical reaction to this novel. 读这部小说最典型的感受就是想睡觉。
A: ♣近  doziness, drowsiness
A: ♣反  insomnia, sleeplessness, wakefulness 失眠

Q:sonnet  ['sɔnit]
A: ♠考法1  n. 十四行诗： a 14-line verse form usually having one of several conventional rhyme schemes
A: ♣例  a sonnet that celebrates love 一首歌颂爱情的十四行诗
A: ♣反  doggerel 幽默不正式的诗，打油诗

Q:soothe  [su:ð]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 带来慰藉，安慰： to bring comfort, solace, or reassurance to
A: ♣例  There seemed to be no words sufficient to soothethe widow. 任何话语好像都不足以安慰这个寡妇。
A: ♣近  cheer, comfort, console, solace
A: ♣反  agonize, distress, harrow, torment, torture, trouble 使痛苦，折磨
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使镇静，使安心： to free from distress or disturbance
A: ♣例  He took her in his arms and soothed her. 他把她抱在怀中以让她镇静下来。
A: ♣近  becalm, compose, lull, lullaby, quiet, quieten, salve, settle, still, tranquilize
A: ♣反  agitate, discompose, disquiet, disturb, perturb, upset, vex 打扰，使不安
A: ♠考法3  vt. 弱化，缓解： to make more bearable or less severe
A: ♣例  Hot tea with honey will soothe a sore throat. 加了蜂蜜的热茶可以缓解喉咙的酸痛。
A: ♣近  abate, allay, alleviate, assuage, ease, mitigate, mollify, palliate, relieve, soften
A: ♣反  aggravate, exacerbate, intensify 恶化

Q:sop  [sɔp]
A: ♠考法1  n. 安慰物： something yielded to placate or soothe
A: ♣例  to provide with the salary raise as a sop 提高工资作为安慰
A: ♣近  balm, emollient, placebo,salve, unguent
A: ♣反  irritant, stimulant 刺激物
A: ♠考法2  n. 贿赂，回扣： something given or promised in order to improperly influence a person's conduct or decision
A: ♣例  As a sop to the teachers' union for supporting his reelection campaign, the mayor promised to push for the abolition of the residency requirement. 市长答应推动废除获得绿卡的限制条件，以此作为换取选举中教师联盟支持的条件。
A: ♣近  backhander, boodle, cumshaw, fix
A: ♠考法3  vt. 浸湿，湿透： to wet thoroughly
A: ♣例  My book fell in the swimming pool and was thoroughly sopped before I could fish it out. 我的书掉进了游泳池，在我把它捞出来之前已经彻底湿透了。
A: ♣近  douse, drench, drown, impregnate, macerate, saturate, soak, sodden, souse, steep
A: ♣反  dehydrate, dry, desiccate 脱水；parch, sear, scorch 烤干，烧焦；wring 拧干

Q:sophism  ['sɔfizəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 假推理，诡辩： deceptive or fallacious argumentation
A: ♣例  Political selection is more dependent on sophism and less on economic literacy. 政治选举更多的是依靠诡辩，而非简练的文笔。
A: ♣近  sophistry

Q:sophisticated  [sə'fistikeitid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 精明的，老于世故的： having acquired worldly knowledge or refinement; lacking natural simplicity or naiveté
A: ♣例  On the train I met a surprisingly sophisticated and widely traveled child. 在火车上我见到了一个老练得让人惊讶的、见多识广的孩子。
A: ♣近  cosmopolitan, debonair, knowing, smart, suave, urbane, worldly
A: ♣反  guileless, ingenuous, innocent, na?ve 天真的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 复杂的： very complex or complicated
A: ♣例  a very sophisticated machine that is a marvel of modern design 一个十分复杂的机器，是现代设计的最高成就
A: ♣近  baroque, byzantine, complicated, convoluted, elaborate, intricate, involved, knotty, labyrinthine, tangled
A: ♣反  plain, simple 简单的
A: ♣派  sophistication n. 精明；复杂

Q:soporific  [,sɔpə'rifik]
A: ♠考法1  n. 安眠药： a drug or other substance that induces sleep
A: ♣例  Alcohol is a poor hypnotic because it disturbs sleep patterns, and so can worsen sleep disorders. 酒精是一种欠佳的安眠药，因为它会干扰睡眠的固定模式，从而恶化睡眠紊乱的情况。
A: ♣近  hypnotic
A: ♣反  stimulant 兴奋剂
A: ♠考法2  adj. 催眠的： causing or tending to cause sleep
A: ♣例  This medication is soporific, so do not drive after taking it. 这种药物是催眠的，服用之后切忌开车。‖the soporific heat of summer 夏日里催人欲睡的阳光
A: ♣近  narcotic, opiate, slumberous, somniferous, somnolent
A: ♣反  arousing, waking, invigorating, stimulating 刺激性的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 慵懒的，困倦的： of, relating to, or marked by sleepiness or lethargy
A: ♣例  A big lunch always makes me soporific in the afternoon. 中午一顿大餐总是让我下午感到困倦。
A: ♣近  dozy, drowsy, sleepy
A: ♣反  awake, conscious, wakeful 清醒的；alert 警醒的；sleepless, insomniac 无法入睡的

Q:sordid  ['sɔ:did]

A: ♣例  I will not let my children grow up in such a sordid environment. 我绝不会让我的孩子在这样一个肮脏的环境之中成长。
A: ♣近  besmirched, dirty, dusty, filthy, foul, grubby, muddy, nasty, smudged, soiled, stained, sullied, unclean
A: ♣反  clean, immaculate, spotless, stainless, unsoiled, unstained, unsullied 干净的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 卑鄙的： marked by baseness or grossness
A: ♣近  Behind his generous donation were sordid motives. 在他慷慨捐资的背后有着卑鄙的动机。
A: ♣近  base, contemptible, despicable, detestable, dishonorable, execrable, ignominious, mean, vile, wretched
A: ♣反  honorable, lofty, noble, straight, upright, venerable, virtuous高尚的，值得尊敬的

Q:sound  [saund]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 牢固的，不可动摇的： marked by the ability to withstand stress without structural damage or distortion
A: ♣例  The bridge is structurally sound. 这座大桥在结构上是稳固的。
A: ♣近  bombproof, fast, firm, stalwart, strong, sturdy
A: ♣反  ramshackle 摇摇欲坠的；rickety, unstable, unsteady 不稳定的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 健康的，强壮的： free from injury or disease: exhibiting normal health
A: ♣例  The horse is getting old, but still perfectly sound. 虽然在变老，但这匹马依然相当健康。
A: ♣近  bouncing, fit, hale, healthy, hearty, robust, well, well-conditioned, wholesome
A: ♣反  ailing, diseased, ill, sick 生病的；decrepit, enfeebled, feeble, infirm 虚弱的
A: ♠考法3  adj. （逻辑上）严谨的： based on valid reasoning
A: ♣例  Sound reasoning alone should tell you that the result is invalid. 从纯粹严谨的逻辑演绎出发，这个结论是不正确的。
A: ♣近  analytic, coherent, consequent, rational, reasonable, sensible, valid, well-founded, well-grounded
A: ♣反  illegitimate, illogical, incoherent, inconsequent, invalid, irrational, unreasonable, unsound, weak （逻辑上）站不住脚的
A: ♣派  soundness n. （逻辑上的）无疵

Q:sparing  ['spεəriŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 节俭的，节约的： marked by or practicing careful restraint (as in the use of resources)
A: ♣例  The sparing couple are trying to save up enough for a house. 节俭的夫妻希望能够攒钱买套房。
A: ♣近  economical, economizing, provident, scrimping, thrifty
A: ♣反  prodigal, profligate, spendthrift, squandering, wasteful 浪费的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 不足的，缺乏的： less plentiful than what is normal, necessary, or desirable
A: ♣例  Unfortunately, the explanation of the health insurance plan was somewhat sparing on details. 不幸的是，健康保险上的说明似乎不够详细。‖The map is sparing of information. 这张地图的信息量太少了。
A: ♣近  exiguous, niggardly, poor, scant, scanty, scarce, skimp, skimpy, slender, slim, spare, sparse, stingy
A: ♣反  abundant, ample, bountiful, copious, generous, liberal, plenteous, plentiful 足量的

A: ♣反  abundant, ample, bountiful, copious, generous, liberal, plenteous, plentiful大量的，丰富的

Q:spat  [spæt]

A: ♣近  altercation, controversy, disagreement, dispute, imbroglio, quarrel, squabble, tiff, wrangle
A: ♣近  amity, concord, harmony, rapport, rapprochement 和睦，友好

A: ♠考法2  n. 大量： a large number or amount

A: ♣近  abundance,bundle, dozen, multiplicity, myriad, plentitude, profusion, scad, shipload, slew, volume, wealth
A: ♣反  ace, bit, driblet, glimmer, handful, hint, mite, mouthful, nip, ounce, pittance, sprinkle, trace 少量

A: ♣近  beguiling, deceitful, deceiving, deluding, delusive, delusory, fallacious, false, misleading

Q:spectrum  ['spektrəm]

Q:speculate  ['spekjuleit]

Q:spendthrift  ['spendθrift]
A: ♠考法1  n. 挥霍者，败家子： a person who spends improvidently or wastefully
A: ♣例  The spendthrift managed to blow all of his inheritance in a single year. 这个败家子只用了一年就把自己继承的遗产挥霍一空。
A: ♣近  fritterer, profligate, spender, squanderer, waster, wastrel
A: ♣反  economizer, penny-pincher 节约的人；hoarder, miser, niggard 吝啬鬼
A: ♠考法2  adj. 挥霍的，不节俭的： given to spending money freely or foolishly
A: ♣例  Spendthrift consumers amassed a mountain of debt on their credit cards. 那些爱挥霍财富的消费者们在他们的信用卡上累积了一大笔债务。
A: ♣近  extravagant, improvident, squandering, thriftless, unthrifty, wasteful
A: ♣反  conserving, economical, frugal, penny-pinching, provident, scrimping, skimping, thrifty 节俭的

Q:spent  [spent]

A: ♣近  beaten, bleary, done, drained, enervate, exhausted, fatigued, jaded, prostrate, tired, wearied, worn-out
A: ♣反  active, energetic, invigorated, peppy, strengthened, strong, tireless, vitalized, weariless 充满活力的

A: ♣近  gangling, gangly, lanky, spindling
A: ♣反  squat 矮胖的

Q:spiny  ['spaini]

A: ♣近  brambly, prickly, thorny

A: ♠考法2  adj. 棘手的，麻烦的： requiring exceptional skill or caution in performance or handling

A: ♣近  catchy, delicate, difficult, knotty, problematic, sensitive, sticky, ticklish, thorny, tough, troublesome
A: ♣反  easy, effortless, manageable, painless, simple, straightforward, uncomplicated, undemanding 简单的

Q:spleen  [spli:n]

A: ♣例  She vented her spleen on her boyfriend and felt much better for having done so. 在她把怒气一股脑地倾泻到她男朋友身上之后，她感觉好多了。
A: ♣近  angriness, choler, furor, fury, indignation, ire, madness, outrage, rage, wrath
A: ♣反  delight, pleasure 高兴，愉悦

A: ♣反  disassociate, disconnect, disjoin, divide, sever, split, sunder 分开

Q:splinter  ['splintə]

A: ♣例  She got a splinter from the unfinished wall. 她的手被还没有装修的墙扎了一根刺。

A: ♣反  chunk, slab 厚板
