A: ♣例  splintered the carrots into little sticks 把胡萝卜切成丝
A: ♣近  slice

Q:splutter  ['splʌtə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 急切而不清楚地说： to speak hastily and incoherently, as when confused or angry
A: ♣例  They begin to splutter and move restlessly about if they feel time is slipping away without some return. 当他们感到时间在悄悄流逝却一无所得时，他们便开始激动地说话，不安地走动。
A: ♣近  babble, drivel, gabble, gibber, jabber, sputter, stammer, stutter
A: ♣反  articulate, enunciate, pronounce 清楚地说

Q:spontaneous  [spɔn'teiniəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 自发的，不经思索的： acting or activated without apparent thought or deliberation
A: ♣例  Hugging a crying child is simply a spontaneous reaction. 去抱一个哭泣的小孩是很自然而然的反应。
A: ♣近  automatic, impulsive, instinctive, involuntary, mechanical, natural
A: ♣反  calculated, deliberate, intentional, planned, predetermined, premeditated, studied 有计划的，蓄意的

Q:spoof  [spu:f]
A: ♠考法1  n. 轻松幽默的模仿，小恶搞： a work that imitates and exaggerates another work for comic effect
A: ♣例  Many viewers thought that the spoof of a television newscast was the real thing. 许多观众认为这则新闻报道被恶搞之后的作品才是真实的东西。
A: ♣近  burlesque, caricature, mimicking, parody, travesty
A: ♠考法2  v. 诱骗，诱使相信： to cause to believe what is untrue
A: ♣例  The public was spoofed by a supposedly plausible report of a UFO encounter.一个听起来真实的UFO遭遇报告欺骗了大众。
A: ♣近  beguile, cozen, delude, dupe, fool, hoax, misguide, misinform, mislead, trick
A: ♣反  disabuse, disenchant, disillusion, undeceive 使醒悟

Q:sporadic  [spəu'rædik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 偶尔的，零星发生的： not often occurring or repeated
A: ♣例  On the whole, situation has significantly improved with only sporadic disturbances. 总体而言，局势得到了明显的改善，现在只有偶尔发生的骚乱。
A: ♣近  few, infrequent, occasional, odd, rare, scarce, seldom, uncommon
A: ♣反  frequent, habitual, repeated 时常发生的

Q:sprawl  [sprɔ:l]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 杂乱无序地发展： to grow, develop, or spread irregularly and without apparent design or plan
A: ♣例  The city sprawls down the whole coast. 城市顺着整条海岸线蔓延。
A: ♣近  ramble, scramble, straddle
A: ♣派  sprawling adj. 蔓延的，不规则伸展的

Q:sprightly  ['spraitli]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 活泼的，充满活力的： full of spirit and vitality
A: ♣例  He was deeply impressed by the sprightly Gypsy dance. 活力四射的吉普赛舞蹈给他留下了深刻印象。
A: ♣近  active, airy, animated, brisk, energetic, frisky, gay, jaunty, kinetic, mettlesome, racy, spirited, vital, vivacious
A: ♣反  dead, inactive, inanimate, lackadaisical, languid, languishing, leaden, lifeless, listless, spiritless, vapid没精神的

Q:spur  [spə:]
A: ♠考法1  n. 刺激物： something that arouses action or activity
A: ♣例  The threat of losing its only sports franchise was the spur the city council needed to finally do something about the rising crime rate. 有可能失去唯一的体育赛事举办权带来的威胁，成为了刺激市政府决定就攀升的犯罪率采取相关措施的因素。
A: ♣近  boost, catalyst, impetus, incentive, incitement, instigation, momentum, motivation, provocation, stimulus
A: ♣反  deterrent, disincentive 阻碍物
A: ♠考法2  n. 支撑物： a structure that holds up or serves as a foundation for something else
A: ♣例  a weak wall that might need a spur 一面或许需要支撑的墙
A: ♣近  brace, buttress, mount, prop, reinforcement, shore, underpinning
A: ♠考法3  vt. 刺激，激励： to incite or stimulate
A: ♣例  Appreciation spurred his ambition. 赞扬激起了他的雄心壮志。
A: ♣近  arouse, excite, exhort, goad, instigate, prod, stir, urge
A: ♣反  bridle, check, constrain, curb, deter, fetter, hamper, inhibit, manacle, shackle 制止，阻碍

Q:spurious  ['spjuəriəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 假的，伪造的： lacking authenticity or validity in essence or origin; not genuine
A: ♣例  In statistics, a spurious relationship is a mathematical relationship in which two events or variables have no direct causal connection, but it may be wrongly inferred that they do, due to either coincidence or the presence of a certain third, unseen factor. 在统计学中，“伪相关关系”是两个不存在因果关联的事件或变量，因为巧合或是不可见的第三方因素，而被误判为存在因果联系的关系。
A: ♣近  apocryphal, bogus, counterfeit, fake, forged, phony, sham
A: ♣反  authentic, bona fide, genuine, real 真实的
A: ♣派  spuriously adv. 伪造地，虚假地

Q:spurn  [spə:n]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 摈弃，拒绝： to reject with disdain or contempt
A: ♣例  spurned his recommendation 拒绝了他的推荐‖Fiercely independent, the elderly couple spurned all offers of financial help. 这对老夫妻极其独立，回绝了所有经济上援助。
A: ♣近  decline, disapprove, negative, refuse, reject, reprobate, repudiate
A: ♣反  accede, accept, agree, approve, assent, consent, embrace 同意，接受
A: ♣派  spurned adj. 被摒弃的，被拒绝的

Q:squabble  ['skwɔbl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 口角，小争吵： a noisy quarrel, usually about a trivial matter
A: ♣例  a brief squabble over what to do next 关于接下来该做什么的争吵
A: ♣近  altercation, argument, controversy, disagreement, dispute, imbroglio, quarrel, riff, spat, skirmish, wrangle
A: ♣反  harmony 和谐

Q:squalid  ['skwɔlid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 污秽的，肮脏的： dirty and wretched
A: ♣例  The migrants have been living in squalid conditions. 移民们一直居住在肮脏的条件下。
A: ♣近  black, dirty, filthy, foul, impure, nasty, slipshod, slovenly, unclean
A: ♣反  clean, immaculate, spotless, unsoiled, unsullied 干净的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 道德败坏的： morally repulsive
A: ♣例  the squalid atmosphere of intrigue and betrayal 充满了阴谋与背叛的不正之风
A: ♣近  base, despicable, ignoble, scurvy, sordid, vile, wretched
A: ♣反  moral, noble 品格高尚的

Q:squall  [skwɔ:l]
A: ♠考法1  n. （通常伴随着雨或雪的）风暴，暴风雪： a brief, sudden, violent windstorm, often accompanied by rain or snow
A: ♣例  A snow squall is expected tonight. 今晚预计有暴风雪。
A: ♣近  blizzard, hailstorm, snowstorm, tempest
A: ♠考法2  vt. 尖叫： to scream or cry loudly and harshly
A: ♣例  The baby squalled in pain. 婴儿因为疼痛而大叫。
A: ♣近  cry, howl, screech, shout, shriek, shrill, squeal, thunder, yelp, yell
A: ♣反  murmur, mutter, whisper 低声细语

Q:squander  ['skwɔndə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使分散： to cause (members of a group) to move widely apart
A: ♣例  A single blast of the shotgun squandered the herd of deer. 猎枪的一声枪响让鹿群四处逃窜。
A: ♣近  disband, dispel, disperse
A: ♣反  assemble, cluster, collect, concentrate, congregate, gather, ingather 使聚集，使集中
A: ♠考法2  vt. 浪费： to spend wastefully or extravagantly
A: ♣例  He squandered his inheritance on women and gambling. 他把他继承的遗产浪费在女人和赌博上。
A: ♣近  blow, dissipate, fritter, lavish, misspend, waste
A: ♣反  conserve, husband 节约，节俭
A: ♣派  squandering adj. 浪费的

Q:squat  [skwɔt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 又矮又胖的： being compact and broad in build and often short in stature
A: ♣例  a squat but adroit craftsman 一个又胖又矮，但是手艺灵巧的工匠
A: ♣近  chunky, dumpy, heavyset, squatty, stocky, stout, stubby, stumpy, thickset
A: ♣反  gangling, lanky 瘦高的

Q:squeamish  ['skwi:miʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 恶心的，晕船的： affected with nausea
A: ♣例  the rolling of the ship made the young sailor squeamish 摇晃的船只让年轻的水手感到恶心
A: ♣近  ill, nauseated, qualmish, queasy, queer, queerish, sick, sickish
A: ♣反  healthy, well 状态良好的

Q:squelch  [skweltʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 压制，镇压（运动）： to put a stop to (something) by the use of force
A: ♣例  The authority tried to squelch the workers’ protest. 政府试图镇压工人的游行。
A: ♣近  crush, muffle, quell, repress, squash, subdue, suppress, crack down
A: ♣反  abet, aid, assist, back, help, support, prop up 支持，帮助
A: ♠考法2  vt. 击溃，使无言以对： to put down or silence, as with a crushing retort
A: ♣例  His irritated glare squelched any other potential objectors. 他怒目而视，使得其他的反对者都不敢说话。
A: ♣近  dumb, extinguish, mute, quiet, settle, still, shut up
A: ♣反  foment, incite, instigate, provoke, stir 激发，激起
A: ♣派  squelcher n. 镇压者

Q:squint  [skwint]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 斜视，睥睨： to look or glance sideways
A: ♣例  The driver squinted as the sun hit his windshield. 阳光使得驾驶员不得不把眼睛偏向一边
A: ♣近  leer
A: ♣反  gaze, goggle 直视

Q:stabilize  ['steibilaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt./vi. 使稳定；变得稳定： to make stable, steadfast, or firm; to become stable, steadfast, or fixed
A: ♣例  a policy that intended to stabilize the situation in Iraq 一项旨在维护伊拉克局势稳定的政策‖The country's population has stabilized at 3.2 million. 这个国家的人口维持在三百二十万。
A: ♣近  ballast, poise, steady
A: ♣反  destabilize 使不稳定；overthrow, overturn, subvert 推翻，颠覆
A: ♣派  stability n. 稳定性

Q:stalwart  ['stɔ:lwət]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无所畏惧的： feeling or displaying no fear by temperament
A: ♣例  the stalwart soldiers in the army of Alexander the Great, who willingly followed him to the ends of the known world 亚历山大大帝军队中无所畏惧的士兵们，他们愿意跟随亚历山大奔赴世界的尽头
A: ♣近  bold, courageous, dauntless, fearless, gallant, intrepid, manful, stout, stouthearted, valiant, valorous
A: ♣反  cowardly, craven, fearful, gutless, nerveless, pusillanimous, spineless, spiritless, timorous 怯懦的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （体魄等）强健的： marked by outstanding strength and vigor of body, mind, or spirit
A: ♣例  a stalwart supporter of the UN 联合国的坚定支持者‖a lithe yet stalwart athlete 瘦小但结实的运动员
A: ♣近  brawny, firm, muscular, rugged, sinewy, sound, stout, strong, sturdy
A: ♣反  delicate, feeble, frail, weak, wimpy 脆弱的

Q:stamina  ['steiminə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 耐力： physical or moral strength to resist or withstand illness, fatigue, or hardship
A: ♣例  A marathon challenges a runner's stamina. 马拉松挑战参赛者的耐力。
A: ♣近  endurance, tolerance
A: ♣反  frailty 脆弱

Q:stammer  ['stæmə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 口吃，结巴： to speak with involuntary pauses or repetitions
A: ♣例  The frightened child started to stammer. 受惊吓的小孩开始结巴地说话。
A: ♣近  falter, stutter
A: ♣反  articulate 清楚地说

Q:startle  ['stɑ:tl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使吓一跳，使大吃一惊： to frighten or surprise suddenly and usually not seriously
A: ♣例  They were startled at the prohibitive price. 他们被高得离谱的价格吓到了
A: ♣近  amaze, astonish, astound, dumbfound, rock, scare, shock, stun, stupefy
A: ♣反  reassure 消除恐惧或疑虑
A: ♣派  startling adj. 惊人惊奇的

Q:stasis  ['steisis]
A: ♠考法1  n. 平衡，停滞： a condition of balance among various forces
A: ♣例  For the time being, the populations of the national park's predators and prey remain in stasis. 目前国家公园中捕食者和猎物的数量保持着一定的平衡。‖Language is a primary element of culture,and stasis in the arts is tantamount to death. (Charles Marsh) 语言是文化当中的主要元素，艺术的停滞和平衡就等同于死亡。——查理斯?马氏
A: ♣近  counterpoise, equilibration, equilibrium, equipoise, poise
A: ♣反  disequilibration, disequilibrium, imbalance, nonequilibrium, unbalance 不平衡

Q:static  ['stætik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 静态的，停滞的： characterized by a lack of movement, animation, or progression
A: ♣例  Both your pictures are of static subjects. 你的两张照片都是静物。‖a static economy 停滞不前的经济
A: ♣近  inactive, fixed, immobile, immotile, immovable, inert, stable, stagnant, stationary, still
A: ♣反  active, dynamic, lively, vibrant 充满活力的；mobile, movable 可移动的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无改变的： showing little change
A: ♣例  a static population 没有变化的人口
A: ♣近  inflexible, invariable, rigid, stiff, steadfast
A: ♣反  capricious, changeful, fluid, mercurial, temperamental, versatile, volatile 容易变化的
A: ♣派  stasis n. 静止不变

Q:stature  ['stætʃə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 高度，身高： natural height (as of a person) in an upright position
A: ♣例  a man of surprisingly great stature 拥有惊人身高的人
A: ♣近  altitude, elevation, inches
A: ♠考法2  n. 才干，水平： quality or status gained by growth, development, or achievement
A: ♣例  This club has grown in stature over the last 20 years. 二十年间这家俱乐部的水平得到了提升。
A: ♣近  merit, quality, value, virtue, worth

Q:staunch  [stɔ:ntʃ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 忠诚的，坚定的： steadfast in loyalty or principle
A: ♣例  a staunch believer in the democratic system 民主制度的坚定拥护者‖No matter what happens I will be your staunchest supporters. 不论发生什么，我都会是你最忠诚的支持者。
A: ♣近  constant, dedicated, devoted, devout, faithful, fast, loyal, pious, steadfast, steady, true, true-blue
A: ♣反  disloyal, inconstant, perfidious, recreant, traitorous, treacherous 不忠诚的；fickle 善变的

Q:steadfast  ['stedfəst]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 坚定的，忠诚的： firm in belief, determination, or adherence
A: ♣例  Her comrades remained steadfast despite brutal tortures. 尽管有残酷的折磨，她的同志们都保持了忠诚。
A: ♣近  constant, dedicated, devoted, devout, loyal, pious, staunch, steady, true-blue
A: ♣反  disloyal, perfidious, recreant, traitorous, treacherous, unfaithful 不忠的

Q:stealth  [stelθ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 秘密行动： the act or action of proceeding furtively, secretly, or imperceptibly
A: ♣例  Both sides advanced by stealth. 双方都隐秘地行军。
A: ♠考法2  adj. 秘密的： intended not to attract attention
A: ♣例  The SWAT team carried out a stealth raid on the house, which was believed to be harboring a terrorist cell. 特警们对这间被认为是恐怖分子老巢的房屋进行了秘密的突袭。
A: ♣近  backstairs, clandestine, covert, furtive, private, sneak, stealthy, surreptitious, undercover, underground
A: ♣反  open, overt, public 公开的，光明正大的
A: ♣派  stealthy adj. 秘密的，隐秘的

Q:steep  [sti:p]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 浸泡： to make thoroughly wet
A: ♣例  steep the tea for five minutes 浸泡茶叶五分钟
A: ♣近  drench, drown, impregnate, macerate, saturate, sodden, sop, souse
A: ♣反  desiccate, dry, parch, sear 烘烤，烤干；wring 拧干
A: ♠考法2  adj. 陡峭的： having an incline approaching the perpendicular
A: ♣例  a very steep rock face that is nearly impossible to climb 一面非常陡峭以至于不可能攀爬的岩石
A: ♣近  abrupt, precipitate, sheer
A: ♣反  gradual 逐渐变化的；flat 平坦的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 过分的，过高的： going beyond a normal or acceptable limit in degree or amount
A: ♣例  We would like to hire him, but his salary demands are just too steep. 我们很想雇用他，可是他对于薪水的要求实在是太高了。
A: ♣近  exorbitant, extravagant, extreme, immoderate, inordinate, insane, lavish, overdue, overweening, plethoric, stiff
A: ♣反  moderate, modest, reasonable, temperate 适度的

Q:stench  [stentʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 臭气，恶臭： a strong, foul odor
A: ♣例  We finally discovered the dead rat that was causing the stench in the living room. 我们终于发现是死老鼠带来了卧室里的恶臭。
A: ♣近  fetor, funk, malodor, reek, stink
A: ♣反  aroma, fragrance, perfume, scent 香气

Q:stentorian  [sten'tɔ:riən]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 声音洪亮的： extremely loud
A: ♣例  an tenor with a stentorian voice 拥有洪亮声音的男高音‖The professor's stentorian voice was enough to keep even the drowsiest student awake. 教授洪亮的声音足以使最困的学生保持清醒。
A: ♣近  blaring, blasting, clamorous, deafening, earsplitting, plangent, resounding, roaring, sonorous, thunderous
A: ♣反  gentle, low, soft 声音轻柔的

Q:stereotype  ['steriəutaip]
A: ♠考法1  n. 成见，老套的理念： a conventional, formulaic, and oversimplified conception, opinion, or image
A: ♣例  The noble savage was a stereotype that appealed to 18th-century intellectuals, who viewed European civilization as decadent and corrupt. “高贵的野蛮人”这一概念是为了迎合十八世纪的文人而提出的，他们将欧洲视作一支正在堕落和腐化的文明。
A: ♣近  concept, conception, generality, notion

Q:sterile  ['sterail]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 贫瘠的： not productive or effective
A: ♣例  a sterile land which used to be a forest 曾经是森林的一块贫瘠土地
A: ♣近  barren, effete, fruitless, impotent, infertile
A: ♣反  verdant （因长满植物而）青翠的；fat, fertile, fruitful 肥沃的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无菌的： free from live bacteria or other microorganisms
A: ♣例  The hospitals in the war-torn city often lack necessary drugs and sterile surgical supplies. 在这个被战争所蹂躏的城市中的医院通常缺乏必需的药物和无菌的手术用品。
A: ♣近  aseptic, germfree, hygienic
A: ♣反  insanitary, unhygienic 不卫生的；contaminated, polluted 受污染的
A: ♣派  sterilize v. 消毒，杀菌

Q:stickler  ['stiklə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 坚持细节的人，一丝不苟的人： one who insists on exactness or completeness in the observance of something
A: ♣例  a stickler for perfection 完美主义者‖a stickler for neatness 有洁癖的人
A: ♣近  disciplinarian, pedant, purist, martinet

Q:stiff  [stif]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 僵硬的，无法弯曲的： lacking in suppleness or flexibility
A: ♣例  a stiff cardboard packing box 不易弯折的硬纸板盒‖When I got out of bed this morning my back was stiff as a board. 今早起床时我的背和木板一样僵硬。
A: ♣近  immalleable, impliable, inflexible, petrified, rigid, unbending, unyielding
A: ♣反  flexible, floppy, pliable, pliant, supple, yielding 柔软的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （在社交场合）缺乏优雅的，不自在的： lacking social grace and assurance
A: ♣例  She always felt stiff and ill-at-ease whenever she was introduced to her father's friends. 只要她被介绍给父亲的朋友，她就会感到不自在和浑身不舒服。
A: ♣近  clumsy, gauche, graceless, inelegant, rustic, stilted, uncomfortable, uneasy, wooden
A: ♣反  graceful, suave, urbane 风度翩翩的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 过分的，过高的： going beyond a normal or acceptable limit in degree or amount
A: ♣例  Don't you think that's a pretty stiff fine for such a minor infraction? 你难道不觉得对于这么小的一个错误，罚款实在太高了么？
A: ♣近  exorbitant, extravagant, extreme, immoderate, inordinate, insane, lavish, overdue, overweening, plethoric, steep
A: ♣反  moderate, modest, reasonable, temperate 适度的
A: ♠考法4  adj. 艰苦的，费力的： requiring consid

Q:stifle  ['staifl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 抑制（声音、呼吸等）： to keep in or hold back
A: ♣例  to stifle free expression 限制言论自由
A: ♣近  choke, muffle, mute, repress, smother, strangle, suffocate, suppress
A: ♣反  foment, incite, instigate, provoke, stir 激发，激起
A: ♣派  stifling adj. 抑制的

Q:stigma  ['stiɡmə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 耻辱，污名： a mark of shame or discredit
A: ♣例  the stigma of cowardice 由懦弱而带来的污点‖There's a social stigma attached to receiving welfare. 伴随着社会福利有一种社会耻辱感。
A: ♣近  blemish, brand, onus, slur, smirch, smudge, spot, stain, taint
A: ♣反  award, credit, honor 荣誉；fame, glory, renown, repute 好名声

Q:stigmatize  ['stiɡmətaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使蒙上污名： to characterize or brand as disgraceful or ignominious
A: ♣例  Urban construction workers are often stigmatized by the rest of society as lazy and dirty. 城市里的建筑工人往往被社会里的其他人污蔑为是懒惰而肮脏的。
A: ♣近  abase, debase, degrade, demean, discredit, disgrace, dishonor, foul, humiliate, shame, sink, smirch
A: ♣近  aggrandize, canonize, deify, elevate, exalt 提升（名誉，声望等）

Q:stingy  ['stindʒi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 小气的，吝啬的： being unwilling or showing unwillingness to share with others
A: ♣例  too stingy to tip the waiter 小气到不肯给小费
A: ♣近  closefisted, mean, mingy, miserly, niggardly, parsimonious, penurious, sparing, stinting, tightfisted
A: ♣反  bountiful, charitable, freehanded, generous, liberal, munificent, openhanded 慷慨的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 极少量的： less plentiful than what is normal, necessary, or desirable
A: ♣例  Many people may consider this a rather stingy amount of food. 很多人都会认为这是分量比较少的食物。
A: ♣近  exiguous, poor, scant, scanty, scarce, skimpy, sparse
A: ♣反  abundant, ample, bounteous, copious, plenteous, plentiful 大量的
A: ♣派  stinginess n. 小气

Q:stint  [stint]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 吝惜，节省： to be sparing or frugal
A: ♣例  They never stint with their praise. 他们从不吝啬他们的赞美之词。
A: ♣近  scrimp, skimp
A: ♣近  blow, dissipate, fritter, lavish, misspend, squander, waste 浪费

Q:stipple  ['stipl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 点刻，用点标记： to mark with small spots especially unevenly
A: ♣例  They crossed a field stippled with purple lavender. 他们穿越了一片有紫色薰衣草点缀的田野。
A: ♣近  blotch, dapple, dot, freckle, marble, mottle, speckle, splotch, sprinkle, spot

Q:stipulate  ['stipjuleit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 规定，特定要求： to specify or arrange in an agreement
A: ♣例  Total disarmament was stipulated in the peace treaty. 和平协约中要求彻底解除武装。
A: ♣近  claim, designate, detail, particularize, qualify
A: ♣反  relinquish, surrender, yield, waive 放弃（权力等）
A: ♣派  stipulation n. 规范，要求

Q:stitch  [stitʃ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 突然剧痛： a sharp unpleasant sensation usually felt in some specific part of the body
A: ♣例  He had to drop out of the race when the stitch in his side became too painful. 因为他突然感到剧痛，所以不得不放弃比赛。
A: ♣近  ache, pang, prick, shoot, smart, sting, throe, tingle, twinge
A: ♣反  comfort, ease, easiness 舒适的感觉

Q:stock  [stɔk]
A: ♠考法1  n. 库存，储备： the inventory of goods of a merchant or manufacturer
A: ♣例  This type of product is currently out of stock. 这种商品已经脱销。
A: ♣近  inventory, pool, repertoire, reserve, reservoir
A: ♠考法2  adj. 普通的，常备的： commonly used or brought forward
A: ♣例  the stock answers to sensitive questions 对于敏感问题的常备回答
A: ♣近  common, conventional, general, ordinary, prosaic, routine, standard, universal
A: ♣反  unique 独特的

Q:stockade  [stɔ'keid]
A: ♠考法1  n. 栅栏，围栏： an enclosure or pen made with posts and stakes
A: ♣例  a heavy stockade that protected the troops 保护驻扎部队的厚厚的栅栏
A: ♣近  barricade, barrier, blockade, fence, wall
A: ♠考法2  n. 监狱： a place of confinement for persons held in lawful custody
A: ♣例  All POWs were kept in a remote stockade. 所有的战俘都被关在一个遥远的监狱里。
A: ♣近  bastille, coop, jail, pen, prison

Q:stodgy  ['stɔdʒi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 平庸的，乏味的： dull, unimaginative, and commonplace
A: ♣例  The sitcom was offbeat and interesting in its first season, but has since become predictable and stodgy. 这部情景喜剧在第一季是离奇而有趣的，但是近来变得老套和乏味。
A: ♣近  arid, dreary, dull, flat, jading, jejune, monochromatic, monotonous, pedestrian, stale, tedious, wearisome
A: ♣反  absorbing, engaging, engrossing, gripping, interesting, intriguing, involving, riveting 吸引人的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 非常守旧的： extremely old-fashioned
A: ♣例  Without notice she received a letter from his stodgy father. 她毫无征兆地收到了一封来自她保守父亲的信。
A: ♣近  conservative, hidebound, intolerant
A: ♣反  avant-guard 先锋派的；radical 激进的
A: ♣派  stodginess n. 乏味，无趣

Q:stoic  ['stəuik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 隐忍的，冷静的： seemingly indifferent to or unaffected by pleasure or pain
A: ♣例  stoic resignation in the face of hunger 默默忍受着饥饿
A: ♣近  aloof, apathetic, detached, forbearing, indifferent, impassive, phlegmatic, stolid, tolerant, unemotional
A: ♣反  demonstrative, emotional, fervent, fervid, impassioned, passionate, vehement 充满热情的

Q:stoke  [stəuk]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 添加燃料： supply with fuel
A: ♣例  She was stoking the furnace. 她正用给火炉添木头。
A: ♣近  fuel, rekindle
A: ♠考法2  vt. 增大，促进： to make greater in size, amount, or number
A: ♣例  stoke workers’ commitment to the company by raising their salaries 通过加薪来提升员工对公司的忠诚度
A: ♣近  aggrandize, amplify, augment, boost, enlarge, escalate, expand, extend, multiply, raise
A: ♣反  abate, decrease, diminish, downsize, dwindle, lessen, lower, minify, reduce, subtract 减少

Q:stolid  ['stɔlid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 无动于衷的，感情麻木的： having or revealing little emotion or sensibility
A: ♣例  Her face showed nothing but stolid indifference. 她的脸上只露出了麻木和冷漠。
A: ♣近  apathetic, catatonic, deadpan, emotionless, impassive, indifferent, numb, phlegmatic, stoic
A: ♣反  demonstrative, emotional, fervent, fervid, impassioned, passionate, vehement 充满热情的
A: ♣派  stolidity n. 麻木，无动于衷

Q:stomach  ['stʌmək]
A: ♠考法1  v. 容忍： to bear without overt reaction or resentment
A: ♣例  I can't stomach his bragging. 我受不了他自吹自擂了。
A: ♣近  abide, brook, countenance, endure, handle, stand, tolerate
A: ♣反  decline, refuse, reject, repudiate, spurn 拒绝

Q:stonewall  [,stəun'wɔ:l]
A: ♠考法1  v. 拒绝（合作），阻挠： to be uncooperative, obstructive, or evasive
A: ♣例  lobbying efforts to stonewall passage of the legislation 意在阻止法律通过的游说行动
A: ♣近  blockade, filibuster, hinder, impede, obstruct
A: ♣反  collaborate, cooperate 合作

Q:stouthearted  ['staut'hɑ:tid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 勇敢的： having a stout heart or spirit
A: ♣例  a stouthearted army officer who risked his life to save his men 为了拯救部下宁愿牺牲自己的勇敢军官
A: ♣近  bold, brave, courageous, dauntless, fearless, gallant, intrepid, stalwart, stout, valiant, valorous
A: ♣反  cowardly, craven, fearful, gutless, nerveless, pusillanimous, spineless, spiritless, timorous 怯懦的

Q:strait  [streit]
A: ♠考法1  n. 海峡： a narrow channel joining two larger bodies of water
A: ♣例  Thousands of vessels pass through the straits annually. 每年数以千计的货轮要通过这个海峡。
A: ♣近  channel, narrow, neck
A: ♣反  isthmus 地峡
A: ♠考法2  n. 痛苦： a state of great suffering of body or mind
A: ♣例  in dire straits over the loss of her mother’s cherished necklace 因为丢失了母亲最珍贵的项链而陷入了极端的痛苦之中
A: ♣近  affliction, agony, anguish, excruciation, misery, pain, torment, torture, travail, tribulation, woe

Q:strand  [strænd]

A: ♣例  a strand of DNA DNA中的一条链
A: ♣近  thread
A: ♠考法2  v. 遗弃，使置于困境： to leave in a strange or an unfavorable place especially without funds or means to depart
A: ♣例  The convoy was stranded in the desert. 车队被困在了沙漠之中。
A: ♣近  abandon, desert, forsake, maroon, quit
A: ♣反  evacuate, reclaim, rescue 救出

Q:stratify  ['strætifai]

A: ♣近  assort, categorize, classify, differentiate, distinguish, separate
A: ♣反  homogenize 使均匀；commingle, mingle 混合
A: ♣派  stratification n. 分层化

Q:stray  [strei]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 漫无目的的： lacking a definite plan, purpose, or pattern
A: ♣例  No stray sighting of UFO’s has been rigorously analyzed by scientists. 在无规律出现的UFO事件之中，尚未有被科学家严谨分析的案例。
A: ♣近  aimless, arbitrary, desultory, erratic, haphazard, scattered, slapdash
A: ♣反  methodical, orderly, organized, regular 有条理的，有组织的；systematic, systematized 系统性的
A: ♠考法2  vi. 离群，迷途，偏离： to move away from a group, deviate from the correct course, or go beyond established limits
A: ♣例  to stray from the main road 偏离了主干道
A: ♣近  deviate, digress, err, wander

Q:strength  [streŋθ]

A: ♣近  energy, force, might, potency, power, puissance, sinew, vigor
A: ♣反  impotence, impotency, powerlessness, weakness 无力
A: ♠考法2  n. （抵抗攻击、压力的）强度： the ability to withstand force or stress without being distorted, dislodged, or damaged
A: ♣例  This cheap shelve unit doesn't have the strength to hold all those books. 这个廉价的书架不足以支撑所有的书本。
A: ♣近  firmness, soundness, sturdiness
A: ♣反  insecurity, instability, precariousness, shakiness, unstableness, unsteadiness 不稳固
A: ♣派  strengthen vt. 增强

A: ♣例  The inner surface of the bark is smooth, of a pale, yellowish brown and very finely striated. 树皮的内部十分光滑，显着偏暗偏黄的棕色，并且有着十分精细的条纹。
A: ♣近  furrow, streak, stripe
A: ♣派  striated adj. 有条纹的

Q:strike  [straik]

A: ♣近  aggression, assault, charge, offense, onset, onslaught, raid, rush
A: ♠考法2  vt. 铸造（奖牌）： to form by stamping, printing, or punching
A: ♣近  build, fabricate, forge, form, make, mold, shape
A: ♠考法3  vt. 击打： to aim and usually deliver a blow, stroke, or thrust (as with the hand, a weapon, or a tool)
A: ♣例  angrily stuck the security guard 愤怒地殴打保安
A: ♣近  bat, beat, hammer, hit, knock, nail, punch, swat
A: ♠考法4  vt. 袭击，攻击： to take sudden, violent action against
A: ♣例  A rattlesnake strikes its prey with lightning speed. 响尾蛇以惊人的速度攻击了它的猎物。
A: ♣近  assail, beset, storm, set on
A: ♠考法5  vt. 撞击： to come into usually forceful contact with something
A: ♣例  One bullet-train struck the other one which had been forced to stop on a viaduct due to lightning strike, resulting in huge casualties. 一辆动车撞向了另一辆因雷击而停在高架桥上的动车，造成了巨大的人员伤亡。
A: ♣近  bang, bash, bump, collide, crash, impact, impinge, ram, slam, smash, swipe, t

Q:subdue  [səb'dju:]

Q:subject  ['sʌbdʒikt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 臣民，受支配的人： one that is placed under authority or control
A: ♣例  Because of the tense situation in that country, British subjects were advised to return home as soon as possible. 因为该国紧张的局势，英国公民被建议尽快返回英国国内。
A: ♣近  citizen, national
A: ♣反  alien 外来人；potentate 统治者
A: ♠考法2  adj. 取决于其他因素的： contingent on or under the influence of some later action
A: ♣例  The price of seafood is subject to weather conditions. 海鲜的价格受天气影响。
A: ♣近  affected, conditional, contingent, dependent, reliant, subordinate
A: ♣反  independent, unconditional 独立的

Q:subjugate  ['sʌbdʒəɡeit]

A: ♣反  discharge, emancipate, enfranchise, liberate, manumit, release, unfetter 解放，释放
A: ♣派  subjugation n. 征服

Q:sublime  [sə'blaim]

A: ♣例  the sublime virtue of having given all one's worldly goods to the poor 将所有财产都捐给穷人的崇高美德
A: ♣近  chivalrous, elevated, gallant, greathearted, lofty, magnanimous, noble
A: ♣反  base, debased, degenerate, degraded, ignoble, low 可鄙的
A: ♠考法2  adj. （因为杰出、装光、美丽等而）令人惊叹的： tending to inspire awe usually because of elevated quality (as of beauty, nobility, or grandeur) or transcendent excellence
A: ♣例  the sublime beauty of the canyon 峡谷令人惊叹的美丽
A: ♣近  amazing, astonishing, astounding, awesome, fabulous, miraculous, portentous, prodigious, staggering, stunning, stupendous, wonderful
A: ♣反  common, ordinary 平常的，普通的
A: ♣派  sublimity n. 庄严，壮观

A: ♣反  apparent, clear, evident, manifest, obvious, patent 明显的

Q:submissive  [səb'misiv]

A: ♣反  contumacious, defiant, intractable, obstreperous, rebellious, recalcitrant, refractory, unruly 不顺从的
A: ♣派  submission n. 服从，顺从

Q:subordinate  [sə'bɔ:dinət]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 下级的，次要的： belonging to a lower or inferior class or rank
A: ♣例  His contention is that environment plays a subordinate role to heredity in determining what we become. 他的观点就是：在决定我们成长的因素——环境和遗传之中，前者处于更次要的地位。
A: ♣近  inferior, junior, lower, minor, secondary, subject, tributary
A: ♣反  greater, higher, major, primary, prime, senior, superior 更优等的，更高等的
A: ♠考法2  vt. 征服： to bring under one's control by force of arms
A: ♣例  It is one of the lessons of history that more powerful civilizations often subordinate weaker ones. 强大的文明往往征服弱势的文明，这是历史的教训之一。
A: ♣近  conquer, dominate, overpower, pacify, subdue, subject, subjugate, vanquish
A: ♣反  capitulate, surrender 投降；lose 失败

Q:subservient  [səb:sə:viənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 奉承的，屈从的： obsequiously submissive
A: ♣近  amenable, biddable, compliant, conformable, docile, obeisant, obsequious, servile, submissive, tractable
A: ♣反  contumacious, defiant, intractable, obstreperous, rebellious, recalcitrant, refractory, unruly 不顺从的
A: ♣派  subservience n. 服从

Q:subside  [səb'said]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 下陷，下沉，减弱： to tend downward
A: ♣例  Local officials say the flood waters have subsided. 当地官员表示洪水已经退去。‖As the noise of the siren subsided, I was able to fall back to sleep. 随着警笛声的减弱，我可以再次睡着了。‖The pain will subside in a couple of hours. 几个小时之内疼痛感就会退去的。
A: ♣近  abate, decline, decrease, diminish, drop, dwindle, ebb, fall, lessen, moderate, recede, wane
A: ♣反  balloon, burgeon, escalate, expand, grow, increase, intensify, rise, snowball, soar, wax 上升，增大
A: ♣派  subsidence n. 下沉

Q:subsidiary  [səb'sidiəri]

A: ♣例  The river has several subsidiary streams. 这条河拥有数条支流。
A: ♣近  minor, secondary, subordinate, tributary
A: ♣反  capital, cardinal, central, chief, key, leading, main, paramount, predominant, primary, principal, supreme 主要的，重要的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 起辅助作用的： furnishing aid or support
A: ♣例  Attached are subsidiary materials. 附件当中的是辅助资料。
A: ♣近  accessory, auxiliary, contributory, supplemental, supporting, upholding

Q:subsidy  ['sʌbsidi]
A: ♠考法1  n. 补助金，津贴： monetary assistance granted by a government to a person or group in support of an enterprise regarded as being in the public interest
A: ♣例  a subsidy to manufacturers during the war 战争期间对制造商的补贴金
A: ♣近  allotment, allowance, appropriation, grant, subvention
A: ♣派  subsidize vt. 提供补助

Q:substantial  [səb'stænʃəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 物质的： of, relating to, or having substance
A: ♣例  a world of dreams, even less substantial than a rainbow 一个梦想中的世界，甚至比彩虹还虚无缥缈
A: ♣近  corporeal, concrete, gross, material, objective, physical, tangible
A: ♣反  tenuous, vaporous 空洞的，空幻的；diaphanous, ethereal, immaterial 非物质的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 有重大意义的： considerable in importance, value, degree, amount, or extent
A: ♣例  made a substantial progress 取得了实质性的进展
A: ♣近  consequential, considerable, earthshaking, important, meaningful, momentous, significant, weighty
A: ♣反  inconsequential, inconsiderable, insignificant, little, minor, negligible, slight, trifling, trivial 微不足道的

Q:substantiate  [səb'stænʃieit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 证实： to support with proof or evidence
A: ♣例  There is little scientific evidence to substantiate the claims. 现在还缺乏足够的科学证据来证实这种言论。
A: ♣近  attest, authenticate, confirm, corroborate, justify, validate, verify
A: ♣反  controvert, disprove, rebut, refute 反驳
A: ♣派  substantiated adj. 经证实的
A: ♠考法2  vt 使实体化： to give material form to
A: ♣例  The artist's intense feelings are substantiated by his paintings' bold colors and broad brush strokes. 画家强烈的情感通过他画作中鲜艳的色彩和很宽的笔画体现出来。
A: ♣近  embody, epitomize, externalize, incarnate, incorporate, manifest, materialize, personalize
A: ♣反  disembody 使脱离肉体
A: ♣派  substantiated adj. 已证实的

Q:substantive  ['sʌbstəntiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 本质的，关键的： of or relating to the essence or substance
A: ♣例  The substantive information is their political stance. 关键的信息是他们的政治立场。
A: ♣近  constitutional, elemental, essential, fundamental, substantial, vital
A: ♣反  inconsequential, inconsiderable, insignificant, insubstantial, negligible, nominal 不重要的

Q:substitute  ['sʌbstitju:t]
A: ♠考法1  n. 取代者，替代品： a person or thing that takes the place or function of another
A: ♣例  If you like, you can use nuts as a substitute for coconut in that recipe. 如果您不反对，我们可以将菜单里的椰子换成坚果。
A: ♣近  backup, cover, fill-in, relief, replacement, reserve, stand-in, surrogate
A: ♠考法2  vt. 取代，替代： to take the place of
A: ♣例  substituting moral power for physical force 将暴力用道德的力量代替‖BFR molecules have some atoms substituted by bromide atoms, which makes it fire-resistant. 在溴化阻燃剂的分子中，一部分原子被溴原子取代，从而使它不易燃烧。
A: ♣近  displace, relieve, replace, supersede, supplant, cut out
A: ♣派  substitution n. 取代

Q:subterfuge  ['sʌbtəfju:dʒ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 狡计： deception by artifice or stratagem in order to conceal, escape, or evade
A: ♣例  The spy obtained the documents by subterfuge. 间谍通过狡猾的计谋获得了文件。
A: ♣近  artifice, cheat, chicanery, deception, fraud, trickery, wile

Q:subtle  ['sʌtl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 微妙的，难以感知的： (so slight as to be)difficult to understand or perceive
A: ♣例  subtle differences in meaning between the words 单词词义之间的细微差别
A: ♣近  delicate, elusive, evasive, faint, fine, impalpable, intangible, nice, slight
A: ♣反  blatant, conspicuous, obvious, patent, plain 明显的； open, public 公开的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 巧妙的，间接或带有欺骗性的： clever at attaining one's ends by indirect and often deceptive means
A: ♣例  used subtle methods of persuasion 采用了十分巧妙的劝说方式
A: ♣近  beguiling, crafty, cunning, cute, designing, devious, foxy, guileful, scheming, shrewd, sly, tricky, wily
A: ♣反  artless, guileless, ingenuous, innocent, undesigning 天真纯朴的，无伪装的
A: ♣派  subtlety n. 微妙；微妙的想法

Q:subvert  [səb'və:t]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 颠覆： to overturn or overthrow from the foundation
A: ♣例  an alleged plot to subvert the state 一个谣传的旨在推翻政权的阴谋
A: ♣近  overthrow, overturn, topple
A: ♣反  reinforce 加强
A: ♣派  subversion n. 颠覆

Q:succinct  [sək'siŋkt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 简明的，简洁的： characterized by clear, precise expression in few words
A: ♣例  His speech is always succinct and perspicacious. 他的发言总是简洁而一针见血。
A: ♣近  apothegmatic, brief, compact, compendious, concise, laconic, pithy, summary, telegraphic, terse
A: ♣反  circuitous, circumlocutory, diffuse, long-, prolix, rambling, verbose, windy, wordy 冗长的
A: ♣派  succinctness n. 简洁，扼要

Q:succor  ['sʌkə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 救援，援助： to go to the aid of
A: ♣例  We see it as our duty to succor anyone in need. 我们视帮助他人为自己的职责
A: ♣近  aid, assist, help, relieve, support

Q:succumb  [sə'kʌm]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 屈服： to yield to superior strength or force or overpowering appeal or desire
A: ♣例  refused to succumb to her fears and defiantly walked through the dark cemetery 拒绝向自己的恐惧屈服，而是倔强地走过了幽暗的墓地
A: ♣近  bow, capitulate, concede, submit, surrender, give in
A: ♣反  resist 抵抗
A: ♠考法2  vi. 死亡： to be brought to an end (as death) by the effect of destructive or disruptive forces
A: ♣例  The patient lay so still and pale that everyone thought he had succumbed, and then he opened his eyes. 面色惨白的病人静静地躺在床上，正当所有人都怀疑他已经过逝时，他突然睁开了眼睛。‖The doctor worked tirelessly until finally he, too, succumbed to the plague. 医生不知劳累地工作，直至最后，他也死于瘟疫。
A: ♣近  decease, demise, expire, perish, pass away
A: ♣反  endure, stand 忍受住；breathe, live, survive 存活

Q:suffocate  ['sʌfəkeit]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使窒息： to deprive of oxygen
A: ♣例  The law requires the owner of a discarded refrigerator to remove its door so that a child won't get trapped inside and suffocate. 法律要求废弃冰箱的所有者移除箱门，从而防止儿童被困其中而窒息致死。
A: ♣近  asphyxiate, choke, smother, stifle, strangle
A: ♣派  suffocating adj. 令人窒息的，压抑的

Q:suffuse  [sə'fju:z]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （色彩等）弥漫，染遍，充满： to spread through or over, as with liquid, color, or light
A: ♣例  a room suffused with warm sunlight 一个充满温暖阳光的房间
A: ♣近  flush, fill, imbue, infuse, interpenetrate, percolate, pervade, transfuse
A: ♣派  suffusing adj. 弥漫的

Q:sulk  [sʌlk]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 生气，愠怒： to be sullenly aloof or withdrawn, as in silent resentment or protest
A: ♣例  He would sulk for hours whenever he didn’t get what he want. 当他的愿望没被满足时，他会生几个小时的闷气
A: ♣近  frown, grump, mope, pout
A: ♣反  crow, delight, exuberate, jubilate, rejoice, triumph 感到高兴，雀跃
A: ♣派  sulky adj. 生气的，不悦的

Q:sullen  ['sʌlən]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 闷闷不乐的： causing or marked by an atmosphere lacking in cheer
A: ♣例  She remained sullen amid festivities alone. 她独自一人在喜庆的气氛中闷闷不乐。‖sullen skies that matched our mood on the day of the funeral 葬礼当天与我们很搭调的沉闷天气
A: ♣近  bleak, cheerless, dark, depressing, dire, gloomy, glum, gray, lugubrious, morose, saturnine, sulky, surly
A: ♣反  bright, cheerful, cheering, cordial, festive, gay 欢快的
A: ♣反  lighthearted 高兴的

Q:summary  ['sʌməri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 摘要： an abstract, abridgment, or compendium especially of a preceding discourse
A: ♣例  Many book reports choose to begin with a summary of the book. 许多书评以该书的摘要开始。
A: ♣近  abstract, brief, epitome, outline, recapitulation, synopsis, summarization
A: ♣反  elaboration 详细解释
A: ♠考法2  adj. 就地的，立即的： done or executed on the spot and without formality
A: ♣例  a summary trial and speedy execution 就地的判决和快速的处决
A: ♣近  drumhead
A: ♣反  prolonged, protracted 拖延的

Q:summit  ['sʌmit]
A: ♠考法1  n. 顶点： the highest point
A: ♣例  the summit of his ambition 他雄心壮志的顶点
A: ♣近  acme, apex, climax, crescendo, crest, crown, culmination, meridian, peak, pinnacle, top, zenith
A: ♣反  bottom, nadir 最低点

Q:summon  ['sʌmən]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 召集，召唤： to call together
A: ♣例  The general summoned all his troops before the operation. 行动之前，将军把所有的部队召集到了一起。
A: ♣近  assemble, convene, convoke, muster, rally
A: ♣反  dismiss 解散
A: ♠考法2  vt. 传唤（出庭、出席）： to command by service of a summons, especially to appear in court
A: ♣例  was summoned to answer charges 他被传唤出庭应对起诉
A: ♣近  call, hail

Q:sumptuous  ['sʌmptjuəs]

A: ♣例  The hotel claims to offer sumptuous furnishings and exquisitely prepared cuisine. 酒店宣称有奢华的装潢和精心准备的食物。
A: ♣近  deluxe, lavish, lush, luxurious, opulent, palatial, resplendent, splendid, superb
A: ♣反  ascetic, austere, humble, spartan简朴的

Q:sunder  ['sʌndə]

A: ♣例  a city sundered by racial conflict 一个因种族冲突而分裂的城市
A: ♣近  disassociate, disconnect, disjoin, disunite, divide, part, rend, rive, separate, sever, unyoke
A: ♣反  bond, connect, join, link, unify, unite, yoke 连接，结合
A: ♣派  asunder adv. 分开地，分裂地

Q:supercilious  [,sju:pə'siliəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 高傲的，傲慢的： feeling or showing haughty disdain
A: ♣例  The aristocrat reacted to their breach of etiquette with a supercilious smile. 贵族对破坏他们破坏礼节的行为报以傲慢的一笑。
A: ♣近  arrogant, assumptive, bumptious, haughty, imperious, pompous, presumptuous, overbearing, superior
A: ♣反  humble, moderate, modest 谦逊的

Q:superficial  [,sju:pə'fiʃəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 表面的，肤浅的： lacking in depth, solidity, and comprehensiveness
A: ♣例  The official’s superficial report on the situation provoked wide blame on the Internet. 官员对于情况敷衍般的描述激起了网络上的广泛谴责。
A: ♣近  cursory, facile, perfunctory, shallow, sketchy, skin-deep
A: ♣反  profound 深刻的；comprehensive, exhaustive 全面的
A: ♣派  superficiality n. 表面现象

Q:superfluous  [sju'pə:fluəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 多余的，过剩的： exceeding what is sufficient or necessary
A: ♣例  a complicated algorithm that could filter all superfluous information 一个能滤除所有的多余信息的复杂算法
A: ♣近  excessive, extra, redundant, surplus
A: ♣反  deficient, inadequate, insufficient, scanty, scarce, short, skimpy, sparse 不足的
A: ♣派  superfluity n. 多余，过剩

Q:superimpose  [,sju:pərim'pəuz]
A: ♠考法1  v. 添声加色，使形象、某因素或性质更加清楚：to add as a distinct feature, element, or quality:
A: ♣例  superimposed her own interpretation when she retold the story 她重复故事的时候，加入了自己的解释

Q:supersede  [,sju:pə'si:d]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 取代，替代： to displace in favor of another
A: ♣例  That edition of the dictionary that you have has been superseded by a more recent one. 你买的那一版的字典已经被最近新出的版本取代了。
A: ♣近  displace, relieve, replace, substitute, supplant, cut out

Q:supine  [sju:'pain]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 懒散的，懒得动的、倦怠的、消极的或漠不关心的： showing lethargy, passivity, or blameworthy indifference
A: ♣例  a supine legislature that is afraid to take action 害怕采取行动的不作为的立法机关
A: ♣近  inert， passive， dormant， torpid
A: ♣反  vigilant 警惕的

Q:supplant  [sə'plɑ:nt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 排挤，篡夺…的位置： to usurp the place of, especially through intrigue or underhanded tactics
A: ♣例  Old traditions were fading away and being supplanted by modern ways. 老传统逐渐式微，被现代方式取代。
A: ♣近  displace, displant, substitute, supersede, cut out

Q:supple  ['sʌpl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 易弯曲的，柔软的： readily bent; pliant
A: ♣例  supple limbs 柔软的四肢 || a supple mind 灵活的头脑
A: ♣近  bendy, flexible, limber, lissome, lithe, pliable, pliant, lithesome
A: ♣反  inflexible, stiff, rigid 坚硬
A: ♣派  suppleness n.柔软

Q:supplement  ['sʌplimənt]
A: ♠考法1  n./v.增补，补充： something that serves to complete or make up for a deficiency in something else
A: ♣例  recommends taking a vitamin C supplement to prevent colds 建议补充维生素C来预防感冒
A: ♣近  addendum, addition, expansion, increment, proliferation, step-up

Q:supplicate  ['sʌplikeit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 恳求，乞求： to make a request to (someone) in an earnest or urgent manner
A: ♣例  God is not just someone to be supplicated in times of trouble. 我们不应该只在困难时候才向主祷告。
A: ♣近  beseech, conjure, entreat, impetrate, implore, solicit, plead to, appeal to
A: ♣反  demand 强求

Q:supposition  [,sʌpə'ziʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 猜想，推测： an opinion or judgment based on little or no evidence
A: ♣例  It's pure supposition on your part that there's something illegal going on next door. 你说隔壁在进行非法勾当纯属猜测。
A: ♣近  hypothesis, proposition, surmise,premise, presumption
A: ♣反  certainty 确定

Q:suppress  [sə'pres]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 抑制（表情）： to inhibit the expression of (an impulse, for example); check
A: ♣例  suppress a smile 忍住笑容
A: ♣近  repress, smother, stifle, choke back, hold back
A: ♣反  stimulate 激励
A: ♠考法2  v. 用暴力终止，镇压： to put a stop to (something) by the use of force
A: ♣例  Nothing could suppress the rising tide of protest. 暴力也难以控制越来越激烈的游行示威活动。
A: ♣近  clamp down on, crack down on, put down, quash, repress, silence, slap down, snuff out, squash, squelch, subdue

Q:surcharge  [sə:'tʃɑ:dʒ]
A: ♠考法1  v./n. 过高收费： to charge (someone) too much for goods or services
A: ♣例  The airline has added a $30 fuel surcharge on all international flights. 该航空公司对所有国际航线上涨了30美元的燃油税。
A: ♣近  gouge, soak, sting

Q:surfeit  ['sə:fit]
A: ♠考法1  v./n. 过量，饮食过度： to feed or supply to excess
A: ♣例  He surfeited himself with chocolate. 他巧克力吃多了
A: ♣近  overabundance, overage, overflow, plethora, redundancy, superfluity, surplus
A: ♣反  deficiency, deprivation, insufficient supply, famish, starve 短缺，匮乏

Q:surly  ['sə:li]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 脾气不好的： irritably sullen and churlish in mood or manner
A: ♣例  The surly receptionist told us we would have to wait outside in the rain. 态度粗暴的服务员说我们必须在外面等——哪怕是在下雨。
A: ♣近  acid, bearish, bilious, cantankerous, disagreeable, dyspeptic, ill-humored, ill-natured, ornery, splenetic
A: ♣反  amiable, good-humored, good-natured, good-tempered 性格好的

Q:surmise  ['sə:maiz]
A: ♠考法1  n. （根据不足的）推测，揣测： a thought or idea based on scanty evidence
A: ♣例  My surmise is that the couple’s “good news” is the announcement that they are going to have a baby. 我猜那对夫妻说的“好消息”就是他们要有小孩了。
A: ♣近  guess, hypothesis, shot, supposition, theory
A: ♣反  fact 事实
A: ♠考法2  vt. 推测： to form a notion of from scanty evidence
A: ♣例  From his tone I surmised that he was unhappy. 从他的语气中我猜测他并不高兴。
A: ♣近  assume, conjecture, daresay, imagine, infer, presume, speculate, suppose, suspect
A: ♣反  demonstrate, prove, substantiate, validate 证明

Q:surmount  [sə:'maunt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 战胜，获得胜利： to achieve a victory over
A: ♣例  an Olympic swimmer who surmounted endless obstacles to achieve her goals 一个克服重重困难最终实现目标的奥运游泳运动员
A: ♣近  conquer, defeat, overbear, overcome, overmatch, prevail, subdue, triumph, win
A: ♣反  lose 失败

Q:surpass  [sə'pɑ:s]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 超越，强于： to become better, greater, or stronger than
A: ♣例  She always tried to surpass her older brother at anything he did, which results in his diffidence. 她在任何一个方面都要比她哥哥优秀，由此导致了他自信心的匮乏。
A: ♣近  beat, better, eclipse, exceed, excel, outclass, outmatch, outshine, outstrip, overtop, transcend
A: ♣反  fall behind 落后
A: ♠考法2  vt. 突破（界限，纪录等）： to go beyond the limit of
A: ♣例  The sales of the band's newest CD have surpassed the combined sales of its last two albums. 乐队新专辑的发售量甚至超过了前两张销售量的总和。
A: ♣近  break, outreach, outrun, overpass, overreach, overrun, overstep

Q:surrender  [sə'rendə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 交出，放弃，投降： to give (something) over to the control or possession of another usually under duress
A: ♣例  surrender a contractual right 放弃契约上规定的一项权利
A: ♣近  abnegate, cede, relinquish, renounce, resign
A: ♣反  appropriate 挪用，占为己有
A: ♠考法2  v. 沉溺于： to give (oneself) over to something especially unrestrainedly
A: ♣例  surrendered himself to grief 沉湎于悲伤
A: ♣近  deliver, give up, indulge, yield

Q:surreptitious  [,sʌrəp'tiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 偷偷摸摸的，保密的： undertaken or done so as to escape being observed or known by others
A: ♣例  took a surreptitious glance at her knees 偷偷瞟了一下她的膝盖
A: ♣近  backstairs, clandestine, covert, furtive, privy, underground, underhanded, behind-the-scenes
A: ♣反  barefaced, aboveboard, open, overt, public 光明正大的

Q:surrogate  ['sʌrəɡeit]
A: ♠考法1  n. 替代品： one that takes the place of another
A: ♣例  For some people, Google Earth is never a justified surrogate for actual travel. 对于一部分人而言，谷歌地球决不是旅行的合理替代品。
A: ♣近  backup, cover, fill-in, relief, replacement, reserve, stand-in, substitute

Q:surveillance  [sə:'veiləns]
A: ♠考法1  n. 监视，监控： close observation of a person or group, especially one under suspicion
A: ♣例  government surveillance of suspected terrorists 政府对于恐怖分子嫌疑人的监控
A: ♣近  oversight, supervision, watch

Q:susceptibility  [sə,septə'biləti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 易受感染的性质或状态： the quality or state of having little resistance to some outside agent
A: ♣例  A weak immune system causes increased susceptibility to disease. 弱的免疫系统会增大患病的概率。
A: ♣近  defenselessness, vulnerability, weakness
A: ♣反  immunity, invulnerability 免疫

Q:suspend  [sə'spend]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 暂停，中止： to bring to a formal close for a period of time
A: ♣例  suspended the trial 暂停审判
A: ♣近  prorogue, recess
A: ♣反  invoke 实行
A: ♠考法2  vt. 悬挂： hang
A: ♣例  suspended a banner proclaiming the town's “Heritage Days” from the archway 在拱门上方悬挂了一条庆祝“遗产日”的条幅
A: ♣反  erect, let fall 使直立，落下

Q:suture  ['su:tʃə]
A: ♠考法1  n./v. 缝合： the process of joining two surfaces or edges together along a line by or as if by sewing
A: ♣例  The doctor cleaned, sutured, and bandaged the wound. 医生将伤口清洗、缝合、包扎。
A: ♣反  incision, avulse 切开，撕脱

Q:svelte  [svelt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （女人）体态苗条的，优雅的： slender or graceful in figure or outline; slim.
A: ♣例  The svelte dancer seemed to float across the stage. 苗条的舞者看起来就像在舞台上漂浮。
A: ♣近  bony, lean, skinny, slender, slim
A: ♣反  plump, corpulent, paunchy and awkward 丰满的，大腹便便而笨拙的

Q:swagger  ['swæɡə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 大摇大摆地走，趾高气昂地走： to conduct oneself in an arrogant or superciliously pompous manner
A: ♣例  The young man confidently swaggered across the room. 年轻人高傲地在房间里走来走去。
A: ♣近  prance, sashay, stalk
A: ♠考法2  v. 自夸，吹嘘： boast, brag
A: ♣例  I would swagger if I'd won first place in the bowling tournament. 如果我赢了保龄球锦标赛我肯定会自夸。
A: ♣近  brag, vapor, vaunt, gasconade

Q:swear  [swεə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 咒骂： to use profane or obscene language: curse
A: ♣例  no one is allowed to swear in this house 这个房间里禁止说脏话
A: ♣近  blaspheme, curse, cuss
A: ♣反  accolade 赞美
A: ♠考法2  v. 宣誓： to promise or pledge with a solemn oath; vow
A: ♣例  He swore his oath of allegiance to the queen. 他宣誓效忠女王
A: ♣近  attest, depose, covenant, pledge, vow

Q:sweltering  ['sweltəriŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 酷热的： oppressively hot
A: ♣例  The air conditioning was broken, and it was sweltering in the room. 空调坏了，房间里酷热难耐。
A: ♣近  boiling, scorching, searing, sultry, torrid, fiery
A: ♣反  algid, arctic, bone-chilling, freezing, frigid, frozen, glacial, ice-cold, iced, icy 严寒的

Q:swerve  [swə:v]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 突然改变方向： to turn aside abruptly from a straight line or course
A: ♣例  The car swerved sharply to avoid the squirrel in the road. 为了避开路中的松鼠，汽车猛地转向。
A: ♣近  detour, deviate, diverge, sheer, swing, veer
A: ♣反  maintain direction, straighten 保持方向，直行

Q:swill  [swil]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 痛饮，大口地吃： to drink greedily, to eat greedily or to excess
A: ♣例  Considering the way she swills carbonated drinks, she ought to own stock in Pepsi company. 鉴于她对碳酸饮料消费的贡献，百事公司应该给她分点股份。
A: ♣近  gulp, quaff, swig
A: ♣反  sip 啜饮

Q:swindle  ['swindl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 欺骗，骗取： to cheat or defraud of money or property
A: ♣例  Hundreds of people were swindled out of their savings 几百人都被骗去了存款。
A: ♣近  bilk, con, hustle, fiddle, gyp, bunco, flimflam

Q:sybarite  ['sibərait]
A: ♠考法1  n. 沉于奢侈逸乐者，酒色之徒： a person devoted to pleasure and luxury; a voluptuary
A: ♣例  The prince was remembered as a self-indulgent sybarite. 王子酒色之徒的名声远扬。
A: ♣近  debauchee, decadent, hedonist, sensualist
A: ♣反  spartan, ascetic 禁欲者

Q:sycophant  ['sikəfənt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 马屁精： a servile self-seeking flatterer
A: ♣例  When her career was riding high, the self-deluded actress often mistook sycophants for true friends. 当她的事业如日中天之时，该演员总是把一些马屁精误以为是真朋友。
A: ♣近  fawner, flunky , lickspittle, toady, apple-polisher, bootlicker, brownnoser

Q:syllabus  ['siləbəs]
A: ♠考法1  n. 提纲，摘要：课文、演讲或研究课题的要点的概要或提纲： an outline or a summary of the main points of a text, lecture, or course of study
A: ♣例  Have you got next year’s syllabus? 你拿到明年的教学大纲了吗？

Q:syllogism  ['silədʒizəm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 由一般到个别的推理；演绎： reasoning from the general to the specific; deduction
A: ♣例  The syllogism was at the core of traditional deductive reasoning, where facts are determined by combining existing statements, in contrast to inductive reasoning where facts are determined by repeated observations. 从一般到个别的推理是传统演绎推理的核心由结合现存状态所确定，而归纳推理则由重复观测来确认。
A: ♣派  syllogize v. 用三段论论证

Q:symbiosis  [,simbi'əusis]
A: ♠考法1  n. 共生关系： the living together in more or less intimate association or close union of two dissimilar
A: ♣例  The bird lives in symbiosis with the hippopotamus. 这种鸟和河马是共生关系。
A: ♣反  unrelated growth 无关联的生长

Q:symmetry  ['simitri]
A: ♠考法1  n. 对称： balanced proportions
A: ♣例  The building has perfect symmetry. 这栋房子是完美的对称构造。
A: ♣近  balance, coherence, consonance, proportion
A: ♣反  disproportion, asymmetry, discordance, disproportion, disunity, imbalance, incoherence, violence 不均衡，混乱

Q:synchronous  ['siŋkrənəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj 同时期的，同相的： having identical period and phase
A: ♣例  The synchronous arrival of a baby sister and loss of a beloved grandmother strongly affected the girl. 妹妹的出生和奶奶的去世同时发生，给小姑娘造成了巨大的影响
A: ♣近  coetaneous, coeval, coexistent, concurrent, contemporaneous, simultaneous
A: ♣反  occurring at different times, noncontemporaneous, out-of-phase 发生在不同时代的

Q:synergic  [si'nə:dʒik]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 合作的： working together: cooperating
A: ♣例  synergic muscles 协同肌肉
A: ♣反  antagonistic 敌对的

Q:synonymous  [si'nɔniməs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 同义的： having the same or a similar meaning
A: ♣例  Paris has always been synonymous with elegance, luxury and style. 巴黎在人们心中就是优雅、奢侈、时尚的同义词。

Q:synopsis  [si'nɔpsis]
A: ♠考法1  n. 摘要，概要： a brief outline or general view; an abstract or a summary.
A: ♣例  Just give me a synopsis of the movie. 把电影的大致情节给我说说就行。
A: ♣近  abstract, brief, digest, recapitulation, roundup, summarization, epitome

Q:synthesis  ['sinθisis]
A: ♠考法1  n. 合成，综合： the combination of parts or elements so as to form a whole
A: ♣例  a philosophy that is a kind of synthesis of several schools of Western and Eastern thought 哲学史东西方很多流派思想的综合
A: ♣近  admixture, alloy, amalgamation, compound, conflation, fusion, meld
A: ♣反  analysis, take apart 分解

Q:tacit  ['tæsit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 暗示的： implied or indicated (as by an act or by silence) but not actually expressed
A: ♣例  tacit consent 默许
A: ♣近  implied, unexpressed, unspoken, unvoiced, wordless
A: ♣反  explicit, express, expressed, spoken, stated, voiced 明确的表达，直率的

Q:taciturn  ['tæsitə:n]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 沉默寡言的，话少的： temperamentally disinclined to talk
A: ♣例  A taciturn man never initiates a conversation. 一个寡言的男人从不主动和人说话。
A: ♣近  laconic, reserved, reticent, tight-lipped, uncommunicative
A: ♣反  garrulous, loquacious, glib, expansive, prolix, voluble 多话的

Q:tackle  ['tækl]
A: ♠考法1  v. 着手处理： to start work on energetically
A: ♣例  Once I clean the kitchen, I think I'll tackle the bathroom. 等我把厨房收拾干净了，就去收拾浴室。
A: ♣近  dive into, wade in

Q:tact  [tækt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 机敏，精明，不冒犯： a keen sense of what to do or say in order to maintain good relations with others or avoid offense
A: ♣例  She talked to her neighbor with supreme tact. 她和邻居说话语调十分圆滑。
A: ♣近  diplomacy
A: ♣反  clumsiness, insensitivity, tactlessness 笨拙

Q:tactile  ['tæktail]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有触觉的，能触知的： perceptible by touch: tangible
A: ♣例  The thick brushstrokes give the painting a tactile quality. 粘稠的笔触给了这幅画一种厚实的感觉。

Q:tactless  ['tæktlis]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不机智的，笨拙的： bluntly inconsiderate or indiscreet.
A: ♣例  tactless comments 不明智的评论
A: ♣近  graceless, ill-advised, imprudent, indelicate, injudicious, undiplomatic
A: ♣反  advisable, discreet, judicious, prudent, tactful, wise 小心谨慎的，明智的

Q:taint  [teint]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （品质）污损： to affect slightly with something morally bad or undesirable
A: ♣例  A tendency toward conceitedness taints that athlete's status as a role model. 该运动员自负的倾向玷污了其行为模范的地位。
A: ♣近  blemish, darken, mar, spoil, tarnish, vitiate
A: ♣派  tainted 污损的
A: ♣反  pristine, unspoiled, wholesome, unadulterated 纯洁的，健全的

Q:talisman  ['tælizmən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 护身符： something worn or kept to bring good luck or keep away evil
A: ♣例  A pendant of white nephrite jade is often worn by Indians as a talisman to ward off heart disease. 印度人通常戴一串软玉项链防止心脏病发作。
A: ♣近  amulet, fetish, mascot, mojo, periapt, phylactery

Q:tame  [teim]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 被驯化的： reduced from a state of native wildness especially so as to be tractable and useful to humans
A: ♣例  Every evening, a wild Canada goose is at the food trough with our tame geese. 每天傍晚的食槽边总会出现一只野生加拿大鹅和我们的饲养家鹅一起进食。
A: ♣近  domestic, domesticated, tamed
A: ♣反  feral, savage, undomesticated, untamed, wild 野生的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无聊的，乏味的： lacking spirit, zest, interest, or the capacity to excite
A: ♣例  That action movie was so tame I fell asleep about 20 minutes into it. 那部动作片实在是太无聊了，我刚开场二十分钟就睡着了。
A: ♣近  arid, drab, dreary, drudging, humdrum, insipid, jading, jejune, monochromatic, monotonous, pedestrian, ponderous, stale, stodgy, tedious, tiresome, wearisome
A: ♣反  absorbing, engaging, engrossing, gripping, interesting, intriguing, involving, riveting 令人感兴趣的
A: ♠考法3  vt. 控制，抑制： to keep from exceeding a desirable degree or level (as of expression)
A: ♣例  Try to tame your language when you are in front of the kids. 在孩子面前注意一下你的措辞。
A: ♣近  bridle, check, constrain, contain, curb, govern, hold, inhibit, keep, measure, regulate, rein, res

Q:tamper  ['tæmpə]

A: ♣例  tamper with tradition 坏了规矩
A: ♣近  diddle with, fiddle with, fool with, mess with
A: ♠考法2  v. 玩弄： to tinker with rashly or foolishly
A: ♣例  Don't tamper with my feelings. 不要玩弄我的感情。

Q:tangent  ['tændʒənt]

A: ♣例  tangent remarks 不相关的评论
A: ♣近  excursive, digressive
A: ♣反  essential 重要的

Q:tangible  ['tændʒəbl]

A: ♣近  palpable, touchable
A: ♣反  impalpable, intangible, unable to perceive 无法感知的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 确凿的， 真实的： possible to be treated as fact; real or concrete
A: ♣例  tangible evidence 确凿的证据

Q:tangle  ['tæŋɡl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 困惑，不解： a state of perplexity or complete bewilderment
A: ♣例  My mind has been in a tangle ever since I learned some information about an old, deceased acquaintance. 自从我获知一些关于已故的老熟人的消息之后我就陷入了困惑之中。
A: ♣近  bafflement, befuddlement, bemusement, bewilderment, confusedness, distraction, muddle, mystification, perplexity, puzzlement, whirl
A: ♣反  assurance, certainty, certitude, confidence, conviction, sureness 确信
A: ♠考法2  vt. 纠缠，使…纠结： to seize and hold in or as if in a snare
A: ♣例  was at last tangled in the web of lies that he had told to everyone 最终被自己所编织的谎言缠住了
A: ♣近  enmesh, ensnare, ensnarl, entrap, mesh, net, snare, trap
A: ♣反  disentangle 解开

Q:tangy  ['tæŋi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 刺激的： having a powerfully stimulating odor or flavor
A: ♣例  a tangy sauce with a strong aftertaste 味道很刺激的酱料，回味无穷
A: ♣近  pungent, strong
A: ♣反  bland, mild, smooth不刺激的

Q:tantalize  ['tæntəlaiz]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 激起，挑逗： to excite (another) by exposing something desirable while keeping it out of reach
A: ♣例  He was tantalized by the possibility of earning a lot of money quickly. 有人用迅速致富挑逗他。
A: ♣反  comfort, console, solace, alleviate, assuage, relieve, satiate 安慰，缓和

Q:tantamount  ['tæntəmaunt]

A: ♣例  a relationship tantamount to marriage 到了谈婚论嫁地步的关系
A: ♣反  incommensurate 不相称的

Q:tantrum  ['tæntrəm]

A: ♣例  had a tantrum 大发脾气
A: ♣近  blowup, explosion, fit
A: ♣反  pacification 平静

Q:taper  ['teipə]

A: ♣例  taper to a point 逐渐变成为一点
A: ♣近  abate, decline, diminish, dwindle, shrink, wane, drain away
A: ♠考法2  v. 逐渐减少，减弱： to diminish or lessen gradually
A: ♣例  The storm finally tapered off. 风暴逐渐平静了。
A: ♣近  subside, die down, phase down, fall away, let up

Q:tardy  ['tɑ:di]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 缓慢的，迟缓的： moving slowly: sluggish
A: ♣例  He was tardy to work. 他做事拖拖拉拉。
A: ♣近  crawling, creeping, dallying, dawdling, dilatory, dragging, lagging, languid, sluggish
A: ♣反  bolting, brisk, fleet, flying, meteoric, rocketing, scooting, scudding, scurrying, swift, whirling 迅速的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 延后的，迟的： delayed beyond the expected or proper time
A: ♣例  a tardy arrival 迟到
A: ♣近  behind, belated, delinquent, overdue
A: ♣反  early, inopportune, precocious, premature, unseasonable, untimely 提早的

Q:tarnish  ['tɑ:niʃ]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 玷污： to affect slightly with something morally bad or undesirable
A: ♣例  an arrest for shoplifting tarnished her reputation 因在商店行窃被捕玷污了她的声望
A: ♣近  blemish, mar, stain, vitiate

Q:tasty  ['teisti]

A: ♣例  the tasty prospect of getting his revenge 报仇成功的诱人前景
A: ♣近  agreeable, delectable, delightful, satisfying, savory
A: ♣反  uninteresting, disagreeable, unpalatable, unpleasant, unwelcome 无趣的，令人失望的

Q:tatty  ['tæti]

A: ♣例  a tatty shirt 破旧的衬衣
A: ♣近  dilapidated, scruffy, seedy, sleazy, tatterdemalion, tatty, threadbare
A: ♣反  smart 漂亮的

Q:taunt  [tɔ:nt]

A: ♣例  The boys continually taunted each other. 男孩子们互相挑衅。
A: ♣近  bait, hassle, haze, heckle, needle, ride

Q:taut  [tɔ:t]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 紧绷的： not loose or flabby
A: ♣例  taut muscles 紧实的肌肉
A: ♣反  lax, loose, slack 松弛的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 整洁的： kept in proper order or condition, kept in trim shape; neat and tidy
A: ♣例  a taunt ship 保养得不错的船
A: ♣近  kempt, orderly, shipshape, trim

Q:tawdry  ['tɔ:dri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 俗丽的： cheap and gaudy in appearance or quality; ignoble
A: ♣例  a tawdry attempt to smear his opponent 企图污蔑对手的下三滥的手段
A: ♣近  meretricious, gaudy, flashy, garish
A: ♣反  exquisite 高雅的

Q:taxing  ['tæksiŋ]

A: ♣例  The journey proved to be very taxing. 旅途很艰辛。
A: ♣近  arduous, burdensome, exacting, grueling, laborious, onerous, toilsome
A: ♣反  light, easy 轻快的

Q:tedious  ['ti:diəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 冗长乏味的： tiresome because of length or dullness: boring
A: ♣例  a tedious public ceremony 冗长无聊的公开仪式
A: ♣近  drab, dreary, jading, monotonous, stale, stodgy, stuffy, weary, drudging
A: ♣反  entertaining, absorbing, stimulating, engaging, engrossing, gripping, interesting, intriguing, involving, riveting 令人愉快的，吸引人的

Q:teeming  ['ti:miŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 大量的： possessing or covered with great numbers or amounts of something specified
A: ♣例  oceans teeming with life 孕育着无穷生命的海洋
A: ♣近  abundant, ample, awash, cornucopian, flush, fraught, lousy, replete, swarming, thick, thronging
A: ♣反  bare, barren, blank, devoid, empty, stark, vacant, void 贫瘠的，空无一物的

Q:teeter  ['ti:tə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 蹒跚，不稳定的行走： to move unsteadily: wobble
A: ♣例  She teetered down the street in her high heels. 她穿着高跟鞋，在街上摇摇欲坠。
A: ♣近  careen, dodder, lurch, reel
A: ♣反  stabilize 使…稳固
A: ♠考法2  v. 犹豫不决： to show uncertainty about the right course of action
A: ♣例  was teetering on the brink of making a decision about college
A: ♣近  balance, dither, falter, hang back, scruple, shilly-shally, stagger, vacillate, waver, wobble
A: ♣反  dive in, plunge in

Q:teetotalism  [ti:'təutəlizəm]

A: ♣反  intemperance 饮酒过度

Q:telling  ['teliŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有效的，显著的： effective, expressive
A: ♣例  the most telling evidence 最有力的证据
A: ♣近  compelling, conclusive, convincing, forceful, persuasive, satisfying
A: ♣反  inconclusive, indecisive, ineffective, uncompelling, unconvincing, unpersuasive 无效的

Q:temerity  [ti'merəti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 鲁莽，冒失： foolhardy disregard of danger; recklessness
A: ♣例  She was punished for his temerity. 她因冒失迟到了苦头。
A: ♣近  audacity, brashness, presumption, presumptuousness
A: ♣反  circumspection, cautious approach, pusillanimity 谨慎

Q:temperate  ['tempərit]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 言行举止有分寸的： avoiding extremes in behavior or expression
A: ♣例  rather temperate in his appraisal of the movie, calling it good but not great 对于电影的赞赏很适度，说其“还好”而不是“很棒”
A: ♣反  immoderate, extreme, frivolous 极端的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 有节制的： given to or marked by restraint in the satisfaction of one's appetites
A: ♣例  a soft-spoken, serious-minded person of temperate habits 一个说话温和、认真严肃的人，兴趣爱好都很适度
A: ♣近  abstentious, abstinent, continent, self-abnegating, self-denying, sober
A: ♣反  self-indulgent 放纵的

Q:tempestuous  [tem'pestjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 突然且剧烈的变化： marked by sudden or violent disturbance
A: ♣例  In terms of social change, the 1960s are generally considered the most tempestuous decade in recent American history. 就社会变革来说，20世纪60年代是近现代美国历史上最动荡的十年。
A: ♣近  cataclysmal, tumultuous, turbulent
A: ♣反  serene 平静的

Q:temporal  ['tempərəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 世俗的，尘世的： of or relating to earthly life
A: ♣例  The master told his disciples not to worry about temporal concerns, but instead focus on spiritual matters. 大师要弟子们不要为尘世间的纷争而苦恼，而是将精神集中于灵魂上的思考。
A: ♣近  carnal, earthborn, earthbound, fleshly, material, mundane, secular, sublunary, terrene, terrestrial, worldly
A: ♣反  heavenly, unearthly, unworldly 非尘世间的；spiritual 精神上的；religious 宗教的

Q:temporize  ['tempəraiz]
A: ♠考法1  v. 行动躲躲闪闪以争取时间、躲避争论等： to act evasively in order to gain time, avoid argument, or postpone a decision
A: ♣例  “Colonial officials . . . ordered to enforce unpopular enactments, tended to temporize, to find excuses for evasion”(J.H. Parry) “被命令来执行不受欢迎法案的殖民地官员们倾向于敷衍了事，去寻找逃避的理由”(J.H.帕里)

Q:tenable  ['tenəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有据可依的，无懈可击的： capable of being held or defended; reasonable
A: ♣例  a tenable theory 一个站得住脚的理论 || a tenable outpost 一个守得住的前哨
A: ♣近  defendable, justifiable, maintainable, supportable, sustainable
A: ♣反  unjustified, unsound, specious, indefensible, fallacious 不合理的

Q:tenacious  [ti'neiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 顽固的，不屈不挠的： persistent in maintaining something valued or habitual
A: ♣例  a tenacious advocate of civil rights 公民权的坚定捍卫者
A: ♣近  dogged, insistent, persevering, pertinacious
A: ♣反  negotiable, vacillated 可商量的，踌躇的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 粘着的： tending to adhere to objects upon contact
A: ♣例  You'll have enough time getting those tenacious gum off of your wool sweater. 你有足够的时候去把羊毛毛衣上面那块粘着的泡泡糖弄下来。
A: ♣近  adherent, adhesive, clingy, glutinous, tacky, viscid
A: ♣反  nonadhesive 不具有粘性的

Q:tendentious  [ten'denʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有偏见的： marked by a tendency in favor of a particular point of view: biased
A: ♣例  He made some extremely tendentious remarks. 他有些评论颇具偏向性。
A: ♣近  partial, distorting, subjective, biased
A: ♣反  unbiased, unprejudiced 公平的

Q:tender  ['tendə]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 正式提出： to offer formally
A: ♣例  tender a letter of resignation 正式提交辞职信
A: ♣近  extend, proffer, trot out
A: ♣反  withdraw 撤回
A: ♠考法2  adj. 考虑周到的，关心同情的： having or marked by sympathy and consideration for others
A: ♣例  an especially tender teacher who loves having kids with special educational needs in her class 特别无微不至的老师，爱着那些需要特别教育的孩子们
A: ♣近  beneficent, benevolent, benignant, compassionate, softhearted
A: ♣反  atrocious, barbarous, bestial, brutal, callous, cruel, fiendish, inhuman, insensate, sadistic, savage, truculent, uncompassionate, vicious 尖酸刻薄的

Q:tentative  ['tentətiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 暂时性的，尝试的： not fully worked out or developed
A: ♣例  Our plans are only tentative at this point and will depend on whether you can come. 我们的计划只是暂时性的，具体还要看你能否前来。
A: ♣近  ad interim, impermanent, interim, provisional, provisionary, provisory, short-term, temporary, trial
A: ♣反  final 最终的；ceaseless, endless, eternal, immortal, permanent, perpetual, undying 永久性的

Q:tenuous  ['tenjuəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 没有实际内容的： having little substance; flimsy
A: ♣例  a tenuous argument 站不住脚的论点
A: ♣反  substantial 实质的

Q:tepid  ['tepid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不太热心的： showing little or no interest or enthusiasm
A: ♣例  a tepid response 冷漠的回应 || the tepid conservatism of the fifties 五十年代那种温和的保守主义
A: ♣近  lukewarm, halfhearted, uneager, unenthusiastic
A: ♣反  ardent, ebullient, feverish, keen, passionate, wholehearted 热心的

Q:terminology  [,tə:mi'nɔlədʒi]

A: ♣例  the terminology favored by sportscasters 体育节目转播员喜欢用的那些术语 || medical terminology that can be hard for the patient to understand 那些病人们难以理解的医学术语
A: ♣近  argot, cant, dialect, jargon, jive, lingo, patois, patter, slang

Q:terminus  ['tə:minəs]

A: ♣反  outset, sustain 开始，持续

Q:terror  ['terə]

A: ♣例  Many civilians fled in terror. 很多黎民百姓极度恐慌逃难去了。
A: ♣近  anxiety, dread, fearfulness, fright, horror, panic, trepidation

Q:terse  [tə:s]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 简洁的，简明的： brief and to the point; effectively concise
A: ♣例  dismissed me with a terse “no” 用一个简单的“不”把我打发了
A: ♣近  compact, compendious, laconic, pithy, succinct
A: ♣反  circuitous, circumlocutory, diffuse, long-winded, prolix, rambling, verbose, windy, wordy 冗长啰嗦的

Q:testimony  ['testiməni]

A: ♣近  attestation, confirmation, documentation, substantiation, testament, validation
A: ♣反  disproof 反驳

Q:testy  ['testi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 易怒的，暴躁的： easily annoyed: irritable
A: ♣例  That coworker would be easier to get along with if she weren't so testy all the time. 如果那个同伴不是一直那么暴怒的话，她还是挺好相处的。
A: ♣近  choleric, irascible, peevish, perverse, pettish, petulant
A: ♣反  affable, good humor, unable to irritate, imperturbable, patient 和蔼可亲的，冷静的，忍耐的

Q:tether  ['teðə]

A: ♣例  They tethered the horses in the shade. 他们把马摔在棚子里
A: ♣反  detach, tear loose 分开，撕裂
A: ♠考法2  n. 能力或忍耐力的极限： the limit of one's strength or resources
A: ♣例  drought-stricken farmers at the end of their tether 受干旱打击的农民忍无可忍

Q:theatrical  [θi'ætrikəl]

A: ♣例  assumed a theatrical pose 摆出夸张的姿势
A: ♣近  dramatic, histrionic, melodramatic, stagy
A: ♣反  natural, understated, reserved, restraint 自然的

Q:therapeutic  [,θerə'pju:tik]

A: ♣近  curative, healing, officinal, remedial, restorative

Q:thick-skinned  ['θikskind]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 冷漠无情的，不顾及他人感受的： largely unaffected by the needs and feelings of other people
A: ♣例  She was so thick-skinned that she was clueless about the fact that the joke had hurt her friend's feelings. 她很少顾及他人的感受，以至于她根本没有意识到那个玩笑伤害了她朋友的感情。
A: ♣近  affectless, callous, cold-blooded, heartless, indurate, inhumane, insensitive, merciless, obdurate, ruthless
A: ♣反  charitable, compassionate, humane, kindhearted, merciful, sympathetic, tender, warmhearted 慈善的

Q:thorny  ['θɔ:ni]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 多刺的： full of thorns
A: ♣例  Stay out of the thorny brambles unless you want a ton of scratches. 离那些荆棘丛远一点，除非你想满身都是窟窿。
A: ♣反  smooth 平滑的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 棘手的： full of difficulties or controversial points : ticklish
A: ♣例  a thorny problem 棘手的问题
A: ♣近  catchy, delicate, knotty, prickly, ticklish

Q:threadbare  ['θredbεə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 陈腐的： overused to the point of being worn out; hackneyed
A: ♣例  a novel filled with nothing but threadbare clichés 一部满是陈词滥调的小说
A: ♣近  banal, cliché, commonplace, hackney, shopworn, trite
A: ♠考法2  adj. 贫穷的： lacking money or material possessions
A: ♣例  never knew that she had so many threadbare relatives until she won the lottery 赢了彩票之后才知道她有这么多穷亲戚
A: ♣近  beggared, destitute, down-and-out, famished, impecunious, impoverished, indigent, necessitous, needful, pauperized, penniless, penurious, poverty-stricken, skint
A: ♣反  affluent, deep-pocketed, flush, opulent, silk-stocking, wealthy, well-heeled, well-off, well-to-do 富裕的
A: ♠考法3  adj. 破烂的： worn or torn into or as if into rags
A: ♣例  I loved that threadbare shirt, but after 10 years of wear, it was time to throw it away. 我很喜欢那件旧旧的衬衣，但是已经穿了10年了，是该扔了。
A: ♣近  frayed, raggedy, ratty, seedy, shabby, tattered, worn-out

Q:thrill  [θril]

A: ♣近  bang, boot, exhilaration, frisson, jollies, kick, rush, titillation, wallop
A: ♠考法2  vt. 使兴奋，使激动： a pleasurably intense stimulation of the feelings
A: ♣例  I was thrilled to hear that you got the promotion that you’d been so desperately wanting. 听到你终于获得了梦寐已久的升迁，我感到非常激动。
A: ♣近  arouse, charge, electrify, excite, exhilarate, galvanize, intoxicate, provoke, stimulate, titillate, pump up
A: ♣反  bore, jade, pall, tire, weary 使厌倦
A: ♣派  thrilling adj. 刺激的；thriller n. 恐怖电影

Q:throng  [θrɔŋ]

A: ♣反  imperturbable 镇静的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 棘手的，对技巧要求高的： requiring exceptional skill or caution in performance or handling
A: ♣例  Trying to tell him that his zipper is down without embarrassing him will be a ticklish task. 如何体面得体地提醒他拉链没关好是一个技巧活儿。
A: ♣近  catchy, delicate, difficult, dodgy, knotty, prickly, problematic, sensitive, spiny, sticky, thorny, touchy, tough, tricksy

Q:timely  ['taimli]

A: ♣近  immediate, punctual, speedy
A: ♣反  belated, late, tardy 迟到的，延迟的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 恰到好处的，合乎适宜的： appropriate or adapted to the times or the occasion
A: ♣例  Timely invitation to lunch that came just as I was starting to feel hungry. 正当我开始感到饥饿的时候，就有人适时地邀请我吃午饭了。
A: ♣近  opportune, seasonable, well-timed
A: ♣反  inopportune, unseasonable, untimely 不合时宜的

Q:tinge  [tindʒ]

A: ♣例  just slightly tinge the frosting with yellow food coloring to give it a lemony look 略微在霜糖表面加一点黄色色素，有一点柠檬的感觉就可以了
A: ♣近  dye, pigment, stain, tincture, tint
A: ♣反  suffuse, decolorize 遍染，使脱色

Q:tirade  [tai'reid]

A: ♣近  harangue, diatribe, jeremiad, philippic, rant
A: ♣反  eulogy, encomium, panegyric, tribute 颂词

Q:tonic  ['tɔnik]

A: ♣例  tonic medicine 补药
A: ♣近  medicinal, restorative, salubrious, salutary, salutiferous, sanative, wholesome
A: ♣反  insalubrious, noxious, unhealthful, unhealthy, unwholesome 不健康的

Q:topsy-turvy  [,tɔpsi'tə:vi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 混乱的，不整洁的： lacking in order, neatness, and often cleanliness; totally disordered
A: ♣例  The office is still topsy-turvy even though we moved in months ago. 尽管我们上个月就搬了进来，办公室还是混乱不堪。‖turning our ordered life topsy-turvy 把原本有序的生活彻底打乱
A: ♣近  chaotic, confused, disarranged, disarrayed, disheveled, disorderly, jumbled, messed, rumpled, sloppy, unkempt, untidy
A: ♣反  bandbox, crisp, kempt, neat, orderly, organized, shipshape, tidy, trim, well-ordered 整洁的，有序的

Q:torpid  ['tɔ:pid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 麻木的，没有知觉的： lacking in sensation or feeling
A: ♣例  My tongue and throat remained torpid for a time following the endoscopy. 胃镜检查之后，我的舌头和喉咙一直是麻木的。
A: ♣近  asleep, benumbed, dead, insensitive, numbed, unfeeling
A: ♣反  feeling, sensible, sensitive
A: ♠考法2  adj. 迟钝的，行动迟缓的： slow to move or act
A: ♣例  a torpid sloth that refused to budge off its tree branch 趴在树枝上一动不动的树獭
A: ♣近  dull, inert, lethargic, quiescent, sleepy, sluggish, torpid
A: ♣反  active 活跃的

Q:torpor  ['tɔ:pə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 缺乏兴趣： lack of interest or concern
A: ♣例  After a lifetime of setbacks, defeats, and failures, he could only greet the latest bad news with a resigned fatalism and dull torpor. 一生都充满了挫折、失败，他只能用宿命论和麻木不仁来迎接又一次的坏消息。
A: ♣近  apathy, casualness, complacence, disinterestedness, disregard, incuriosity, insouciance, nonchalance
A: ♣反  concern, interest, regard 有兴趣
A: ♠考法2  n. （肉体或精神上的）迟钝： physical or mental inertness
A: ♣例  Following Thanksgiving dinner, we spent the rest of the day lounging about in a contented torpor. 吃完感恩节晚餐后，我们慵懒地靠在沙发上打发剩下的时间。
A: ♣近  languor, lassitude, listlessness, stupor
A: ♣反  vigor, vim, vitality, vivacity 活力

Q:torrential  [tɔ'renʃəl]

A: ♣例  a torrential rain 倾盆大雨
A: ♣反  trickling 涓涓细流的

Q:torrid  ['tɔrid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 酷热的： intensely hot
A: ♣例  the dry, torrid summers in southern Arizona 南亚利桑那州干燥、炎热的夏天
A: ♣近  hot, scalding, scorching, sweltering
A: ♣反  arctic, bone-chilling, freezing, frigid, frozen, glacial, icy 寒冷的

A: ♣近  ardent, burning, fervid, flaming, glowing, impassioned, incandescent, intense, passionate, vehement
A: ♣反  dispassionate, emotionless, impassive, unemotional 冷漠的

Q:tortuous  ['tɔ:tjuəs]

A: ♣近  bending, curling, curvy, devious, serpentine, sinuous, twisted, windy
A: ♣反  direct, straightforward 直接的

Q:tout  [taut]

A: ♣近  acclaim, laud, praise, ballyhoo, tout
A: ♣反  asperse, censure, denounce, berate, rate, revile, vituperate 指责

Q:toy  [tɔi]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 草率或不认真地对待： to handle thoughtlessly, ignorantly, or mischievously
A: ♣例  That microscope is a delicate instrument, not something to be toyed with. 那个显微镜是精密仪器，不是随随便便的一个玩具。
A: ♣近  diddle with, fiddle with, fool with, mess with, monkey with, tinker with, twiddle with

Q:tractable  ['træktəbl]

A: ♣近  obedient, amenable, docile, flexible, manageable, compliant, submissive, tame

Q:tranquility  [træŋ'kwiləti]

A: ♣近  break, outreach, outrun, overpass, overreach, overrun, overshoot, overstep, surpass

A: ♣近  alchemize, metamorphose, transform, transmute, transpose, transubstantiate, make over

Q:transgress  [træns'ɡres]

A: ♣例  don't even think about transgressing the drug laws of that Asian country, for punishments are severe and there's nothing that our government can do to intervene 别指望违背亚洲国家的药品相关法，因为惩罚非常严厉，政府会尽全力干涉
A: ♣近  breach, break, contravene, fracture, infringe, offend, traduce
A: ♣反  follow, mind, obey, observe, comply with, conform to 遵守

Q:transient  ['trænziənt]

A: ♣例  transient pleasure 短暂的快乐
A: ♣近  transitory, ephemeral, evanescent, fleeting, temporary
A: ♣反  ceaseless, dateless, deathless, endless, enduring, eternal, everlasting, immortal, lasting, long-lived, permanent, perpetual, timeless, undying, unending 永恒持久的

Q:transitory  ['trænsitəri]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 短暂的： existing or lasting only a short time; short-lived or temporary
A: ♣例  most of life’s joys are transitory 尘世间的欢乐都是过眼烟云，转瞬即逝
A: ♣近  transient, ephemeral, evanescent, fleeting, temporary
A: ♣反  ceaseless, dateless, deathless, endless, enduring, eternal, everlasting, immortal, lasting, long-lived, permanent, perpetual, timeless, undying, unending

Q:translucent  [trænz'lju:sənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 透明的： permitting the passage of light: clear, transparent
A: ♣例  translucent dewdrop 透明的露珠
A: ♣近  transparent, limpid, pellucid, lucent, lucid, transpicuous
A: ♣反  opaque 不透明的

Q:transparent  [træns'pærənt]
A: ♠考法1 adj. 透明的： capable of transmitting light
A: ♣近  translucent, limpid, pellucid, lucent, lucid, transpicuous
A: ♣反  cloudy, opaque 不透明的
A: ♠考法2 adj. 没有歧义，清晰易懂的： not subject to misinterpretation or more than one interpretation
A: ♣例  His meaning in leaving the conversation is transparent: he doesn't want to talk about his combat experiences. 他结束这个话题的意图很明显：不想谈论当年参战的事。
A: ♣近  obvious, clear, apparent, patent, understandable, apprehensible, comprehendible, fathomable
A: ♣反  ambiguous, clouded, cryptic, enigmatic, equivocal, indistinct, mysterious, obfuscated, obscure, unapparent, unclarified, unclear, unclouded 难以理解的

Q:travail  ['træveil]
A: ♠考法1  n./v. 辛苦劳动： work, especially when arduous or involving painful effort
A: ♣例  writer’s literary travail 作家辛勤的文学创作 || Labor Day is the day on which we recognize those men and women who daily travail with little appreciation or compensation. 劳动节是我们向那些平日辛勤劳作但是很少受到大家关注和补偿的工人致敬的日子。
A: ♣近  drudgery, fatigue, grind

Q:traverse  ['trævəs]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 横穿： to travel or pass across, over, or through
A: ♣例  The spider traversed the wall from end to end. 蜘蛛侠攀岩走壁。
A: ♣近  course, cover, cross, cut across, navigate, pass over, perambulate, peregrinate, proceed along, transit, travel

Q:travesty  ['trævisti]

A: ♣例  a travesty of his classmate’s manner 滑稽的模仿其他同学的举止
A: ♣近  caricature, burlesque, parody, spoof, mock
A: ♣反  paragon 完美的模范

Q:treacherous  ['tretʃərəs]

A: ♣例  a treacherous ally 不忠的盟友
A: ♣近  faithless, disloyal, perfidious, recreant, traitorous, unfaithful, unloyal, betraying
A: ♣反  constant, dedicated, devoted, staunch, down-the-line, faithful, fast, loyal, steadfast, steady, true 忠诚的

Q:trenchant  ['trentʃənt]
A: ♠考法1 adj. 锐利的： keen, sharp
A: ♣例  Even the most trenchant sword could not sever the bonds of loyalty between them. 即使最锋利的刀剑也不能切断他们的忠诚。
A: ♣近  keen, sharp
A: ♣反  blunt, blunted, dull, obtuse 钝的
A: ♠考法2 adj. （言辞）一针见血的： vigorously effective and articulate
A: ♣例  trenchant criticisms 一针见血的批评
A: ♣近  incisive
A: ♣反  vague 含糊的

Q:trepidation  [,trepideiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 恐惧，战栗： the emotion experienced in the presence or threat of danger; apprehension
A: ♣例  trepidation about starting a new career 对开创一项新事业而感到恐惧
A: ♣近  fear, fright, horror, apprehension
A: ♣反  boldness, bravery, dauntlessness, intrepidity 大胆

Q:trespass  ['trespəs]
A: ♠考法1 vi. 非法侵入，违反： to commit an offense
A: ♣例  I consider him to be trespassing against all of us when he trespasses against any one of us. 当他冒犯我们当中一个人的时候，他就冒犯了我们全部
A: ♣近  transgress, invade, intrude
A: ♣反  withdraw, retreat 撤退

Q:tribute  ['tribju:t]

A: ♣例  pay a high tribute to… 赞颂
A: ♣近  accolade, eulogy, encomium, panegyric, tribute 颂词
A: ♣反  denunciation, condemnation, criticism, censure, reproof, reprobation 批评，指责

Q:trickle  ['trikl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 一滴滴地流，徐徐地流： to issue or fall in drops
A: ♣例  Tears trickled down her cheeks. 眼泪从她的脸上一滴一滴地流下。
A: ♣反  pour, roll, stream, gush 喷涌

Q:trifle  ['traifl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 不重要的事： something of little importance or value
A: ♣例  Let us not speak of trifles when our nation may be going to war. 战事在即，我们还是先放下这些琐事吧。
A: ♣近  bagatelle, frippery, triviality
A: ♠考法2  vi. 不正经地对待，玩弄： to behave amorously without serious intent
A: ♣例  Do not trifle with me unless you mean to ask me to marry you. 如果你不是真心想和我结婚，就请不要来玩弄我的感情。
A: ♣近  coquet, dally, flirt, frivol, toy
A: ♣派  trifling adj. 不重要的

Q:trifling  ['traifliŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 细微的，不重要的： lacking in significance or solid worth
A: ♣例  Deciding what you want to do for a living is no trifling matter. 决定维持生计的行当可不是一件小事。‖trifling differences between the theatrical and DVD versions of the movie 影院版和DVD版电影当中的细微区别
A: ♣近  frivolous, inconsequential, inconsiderable, insignificant, minor, minute, negligible, nugatory, slight, trivial
A: ♣反  consequential, eventful, important, meaningful, momentous, significant, substantial, weighty 重要的

Q:trite  [trait]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 陈腐的，陈词滥调的： hackneyed or boring from much use, not fresh or original
A: ♣例  “You win some, you lose some” is a trite expression. “有得必有失”是老生常谈了。
A: ♣近  bathetic, cliché, hackneyed, threadbare, timeworn, banal
A: ♣反  fresh, new, novel, original, unclichéd, unhackneyed 新鲜的

Q:trivial  ['triviəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 琐碎的，无足轻重的： of little worth or importance
A: ♣例  why spend so much time on trivial decisions, like whether the cola should be regular or diet? 为什么花这么多时间在这种琐碎的决定上，比如可乐要喝一般的还是健怡？
A: ♣近  inconsiderable, insignificant, minor, petty, inconsequential, paltry, trifling
A: ♣反  consequential, material, momentous, weighty, indispensable, substantive, grandiose, massive 重要的

Q:truant  ['tru:ənt]

A: ♣例  play truant 逃学
A: ♣近  shirk, malinger, goldbrick, avoid, escape, evade, parry, sidestep, circumvent, fence, hedge, avert, elude, shun, skirt, dodge, bilk, eschew
A: ♣反  dutiful 尽职尽责的

Q:truce  [tru:s]

A: ♣例  truce agreement 休战协议

Q:truculent  ['trʌkjulənt]

A: ♠考法2 adj. 好战的： feeling or displaying eagerness to fight

A: ♣近  belligerent, bellicose, combative, militant, aggressive, feisty
A: ♣反  nonaggressive, nonbelligerent, pacific, peaceable, peaceful, uncombative, uncontentious 好和平的

Q:trudge  [trʌdʒ]

A: ♣反  breeze, glide, slide, waltz, whisk, flit 快速通过

Q:trumpet  ['trʌmpit]

Q:truncate  ['trʌŋkeit]

A: ♣反  elongate, extend, lengthen, prolong, protract 延长

Q:truss  [trʌs]

A: ♣反  unbind, untie 解开

A: ♣反  quietude, quiescence, serenity, tranquility 安静

A: ♣反  clear , limpid, lucid, pellucid, , crystalline 清澈的

Q:turbulent  ['tə:bjulənt]

A: ♣近  rough, rugged, stormy, tempestuous

A: ♣反  calm, ease, peace, peacefulness, quiet, tranquility, silence, serenity 安静

A: ♣反  extraordinary, infrequent, rare, seldom, uncommon, unfamiliar, unusual, unique, particular 独特的，不常见的

A: ♣反  contentment, delight, gratification, happiness, pleasure 满意，高兴

A: ♣近  consentaneous, uncontested

Q:unassailable  [,ʌnə'seiləbl]
