A: ♣例  an unassailable article 无可争辩的文章
A: ♣近  undeniable, inviolable, sacrosanct , irrefutable, indisputable, unexceptionable, unimpeachable
A: ♣反  controversial 有争议的

Q:unavailing  [,ʌnə'veiliŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 徒劳的，无果的： producing no results
A: ♣例  an unavailing effort to avert a war 试图避免战争的徒劳尝试
A: ♣近  abortive, barren, bootless, fruitless, ineffectual, unproductive, unprofitable, unsuccessful, useless, vain
A: ♣反  effective, effectual, efficacious, fruitful, potent, productive 有效的；successful 成功的

Q:uncanny  [,ʌn'kæni]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 离奇的，奇异的： being so extraordinary or abnormal as to suggest powers which violate the laws of nature
A: ♣例  The silence was uncanny. 静得出奇
A: ♣近  magical, miraculous, phenomenal, preternatural, superhuman, supernormal, transcendent, transcendental, uncanny, unearthly
A: ♣反  ordinary, commonplace, normal 平凡的

Q:uncouth  [,ʌn'ku:θ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 粗俗的，没有品位的： lacking in refinement or good taste
A: ♣例  the movie's uncouth humor seemed to be purposely offensive 电影里一些恶俗的幽默貌似是故意的
A: ♣近  crass, rude, discourteous, disgracious, ungraceful, crude, ill-bred, ill-mannered, uncivil, unrefined
A: ♣反  genteel, cultivated, cultured, polished, urbane, seemly 得体的，有教养的

Q:unctuous  ['ʌŋktjuəs]
A: ♠考法1 adj. 油嘴滑舌的，谄媚的： overly or insincerely flattering
A: ♣例  an unctuous appraisal of the musical talent shown by the boss's daughter 拍老板马屁，说他女儿音乐剧的才能非常卓越
A: ♣近  adulatory, gushing, hagiographic, oily, oleaginous, soapy
A: ♠考法2  adj. 夸张的，做作的： characterized by affected, exaggerated, or insincere earnestness
A: ♣例  an unctuous effort to appear religious to the voters 过分做作想在选民面前表现地虔诚
A: ♣近  artificial, backhanded, counterfeit, fake, feigned, hypocritical, phony, pretended
A: ♣反  artless, candid, genuine, heartfelt, honest, sincere, undesigning, unfeigned 真实的

Q:underdog  ['ʌndədɔɡ]

A: ♣反  bully 欺凌弱小者

Q:undergird  [,ʌndə'ɡə:d]

A: ♣例  facts and statistics undergird his commentary 事实和数据支持了他的评论
A: ♣近  strengthen, support, fortify, reinforce, bear, bolster, brace, buttress, carry, stay, sustain, underpin, uphold, prop up, shore up
A: ♣反  undermine, weaken, debilitate, enfeeble, enervate 削弱

Q:undermine  [,ʌndə'main]

A: ♣例  undermine a fortress 挖地道破坏堡垒
A: ♣近  undermine, weaken, debilitate, enfeeble, enervate
A: ♣反  strengthen, support, fortify, reinforce 加强

Q:underscore  [,ʌndə'skɔ:]

A: ♣近  accentuate, italicize, stress, underline, bring out
A: ♣反  deemphasize, downplay 轻描淡写

Q:understate  [,ʌndə'steit]

A: ♣例  understate a problem 低调处理问题
A: ♣近  downplay
A: ♣反  vaunt, exaggerate, overstate 夸大
A: ♣派  understated adj. 朴素的： avoiding obvious emphasis or embellishment
A: ♣近  conservative, low-key, muted, repressed, restrained, sober, subdued, unflashy, unpretentious
A: ♣反  flamboyant, flaring, flashy, garish, gaudy, glitzy, ostentatious, splashy 夸张的，华丽的

Q:understudy  ['ʌndə,stʌdi]

A: ♣例  be an understudy to sb 作为某人的替补
A: ♣近  deputy

Q:unexceptionable  [,ʌnik'sepʃənəbl]

A: ♣近  unassailable, undeniable, irrefutable, indisputable, unexceptionable, unimpeachable
A: ♣反  assailable, controversial 有争议的

Q:unflappable  [,ʌn'flæpəbl]

A: ♣例  a unflappable general 一个镇定的将军
A: ♣近  collected, composed, disimpassioned, imperturbable
A: ♣反  perturbable, shakable, disturbed, nervous 紧张的

Q:ungainly  [,ʌn'ɡeinli]

A: ♣近  clumsy, awkward, blundering, maladroit
A: ♣反  coordinated, graceful, adroit, dexterous, lissome 协调的，灵巧的

Q:unimpeachable  [,ʌnim'pi:tʃəbl]

A: ♣例  An unimpeachable evidence 无可置疑的证据
A: ♣近  unassailable, undeniable, irrefutable, indisputable, unexceptionable, unimpeachable
A: ♣反  assailable, controversial, open to question 可争辩的

Q:unkempt  [,ʌn'kempt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 凌乱的，无序的： lacking in order, neatness, and often cleanliness
A: ♣例  unkempt hotel rooms 凌乱的酒店房间
A: ♣近  slovenly, slipshod, sloppy, unneat, untidy, topsy-turvy, jumbled
A: ♣反  bandbox, neat, orderly, organized, shipshape, tidy, trim, uncluttered, well-ordered 有序的，井井有条的

Q:unlettered  [,ʌn'letəd]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 未受教育的，文盲的： not adept at reading and writing; deficient in the knowledge that can be acquired from books. illiterate
A: ♣例  unlettered sector of society 未受教育的地区
A: ♣近  ignorant, illiterate, uneducated, untutored
A: ♣反  educated, knowledgeable, erudite, literate, schooled, well-informed, well-read 博学的，受过教育的

Q:unpretentious  [,ʌnpri'tenʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 低调的，谦逊的： lacking pretension or affectation; modest
A: ♣例  an unpretentious virtuoso 一位谦虚的大师
A: ♣近  demure, down-to-earth, lowly, meek, unassuming, humble, modest, unostentatious
A: ♣反  arrogant, bumptious, conceited, egotistic, fastuous, haughty, imperious, lordly, overweening, peremptory, pompous, presuming, presumptuous, self-asserting, supercilious, superior, toplofty, uppish, flamboyant, ostentatious 傲慢的，自负的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 坦诚的，自然的： free from any intent to deceive or impress others
A: ♣例  a simple and unpretentious account about growing up in the rural South 一段简单坦率的关于在南部乡村成长经历的叙述
A: ♣近  artless, genuine, honest, ingenuous, innocent, naive, simple, sincere, true, unpretending
A: ♣反  affected, artful, artificial, assuming, dissembling, dissimulating, fake, guileful, insincere, phony 做作的，虚伪的

Q:unproductive  [,ʌnprə'dʌktiv]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 徒然的，无效的： not productive; idle
A: ♣例  her attempts to write a novel have been unproductive 她一直想写本小说的努力只是徒然
A: ♣近  abortive, barren, fruitless, otiose, profitless, unavailing, unprofitable, unsuccessful, useless, vain
A: ♣反  deadly, effective, effectual, efficacious, efficient, potent, productive, profitable, successful, virtuous, telling 有效的

Q:unremitting  [,ʌnri'mitiŋ]

A: ♣例  Unremitting rain lasted for six days. 连续下了六天的雨。
A: ♣近  ceaseless, continual, continuing, incessant, nonstop, perpetual, unbroken, uninterrupted
A: ♣反  discontinuous, intermittent 不连续的，有间断的

Q:unrequited  [,ʌnri'kwaitid]

A: ♣近  unreciprocated
A: ♣反  remunerative, gainful, lucrative, profitable 有报酬的

Q:unruly  [,ʌn'ru:li]

A: ♣例  an unruly child 一个不听话的孩子
A: ♣近  indocile, indomitable, intractable, recalcitrant, uncontrollable, undisciplined, ungovernable, unmanageable, insubordinate
A: ♣反  amenable, biddable, compliant, conformable, docile, obedient, submissive, tractable, subdued, mild, manageable, disciplined 顺从的，守纪律的

Q:untenable  [,ʌn'tenəbl]

A: ♣近  assailable, controversial, open to question 可质疑的
A: ♣反  unassailable, undeniable, irrefutable, indisputable, unexceptionable, unimpeachable 无可指责的，无懈可击的

Q:untold  [,ʌn'təuld]

A: ♣例  untold wealth 不知其数的财富
A: ♣近  incalculable, innumerable, countless, innumerous, uncountable, uncounted
A: ♣反  countable, enumerable, numberable, quantifiable, calculable 可以计算的

Q:untoward  [,ʌntə'wɔ:d]

A: ♣例  an untoward incident 不幸的事故
A: ♣近  unpropitious, unlucky, misfortunate, unfortunate
A: ♣反  auspicious, propitious, favorable, fortunate 吉利的，幸运的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 难以驯服的，难以驾驭的： given to resisting control or discipline by others
A: ♣例  a program for untoward teenagers that is designed to give them the kind of discipline that their parents were unable or unwilling to administer 一个以任性、桀骜不驯青少年为对象的项目，旨在弥补家长管教不周之处
A: ♣近  froward, headstrong, intractable, recalcitrant, refractory, unruly, wayward, willful
A: ♣反  controllable, governable, manageable, tractable 易管教的，顺从的

Q:unwitting  [,ʌn'witiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 不知道的，未觉察的： not knowing, unaware
A: ♣例  Please forgive my unwitting interruption of your conversation. 请原谅我无意间打断了你们的谈话。
A: ♣近  unaware, ignorant
A: ♣反  acquainted, aware, cognizant, conscious, conversant, grounded, informed, knowing, mindful 有意识的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 偶然的，并非有意的： happening by chance; not intended
A: ♣例  an unwitting mistake made in copying the material 在打印过程中一个无心的过失
A: ♣近  casual, chance, fluky, fortuitous, inadvertent, incidental, unintentional
A: ♣反  calculated, deliberate, intended, intentional, planned, premeditated, prepense 故意的，蓄意的

Q:unwonted  [,ʌn'wəuntid]

A: ♣近  uncommon, unordinary, unusual
A: ♣反  wonted, usual, routine, habitual, accustomed, customary 平常的

A: ♣近  support, bolster, advocate, champion, endorse, espouse

Q:utter  ['ʌtə]

A: ♣例  She tried not to utter a sound as the doctor gave her a flu shot. 她克制自己不在打针的时候喊出来。
A: ♣近  articulate, bring out, enunciate, verbalize, vocalize
A: ♠考法2 adj. 完全的，绝对的： complete; absolute; entire
A: ♣例  be at an utter loss what to do 完全不知道怎样才好
A: ♣近  entire, total, stark, sheer, unqualified
A: ♣反  partial 部分的

A: ♣例  vaccinate sb. for smallpox 为某人接种牛痘疫苗以防天花

Q:vacillate  ['væsileit]

A: ♣例  Parents vacillate between saying no and yes, but actually neither response seems satisfactory to their children. 父母总是犹豫不定，不知道是该同意还是该反对，但是事实上哪种答案对他们的孩子都不理想。

A: ♣反  equipoise 平衡；静止

Q:vacuous  ['vækjuəs]

A: ♣派  vacuity n. 空虚，空白

A: ♣反  pellucid 清澈透明的

Q:valid  ['vælid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 逻辑上正确的： logically correct
A: ♣例  Only further experiments will show whether your theory is valid. 只有进一步的实验才能验证你的理论是否正确。‖Your argument isn't valid because you're taking what should be the conclusion and using it as a premise. 你的论述逻辑上是错误的，因为你把本该是结论的东西当成了前提条件。
A: ♣近  analytic, coherent, consequent, rational, reasonable, sensible, sound, well-founded, well-grounded
A: ♣反  groundless, illegitimate, illogical, incoherent, inconsequent, invalid, irrational, unreasonable, unsound （逻辑上）站不住脚的
A: ♣派  validity n.合乎逻辑

A: ♣反  build, construct, erect, establish, raise, rear 建造
A: ♣派  vaporous adj. 模糊的，空洞的

Q:variance  ['vεəriəns]

A: ♣反  accord, agreement, concord, concordance, harmony, peace 和谐，一致
A: ♣派  variant adj. 变体的，不同的

Q:varnish  ['vɑ:niʃ]

A: ♣近  adorn, bedeck, bedizen, decorate, embellish, garnish, ornament
A: ♠考法2  vt. 粉饰（令人不悦的东西）： to cover or conceal (as something unpleasant) with something that gives an attractive appearance
A: ♣例  She tried to varnish her mistakes. 她试图掩盖她的失误。
A: ♣近  blanch, extenuate, gloss, palliate, sugarcoat, veneer
A: ♣反  bare, disclose, discover, divulge, expose, reveal, uncloak, uncover, unmask, unveil 揭露

Q:vault  [vɔ:lt]

A: ♣近  bound, hop, jump, leap, spring
A: ♠考法2  vi. 一跃而至： to accomplish something as if by leaping suddenly or vigorously
A: ♣例  She vaulted into a position of wealth. 她一夜暴富。

Q:vaunt  [vɔ:nt]

A: ♣派  vehemence n. 强烈

Q:venal  ['vi:nəl]

A: ♣近  bribable, corruptible, dirty, purchasable

Q:vendor  ['vendɔ:]

Q:veneer  [və'niə]

A: ♣近  cover, fa?ade, mask
A: ♣反  center, core, kernel 核心
A: ♠考法2  vt. 粉饰（不好的东西）： to cover over with a veneer; especially to conceal (as a defect of character) under a superficial and deceptive attractiveness
A: ♣近  blanch, extenuate, gloss, palliate, sugarcoat, varnish
A: ♣反  bare, disclose, discover, divulge, expose, reveal, uncloak, uncover, unmask, unveil 揭露

A: ♣例  She is venerated by the public as a saint. 她被当作圣人，受万众景仰。
A: ♣近  adore, deify, esteem, regard, respect, revere
A: ♣反  despise, disdain, disregard, flout, scorn 轻视，蔑视
A: ♣派  veneration n. 尊敬

Q:venial  ['vi:niəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 可宽恕的： easily excused or forgiven
A: ♣例  Taking the restaurant's menu as a souvenir seems like a venial offense. 把餐厅的菜单当成纪念品带走似乎是一个可以宽恕的罪行。
A: ♣近  condonable, excusable, forgivable, pardonable, remissible, remittable
A: ♣反  heinous, indefensible, inexcusable, mortal, unforgivable, unpardonable 罪大恶极的，不可饶恕的

Q:venom  ['venɔm]
A: ♠考法1  n. 毒液： poisonous matter normally secreted by some animals as snakes, scorpions, or bees
A: ♣例  an antidote to snake venom 蛇毒的解药
A: ♣近  toxic, toxin
A: ♣反  antidote 解药
A: ♠考法2  n. 恶意，恶毒的用心： the desire to cause pain for the satisfaction of doing harm
A: ♣例  She spoke of him with venom in her voice. 她的评论怀揣着恶意。
A: ♣近  despite, malevolence, maliciousness, malignance, malignity, meanness, nastiness, spite, viciousness
A: ♣反  comity, friendship, goodwill 友善

Q:veracious  [və'reiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 诚实的，说实话的： being in the habit of telling the truth
A: ♣例  a veracious witness 诚实的证人‖He has a reputation for being veracious, so people generally take his word for things. 他诚实的名声让其他人通常都相信他说的话
A: ♣近  honest, truthful
A: ♣反  dishonest, lying, mendacious, prevaricating, untruthful 说谎的，不诚实的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 精确的，准确的： precise, accurate
A: ♣例  a novel that presents a fairly veracious and unvarnished picture of the lives of affluent suburbanites 一部准确而不加修饰地描述郊区富人生活的小说
A: ♣近  accurate, exact, precise, proper, right, true
A: ♣反  false, improper, inaccurate, incorrect, inexact, untrue, wrong 不准确的
A: ♣派  veracity n. 诚实

Q:verbatim  [və:'beitim]
A: ♠考法1  adv. 逐字地，一字不差地： in the exact words
A: ♣例  You can't just copy the encyclopedia article verbatim for your report - that's plagiarism. 你不能一字不差地抄百科全书上的内容——这是剽窃。
A: ♣近  ad verbum, directly, exactly, word for word
A: ♣反  inaccurately, inexactly 不准确地
A: ♣派  verbalism n. 言辞，单词

Q:verbose  [və:'bəus]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 冗长的，啰嗦的： containing more words than necessary
A: ♣例  a verbose orator 啰嗦的演讲者‖She has a verbose writing style. 她的文风很啰嗦。
A: ♣近  circuitous, circumlocutory, diffuse, garrulous, long-winded, prolix, rambling, verbose, windy
A: ♣反  brief, compact, concise, pithy, succinct, terse 简洁的
A: ♣派  verbosity n. 冗长，啰嗦

Q:verdant  ['və:dənt]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （因长满植物而）翠绿的，郁郁葱葱的： green with vegetation; covered with green growth
A: ♣例  verdant fields 翠绿的田野
A: ♣近  green, grown, leafy, luxuriant, overgrown
A: ♣反  barren, impoverished, infertile, leafless, sterile 贫瘠的

Q:verify  ['verifai]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 校验，证实： to determine or test the truth or accuracy of, as by comparison, investigation, or reference
A: ♣例  We need to verify your passport. 我们需要校验阁下的护照。
A: ♣近  attest, authenticate, certify, corroborate, substantiate, support, validate, vindicate
A: ♣反  disprove, rebut, refute 反驳，驳斥
A: ♣派  verified adj. 经证实的；verification n. 证实

Q:verisimilar  [,veri'similə]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 似乎真实的： appearing to be true or real
A: ♣例  a verisimilar tale 一个似乎为真的传奇
A: ♣近  likely, plausible, probable
A: ♣反  implausible, incredible, unbelievable 难以置信的

Q:veritable  ['veritəbl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 真正的，确实的： being in fact the thing named and not false, unreal, or imaginary
A: ♣例  a veritable manuscript 一份原稿
A: ♣近  authentic, credible, genuine, real, true, unquestionable, bona fide
A: ♣反  bogus, counterfeit, fake, false, mock, phony, pseudo, sham, spurious 伪造的，虚假的

Q:vernacular  [və'nækjulə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 方言： a nonstandard language or dialect of a place, region, or country
A: ♣例  phrases that occur in the common vernacular 常见方言中的词组
A: ♣近  argot, cant, dialect, jargon, lingo, slang
A: ♠考法2  adj. 非正式的，口头的： used in or suitable for speech and not formal writing
A: ♣例  writes essays in a very easy-to-read, vernacular style 用一种易懂的口头化风格写作
A: ♣近  conversational, informal, nonliterary, vulgar
A: ♣反  bookish, formal, learned, literary 书面的，正式的

Q:versatile  ['və:sətail]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 多才多艺的，全能的： able to do many different kinds of things
A: ♣例  We have found a versatile baseball player who can play any position. 我们发现了一个能打任何位置的全能型球员。
A: ♣近  adaptable, all-around, ambidextrous, protean, universal
A: ♣反  limited 受限制的，有限的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 易改变的： changing or fluctuating readily
A: ♣例  a versatile disposition 多变的性格
A: ♣近  capricious, changeable, fluid, inconstant, mercurial, skittish, temperamental, variable, volatile
A: ♣反  certain, changeless, constant, immutable, invariable, settled, stable, stationary, steady, unchangeable, unvarying 固定的，不变的

Q:verse  [və:s]

A: ♣例  well versed in the theater 精通剧院‖While in prison, he versed himself in the rights of the incarcerated. 当他身处监狱时，他通过自学熟悉了囚犯所享有的权利。
A: ♣近  acquaint, familiarize, inform
A: ♣反  misinform, mislead 误导
A: ♠考法2  n. 诗歌： a composition using rhythm and often rhyme to create a lyrical effect
A: ♣例  composed a short verse for his father’s birthday 为他父亲的生日创作了一首小诗
A: ♣近  ballad, lyric, poetry, song
A: ♣反  prose 散文

Q:versed  [və:st]

A: ♣近  accomplished, adept, complete, consummate, experienced, expert, master, practiced, professed, skilled, veteran, virtuoso
A: ♣近  amateur, inexperienced, inexpert, jackleg, unprofessional, unseasoned, unskilled 业余的，不精通的

Q:vestige  ['vestidʒ]

A: ♣例  A few strange words carved on a stone were the only vestige of the lost civilization. 石碑上刻着的几个奇怪的字符是这个失落文明的唯一的遗迹。‖the fossilized vestige of a dinosaur that traversed that muddy landscape millions of years ago 千万年横跨那块泥泞土壤的恐龙的化石碎片
A: ♣近  echo, ghost, relic, remain, remnant, residual, shadow, trace
A: ♣派  vestigial adj. 残留的；退化的

Q:vestigial  [ve'stidʒiəl]

A: ♣例  snake that has vestigial limbs 拥有退化四肢的蛇
A: ♣近  incomplete, rudimentary, undeveloped
A: ♣反  adult, full-blown, full-fledged, matured, ripe, ripened 成熟的，发育完全的

Q:veteran  ['vetərən]

A: ♣例  As a veteran of overseas travel, she offered us solid advice about planning our trip. 作为一名资深的旅行家，她给了我们提供了许多关于旅行规划的中肯建议。

A: ♣反  beginner, colt, fledgling, freshman, greenhorn, neophyte, novice, recruit, rookie, tenderfoot, tyro 新手

A: ♣反  amateur, inexperienced, inexpert, unprofessional, unseasoned, unskilled, unskillful 业余的，经验不足的

Q:veto  ['vi:təu]

A: ♣近  blackball, decline, disallow, disapprove, kill, negative, refuse, reject
A: ♣反  accredit, approbate, authorize, clear, confirm, finalize, formalize, ratify, sanction, warrant 批准

A: ♣例  The American virtuoso cellist Lynn Harrell joins the orchestra as soloist in Shostakovich’s technically challenging Cello Concerto No 2. 来自美国的技艺精湛的大提琴家林恩?哈雷尔作为独奏者加入了乐队，共同演绎肖斯塔科维奇充满挑战的《第二大提琴协奏曲》。
A: ♣近  accomplished, adept, consummate, experienced, masterful, professed, skilled, versed, veteran
A: ♣反  amateur, inexperienced, inexpert, unprofessional, unseasoned, unskilled, unskillful 业余的，经验不足的
A: ♣派  virtuosity n. 精湛技艺

Q:virtuous  ['və:tʃuəs]

A: ♣近  decent, ethical, honest, honorable, moral, noble, righteous, straight, upright
A: ♣反  bad, evil, immoral, indecent, sinful, unethical, unrighteous, wicked, wrong 邪恶的

Q:virulent  ['virjulənt]

A: ♣反  innocuous 无害的；healthy, salubrious, wholesome 有益健康的

A: ♣近  cruel, malevolent, malicious, malignant, spiteful, vicious
A: ♣反  benevolent, benign, benignant, loving 仁慈的
A: ♣派  virulence n. 毒性，恶毒

Q:visionary  ['viʒənəri]

A: ♣近  chimerical, dreamy, fabulous, fantastic, illusory, phantom, unreal
A: ♣反  actual, existent, existing, real 真实存在的

A: ♣近  farseeing, farsighted, forehanded, foreseeing, forethoughtful, prescient, proactive, provident
A: ♣反  improvident, myopic, shortsighted 目光短浅的

Q:vitality  [vai'tæləti]
A: ♠考法1  n. 活力，生命力： physical or mental vigor especially when highly developed
A: ♣例  Her vitality seemed to spread to everyone around her. 她的活力似乎能影响身边的每一个人
A: ♣近  animation, bounce, dynamism, energy, liveliness, robustness, verve, vibrancy, vigorousness, vim
A: ♣反  lethargy, listlessness, sluggishness, torpidity 精神不振
A: ♣派  vitalize vt. 激发，使有活力

Q:vitiate  ['viʃieit]
A: ♠考法1  v. 削弱，损害： to reduce the value or impair the quality of
A: ♣例  Too many grammatical errors can vitiate the soundness of your writing, so double-check is recommended before submission. 太多的语法错误会削弱你论证的力度，所以强烈建议交稿前检查几遍。
A: ♣近  blemish, cripple, deface, degrade, deteriorate, flaw, harm, impair, mar, undermine
A: ♣反  doctor, fix, mend, patch, rebuild, recondition, reconstruct, renovate, repair, revamp 修复，再生
A: ♠考法2  v. （在道德、审美上）降低，堕落： to debase in moral or aesthetic status
A: ♣例  Penchant for coarse language vitiates what is otherwise a refined literary style. 使用粗俗语言的倾向使得本该是一个高雅的文体变得不堪入目。
A: ♣近  abase, cheapen, corrupt, debauch, demean, demoralize, deprave, pervert, profane, prostitute, subvert
A: ♣反  elevate, ennoble, uplift 使高尚
A: ♣派  vitiated adj. 受损害的

Q:vitriolic  [,vitri'ɔlik]

A: ♣例  vitriolic criticism 刻薄的批评
A: ♣近  acerbic, acid, acrid, bitter, biting, caustic, corrosive, harsh, mordant, scalding, scathing, sharp, tart
A: ♣反  balmy, benign, bland, delicate, light, mellow, mild, nonabrasive, soft, soothing, tender 柔和的
A: ♣派  vitriol n. 刻薄的话语

A: ♣派  vituperative adj. 辱骂的

A: ♣派  vivacity n. 活力，活泼

Q:vocation  [vəu'keiʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 职业： the work in which a person is regularly employed
A: ♣例  finally made soccer her vocation instead of just a hobby 终于将足球从爱好升级为谋生的职业
A: ♣近  calling, employment, occupation, profession, trade, work
A: ♣反  hobby 爱好
A: ♣派  vocational adj. 职业的，为职业做准备的

Q:vociferous  [vəu'sifərəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 喧哗的，大叫大嚷的： making, given to, or marked by noisy and vehement outcry
A: ♣例  Vociferous opponents of the bill protested angrily outside the Congress. 议案的反对者在国会外愤怒地举行了声势浩大的抗议活动
A: ♣近  blatant, boisterous, clamant, clamorous, obstreperous, strident, yowling
A: ♣反  reticent, taciturn 沉默的；serene, tranquil 宁静的

Q:volatile  ['vɔlətail]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 多变的： characterized by or subject to rapid or unexpected change
A: ♣例  a boss of volatile moods 一个性情多变的老板‖The stock market can be very volatile. 股市瞬息万变。
A: ♣近  capricious, changeable, fluid, inconstant, mercurial, skittish, temperamental, variable, versatile
A: ♣反  certain, changeless, constant, immutable, invariable, settled, stable, stationary, steady, unchangeable, unvarying 固定的，不变的
A: ♣派  volatility n. 易变性，易挥发性

Q:volition  [vəu'liʃən]
A: ♠考法1  n. 意志，自愿选择的行为： the act or power of making one's own choices or decisions
A: ♣例  beyond his volition or control 超出了他的意志和控制范围
A: ♣近  choice, decision, discretion, will
A: ♣反  coercion, compulsion, constraint, duress, force, pressure 强迫，迫使

Q:voluble  ['vɔljubl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 健谈的，话多的： characterized by ready or rapid speech
A: ♣例  The voluble gadfly ruined the party. 聚会被那个话又多又让人讨厌的人破坏了。
A: ♣近  chatty, eloquent, garrulous, glib, loquacious, talkative, vocative
A: ♣反  reticent, taciturn 沉默的；laconic, reserved, succinct 惜字如金的
A: ♣派  volubility n. 口若悬河

Q:voluminous  [və'lju:minəs]

A: ♣例  trying to keep a track of voluminous academic database 尝试追踪数目庞大的学术数据库
A: ♣近  colossal, considerable, elephantine, enormous, gargantuan, gigantic, mammoth, numerous, oversize
A: ♣反  scanty, scarce 缺乏的；dwarf, little, small, undersized 数量少的

Q:voluptuous  [və'lʌptjuəs]

A: ♣例  They spent a long and voluptuous holiday in Venice. 他们在威尼斯度过了一个漫长而奢华的假期。
A: ♣近  carnal, epicurean, luscious, lush, luxurious, indulgent, sensual, sensuous
A: ♣反  ascetic, spartan, self-denying 克己的，自制的
A: ♣派  voluptuary n. 酒色之徒

Q:voracious  [vɔ'reiʃəs]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有很大食量的，贪吃的： having a huge appetite
A: ♣例  He has a voracious appetite. 他的食量惊人。
A: ♣近  edacious, esurient, gluttonous, swinish
A: ♣反  abstemious, abstentious 有节制的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 贪婪的，如饥似渴的： having or marked by an insatiable appetite for an activity or pursuit
A: ♣例  a voracious reader who locked himself up in the study 一个把自己锁在书房的贪婪的读者
A: ♣近  acquisitive, avid, covetous, grasping, greedy, hungry, rapacious, ravenous, thirsty
A: ♣反  apathetic, indifferent, uneager, unenthusiastic 无所谓的
A: ♣派  voracity n. 食欲，贪婪

Q:votary  ['vəutəri]

A: ♣例  refused to vouchsafe an explanation 拒绝给出任何解释
A: ♣近  accord, award, grant, vest
A: ♣反  withhold 保留，不给予；recant, retract, withdraw 撤回，收回

Q:voyeur  [vwɑ:'jə:]

A: ♣例  They accidentally found out that their ostensibly benign neighbor is actually a voyeur. 他们偶然间发现那个表面和善的邻居居然是一个偷窥狂。
A: ♣近  peeper
A: ♣派  voyeurism n. 偷窥癖

Q:vulgar  ['vʌlɡə]

A: ♣例  He is a vulgar man but his music is quite divine. 虽然他是一个粗俗的人，但他的音乐却十分神圣。
A: ♣近  bawdy, coarse, crass, crude, dirty, filthy, gross, lowbred, indecent, nasty, obscene, ribald, rude, uncouth
A: ♣反  civilized, cultivated, cultured, genteel, polished, refined, urbane, well-bred 有教养的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 口头的，非正式的： used in or suitable for speech and not formal writing
A: ♣例  Latin was once the language of scholars, and English the vulgar language used by the common people. 很久以前拉丁语才是学术界的官方语言，而英语是普通百姓所使用的。
A: ♣近  conversational, informal, nonliterary, unliterary, vernacular
A: ♣反  bookish, formal, learned, literary 书面的，正式的

Q:vulnerable  ['vʌlnərəbl]

A: ♣近  assailable, endangered, exposed, subject, susceptible
A: ♣反  guarded, protected, shielded 有保护的；invincible, invulnerable 无敌的
A: ♣派  vulnerability n. 弱点，易受伤害

Q:waddle  ['wɔdəl]

A: ♣近  careen, dodder, reel, teeter, totter

Q:waffle  ['wɔfəl]

A: ♣反  articulate 清楚地说

Q:waft  [wɑ:ft]

A: ♣例  Heavenly aromas wafted from the kitchen. 令人欣悦的香气从厨房飘出。‖A feather wafted past us and settled on the grass. 一片羽毛飘过我们身边，落在草地上。
A: ♣近  buoy, drift, glide, hang, hover, raft
A: ♣反  flounder, sink 沉没；submerge 下沉

Q:wag  [wæɡ]

A: ♣近  comedian, comic, droll, humorist, joker, wit
A: ♠考法2  vt. 摆动： to move to and fro or up and down especially with quick jerky motions
A: ♣例  The dog wagged its tail. 狗摆动着它的尾巴。
A: ♣近  swish, switch, waggle

Q:wan  [wɔn]

A: ♣近  ashen, ashy, blanched, livid, lurid, sickly, pale, pallid
A: ♣反  blooming, florid, flush, full-blooded, glowing, red, rosy, rubicund, ruddy, sanguine 红润的，健康的

Q:wanderlust  ['wɔndəlʌst]

A: ♣例  His wanderlust would not allow him to stay long in one spot. 他对旅行的渴望让他不可能在一处久待。

Q:wane  [wein]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 减少，衰退，降低： to decrease in size, extent, or degree
A: ♣例  In the evening the storm finally waned. 傍晚时分风暴终于减弱了。‖The moon waxes and then wanes. 月有阴晴圆缺。
A: ♣近  abate, decline, diminish, dwindle, ease, ebb, fall, lessen, lower, moderate, recede, shrink, subside, taper
A: ♣反  accumulate, balloon, burgeon, enlarge, escalate, expand, grow, increase, intensify, mushroom, rise, snowball, soar, wax 增加，扩大，上升
A: ♣派  waning adj. 衰退的，减少的

Q:want  [wɔnt]
A: ♠考法1  n. 短缺： the condition or quality of lacking something usual or necessary
A: ♣例  There's a notable want of teachers in rural areas. 农村地区存在着值得注意的师资短缺问题
A: ♣近  absence, dearth, deficiency, drought, famine, inadequacy, insufficiency, lack, paucity, scarcity, shortage
A: ♣反  abundance, adequacy, amplitude, opulence, plenitude, plenty, sufficiency, wealth 丰富，大量
A: ♠考法2  vt. 渴望： to have a strong desire for
A: ♣例  I want a new car so badly! 我太想要一辆新车了！‖She wanted more time to finish the test. 她希望能有更多的时间来完成考试。
A: ♣近  ache, covet, crave, hunger, itch, long, lust, pine, repine, thirst, wish, yearn
A: ♣反  abhor, abominate, despise, detest, execrate, hate, loathe 厌恶，反感

Q:wanting  ['wɔntiŋ]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 未出现的，缺少的： not present or in evidence
A: ♣例  Grass is almost entirely wanting in that arid wasteland. 那片荒漠几乎没有长一丝青草。
A: ♣近  absent, lacking, missing, nonexistent
A: ♣反  existent, present 存在的，出现的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 未达到要求的： not being up to standards or expectations
A: ♣例  He examined her work and found it wanting. 他检查了她的作业，发现不合要求。‖We tried her cooking and found it to be very wanting. 我们试了试她的厨艺，结果发现很不尽人意。
A: ♣近  deficient, dissatisfactory, ill, inferior, lousy, paltry, poor, unacceptable, unsatisfactory, wretched
A: ♣反  acceptable, adequate, passable, tolerable 可接受的；satisfactory 令人满意的

Q:warmonger  ['wɔ:,mʌŋɡə]

Q:warp  [wɔ:p]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 使偏向： to turn from a correct or proper course
A: ♣近  avert, deflect, divert, veer
A: ♣反  straighten 使变直，使回归正轨
A: ♠考法2  vt. 扭曲，变形： to twist (something) out of a natural or normal shape or condition
A: ♣例  The heat caused the wood to warp. 高温使得木头变形了。
A: ♣近  deform, misshape, screw, torture
A: ♠考法3  vt. 曲解： to change so much as to create a wrong impression or alter the meaning of
A: ♣例  The faulty English translation really warps the meaning of the original Chinese text. 错误的英语翻译曲解了中文的原意。
A: ♣近  distort, falsify, misinterpret, misrepresent, twist
A: ♣反  clarify, clear, explain, illuminate, illustrate 澄清
A: ♣派  warped adj. 弯曲的，变形的

Q:warrant  ['wɔrənt]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 承诺： to assume responsibility for the satisfactory quality or performance of
A: ♣例  The computer company unconditionally warrants all of its products for one full year. 这个电脑公司对所有的产品提供为期一年的质量保证。
A: ♣近  assure, avouch, guarantee, vouch
A: ♠考法2  vt. 批准，认可： to give official acceptance of as satisfactory
A: ♣例  The law warrants these measures. 法律允许这些措施。
A: ♣近  approbate, authorize, clear, confirm, finalize, formalize, ratify, sanction
A: ♣反  decline, deny, disallow, disapprove, negative, reject, veto 禁止，否决
A: ♣派  warranted adj. 有正当理由的；warranty n.保证，承诺

Q:wary  ['wεəri]

A: ♣例  kept a wary eye out for signs of the enemy 对敌人出现的征兆保持警惕
A: ♣近  alert, cautious, chary, circumspect, conservative, guarded, heedful, vigilant, watchful
A: ♣反  careless, heedless, incautious, unguarded, unmindful, unwary 不谨慎的
A: ♣派  wariness n. 谨慎，小心

Q:wastrel  ['weistrəl]

Q:wax  [wæks]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 月亮渐满： to increase in phase or intensity, used chiefly of the moon, other satellites, and inferior planets
A: ♣反  wane 月亮渐亏
A: ♠考法2  vt. 用蜡涂、处理或上光： to coat (something) with a slippery substance in order to reduce friction
A: ♣例  wax the floor 给地板打蜡
A: ♣近  grease, oil, slick
A: ♣反  coarsen, rough, roughen 使粗糙
A: ♠考法3  vi. 增大，增强： to increase in size, numbers, strength, prosperity, or intensity
A: ♣例  The commitment of the young volunteers to the cause seems to wax. 青年志愿者们对于这项事业的投入似乎在增多。
A: ♣近  accelerate, accumulate, appreciate, balloon, boom, burgeon, enlarge, escalate, expand, proliferate, rise
A: ♣反  contract, decrease, diminish, dwindle, lessen, recede 减少，减弱
A: ♣派  waxing adj. 增加的

Q:waylay  [,wei'lei]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 埋伏，伏击： to lie in wait for or attack from ambush
A: ♣例  Unsuspecting tourists are often waylaid by gangs. 不警惕的旅客们常常被犯罪团伙偷袭。‖We were waylaid by a group of protestors with rocks. 我们被一群示威者用石头偷袭了。
A: ♣近  ambush, assault, lurk, surprise

Q:wayward  ['weiwəd]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 刚愎自用的，不服管束的： following one's own capricious, wanton, or depraved inclinations
A: ♣例  had always been the most wayward of their three children 总是三个小孩里最不听话的一个‖wayward children with a history of behavioral problems 过去行为上有些问题的调皮小孩
A: ♣近  balky, contrary, contumacious, defiant, intractable, obstreperous, rebellious, recalcitrant, refractory, unruly
A: ♣反  amenable, biddable, compliant, conformable, docile, obedient, ruly, submissive, tractable 顺从的

Q:weather  ['weðə]

A: ♣例  We haveve weathered worse crises, and so we'll survive this one. 更为严重的危机我们都闯过了，这个也不会有问题的。‖They weathered a terrible storm while at sea. 他们在海上平安渡过了一场巨大的风暴。
A: ♣近  survive
A: ♣反  decease, die, expire, perish, succumb, pass away 死亡，消亡

Q:welter  ['weltə]
A: ♠考法1  n. 混乱；动乱： a state of wild disorder
A: ♣例  There was a welter of pushing and shoving. 到处是推搡和拥挤的混乱局面。‖The troop withdrawal would plunge the country into a welter of anarchy and endless civil war. 撤军会使得这个国家陷入无政府的动乱和无尽的内战中。
A: ♣近  disturbance, furor, hurricane, pandemonium, turmoil, turmoil, uproar, whirl
A: ♣反  calm, peace, tranquility 平静，宁静；order 秩序

Q:wheedle  ['hwi:dl]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （用花言巧语）诱惑，哄骗： to persuade or attempt to persuade by flattery or guile
A: ♣例  wheedled him into working for them 哄骗他为他们工作‖She pleaded and wheedled, but I wouldn't be swayed. 她软磨硬泡地求我，但我仍不动摇。
A: ♣近  adulate, blandish, cajole, coax
A: ♣反  coerce, compel, demand, force, oblige, require 迫使，强求

Q:whet  [hwet]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 磨快： to sharpen by rubbing on or with something (as a stone)
A: ♣例  whetted the dagger with the grindstone 用磨石把匕首磨锋利
A: ♣近  edge, grind, hone, stone, strop
A: ♣反  blunt, dull 使变钝

Q:whiff  [hwif]
A: ♠考法1  n. 微风： a quick puff or slight gust especially of air, odor, gas, smoke, or spray
A: ♣例  A whiff of fresh air reinvigorated him. 一股清新的空气让他恢复了活力。
A: ♣近  breath, puff
A: ♣反  blast 强烈的气流
A: ♠考法2  n. 细微的信号，略微痕迹： an almost imperceptible sign of something
A: ♣例  Even a whiff of appreciation for everything I've done for her would have been nice. 她哪怕是对我为她的付出流露出一丁点的感激之情也好啊。‖Humanity is unregenerable and hates the language of conformity, since conformity has a whiff of the inhuman about it. (Anthony Burgess) 人性是不能改造也无发统一的，因为一致性本身带有一点点不人道的意味。（安东尼?伯吉斯）
A: ♣近  flicker, glimmer, suggestion, touch, trace

Q:whimsical  ['hwimzikəl]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 反复无常的： prone to sudden illogical changes of mind, ideas, or actions
A: ♣例  It’s hard to make plans with such a whimsical friend. 和这样一个反复无常的朋友做决定是很困难的。
A: ♣近  capricious, fickle, freakish, mercurial, volatile
A: ♣反  resolute, unwavering 坚决的
A: ♣派  whimsicality n. 反复无常

Q:wholesome  ['həulsəm]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 有益身心健康的： promoting mental, moral, or social health
A: ♣例  trying to eat a more wholesome diet 尽可能有更健康的饮食习惯
A: ♣近  healthy, restorative, salubrious, recuperative, tonic
A: ♣反  insalubrious, noxious, unhealthy, unwholesome 不健康的，有害的
A: ♣派  wholesomeness n. 健康

Q:wicked  ['wikid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 邪恶的： morally very bad
A: ♣例  a wicked urge to steal just for the sake of stealing 纯粹为了偷盗而偷盗的邪恶冲动
A: ♣近  dark, evil, immoral, iniquitous, nefarious, sinful, vicious, villainous
A: ♣反  decent, ethical, good, honest, honorable, moral, righteous, sublime, upright, virtuous 高尚的
A: ♣派  wickedness n. 邪恶

Q:willful  ['wilful]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 固执的，倔强的： obstinately and often perversely self-willed
A: ♣例  Finally the parents sought professional counseling for the willful child. 最终家长不得不为倔强的小孩寻求专业咨询。
A: ♣近  adamant, headstrong, immovable, implacable, inconvincible, inflexible, intransigent, mulish, obdurate, pertinacious, perverse, stubborn, unyielding, wrongheaded
A: ♣反  acquiescent, agreeable, amenable, compliant, flexible, pliable, pliant, relenting, yielding 易受影响的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 故意的： done deliberately
A: ♣例  a willful attempt to cheat her siblings out of their rightful inheritance 一个想将继承权从她的姊妹手里骗过来的故意企图
A: ♣近  conscious, deliberate, intended, intentional, knowing, purposeful, voluntary, willed, witting
A: ♣反  accidental, chance, haphazard, inadvertent, incidental, random 不经意的，偶然的

Q:willy-nilly  ['wili'nili]
A: ♠考法1  adv. 不论是否愿意的（地）： whether desired or not
A: ♣例  After her boss fell sick, she willy-nilly found herself directing the project. 在她老板生病后，她发现自己不论愿不愿意，都得指导这项工程。
A: ♣近  helplessly, inescapably, inevitably, perforce, unavoidably
A: ♠考法2  adj. 无秩序的，随意的： without order or plan
A: ♣例  willy-nilly taxing laws 杂乱无序的税收法
A: ♣近  aimless, arbitrary, desultory, erratic, haphazard, scattered, slapdash, stray
A: ♣反  methodical, orderly, organized, regular, systematic 有序的，有组织的

Q:wilt  [wilt]
A: ♠考法1  vi. （花、植物等）萎蔫： to become limp or flaccid
A: ♣例  The plants wilted after I forgot to water them for three whole days. 在我整整三天忘记浇水之后，植物们全都萎蔫了。
A: ♣近  flag, hang, loll, sag, swag
A: ♠考法2  vi. 精神萎靡，憔悴： to feel or exhibit the effects of fatigue or exhaustion
A: ♣例  She had wilted a bit after walking around the hot and humid city. 在炎热潮湿的城市中行走使得她略显憔悴。‖His brain wilted from hitherto unprecedented weariness. 在前所未有的疲劳面前，他的开始变得神情憔悴。
A: ♣近  decay, droop, emaciate, fade, fail, lag, languish, sink, waste, wither
A: ♣反  convalesce, rally, rebound, recover, recuperate 康复，复原

Q:wily  ['waili]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 狡诈的，狡猾的： clever at attaining one's ends by indirect and often deceptive means
A: ♣例  He is an experienced and wily old statesman. 他是一个经验丰富而狡诈的老销售员。‖His wily plan only rebounded on him. 聪明反被聪明误。
A: ♣近  beguiling, cagey, crafty, cunning, devious, foxy, guileful, scheming, shrewd, slick, sly, subtle, tricky
A: ♣反  artless, guileless, ingenuous, innocent, undesigning 天真的，单纯的

Q:wince  [wins]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 畏缩： to shrink back involuntarily as from pain
A: ♣例  winced at the horrible corpses 在令人恐惧的尸体面前畏缩
A: ♣近  blench, cringe, quail, quiver, recoil, shrink, tremble
A: ♣反  confront, face, meet 直面；challenge 挑战

Q:windbag  ['windbæɡ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 健谈的人： an exhaustively talkative person
A: ♣例  With a windbag like that, who needs a wind farm to meet our energy needs? 有了他这样一个多话的“吹风机”，谁还要风力发电厂来满足电力需求呢？
A: ♣近  babbler, conversationalist, gabbler, gasbag, prattler

Q:windy  ['windi]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 冗长的： characterized by wearisome verbosity
A: ♣例  a windy saleswoman who told us a lot more than we wanted to know about vacuum cleaners 一个啰嗦的女销售员，一个劲地说着我们不想知道的关于吸尘器的细节
A: ♣近  circuitous, circumlocutory, diffuse, garrulous, prolix, rambling, verbose
A: ♣反  compact, concise, crisp, pithy, succinct, terse 简洁的

Q:winsome  ['winsəm]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 迷人的，漂亮的： generally pleasing and engaging often because of a childlike charm and innocence
A: ♣例  fascinated by her winsome smile 为她动人一笑所倾倒
A: ♣近  adorable, charming, disarming, enchanting, endearing, sweet, winning
A: ♣反  abhorrent, abominable, detestable, hateful, loathsome, odious 令人厌恶的
A: ♣派  winsomeness n. 迷人

Q:wiretap  ['waiətæp]
A: ♠考法1  n./vt. 偷听，窃听： to tap a telephone or telegraph wire in order to get information
A: ♣例  This line is not clean asCIAmight have wiretapped it. 这根线路不安全，因为中情局可能已经在监听了。
A: ♣近  eavesdrop, overhear, tap

Q:wistful  ['wistful]
A: ♠考法1  adj. （带着忧伤而）渴望的，怀念的： full of yearning or desire tinged with melancholy
A: ♣例  There was a wistful look in his eyes when he spoke of his childhood. 当他谈起他的童年时，眼眶中不禁流露出一种带有忧伤的怀念之情。
A: ♣近  longing, nostalgic, reminiscent, yearning
A: ♣反  apathetic, indifferent, insouciant, nonchalant, perfunctory, unconcerned 无所谓的，不感兴趣的

Q:wit  [wit]
A: ♠考法1  n. 机智，智慧： the natural ability to perceive and understand
A: ♣例  lacked the wit to judge 缺乏判断的智慧
A: ♣近  astuteness, brilliance, foxiness, intelligence, keenness, perspicacity, sagacity, sharpness, shrewdness
A: ♣反  brainlessness, dullness, fatuity, lunacy, silliness 愚蠢
A: ♠考法2  n. 智者，有智慧的人： a person of exceptional intelligence
A: ♣例  a man who fancied himself as a great wit 一个把自己想象成智慧的化身的男子
A: ♣近  illuminati, pundit, sage, savant, scholar
A: ♣反  dolt, fool, idiot, simpleton 傻子
A: ♣派  witty adj. 有智慧的

Q:withdraw  [wið'drɔ:]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 撤退： to take back or away
A: ♣例  The army was forced to withdraw from the frontline. 部队被迫从前线撤回
A: ♣近  recede, retreat, fall back
A: ♣反  advance 前进；place, position, put 放置，安置
A: ♣派  withdrawal n. 撤退；withdrawn adj. 性格内向的，离群的

Q:wither  ['wiðə]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 枯萎，凋谢： to become dry and sapless
A: ♣例  Amaranth is a legendary flower that never withers. 传说中的Amaranth是一种永不凋谢的花。
A: ♣近  dry, fade, shrivel, wane, wilt, wizen
A: ♣反  revive 复活；bloom, flourish, prosper, thrive 繁茂
A: ♣派  withering adj. 凋谢的，凋亡的

Q:withhold  ['wið'həuld]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 扣压，不给予： to refrain from granting, giving, or allowing
A: ♣例  withhold sensitive information 限制敏感信息的传播
A: ♣近  decline, disallow, disapprove, detain, refuse, reject, reprobate, restrain, retain
A: ♣反  allow, concede, grant, permit 授予

Q:wizen  ['wizən]
A: ♠考法1  vt. （使）凋谢，（使）枯萎： to become dry, shrunken, and wrinkled often as a result of aging or of failing vitality
A: ♣近  dry, mummify, shrivel, wither
A: ♣反  revive 复活；bloom, flourish, prosper, thrive 繁茂
A: ♠考法2  adj. 凋谢的, 枯萎的： shriveled or dried up
A: ♣近  faded, withered
A: ♣反  blooming 盛开的

Q:wobble  ['wɔbl]
A: ♠考法1  vi. 摇晃，颤抖： to move or proceed with an irregular rocking or staggering motion or unsteadily and clumsily from side to side
A: ♣例  The drunk stood up, wobbled for a moment, and fell forward. 醉汉站了起来，晃动了一阵，然后向前倒了下去。
A: ♣近  rock, totter
A: ♣反  stabilize 使稳定
A: ♠考法2  vi. 犹豫不决： to show uncertainty about the right course of action
A: ♣例  We cannot tolerate the government wobbling at this critical time. 我们不能容忍政府在这种关键时刻犹豫不决。
A: ♣近  falter, stagger, teeter, vacillate, waver

Q:worldly  ['wə:ldli]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 世间的，世俗的： of this world rather than spiritual or religion affairs
A: ♣例  preoccupied with worldly concerns 纠缠于世俗的忧虑‖It is time you woke up and focused your thoughts on more worldly matters. 现在你应该停止做梦然后把自己的精力集中在更现实的问题上了。
A: ♣近  carnal, corporeal, material, mundane
A: ♣反  mental, spiritual 精神的；heavenly 天国的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 老练的： experienced in human affairs
A: ♣例  My little sister was worldly and sophisticated, quite unlike me. 与我截然不同的是，我的妹妹在为人处世方面非常老练。
A: ♣近  cosmopolitan, sophisticated
A: ♣反  ingenuous, innocent, na?ve, unsophisticated 天真的

Q:worship  ['wə:ʃip]
A: ♠考法1  n. 崇拜，敬仰： extravagant respect to an object of esteem
A: ♣例  the belief in swords and the worship of force 刀剑信仰与武力崇拜
A: ♣近  adulation, adoration, deification, idolatry, reverence, veneration
A: ♣反  dislike, dismissal, disregard, hatred, loathing, scorn 反感，厌恶
A: ♠考法2  v. 崇拜，膜拜： to offer honor or respect to (someone) as a divine power
A: ♣例  The ancient Greeks worshipped many different gods. 古希腊人崇拜不同的神明。
A: ♣近  adore, deify, glorify, revere, venerate
A: ♣反  blaspheme, desecrate, profane, violate 亵渎

Q:wrangle  ['ræŋɡl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 纷争，争端： an often noisy or angry expression of differing opinions
A: ♣例  There was a bit of a wrangle over how much money to give the high school for its sports programs. 这个高中应该获得多少体育项目的拨款引起了一阵纷争。
A: ♣近  altercation, controversy, disagreement, dispute, fight, imbroglio, quarrel, squabble
A: ♣反  harmony 和谐
A: ♠考法2  vi. 争吵： to quarrel noisily or angrily
A: ♣例  Local residents wrangled for hours about property taxes. 当地居民就房产税的问题争吵不休。
A: ♣近  altercate, argue, bicker, controvert, hassle, quibble, spat, tiff
A: ♣派  wrangler n. 争吵的人

Q:wrest  [rest]
A: ♠考法1  vt. 拧，扭动： to pull, force, or move by violent wringing or twisting movements
A: ♣例  wrest the lid off this pickle jar 把泡菜罐的盖子拧下来
A: ♣近  twist, wrench, wring
A: ♠考法2  vt. 辛苦地获得： to gain with difficulty by or as if by force, violence, or determined labor
A: ♣例  farmers who were used to wresting a living from the barren land 一度依靠贫瘠的土地恶劣度日的农民
A: ♣近  scrape, scrounge, squeeze

Q:wretched  ['retʃid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 极差的： very poor in quality or ability
A: ♣例  the wretched conditions of the refugee camp 难民营极恶劣的条件
A: ♣近  bad, coarse, inferior, low-grade, mediocre, miserable, poor, rubbishy, terrible, trashy
A: ♣反  excellent, fine, first-class, first-rate, good, high-grade, superior 优质的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 沮丧的： deeply afflicted, dejected, or distressed in body or mind
A: ♣例  She was wretched for weeks after breaking up with her boyfriend. 她与男友分手后郁闷了几个星期。
A: ♣近  blue, crestfallen, dejected, doleful, dolorous, gloomy, melancholy, mournful, rueful, sorrowful, woeful
A: ♣反  blissful, buoyant, cheerful, delighted, glad, happy, joyful, jubilant 欢乐的
A: ♣派  wretchedness n. 沮丧

Q:wrongheaded  ['rɔŋ'hedid]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 固执己见的，坚持（错误观点）的： stubborn in adherence to wrong opinion or principles
A: ♣例  In spite of other’s objections, he is always wrongheaded in his opinions. 他总是不管他人的反对而坚持自己哪怕是错误的观点。
A: ♣近  adamant, headstrong, immovable, implacable, inconvincible, inflexible, intransigent, mulish, obdurate, pertinacious, perverse, stubborn, unyielding, willful
A: ♣反  acquiescent, agreeable, amenable, compliant, flexible, pliable, pliant

Q:wry  [rai]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 扭曲的： abnormally twisted or bent to one side
A: ♣例  a wry smile 扭曲的笑容
A: ♣近  bending, crooked, curving, devious
A: ♣反  common, normal, usual 正常的
A: ♠考法2  adj. 坚持错误的： stubborn in adherence to wrong opinion or principles
A: ♣近  headstrong, obstinate, pertinacious, perverse, stubborn, wrongheaded
A: ♣反  amenable, compliant, complying, flexible, pliable, pliant, relenting, yielding 容易改变立场的

Q:xenophobe  ['zenəfəub]
A: ♠考法1  n. 仇视（或畏惧）外国人（或外国事物）者： one unduly fearful of what is foreign and especially of people of foreign origin
A: ♣例  But from what I know, no way could this thoroughly US-educated woman (from the age of 12) be a xenophobe. 但根据我的了解，这个从12岁起就接受彻底的美国教育的女人不可能是抵触外国事物的人。
A: ♣反  xenomania 媚外的人
A: ♣派  xenophobia n. 仇外情绪

Q:yoke  [jəuk]
A: ♠考法1  v. 连接： to become joined or linked
A: ♣例  yoked several ideas together to propose a novel theory 将几个想法结合起来提出一个全新的理论
A: ♣近  chain, conjugate, hook, interconnect, join, link, unite
A: ♣反  disconnect, disjoin, dissever, disunite, separate, sunder, unchain, unlink, unyoke 分开

Q:yokel  ['jəukəl]
A: ♠考法1  n. 乡下人，天真纯朴的人： a naive or gullible inhabitant of a rural areaor small town
A: ♣例  a lame comedy about the misadventures of yokels in the big city 描述乡下人在大都市中遭遇的不幸的劣质喜剧
A: ♣近  bucolic, bumpkin, churl, provincial, rustic
A: ♣反  cosmopolitan 云游四海的人

Q:zeal  [zi:l]
A: ♠考法1  n. 热心，热诚： enthusiastic devotion to a cause, ideal, or goal and tireless diligence in its furtherance
A: ♣例  preaches with fanatical zeal 带着狂热进行传教
A: ♣近  ardor, devotion, enthusiasm, fervidness, fervor, passion
A: ♣反  apathy, indifference, nonchalance, torpor, unconcern 麻木，冷漠
A: ♣派  zealous adj. 狂热的

Q:zealot  ['zelət]
A: ♠考法1  n. 狂热者： a zealous person; especially: a fanatical partisan
A: ♣例  a religious zealot calling for another Crusade 呼唤下一场十字军东征的宗教狂热者
A: ♣近  activist, crusader, fanatic, partisan, red hot
A: ♣派  zealotry n. 狂热的行为

Q:zenith  ['zeniθ]
A: ♠考法1  n. 最高点，巅峰： culminating point
A: ♣例  at the zenith of his power 位极人臣
A: ♣近  acme, apex, apogee, climax, crescendo, crest, peak, pinnacle, summit, top
A: ♣反  bottom, nadir 最低点

Q:zesty  ['zesti]
A: ♠考法1  adj. 刺激的，开胃的： appealingly piquant or lively
A: ♣例  a zesty sauce 味道刺激的酱汁
A: ♣近  peppery, piquant, pungent, salty, savory, spicy, zingy
A: ♣反  bland, insipid, vapid, zestless 乏味的
